Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]C.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Transplant ureteral stricture. Failed stricture protocol, balloon ureteroplasty and cutting balloon ureteroplasty. Joint decision to pursue stenting over surgical repair.  Procedure:  1. Right antegrade nephrostogram and conversion to ureteral stent. 2. Placement of right percutaneous nephrostomy.   Findings:  1. Right antegrade nephrostogram demonstrates persistent long-segment ureteral stricture extending from the renal pelvis to the ureterovesicular anastomosis. Existing PCNU is clogged. 2. Newly placed JJ ureteral stent is appropriately positioned with the proximal loop in the renal pelvis and distal loop in the urinary bladder. 3. Successful placement of 8Fr Right PCN with cope loop in the renal pelvis.   Impression:  1. Successful conversion of right lower quadrant transplant PCNU to [HOSPITAL]le-J ureteral stent. 2. Successful placement of right lower quadrant transplant safety PCN.  Plan:   1. Cap PCN and monitor clinical course. 2. Return to IR in 1-2 weeks once tolerating capping for repeat labs and PCN removal. 3. Patient given extensive uncapping guidelines, including but not limited to development of fevers, chills, difficulty urinating, dysuria, abdominal pain.   Technique:  With the patient in prone position, the bilateral flanks were prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. A scout radiograph was obtained.   A sample was obtained for cytology evaluation.Contrast was then injected through the existing nephroureterostomy tube and imaging of the collecting was system performed. This demonstrated persistent stricture with clogging of the tube in its mid to distal portions. Additionally, a bifid collecting system was noted with normal appearance of the upper and mid pole calyces, and an isolated lower pole pelvis draining separately into the proximal ureter.   A 0.035" Glidewire advantage was placed through the tube into the bladder and the tube removed over the wire and discarded. An 8 French sheath was then advanced over the wire into the bladder. An additional Amplatz wire was advanced into the bladder as a safety wire.  The new 8 French by 12 cm [VENDOR] nephroureteral stent was then advanced over the wire under fluoroscopic guidance, and successfully deployed with the distal loop in the bladder, and the proximal loop in the renal pelvis.  Then over the Amplatz safety wire, a new 8 French nephrostomy tube was advanced with cope loop formed in the renal pelvis. It took quite a bit of maneuvering to appropriately position the newly placed PCN and JJ stent, however at the end of the procedure both were adequately positioned with contrast flowing through the stent into the bladder.  The new PCN was sutured to the soft tissues and placed to gravity drainage for initial decompression. A sterile dressing was applied.    The patient tolerated the proc[PATIENT] well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP, Lateral and Oblique views.   Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a 5 French Vascade closure device  followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: Non-invasive imaging.  FINDINGS: RIGHT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. There is evidence of mild intracranial atherosclerotic disease within the cavernous and supraclinoid internal carotid artery. The visualized ECA branches opacify normally.   RIGHT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CERVICAL: There is evidence of smooth atherosclerotic plaque however not resulting in stenosis at the proximal cervical internal carotid artery. There is mild stenosis of the proximal external carotid artery. The visualized ECA branches opacify normally.   RIGHT SUBCLAVIAN ARTERY,CERVICAL: The origin of the right vertebral artery is occluded. The right vertebral artery is reconstituted by muscular branches from the thyrocervical trunk beginning at the mid cervical segment. The remaining subclavian branches opacify normally. The right vertebral artery appears to end in PICA.   LEFT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is mild atherosclerotic disease within the left cavernous and supraclinoid internal carotid arteries No aneurysm or early draining vein was identified.. The visualized ECA branches opacify normally.   LEFT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CERVICAL: There is very mild stenosis at the proximal left internal carotid artery. The carotid bulb is smooth, without irregularity. There is mild stenosis at the proximal left external carotid artery.  LEFT SUBCLAVIAN ARTERY, CERVICAL: There is a stent visualized at the origin of the left vertebral artery with mild in-stent stenosis at the proximal end. The proximal and lateral end of the stent appears to project into the subclavian artery as a shelf.  LEFT SUBCLAVIAN ARTERY, CEREBRAL: The cervical vertebral artery opacifies normally. Reflux into the contralateral vertebral artery was not seen. There is mild intracranial atherosclerotic disease of the basilar artery. No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein was identified.  COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: 1. Mild in-stent stenosis at the proximal end of the left vertebral artery origin stent, not flow-limiting. 2. Chronic occlusion of the origin of the right vertebral artery, with reconstitution via muscular branches of the thyrocervical trunk. 3. Minimal carotid stenosis of the bilateral internal carotid arteries, with mild stenosis of the origins of the bilateral external carotid arteries.. A modified Allen test (Barbeau test Type B) was performed on the left wrist to confirm patency of the ulnopalmar arch using pulse oximetry.   1% lidocaine solution was administered for local anesthesia. Access was obtained to the left radial artery using a 21 gauge micro needle and ultrasound guidance. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. A wire was placed through the needle. A hydrophilic Glidesheath was advanced slowly over the wire. 3000 units of heparin, 200 mcg of nitroglycerin and 2.5 mg of verapamil was given through the arterial sheath with slow hemodilution. A side flush was started.   A 5-Fr [VENDOR]y/[HCW][VENDOR] catheter was advanced over an 0.035" wire into the abdominal aorta. The catheter was used to catheterize the visceral vessels described below. Angiograms were performed. A microcatheter system was used to catheterize distal visceral and hepatic vessels, as described below. Specific vessels catheterized and embolized are described in detail below. Tumor blush was confirmed on angiography.  Once the catheter was in adequate position, a pre-determined dose of 90-Yttrium radioactive particles was infused into the target hepatic artery. The microcatheter was flushed and the microcatheter was disposed of appropriately.   All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. A TR Band was placed on the left wrist for hemostasis. The access sheath was removed and no hematoma was seen. A radial artery pulse was confirmed distal to the puncture site confirming patent hemostasis.   The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications.   Additional Medications: Zofran 4 mg IV. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]C.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Central venous access needed to start AML treatment.    Procedure:   1.	Tunneled central venous catheter placement  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the tunneled catheter, as described, the tip terminates near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a power-injectable, 5 Fr x 26 cm, tunneled non-cuffed central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein - dobule lumen  Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care.  The catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed below.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a peel-away sheath set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture peel-away sheath set, the wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.  Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  43 y.o. female with recurrent progressive endocervical adenocarcinoma on tisotumab, history of radiation cystitis, and obstructive uropathy with R PCNU and L nephroureteral stent in place admitted for pain control and hematuria. CT A/P [DATE] demonstrates appropriately positioned R PCNU with decompressed collecting system with persistent mild to moderate left hydronephrosis despite indwelling stent. Urology recommending Left PCN insertion for improved decompression of left collecting system as it appears that patient has failed left stent. If possible, recommend retrieval of left stent during this procedure. May consider modified Left PCNU with tubing extending into the ureter but not full PCNU into bladder (stent curl in bladder may worsen patient's urinary symptoms and hematuria in the setting of radiation cystitis).    Procedure:   1.	Left nephrostogram and nephrostomy tube placement      Findings:  Comparison is made to a previous exam dated    .  1.	Severe left hydroureteronephrosis under ultrasound evaluation  2.	Antegrade nephrostogram demonstrates severe hydronephrosis with passage of contrast up to the mid ureter  Catheter(s):  10.2 F Cook nephrostomy tube  Impression:   1.	Uneventful ultrasound and fluroscopic-guided placement of a left nephrostomy tube as described above.      Treatment Plan:   Patient should return for routine check and change in 8-12 weeks.        Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained to the patient. Written informed consent was obtained.  A time out/call to order was performed prior to procedure initiation.  The soft tissues overlying the access site were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Ultrasound was utilized to identify an appropriate access site. Static ultrasound image was obtained and stored to PACS for reference purposes. Subsequently, under fluoroscopic and real-time concurrent ultrasound guidance, access was obtained into a posterior, inferior calyx using a 21 ga needle and a triaxial sheath system (Greb). Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site. A wire was advanced centrally. Serial dilation was accomplished over the wire. The wire and inner dilator were removed. Non-ionic contrast was injected into the collecting system and images of the antegrade pyelogram were obtained and stored to PACS.  An 0.035” wire was advanced through the existing access. A nephrostomy tube was advanced over the wire and the Cope loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis. Contrast injection confirmed location. The catheter was sutured to the flank with monofilament suture and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.  The procedure was well tolerated, and patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. No evidence of thrombosis, perforation, or other complication.  Impression:   1.  Uneventful image guided placement of an infrarenal IVC filter.  Treatment Plan:  1. Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained.  The specific risks of bleeding, infection, pulmonary embolism, filter maldeployment, and filter migration were detailed and accepted. Written informed consent was obtained. The patient was assessed for conscious sedation and found to be an adequate candidate. A dedicated nurse monitored heart rate, blood pressure, and oxygen saturation throughout the procedure. All instruments and devices were removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression. No immediate complication occurred, and the patient was discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM AND COIL EMBOLIZATION OF ANTERIOR COMMUNICATING ARTERY ANEURYSM    CLINICAL INDICATION: 54 years-year-old Male with PMH of remote TBI, tobacco use, and daily alcohol use who was brought to medical attention after he was found unresponsive. CT head revealed diffuse subarachnoid hemorrhage and CTA demonstrated an anterior communicating artery aneurysm. Diagnostic cerebral angiogram and treatment of ruptured aneurysm is indicated.  PROCEDURE: Cerebral angiogram, coil embolization of an anterior communicating artery aneurysm.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: 2 hours.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician.  He supervised the entire procedure. [HCW] and [HCW]. were the fellows. Each actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS CATHETERIZED: Right external carotid artery Right internal carotid artery Right vertebral artery Left internal carotid artery Left external carotid artery Right anterior cerebral artery Anterior communicating artery  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right common femoral artery Right external carotid artery Right internal carotid artery Right vertebral artery Left internal carotid artery Left external carotid artery   VESSELS TREATED (in sequence): Anterior communicating artery  ANESTHESIA:   General Anesthesia administered by anesthesiology staff.  Pre- Intra- and post- anesthesia records are available in the patient chart.   MEDICATIONS GIVEN:  Heparin 7000 units IV Aspirin 300 mg PR Protamine 25 mg IV Ancef 2 gram IV  MATERIALS USED:  5 French micropuncture kit Cope mandrel wire 5 French transitional dilator 6 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 6 French 65cm Arrow sheath 0.038" Bentson guidewire 0.035" Terumo glidewire  5 French Cordis Vertebral catheter 6 French Sofia guide catheter Headway 17 Advanced microcatheter Transcend-EX microguidewire Asahi 014 microguidewire 7 mm x 4 mm Hyperform balloon microcatheter 4 mm x 15 mm Scepter XC balloon microcatheter Omnipaque 300 contrast material (150 cc) Perclose ProGlide closure device  COILS: Framing coil: Optimax complex 7 mm x 20 cm Filling coils:  Optimax complex 6 mm x 11 cm Optimax complex 4.5 mm x 10 cm Optima complex-10 3 mm x 8 cm Optima complex-10 3 mm x 6 cm Optima complex-10 3 mm x 6 cm Optima complex-10 3 mm x 4 cm  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, hemorrhage, renal failure, limb loss, death, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.  After informed, written consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion after intubation by the anesthesiology team. Access to the vascular system was gained by a single-wall puncture of the right common femoral artery. An angiogram of the right common femoral artery was performed through the outer cannula the dilator in order to ensure appropriate location of the arteriotomy and suitability of the artery for use of closure device. A 6 French short sheath was introduced into the right common femoral artery  using Seldinger technique. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously. Using fluoroscopic guidance, the 5 French diagnostic catheter was used to select the bilateral internal carotid arteries and the left vertebral artery.  Digital angiograms were performed of these vessels, centered over the head. Ipsilateral and contralateral oblique projections were obtained of both internal carotid artery injections to evaluate for anterior communicating or MCA bifurcation aneurysms.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: Rotational angiography was also performed from the diagnostic catheter in the mid cervical segment of the right internal carotid artery for better delineation of the intracranial vasculature. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.  Following the diagnostic angiogram, an aspirin rectal suppository (300 mg) and an additional 2000 units of heparin IV were administered in preparation for coiling. A CTs were checked and additional heparin boluses were administered as needed in order to maintain an ACT between 250 and 300. The 6 French short Terumo sheath was exchanged over a Bentson wire for a 6 French 65 cm arrow long sheath. The diagnostic catheter and Bentson guidewire were advanced through the arrow sheath and used to select the right internal carotid artery. The arrow sheath was advanced into the right common carotid artery. The diagnostic catheter and Bentson guidewire were removed. The Sofia guide catheter was advanced over the Terumo Glidewire through the error sheath, and under roadmap guidance was advanced into the right internal carotid artery just proximal to the tonsillar loop. The Terumo Glidewire was withdrawn.  The balloon was then prepared on an adjacent table, and the microguidewire and the balloon were passed coaxially through the guide catheter into the 6 French Sofia catheter. The microcatheter and microwire and Hyperform balloon were advanced past the cervical into the ascending petrous portion of the right internal carotid artery. The Sofia catheter was advanced over these into the petrous segment of the right ICA. We attempted to advance the Hyperform balloon into the ACA, but was difficult to push and there seemed to be friction with the headway catheter. It was therefore removed and replaced with a scepter xc balloon which was advanced into the right ACA and positioned over the neck of the aneurysm without difficulty. Superselective catheterization of the anterior communicating artery aneurysm performed with the microcatheter over a microguidewire.   The aneurysm was framed and filled with the aforementioned coils using roadmap and blank roadmap technique. After the first several coils were placed within the aneurysm we withdrew the microcatheter from the aneurysm and reaccessed the aneurysm in order to more completely fill the aneurysm. The balloon was left in place in case of aneurysm rupture, but was not inflated during the case.   A final cerebral angiogram was done in the AP and lateral projection to evaluate for residual filling, and distal emboli.  Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Ancef was administered.  Hemostasis was achieved by application of a Perclose ProGlide. A Tegaderm was then applied over the puncture site.  COMPARISON: None.  FINDINGS: RIGHT COMMON FEMORAL ARTERY: The arteriotomy is above the bifurcation of the right common femoral artery and the diameter of the vessel is adequate for a Perclose ProGlide.  RIGHT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is a saccular aneurysm of the anterior communicating artery, the dimensions of which are described on 3-D rotational angiogram discussed below. No other aneurysms are identified. There is a tortuous tonsillar loop. No focal stenosis or early draining vein are identified.   RIGHT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. Reflux of contrast into the  left vertebral artery was achieved. The origin of PICA is normal bilaterally.   LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. Again there is seen a tortuous tonsillar loop.  LEFT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-EMBOLIZATION): There is a dense coil pack within the body of the aneurysm with no appreciable ongoing contrast opacification within the aneurysm. There are no perfusion deficits to suggest distal emboli in the distal circulation.  3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE right internal carotid artery:  3-D rotational angiography demonstrated a lobulated, narrow neck anterior communicating artery aneurysm which measures 7.8 x 7.6 x 6.7 x 2.9 mm (axial by axial by neck-to-dome by neck). This is the source of the patient's subarachnoid hemorrhage.    COMPLICATIONS: None.  IMPRESSION: 1. There is a lobulated, narrow neck anterior communicating artery aneurysm which measures 7.8 x 7.6 x 6.7 x 2.9 mm (axial by axial by neck-to-dome by neck). This is the source of the patient's subarachnoid hemorrhage. 2. Successful coil embolization of the above aneurysm with dense coil pack and no evidence of ongoing aneurysmal filling. 3. No other aneurysms were identified 4. Bilateral tonsillar loops of the internal carotid arteries.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Lytic spinal lesions at T11 and L4, with acute compression fractures  Additional Clinical Indication: Acute (6 weeks or less) T11 and L4    . Spine MRI/bone-scan is within 30 days of this procedure and was performed on [DATE]. Patient has severe back pain despite optimal non-surgical management with severe impact of vertebral body compression fracture(s) on daily functioning. Patient has kyphotic deformity due to vertebral body compression fracture(s).    Procedure:   1.	Image-guided kyphoplasty  2.	Image-guided bone biopsy  3.	Image-guided radiofrequency ablation of bone mass  Findings:   1.	Pre-intervention: Redemonstrated L4 compression deformity. 2.	Post-intervention:  Successful deposition of cement within the treated vertebral body/bodies with no evidence of extravasation.    Impression:   1.	Successful image guided augmentation of vertebral levels: T11 and L4, with biopsy of T11 and radiofrequency ablation performed at both levels.  Treatment Plan:   Physical therapy as tolerated.  Technique:   The patient was brought to the interventional radiology suite and placed on the table in prone position. The wide area of the back around the affected area(s) was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion.   All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). A scout image was obtained in AP and lateral projections.   Skin was anesthetized with a 2% lidocaine solution.   Level by level technique:   -Vertebral level:  T11     -Pedicle access:  Bipedicular -Access trocar gauge:  11-gauge -Balloon utilized:  15 mm  Prior to injection of cement, balloons were inserted and inflated under biplane fluoroscopy.  Static fluoroscopic images were stored to PACS documenting balloon utilization and position. -Biopsy obtained:  Yes -Indication for biopsy: Lytic lesion within the vertebral body -Ablation Performed: Stryker Optablate radiofrequency ablation, within the vertebral body bilaterally and within the right pedicle -Indication for Ablation: Pathologic Compression Fracture with Assosciated Pain  -Vertebral level:  L4     -Pedicle access:  Bipedicular -Access trocar gauge:  11-gauge -Balloon utilized:  20 mm  Prior to injection of cement, balloons were inserted and inflated under biplane fluoroscopy.  Static fluoroscopic images were stored to PACS documenting balloon utilization and position. -Biopsy obtained:  no -Indication for biopsy: NA -Ablation Performed: Stryker Optablate radiofrequency ablation, within the vertebral body and pedicles bilaterally -Indication for Ablation: Pathologic Compression Fracture with Assosciated Pain  Additional Procedural Details:   Utilizing AP, oblique and lateral fluoroscopy, needles were inserted into the affected vertebral body/bodies. Needles were advanced under careful, intermittent biplane fluoroscopy to ensure that the medial wall of the pedicle was not violated prior to transgression of the needle tip into the posterior wall of the vertebral body. The drill was then advanced to the anterior one-third of the vertebral body on each side.     Balloon(s) was/were inserted into the effected vertebral body/bodies and inflated under fluoroscopy. Static fluoroscopic images were stored to PACS documenting balloon position. Cement was mixed and balloons were removed after being deflated.  Cement was then injected under careful, intermittent biplane fluoroscopy to ensure no significant extravasation of PMMA cement beyond the borders of the vertebral body. Cement injection was stopped once there was adequate fill of the vertebral body. Trochars were removed with hemostasis obtained with focal compression. Static fluoroscopic images were obtained after removal of all needles documenting final cement position. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  69-year-old female with UTI sepsis secondary to right staghorn calculus.  Procedure:   1.	Right nephrostogram and nephrostomy tube placement      Findings:    1.	Mild hydronephrosis survey ultrasound.  2.	Staghorn calculus visualized pelvis. Spontaneous contrast flow into the bladder.  Catheter(s):  8.5 F Cook nephrostomy tube  Impression:   1.	Uneventful ultrasound and fluroscopic-guided placement of a right nephrostomy tube as described above.      Treatment Plan:   Patient should return for routine check and change in 12 weeks.        Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained to the patient. Written informed consent was obtained.  A time out/call to order was performed prior to procedure initiation.  The soft tissues overlying the access site were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Ultrasound was utilized to identify an appropriate access site. Static ultrasound image was obtained and stored to PACS for reference purposes. Subsequently, under fluoroscopic and real-time concurrent ultrasound guidance, access was obtained into a posterior, inferior calyx using a 21 ga needle and a triaxial sheath system (Neff). Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site. A wire was advanced centrally. Serial dilation was accomplished over the wire. The wire and inner dilator were removed. Non-ionic contrast was injected into the collecting system and images of the antegrade pyelogram were obtained and stored to PACS.  An 0.035” wire was advanced through the existing access. A nephrostomy tube was advanced over the wire and the Cope loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis. Contrast injection confirmed location. The catheter was sutured to the flank with monofilament suture and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.  The procedure was well tolerated, and patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]  Clinical Indication:  NASH cirrhosis c/b HCC s/p Y90 seg2 lesion now with multifocal HCC in need of LDT  Additional Clinical Information: Hepatocellular carcinoma with intrahepatic tumors  PROCEDURE:   1. US-guided left radial artery access 2. Diagnostic visceral angiography 3. Selective internal radioembolization with Yttrium-90 4. Cone-beam CT performed for intraprocedural localization, as detailed below.  FINDINGS: ANGIOGRAPHY: Vessels catheterized and angiograms performed, as follows:  Celiac artery: Tumoral blush identified. Right hepatic artery: Tumoral blush identified.se 25 Right hepatic artery: Tumoral blush identified. se 22 Right hepatic artery: Tumoral blush identified. se 42   Specific technical notes / catheter selection: None  CBCT: Yes Catheter location: Right hepatic artery Findings: Tumoral blush identified with supply from the target vessel.  Gelfoam embolization with the intention to protect distally performed from right hepatic artery se21  Transcatheter embolization using Yttrium-90 microspheres performed from: Right hepatic artery (series 42, 22, 25   IMPRESSION:   Successful Yttrium-90     selective internal radiotherapy of a segments 5 and 8 hepatocellular carcinomas.  TREATMENT PLAN:  1. Patient will return to clinic in 6-8 weeks with abdominal MRI and labs.  2. Access site precautions and orders placed.  TECHNIQUE:  With the patient in the supine position, the left wrist was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The left wrist was evaluated with ultrasound and left radial artery patency and acceptable size criteria were documented and images were properly stored in PACS. A modified Allen test (Barbeau test B) was performed on the left wrist to confirm patency of the ulnopalmar arch using pulse oximetry.   1% lidocaine solution was administered for local a[HCW]. Access was obtained to the left radial artery using a 21 gauge micro needle and ultrasound guidance. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. A wire was placed through the needle. A hydrophilic Glidesheath was advanced slowly over the wire. 3000 units of heparin, 200 mcg of nitroglycerin and 2.5 mg of verapamil was given through the arterial sheath with slow hemodilution. A side flush was started.   A 5-Fr [VENDOR]y/[HCW][VENDOR] catheter was advanced over an 0.035" wire into the abdominal aorta. The catheter was used to catheterize the visceral vessels described below. Angiograms were performed. A microcatheter system was used to catheterize distal visceral and hepatic vessels, as described below. Specific vessels catheterized and embolized are described in detail below. Tumor blush was confirmed on angiography.  Cone Beam CT (CBCT) was performed intraprocedurally for purposes of treatment planning, targeting and dose calculation. Axial and coronal images were created and 3D reconstruction was performed on a separate dedicated workstation under concurrent supervision.  Once the catheter was in adequate position, a pre-determined dose of 90-Yttrium radioactive particles was infused into the target hepatic artery. The microcatheter was flushed and the microcatheter was disposed of appropriately.   All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. A TR Band was placed on the left wrist for hemostasis. The access sheath was removed and no hematoma was seen. A radial artery pulse was confirmed distal to the puncture site confirming patent hemostasis.   The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications.   Additional Medications: Benadryl 50 mg IV, Decadron 8 mg IV, Zofran 4 mg IV. Radial cocktail: Heparin 3,000U IA, Nitroglycerin 200 mcg IA, Verapamil 2.5 mg IA  Procedural Personnel Attending(s): [HCW] Fellow(s):     Resident(s):     Advanced practice provider(s): None  Complications: No immediate complications. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Acute on chronic kidney injury. Dialysis fistula malfunction. Needs access for HD.  Procedure:   1.	Non-tunneled large bore central venous catheter placement  Findings:   1.	The left internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	Hickman catheter on the right. 3.	After placement of the large bore central venous catheter, as described, the tip terminates in the right atrium.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a 14 French,  20 cm, non-tunneled large bore central venous catheter via the left internal jugular vein.  Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care. The catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).    The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the left internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic. Ultrasound evaluation of the vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS. Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS.  A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, a 0.035 Amplatz wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   The venotomy tract was dilated to allow introduction of the catheter over the wire. The catheter was subsequently introduced over the wire and the wire removed. The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  End-stage renal disease requiring hemodialysis access. Known central venous stenoses.  Procedure:   1.	Bilateral upper extremity to central venography 2.	Inferior vena cavagram 3.	US evaluation of the right internal jugular vein 4.	Conversion of left femoral vein vascath to permcath  Findings:   1.	Occlusion of the bilateral brachiocephalic veins with sluggish flow towards the heart via collaterals. 2.	Patent IVC with large filling defects in the infrarenal IVC and bilateral common iliac veins corresponding to non-occlusive thrombosis demonstrated on recent cross-sectional imaging.  3.	Distal right IJ thrombus as also seen on recent cross-sectional imaging. 4.  Successful conversion of preexisting left groin vascath to 55cm permcath, terminating near the inferior cavoatrial junction.  Catheter is ready to use.  Impression:   1. Right internal jugular and iliocaval acute thromboses. 2. Bilateral brachiocephalic venous occlusion, with extensive collaterals. 3. Successful placement of left common femoral venous tunneled hemodialysis catheter.  Treatment Plan:   1. Routine catheter care. 2. The catheter is ready for immediate use. 3. Therapeutic anticoagulation recommended.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  Bilateral upper extremity central venography was performed by contrast injection into previously placed peripheral intravenous catheters under fluoroscopy with findings as detailed above. The right internal jugular vein was evaluated with ultrasound and permanent images stored to PACS.  The skin and subcutaneous tissues surrounding the indwelling left common femoral venous nontunneled catheter were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic. Contrast was injected into this catheter and images were stored. After local anesthetic was injected, a new 55 cm PermCath was tunneled through the skin of the thigh towards the venotomy site. A 0.035 inch stiff Amplatz wire was advanced through the indwelling catheter, and the indwelling catheter was removed over the wire. A peel-away sheath was advanced over the wire. The new catheter was advanced through the peel-away sheath into the inferior vena cava.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.  The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location: Procedure:   Indication:  UVJ obstruction with failed cystoscopic double-J ureteral stent placement  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Right obstructive uropathy with failed cystoscopic double-J ureteral stent placement by urology. They could not find the ureteral orifice.  Procedures: 1. US guided calyceal access   2. Right antegrade pyelography  3. Right percutaneous nephroureteral catheter placement  Findings: Outside CT of the abdomen and pelvis from [DATE] was reviewed  1. There is mild to moderate right hydroureteronephrosis with high-grade obstruction at the UVJ. 2. Hydronephrosis and needle entry images into the right posterior interpolar calyx were stored to PACS. Urine returned was clear. 3. The 8.5 French by 28 cm nephroureteral catheter has its proximal cope loop in the renal pelvis and its distal cope loop in the urinary bladder.    [HCW]n:   Uneventful image guided placement of an 8.5 French by 28 cm nephroureteral catheter as described.  Treatment plan:  Routine exchange in 8 weeks  Catheter should be flushed every 6 hours until urine clears. Then daily flushes will be adequate.   Technique:  Right nephroureteral catheter placement:  1% lidocaine was used as local anesthetic. Under direct ultrasound guidance a 10 cm 22 Chiba needle was introduced into the posterior interpolar calyx.  Entry was documented and images were stored to PACS. An 0.018" wire was passed through the needle into the renal pelvis. The needle was removed and a 6 French coaxial dilator was placed over the wire.  Urine was aspirated and discarded. Antegrade pyelography was performed.    A 4 French angled glide catheter and Glidewire were placed coaxially through the transitional dilator and access to the bladder achieved. Contrast injection confirmed location. An Amplatz wire was placed and coiled in the bladder.   The dilator was removed and an 8.5 French by 28 cm  nephroureteral catheter was advanced over the wire. The distal cope loop was formed in the urinary bladder and the proximal Cope loop  was formed within the renal pelvis.  The catheter was anchored to the skin utilizing 2-0 Ethilon and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.  The procedure was well-tolerated, and the patient was discharged still asleep into the care of anesthesiology for transfer to the PACU. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Previously ruptured RCC in the right kidney. Ongoing hematuria with anemia.  PROCEDURE:   1. US-guided left radial artery access 2. Visceral angiography 3. Arterial embolization 4. Post-embolization angiography  FINDINGS: ANGIOGRAPHY: Vessels catheterized using base catheter and microcatheter/microwire combination and angiograms performed:  Right renal artery: No active hemorrhage. Anterior division right renal artery: No active hemorrhage. No pseudoaneurysm or AV fistula. Retropelvic right renal artery: No active hemorrhage. No pseudoaneurysm or AV fistula. Right inferior pole segmental artery: Tumoral blush identified. No active extravasation. Post-embolization right renal inferior pole segmental artery angiography: Nonopacification of tumor blush.  Transcatheter embolization: Vessel 1: Right renal inferior pole segmental renal artery Embolic: Ethanol/lipiodol Details (type/size/volume/number):  1:1 ratio ethanol:lipiodol Total 0.7 cc delivered  IMPRESSION:   1.	Technically successful ethanol embolization of tumor blush supplied by the right renal inferior pole artery. 2.	No angiographic findings of active arterial bleeding, arteriovenous fistula, or pseudoaneurysm in the right kidney.  TREATMENT PLAN:  1. Continued clinical and laboratory monitoring recommended. Please contact interventional radiology if there is a change in clinical status. 2. Extended TR band protocol. To be removed in 2 hours. Left-hand neurovascular checks Q1 hours for 4 hours.  3. Plan to discuss a followup ablation of known renal mass in IR clinic.  TECHNIQUE:  With the patient in the supine position, the left wrist was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The left wrist was evaluated with ultrasound and appropriate left radial artery access criteria were documented. A modified Allen test (Barbeau test) was performed on the left wrist to confirm patency of the ulnopalmar arch using pulse oximetry (Barbeau B).  1% lidocaine solution was administered for local anesthesia. Access was obtained to the left radial artery using a 21 gauge needle and ultrasound guidance,. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. A wire was placed through the needle. A hydrophilic Glidesheath was advanced slowly over the wire. 3000 units of heparin, 200 mcg of nitroglycerin and 2.5 mg of verapamil was given through the arterial sheath with slow hemodilution. A side flush was started.   A 5-Fr RAVI MG1 catheter was advanced over an 0.035" Bentson wire into the aorta. The catheter was used to catheterize the right renal artery as detailed above. Multiple angiograms were performed both from the main renal artery, and subselective interlobar renal arteries. No active extravasation, pseudoaneurysm or AV fistula identified. The right inferior pole segmental artery was then subselectively catheterized using a 2.4 Progreat microcatheter/[VENDOR]ster microwire combination.   Angiogram was performed from the microcatheter which demonstrated tumor blush. The above embolization was then performed. A postembolization angiogram demonstrated no further flow to the tumor. This same microcatheter/microwire combination was then used to subselectively catheterize any remaining interlobar arteries, without any abnormality identified.  An upward going capsular branch arising from the main renal artery was then catheterized, and angiogram again demonstrated no active extravasation or abnormality.   All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. A band was placed on the left wrist for hemostasis. The access sheath was removed, and a developing hematoma was noted proximally to the TR band (up on the forearm). An additional large TR band was attempted to be applied over the hematoma, however unsuccessful. Coban wrap was then used to wrap the forearm. Radial pulse was still palpable, with preserved waveform and oxygen readings.  The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition. DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM, POSSIBLE PREOPERATIVE TUMOR EMBOLIZATION  CLINICAL INDICATION: This is a 31 years Male who developed left eye blurry vision no evidence found to have a large sphenoid wing mass. He is now planned to undergo surgical resection and presents for diagnostic cerebral angiography and possible tumor position.   PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram, possible preoperative tumor embolization  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 60 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] and [HCW] were the fellow. [HCW] was the resident.  Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right internal carotid artery Right external carotid artery Left internal carotid artery Left external carotid artery Left vertebral artery Left ascending pharyngeal artery  ANESTHESIA: General endotracheal anesthesia was administered under the supervision of the attending anesthesiologist. Pre-, intra-, and post-anesthesia monitoring records are available in the chart.  MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine SQ 10 cc  Heparin 3000 units IV Protamine 20 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.038" Bentson guidewire 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 5 French Cordis Vertebral catheter  Headway 17 advanced straight microcatheter Transend-EX microguidewire Omnipaque-300 contrast material (80 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 5 French sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP, Lateral and Oblique views.   After reviewing the angiograms, we identified that the tumor supply was predominantly via the bilateral internal carotid arteries without safe target that would result in a high field embolization. We selectively catheterize the left ascending pharyngeal artery using a headway 17 microcatheter over the transcend microguidewire. We performed an angiogram of the left ascending pharyngeal artery. The left ascending pharyngeal artery supplied a very minor portion of the tumor and it was felt that embolization of this branch would not result in a significant decrease in tumor blush overall. At this point the procedure was concluded.  Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a 5 French Vascade closure device  followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: Noninvasive imaging.  FINDINGS: RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. There is a tumor blush present, supplied primarily by the meningohypophyseal trunk of the right internal carotid artery.  RIGHT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula. No tumor blush is present.  LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. There is a large hypervascular tumor blush present, centered at the left sphenoid wing, supplied predominantly by the inferolateral trunk of the left internal carotid artery.  LEFT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula. There is a small amount of tumor blush supplied by the ascending pharyngeal artery.  LEFT ASCENDING PHARYNGEAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is a small amount of tumor blush supplied by a distal superior pharyngeal branch of the left ascending pharyngeal artery.  LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. Reflux of contrast into the contralateral vertebral artery was achieved. The origin of PICA is normal bilaterally. No tumor blush is present.  COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: 1. There is a large hypervascular tumor centered at the left sphenoid wing supplied predominantly by the inferolateral trunk of the left internal carotid artery, with additional supply from the meningohypophyseal trunk of the right internal carotid artery and the left ascending pharyngeal artery. No targets for safe and high yield embolization were identified.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]  Clinical Indication:  Pancreatic cancer with recurrent ascites  Procedure:   1.	Ultrasound and fluoroscopic-guided tunneled abdominal ascites drain catheter placement       Findings:   1.	Ultrasound demonstrates large volume ascites over the abdomen. 2.	Final static fluoroscopic image documents the catheter coiled over the left abdomen in satisfactory position.        Impression:   1.	Technically successful insertion of 15,5 French  tunneled abdominal ascites drain.       Treatment Plan:   The catheter may be used immediately. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]C.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Status post liver transplant, primary biliary cirrhosis, elevated liver enzymes  Procedure:   Transjugular liver biopsy with pressure measurements  Findings:   1. Pressures:  Free hepatic vein: 3 mm Hg Wedged hepatic vein: 8 mm Hg HVPG: 5 mm Hg (normal)   Right atrium: 5 mm Hg   Impression:   Successful image guided transjugular liver biopsy. Technique:   The procedure, options, and risks were reviewed with patient, including bleeding, infection, and pneumothorax. A time out was performed before initiating the procedure.  The skin overlying the access site was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). Patient sedation was performed, as detailed below.  The right neck was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. No immediate complication occurred, and the patient was discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM AND ENDOVASCULAR PIPELINE EMBOLIZATION OF A RIGHT VERTEBRAL ARTERY ANEURYSM  CLINICAL INDICATION: 61-year-old gentleman with a history of tobacco use and an incidentally discovered right vertebral artery aneurysm which was first noted on evaluation for a transient episode of global amnesia. Given the size and location of the aneurysm, as well as the patient's age and health status, treatment is indicated.  PROCEDURE:  1.	Cerebral angiogram  2.	Endovascular pipeline embolization  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 1.5 hours.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] and [HCW] were the fellows. Each actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS CATHETERIZED: Right vertebral artery  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right radial artery (roadmap) Right subclavian artery Right vertebral artery  VESSELS TREATED (in sequence): Right vertebral artery  ANESTHESIA: General endotracheal anesthesia. Pre-, intra-, and post-anesthesia monitoring records are available in the chart.  MEDICATIONS:  Nitropaste Heparin 5000 units (1000 units IA - right radial artery, 4000 units IV) Nitroglycerin 200 mcg IA (right radial artery) Verapamil 2.5 mg IA (right radial artery)   MATERIALS:  6 French Terumo slender sheath with introducer kit 0.035" Terumo Glidewire (180 cm) 5 French Sofia guide catheter (115 cm) Phenom 27 microcatheter (150 cm) Asahi 018 microguidewire (200 cm) 6 mm x 20 mm pipeline vantage embolization device TR band Omnipaque-300 contrast (100 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, stent thrombosis/stenosis, stent migration, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, non-target embolization, puncture site hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed, written consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite, intubated, and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Ultrasound evaluation of the right radial artery was performed prior to prepping and draping. The radial artery was visualized using ultrasound from the distal wrist to its origin. The radial artery was patent throughout it's course from the wrist with origin from the brachial artery. Prior to prepping a small amount of Nitropaste was applied over the course of the radial artery on the distal wrist. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right radial artery under ultrasound guidance. The introducer wire was visualized within the radial artery using ultrasound. The course of the introducer wire was also visualized using fluoroscopy. Once we were satisfied that the introducer wire was well positioned within the radial and brachial artery, the 6 French Terumo slender sheath was advanced into the right radial artery over the introducer wire. Through the Terumo slender sheath, a roadmap angiogram of the of the right radial artery was obtained to evaluate for radiolucent and to ensure that there are no problems with the access site. A radial "cocktail" of 1000 units of heparin, 200 mcg of nitroglycerin, and 2.5 mg of verapamil were administered slowly through the Terumo slender sheath into the right radial artery. An additional 4000 units of heparin were administered IV. ACT checks were performed and additional heparin boluses were administered as needed in order to achieve a ACT of 250-300.  The 5 French Sofia catheter over a Terumo Glidewire were advanced through the radial sheath, and under fluoroscopic guidance were advanced into the proximal subclavian artery. An angiogram of the right subclavian artery was performed ordered to visualize the origin of the right vertebral artery. Using fluoroscopic guidance the vertebral artery was selected using the Terumo Glidewire, and the Sofia catheter was advanced over the Terumo Glidewire into the distal V2 segment of the right vertebral artery. Digital angiograms were performed in the AP and lateral projections centered over the head and neck.   3D rotational angiography was performed with the Sofia catheter in the distal V2 segment of the right vertebral artery to better delineate the intracranial vasculature. The acquisition was processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.   A working projection was obtained to best demonstrate the neck of the right vertebral artery aneurysm, as well as, the distal and proximal landing zones for the stent. Superselective catheterization of the distal vertebral artery was performed with the [VENDOR]om 27 microcatheter over the Asa[VENDOR] 18 microguidewire. The tip of the microguidewire was situated in the distal V4 segment of the right vertebral. The microguidewire in the phenom catheter was then exchanged for a 6 mm x 20 mm pipeline embolization device. The device was deployed under fluoroscopic guidance and a single shot X-ray was performed to confirm that the distal and proximal ends of the pipeline embolization device were in the right vertebral artery, just proximal to the origin of the anterior spinal artery and the V3 segment, respectively. Postprocessing of the pipeline embolization device was not needed.  A final AP and Lateral angiogram were completed to evaluate the distal vasculature for perfusion deficits and emboli.   After completion of the procedure, the sheath was removed and hemostasis obtained using a TR band.  COMPARISON: Angiograms dated [DATE] and [DATE].  FINDINGS:  RIGHT SUBCLAVIAN ARTERY: The origin of the vertebral artery, mammillary artery, and thyrocervical and costocervical trunks are visualized. The aneurysm of the V4 segment of the right vertebral artery is better visualized on the dedicated vertebral artery runs discussed below. Otherwise, the course and caliber of the the visualized portions of these vessels and their branches are normal in course and caliber.  RIGHT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: Grossly unchanged right vertebral artery aneurysm which arises just distal to the origin of the PICA. The anterior spinal artery originates from the right vertebral artery distal to the aneurysm.    RIGHT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-PIPELINE EMBOLIZATION): There is a small region along the inferior aspect of the midportion of the stent as it crosses over the turn in the vertebral artery that is not quite apposed to the artery. The Pipeline device is otherwise well apposed to the vessel walls throughout it's course. The device does not cover the origin of the anterior spinal artery. Stasis of contrast is noted within the aneurysm. . No perfusion deficits to suggest distal emboli are present.  3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY: A 3D rotational angiogram of the  right vertebral artery was completed and post-processed on an independent work station. 3D angiography revealed grossly stable wide necked aneurysm of the vertebral artery which originates just distal to and separate from the posterior inferior cerebellar artery. This imaging was obtained primarily for acquisition of appropriate treatment views as well as sizing of device.   COMPLICATIONS: none immediate.  IMPRESSION:  1.	Grossly stable widening aneurysm of the right vertebral artery which originates just distal to but separate from the PICA. 2.	Successful placement of pipeline vantage embolization device in the right vertebral artery covering the above aneurysm with resulting contrast stagnation within the aneurysm.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Ureteral mass with right ureteral obstruction  Procedure:   1.	Right nephrostogram and nephrostomy tube placement      Findings:  Comparison is made to a previous exam dated [DATE] US  1.	Ultrasound exam with severe right hydronephrosis.  2.	Anterograde nephrostogram with high-grade obstruction at the proximal ureter with extrinsic mass compression/deviation   Catheter(s):  8.5 F Cook nephrostomy tube  Impression:   1.	Uneventful ultrasound and fluroscopic-guided placement of a right nephrostomy tube as described above.      Treatment Plan:   Patient should return for routine check and change in 8-12 weeks.        Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained to the patient. Written informed consent was obtained.  A time out/call to order was performed prior to procedure initiation.  The soft tissues overlying the access site were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Ultrasound was utilized to identify an appropriate access site. Static ultrasound image was obtained and stored to PACS for reference purposes. Subsequently, under fluoroscopic and real-time concurrent ultrasound guidance, access was obtained into a posterior, inferior calyx using a 21 ga needle and a triaxial sheath system (Neff). Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site. A wire was advanced centrally. Serial dilation was accomplished over the wire. The wire and inner dilator were removed. Non-ionic contrast was injected into the collecting system and images of the antegrade pyelogram were obtained and stored to PACS.  An 0.035” wire was advanced through the existing access. A nephrostomy tube was advanced over the wire and the Cope loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis. Contrast injection confirmed location. The catheter was sutured to the flank with monofilament suture and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.  The procedure was well tolerated, and patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by nurse present during the entire procedure. Patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Double lumen PICC placement using ultrasound and fluoroscopy      Findings:   1.  Vein patency was documented by ultrasound and stored to PACS. 2. Uneventful image guided placement of 5 French, 43 cm double-lumen PICC in the left or right upper extremity as described. The lumens flush and aspirate appropriately. Patient's Name: [PATIENT]  MRN: [ID] Procedure date: [DATE].  IR PERIPHERAL PICC  Indications: The patient is planned for long-term IV antibiotics.  Request is made for PICC placement.  Procedure: After explaining the technique, risks, benefits, alternatives, and answering all questions, informed consent was obtained from the patient. Timeout identifying the correct patient, procedure, site, allergies was performed and observed by the operating team. The patient was positioned supine with the right  arm abducted and resting on an arm board. The procedure is performed under continuous physiologic monitoring. The right arm and elbow region were prepped with by chlorhexidine and draped in a sterile fashion.  Following temporal application of a tourniquet across the right  axilla administration of local anesthesia using lidocaine 1% with epinephrine 2 ml, under ultrasound  guidance, access was obtained into the right brachial vein using a micropuncture device. Of note, the basilic vein is small in caliber. A 0.018" guidewire was advanced under fluoroscopy centrally into the SVC. Over the guidewire, a peel-away sheath was advanced. Following removal of the guidewire, a the available 5 F double  lumen power PICC was advanced through the sheath after trimming to a length of 45 cm. The sheath was peeled away and the line was further advanced with the tip at the SVC/upper right atrium. Both  lumens  demonstrated easy aspiration and injection and were  flushed with hep saline per protocol. Hemostasis was secured. Sterile occlusive dressing was applied including a Biopatch.  The PICC is ready to use. The patient tolerated to the procedure well. There were no intraprocedural complications. The patient was transferred to recovery in stable condition and eventually discharged. Please also refer to the Procedure note placed in the patient's EPIC chart on the date of the procedure. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Acute on chronic liver failure. Possible hepatorenal syndrome. Need for HD.  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled large bore central venous catheter placement. 2.	Removal of pre-existing nontunneled central venous catheter.  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the large bore central venous catheter, as described, the tip terminates in the right atrium.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a  15.5 French, 19 cm (tip-to-cuff), tunneled large bore central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.  Treatment Plan:   1. Routine catheter care. 2. The catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All [HOSPITAL]ts of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissues overlying the vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle. An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 Nitrex wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 Amplatz wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the dialysis catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The venotomy tract was serially dilated to allow introduction of a peel-away sheath.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Malignant biliary obstruction with dislodged drain   Procedure:   Left external biliary drain replacement  Findings:   1.	Existing drain is completely dislodged. Hand injection of the drain does not communicate with the biliary tree. 2.	Newly placed biliary drain is appropriately positioned with the distal tip in the central left hepatic duct.  Impression:   Uneventful image guided replacement of the biliary catheter as described.  Treatment Plan:   Leave the drain to gravity bag.   Technique:   The existing catheter and surrounding soft tissues were prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site.  Hand injection of contrast was performed, however, the catheter no longer communicating with the biliary tree. The catheter was cut and removed. A 5 French Kumpe catheter was introduced into the tract and manipulated centrally. Eventually the left hepatic bile ducts were entered and the Kumpe catheter was advanced centrally over a Glidewire. The Glidewire was removed and an Amplatz wire was placed. A new 10 French Dawson-Mueller drain was formed within the central left hepatic duct. Contrast was injected to confirm tube position. The catheter was secured to the skin with 2-0 Ethilon. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Squamous cell carcinoma of the tongue  Procedure:   1.	Gastrostomy tube placement under fluoroscopic guidance.  Findings:   1.	The gastrostomy tube is in good position.  2.	Gentle hand injection of contrast material confirms positioning of the gastrostomy tube within the gastric lumen.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of 18 French MIC gastrostomy tube as above.  Treatment Plan:   The tube should be placed to gravity drainage and should not be used for 24 hours. 25 cc of water can be administered per hour. At 4 hours, if residuals are less than 30%, the patient can have tube feeds advanced starting at a half dose.   Technique:   Informed consent for the procedure was obtained, and time-out was performed prior to the procedure.  The skin overlying the access site was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the mid abdomen were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.   Using fluoroscopic and ultrasonographic guidance, an appropriate puncture site was identified.  3 T-fasteners were placed adjacent to the planned tube access site. Positioning of the T-fasteners within the gastric lumen was confirmed by return of air and direct injection of contrast material.  Next, under fluoroscopic guidance, an 18-gauge needle was directed into the gastric lumen. Needle positioning within the gastric lumen was confirmed with aspiration of air as well as gentle hand injection of contrast material.  A wire was advance through the 18-gauge needle.  The 18-gauge needle was removed over a wire. Dilation was accomplished over the stiff wire using an 8mm by 4 cm balloon. An 18 French Halyard G-tube was advanced over a wire in an antegrade fashion after deflating the balloon and advanced through the anterior abdominal wall. All wires and catheters were removed. The bulb was inflated with 10 mL of a 10% contrast mixture. Gentle hand injection of contrast material documents the gastric feeding tube within the gastric lumen. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained for reference purposes. The tube was flushed with saline. It was affixed to the anterior abdominal wall with a rubber flange. The patient tolerated the procedure well at time of procedure completion without complication. Patient's Name: [PATIENT] MRN: [ID] Procedure date: [DATE] 3:15 PM  IR TUNNELED LARGE BORE CVC  Indications: Acute renal failure in need for hemodialysis.  Request is made for conversion of the non tunneled to tunneled dialysis catheter. The patient presents with an indwelling right  internal jugular vein non tunneled catheter without complications at the entry site.   Procedure: After explaining the technique, risks, benefits, alternatives, and answering all questions, informed consent was obtained from the patient. Timeout identifying the correct patient, procedure, site, allergies was performed and observed by the operating team. The patient was positioned supine. The procedure is performed under continuous physiologic monitoring. The patient received intravenous conscious sedation using Versed and fentanyl.  The right   side of the lower neck and upper chest including the indwelling 13  F Trialysis  catheter was prepped with chlorhexidine followed by Betadine and draped in a sterile fashion. No evidence of inflammation/infection at the entry site of the catheter is noted.   Following administration of local anesthesia using lidocaine 2% with epinephrine  10  ml at the right   side of the root of the neck extending to the right  infraclavicular region, 0.035" guidewire was advanced through the existing catheter under fluoroscopy into the SVC. Through skin stab incision in the right  infraclavicular region, a 15 F x 19  cm [tip to cuff] dialysis catheter was tunneled exiting at the root of the neck  at the exit of the non tunneled catheter. A peel-away sheath was advanced under fluoroscopy over the guidewire under fluoroscopy following intact removal of the non tunneled catheter [13 F x 15  cm]. Following removal of the guidewire and inner dilator, the catheter was advanced into the SVC and buried in the subcutaneous tissues following peeling of the sheath. Hemostasis was secured. The catheter tip was adjusted at the level of the SVC/upper right atrium. Both ports demonstrated easy aspiration and injection and were flushed with hep saline per protocol. The incision at the root of the neck was closed with Dermabond. The catheter was anchored to the skin using Ethilon 2/0 interrupted skin stitches. Sterile occlusive dressing was applied at the exit of the catheter in infraclavicular region. The patient tolerated to the procedure well. There were no intraprocedural complications. The patient was transferred to recovery in stable condition and eventually to the floor. The catheter is ready to use. Please also refer to the Procedure note placed in the patient's EPIC chart on the date of the procedure.  Fluoroscopy time: 00:10.6 min.  Device implanted: Duraflow 15F x 24 cm, Lot.#[ID], cat. #[ID].   Recommendations: The patient will need routine catheter check and possible exchange every 3 months.  Fellows: None. Residents: None.  IMPRESSION: 1. Uneventful image guided right   internal jugular  vein tunneled dialysis catheter placement following removal of the non tunneled catheter. The catheter is ready to use. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Chronic pelvic pain with intermittent right obstructive uropathy. A nephroureteral catheter was placed on [DATE]. The patient comes for conversion back to a nephrostomy tube.   Findings: Comparison is made to a previous exam dated [DATE].  1. Scout radiograph shows a right nephroureteral catheter with both cope loops in their expected location. 2. Contrast injection and wire passage confirmed occlusion of the distal 10 cm of the nephroureteral catheter. 3. The drain was severely encrusted. 4. With great difficulty, the catheter was removed intact. 5. Catheter injection once the catheter was retracted into the mid ureter showed irregularity of the entire ureter but prompt drainage to the bladder. 6. An 8.5 French nephrostomy tube has its cope loop in the renal pelvis.  Impression:   Difficult but successful image-guided conversion of a severely encrusted right nephroureteral catheter to an 8.5 French nephrostomy tube as described above.  Plan:  Flush catheter b.i.d.  Routine change in 8-10 week. The crystals and encrusted catheter was sent to the lab for stone analysis.  Technique:  The existing catheter and surrounding soft tissues were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  A scout radiograph was obtained.   Right nephroureteral tube PCN conversion:  Non-ionic contrast was injected through the existing right nephroureteral catheter and images of the collecting system obtained.  A 0.035” glide wire was advanced through the existing right nephroureteral catheter. The wire could not be negotiated out the end of the catheter. It did come out a sidehole and was easily advanced and looped in the bladder. With resistance, the distal cope loop was unformed old at the UVJ.  Attempt at placing a long 9 French peel-away sheath was unsuccessful as the peel-away buckled in the soft tissues. It did, however, disrupt the mature tract.  Substantial traction was needed to remove the encrusted catheter. Once the wire had been delivered at the skin, attempts were made to remove particulate in the distal portion of the catheter; however, the catheter could not be cleared. Ultimately, the PCNU was removed intact. The occluded catheter and crystals were sent to the lab for analysis.  A new 8.5 F nephrostomy catheter was advanced over the wire and the Cope loop formed in the renal pelvis.  Contrast injection confirmed location. The catheter was sutured to the flank with Ethilon and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.  The procedure was well tolerated, and patient discharged from the angio suite in satisfactory condition.   Procedural Personnel Attending(s): [HCW] Fellow(s): None Resident(s): None Advanced practice provider(s): None  Complications: No immediate complications.
