All vital signs were monitored and recorded by nurse present during the entire procedure. Patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Administered by the specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for a total of 90 minutes (Total intra service time).  Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.  Medications: Versed 4 mg IV. Fentanyl 300 mcg IV. 2.25 mg IV Dilaudid  Antibiotics: 2 g IV Rocephin  Blood loss:  Less than 10 ml  Checklist:	Informed consent was obtained discussing the risks, benefits and alternatives to the planned procedure.  Pre-sedation H&P was performed and sedation consent obtained. The patient’s name, medical record number, date of birth, allergies, procedure being performed including site and pertinent laboratory values were reviewed and confirmed with the technologist, nurse and patient.  These requirements including the Time Out were met prior to initiating the procedure.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Right obstructive uropathy with UTI.   Procedure:  Ultrasound guided placement of a 10.2 French right nephrostomy tube Antegrade pyelography    FINDINGS: CT from [DATE] was reviewed  1. There is moderate pelvicalyceal dilatation by ultrasound.  Hydronephrosis and needle entry images were stored to PACS. 2. Urine returned was grossly purulent. A sample was sent. 3. A posterior interpolar calyx was accessed. 4. The nephrostomy Cope loop is in the renal pelvis.  IMPRESSION:  Uneventful right nephrostomy tube placement via a posterior  interpolar calyx utilizing ultrasound guidance.  TREATMENT PLANNING:  The tube should be placed to gravity.  After several weeks to drainage, an attempt at internalization to a nephroureteral catheter could be performed to make the tube more stable.  TECHNIQUE:  [HCW]he right flank was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Ultrasonographic evaluation was carried out. A moderately dilated pelvicalyceal system was identified.  Under ultrasound guidance, a 22-gauge Chiba needle was advanced into the posterior calyx. No urine returned.  A 0.018" wire was placed. The needle was exchanged for a transitional dilator. Purulent urine returned through the dilator. A sample was sent for analysis.  A 0.035" Glidewire and 4 French angled catheter were used in attempt to traverse the high-grade UPJ obstruction. In light of purulent drainage, the decision was made to place a nephrostomy tube. An 035 wire as placed into the renal pelvis.  A an 0.2 French nephrostomy tube was advanced over the wire and the Cope loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis. A total of 45 mL frankly purulent material was aspirated from the renal pelvis. The catheter was injected. It was sutured to the skin with 2-0 Ethilon and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.  The procedure was well-tolerated, and the patient was discharged still asleep into the care of anesthesiology for transfer to the PACU. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  End-stage renal disease, permacath requested  Procedure:   1.	Exchange of non-tunneled for tunneled right internal jugular hemodialysis catheter  Findings:   1.	After placement of the tunneled catheter, the tip terminates in the right atrium.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided exchange of non-tunneled for tunneled 16 French 23 cm cuff to tip right internal jugular hemodialysis catheter.   Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care.  The catheter is ready for immediate use.     Technique:   The skin overlying the right neck and chest was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).    An Amplatz guidewire was placed through the existing non-tunneled right internal jugular hemodialysis catheter. Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site. The non-tunneled right internal jugular hemodialysis catheter was removed.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS.  Procedural Personnel Attending(s): [HCW]  Complications: No immediate complications. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Cirrhosis c/b HCC s/p resection c/b recurrence at margin now s/p   PROCEDURE:  Y90 Shunt study/mapping using MAA  1. US-guided left radial artery access. 2. Diagnostic visceral angiography 3. MAA delivery Cone-beam CT performed for intraprocedural localization, as detailed below.  FINDINGS: ANGIOGRAPHY: Vessels catheterized and angiograms performed, as follows:  Superior mesenteric artery: No replaced or accessory hepatic arterial supply. Celiac artery: Tumoral blush identified. Right hepatic artery: Tumoral blush identified. Segment IV  hepatic artery: Tumoral blush identified.  Specific technical notes / catheter selection: None.  CBCT: Yes Catheter location: Right hepatic artery Findings: Tumoral blush identified with supply from the target vessel.  Embolization: No Vessel embolized: N/a Coils used: N/a  MAA delivery performed from: Right hepatic artery (series 16 and 21  Future target Y90 delivery catheter position(s): right_ artery (Series 9 image 10), also suspect supply from phrenic and/or left gastric  Treatment device: cTACE Additional details:      IMPRESSION:   Successful Yttrium-90     selective internal radiotherapy mapping. Flow in vessels supplying tumor is easily overwhelmed with contrast injection. Also suspect extrahepatic supply.  TREATMENT PLAN:  1. Patient will return in 2-4 weeks for cTACE. Will utilize antireflux/balloon catheter to deliver therapy.  2. Access site precautions and orders placed.  TECHNIQUE:  With the patient in the supine position, the left wrist was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The left wrist was evaluated with ultrasound and left radial artery patency and acceptable size criteria were documented and images were properly stored in PACS. A modified Allen test (Barbeau test Type B) was performed on the left wrist to confirm patency of the ulnopalmar arch using pulse oximetry.   1% lidocaine solution was administered for local anesthesia. Access was obtained to the left radial artery using a 21 gauge micro needle and ultrasound guidance. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. A wire was placed through the needle. A hydrophilic Glidesheath was advanced slowly over the wire. 3000 units of heparin, 200 mcg of nitroglycerin and 2.5 mg of verapamil was given through the arterial sheath with slow hemodilution. A side flush was started.   A 5-Fr [VENDOR]y/[HCW][VENDOR] catheter was advanced over an 0.035" wire into the abdominal aorta. The catheter was used to catheterize the visceral vessels described below. Angiograms were performed. A microcatheter system was used to catheterize distal visceral and hepatic vessels, as described below. Specific vessels catheterized and embolized are described in detail below. Tumor blush was confirmed on angiography.  Cone Beam CT (CBCT) was performed intraprocedurally for purposes of treatment planning, targeting and dose calculation. Axial and coronal images were created and 3D reconstruction was performed on a separate dedicated workstation under concurrent supervision.  After confirmation of target treatment vessel, 5 mCi of Tc-99 MAA was injected slowly in this location though the catheter.   All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. A TR Band was placed on the left wrist for hemostasis. The access sheath was removed and no hematoma was seen. A radial artery pulse was confirmed distal to the puncture site confirming patent hemostasis.   The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. The patient was transferred to the Nuclear Medicine department for imaging. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by nurse present during the entire procedure. Patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Patient's Name: [PATIENT]  MRN: [ID] [DATE] 10:05 AM   *	IR CENTRAL PORT, IR PERIPHERAL PICC placement *	Left arm PICC removal  Indications: The patient presents with mental cell lymphoma and is currently on IV chemotherapy via a left arm PICC.  Request is made for placement of an infusion port and removal of the PICC. The patient reported no current problems including infection, inflammation or swelling related to the left arm PICC.  Procedure: After explaining the technique, risks, benefits, alternatives, and answering all questions, informed consent was obtained from the patient. Timeout identifying the correct patient, procedure, site, allergies was performed and observed by the operating team. The patient was positioned supine with the head turned to the left. The procedure is performed under continuous physiologic monitoring. The patient received intravenous conscious sedation using Versed 2 mg and fentanyl 100 mcg.  Also the patient received Ancef 2 g IV.  The right side of the lower neck and upper chest was prepped with Betadine followed by chlorhexidine and draped in a sterile fashion.  Following administration of local anesthesia using lidocaine 1% with epinephrine 6ml at the right  side of the root of the neck, under ultrasound  guidance, access was obtained into the right  internal jugular vein using a micropuncture device. A 0.018" guidewire was advanced under fluoroscopy into the vein centrally. Further administration of local anesthesia using lidocaine 1% with epinephrine 8 mL into the right  infraclavicular region. A transverse 3.5  cm incision was performed and a pocket created inferior to the incision to accommodate the port using both sharp and blunt dissection. Through the infraclavicular incision, the port tubing 8 F was tunneled exiting at the root of the neck following a nick incision at the exit of the guidewire. The guidewire was upgraded to 0.035" guidewire that was advanced under fluoroscopy through the SVC into the IVC. [HCW]way sheath was advanced over the guidewire. Following removal of the guidewire and the stiffener, the port tubing was advanced after trimming to a length of 18 cm. The sheath was peeled away and the line was buried in the subcutaneous tissues. The tip of the line is at the SVC/upper right atrium. The port was tested demonstrating easy aspiration and injection and was flushed with normal saline followed by hep saline as per protocol. The port was anchored in the subcutaneous tissues using nonabsorbable 2/0 interrupted stitches. The wound was irrigated. Hemostasis secured. The incision at the root of the neck was closed using Dermabond. The infraclavicular incision was closed using subcutaneous followed by subcuticular Vicryl 4/0 continuous stitches. Steri-Strips were applied followed by Sterile occlusive dressing. The patient tolerated to the procedure well. There were no intraprocedural complications.   The left arm was abducted and resting on an arm board. Initial assessment did not reveal any inflammation, infection or discharge at the exit site of the 5F double lumen PICC. The left arm was prepped with chlorhexidine and draped in sterile fashion. The PICC was removed intact with the length of 40 cm. Sterile dry occlusive dressing was applied. The patient was transferred to recovery in stable condition and eventually discharged. The port is ready to use. Please also refer to the Procedure note placed in the patient's EPIC chart on the date of the procedure.  Fluoroscopy time: 00:33.6 min.  Device implanted: 8F single lumen power port, Ref #[ID], Lot #[ID].  Fellows: None. Residents: None.  IMPRESSION: 1. Uneventful ultrasound fluoroscopy guided placement of 8F Power  infusion port in the right  internal jugular vein. The port is ready to use. 2. Uneventful removal of the left arm PICC.  Voice recognition is used in generating this report.

DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: This is a 67 years Female who presents for diagnostic cerebral angiography following incidental finding of anterior communicating artery aneurysm   PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 30 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] was the fellow. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right Internal Carotid Artery Right External Carotid Artery Left Common Carotid Artery Left Subclavian Artery   ANESTHESIA: Local in the right groin with bupivacaine. Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by the nurse present during the entire procedure. The patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Sedation was administered by a specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for the duration of the procedure as outlined above (Total intra service time, 30min ). Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.   MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine SQ 10 cc  Versed 1 mg IV Fentanyl 50 mcg IV Heparin 3000 units IV Protamine 20 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.038" Bentson guidewire 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 5 French Cordis Vertebral catheter  5 French Simmons 3 Glide catheter  Cardiva Vascade Visipaque-270 contrast material (120 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 5 French sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP, Lateral and Oblique views.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY:  Rotational angiography was also performed from the diagnostic catheter in the right internal carotid artery for better delineation of the underlying angioarchitecture. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.    Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a Vascade followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: Noninvasive imaging.  FINDINGS:  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is a 4.6 x 4.8 x 4.1 mm medially directed anterior communicating artery aneurysm which fills predominantly from the right A1 segment of the ACA. The bilateral ACA branches fill from the right A1. The right internal carotid artery and its segments are normal course and caliber. The right posterior communicating artery is dominant supplies the posterior cerebral artery territory. The MCA and its branches are normal course and caliber. There is normal cortical venous drainage.   RIGHT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   LEFT SUBCLAVIAN ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. Reflux of contrast into the contralateral vertebral artery was not achieved. The origin of PICA is normal unilaterally (we will defer to CTA for evaluation of the contralateral PICA). This run is limited by the distal location of the catheter with poor contrast opacification.  LEFT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is a mildly hypoplastic left A1 segment of the ACA with brief visualization of the anterior communicating artery aneurysm. The left posterior communicating artery is dominant supplies the posterior cerebral territory. The segments of the left internal carotid artery are normal course and caliber. The MCA and its branches are normal course and caliber. There are normal cortical venous drainage  LEFT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.    3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: 3D Rotational angiography with volume-rendered three-dimensional reconstruction on an independent workstation, demonstrated a medially directed anterior communicating artery aneurysm measuring 4.8 x 4.8 x 4.1 mm and is without irregular features. The bilateral ACA territories are visualized on this run.   COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: There is a medially directed 4.8 x 4.8 x 4.1 mm anterior communicating artery aneurysm filling predominantly from the right A1 segment of the ACA. The left A1 segment of the ACA is hypoplastic. No other aneurysms are identified.  [HCW], was present for the key and critical portions of the procedure and associated imaging guidance.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Gastrointestinal disorder on total parenteral nutrition. Hickman catheter placed [DATE] now with catheter malfunction  Procedure:  1. Fluoroscopic guided exchange of tunneled Hickman catheter  Findings:  1. Scout image demonstrates existing right IJ tunneled Hickman with tip positioned in the right atrium. 2. Newly exchanged right IJ tunneled Hickman is appropriately positioned with the tip in the right atrium.   Impression:  Uneventful image guided wire exchange of a right IJ tunneled Hickman catheter.   Plan:  Catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:  The right chest wall and area immediately around the existing double lumen Hickman catheter was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier.  Using local anesthetic, the tract was anesthetized. Utilizing a hemostat, the tract was accessed and the cuff freed from the surrounding soft tissues. Two stiff angled glided wires was advanced through each lumen of the existing Hickman catheter and navigated down the IVC under direct fluoroscopic guidance. The catheter was then pulled with gentle traction until it was completely removed over the wire.  A new double lumen Hickman catheter was advanced over the wire until the tip was positioned appropriately and the cuff positioned within the tunnel. 2-0 Prolene suture was placed at the catheter tunnel exit site. Sterile dressing was applied.  The catheter was aspirated, flushed, and heparinized per protocol. The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient was discharged in satisfactory condition. Patient has kyphotic deformity due to vertebral body compression fracture(s).     Procedure:   1.	Image-guided kyphoplasty of L2 vertebral body  Findings:   1.	Pre-intervention: Previously treated T8-L1, L2 target  2.	Post-intervention:  Successful deposition of cement within the treated vertebral body/bodies with no evidence of extravasation.    Impression:   1.	Successful image guided augmentation of vertebral levels: L2    Treatment Plan:   1.	 A fracture of the hip, spine or distal radius in patients over 50 years of age warrants testing or treatment for osteoporosis if not previously undertaken.   Patient was instructed to take part in an osteoporosis prevention/treatment program.   Technique:   The patient was brought to the interventional radiology suite and placed on the table in prone position. The wide area of the back around the affected area(s) was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion.   All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). A scout image was obtained in AP and lateral projections.  Skin was anesthetized with a 2% lidocaine solution.   Level by level technique:   -Vertebral level:  L2     -Pedicle access:  Bipedicular -Access trocar gauge:  8-gauge -Balloon utilized:  15 mm  Prior to injection of cement, balloons were inserted and inflated under biplane fluoroscopy.  Static fluoroscopic images were stored to PACS documenting balloon utilization and position. -Biopsy obtained:  No -Indication for biopsy: N/A -Ablation Performed: N/A  Additional Procedural Details:   Utilizing AP and lateral fluoroscopy, needles were inserted into the affected vertebral body/bodies. Needles were advanced under careful, intermittent biplane fluoroscopy to ensure that the medial wall of the pedicle was not violated prior to transgression of the needle tip into the posterior wall of the vertebral body. The drill was then advanced to the anterior one-third of the vertebral body on each side.  No ablation was performed.  Balloon(s) was/were inserted into the effected vertebral body/bodies and inflated under fluoroscopy. Static fluoroscopic images were stored to PACS documenting balloon position. Cement was mixed and balloons were removed after being deflated.  Cement was then injected under careful, intermittent biplane fluoroscopy to ensure no significant extravasation of PMMA cement beyond the borders of the vertebral body. Cement injection was stopped once there was adequate fill of the vertebral body. Trochars were removed with hemostasis obtained with focal compression. Static fluoroscopic images were obtained after removal of all needles documenting final cement position. CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM AND WOVEN ENDOBRIDGE (WEB) EMBOLIZATION OF BASILAR APEX ANEURYSM    CLINICAL INDICATION: 54-year-old female with past medical history of hypertension, sickle cell disease and multiple incidentally discovered intracranial aneurysms including a right M1 segment aneurysm, a right MCA bifurcation aneurysm, and a right SCA aneurysm for which she previously underwent right-sided orbitozygomatic craniotomy and clip ligation in [DATE]. She also has a basilar apex aneurysm which is indicated.   PROCEDURE: Cerebral angiogram, Woven Endobridge device embolization of basilar apex aneurysm.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: 4 hours.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician.  He supervised the entire procedure. [HCW] and [HCW] were the fellows. Each actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS CATHETERIZED: Left vertebral artery Basilar artery  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right subclavian artery Right common femoral artery Left vertebral artery Left subclavian artery  VESSELS TREATED (in sequence): Basilar artery  ANESTHESIA:   General Anesthesia administered by anesthesiology staff.  Pre- Intra- and post- anesthesia records are available in the patient chart.   MEDICATIONS GIVEN:  Verapamil 2.5 mg intra-arterial into the right radial artery Nitroglycerin 200 mcg intra-arterial into the right radial artery Heparin 1000 units into the right radial artery Heparin 4000 units IV Ancef 2 gram IV  MATERIALS USED:  6 French Terumo slender sheath, long 5 French micropuncture kit Cope mandrel wire 5 French transitional dilator 6 French 65cm Arrow sheath 0.035" Bentson guidewire 0.035" Terumo glidewire (180 cm) 5 French Merit Performa Vertebral catheter 5 French Cordis Vertebral catheter 6 French Sofia guide catheter, 115 cm 5 French Sofia guide catheter, 115 cm  VIA 17 microcatheter (156 cm) Asahi 014 microguidewire (200 cm) Omnipaque 300 contrast material (180 cc) 6 French AngioSeal closure device  DEVICE IMPLANTED: Woven Endobridge SL 7 mm x 4 mm  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, hemorrhage, renal failure, limb loss, death, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.  After informed, written consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion after intubation by the anesthesiology team.   Initial access to the vascular system was via the right radial artery. A right radial artery line and replaced by anesthesia staff. Through the pre-existing right radial catheter a guidewire was introduced and the radial artery line catheter was exchanged for a 6 French slender Terumo sheath. A radial cocktail consisting of 2.5 mg of verapamil, 200 mcg of nitroglycerin, and 1000 units of heparin was given slowly via the radial sheath. Under fluoroscopic guidance, the 5 French [VENDOR] Performa vertebral catheter was advanced over the 150 cm baby J Glidewire. A roadmap angiogram of the right subclavian was performed. There is evident from this roadmap angiogram that the V2 segment of the right vertebral artery was significantly more tortuous than head appeared on the CT angiogram. Given this we decided to abandon the approach from the right vertebral artery and therefore the right radial approach in favor of a left vertebral artery approach via femoral access.  Access to the vascular system was gained by a single-wall puncture of the right common femoral artery. An angiogram of the right common femoral artery was performed through the outer cannula the dilator to confirm that the arteriotomy was an appropriate location in adequate for use of appropriate closure device. A 6 French 65cm Arrow sheath was introduced into the descending aortausing Seldinger technique and fluoroscopic guidance.  Using fluoroscopic guidance, the 5 French selection catheter was advanced through the arrow sheath to select the left subclavian artery and left vertebral artery.  The arrow sheath was then advanced over the selection catheter into the left subclavian artery. Digital angiogram was performed, centered over the head.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY: Rotational angiography was also performed from the diagnostic catheter in the proximal to mid V2 segment of the left vertebral artery for better delineation of the intracranial vasculature. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.  Following the diagnostic angiogram, the 5 French diagnostic catheter was withdrawn.  Through the long sheath, a 6 French Sofia guide catheter was advanced into the left vertebral artery over the VIA 17 microcatheter and Asahi 014 microguid[HCW]. However we were unable to advance the microcatheter and microguidewire beyond the proximal V3 segment for the 072 Navien guide catheter beyond the mid to distal V2 segment due to the tortuosity of the V2 segment of the left vertebral artery. We therefore removed the 6 French Sofia guide catheter and the microcatheters. Were ultimately able to advance and 5 French Sofia guide catheter over a Terumo Glidewire into the proximal V3 segment of the left vertebral artery.   Superselective catheterization of the basilar artery aneurysm was then performed with the VIA 17 microcatheter over a Asahi 014 microguidewire. The WEB SL 7 mm x 4 mm device was then deployed inside of the aneurysm using roadmap and blank roadmap technique.   A final cerebral angiogram was done in the AP and lateral projection to evaluate for residual filling, and distal emboli.  Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine.  An angiogram of the right common femoral artery was obtained to confirm that the arterial puncture was above the bifurcation that the vessels of adequate size to use a 8 French AngioSeal. Ancef was administered.  Hemostasis was achieved by application of a 8 French AngioSeal. A Tegaderm was then applied over the puncture site.  COMPARISON: None.  FINDINGS: RIGHT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CERVICAL (ROADMAP): This run was done primarily for navigation and selection of the right vertebral artery and is of limited diagnostic utility. Within those confines, there is severe tortuosity of the V2 segment of the right vertebral artery.  RIGHT COMMON FEMORAL ARTERY: The arteriotomy is above the bifurcation of the right common femoral artery and the diameter of the vessel is adequate for a 6 French AngioSeal.  LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CERVICAL (ROADMAP): This run was done primarily for navigation and selection of the left vertebral artery and is of limited diagnostic utility. Within those confines, there is also severe tortuosity of the V2 segment of the right vertebral artery, albeit less than was visualized on the right. Additionally the caliber of the left vertebral artery is significantly larger than that of the right vertebral artery.  LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is a posteriorly projecting basilar apex aneurysm which is grossly unchanged from prior angiogram, the dimensions of which are described on the 3-D rotational angiography discussed below. There is a surgical clip seen in the expected location of the previously seen superior cerebellar artery aneurysm. No visualized recurrence or residual superior cerebellar artery aneurysm.  LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-WOVEN ENDOBRIDGE DEVICE DEPLOYMENT): There is a Web device deployed within the basilar apex aneurysm. There is good apposition to the walls of the aneurysm, especially at the base, without evidence of endoleak. There is significant contrast stagnation within the dome of the aneurysm. The bilateral P1 segments appear patent and fill without delay. There are no perfusion deficits to suggest distal emboli in the posterior circulation.  LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CERVICAL: No evidence of dissection post catheterization of the left vertebral artery.  LEFT SUBCLAVIAN ARTERY, CERVICOTHORACIC: No evidence of dissection or stenosis of the origin of the left vertebral artery post catheterization.  3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY:  3-D rotational angiography demonstrated posteriorly directed basilar apex aneurysm which measures 5.7 x 6.2 x 5.6 x 2.3 mm (axial by axial by neck-to-dome by neck) which is grossly stable in appearance compared to prior.    IMPRESSION: 1.	Successful deployment of WEB device within unruptured basilar apex aneurysm with maintained patency of the bilateral PCAs. 2.	No evidence of recurrence or residual previously ligated superior cerebellar artery aneurysm

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Ulcerative colitis with short gut syndrome. Needs TPN.  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled central venous double-lumen Hickman catheter placement       Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the Hickman catheter, as described, the tip terminates near the cavoatrial junction..  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a tunneled Hickman catheter.       Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care.  The catheter is ready for immediate use.        Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS.  A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 Amplatz wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance. An image was saved.  Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The venotomy tract was dilated to allow introduction of a peel-away sheath.  The cut to length catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The catheter was tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.   The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. The new tube is appropriately positioned within in the stomach.  Impression:   1.	Successful replacement of 18 French MIC gastrostomy tube.      Treatment Plan:   It is OK to use the tube immediately.  Routine check and change recommended in 6 months.  Technique:   Informed consent for the procedure was obtained, and time-out was performed prior to the procedure. The replacement tube overlies the stomach on static fluoroscopic image saved to PACS.  The balloon was inflated with 10 mL of a 10% contrast mixture. Gentle hand injection of contrast material documents the gastric feeding tube within the gastric lumen. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Multiple myeloma  Procedure:  1. Ultrasound and Fluoroscopic guided placement of a tunneled, cuffed central venous catheter  Findings:  1. The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and normal. Vein patency and needle entry were stored to PACS. 2. The newly placed catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating in the right atrium.  Impression:   Uneventful image guided placement of right internal jugular vein tunneled Trifusion catheter as described.  Technique:  The right neck and chest region was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. The region was ultrasonographically evaluated.  Using local anesthetic and ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was punctured with a 21 gauge needle.  An image documenting vein patency and needle entry was saved and stored to PACS.   A 0.018” wire was passed centrally and the needle exchanged for a 5 French transitional dilator. A 0.035” wire was advanced through the dilator and negotiated into the IVC.  The skin tract was dilated and a 13 French dilator peel-away combination placed over the wire.  The soft tissues caudal and lateral to the sheath entry site were anesthetized with lidocaine with epinephrine. A dermatotomy was made and a tunneling tool brought from the dermatotomy to the venotomy. The catheter was brought through the tunnel.  During suspended respiration, the catheter was advanced through the peel-away and positioned centrally using fluoroscopy. The peel-away was removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression.  The venotomy was closed with Dermabond and Steri-Strips applied. A single Prolene suture was placed at the catheter tunnel exit site. An antimicrobial disc and sterile dressing were applied.  The catheter was aspirated, flushed, and heparinized per protocol. The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient was discharged in satisfactory condition. The lumens flush and aspirate appropriately.        Treatment Plan:   Catheter tip position is confirmed as above. It is OK to use this line.       Technique:   The site was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).   Ultrasound evaluation of the right basilic vein was performed, demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS. Local anesthetic was used over the access site. Under ultrasound guidance, the right basilic vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS.    A 0.018" wire was passed however could not be advanced up the arm, concerning for proximal occlusion. The needle was removed.  Ultrasound evaluation of the brachial veins demonstrate patency. More local anesthetic was used over the new access site. Under ultrasound guidance the right brachial vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle. The 018 wire was then advanced centrally and the needle exchanged for a dilator peel-away combination. The wire was used to determine catheter length, and a 5 French double-lumen PICC line cut to appropriate length. The tailored catheter was advanced through the peel-away and positioned centrally using fluoroscopy.   The peel-away was removed, and hemostasis achieved with manual compression. The catheter was aspirated, flushed, and locked per protocol. It was secured in place with Ethilon.  An antimicrobial disc and sterile dressing were applied.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Head and neck cancer. Needs enteral nutrition access.  Procedure:   1.	Gastrostomy tube placement under fluoroscopic guidance.  Findings:   1.	The gastrostomy tube is in good position.  2.	Gentle hand injection of contrast material confirms positioning of the gastrostomy tube within the gastric lumen.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of 18 French MIC gastrostomy tube as above.  Treatment Plan:   The tube should be placed to gravity drainage and should not be used for 4 hours. 25 cc of water can be administered per hour. At 4 hours, if residuals are less than 30%, the patient can have tube feeds advanced starting at a half dose.   Technique:   Informed consent for the procedure was obtained, and time-out was performed prior to the procedure.  The skin overlying the access site was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the mid abdomen were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.   Using ultrasound, the liver edges were demarcated. Under direct fluoroscopic guidance, an appropriate puncture site was identified.  3 T-fasteners were placed adjacent to the planned tube access site. Positioning of the T-fasteners within the gastric lumen was confirmed by return of air and direct injection of contrast material.  Next, under fluoroscopic guidance, an 18-gauge needle was directed into the gastric lumen. Needle positioning within the gastric lumen was confirmed with aspiration of air as well as gentle hand injection of contrast material.  A wire was advance through the 18-gauge needle.  The 18-gauge needle was removed over a wire. Serial dilation was accomplished over the stiff wire using the telescoping dilator. An 18 French Halyard G-tube was advanced over a wire in an antegrade fashion and advanced through the anterior abdominal wall. All wires and catheters were removed. The bulb was inflated with 10 mL of a sterile water. Gentle hand injection of contrast material documents the gastric feeding tube within the gastric lumen. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained for reference purposes. The tube was flushed with saline. It was affixed to the anterior abdominal wall with a rubber flange. The patient tolerated the procedure well at time of procedure completion without complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Biliary atresia with liver transplant as a child. The hepatic artery occlusion with biliary cast syndrome. He has internal/external biliary drain replacement and bile ducts suite every 5 weeks. Here for routine maintenance.  Procedure:   1.	Catheter cholangiogram through existing percutaneous access 2.	Fogarty balloon sweep of the bile duct 3.	Left internal/external biliary drain replacement  Findings:   1.	Cholangiogram through the existing 22 French [VENDOR] tech catheter demonstrates adequate filling of the bile duct and small bowel. 2.	Newly placed biliary drain is appropriately positioned with the distal tip in the Roux limb and the proximal side hole in a peripheral bile duct with the radiopaque marker at midline along the spinous process.  Impression:   Uneventful image guided biliary Fogarty balloon sweep and replacement of 22 French internal/external mesenteric biliary catheter replacement.  Treatment Plan:   Routine exchange has been set up for 5 weeks.  Technique:   The existing catheter and surrounding soft tissues were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  A 0.035" Amplatz was negotiated through the catheter into the small bowel.  The catheter was removed and a 5.5 French by 40 cm Fogarty was placed over the wire. The balloon was inflated in the bile duct and advanced over the Amplatz through the anastomosis twice. A new 22 French Bentec catheter was advanced over the glide and positioned fluoroscopically. Contrast was injected to confirm tube position. The tube was sutured in place and capped.     The catheter was secured to the skin with 2-0 Ethilon.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Lymphoma  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen Bard 20 cm port (standard profile)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen Bard power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 2-0 absorbable sutures. A running 4-0 absorbable subcuticular stitch and  Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with a single subcuticular stitch and Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Right ovarian cancer  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance on the right chest  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen Bard port (standard profile)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen Bard power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).   The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 2-0 absorbable sutures. A running 4-0 absorbable subcuticular stitch and  Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with a single subcuticular stitch and Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Myelodysplastic syndrome  Procedure:  1. Ultrasound and Fluoroscopic guided placement of a tunneled, cuffed central venous catheter  Findings:  1. The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and normal. Vein patency and needle entry were stored to PACS. 2. The newly placed catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating in the right atrium.  Impression:   Uneventful image guided placement of right internal jugular vein tunneled Trifusion catheter as described.  Technique:  The right neck and chest region was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. The region was ultrasonographically evaluated.  Using local anesthetic and ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was punctured with a 21 gauge needle.  An image documenting vein patency and needle entry was saved and stored to PACS.   A 0.018” wire was passed centrally and the needle exchanged for a 5 French transitional dilator. A 0.035” wire was advanced through the dilator and negotiated into the IVC.  The skin tract was dilated and a 13 French dilator peel-away combination placed over the wire.  The soft tissues caudal and lateral to the sheath entry site were anesthetized with lidocaine with epinephrine. A dermatotomy was made and a tunneling tool brought from the dermatotomy to the venotomy. The catheter was brought through the tunnel.  During suspended respiration, the catheter was advanced through the peel-away and positioned centrally using fluoroscopy. The peel-away was removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression.  The venotomy was closed with Dermabond and Steri-Strips applied. A single Prolene suture was placed at the catheter tunnel exit site. An antimicrobial disc and sterile dressing were applied.  The catheter was aspirated, flushed, and heparinized per protocol. The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient was discharged in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  End-stage renal disease on hemodialysis  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled dialysis catheter placement 2.	Removal of left internal jugular Vas-Cath  Findings:   1.	Left internal jugular vein with Vas-Cath in place with tip near the cavoatrial junction 2.	After placement of the new tunneled dialysis catheter, as described, the tip terminates near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated exchange of nontunneled dialysis catheter for new 15.5 French 23 cm tip to cuff tunneled dialysis catheter   Treatment Plan:   1. Routine catheter care. 2. The catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed below.  The skin and subcutaneous tissues surrounding the existing left IJ nontunneled dialysis catheter were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic. A 0.035 wire was placed through the Vas-Cath port and directed into the IVC under fluoroscopic guidance. The Vas-Cath was removed over the wire and replaced with a dilator. Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the dialysis catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The venotomy tract was dilated to allow introduction of a peel-away sheath.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   At this point during the procedure the patient's oxygen saturation began to decrease into the 60s and 70s. A code met was called and patient was reversed using the Narcan. After reversal and treatment with nonrebreather patient's oxygen saturation returned to 98%. Patient was an alert and oriented moving extremities.  After the code met was called, the area was reprepped. The catheter was tested however neither port was able to be aspirated. Catheter was exchanged over the wire for a new catheter which functioned properly.  The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Breast cancer status post bilateral mastectomy. Patient with recurrent chylous leak. Prior lymphangiogram without thoracic duct leak, no embolization performed. Patient underwent thorascopic thoracic duct ligation, with persistent chylous leak.  PROCEDURE:   1. Lymphangiogram. 2. Accessory thoracic duct embolization. 3. Direct cisterna chyle leak embolization.   FINDINGS:  1. No thoracic duct opacification, in keeping with prior surgical ligation.  2. Access into an accessory thoracic duct, without evidence of leak. Successfully embolized with glue (1:1 glue:Lipiodol, 2 cc).  3. Direct access into leak originating at this cisterna chyle, successfully embolized with glue (1:2 glue:Lipiodol, 3 cc).  IMPRESSION:   Technically successful accessory thoracic duct and cisterna chyle glue embo[HCW].  TREATMENT PLAN:  Monitor chest tube drain output, and follow-up with cardiothoracic surgery.   TECHNIQUE:  With the patient in the supine position, the bilateral groins and wide abdomen was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier.   A scout radiograph demonstrated lipiodol staining in the bilateral groins from prior lymphangiogram.  Ultrasound evaluation of bilateral groins demonstrated very few scant, normal-appearing lymph nodes. A small lymph node in the right groin was accessed using a 25-gauge spinal needle, and lipiodol was injected. Under fluoroscopic visualization, lipiodol was seen transiting up the iliac chain. Evaluation of the left groin without any appropriate lymph node target lipiodol injection.  A lymph node in the left iliac chain was then targeted under direct fluoroscopic guidance and accessed using a 21-gauge Chiba needle. More lipiodol was injected, and transitted up the iliac chain to the abdominal lymph nodes.  Intermittent fluoroscopy demonstrated transit of the lipiodol through the abdominal lymphatic network to cisterna chyle, however no lipiodol was seen transiting up into the chest. The cisterna chyle, was then directly accessed using a 21-gauge Chiba needle under fluoroscopic guidance. Lipiodol injection demonstrated mild lipiodol opacification and transit up into the chest however no dominant intrathoracic lymphatic duct or definite intrathoracic leak could be identified. A V18 wire was able to be navigated into an accessory thoracic duct into the chest. Cone beam CT confirmed positioning of the wire in this duct, without evidence of leak. The thoracic duct (known location from prior lymphangiogram), could not be identified, in keeping with the patient's known history of thoracic duct ligation.  Attention was then turned to the patient's neck, where we attempted to access the venolymphatic junction deep to the left internal jugular vein, however multiple attempts were unsuccessful, and these attempts were aborted.  We then reviewed the images obtained point extensively, that even before early injections of the cisterna chyle, lipiodol appeared to be leaking towards the right upper quadrant/right lower chest. Cone beam CT was then performed, and lipiodol was confirmed in the right pleural space, indicating that this truly was the site of leak.   The 21-gauge Chiba needle was then used to access a lymph node one vertebral body lower than the cisterna chyle, and glue was injected to this lymph node (with some retrograde flow noted down the abdominal lymphatic chain). The needle was then used to access the confirmed leak near its neck adjacent to the cisterna chyle. More glue was injected, under direct fluoroscopic evaluation, and lipiodol was seen within the chest tube.  At the end of the procedure all needles and wires were removed from the patient's body. The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. Here for routine exchange   Procedure:  1. Bilateral antegrade nephrostogram and percutaneous nephroureterostomy exchange.   Findings:  1. Newly placed PCNUs are appropriately positioned with the proximal loop in the renal pelvis and distal loop in the urinary bladder.  Impression:  Uneventful image-guided exchange of bilateral percutaneous nephroureterostomy tubes.   Plan:   Patient will be due for routine exchange in 10-12 weeks. Patient was extremely uncomfortable during the procedure and recommend future exchanges with mac anesthesia   Technique:  With the patient in prone position, the bilateral flanks were prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. A scout radiograph was obtained.   Right PCNU exchange   Contrast was injected through the existing nephrostomy/nephroureterostomy tube and imaging of the collecting was system performed. A 0.035" wire was placed through the tube and the tube removed over the wire and discarded. A new, 8-French x 24 cm nephroureterostomy tube was advanced over the wire under fluoroscopic guidance. The wire was removed and the proximal loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis. Contrast injection confirmed location.  The catheter was sutured to the flank and placed to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.    Left PCNU exchange   Contrast was injected through the existing nephrostomy/nephroureterostomy tube and imaging of the collecting was system performed. A 0.035" wire was placed through the tube and the tube removed over the wire and discarded. A new, 8-French x 24 cm nephroureterostomy tube was advanced over the wire under fluoroscopic guidance. A sterile dressing was applied.    The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Right obstructive uropathy with ureteral stone. Failed cystoscopic double-J ureteral stent placement  Procedure:   1. US guided calyceal access   2. Right antegrade pyelography  3. Right percutaneous nephroureteral catheter placement  Findings: Abdominal CT from [DATE] was reviewed  1. There is moderate to severe right hydroureteronephrosis with parenchymal thinning and obstruction in the distal ureter near the lower SI joint. 2. Hydronephrosis and needle entry images into the posterior interpolar calyx were stored to PACS. Urine returned was cloudy. 3. A urine sample was sent for analysis 4. The renal pelvis is bifid. 5. An 8.5 French by 28 cm nephroureteral catheter has its proximal cope loop in the lower pole moiety of the bifid renal pelvis and its distal cope loop in the urinary bladder.   Impression:   Uneventful image guided placement of an 8.5 French by 28 cm right nephroureteral catheter as described.  Treatment plan:  The patient will follow-up with urology. Follow-up catheter maintenance was scheduled for 8 weeks.   Technique:  Right:  1% lidocaine was used as local anesthetic. Under ultrasound guidance a 21-gauge micropuncture needle was introduced into the posterior interpolar calyx.  An 0.018" wire was passed through the needle into the renal pelvis. The needle was removed and a 6 French coaxial dilator was placed over the wire.   Antegrade pyelography was performed.    A 4 French angled glide catheter and Glidewire were placed coaxially through the transitional dilator and access to the bladder achieved. Contrast injection confirmed location. An Amplatz wire was placed and coiled in the bladder.   The dilator was removed and an 8.5 French by 28 cm  nephroureteral catheter was advanced over the wire. The distal cope loop was formed in the urinary bladder and the proximal Cope loop  was formed within the renal pelvis.  The catheter was anchored to the skin utilizing 2-0 Ethilon and attached to gravity drainage. Later, in the ARU, the tube was capped at the request of the referring urologist.   The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite  still asleep discharged into the care of anesthesiology for transfer to the PACU. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Liver transplant rejection; need for Plex therapy  Procedure:   1.	Non-tunneled large bore central venous catheter placement  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the large bore central venous catheter, as described, the tip terminates near cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a 14 French,  20 cm, non-tunneled large bore central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.  Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care. The catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. Local anesthesia was used for this procedure   The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic. Ultrasound evaluation of the vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS. Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS.  A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter. There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Patient with prostate cancer requiring IV chemotherapy  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen MedComp port (dignity)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen Medcomp power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed below.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 3-0 absorbable sutures. A running 4-0 absorbable subcuticular stitch and  Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with     Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). Procedure was performed with anesthesia. Please refer to anesthesia notes for details. The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 3-0 absorbable sutures. A running 4-0 absorbable subcuticular stitch and  Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with     Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Gallbladder mass with central biliary obstruction  Procedure:   1.	Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram 2.	Placement of percutaneous transhepatic internal/external biliary drain 3.	Gallbladder mass biopsy under ultrasound guidance   Findings:   1.	Occlusion of the common bile duct secondary to extrinsic compression from known mass.  Impression:   1. Technically successful percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography and drainage catheter placement. 2. Technically successful gallbladder mass biopsy under ultrasound guidance.    Plan:  1.	Open to bag drainage for 24 hours.  2.	Routine drain exchange in 8 weeks.  Technique:   The anterior abdominal wall and bilateral flanks were prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier.  An appropriate skin entry site was identified using fluoroscopy and ultrasound, and anesthetized with local.  Under fluoroscopic guidance, a 22G Chiba needle was advanced into the liver.  A bile duct was entered and the biliary system was opacified with contrast. Cholangiographic images were obtained.  Two-stick technique: A suitable duct for drain placement was then identified on the right. Under direct sonographic guidance, a right duct was accessed with a second 22 gauge Chiba needle.  A 0.018" wire was passed centrally, and the needle exchanged for a nonvascular access catheter. The inner stiffener, dilator, and 0.018" wire were removed and contrast was injected to confirm location.  A 0.035" glidewire and 4 French angled catheter were negotiated into the small bowel. The glidewire was removed and contrast was injected to confirm location. A 0.035" Amplatz wire was placed through the catheter, and the catheter subsequently removed.   Drain placement: Finally, an 10.2 French     internal-external biliary drain was placed over the wire. The anchor/loop was formed and locked. Attention was paid that side holes were positioned within the biliary system. Contrast was injected to confirm location. The catheter was secured to the skin with 2-0 suture material and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.  Contrast was injected through the existing biliary drainage catheter and cholangiographic images obtained.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition.  Biopsy: Under ultrasound guidance an introduced was advanced into the gallbladder mass. Via the introducer an 18G mission biopsy needle was advanced into the gallbladder mass and biopsy was obtained. Samples were sent in formalin. Gel foam tract embolization was performed via the introducer. The needle was removed and sterile dressing applied. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Metastatic disease of unknown primary with new bilateral hydronephrosis  Procedure:   1.	Left nephrostogram and nephrostomy tube placement      Findings:  Comparison is made to a previous exam dated [DATE] US.  1.	Ultrasound exam of the kidneys was performed demonstrating moderate left hydronephrosis. The right renal cortex was atrophic and poorly visualized. No right hydronephrosis was seen.  2.	Left antegrade nephrostogram was performed with moderate hydronephrosis and no passage of contrast urinary bladder. 3.	Nephrostomy tube appropriately positioned within the left renal pelvis.  Catheter(s):  8.5 F     nephrostomy tube  Impression:   1.	Uneventful ultrasound and fluroscopic-guided placement of a left nephrostomy tube as described above.      Treatment Plan:   Patient should return for [HOSPITAL]ine check and change in 8-12 weeks.        Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained to the patient. Written informed consent was obtained.  A time out/call to order was performed prior to procedure initiation.  The soft tissues overlying the access site were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Ultrasound was utilized to identify an appropriate access site. Static ultrasound image was obtained and stored to PACS for reference purposes. Subsequently, under fluoroscopic and real-time concurrent ultrasound guidance, access was obtained into a posterior, inferior calyx using a 21 ga needle and a triaxial sheath system (Neff). Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site. A wire was advanced centrally. Serial dilation was accomplished over the wire. The wire and inner dilator were removed. Non-ionic contrast was injected into the collecting system and images of the antegrade pyelogram were obtained and stored to PACS.  An 0.035” wire was advanced through the existing access. A nephrostomy tube was advanced over the wire and the Cope loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis. Contrast injection confirmed location. The catheter was sutured to the flank with monofilament suture and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.  The procedure was well tolerated, and patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  End-stage renal disease, difficult intravenous access  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled central venous catheter placement   Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the tunneled catheter, as described, the tip terminates near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a double lumen power-injectable, 5 Fr, 22 cm, tunneled non-cuffed central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.  Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care.  The catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed below.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a peel-away sheath set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture peel-away sheath set, the wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.  Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS.
