Embolization: No Vessel embolized: N/a Coils used: N/a  MAA delivery performed from:  - 50% posterior branch of the right hepatic artery (series 21 image 1) - 25% proximal branch of the left hepatic artery, supplying the caudate lobe (series 29 image 1) cbct 6036 - 25% posterior branch of the right hepatic artery (series 39 image 1)  Future target Y90 delivery catheter position(s): Same as where MAA was delivered.CBCT 6036 caudate (25%), CBCT 6066 seg7(50%), CBCT 6066 seg 4a (25%) Treatment device: SIRTEX Split-Dose: .yes Dosimetry Model: MIRD dosed to the right lobe/segment. Desired lobar/tumoral (if partition) dose: 80-150 (unless split) Gy Additional details:     5cm seg7 LR5 (mr se7im11)  1.8cm caudate LR5 (mr se7im17) CBCT 6036 1.5cm seg4a/8 LR5 (mr se7im10) CBCT 6066 2.5cm seg8 LR4 (mr se7im14) CBCT 1.1cm seg4a/8 LR4 (mr se20im22) CBCT   IMPRESSION:   Successful Yttrium-90 SIRsphere selective internal radiotherapy mapping.  TREATMENT PLAN:  1. Patient will return in 2-4 weeks for Y90 radioembolization. 2. Access site precautions and orders placed.  TECHNIQUE:  With the patient in the supine position, the left wrist was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The left wrist was evaluated with ultrasound and left radial artery patency and acceptable size criteria were documented and images were properly stored in PACS. A modified Allen test (Barbeau test B) was performed on the left wrist to confirm patency of the ulnopalmar arch using pulse oximetry.   1% lidocaine solution was administered for local anesthesia. Access was obtained to the left radial artery using a 21 gauge micro needle and ultrasound guidance. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. A wire was placed through the needle. A hydrophilic Glidesheath was advanced slowly over the wire. 3000 units of heparin, 200 mcg of nitroglycerin and 2.5 mg of verapamil was given through the arterial sheath with slow hemodilution. A side flush was started.   A 5-Fr [HCW]/[HCW] catheter was advanced over an 0.035" wire into the abdominal aorta. The catheter was used to catheterize the visceral vessels described below. Angiograms were performed. A microcatheter system was used to catheterize distal visceral and hepatic vessels, as described below. Specific vessels catheterized and embolized are described in detail below. Tumor blush was confirmed on angiography.  Cone Beam CT (CBCT) was performed intraprocedurally for purposes of treatment planning, targeting and dose calculation. Axial and coronal images were created and 3D reconstruction was performed on a separate dedicated workstation under concurrent supervision.  After confirmation of target treatment vessel, 5 mCi of Tc-99 MAA was injected slowly in this location though the catheter.   All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. A TR Band was placed on the left wrist for hemostasis. The access sheath was removed and no hematoma was seen. A radial artery pulse was confirmed distal to the puncture site confirming patent hemostasis.   The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. The patient was transferred to the Nuclear Medicine department for imaging. After confirmation of target treatment vessel, 5 mCi of Tc-99 MAA was injected slowly in this location though the catheter.   All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. A TR Band was placed on the left wrist for hemostasis. The access sheath was removed and no hematoma was seen. A radial artery pulse was confirmed distal to the puncture site confirming patent hemostasis.   The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. The patient was transferred to the Nuclear Medicine department for imaging. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled central venous catheter placement       Findings:   1.	The left internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the tunneled catheter, as described, the tip terminates near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a power-injectable, 5 Fr, 33 cm, tunneled non-cuffed central venous catheter via the left internal jugular vein.       Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care.  The catheter is ready for immediate use.        Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed below.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the left internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the left internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the left internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a peel-away sheath set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture peel-away sheath set, the wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.  Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  [ID]C[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  HCC. Prior treatments with Y90 and microwave ablation. Persistent nodular residual disease on most recent MRI.  PROCEDURE:   1. US-guided right femoral artery access. 2. Diagnostic visceral angiography. 3. Transarterial chemoembolization segment 7 and segment 8 branches. 4. Transarterial bland embolization of the right phrenic artery. 5. Right common femoral artery angiogram and closure.  Cone-beam CT performed for intraprocedural localization, as detailed below.  FINDINGS: ANGIOGRAPHY: Vessels catheterized and angiograms performed, as follows:  Celiac artery: Conventional anatomy. Right hepatic artery: Extensive tumoral blush identified.  Posterior branch right hepatic artery: Tumoral blush identified. Anterior branch right hepatic artery: Tumoral blush identified.  Right phrenic artery: Vascular supply to the region of the previously treated tumor, without definite tumor blush.  Specific technical notes / catheter selection: 5 French sheath SOS2 catheter 2.4 Progreat microcatheter Fathom microwire  CBCT: Yes Catheter location: Right hepatic artery Findings: Tumoral blush identified with supply from the multiple branches of the anterior and posterior division.   Transcatheter embolization:  Tumor location: Segment 7/8  Embolic 1: Conventional TACE (50 mg doxorubicin in 5 mL contrast mixed 1:1 with lipiodol) for 10 mL total solution. Embolic 2: 2 vials 100-300 Embospheres  Phrenic artery embolization: Additional bland embolization of the right phrenic artery to substasis with 100-300 um embospheres.  IMPRESSION:   1. MAA shunt study aborted due to unfavorable multivascular supply to the tumor.  2. Successful conventional-TACE treatment of the segment 7/8 hepatocellular carcinoma.  3. Additional bland embolization to the right phrenic artery.  TREATMENT PLAN:  1. [HCW]t will return to clinic in 6-8 weeks with abdominal MRI and labs.  2. Access site precautions and orders placed.  TECHNIQUE:  With the patient in the supine position, the groin was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The patient was placed on the table in a supine position. Following standard prepping and draping, the common femoral artery was punctured using a needle, and an .035 Bentson wire was advanced into the aorta. A 5-French vascular sheath was placed over the wire into the common femoral artery. A side flush was started.  A 5-Fr SOS2 catheter was advanced over an 0.035" Bentson wire into the abdominal aorta. The catheter was used to catheterize the celiac artery. Angiograms and cone beam CT were performed and demonstrated multifocal vascular supply to the large segment 7/8 tumor, rendering the patient in unfavorable candidate. Additionally, cone beam CT showed favorable response to conventional chemotherapy performed along the superior margins of the tumor.   After conversation with the patient and his family, the decision was made to abandon MAA shunt study and pursue conventional TACE treatment. Consent was obtained from the patient's daughter, and doxorubicin was ordered from the pharmacy.  The above microwire/microcatheter system was used to catheterize distal the anterior and posterior divisions of the right hepatic artery, and chemoembolization was performed as detailed above. Follow-up contrasted and noncontrasted cone beam CTs confirmed successful treatment of the viable tumor, with minimal embolization of the normal hepatic parenchyma.  Attention was then turned to the phrenic artery, which previously demonstrated vascular supply to the superior aspects of the tumor. Phrenic artery was catheterized using a Mickelson. Repeat angiography today demonstrated vascular supply approaching the tumor, without definite tumoral blush. The decision was made to treat with bland embolization as detailed above.   A right common femoral artery angiogram was performed, demonstrating appropriate vascular access above the profunda femoris artery bifurcation. All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. Hemostasis was achieved using Perclose vascular closure device. The site was dressed in usual fashion.  The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  55 year-old female with untreated HCV and HPV-related Stage I cT2 N1 M0 SCC of the right palatine tonsil and ipsilateral lymph nodes in levels II-IV  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen Bard port (standard profile)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen Bard power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).   The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 2-0 absorbable sutures. A running 4-0 absorbable subcuticular stitch and  Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with a single subcuticular stitch and Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM AND ENDOVASCULAR PIPELINE EMBOLIZATION OF A RIGHT SUPERIOR HYPOPHYSEAL ARTERY ANEURYSM  CLINICAL INDICATION: 49-year-old female with a past medical history of tobacco use, hypertension, dyslipidemia who presented to [HOSPITAL] in [DATE] with high grade subarachnoid hemorrhage secondary to a ruptured basilar tip aneurysm for which he underwent WEB embolization. She is also noted to have unruptured right pericallosal artery aneurysm and superior hypophyseal artery aneurysm. She made a remarkable recovery following her subarachnoid hemorrhage. Given her young age, good health, and history of ruptured aneurysm, treatment of her other aneurysms was indicated. She underwent craniotomy and clip ligation of the pericallosal aneurysm [DATE] this past year. She returns today for pipeline embolization of the right superior hypophyseal artery aneurysm.  PROCEDURE:  1.	Cerebral angiogram  2.	Endovascular pipeline embolization   DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 2 hours.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] was the fellow. [HCW], PhD was the resident. Each actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS CATHETERIZED: Right internal carotid artery Right middle cerebral artery Left vertebral artery Left internal carotid artery  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right common femoral artery Right internal carotid artery Left vertebral artery Left internal carotid artery  VESSELS TREATED (in sequence): Right internal carotid  ANESTHESIA: General endotracheal anesthesia. Pre-, intra-, and post-anesthesia monitoring records are available in the chart.  MEDICATIONS:  Heparin 5000 units IV Ancef 2 grams IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 8 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 0.035" Bentson Guidewire 0.035" Terumo Glidewire (180 cm) 6 French 65 cm arrow  5 French Merit Performa Vertebral catheter 058 Navien guide catheter (115 cm) Phenom 27 microcatheter (150 cm) Asahi 018 microguidewire (200 cm) 3.25 mm x 12 mm pipeline embolization device 6 French Angio-Seal closure device Omnipaque-300 contrast (120 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, stent thrombosis/stenosis, stent migration, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, non-target embolization, puncture site hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed, written consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite, intubated, and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery. Through the dilator sheath, an angiogram of the of the right common femoral artery was obtained to ensure the arteriotomy was above the level of the bifurcation and the CFA was of sufficient size to use the 6 French Angio-Seal closure device. 6 French 65 cm arrow sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery, and under fluoroscopic guidance was advanced into the proximal descending aorta over the Bentson wire. 5000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement; additional boluses of heparin were administered at one-hour intervals. The ACT was checked to ensure that it was between 250-300.   The diagnostic catheter was used to select the right carotid artery. A roadmap angiogram right carotid artery was performed. The diagnostic catheter was advanced over the Terumo Glidewire into the right internal carotid artery. The arrow sheath was advanced over the diagnostic catheter into the right common carotid artery. Digital angiograms were performed centered over the head in the AP and lateral projections.  3D rotational angiography was performed with the selection catheter in the mid cervical segment of the right internal carotid artery to better delineate the right superior hypophyseal artery aneurysm and anatomy of the right intracranial ICA. The acquisition was processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.   The diagnostic catheter was removed from the arrow sheath and the 058 Navien guide catheter was advanced over the Terumo Glidewire into the distal cervical segment of the right internal carotid artery using roadmap angiogram fluoroscopic guidance. The Glidewire was withdrawn.   A working projection was obtained to best demonstrate the neck of the superior hypophyseal artery aneurysm, as well as, the distal and proximal landing zones for the stent. Superselective catheterization of the right middle cerebral artery was performed with the Phenom 27 microcatheter over the Asahi 18 microguidewire. The tip of the microguidewire was situated in the distal M1/proximal M2 of the right MCA. The microguidewire in the pipeline catheter was then exchanged for a 3.25 mm x 12 mm pipeline embolization device. The device was deployed under fluoroscopic guidance and a single shot X-ray was performed to confirm that the distal and proximal ends of the pipeline embolization device were in the right ICA communicating segment and right ICA cavernous segment, respectively. There was good apposition of the device along its entire course and therefore postprocessing of the pipeline embolization device was not required.  A final AP and Lateral angiogram were completed to evaluate the distal vasculature for perfusion deficits and emboli.   Using fluoroscopic guidance,  the additional arteries  listed above were selectively catheterized. Digital angiograms were performed in the AP and lateral projections centered over the head and neck.   After completion of the procedure, the sheath was removed and hemostasis obtained using the 6 French Angio-Seal closure device. A Tegaderm were then applied over the puncture site.  COMPARISON: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram from outside institution from [DATE] of this past year.  FINDINGS: RIGHT COMMON FEMORAL ARTERY: Mild focal spasm of the proximal deep femoral artery related to access. The arteriotomy was above the level of the bifurcation and the CFA was of sufficient size to use the 6 French Angio-Seal closure device.   RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  There is a medially directed superior hypophyseal artery aneurysm, the dimensions of which are described on the 3-D angiography discussed below. Measurements of the ICA diameter were taken in very from 3.2 mm in the distal ophthalmic/proximal communicating segment to 2.8 mm in the cavernous segment. There is mild catheterization related vasospasm of the distal cervical ICA. The right middle meningeal artery originates from the distal cervical ICA.  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-PIPELINE EMBOLIZATION): The Pipeline device is well apposed to the vessel walls throughout it's course without endoleak. . Stasis of contrast is noted within the aneurysm. . Once again there is noted to be mild to moderate catheter related spasm of the right ICA without flow limitation. No perfusion deficits to suggest distal emboli are present.  LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is a WEB device seen in the expected location. There is no filling of the previously seen basilar apex aneurysm. Reflux of contrast into the  contralateral vertebral artery was achieved. The origin of PICA is normal bilaterally.   LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There are aneurysm clips seen in the expected location. There is no evidence of ongoing filling from the previously treated pericallosal aneurysm. No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified.     3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY: A 3D rotational angiogram of the  right internal carotid artery was completed and post-processed on an independent work station. 3D angiography revealed a superior hypophyseal artery aneurysm which measures 3.0 x 2.8 x 2.6 x 2.3 mm (axial by axial by neck-to-dome by neck). The internal carotid artery from the distal ophthalmic segment to the mid cavernous segment measures from 3.1 to 3.4 mm in diameter.    COMPLICATIONS: none immediate.  IMPRESSION:  1.	Successful placement of pipeline embolization device in the right ICA for treatment of unruptured superior hypophyseal artery aneurysm. 2.	Mild iatrogenic catheter related vasospasm of the right ICA stenosis 3.	No evidence of residual or recurrent basilar apex aneurysm or left pericallosal aneurysm. 4.	Independent origin of the right subclavian artery, remote from the origin of the right common carotid artery. Common origin of the right and left common carotid arteries, which did not require reverse curve catheter for catheterization.

DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: This is a 40 years Female with past medical history of heart failure, lupus, hypertension, COPD, with an incidental ACA aneurysm, status post balloon assisted coil embolization [DATE]. She now presents for follow-up diagnostic cerebral angiography.    PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 30 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] was the fellow.   VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: None  ANESTHESIA: Local in the right groin with bupivacaine. Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by the nurse present during the entire procedure. The patient returned to baseline mental status prior to trans[HCW] from the department. Sedation was administered by a specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for the duration of the procedure as outlined above (Total intra service time, 30 min ). Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.  MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine SQ 25 cc  Fentanyl 25 mcg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.038" Bentson guidewire 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 5 French Simmons 3 Glide catheter   TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. We attempted to gain access to the right common femoral artery using ultrasound but were unable to despite several attempts. We did cannulate the common femoral vein using the microcatheter dilator, then removed the microcatheter dilator and held manual pressure for 10 minutes until adequate hemostasis was achieved. We then discussed with the patient different options done to proceed. Given the result of the aneurysm coiling during her treatment angiogram, we recommended that the patient first obtained an MRA time-of-flight time resolved. If that MRA were to show concern for recurrence, we could bring the patient back on a different date and attempt a transradial approach. The patient was agreeable to this plan and we aborted the procedure.  COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: 1. Aborted diagnostic cerebral angiogram due to difficulty obtaining access into the right common femoral artery which was limited by body habitus. Plan to obtain MRA time-of-flight time resolved in the meantime and consider a radial approach in the future. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Acute cholecystitis with cholecystostomy drain. No output from the drain.  Procedure:   1.	Fluoroscopic guided cholecystogram and cholecystostomy drain replacement  Findings:   1.	 Collapsed gallbladder body with filling of the proximal cystic duct there is no passage into the central cystic duct and into the common bile duct consistent with cystic duct occlusion. Perihepatic ascites.  Impression:   1.	 Technically successful image guided cholecystogram and replacement of cholecystostomy drain  Treatment Plan:   1. Drain to gravity drainage bag. Given collapsed gallbladder cavity, drainage may be minimal. Given perihepatic ascites, there may be leaking from around the drain skin site.  Technique:    The patient was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. The skin and underlying soft tissue was an exercise with 1% lidocaine. Contrast was injected through the existing cholecystostomy drain for a cholecystogram. An Amplatz wire was advanced through the existing drain and looped within the caudal gallbladder body. Upon removal of the existing drain over the guidewire, there was retraction of the tip of the Amplatz wire. An angled catheter was advanced over the wire, however the wire could not be removed through the catheter. The catheter and guidewire were removed together.   Using an angled catheter and Glidewire, the hepatic tract was catheterized and catheter advanced over the guidewire into the gallbladder body. Contrast was injected to confirm a stable position. Different guidewires (Amplatz) were used, however could not be adequately looped within the gallbladder body to advance a multipurpose drainage catheter. A Rosen guidewire was advanced into the gallbladder body, over which, an 8 French anchor drain ([VENDOR]cot) was advanced. The anchor drain was locked within the gallbladder body and connected to gravity drainage bag and sutured to the skin with 2-0 Prolene suture. Contrast injection demonstrated appropriate positioning.   The patient tolerated the procedure without immediate consultation. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  History A-fib on Xarelto, on CPAP for sleep apnea, s/p EVAR [DATE], and subsequent endoleak repair [DATE]. CTA [DATE] with possible endoleak.   PROCEDURE:   1. US-guided right common femoral artery access. 2. Pelvic angiography 3. Right common femoral artery angiogram and closure  FINDINGS: ANGIOGRAPHY: Vessels catheterized using base catheter and microcatheter/microwire combination and angiograms performed: Sheath Passport/Destino Steerable 6.5fr/ C2 5f 100cm, 5f Ang 100cm, Vanschie3 5fr .038in 125cm   Abdominal aorta: No feeding vessels identified. Right internal iliac artery: No active hemorrhage. The iliolumbar branch appears to be an inflow to the aneurysmal sac  Transcatheter embolization: None  IMPRESSION:   1.	Tortuous/ectactic right internal and external iliac vessels 2.	Type ll endo leak with feeding arterial vessels from right iliolumbar branch vessels 3.	No embolization was performed. Unable to catheterize the feeding iliolumbar vessel due to tortuous anatomy.  TREATMENT PLAN:  1.	Will plan for repeat attempt with radial approach and general anesthesia 2.  Routine post-angiography groin cares ordered.  TECHNIQUE: With the patient in the supine position, the groin was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. Following standard prepping and draping, the right common femoral artery was punctured using a needle. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. An 0.035" wire was advanced into the aorta. A Destino steerable vascular sheath was placed over the wire into the common femoral artery. A side flush was started.  A 5-Fr pigtail catheter was advanced over an 0.035" wire into the abdominal aorta and aortogram was performed. A 0.035'' glidewire and angle glide cath combination were navigated up and over the aortic stent into the ipsilateral internal iliac artery. Angiograms were performed and feeding vessel (right iliolumbar) to the aneurysmal sac was identified. Multiple catheter combination attempts to select the iliolumbar feeding vessel was unsuccessful due to tortuous anatomy.  A right common femoral artery angiogram was performed, demonstrating appropriate vascular access above the profunda femoris artery bifurcation. All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. Hemostasis was achieved using vascular closure device. The site was dressed in usual fashion.  The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. Double lumen PICC placement using ultrasound and fluoroscopy      Findings:   1.  Vein patency was documented by ultrasound and stored to PACS. 2.  The catheter tip terminates near the cavoatrial junction.        Impression:   1.	Uneventful image guided placement of 5 French, 54 cm double-lumen PICC in the left upper extremity as described. The lumens flush and aspirate appropriately.        Treatment Plan:   Catheter tip position is confirmed as above. It is OK to use this line.       Technique:   The site was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).   Ultrasound evaluation of the left basilic vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS. Local anesthetic was used over the access site. Under ultrasound guidance, the left basilic vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS.    A 0.018" wire was passed centrally and the needle exchanged for a dilator peel-away combination. The wire was used to determine catheter length, and a 5 French double-lumen PICC line cut to appropriate length. The tailored catheter was advanced through the peel-away and positioned centrally using fluoroscopy.   The peel-away was removed, and hemostasis achieved with manual compression. The catheter was aspirated, flushed, and locked per protocol. It was secured in place with Ethilon.  An antimicrobial disc and sterile dressing were applied.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].IR.1  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  41 y.o. female with Metastatic breast cancer to the bones, lungs, and liver s/p bilateral mastectomy in 2016. She has received several lines of chemotherapy most recently Xeloda until [DATE]. She also received radiation to the skull from [DATE] to [DATE]. She had a restaging CT on [DATE] which showed progression of metastatic disease in the liver. She will be started on Taxol tomorrow (3 weeks on, 1 week off). She is referred to IR to discuss liver directed therapy.   Additional Clinical Information: Metastatic Breast cancer to the liver.  PROCEDURE:   1. US-guided left radial artery access 2. Diagnostic visceral angiography 3. Selective internal radioembolization with Yttrium-90 4. Cone-beam CT performed for intraprocedural localization, as detailed below.  FINDINGS: ANGIOGRAPHY: Vessels catheterized and angiograms performed, as follows:  Celiac artery: Tumoral blush identified. Left hepatic artery: Tumoral blush identified.  Specific technical notes / catheter selection: Sarah catheter, 2.8 progreat  CBCT: Yes Catheter location: Left hepatic artery Findings: Tumoral blush identified with supply from the target vessel.  Transcatheter embolization using Yttrium-90 microspheres performed from: Left hepatic artery (series 8, image 7)  IMPRESSION:   Successful Yttrium-90 Sirspheres selective internal radiotherapy of the left hepatic lobe.  TREATMENT PLAN:  1. Patient will return to clinic in 6-8 weeks with abdominal MRI and labs.  2. Access site precautions and orders placed.  TECHNIQUE:  With the patient in the supine position, the left wrist was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The left wrist was evaluated with ultrasound and left radial artery patency and acceptable size criteria were documented and images were properly stored in PACS. [HCW]d Allen test (Barbeau test B) was performed on the left wrist to confirm patency of the ulnopalmar arch using pulse oximetry.   1% lidocaine solution was administered for local anesthesia. Access was obtained to the left radial artery using a 21 gauge micro needle and ultrasound guidance. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. A wire was placed through the needle. A hydrophilic Glidesheath was advanced slowly over the wire. 3000 units of heparin, 200 mcg of nitroglycerin and 2.5 mg of verapamil was given through the arterial sheath with slow hemodilution. A side flush was started.   A 5-Fr [VENDOR]y/[HCW][VENDOR] catheter was advanced over an 0.035" wire into the abdominal aorta. The catheter was used to catheterize the visceral vessels described below. Angiograms were performed. A microcatheter system was used to catheterize distal visceral and hepatic vessels, as described below. Specific vessels catheterized and embolized are described in detail below. Tumor blush was confirmed on angiography.  Cone Beam CT (CBCT) was performed intraprocedurally for purposes of treatment planning, targeting and dose calculation. Axial and coronal images were created and 3D reconstruction was performed on a separate dedicated workstation under concurrent supervision.  Once the catheter was in adequate position, a pre-determined dose of 90-Yttrium radioactive particles was infused into the target hepatic artery. The microcatheter was flushed and the microcatheter was disposed of appropriately.   All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. A TR Band was placed on the left wrist for hemostasis. The access sheath was removed and no hematoma was seen. A radial artery pulse was confirmed distal to the puncture site confirming patent hemostasis.   The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications.   Additional Medications: Benadryl 50 mg IV, Decadron 8 mg IV, Zofran 4 mg IV. Ultrasound demonstrate abnormally appearing tissue deep to the left trapezius muscle corresponding to Veno-lymphatic malformation seen on most recent MRI of [DATE].  2.	Image-guided needle localization within the malformation with contrast injection demonstrating no clear vascular channel. 3.	Injection of a total of 15 units bleomycin administered half in foam. Impression:  Image-guided bleomycin embolization of a left neck/shoulder veno lymphatic malformation   Lifetime dose bleomycin: 15 units  Treatment Plan:   Follow up bleomycin embolization and 6-8 weeks  Technique:   The patient was transported to the interventional suite and placed in the supine position. The left neck, shoulder, and upper arm were prepped and draped utilizing maximum sterile barrier technique. A call to order was performed as detailed below.  A scout radiograph of the left chest was obtained. Survey ultrasound of the soft tissues of the left neck and shoulder was done. The area of abnormal echogenicity was identified within the left neck and deep to the left trapezius muscle. Multiple attempts were made at intravascular cannulation however injection of contrast did not show much in the way of venous channels.  Following this, 21-gauge Chiba needle was advanced into the targeted region under sonographic guidance. 7.5 units of diluted bleomycin was administered followed by 7.5 units of foamed Bleomycin with Albumin and AIr. A total of 4 cc of foam was administered and 4 cc of straight bleomycin  All needles were removed from the patient and hemostasis obtained with manual compression. Access sites were not covered  The procedure was well-tolerated and the patient left the IR suite in satisfactory/stable condition. CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM AND ENDOVASCULAR PIPELINE EMBOLIZATION OF A RIGHT PICA ANEURYSM  CLINICAL INDICATION: 44-year-old female who is found to have a ruptured right PICA aneurysm.  PROCEDURE:  1.	Cerebral angiogram  2.	Endovascular pipeline embolization  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 2 hours.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] was the fellow. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS CATHETERIZED: Right vertebral artery Right posterior inferior cerebellar artery  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right vertebral artery  VESSELS TREATED (in sequence): Right PICA  ANESTHESIA: General endotracheal anesthesia. Pre-, intra-, and post-anesthesia monitoring records are available in the chart.  MEDICATIONS:  Nitropaste Heparin 5500 units (1000 units intra-arterial into the right radial artery, and 4500 units IV) Nitroglycerin 200 mcg IA into the right radial artery Verapamil 2.5 mg IA into the right radial artery   MATERIALS:  6 French Terumo slender sheath, long (25 cm) 0.035" Terumo Glidewire (180 cm) 5 French Sofia guide catheter (115 cm) 058 Navien guide catheter (105 cm) Phenom 21 microcatheter (150 cm) Asahi 014 microguidewire Transcend-EX microguidewire  Traxcess microguidewire  Aristotle 18 microguidewire (200 cm) 2.5 mm x extending mm pipeline vantage embolization device TR band Omnipaque-300 contrast (120 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, stent thrombosis/stenosis, stent migration, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, non-target embolization, puncture site hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed, written consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite, intubated, and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. A small amount of Nitropaste was placed over the distal radial artery at the wrist. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right radial artery. A long (25 cm) 6 French Terumo slender sheath was introduced into the right radial artery. A radial cocktail of 1000 units of heparin, 200 mcg of nitroglycerin, and 2.5 mg of verapamil was administered intra-arterially into the right radial artery via the sheath. An additional 4000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. A CTs were monitored and additional heparin boluses were given as necessary to maintain an ACT between 250-300  Using fluoroscopic and roadmap guidance, a 5 French Sofia guide catheter was advanced over the Terumo Glidewire into the distal V2 segment of the right vertebral artery. The Terumo Glidewire was removed and the phenom 21 was advanced through the Sofia catheter over the 014 Asahi microguidewire. As we attempted to maneuver the microguidewire and microcatheter around the V3 segment of the right vertebral artery the Sofia catheter continually herniated into the subclavian artery. After several attempts of advancing the system more distally we decided to abandon the Sofia guide catheter in favor of an 058 Navien. Using fluoroscopic and roadmap guidance were able to readily advance the 058 Navien catheter into the distal V3 segment of the right vertebral artery over the Terumo Glidewire. Digital angiograms were performed in the AP and lateral projections centered over the head and neck.   Using the 3-D rotational angiogram in the day prior, we were able to able to select appropriate working projections for placement of the pipeline embolization device.  There phenom 21 microcatheter and Asahi 014 microguidewire were advanced coaxially through the 058 Navien catheter. There was noted that it was difficult to report the microguidewire. However with reshaping microguidewire we were able to advance the microguidewire into the proximal PICA followed by the microcatheter. However despite multiple attempts in the shaping the wire were unable to navigate the wire passed the aneurysm. We tried multiple different shapes and different microguidewire as (as listed above). Ultimately we were able to navigate beyond the aneurysm using a steam-shaped phenom 21 microcatheter as well as and Aristotle 18 microguidewire.  The microguidewire in the phenom catheter was then exchanged for a 2.5 mm x 16 mm pipeline embolization device. The device was deployed under fluoroscopic guidance and a single shot X-ray was performed to confirm that the distal and proximal ends of the pipeline embolization device were opened appropriately, that the device was well apposed to the artery, covered the aneurysm, and that the proximal end of the device remain within the PICA.. Postprocessing of the pipeline embolization device not needed.  A final AP and Lateral angiogram were completed to evaluate the distal vasculature for perfusion deficits and emboli.   After completion of the procedure, the sheath was removed and hemostasis obtained using the TR band.   COMPARISON: Diagnostic angiogram dated [DATE].  FINDINGS:  RIGHT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: Grossly unchanged lobulated and irregular aneurysm of the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery.   RIGHT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-PIPELINE EMBOLIZATION): The Pipeline device is well apposed to the vessel walls throughout it's course without endoleak. . Stasis of contrast is noted within the aneurysm. . No perfusion deficits to suggest distal emboli are present.   COMPLICATIONS: none immediate.  IMPRESSION:  1.	Grossly unchanged irregular and lobulated right PICA aneurysm 2.	Successful placement of pipeline vantage embolization device within the first and second segments of the right PICA for treatment of the above aneurysm with resulting contrast stagnation within the aneurysm following deployment of pipeline device.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL][ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Recurrent colon cancer   Procedure: Right internal jugular single lumen power port placement with imaging   Findings:  The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses.  Needle entry was stored to PACS.  The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating in the right atrium.   A healed scar is present on the right from a previous port.   Impression:   Uneventful image guided placement of right internal jugular  power port catheter as described.    Technique:  The right neck and chest wall region was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Using local anesthetic and ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein vein was punctured with a 21 gauge needle. A PACS image was stored.  A 0.018" wire was passed centrally and the needle exchanged for a 5 French transitional dilator. The smaller wire was exchanged for a 0.035" Amplatz wire.  A  peel-away sheath was placed at the venotomy.  The soft tissues caudal and lateral to the sheath entry site were anesthetized with lidocaine with epinephrine. A #15 blade was used to incise the skin.  Blunt and sharp dissection were used to create a subcutaneous pocket.  The pocket was irrigated with antibiotic solution.  A tunneling tool was brought from the pocket to the venotomy. The catheter was brought through the tunnel.  During suspended respiration, the catheter was advanced through the peel-away and positioned centrally using fluoroscopy. The peel-away sheath was removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression. The catheter was flushed, cut to length and attached to the port reservoir. The reservoir was aspirated, flushed, and locked with TPA (heparin allergy).  It was sutured into the pocket using a single 2-0 Ethilon suture.  The pocket was closed using 3-0 deep interrupted absorbable Vicryl suture, 4-0 running subcuticular absorbable Vicryl suture and Dermabond..  The venotomy was closed with Dermabond. A sterile dressing was applied. The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL][ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Postpartum hemorrhage  PROCEDURE:   1.	Ultrasound-guided right common femoral artery access  2.	Pelvic angiography 3.	Uterine artery embolization  with Gelfoam for post partum bleeding 4.	Post-embolization angiography and Starclose Closure  Findings:  Vessels catheterized and angiograms performed as detailed below:  Infrarenal abdominal aortogram: Internal iliac artery origins identified bilaterally. No active extravasation identified.  Right internal iliac artery: Uterine artery origin identified. No active extravasation identified. Right uterine artery: Prominent uterine arterial branches. No active extravasation identified.  Left internal iliac artery: Uterine artery origin identified. No active extravasation identified. Left uterine artery: Prominent uterine arterial branches. No active extravasation identified.  Embolization: Right uterine: 1. 5ml thin gelfoam slurry 2. 10ml thick gelfoam slurry  Left uterine: 1. 5ml thin gelfoam slurry 2. 10ml thick gelfoam slurry 3. 10mL 2.5mm EmboCube  Intra-arterial medication administration: 400 mcg nitroglycerin to right uterine artery. 100 mcg nitroglycerin to left uterine artery.  Post-Embolization Angiograms: Right uterine artery: Near stasis. Left uterine artery: Near stasis.  Impression:  No active extravasation seen within the pelvis. Abnormal appearing uterine artery is consistent with recent C-section.  Successful bilateral uterine artery embolization, using Gelfoam.  Treatment Plan: 1. Routine access site post-procedural cares ordered. 2. Continued monitoring and resuscitation in the intensive care unit.  Technique: With the patient in the supine position, the right groin was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The patient was placed on the table in a supine position. Following standard prepping and draping, the right common femoral artery was punctured using a needle. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. An 0.035" wire was advanced into the aorta. A vascular sheath was placed over the wire into the common femoral artery. A right common femoral artery angiogram was performed, demonstrating appropriate vascular access above the profunda femoris artery bifurcation. A side flush was started.  Diagnostic catheter and microcatheter were advanced through the sheath into the aorta and used to catheterize the bilateral internal iliac arteries and pelvic vessels described above. Angiograms were performed. Specific vessels catheterized and embolized are described in detail above. The Jada balloon was deflated by 100 mL before embolization. Intra-arterial nitroglycerin was administered to allow for complete embolization. Post-embolization angiography was performed and described above.  All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. Hemostasis was achieved using StarClose. The site was dressed in usual fashion.  The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).    The skin and subcutaneous tissues overlying the vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  The pre-existing nontunneled large bore central venous catheter appears in appropriate position. A 0.035 inch Amplatz wire was advanced through the existing catheter and into the inferior vena cava.  Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the dialysis catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The pre-existing nontunneled large bore catheter was then removed over the wire, and a peel-away sheath was introduced over the wire.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue and absorbable suture.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Leukemia  Procedure:  1. Ultrasound and Fluoroscopic guided placement of a tunneled, cuffed central venous catheter  Findings:  1. The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and normal. Vein patency and needle entry were stored to PACS. 2. The newly placed catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating in the right atrium.  Impression:   Uneventful image guided placement of right internal jugular vein tunneled Trifusion catheter as described.  Technique:  The right neck and chest region was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. The region was ultrasonographically evaluated.  Using local anesthetic and ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was punctured with a 21 gauge needle.  An image documenting vein patency and needle entry was saved and stored to PACS.   A 0.018” wire was passed centrally and the needle exchanged for a 5 French transitional dilator. A 0.035” wire was advanced through the dilator and negotiated into the IVC.  The skin tract was dilated and a 13 French dilator peel-away combination placed over the wire.  The soft tissues caudal and lateral to the sheath entry site were anesthetized with lidocaine with epinephrine. A dermatotomy was made and a tunneling tool brought from the dermatotomy to the venotomy. The catheter was brought through the tunnel.  During suspended respiration, the catheter was advanced through the peel-away and positioned centrally using fluoroscopy. The peel-away was removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression.  The venotomy was closed with Dermabond and Steri-Strips applied. A single Prolene suture was placed at the catheter tunnel exit site. An antimicrobial disc and sterile dressing were applied.  The catheter was aspirated, flushed, and heparinized per protocol. The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient was discharged in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  ESRD with SVC occlusion transferred in after an outside dialysis center removed her right jugular cuffed dialysis catheter. She has not been dialyzed since [DATE]. History is also significant for known IVC occlusion. The IVC appears calcified below the renal veins on prior CT. She has a history of transhepatic catheter in the past and a hostile abdomen with enterocutaneous fistula.   Procedure: 1. Removal of a tunneled single lumen smallbore central venous catheter from the right jugular vein 2. Placement of a temporary trialysis catheter via cut down at the apex of the tunneled catheter  Findings: Multiple prior images were reviewed  1.	 Scout shows an endotracheal tube at thoracic inlet. A CO2 probe projects in the expected location of the mid to distal esophagus. Monitor leads are in place. 2.	A right jugular tunneled non-cuffed central venous catheter has its tip in the right atrium. 3.	The newly placed 14 French 20 cm triple-lumen dialysis catheter has its tip in the right atrium. 2 cm were sewn outside the venotomy. 4.	A self-expanding metal stent projects in the right axillary region. 5.	Multiple surgical clips are present in the abdomen. There is calcification along the expected location of the liver margin on the right. 6.	Calcification is noted in the splenic artery.  Impression:    Difficult but successful placement of a right jugular temporary dialysis catheter via the existing venotomy in the right jugular vein.  Cutdown was performed at the apex of the smallbore catheter, allowing central access and dialysis catheter placement.  Treatment Plan:   This will need to be converted back to a tunneled catheter once the infection has resolved.  More extensive SVC venography and reconstruction could be performed at that same time.  Technique:  The right neck and existing tunneled smallbore catheter and surrounding soft tissues were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  A stiff Glidewire was placed through the existing single-lumen tunneled catheter and negotiated through the right heart and supra renal IVC into the left renal vein. The catheter was removed over the wire and discarded. A 65 cm 5 French catheter was advanced over the stiff glide and attention redirected to cut down.   Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter apex. A #15 blade was used to incise the skin. Blunt and sharp dissection were performed and the catheter was identified and dissected free. The stiff glide was replaced with a regular Glidewire. The hub was removed from the angled catheter and the extravascular fragment delivered at the venotomy. The glide was exchanged for an Amplatz.  The venotomy was serially dilated. Finally, a 13 French dialysis catheter was advanced over the Amplatz and positioned centrally using fluoroscopy. The Amplatz was removed and all 3 lumens were tested. The catheter was sutured in place with 2-0 Ethilon. The cutdown was closed with a single subcuticular absorbable 3-0 Vicryl suture and Dermabond. A sterile dressing was applied.  The procedure was well-tolerated, and the patient was discharged into the care of anesthesiology for transfer to the PACU. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam: [DATE]       Clinical Indication:  Lung cancer in need of access for chemotherapy  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen Bard port (standard profile)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen Bard power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 2-0 absorbable sutures. A running 4-0 absorbable subcuticular stitch and  Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with a single subcuticular stitch and Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]C.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Abnormal Uterine Bleeding. UFE for bridge to hysterectomy.   PROCEDURE:   1.	Ultrasound-guided left radial artery access 2.	Pelvic angiography 3.	Uterine artery embolization 4.	Post-embolization angiography  Findings:  Vessels catheterized and angiograms performed as detailed below:  Right internal iliac artery: Markedly enlarged uterine artery with a myomatous uterus identified. Right uterine artery: Fibroid blush identified. No cervical branches.   Left internal iliac artery: Markedly enlarged uterine artery with a myomatous uterus identified. Left uterine artery: Fibroid blush identified. No cervical branches.  Embolization:  Right uterine: 1 vials 5-700 u EmboSpheres  Left uterine: 2 vials 5-700 u EmboSpheres  Intra-arterial medication administration: Lidocaine 10mg given bilaterally (20 mg total)  Hypogastric Nerve Block: N/a  Post-Embolization Angiograms: Right uterine artery: Sluggish flow without opacification of the uterine fibroids. Left uterine artery: Sluggish flow without opacification of the uterine fibroids.  Technical notes: 5 French slender sheath MPA catheter 125 cm Bentson wire 2.4 Progreat microcatheter Fathom microwire  Impression:  1. Enlarged uterine branches bilaterally with a leiomyomatous uterus, status post successful bilateral uterine artery embolization.  Treatment Plan:  1. The patient will remain admitted and monitored closely overnight. 2. Patient will be discharged with a stool softener/laxative, analgesic, anti-emetic, and a narcotic for pain control. 3. Patient will follow-up in clinic with IR in 1 month.  Technique:  With the patient in the supine position, the left wrist was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The left wrist was evaluated with ultrasound and left radial artery patency and acceptable size criteria were documented. Images were properly stored in PACS. A modified Allen test (Barbeau test Type B) was performed on the left wrist to confirm patency of the ulnopalmar arch using pulse oximetry.   Access was obtained to the left radial artery using a 21 gauge micro needle and ultrasound guidance. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. A wire was placed through the needle. A hydrophilic Glidesheath was advanced slowly over the wire. 3000 units of heparin, 200 mcg of nitroglycerin and 2.5 mg of verapamil was given through the arterial sheath with slow hemodilution. A side flush was started.   The MPA catheter and Bentson wire were advanced through the sheath into the aorta and used to catheterize the bilateral internal iliac arteries and pelvic vessels described above. Angiograms were performed to delineate the origins of the uterine arteries. The above microcatheter/microwire combination was used to catheterize the horizontal segments of the uterine arteries; and the above embolization was performed to substasis with sluggish flow and pruning of the uterine arteries.    All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. A TR Band was placed on the left wrist for hemostasis. The access sheath was removed and no hematoma was seen. A radial artery pulse was confirmed distal to the puncture site confirming patent hemostasis.   The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.IR.1  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Pelvic collection. Suboptimal drain positioning.  Procedure:   Image-guided drain repositioning    Findings:   1.	Preexisting drain overlies the pelvis. 2.	Over-the-wire exchange and repositioning of drain with loop formed within the collection. 3.	Aspiration of ~100 mL old blood.  Impression:   1.	Image-guided exchange and repositioning of pelvic drain. 2.	100 mL old blood removed.  Treatment Plan:   1. Flush drain with 10 cc saline q8h as inpatient and 10 cc saline q24h as outpatient. 2. When drainage falls to below 10 cc/day (excluding flushes) for three consecutive days, please obtain repeat cross-sectional imaging and/or contact IR for possible removal.  Technique:  The patient was transported to the interventional suite in place in the supine position. The suprapubic region was prepped and draped utilizing maximum sterile barrier technique. Call the order was performed with all team members present and participating.  Scout imaging was obtained. Attempted injection of contrast of the pre-existing drain was met with high resistance. The drain and stay suture were cut. A 0.035 wire was advanced through the drain and coiled within the pelvic collection. A new 10.2 French drain was inserted over the wire. The wire and stiffener were removed and the locking loop was formed within the pelvic collection. Adequate positioning was confirmed with contrast injection. A total of 100 mL of old blood was removed through the drain. The drain was secured to the skin with a 2-0 Prolene stitch, connected to accordion suction, and covered with a sterile dressing. The procedure was well-tolerated and the patient remained clinically stable throughout. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication: Aneurysm in the region of the pancreatic head in the setting of isolated, chronic appearing celiac artery stenosis/occlusion, MVC [DATE] with subsequent new migratory, predominantly left-sided abdominal pain and post-prandial component.  PROCEDURE:   1.	US-guided right and left common femoral artery access. (Left access obtained for intraprocedural monitoring overseen by Anesthesia). 2.	Visceral angiography 3.	Arterial embolization 4.	Post-embolization angiography 5.	Bilateral common femoral artery angiogram and closure  FINDINGS:  1.	Patent and compressible left and right common femoral arteries on preliminary US. 2.	Aortography was performed in the sagittal plane at end-inspiration and end-expiration with occlusion of the proximal celiac artery demonstrated in both phases. Dynamic arteriography is therefore unable to establish or rule out underlying median arcuate ligament phenomenon. 3.	Unable to traverse the celiac artery occlusion. Attempts were abandoned after SMA angiography demonstrated very early filling of the target aneurysm indicating an origin near the proximal SMA. Rich pancreaticoduodenal arterial system with brisk filling of the hepatic and splenic arteries via this supply noted. 4.	Successful catheterization of the aneurysm sac directly from the SMA trunk and demonstration of isolated outflow through the dorsal pancreatic artery on contrast injection. No inflow vessel or aneurysm neck of significant length observed. 5.	Coil embolization of the dorsal pancreatic artery with complete hemostasis on post-embolization angiogram. 6.	Coil embolization of the aneurysm sac with post-embolization angiogram demonstrating persistent occlusion of the dorsal pancreatic artery outflow, delayed opacification of tiny perforating branches near the sac which were not amenable to further treatment. Of note, the sac was successfully embolized to its juncture with the SMA trunk. Patency of the SMA and its branches also visualized. 7.	Limited angiography of the bilateral common femoral arteries demonstrated expected access above the femoral bifurcations.  ANGIOGRAPHY: Vessels catheterized using base catheter and microcatheter/microwire combination and angiograms performed:  Celiac artery: Likely chronic occlusion. Delayed opacification of the hepatic and splenic arteries from retrograde/collateral flow from a prominent pancreaticoduodenal system. Occlusion of the proximal celiac artery persists on end-inspiration and end-expiration aortography.  Superior mesenteric artery: Very early filling of a splanchnic aneurysm with angiography in multiple views demonstrating an origin posterolateral to the SMA trunk. The sac was ultimately successfully accessed utilizing an Ansel 2 sheath, Rim catheter, 2.4F ProGreat, and double angle GT microwire. Isolated outflow through the dorsal pancreatic artery on contrast injection. No inflow vessel or aneurysm neck of significant length observed.  Post-embolization angiography of the aneurysm sac: Reflux of contrast out of the aneurysm sac into the proximal superior mesenteric artery. Persistent hemostasis of the treated dorsal pancreatic artery.  Postembolization superior mesenteric artery angiography: No opacification of the aneurysm sac with preservation of flow into the inferior pancreaticoduodenal, middle colic and remainder of superior mesenteric artery branches.   Transcatheter embolization: Vessel 1: Dorsal pancreatic artery  Embolic: Coils Details (type/size/volume/number):  Coil Prestige Plus Complex Xtra Tread 3.5 mm x 30 cm   Vessel 2: Proximal superior mesenteric artery aneurysm sac  Embolic: Coils Details (type/size/volume/number): Coil Prestige Plus Complex Xtra Tread 18mm x 65 cm  Coil Prestige Plus Complex Tread 15mm x 65 cm x2  Coil Embold Fibered 10 mm x 50 cm  Coil Embold Fibered 10 mm x 50 cm  Coil Prestige Plus Complex Tread 2.5 x 8 cm Coil Prestige Plus Complex Tread 2.5 mm x 12 cm    IMPRESSION:   1.	Aneurysm arising from the SMA trunk with isolated dorsal pancreatic artery outflow and no demonstrable inflow neck. The dorsal pancreatic artery and aneurysm sac were embolized to complete hemostasis. 2.	Proximal celiac artery occlusion present on both end-inspiration and end-expiration aortography. Median arcuate ligament phenomenon could not be definitely established or ruled out with this test.  TREATMENT PLAN:  1.	Admission to internal medicine for overnight observation. Coordination of care appreciated greatly. 2.	Strict bed rest with both legs straight for 3 hours. Bilateral lower extremity neurovascular checks q1h for 3 hours post-procedure. 3.	Chemistry, lipase, and CBC labs in the morning. 4.	IR clinic in one month with CTA of the abdomen/pelvis. 5.	Referral to surgery for consideration of possible MALS.  TECHNIQUE: With the patient in the supine position, the bilateral groins was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. Following standard prepping and draping, the left common femoral artery was punctured using a needle under real-time ultrasound and fluoroscopic guidance. A 5 French vascular sheath was placed within the left common femoral artery which was utilized by Anesthesia for intraprocedural monitoring. Following standard prepping and draping, the right common femoral artery was punctured using a needle. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. An 0.035" wire was advanced into the aorta. A 6 French vascular sheath was placed over the wire into the common femoral artery. A side flush was initiated with slow continuous infusion of heparinized saline.  A 5-Fr SOS 2 diagnostic catheter was advanced over an 0.035" wire into the abdominal aorta. The catheter was gently advanced into a proximal celiac artery stump. The distal celiac artery and its branches could not be opacified directly on injection of contrast and a wire could not be passed distally. Aortography was performed using the injector which demonstrated findings related to a chronic celiac axis occlusion as detailed above. Next, angiography was performed of the celiac axis from a lateral projection during end inspiration and end expiration with findings as detailed above.  Next, the SOS 2 diagnostic catheter was used to select the superior mesenteric artery, angiography was performed in multiple views as detailed above. Next a 2.4 F ProGreat microcatheter was used utilizing multiple microwires to navigate into the aneurysm sac which was unsuccessful. The microwire was advanced into the middle colic artery and angiography performed as detailed above.   Over the wire, the existing short 6 French vascular sheath was exchanged for a long 6 French 45 cm Ansel 2 curved sheath. The sheath was advanced into the proximal superior mesenteric artery. Through this a 5 French rim catheter was advanced into the SMA trunk. A 2.4 F progreat microcatheter and double angle GT microwire were then used to access the aneurysm situated posterolateral to the SMA trunk. Angiography was performed. The microcatheter was used to select the dorsal pancreatic artery. Coil embolization was performed as detailed above. Outflow vessel access was lost before further embolization could be performed. Access could not be reestablished but angiography demonstrated that the outflow system was thrombosed. The aneurysm sac was treated utilizing several coils of varying sizes as detailed above. Coil embolization was performed right up until the microcatheter recoiled directly into the proximal superior mesenteric artery.  Post-embolization angiography was performed, as detailed above.  Right and left common femoral artery angiograms were performed, demonstrating appropriate vascular access above the profunda femoris artery bifurcation. All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. Hemostasis was achieved using vascular closure device Angio-Seal bilaterally. The site was dressed in usual fashion.  The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: 74-year-old Female  with PMH of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, remote history of breast cancer status post lumpectomy and chemoradiation therapy, and intracranial atherosclerotic disease on aspirin who presented with problems with balance and was found to have a medial left frontal ICH with a small amount of subarachnoid extension. Diagnostic cerebral angiogram was requested for further evaluation.  PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 45 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] was the fellow. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right internal carotid artery Left internal carotid artery Left internal carotid artery Left external carotid artery Left common carotid artery, cervical Left vertebral artery  ANESTHESIA: Local in the right groin with bupivacaine and MAC provided by anesthesia team.   MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine SQ 10 cc  Heparin 3000 units IV Protamine 20 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.038" Bentson guidewire 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 5 French Cordis Vertebral catheter  Cardiva Vascade Omnipaque-300 contrast material (120 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 5 French sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP, Lateral and Oblique views.   Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a Vascade followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: CTA dated [DATE] and [DATE].  FINDINGS:  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: The left ACA fills and the left MCA partially fills via flow across the anterior communicating artery (due to severe stenosis of the left ICA terminus and hypoplastic left ACA, as seen on left ICA injection discussed below). There is a questionable short segment caliber enlargement of one of the callosomarginal branches which is only visualized in the lateral projection. This may be artifactual or reactive in nature, less likely evidence of RCVS.  No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified.    RIGHT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is severe stenosis of the distal ICA and proximal MCA related to intracranial atherosclerotic disease. There is no visualized left A1 segment. There is significant reflux into the ECA (related to the distal ICA stenosis and additional stenosis in the cervical ICA secondary to FMD, as seen on left common carotid injection discussed below)  No aneurysm or early draining vein are identified.    LEFT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   LEFT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CERVICAL: There is stenosis and irregularity of the proximal mid cervical segment of the ICA which is most consistent with fibromuscular dysplasia changes. There is a tonsillar loop just distal to the FMD changes. Mild irregularity of the proximal ICA and ECA, most likely related to atherosclerotic changes.  LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is partial filling of the left MCA territory via pial collaterals from the left PCA. No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. Reflux of contrast into the contralateral vertebral artery was not achieved. The origin of PICA is normal unilaterally (we will defer to CTA for evaluation of the contralateral PICA).    COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.   IMPRESSION:  1. There is severe stenosis of the distal left ICA and proximal left MCA related to intracranial atherosclerotic disease. 2. There is a questionable short segment caliber enlargement of one of the callosomarginal branches which is only visualized in the lateral projection. This may be artifactual or reactive in nature, less likely evidence of RCVS. 3. No visualized aneurysms or arteriovenous shunting lesions which would explain hemorrhage. 4. There is stenosis and irregularity of the proximal mid cervical segment of the ICA which is most consistent with fibromuscular dysplasia changes. 5. There is no visualized left A1 segment and the left ACA fills from flow across the anterior communicating artery
