Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL][ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Lymphoma with left brachiocephalic vein occlusion in need of central venous access  Informed consent was obtained. A preprocedural pause was performed.  The left upper treatment he was examined with ultrasound, and the left brachial vein was identified to be compressible and patent ultrasound. The left basilic vein was not identifiable as compressible and patent. The skin was marked over accessible portion of the left brachial vein. The site was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. A sterile barrier was created. Under real-time sonography guidance, the skin and subcutaneous tissues overlying the left brachial vein were locally anesthetized with 1% Xylocaine. Under real-time ultrasound guidance, left brachial vein was accessed with a 21-gauge needle. A guidewire was advanced into the central veins but could not be advanced into the superior vena cava under fluoroscopy. The needle was removed, and a 5 French micropuncture graduated dilator was advanced over the guidewire into the brachial vein. The wire was removed, and digital subtraction central left subclavian venography was performed. Venographic images of the left upper extremity from the central veins to the percutaneous access site was also performed with digital subtraction venography.  Based on the findings, the 5 French micropuncture dilator was removed, and manual hemostasis was obtained.  Attention was then paid to the right groin, an ultrasound examination demonstrated a compressible and patent right common femoral vein. The skin overlying the common femoral vein was marked with indelible pen. The site was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. A sterile barrier was created. Local anesthesia was infiltrated into the skin and subcutaneous tissues over the common femoral vein. A 4 cm subcutaneous tunnel was then created from the skin overlying the vein to a site inferolateral to the aforementioned site on the right anterolateral thigh. The distance from the venous access site to the level of the right third lumbar pedicle was measured on a guidewire, in this distance was used to custom cut to length of a 5 French single lumen PICC. The distance from the catheter hub to the tip of the catheter was 34 cm. The catheter was then pulled through the subcutaneous tunnel to venous access site and advanced through the peel-away sheath into the common femoral vein and inferior vena cava. The peel-away sheath was removed, fluoroscopic observation of the path of the catheter was evaluated for kinks in the catheter, and the catheter was aspirated and flushed was saline to confirm adequate function. A fluoroscopic spot image was obtained over the abdomen, located catheter tip at the level of the superior endplate of L3. Catheter was secured to the skin with 3-0 Prolene suture, dressing was applied.  Incidentally, there appear to be 6 lumbar vertebral bodies with probable lumbarization of S1.  FINDINGS: Left upper extremity venography demonstrates a patent paired brachial vein with small axillary vein, occlusion of left subclavian and brachiocephalic veins, with somewhat well-developed collaterals from the junction of the left internal jugular and subclavian veins into the azygos vein and superior vena cava. No contrast flows directly through the subclavian and brachiocephalic veins in the superior vena cava. There are paravertebral collaterals noted.  CONCLUSION: 1. Complete occlusion of the left subclavian and brachiocephalic veins 2. The left basilic vein was not compressible and patent on ultrasound 3. 34 cm single lumen tunneled PICC placed via the right common femoral vein with its tip overlying the superior endplate of L3  Procedural Personnel Attending(s): [HCW] Fellow(s): None Resident(s): None Advanced practice provider(s): None  Complications: No immediate complications. INTRA-OPERATIVE CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: Status-post left-sided craniotomy for clip ligation of recurrent previously coiled anterior communicating artery aneurysm. Intra-operative angiography was requested.  PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: 30 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending. [HCW] was the fellow. [HCW] interpreted the images.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Left internal carotid artery Right internal carotid artery  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.038" Bentson Guidewire  5 French Terumo Pinnacle Sheath 5 French Merit Performa Vertebral catheter Cardiva Vascade Omnipaque-300 contrast material (120 cc)  ANESTHESIA: The patient was under general anesthesia in the operating room.  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed. Informed consent was obtained as part of general consent for the craniotomy.  In the operating room, the patient's groin was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. Puncture of the right common femoral artery was performed and a 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath was placed using sterile Seldinger technique. The sheath was continuously perfused with heparinized saline before and during the surgery.  Following surgical clipping of the aneurysm, an intra-operative angiogram was performed using portable fluoroscopic equipment in the operating room. The 5 French Cordis Vertebral catheter was placed into the above listed vessels using a 0.038" Bentson guidewire. Cerebral angiograms were then completed in AP, lateral, and oblique projections. The surgical clip required adjustment. During clip adjustments, the catheter was left in place and manually flushed with heparinized saline.  After completion of the angiogram, the vascular sheath was removed and hemostasis obtained using a vascade collagen plug, followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram dated [DATE].  FINDINGS:  LEFT AND RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERIES, CEREBRAL (Multiple runs of each over the first 3 clip placements): There is a surgical clip in the expected location. However, over the course of these runs, there is either sluggish residual filling of the aneurysm, or occlusion of one or both right A2 branches due to impingement from the surgical clip.   RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (Final clip position, run 13): There is a surgical clip seen in the expected location. There is no evidence of residual aneurysm and the right A2 callosal marginal branch fills in phase.  No evidence of distal emboli is seen.    LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (Final clip position, run 15): There remains a clip seen in the expected location of the previously visualized aneurysm. There is no residual aneurysm and there is robust in phase filling of the ipsilateral A2 as well as the right A2 pericallosal branch.  No evidence of distal emboli is seen.    COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION:   Status-post clip ligation of previously coiled recurrent anterior communicating artery aneurysm with no angiographic evidence of residual aneurysm and reconstruction of the complex, triplicate A2 anatomy. INTRACRANIAL EMBOLIZATION OF CHRONIC SUBDURAL HEMATOMA MEMBRANES THROUGH MIDDLE MENINGEAL ARTERY, UNILATERAL  CLINICAL INDICATION: This is a 54 years Male with past medical history of developmental delay, cardiomyopathy, AICD, hypertension, right subdural hematoma status post burr hole [DATE] and status post right middle meningeal artery embolization [DATE], who was admitted with recurrence of his right-sided subdural hematoma, status post repeat burr hole evacuation [DATE], who now presents here for embolization through the middle meningeal artery.   PROCEDURE: Diagnostic angiogram. Intracranial particle embolization of chronic subdural hematoma membranes through the middle meningeal artery   DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 1.5 hrs.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician. He supervised the entire procedure. [HCW] was the fellow. They both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right Internal Carotid Artery Right External Carotid Artery Left Internal Carotid Artery Left External Carotid Artery Left Middle Meningeal Artery  VESSELS TREATED: Left Middle Meningeal Artery  ANESTHESIA: General endotracheal anesthesia was administered under the supervision of the attending anesthesiologist. Pre-, intra-, and post-anesthesia monitoring records are available in the chart.  MEDICATIONS:  Heparin 4500units IV Protamine 10 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: [VENDOR] Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 0.035" Bentson guidewire 0.035" Terumo exchange-length glidewire  5 French Cordis Vertebral catheter Excelsior 1018 microcatheter disease 150 cm) Transend EX 0.014" microguidewire (182 cm) Traxcess 14 micro guidewire Contour PVA embolization particles (150-250 microns) Cardiva Vascade Omnipaque 300 contrast material (95 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, spinal cord infarction, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, hemorrhage, nontargeted embolization, necrosis of skin or mucus membranes, renal failure, limb loss, death, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.  After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite, intubated, and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the Right femoral artery; a 5 French Terum[VENDOR] Pinnacle sheath was introduced into the Right femoral artery. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was completed of the above vessels. ACTs were checked periodically and additional heparin was administered to achieve a target of >250. Digital angiograms were performed centered over the head and face. We first evaluated the right internal carotid artery and right external carotid artery, which showed that the right middle meningeal artery was still occluded in both the frontal and parietal branches. We then turned our attention to the left side. An angiogram of the left external carotid artery showed that a prominent branch of the frontal branch of the left middle meningeal artery was crossing midline to the contralateral side. This became our target for embolization.  Superselective catheterization of the left middle meningeal artery was then performed with the [VENDOR]sior 1018 microcatheter and [VENDOR] microguidewire. Contour PVA particles were prepared on an adjacent table and maintained in isobaric suspension with appropriate quantities of saline and contrast and injected into the prominent branch arising from the frontal branch of the left middle meningeal artery using a pulse-spray technique over several minutes. Control angiograms of this vessel were performed before, during, and after the embolization.   Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a Cardiva Vascade followed by manual compression. A Tegaderm was then applied over the puncture site.  COMPARISON: noninvasive imaging.  FINDINGS:   RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is mild to moderate narrowing of the terminal internal carotid artery. There is evidence of slightly delayed opacification of the right MCA branches. A choroidal blush is noted. No anastomosis with right ECA branches is demonstrated.  RIGHT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No anastomosis resulting in ipsilateral ophthalmic artery or intracranial perfusion is identified. There is persistent occlusion of the parietal and frontal branches of the right middle meningeal artery. The remaining branches of the external carotid artery opacify normally.  LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No anastomosis with right ECA branches is demonstrated. There is mild to moderate narrowing of the terminal left internal carotid artery as well as the left A1 segment. There is near complete occlusion of the left M1 segment. There are prominent lenticulostriate vessels, consistent with a moyamoya pattern. The choroidal blush is present. Of note the anterior falcine artery arises from the distal ophthalmic artery.  LEFT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No anastomosis resulting in ipsilateral ophthalmic artery or intracranial perfusion is identified. There is a prominent branch arising from the frontal branch of the left middle meningeal artery which crosses the midline and supplies the right meninges.  LEFT MIDDLE MENINGEAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL (PRE-EMBOLIZATION): No anastomoses with the right ophthalmic artery are demonstrated. No arteriovenous shunting or dural fistula is seen.   LEFT MIDDLE MENINGEAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-EMBOLIZATION): Interval embolization of the prominent branch supplying the contralateral meninges arising from the frontal branch of the left middle meningeal artery with significant stagnation of flow. No other vessel occlusions are identified.   COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: 1.	Successful intracranial PVA embolization through a branch of the left frontal branch of the middle meningeal artery for treatment of chronic subdural hematoma membranes. 2.	There is evidence of Suzuki stage III moyamoya syndrome of the left anterior circulation, specifically mild to moderate narrowing of the terminal left ICA and left A1, along with near complete occlusion of the left M1. There is also mild to moderate narrowing of the right terminal ICA with slight delay in opacification of the right MCA branches.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  76-year-old female with acute T7 compression fracture in the setting of MGUS and possible multiple myeloma. Intractable back pain.  Additional Clinical Indication: Acute (6 weeks or less) compression fracture of T7 vertebral body with MR signal changes. Spine MRI/bone-scan is within 30 days of this procedure and was performed on [DATE]. Patient has severe back pain despite optimal non-surgical management with severe impact of vertebral body compression fracture(s) on daily functioning. Patient has kyphotic deformity due to vertebral body compression fracture(s).     Procedure:   1.	Image-guided kyphoplasty  2.	Image-guided bone biopsy   Findings:   1.	Pre-intervention: Compression fracture identified on T7 vertebral body. Previous kyphoplasty changes of L1 vertebral body. 2.	Post-intervention:  Successful deposition of cement within the treated vertebral body/bodies with no evidence of extravasation.    Impression:   1.	Successful image guided augmentation of vertebral level: T7 with bone biopsy.    Treatment Plan:   1.	 A fracture of the hip, spine or distal radius in patients over 50 years of age warrants testing or treatment for osteoporosis if not previously undertaken.   Patient was instructed to take part in an osteoporosis prevention/treatment program.   Technique:   The patient was brought to the interventional radiology suite and placed on the table in prone position. The wide area of the back around the affected area(s) was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion.   All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). A scout image was obtained in AP and lateral projections.   Skin was anesthetized with a 2% lidocaine solution.   Level by level technique:   -Vertebral level:  T7 -Pedicle access:  Right unipedicular -Access trocar gauge:  11-gauge -Balloon utilized:  15 mm  Prior to injection of cement, balloons were inserted and inflated under biplane fluoroscopy.  Static fluoroscopic images were stored to PACS documenting balloon utilization and position. -Biopsy obtained:  Yes -Indication for biopsy: MGUS, possible multiple myeloma -Ablation Performed: N/A -Indication for Ablation: N/A  Additional Procedural Details:   Utilizing AP and lateral fluoroscopy, needle was inserted into the affected vertebral body/bodies. The needle was advanced under careful, intermittent biplane fluoroscopy to ensure that the medial wall of the pedicle was not violated prior to transgression of the needle tip into the posterior wall of the vertebral body. The drill was then advanced to the anterior one-third of the vertebral body on each side.  No ablation was performed.  Balloon(s) was/were inserted into the effected vertebral body/bodies and inflated under fluoroscopy. Static fluoroscopic images were stored to PACS documenting balloon position. Cement was mixed and balloons were removed after being deflated.  Cement was then injected under careful, intermittent biplane fluoroscopy to ensure no significant extravasation of PMMA cement beyond the borders of the vertebral body. Cement injection was stopped once there was adequate fill of the vertebral body. Trochars were removed with hemostasis obtained with focal compression. Static fluoroscopic images were obtained after removal of all needles documenting final cement position. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.IR.1  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Acute cholecystitis  Procedure:   US-guided percutaneous cholecystostomy tube placement  Findings:   1. Distended gallbladder.   2. Real-time US images through the gallbladder demonstrate appropriate percutaneous drainage.  Impression:   Technically successful US-guided percutaneous cholecystostomy tube placement, performed at bedside in the ICU.  Treatment Plan:   1. Flush drain with 10 cc saline q12h. 2. Follow-up tube check in 6 weeks, will be arranged by IR. At that time, if the cystic duct is patent, can consider capping trial in preparation for removal of catheter and less there are surgical plans for cholecystectomy.  Technique:  Target: Gallbladder Imaging: Ultrasound Drain: 8 Fr APD/Mermaid Drainage: 10 mL black bilious fluid aspirated during procedure Microbiology: Sample sent  A superficial skin entry site was selected based on available imaging and the overlying skin entry site was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier to target the above collection. The skin surface was anesthetized with 1-2% lidocaine. Using continuous real-time grayscale and/or color doppler ultrasound guidance, a needle was introduced into the target site and imaging guidance confirmed adequate positioning. A transperitoneal rather than transhepatic approach was selected given that a transhepatic approach would require traversing the pleura due to a very high location of the gallbladder, and a higher bleeding risk given patient's antiplatelet therapy which could not be held from his recent PCI. The access device was utilized with an 0.035" wire to introduce the drainage catheter listed above following any necessary serial dilatation. Ultrasound images confirmed appropriate positioning within the target structure. The catheter was secured to the skin surface using nonabsorbable suture material and dressed in typical fashion. Any samples not sent to laboratory for analysis were discarded. The patient tolerated the procedure and was sent to the recovery area for monitoring. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Pancreatic cancer with recurrent ascites  Procedure:   1.	Ultrasound and fluoroscopic-guided tunneled abdominal ascites drain catheter placement       Findings:   1.	Ultrasound demonstrates small volume ascites over the abdomen. 2.	Final static fluoroscopic image documents the catheter coiled over the right abdomen in satisfactory position.        Impression:   1.	Technically successful insertion of 15,5 French  tunneled abdominal ascites drain.       Treatment Plan:   The catheter may be used immediately.      Technique:   Informed consent for the procedure was obtained, and time-out was performed prior to the procedure.  The skin overlying the access site was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).   The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right lower quadrant were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the abdomen was performed demonstrating small volume ascites.  Under ultrasound guidance, peritoneal space was accessed with a 5 French Yueh needle.         Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the upper anterior abdomen to the dermatotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the dermatotomy site.  The peritoneal access site was dilated to allow introduction of a peel-away sheath.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the catheter tip over the right, lower abdomen. The dermatotomy site was closed with a resorbable suture and Dermabond.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS.   The catheter was connected to suction and     liters of clear, yellow fluid was drained from the peritoneal cavity. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Pancreatic mass with biliary obstruction  Procedure:   1.	Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram 2.	Placement of percutaneous transhepatic internal/external biliary drain   Findings:   1.	Occlusion of the common bile duct secondary to extrinsic compression from known mass.  Impression:   Technically successful percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography and drainage catheter placement.   Plan:  1.	Open to bag drainage for 24 hours.  2.	Routine drain exchange in 8 weeks.  Technique:   The anterior abdominal wall and bilateral flanks were prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier.  An appropriate skin entry site was identified using fluoroscopy and ultrasound, and anesthetized with local.  Under fluoroscopic guidance, a 22G Chiba needle was advanced into the liver.  A bile duct was entered and the biliary system was opacified with contrast. Cholangiographic images were obtained.  Two-stick technique: A suitable duct for drain placement was then identified on the right. Under direct sonographic guidance, a right duct was accessed with a second 22 gauge Chiba needle.  A 0.018" wire was passed centrally, and the needle exchanged for a nonvascular access catheter. The inner stiffener, dilator, and 0.018" wire were removed and contrast was injected to confirm location.  A 0.035" glidewire and 4 French angled catheter were negotiated into the small bowel. The glidewire was removed and contrast was injected to confirm location. A 0.035" Amplatz wire was placed through the catheter, and the catheter subsequently removed.   Drain placement: Finally, an 10 French     internal-external biliary drain was placed over the wire. The anchor/loop was formed and locked. Attention was paid that side holes were positioned within the biliary system. Contrast was injected to confirm location. The catheter was secured to the skin with 2-0 suture material and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.  Contrast was injected through the existing biliary drainage catheter and cholangiographic images obtained.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. UTI sepsis in the setting of bilateral hydronephrosis.  Procedure:   1.	Bilateral nephrostogram and nephrostomy tube placement      Findings:  Comparison is made to a previous exam dated [DATE].  1.	Moderate bilateral hydronephrosis on survey ultrasound.  2.	Moderate bilateral hydronephrosis. No spontaneous contrast flow into the ileal conduit.  Catheter(s):  8 F mermaid nephrostomy tube  Impression:   1.	Uneventful ultrasound and fluroscopic-guided placement of bilateral nephrostomy tube as described above. Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained to the patient. Written informed consent was obtained.  A time out/call to order was performed prior to procedure initiation.  The soft tissues overlying the left flank access site were prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Same technique was utilized to the right flank access site and nephrostomy tube was placed. Left nephrostogram  2.	New percutaneous left nephrostomy tube placement 3.	Exchange of right nephroureteral tube  Findings:    1.	Existing left nephrostomy tube has a tortuous course. Left nephrostogram shows moderate hydroureteronephrosis with severe presumed malignant stricture in the distal ureter at the UVJ. 2.	Newly placed anterior-approach left nephrostomy tube in the malrotated left kidney is appropriately positioned with more peripheral needle access into the lower pole calyx. Tract evaluation from the new access shows prompt spillage of contrast into the free peritoneal cavity without opacification of intraluminal bowel. 3.	Right nephrostogram shows mild pelvocaliectasis with free passage of flow into the urinary bladder. Newly placed right nephroureteral tube is appropriately positioned with distal tip terminating in the distal ureter above the UVJ.  Catheter: Right modified PCNU 8.5 French Cook, left PCN 8.5 French Cook  Impression:   1.	New percutaneous left nephrostomy tube placement in the malrotated left pelvic kidney. 2.	Replacement of right modified nephroureteral catheter.  Treatment Plan:   Patient should return for routine check and change in 8-12 weeks.  Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained to the patient. Written informed consent was obtained. A time out/call to order was performed prior to procedure initiation.  The existing catheter(s) and surrounding soft tissues were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site. A scout radiograph was obtained.  Left:  In the supine position, non-ionic contrast was injected through the left nephrostomy tube and images of the collecting system obtained and stored to PACS. Because the tube had a tortuous course through the mesentery, this tube was removed. Under ultrasound guidance, the lower pole calyx of the left pelvic malrotated kidney was accessed with a 21-gauge needle and .018" wire.  Using a nonvascular access set, the access was dilated. Contrast was injected through the 6 French outer access catheter. Images were reviewed. A 0.035'' stiff Amplatz wire was advanced through the catheter into the urinary bladder. Using a Tuohy sidearm adaptor attached to the catheter, contrast was injected through the sidearm over the wire as it was pulled back from the proximal left ureter into the lower calyx and subsequently into the free peritoneal space all the way to the skin. Images reviewed and stored to PACS. A new 8.5 French Cook nephrostomy tube was advanced over the wire and the Cope loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis. Contrast injection confirmed appropriate location. The catheter was sutured to the abdominal wall with monofilament suture and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.  Right:  In the prone position, non-ionic contrast was injected through the right modified nephroureteral tube and images of the collecting system obtained and stored to PACS. An 0.035” wire was advanced through the nephrostomy tube. The tube was removed over the wire under direct fluoroscopic visualization. A new nephrostomy tube was advanced over the wire and the Cope loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis. Contrast injection confirmed appropriate location. The catheter was sutured to the flank with monofilament suture and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.  The procedure was well tolerated, and patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Endometrial carcinoma.  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen Bard port (standard profile)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen Bard power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 2-0 absorbable sutures. A running 4-0 absorbable subcuticular stitch and  Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with a single subcuticular stitch and Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Head and neck cancer with dysphagia requiring long-term enteric access for nutrition  Procedure:   1.	Gastrostomy tube placement under fluoroscopic guidance.  Findings:   1.	The gastrostomy tube is in good position.  2.	Gentle hand injection of contrast material confirms positioning of the gastrostomy tube within the gastric lumen.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of 18 French MIC gastrostomy tube as above.  Treatment Plan:   The tube should be placed to gravity drainage and should not be used for 2 hours. Patient will be examined and saline will be flushed into the tube prior to discharge.   Technique:   Informed consent for the procedure was obtained, and time-out was performed prior to the procedure.  The skin overlying the access site was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the mid abdomen were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.   Using fluoroscopic and ultrasonographic guidance, an appropriate puncture site was identified in the region of the patient's prior gastrostomy access.  3 T-fasteners were placed adjacent to the planned tube access site. Positioning of the T-fasteners within the gastric lumen was confirmed by return of air and direct injection of contrast material.  Next, under fluoroscopic guidance, an 18-gauge needle was directed into the gastric lumen. Needle positioning within the gastric lumen was confirmed with aspiration of air as well as gentle hand injection of contrast material.  A wire was advance through the 18-gauge needle.  The 18-gauge needle was removed over a wire. Serial dilation was accomplished over the stiff wire. An 18 French Halyard G-tube was advanced over a wire in an antegrade fashion and advanced through the anterior abdominal wall. All wires and catheters were removed. The bulb was inflated with 10 mL of a 10% contrast mixture. Gentle hand injection of contrast material documents the gastric feeding tube within the gastric lumen. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained for reference purposes. The tube was flushed with saline. It was affixed to the anterior abdominal wall with a rubber flange. The patient tolerated the procedure well at time of procedure completion without complication. DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: Right subdural hematoma  PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram. Possible right middle meningeal artery embolization  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 30 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] was the fellow. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right internal carotid artery Right external carotid artery  ANESTHESIA: General anesthesia  MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine SQ 10 cc  Heparin 5000 units IV Protamine 20 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.035" Bentson guidewire 5 French Boston Scientific sheath 5 French Cordis vert catheter  Mynx Closure Device Visipaque contrast material (60 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 5 French sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 5000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP, Lateral and Oblique views. We closely evaluated the right middle meningeal artery and identified the frontal branch supplying the area of the subdural hematoma. Unfortunately this frontal branch was too small in caliber to catheterize safely. This point we concluded the procedure.  Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a Mynx closure device followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: None.  FINDINGS: RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. Of note the choroidal blush is observed. There is evidence of mass effect from the subdural hematoma.   RIGHT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula. The frontal branch of the right middle meningeal artery appears very small in caliber.   COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: 1. There is a very small caliber of the frontal branch of the right middle meningeal artery, precluding MMA embolization. No intervention was pursued.

Patient will be back for repeat biopsy and upsizing in 4-6 weeks.  Technique:   The existing catheter and surrounding soft tissues were prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site.  An 0.035" GWA wire was negotiated through the catheter into the small bowel. The catheter was removed and exchanged for a 9 French sheath. A pull back sheath cholangiogram was performed. Brush and clamshell biopsy was performed in the region of the stenosis.  The sheath was removed and a new 14 French internal/external biliary drain was placed over the wire. Contrast was injected to confirm tube position. The catheter was secured to the skin with 2-0 Ethilon. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Ovarian cancer   Procedure: Right jugular single lumen low profile chest port placement with imaging   Findings:  The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses.  Needle entry was stored to PACS.  The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating in the right atrium.     Impression:   Uneventful image guided placement of right internal jugular 6 French single lumen power port catheter as described.    Technique:  The right neck and chest wall region was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Using local anesthetic and ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein vein was punctured with a 21 gauge needle. A PACS image was stored.  A 0.018" wire was passed centrally and the needle exchanged for a 5 French transitional dilator. The smaller wire was exchanged for a 0.035" wire.  A peel away sheath was placed at the venotomy.  The soft tissues caudal and lateral to the sheath entry site were anesthetized with lidocaine with epinephrine. A #15 blade was used to incise the skin.  Blunt and sharp dissection were used to create a subcutaneous pocket.  The pocket was irrigated with saline solution and packed.  A tunneling tool was brought from the pocket to the venotomy. The catheter was brought through the tunnel.  During suspended respiration, the catheter was advanced through the peel-away and positioned centrally using fluoroscopy. The peel-away sheath was removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression. The catheter was flushed, cut to length and attached to the port reservoir. The reservoir was aspirated, flushed, and heparinized per protocol.  It was sutured into the pocket using a single 2-0 Ethilon suture.  The pocket was closed using deep interrupted absorbable 3-0 Vicryl suture, 4-0 Vicryl running subcuticular suture and Dermabond.  The venotomy was closed with Dermabond.  Telfa and a sterile dressing were applied. The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  End-stage renal disease, requiring long-term hemodialysis.  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled large bore central venous catheter placement  Findings:   1.	The left internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the large bore central venous catheter, as described, the tip terminates in the right atrium.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a  15.5 French, 27 cm (tip-to-cuff), tunneled large bore central venous catheter via the left internal jugular vein.  Treatment Plan:   1. Routine catheter care. 2. The catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissues overlying the vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the left internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle. An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 Amplatz wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the dialysis catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The venotomy tract was dilated to allow introduction of a peel-away sheath.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Gallbladder cancer with hilar obstruction and failed ERCP on [DATE]. She underwent external biliary drain placement on [DATE] and returns today for internalization.   PROCEDURES: 1. Catheter Cholangiogram 2. Internal/External Biliary Drainage Catheter Placement via a new puncture 3. External biliary drainage catheter replacement  FINDINGS: Abdominal MRI with MRCP from [DATE] was reviewed along with the placement images from [DATE]  1. Catheter cholangiogram shows moderate dilation of the central intrahepatic bile ducts.  2. There is a high-grade obstruction of the biliary tree at the hilum. The left and right ducts communicate but the common hepatic duct is not visualized. 3. The accessed duct is segment IVB  with unfavorable vectors for internalization. 4. A new access was created from a segment VI duct. 5. The previous catheter was replaced as the tract is not mature. 6. Successful placement of 10.2 French internal/external biliary drain via a peripheral segment VI right hepatic duct. 7. The distal common bile duct and ampulla are normal.   IMPRESSION:  TREATMENT PLAN:  The internal-external biliary drainage catheter should remain to gravity drainage. It will be capped as the bilirubin trends down.  The more cephalad catheter can be capped.   PROCEDURE:  The anterior abdominal wall and existing biliary drainage catheter were prepped and draped in standard sterile fashion.  The existing drain was removed over wire and a short 8 French sheath placed. A long 6 French sheath was placed coaxially and used in combination with multiple catheters (5 French angled catheter, C2 glide catheter, and modified Omni Flush catheter) in combination with a Glidewire in attempts to traverse the high-grade obstruction at the hilum. Vectors were unfavorable. A long 6 French sheath was placed from the accessed duct into the left biliary tree and attention redirected to a new access.  An appropriate skin entry site was identified targeting the opacified segment VI bile duct more caudally. Local anesthetic was injected. In a single pass, the bile duct was punctured with a 22-gauge Chiba needle. A 0.018" wire was passed, and the needle exchanged for a 6 French transitional dilator.  The inner stiffener, dilator, and guidewire were removed and contrast was injected to confirm location.  A 0.035" glidewire and 4 French catheter were negotiated across hilar obstruction into the small bowel. The glidewire was removed and contrast was injected to confirm location.  A 0.035" Amplatz wire was placed through the catheter.  A long 6 French sheath was placed over the Amplatz and a pullback sheath cholangiogram performed to assess the distal CBD. A  10.2 French internal-external biliary drain with extended sideholes was placed over the wire. The Cope loop was formed and locked in the duodenum. The side holes were positioned above the level of obstruction. Contrast was injected to confirm location. The catheter was secured to the skin with 2-0 Ethilon and attached to gravity drainage.  A sterile dressing was applied.  The 6 French sheath was removed over an Amplatz wire and a 10.2 French internal/external biliary drain was placed over the wire to be used as an external biliary drain (no APDL available). The catheter was sutured in place and capped.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL][ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Pancreatic adenocarcinoma causing severe circumferential compression of the SMA. Pneumatosis with presumed ischemic gastropathy, and severe postprandial pain.  PROCEDURE:   1. US-guided right common femoral artery access. 2. Visceral angiography 3. Superior mesenteric artery stenting 4. Post stenting angiography 5. Right common femoral artery angiogram and closure  FINDINGS: ANGIOGRAPHY: Vessels catheterized using base catheter and microcatheter/microwire combination and angiograms performed:   Aortogram: Severe narrowing and proximal celiac artery. Superior narrowing of the superior mesenteric artery near its origin.  Superior mesenteric artery: Transcatheter stenting: Details (type/size/volume/number):  Gore VBX 7 mm x 2.9 cm balloon expandable covered stent  IMPRESSION:   Technically successful stenting of the superior mesenteric artery origin.  TREATMENT PLAN:  1. Continued clinical and laboratory monitoring recommended. Please contact interventional radiology if there is a change in clinical status. 2. Routine post-angiography groin cares ordered. 3. Start aspirin 81 mg daily. 4. Follow-up in interventional radiology clinic in 1 month. Follow-up CT angiogram of the abdomen and pelvis in 3 months.  TECHNIQUE: With the patient in the supine position, the groin was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. Following standard prepping and draping, the right common femoral artery was punctured using a needle. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. An 0.035" Bentson wire was advanced into the aorta. A 7 French Ansel vascular sheath was placed over the wire into the common femoral artery. A side flush was started.  A 5-Fr Omni Flush catheter was advanced over the Bentson wire into the abdominal aorta. An initial aortogram was performed to delineate the visceral anatomy. With the superior mesenteric artery identified; the Omni Flush was exchanged for a SOS2 catheter. This catheter was used to select the origin of the superior mesenteric artery. A Glidewire was advanced distally down the SMA, however the SOS2 catheter would not track over the wire. This catheter was then exchanged for a Cobra C2 glide, which was seated in the mid SMA, beyond the stenosis. The Glidewire was removed, and a Rosen was attempted to be advanced however unfortunately was too stiff, and access into the SMA was lost.  The above process was then repeated to select the superior mesenteric artery, however this time instead of a Cobra C2 glide catheter, a Navicross catheter was and advanced to the distal SMA, and the Rosen was able to be advanced into the distal SMA. The Navicross catheter was removed, the Ansel sheath was advanced, and the above VBX stent was loaded through the sheath and positioned appropriately based on the above angiograms. Once in appropriate position, the stent was deployed, without any complication. It was ballooned up to 8 mm (PowerFlex 8 mm x 4 cm balloon), and flow was significantly improved to the distal SMA. Special attention was made to the early branches off the SMA, none of which were covered by our stent.  A right common femoral artery angiogram was performed, demonstrating appropriate vascular access above the profunda femoris artery bifurcation. All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. Hemostasis was achieved using an Angio-Seal vascular closure device. The site was dressed in usual fashion.  The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Metastatic colon cancer. Intrahepatic metastasis producing left bile duct obstruction.  Procedure:   1.	Pullback sheath cholangiogram through existing percutaneous access 2.	Left internal/external biliary drain exchange  Findings:   1.	Sheath cholangiogram demonstrates a portobiliary fistula in the periphery of the left hepatic lobe. The distance from this fistula to the main biliary ductal confluence was measured to be 4.6 cm. 2.	Decision was made to not place an uncovered stent across the patient's left biliary stricture due to an unacceptable likelihood of involving the fistula. Of note, the left biliary stricture did not appear as severe compared to the previous exam, possibly an effect of interval biliary drain placement. 3.	Newly placed 10.2 French left biliary drain with extended sideholes is appropriately positioned with the distal tip in the third portion of the duodenum and the proximal side hole peripheral to the stenosis but central to the portobiliary fistula.  Impression:   1.	Portobiliary fistula in the peripheral left hepatic lobe. 2.	Decision made to not proceed with initial plan of stenting across the left biliary stricture as detailed above. 3.	Replacement of 10.2F internal-external biliary catheter to continue drainage and exclude the portobiliary fistula.  Treatment Plan:  1. Initiate capping trial tomorrow.  2. Repeat cholangiogram in 2-4 weeks to assess for healing of portobiliary fistula. If resolved, would look to place stent at that time.  Technique:   The existing catheter and surrounding soft tissues were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.   The existing tube was initially injected, and determined to be patent. An 0.035" Amplatz wire was negotiated through the catheter into the small bowel. The catheter was removed and exchanged for an 8 French sheath. A pull back sheath cholangiogram was performed which demonstrated the above findings of sizable left to left portobiliary fistula.  A repeat sheath cholangiogram was performed in the RAO projection, and measurements were taken to assess the length of the stricture. It was determined that the risk of stent placement outweighs the potential benefit at this time.  The sheath was removed and a new 10.2 French internal/external biliary drain with extended sideholes was placed over the wire. Contrast was injected to confirm tube position. The catheter was secured to the skin with 2-0 Ethilon. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESR[HOSPITAL].[ID].1  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Right lower extremity and iliac DVT with variceal bleeding  Procedure:   Inferior venacavogram   Retrievable IVC filter placement           Findings:  1. There is no left iliofemoral or caval thrombus. 2. There are single renal veins bilaterally. The IVC is normal in caliber. There is no aberrant anatomy. 3. The filter is appropriately positioned below the lowest renal vein. 4. The left common femoral vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. Needle entry was documented.  Images were stored to PACS. 5. Calcified gallstones are present.  Impression:  No evidence for left iliofemoral or caval thrombus.  Uneventful image guided placement of infrarenal retrievable Denali IVC filter as described.  Recommendation:  IR clinic visit in 3 months for evaluation for retrieval    Technique:  The patient had multiple pressors and lines in the right neck and has clot in the right groin. This prompted a left femoral venous approach.  The left groin was prepped and draped in sterile fashion.   The vascular structures were ultrasonographically evaluated.   Images were stored and transferred to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the left common femoral vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  Vein patency and needle entry were documented. A 0.018" wire was placed and the needle exchanged for a 5 French dilator.  An Amplatz wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava, and the dilator exchanged for a 5 French Omni Flush catheter. Inferior venacavography was performed using dilute nonionic contrast. This is a baseline study to define variant anatomy, caval size, location and number of renal veins, and to evaluate for ileocaval thrombus.  The Amplatz wire was replaced, and the pigtail exchanged for the Denali filter delivery system.  Under direct fluoroscopic guidance, the filter was positioned and deployed.   The sheath was removed, and hemostasis achieved with compression.  No immediate complication occurred, and the patient was discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Rectal adenocarcinoma status post neoadjuvant therapy, pelvic exenteration, and PCNU to a colonic conduit. He has had persistent bleeding following PCNU placement.  Procedure:  1. Right antegrade nephrostogram and percutaneous nephroureterostomy conversion to retrograde ureteral/colonic conduit stent.  Findings:  1. Right antegrade nephrostogram demonstrates numerous filling defects, likely representing blood clots, in the collecting system. Brisk transit of contrast to the colonic conduit. 2. Newly placed retrograde ureteral stent is appropriately positioned with the distal loop in the renal pelvis and catheter exiting the ostomy.  Impression:  Successful conversion of right PCNU to retrograde ureteral/colonic conduit stent (10.2 French by 40 cm biliary drain with standard sideholes)  Plan:   1. Flush drain daily with 10 cc normal saline flush.  2. Patient will be due for routine exchange in 10-12 weeks.   Technique:  With the patient in prone position, the bilateral flanks were prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. A scout radiograph was obtained.   Contrast was injected through the existing nephroureterostomy tube and imaging of the collecting was system performed, demonstrating filling defects throughout the collecting system, with contrast transiting quickly to the colonic conduit.  A Glidewire advantage was advanced through the existing drain into the colonic conduit, and the drain was removed over the wire. An 8 French sheath was advanced over the wire for stability. Using a renal double curve catheter, the wire was advanced through the colonic conduit and out the urostomy (creating through and through access).  A new 10.2 French by 40 cm biliary drain was advanced over the wire (from the urostomy end), with the cope loop formed in the renal pelvis. Contrast injection confirmed adequate positioning.   A sheath-pull back was then performed to delineate the point of entry into the renal collecting system.  The sheath was then retracted back and gelfoam slurry was then used to embolize the percutaneous tract.  A new ostomy bag was placed over the urostomy, and sterile dressing was applied to the back.    The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  69-year old man with recurrent ascites, undergoing cirrhosis evaluation.  Esophageal varices seen on most recent EGD   Procedure:   1.	Paracentesis  2.	Transjugular liver biopsy   Findings:   1.	The right hepatic vein is normal in caliber and appearance. 2.	The biopsy specimen appeared adequate. 3.	measured venous pressures: a. Wedge hepatic venous pressure: 13 mm Hg b. Free hepatic venous pressure: 10 mm Hg c. Corrected Sinusoidal Pressure: 3 mm Hg  d. Right atrial: 9 mm Hg 4.  Large volume, ascites. 5. pigtail catheter projects over the right kidney  Impression:   1.	Transjugular liver biopsy.  -estimated portosystemic pressure gradient, 3 mmHg.   2. large-volume paracentesis   Treatment Plan:  Follow up pathology results.  Technique:  The procedure, options, and risks were reviewed with patient, including bleeding, infection, and pneumothorax. A time out was performed before initiating the procedure.  The skin overlying the access sites were subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). Patient sedation was performed, as detailed below.  Paracentesis: A limited ultrasound of the abdomen was performed and the largest pocket of fluid identified in the right lower abdomen. The site was marked for paracentesis. Local anesthesia was achieved at the skin entry site using 2% lidocaine.  An 8-Fr. x 25 cm pigtail catheter was inserted into the peritoneum at the marked site using trocar technique.  A total of 9 L of clear yellow ascitic fluid was drained; no laboratory analysis requested.  Fluid volume resuscitation was via the intravenous administration of salt-poor Albumin  Transjugular liver biopsy: With the patient in the supine position, sterile technique and sonographic guidance were used to gain 21-g needle access to the right internal jugular vein (RIJV).  Exchange was made over an 0.018-in Cope wire for a 5-Fr. micropuncture set.  This afforded 0.035-in Rosen wire exchange for a 9-Fr. x 30 cm introducer sheath, with the distal tip advanced to the right atrium.  Through the sheath, a 5.Fr. MPA catheter was advanced, over an 0.035-in glide wire, used to cross into the inferior vena cava (IVC).  Over the catheter, the sheath was advanced to the IVC.   The catheter was then used to catheterize the right hepatic vein, then further advanced to an inferolateral wedge position over the glidewire.  This allowed for wedge pressure measurement.  Free hepatic venous pressure was measured vie the sheath, with the distal tip advanced to the hepatic venous confluence.   Exchange was then made over the Rosen wire for a 7-Fr. transjugular liver biopsy kit [Cook], with the distal tip advanced to the inferolateral right liver.  Three biopsy specimens were collected, then sent to Pathology for analysis.   Completion hepatic venogram shows no apparent complication.   All access devices were then removed, with manual compression applied to effect hemostasis.  Patient tolerated the procedure well. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by nurse present during the entire procedure. Patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Administered by the specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for a total of 44 minutes (Total intra service time).  Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.  Medications: Versed 1 mg IV. Fentanyl 50 mcg IV.      Antibiotics: None  Blood loss:  Less than 10 ml  Checklist:	Informed consent was obtained discussing the risks, benefits and alternatives to the planned procedure. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Uterine fibroids with bulk symptoms. Adenomyosis.  PROCEDURE:  1.	Ultrasound-guided left radial artery access 2.	Ultrasound-guided right common femoral artery access 3.	Pelvic angiography 4.	Uterine artery embolization 5.	Post-embolization angiography  Findings:  Vessels catheterized and angiograms performed as detailed below:  Left internal iliac artery: Markedly enlarged uterine artery with a myomatous uterus identified. Left uterine artery: Fibroid blush identified. No cervical branches.  Right internal iliac artery: Markedly enlarged uterine artery with a myomatous uterus identified. Right uterine artery: Fibroid blush identified. No cervical branches.  Left radial artery angiography: Vasospasm seen throughout the left radial artery.  Embolization:   Left uterine: 1. 1 vial 500 um Embozene 2. 1 vial 700 um Embozene  Right uterine: 1. 1 vial 500 um Embozene  Intra-arterial medication administration: 5mL preservative-free lidocaine given bilaterally, after embolization.  Hypogastric Nerve Block: Not performed.  Post-Embolization Angiograms: Left uterine artery: Sluggish flow without opacification of the uterine fibroids. Right uterine artery: Sluggish flow without opacification of the uterine fibroids.  Technical notes: After left-sided embolization was performed. [PATIENT] began experiencing left thumb and index finger paresthesias. Left radial artery angiography demonstrated vasospasm. Left thumb pulse oximetry demonstrated good waveform with 100% saturation. To avoid any further complication related to radial access, the left radial sheath was promptly removed and the remainder of the procedure was performed via right groin access.  Impression:  1. Successful bilateral uterine artery embolization utilizing Embozene particles for adenomyosis and fi[HCW].  2. Transradial access as well as transfemoral access was used for embolization due to likely left radial spasm.  Treatment Plan:  1. The patient will be monitored for 4-6 hours to assess for the need for an observation admission for pain control. 2. Patient will be discharged with a stool softener/laxative, analgesic, anti-emetic, and a narcotic for pain control. 3. Patient will follow-up in clinic with IR.  Technique:  With the patient in the supine position, the left wrist and bilateral groins were prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The left wrist was evaluated with ultrasound and left radial artery patency and acceptable size criteria were documented. Images were properly stored in PACS. A modified Allen test (Barbeau test C) was performed on the left wrist to confirm patency of the ulnopalmar arch using pulse oximetry.   1% lidocaine solution was administered for local anesthesia. Access was obtained to the left radial artery using a 21 gauge micro needle and ultrasound guidance. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. A wire was placed through the needle. A hydrophilic Glidesheath was advanced slowly over the wire. 3000 units of heparin, 200 mcg of nitroglycerin and 2.5 mg of verapamil was given through the arterial sheath with slow hemodilution. A side flush was started. Hypogastric nerve block, if utilized, is detailed above.  Diagnostic catheter and microcatheter were advanced through the sheath into the aorta and used to catheterize the bilateral internal iliac arteries and pelvic vessels described above. Angiograms were performed. Specific vessels catheterized and embolized are described in detail above. Post-embolization angiography was performed and described above. After completion of left-sided angiography and embolization, the patient began to experience left hand symptoms as above. The decision was made to remove all devices from the left wrist. A TR band was placed on the left wrist for hemostasis.  The access sheath was removed and no hematoma was seen. A radial artery pulse was confirmed distal to the puncture site confirming patent hemostasis.  The right common femoral artery was evaluated with ultrasound and seen to be patent. It was accessed using a 21-gauge micropuncture needle. A permanent image was stored to PACS. A wire was placed through the needle, and a 5 French vascular sheath was advanced into the right common femoral artery. Angiogram through the sheath confirmed appropriate access. The procedure was completed via right groin access.  Diagnostic catheter and microcatheter were advanced through the sheath into the aorta and used to catheterize the bilateral internal iliac arteries and pelvic vessels described above. Angiograms were performed. Specific vessels catheterized and embolized are described in detail above. Post-embolization angiography was performed and described above. All instruments and the access sheath were removed. Hemostasis was achieved using Angio-Seal closure device. There were normal right foot pulses after the procedure.  The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Dialysis patient admitted with cardiac issues developed a spontaneous left rectus sheath bleed while on heparin.   Procedure:   Selective left lower extremity arteriography Embolization of the left inferior epigastric artery Follow-up post embolization angio              Findings: Noncontrasted CT of the abdomen and pelvis from [DATE] was reviewed  1. There is dense atherosclerotic calcification of the aortoiliac branches with Monckeberg vascular calcification identified diffusely. 2. The right common femoral artery is patent and compresses. Needle entry was stored to PACS. 3. Left common iliac injection shows the presence of a corona mortis.   4. Left external iliac arteriography shows a normal left inferior epigastric arterial origin. There is no active hemorrhage identified. 5. Left inferior epigastric arteriography shows diminutive branches and no obvious extravasation. 6. After Gelfoam embolization distally, there is no significant forward flow in the left inferior epigastric artery. 7. After deploying three 3 mm x 14 cm Nester possible coils, there is no antegrade flow in the left inferior epigastric branch with significant reflux down the leg and ongoing filling of the obturator branch. 8. The right groin is scarred.   Impression:  No active hemorrhage was identified in the left inferior epigastric artery. The branch was empirically embolized with Gelfoam slurry and coils.   Technique:  The right groin was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. The femoral vessels were ultrasonographically surveyed. Patency was documented and stored to PACS.   The common femoral artery was accessed via Seldinger technique and needle entry was stored to PACS.  A short 6 French vascular sheath was placed.  Over a 0.035" wire a 4 French Sos catheter was reformed in the suprarenal abdominal aorta.  The bifurcation was traversed but the Bentson coursed into the internal iliac branch. Hand injected arteriography was performed and a Smart mask created. A Glidewire was negotiated into the external iliac artery and down the leg. The short sheath at the leg was exchanged for a long Balkan 6 French sheath. This could not be advanced over the bifurcation. An angled catheter was placed over the regular glide and the glide exchanged for a stiff glide. The sheath was then successfully advanced over the bifurcation and positioned in the contralateral, left common iliac artery.  The Cobra glide catheter was positioned in the external iliac artery and arteriography performed.  A 2.8 Progreat microcatheter was introduced coaxially and used to select the left inferior epigastric artery..   Arteriography was performed.   Embolization was carried out using Gelfoam slurry. Once antegrade flow had ceased, 3 pushable 0.018" Nester coils (3 mm x 14 cm) were sequentially deployed. An additional coil deployment was attempted, however, the device malfunctioned and the coil was deployed in the catheter hub. Contrast injection showed no forward flow in the branch and the decision was made to terminate the procedure.    The images were reviewed.  The catheter was removed over a wire. The long 6 French sheath was replaced with a short 6 French sheath. During attempt to deploy a Vascade device, the sheath was inadvertently withdrawn precluding use of the device. Hemostasis was achieved with manual compression.  No immediate complication occurred, and the patient was discharged to the recovery area in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  TAYLOR, FRED       DOB: 10/23/1942    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  CLARKE, KAREN Location:  Emory University Hospital  ESRC.IR.1  Date of exam:  1/3/2024   Clinical Indication:  Postoperative complications of right femur repair. Dysphasia requiring long-term enteral nutrition.  Procedure:   1.	Gastrostomy tube placement under fluoroscopic guidance.  Findings:   1.	Preprocedural scout imaging after gastric insufflation demonstrates adequate percutaneous window to the stomach.  2.	Gentle hand injection of contrast material confirms positioning of the gastrostomy tube within the gastric lumen. The gastrostomy tube is in good position.   Impression:   1.	Successful placement of 18 French MIC gastrostomy tube as above.  Treatment Plan:   The tube should be placed to gravity drainage and should not be used for 4 hours.   25 cc of water can be administered per hour. At 4 hours, if residuals are less than 30%, the patient can have tube feeds advanced starting at a half dose.  Technique:   The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the mid abdomen were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.   Real-time ultrasound guidance demarcated the liver edge, and physical palpation demarcated the left lowest rib. Using fluoroscopic guidance, an appropriate puncture site was identified.  2 T-fasteners were placed adjacent to the planned tube access site. Positioning of the T-fasteners within the gastric lumen was confirmed by return of air and direct injection of contrast material.  Next, under fluoroscopic guidance, an 18-gauge needle was directed into the gastric lumen. Needle positioning within the gastric lumen was confirmed with aspiration of air as well as gentle hand injection of contrast material.  A wire was advance through the 18-gauge needle.  The 18-gauge needle was removed over a wire.   An 8 mm x 4 cm Conquest balloon was loaded coaxially through An 18 French Halyard G-tube and advanced over a wire into the gastric lumen with the trailing edge of the balloon outside the skin entry site. The balloon was inflated along the skin tract until waisting of the balloon was no longer seen and the entire system was advanced under fluoroscopic guidance into the stomach. All wires and catheters were removed. The balloon was inflated with 10 mL of  sterile water. Gentle hand injection of contrast material documents the gastric feeding tube within the gastric lumen. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained for reference purposes. The tube was flushed with saline. It was affixed to the anterior abdominal wall with a rubber flange. The patient tolerated the procedure well at time of procedure completion without complication. Patient Name:  ALMAND, PAULA       DOB: 4/4/1957    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  ROMANCIK, JASON Location:  Emory University Hospital  ESRC.IR.1  Date of exam:  1/3/2024   Clinical Indication:  Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  6 F single-lumen port (standard profile)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 6 French single lumen power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 3-0 absorbable sutures.     Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with     Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication.
