DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: This is a 32 years Female who presents for diagnostic cerebral angiography following multiple CVA concerning for underlying moyamoya disease   PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 30 minutes.  OPERATORS: Brian Howard, MD was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. Jonathan Poggi, MD was the fellow. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right Internal Carotid Artery Right External Carotid Artery Left Internal Carotid Artery Left External Carotid Artery Right Vertebral Artery   ANESTHESIA: Local in the right groin with bupivacaine. Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by the nurse present during the entire procedure. The patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Sedation was administered by a specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for the duration of the procedure as outlined above (Total intra service time, 30 ). Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.   MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine SQ 10 cc Versed 0.5 mg IV Fentanyl 50 mcg IV Heparin 3000 units IA Nitroglycerin 200 mcg IA Verapamil 2.5 mg IA Protamine 20 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.035" Terumo Glidewire 5 French Terumo Slender sheath 5 French Simmons-2 diagnostic catheter  TR Band Omnipaque 300 contrast material (40 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, wrist hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed, written consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite, intubated, and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right radial artery under ultrasound guidance; a 5 French slender sheath was introduced into the right radial artery using ultrasound guidance. 3000 units of heparin, 200 mcg of nitroglycerin, 2.5 mg of verapamil were administered intra-arterially through the sheath after sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, the vessels listed above were selectively catheterized. Digital angiograms were performed of these vessels, centered over the head and neck.   Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a TR Band.  COMPARISON: Noninvasive imaging.  FINDINGS: RIGHT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. There is significant collateralization with the MCA territory on the right side via distal collaterals with the PCA territory with minimal delay in contrast filling. The bilateral AICA and SCA are normal in course caliber. In addition, Reflux of contrast into the contralateral vertebral artery was not achieved. The origin of PICA is normal unilaterally (we will defer to CTA for evaluation of the contralateral PICA).   RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is occlusion of the origin of the right MCA with mild nonflow limiting stenosis of the distal ICA. This is concordant with the noninvasive imaging. There there is significant neovascularization at the distal ICA which supplies a portion of the middle cerebral artery territory as well as numerous pial collaterals with the ACA territory supplying the majority of the hemisphere. There is minimal delay in contrast filling of the MCA territory through these collaterals. There is no aneurysm or early draining vein are identified. There is normal cortical venous drainage.  RIGHT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is mild to moderate stenosis at the distal ICA as well as moderate to severe stenosis of the origin of the left MCA consistent with early stage of moyamoya disease. The branches of the ACA and MCA are normal in course and caliber distal to the A1 and M1 segments respectively. There is no aneurysm or early draining vein are identified. There is normal cortical venous drainage.  LEFT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.    COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: The right internal carotid artery demonstrates occlusion of the origin of the right MCA with mild to moderate stenosis at the distal ICA while the left internal carotid has mild to moderate stenosis at the distal ICA with moderate to severe stenosis of the M1 segment of the left MCA. This is consistent with moyamoya disease. The right MCA territory is supplied primarily by distal collaterals from the PCA and ACA territories. There is mild delay in filling of the MCA territory via these distal collaterals.  [HCW], was present for the key and critical portions of the procedure and associated imaging guidance.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Hematuria. Conversion of right nephroureteral catheter to nephrostomy tube has been requested.  Procedure:   1.	Right nephrostogram(s) and nephrostomy tube replacement  Comparison: Previous exam [DATE], [DATE].  Findings:    1.	Existing nephrostomy tube(s) in appropriate position on scout radiograph. There is a right nephroureteral catheter. On the left side, there is a nephrostomy tube and a double-J ureteral stent. 2.	Nephrostography demonstrates hydronephrosis without drainage into the urinary bladder.   Catheter:  8.5 F Cook nephrostomy tube(s)  Impression:   1.	Uneventful image-guided nephrostomy tube re-placement. The existing nephroureteral catheter was exchanged for a new right-sided nephrostomy tube. The existing catheter(s) and surrounding soft tissues were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). Non-ionic contrast was injected through the existing right nephroureteral catheter and images of the collecting system obtained and stored to PACS.  An 0.035” wire was advanced through the right nephroureteral tube. The tube was removed over the wire under direct fluoroscopic visualization. A new nephrostomy tube was advanced over the wire and the Cope loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis. Contrast injection confirmed appropriate location. The catheter was sutured to the flank with monofilament suture and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.  The procedure was well tolerated, and patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Pancreatic mass with biliary obstruction.   Procedures:   Cholangiogram through existing catheter Biliary covered metallic stent placement Biliary catheter replacement             Findings: Comparison is made with replacement images from [DATE]. Abdominal MRI with MRCP from [DATE] was reviewed.  1. A small peritoneal loop is present on the scout film, easily reduced with gentle traction. 2. A long stricture extends from the cystic duct insertion to the ampulla,  3. After deploying the first stent, there is poor washout. After a second stent was deployed extending toward the duodenum, there is improved flow through the stent into duodenum. 4. The gallbladder fills. 5.  The new 12 French internal/external biliary drain has its distal tip in the duodenum beyond the stent and sideholes extending into the right hepatic ducts.    Impression:  Malignant stricture of the common bile duct. A covered stent was successfully placed with persistently poor drainage. This prompted replacement of the 12 French internal/external biliary drain with removal of the string mechanism and capping.  The intrahepatic bile ducts are not significantly dilated.  Treatment Plan:  Follow-up as scheduled for one month to assess the parenchymal tract and flow through the stents.  Technique:     The existing catheter and surrounding soft tissues were prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site. The existing 12 French catheter was removed over an Amplatz wire. A short 10 French sheath was placed. A long coaxial sheath was placed and a pullback cholangiogram performed to assess stricture length. A marker pigtail was advanced over the wire and stent length determined.  A 10 mm x 10 cm covered viable stent was positioned fluoroscopically and deployed. It opened completely. Contrast injection showed persistent holdup with poor drainage to the duodenum. The stent was felt to be short and a second stent (10 mm x 6 cm) was deployed into the duodenum. Contrast injection showed persistently poor drainage with adequate stent positioning. The common hepatic duct was extremely dilated with initial cholangiography and it may simply be a system with large capacitance.  Over the Amplatz, a modified 12 French internal/external biliary drain was placed and positioned fluoroscopically. The string mechanism was removed to prevent entanglement with the duodenal stent at future intervention. Contrast injection confirmed appropriate positioning. The tube was sutured in place and capped.  Because of frequent dislodgment, a Percu-Stay device was utilized.  The procedure was well poorly tolerated, but the patient was discharged in satisfactory condition. After placement of the large bore central venous catheter, as described, the tip terminates near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1. CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM AND ENDOVASCULAR PIPELINE EMBOLIZATION OF A RIGHT SUPERIOR HYPOPHYSEAL ARTERY ANEURYSM  PROCEDURE:  1.	Cerebral angiogram  2.	Endovascular pipeline embolization 3.	Intra-arterial infusion of nonthrombolytic in pulse spray fashion over 10 minutes  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 1 hours.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] was the fellow. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS CATHETERIZED: Right internal carotid artery Right common femoral artery  VESSELS TREATED (in sequence): Right internal carotid artery  ANESTHESIA: General endotracheal anesthesia. Pre-, intra-, and post-anesthesia monitoring records are available in the chart.  MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine 10 cc SQ Heparin 5000 units IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 6 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 0.035" Bentson Guidewire 0.035" Terumo Glidewire (180 cm) Benchmark long sheath (95 cm) Phenom 27 microcatheter (150 cm) Asahi 018 microguidewire (200 cm) 4.75 mm x 14 mm pipeline embolization device 6 French Angio-Seal closure device Omnipaque-300 contrast (80 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, stent thrombosis/stenosis, stent migration, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, non-target embolization, puncture site hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed, written consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite, intubated, and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 6 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 5000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement; additional boluses of heparin were administered at one-hour intervals. The ACT was checked to ensure that it was between 250-300. Using fluoroscopic guidance, benchmark was advanced into the right internal carotid artery. Digital angiograms were performed in the AP, lateral and oblique projections centered over the head and neck.   3D rotational angiography was performed with the long selection catheter in the right internal carotid artery artery to better delineate the aneurysm and parent vessel. The acquisition was processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.   Through the long selection catheter, 5 mg of intra-arterial milrinone was administered in the right internal carotid artery in pulse spray fashion over 10 minutes for treatment of catheter associated vasospasm.  Over the long selection catheter and 0.035" Terumo Glidewire, the benchmark guide catheter was successfully advanced into the distal internal carotid artery. The Glidewire and long selection catheter were then removed. Through the long sheath a Phenom 27 microcatheter and Asahi 018 microguidewire was advanced into intracranial internal carotid artery.    A working projection was obtained to best demonstrate the neck of the superior hypophyseal aneurysm, as well as, the distal and proximal landing zones for the stent. Superselective catheterization of the right middle cerebral artery was performed with the Phenom 27 microcatheter over the Asahi 018 microguidewire. The tip of the microguidewire was situated in the M1 segment of the MCA. The microguidewire in the pipeline catheter was then exchanged for a 4.75 mm x 14 mm pipeline embolization device. The device was deployed under fluoroscopic guidance and a single shot X-ray was performed to confirm that the distal and proximal ends of the pipeline embolization device were in the communicating segment and right ICA cavernous segment, respectively. Postprocessing of the pipeline embolization device was performed with a curved microwire with successful improvement in apposition of the proximal and distal aspects of the device.  A final AP and Lateral angiogram were completed to evaluate the distal vasculature for perfusion deficits and emboli.   After completion of the procedure, the arteriotomy was above the level of the bifurcation and the CFA was of sufficient size to use the 6 French Angio-Seal closure device. Ancef was administered. The sheath was removed and hemostasis obtained using the 6 French Angio-Seal closure device. A Tegaderm were then applied over the puncture site.  COMPARISON: Prior angiogram from [DATE].  FINDINGS:  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: The previously identified right superior hypophyseal artery aneurysm measuring 4.5 x 5 mm is unchanged in appearance. The ACA and MCA and its branches are normal in course and caliber. There is early washout of the ACA territory suggesting competitive flow from the contralateral hemisphere.  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-PIPELINE EMBOLIZATION): he pipeline device has been deployed across the aneurysm neck in the distal internal carotid artery. There remains a small endoleak proximally as well as poor wall apposition distally. The decision was made to proceed with postprocessing with the microwire.  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-PROCESSING): The Pipeline device is well apposed to the vessel walls throughout it's course without endoleak. Stasis of contrast is noted within the aneurysm. . No perfusion deficits to suggest distal emboli are present.  3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY: A 3D rotational angiogram of the right internal carotid artery was completed and post-processed on an independent work station. 3D angiography revealed the previously described 4.5 x 5 mm inferiorly directed superior hypophyseal artery aneurysm without irregular features.  RIGHT COMMON FEMORAL ARTERY: No abnormalities are detected. The arteriotomy was above the level of the bifurcation and the CFA was of sufficient size to use the 6 French Angio-Seal closure device.   COMPLICATIONS: none immediate.  IMPRESSION:  1.	Successful deployment of a pipeline flow diverting device across the previously described 4.5 x 5 mm inferiorly directed right superior hypophyseal artery aneurysm. Final angiogram demonstrates good wall apposition without evidence of endoleak.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESR[HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Patient with colon cancer requiring IV chemotherapy  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen Bard port (standard profile)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen Bard power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed below.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 3-0 absorbable sutures. A running 4-0 absorbable subcuticular stitch and  Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with     Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  47 year old male with lymphoma needing central venous access for initiation of chemotherapy. VAT team did not feel his arm vasculature was of adequate size for them to place a PICC at bedside.   Procedure:   1.	Double lumen PICC placement using ultrasound and fluoroscopy      Findings:   1.  Vein patency was documented by ultrasound and stored to PACS. 2.  The catheter tip terminates near the cavoatrial junction.        Impression:   1.	Uneventful image guided placement of 5 French, 43 cm double-lumen PICC in the left upper extremity as described. The lumens flush and aspirate appropriately.        Treatment Plan:   Catheter tip position is confirmed as above. It is OK to use this line.       Technique:   The site was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).   Ultrasound evaluation of the left brachial vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS. Local anesthetic was used over the access site. Under ultrasound guidance, the left brachial vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS.    A 0.018" wire was passed centrally and the needle exchanged for a dilator peel-away combination. The wire was used to determine catheter length, and a 5 French double-lumen PICC line cut to appropriate length. The tailored catheter was advanced through the peel-away and positioned centrally using fluoroscopy.   The peel-away was removed, and hemostasis achieved with manual compression. The catheter was aspirated, flushed, and locked per [HCW]ol. It was secured in place with Ethilon.  An antimicrobial disc and sterile dressing were applied.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  83 y/o female with PMH T5 and new acute T6 compression fracture, as patient presents with [HOSPITAL] in the setting of worsening back pain since clinic visit on [DATE]. She has had thoracic pain has been ongoing since [DATE], but patient was unable to seek care with a prior physician who had incidentally taken care of a T7 fracture which resolved her pain symptoms. No motor changes. Intermittent numbness that shoots down the left hand.   Additional Clinical Indication: Subacute (6-12 weeks) T5 and T6 osteoporotic vertebral body/vertebral bodies compression fracture(s). Spine MRI/bone-scan is within 30 days of this procedure and was performed on [DATE]. Patient has severe back pain despite optimal non-surgical management with severe impact of vertebral body compression fracture(s) on daily functioning. Patient has kyphotic deformity due to vertebral body compression fracture(s).     Procedure:   1.	Image-guided kyphoplasty of T5 and T6    2.	Findings:   1.	Pre-intervention: Noted T5 compression fracture and worsening T6 compression fracture. 2.	Post-intervention:  Successful deposition of cement within the treated vertebral body/bodies with mild focal contained anterior extravasation at T5.    Impression:   1.	Successful image guided augmentation of vertebral levels: T5 and T6    Treatment Plan:   1.	 A fracture of the hip, spine or distal radius in patients over 50 years of age warrants testing or treatment for osteoporosis if not previously undertaken.   Patient was instructed to take part in an osteoporosis prevention/treatment program.   Technique:   The patient was brought to the interventional radiology suite and placed on the table in prone position. The wide area of the back around the affected area(s) was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion.   All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). A scout image was obtained in AP and lateral projections.   Skin was anesthetized with a 2% lidocaine solution.   Level by level technique:   -Vertebral level:  T5 kyphoplasty -Pedicle access:  Bipedicular -Access trocar gauge:  10-gauge -Balloon utilized:  15 mm  Prior to injection of cement, balloons were inserted and inflated under biplane fluoroscopy.  Static fluoroscopic images were stored to PACS documenting balloon utilization and position. -Biopsy obtained:  No -Indication for biopsy: N/A -Ablation Performed: N/A -Indication for Ablation: N/A  Vertebral level:  T6 kyphoplasty -Pedicle access:  Unipedicular -Access trocar gauge:  10-gauge -Balloon utilized:  15 mm  Prior to injection of cement, balloons were inserted and inflated under biplane fluoroscopy.  Static fluoroscopic images were stored to PACS documenting balloon utilization and position. -Biopsy obtained:  No -Indication for biopsy: N/A -Ablation Performed: N/A -Indication for Ablation: N/A  Additional Procedural Details:   Utilizing AP and lateral fluoroscopy, needles were inserted into the affected vertebral body/bodies. Needles were advanced under careful, intermittent biplane fluoroscopy to ensure that the medial wall of the pedicle was not violated prior to transgression of the needle tip into the posterior wall of the vertebral body. The drill was then advanced to the anterior one-third of the vertebral body on each side.  No ablation was performed.  Balloon(s) was/were inserted into the effected vertebral body/bodies and inflated under fluoroscopy. Static fluoroscopic images were stored to PACS documenting balloon position. Cement was mixed and balloons were removed after being deflated.  Cement was then injected under careful, intermittent biplane fluoroscopy to ensure no significant extravasation of PMMA cement beyond the borders of the vertebral body. Cement injection was stopped once there was adequate fill of the vertebral body. Trochars were removed with hemostasis obtained with focal compression. Static fluoroscopic images were obtained after removal of all needles documenting final cement position. DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 45 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] was the fellow. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right Internal Carotid Artery Right external carotid artery Left Internal Carotid Artery Left Vertebral Artery Right Vertebral Artery  ANESTHESIA: General anesthesia, see anesthesia MAR.  MEDICATIONS:  Heparin 3000 units IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.035" Bentson guidewire 5 French Boston Scientific sheath 4 French Berenstein Glide catheter  Mynx Closure Device Visipaque-270 contrast material (120 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 5 French sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP, Lateral and Oblique views.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY:  Rotational angiography was also performed from the diagnostic catheter in the right internal carotid artery for better delineation of the underlying angioarchitecture. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.    3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY:  Rotational angiography was also performed from the diagnostic catheter in the right internal carotid artery for better delineation of the underlying angioarchitecture. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.    Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a Mynx Closure Device followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: Noninvasive imaging.  FINDINGS: RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is a small aneurysm originating from the posterior wall of the proximal A1 segment of the ACA which is only clearly visualized on the three-dimensional reconstructions. The distal ACA and its branches are normal course and caliber. There is an anterior communicating artery with brief filling of the contralateral ACA territory. The distal ICA and its segments are normal in course and caliber . The MCA and its branches are normal course and caliber.   RIGHT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. The distal ICA and its segments are normal in course and caliber. The ACA and MCA and its branches are normal in course and caliber. There is normal cortical venous drainage.   LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. Reflux of contrast into the right vertebral artery was not achieved. The origin of left PICA is normal.   RIGHT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. Reflux of contrast into the left vertebral artery was not achieved. The right anterior inferior cerebellar artery is dominant and appears to supply the PICA territory. There is early contrast washout likely due to the proximal location of the diagnostic catheter.  3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: 3D Rotational angiography with volume-rendered three-dimensional reconstruction on an independent workstation, demonstrated a 1.5 x 1.5 x 1 mm irregularly-shaped aneurysm originating from the posterior wall of the proximal A1 segment of the right ACA.  3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: 3D Rotational angiography with volume-rendered three-dimensional reconstruction on an independent workstation, demonstrated no underlying aneurysmal dilatation.   COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: There is a 1.5 x 1.5 x 1 mm irregularly-shaped aneurysm originating from the posterior wall of the proximal A1 segment of the right ACA. This is likely the source the patient's underlying subarachnoid hemorrhage. No other vascular abnormalities are visualized in this angiogram.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  right breast cancer post right modified radical mastectomy - ready for port for chemo treatments  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen Bard port (standard profile)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen Bard power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 3-0 absorbable sutures. A running 4-0 absorbable subcuticular stitch and  steri-strips were used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with steri-strips.  The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by nurse present during the entire procedure. Patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the [HOSPITAL]rtment. Tunneled central venous catheter placement       Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the tunneled catheter, as described, the tip terminates near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1. DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM, SOLUMBRA THROMBECTOMY  CLINICAL INDICATION: This is a 46 years year old Female who presents with an acute stroke syndrome secondary to a right M1 occlusion.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 100 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW], was the attending physician. He supervised the entire procedure. [HCW] was the fellow. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right Common Carotid Artery Right Internal Carotid Artery Right common femoral artery  ANESTHESIA: General anesthesia. Pre-, intra-, and post-anesthesia monitoring records are available in the chart.  Intubation was performed in part due to medical necessity  MEDICATIONS:  Heparin 5000 units IV Ancef 2 g IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 8 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 8 French Walrus balloon guide catheter 0.035" [HCW] Guidewire 0.035" [HCW] Guidewire, exchange length 5 French Simmons 3 Glide catheter Asahi 018 microguidewire Trak 21 microcatheter RED 68 Aspiration Catheter Trevo NXT 4 x 41 Stentriever device  Mynx closure device Omnipaque-300 contrast (120 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient's family (medical proxy). Specifically, the risks of intracranial or systemic hemorrhage, cerebral infarction, distal emboli, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, device malfunction, groin hematoma, arterial dissection/laceration, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite, intubated, and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; an 8 French sheath was introduced into the right common femoral artery. The 8 French balloon guide-catheter and diagnostic catheter were introduced into the right common carotid artery as a system. A roadmap angiogram was completed of the common carotid artery to visualize the carotid bifurcation. The diagnostic catheter was then used to select the internal carotid artery over the guidewire. The balloon guide catheter was then advanced into the cervical internal carotid artery over the wire and diagnostic catheter. The wire and diagnostic catheter were then removed and the balloon guide was connected to a continual heparinized saline flush. Digital angiograms were performed centered over the head.   The initial TICI score was 0 secondary to a right M1 occlusion.  A triaxial system of the aspiration catheter, microcatheter, and microguidewire were advanced into the internal carotid artery over roadmap guidance. The Trak 21 microcatheter and Asahi 018 microwire were then advanced through the aspiration catheter past the M1 occlusion. A microrun confirmed intravascular placement.  The aspiration catheter was then tracked to the face of the clot. The wire was removed from the microcatheter and replaced with the Trevo NXT 4 x 41 stentriever device.  The stentriever was deployed under fluoroscopy and the allowed to set in the clot for 5 minutes. The microcatheter was removed so that that the stentriever was "naked" in the aspiration catheter. The balloon on the guide catheter was then inflated. The stentriever was then removed under continuous aspiration using a 60cc syringe. Thrombus was  identified within the stentriever device and the aspirate.  The balloon on the guide was deflated and a cerebral angiogram was performed through the guide catheter. Recanalization of the M1 was achieved with revascularization of the distal territory consistent with TICI 1. The remained clot in multiple M2 branches.   A triaxial system of the aspiration catheter, microcatheter, and microguidewire were again advanced into the internal carotid artery over roadmap guidance. The Trak 21 microcatheter and Asahi 018 microwire were then advanced through the aspiration catheter past the M1 occlusion for second pass. A microrun confirmed intravascular placement.  The aspiration catheter was then tracked to the face of the clot. The wire was removed from the microcatheter and replaced with the Trevo NXT 4 x 41 stentriever device.  The stentriever was deployed under fluoroscopy and the allowed to set in the clot for 5 minutes. The microcatheter was removed so that that the stentriever was "naked" in the aspiration catheter. The balloon on the guide catheter was then inflated. The stentriever was then removed under continuous aspiration using a 60cc syringe. Thrombus was  identified within the stentriever device.  The balloon on the guide was deflated and a cerebral angiogram was performed through the guide catheter. Recanalization of the inferior division of the MCA was achieved with revascularization of the distal territory consistent with TICI 2b.  A triaxial system of the aspiration catheter, microcatheter, and microguidewire were again advanced into the internal carotid artery over roadmap guidance. The Trak 21 microcatheter and Asahi 018 microwire were then advanced through the aspiration catheter past the M1 occlusion for third pass. A microrun confirmed intravascular placement.  The aspiration catheter was then tracked to the face of the clot. The wire was removed from the microcatheter and replaced with the Trevo NXT 4 x 41 stentriever device.  The stentriever was deployed under fluoroscopy and the allowed to set in the clot for 5 minutes. The microcatheter was removed so that that the stentriever was "naked" in the aspiration catheter. The balloon on the guide catheter was then inflated. The stentriever was then removed under continuous aspiration using a 60cc syringe. Thrombus was  identified within the stentriever device.  The balloon on the guide was deflated and a cerebral angiogram was performed through the guide catheter. Recanalization of the right MCA was achieved with revascularization of the distal territory consistent with TICI 3.  A final run of the cervical segment of the right internal carotid artery was performed given the unstable plaque noted on initial imaging.  An angiogram of the right common femoral artery was obtained; the artery was deemed appropriate for use of the mynx closure device. The sheath was removed and hemostasis obtained by deployment of the mynx closure device. A Tegaderm was then applied over the puncture site.  COMPARISON: Non-invasive imaging, same day  FINDINGS:  RIGHT  COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CERVICAL: There is unstable plaque located at the origin of the cervical portion of the right internal carotid artery which is highly irregular. The ECA branches opacify normally.  RIGHT  INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: A right M1 occlusion is identified consistent with TICI 0.  RIGHT  INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-THROMBECTOMY, 1st pass): Reperfusion has been reestablished consistent with TICI 1. There is severe spasm noted in the M1 segment of the MCA with clot noted in multiple M2 branches of the MCA.  RIGHT  INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-THROMBECTOMY, 2nd pass):  Reperfusion has been reestablished consistent with TICI 2b. There remains clot noted in the superior division of the right MCA. The previously identified right M1 segment vasospasm is markedly improved following administration of vasodilators.  RIGHT  INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-THROMBECTOMY, 3rd pass):  Reperfusion has been reestablished consistent with TICI 3.   RIGHT  COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CERVICAL: The majority of the previously identified unstable plaque is no longer visible suggesting that it was removed during one of the thrombectomy passes. There remains mild mild to moderate stenosis at the origin of the right ICA. The ECA branches opacify normally.  RIGHT FEMORAL ARTERY: No abnormalities are detected. This vessel is suitable for use of a closure device.  COMPLICATIONS: none immediate.  IMPRESSION:  1. Right M1 occlusion with initial occlusion consistent with TICI 0.  2. Status-post 3 pass thrombectomy with resultant TICI 3. Prior to intervention, there was unstable plaque noted at the origin of the right ICA, this was improved following mechanical thrombectomy suggesting removal of the majority of this plaque during the thrombectomy procedure.

No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. The distal ICA and its segments are normal in course and caliber. The ACA and MCA and its branches are normal in course and caliber. There is normal cortical venous drainage.   LEFT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is a small right occipital pial arteriovenous malformation supplied by a distal branch of the posterior cerebral artery with drainage primarily via a single ectatic cortical vein draining into the basal vein of Rosenthal and vein of Galen. There is no prenatal or nidal aneurysm identified. Reflux of contrast into the contralateral vertebral artery was achieved. The origin of PICA is normal bilaterally.    COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: There is a small right occipital pial arteriovenous malformation supplied by distal branch of the right posterior cerebral artery with drainage via a single ectatic cortical vein into the basal vein of Rosenthal and vein of Galen. No other aneurysm or vascular malformation is identified.  [HCW], was present for the key and critical portions of the procedure and associated imaging guidance.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Endocarditis, bacteremia. Right pleural effusion.  Procedure:  1. Fluoroscopic guided exchange of left groin tunneled hemodialysis catheter - 50cm tip-to-cuff 2. Ultrasound and fluoroscopic guided right chest tube placement  Findings:  1. Scout image demonstrates existing left groin tunneled hemodialysis catheter tip positioned in the right atrium. 2. Newly exchanged left groin tunneled hemodialysis catheter is appropriately positioned with the tip in the right atrium. 3. Small loculated right hemothorax. 4. Successful placement of right chest tube - mid axillary line, posterior course. 5. Small volume of dark red blood products draining from newly placed chest tube.  Impression:  1. Uneventful image guided wire exchange of left groin tunneled hemodialysis catheter. 2. Successful right chest tube placement as above.  Plan:  1. Left groin tunneled hemodialysis catheter is ready for immediate use.  2. Maintain newly placed 12Fr mid-axillary line right chest tube to continuous 20cm H2O suction, record output.  Further management per primary team  Technique:  PermCath exchange:  The left groin and area immediately around the existing double lumen tunneled hemodialysis catheter was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier.  Using local anesthetic, the tract was anesthetized. Utilizing a hemostat, the tract was accessed and the cuff freed from the surrounding soft tissues. 2 stiff glide wires were advanced through the catheter and into the SVC. The catheter was then pulled with gentle traction until it was completely removed over the wire.   A new identical catheter was advanced over the wires until the tip was positioned appropriately and the cuff positioned within the tunnel. Prolene suture was placed at the catheter tunnel exit site. An antimicrobial disc and sterile dressing were applied.  The catheter was aspirated, flushed, and heparinized per protocol.  Right chest tube placement:  Target: Right pleural effusion Imaging: US+fluoro Drain: 12 French Cook multipurpose drain Drainage: Small volume of dark red serosanguinous fluid aspirated during procedure  A superficial skin entry site was selected based on available imaging and the overlying skin entry site was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier to target the above collection. The skin surface was anesthetized with 1-2% lidocaine. Using continuous real-time grayscale and/or color doppler ultrasound guidance, a needle was introduced into the target site and imaging guidance confirmed adequate positioning. The access device was utilized with an 0.035" wire to introduce the drainage catheter listed above following any necessary serial dilatation. Ultrasound images confirmed appropriate positioning within the target structure. The catheter was secured to the skin surface using nonabsorbable suture material and dressed in typical fashion. Any samples not sent to laboratory for analysis were discarded. The patient tolerated the procedure and was sent to the recovery area for monitoring. INTRA-OPERATIVE CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: Status-post clip sacrifice of right A1 segment for A1 segment aneurysm. Intra-operative angiography was requested.  PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: 20 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending. [HCW] was the fellow. [HCW] interpreted the images.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right internal carotid artery Left internal carotid artery  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.038" Bentson Guidewire  4 French Terumo Pinnacle Sheath 4 French Berenstein Glide catheter Omnipaque-300 contrast material (40 cc)  ANESTHESIA: The patient was under general anesthesia in the operating room.  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient's family (medical proxy).. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed. Informed consent was obtained as part of general consent for the craniotomy.  In the operating room, the patient's right groin was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. Puncture of the right common femoral artery was performed and a 4 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath was placed using sterile Seldinger technique. The sheath was continuously perfused with heparinized saline before and during the surgery.  Following surgical clipping of the A1 segment aneurysm, an intra-operative angiogram was performed using portable fluoroscopic equipment in the operating room. The 4 French Vertebral catheter was placed into the right and left internal carotid arteries using a 0.035" Bentson guidewire. Cerebral angiograms were then completed in AP and lateral projections.  After completion of the angiogram, the vascular sheath was removed and hemostasis obtained using manual compression.  COMPARISON: Prior angiogram from [DATE].  FINDINGS:  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: The distal ICA and its segments are normal in course and caliber. The MCA branches are normal course and caliber. The ACA and its branches are no longer visualized following surgical clipping of the A1 segment of the ACA.  No evidence of distal emboli is seen.   LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: The distal ICA and its segments are normal in course and caliber. The MCA branches are normal course and caliber. The bilateral ACA territories fill from the A1 segment of the left ACA.  No evidence of distal emboli is seen.   COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: Successful clip sacrifice of the right A1 segment of the ACA for a small right A1 segment aneurysm. The bilateral ACA territories fill from the left internal carotid injection. There is no evidence of residual aneurysm or distal emboli.

Patient's Name: [PATIENT] MRN: [ID] [DATE] 4:20 PM  IR GASTROSTOMY TUBE  Indications: Patient presented with a leaking torn G-tube. Request is made for IR placement.  Procedure: After explaining the technique, risks, benefits, alternatives, and answering all questions, informed consent was obtained from the patient's next of kin, his mother. Timeout identifying the correct patient, procedure, site, allergies was performed and observed by the operating team. The patient was positioned supine. The procedure is performed under continuous physiologic monitoring. An old G-tube is seen in the left upper abdominal quadrant with no evidence of inflammation. However, the balloon port is torn. The stoma site was prepped with chlorhexidine  and draped in a sterile fashion.  Initial fluoroscopic evaluation revealed contrast within the balloon of the G-tube. Contrast was then injected and observed under fluoroscopy through the existing G-tube. The balloon of the G-tube was in the distal duodenum. Local anesthesia using lidocaine 1% with epinephrine was infiltrated at the stoma site. A 0.035 " guidewire was advanced through the G-tube under fluoroscopy. Attempts were made to deflate the retaining balloon culminating to percutaneous puncture using a 25G spinal needle. The overall G-tube was removed intact. Using a 5F Kumpe catheter over a 0.035 " Amplatz guidewire, the tract was cannulated tendon into the existing guidewire successfully and the wire advanced through the stomach/pylorus   . After removal of the initial guidewire and over the Amplatz guidewire, a 22F MIC  G-tube was placed with the internal length of 2 cm. The retaining balloon was inflated using 8 mL of normal saline with very diluted contrast. Contrast was then injected and aspirated under fluoroscopy revealing good intragastric position with no evidence of extravasation or leakage. Hemostasis was secured. Sterile occlusive dressing was applied. The patient tolerated to the procedure well. There were no intraprocedural complications. The G-tube is ready to use. The patient was transferred to recovery in stable condition and eventually discharged. Of note, internal holes were identified in the old G-tube and the possibility of peritoneal soiling cannot be entirely excluded. The patient was given Ancef 2 g IV and will need to be monitored for possible infection and the need to continue antibiotics. Please also refer to the Procedure note placed in the patient's EPIC chart on the date of the procedure.  Fluoroscopy time:  00:59.9 min.  Device implanted: [HOSPITAL]  Ref [ID], LOT #[ID].  Recommendations: The patient will need check and exchange of the G-tube every 3 months or earlier if the need arises..  Fellows: None. Residents: None.  IMPRESSION: 1. Uneventful G-tube exchange. The G-tube is ready to use. 2. The patient was given Ancef 2 g IV as the old tube demonstrated internal holes with the possible peritoneal soiling.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Multiple myeloma  Procedure:  1. Ultrasound and Fluoroscopic guided placement of a tunneled, cuffed central venous catheter  Findings:  1. The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and normal. Vein patency and needle entry were stored to PACS. 2. The newly placed catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating in the right atrium.  Impression:   Uneventful image guided placement of right internal jugular vein tunneled Trifusion catheter as described.  Technique:  The right neck and chest region was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. The region was ultrasonographically evaluated.  Using local anesthetic and ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was punctured with a 21 gauge needle.  An image documenting vein patency and needle entry was saved and stored to PACS.   A 0.018” wire was passed centrally and the needle exchanged for a 5 French transitional dilator. A 0.035” wire was advanced through the dilator and negotiated into the IVC.  The skin tract was dilated and a 13 French dilator peel-away combination placed over the wire.  The soft tissues caudal and lateral to the sheath entry site were anesthetized with lidocaine with epinephrine. A dermatotomy was made and a tunneling tool brought from the dermatotomy to the venotomy. The catheter was brought through the tunnel.  During suspended respiration, the catheter was advanced through the peel-away and positioned centrally using fluoroscopy. The peel-away was removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression.  The venotomy was closed with Dermabond and Steri-Strips applied. A single Prolene suture was placed at the catheter tunnel exit site. An antimicrobial disc and sterile dressing were applied.  The catheter was aspirated, flushed, and heparinized per protocol. The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient was discharged in satisfactory condition. DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: This is a 60 years Female who presents for diagnostic cerebral angiography following prior pipeline embolization of a left lenticulostriate aneurysm and a right ophthalmic artery segment aneurysm   PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 30 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] was the fellow. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right Internal Carotid Artery Left Internal Carotid Artery Left Vertebral Artery   ANESTHESIA: Local in the right groin with bupivacaine. Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by the nurse present during the entire procedure. The patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Sedation was administered by a specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for the duration of the procedure as outlined above (Total intra service time, 30 ). Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.  MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine SQ 10 cc  Versed 1 mg IV Fentanyl 50 mcg IV Heparin 3000 units IV Protamine 20 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.038" Bentson guidewire 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 5 French Cordis Vertebral catheter  Cardiva Vascade Visipaque-270 contrast material (120 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 5 French sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP, Lateral and Oblique views.   Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a Vascade followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: Noninvasive imaging.  FINDINGS:  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: The previously placed right ICA stent is patent and without in-stent stenosis. There is no residual ICA aneurysm. The MCA and its branches are normal course and caliber. The A1 segment of the right ACA is diminutive in size although the distal ACA wrenches appear normal in course and caliber. There is normal cortical venous drainage.  LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: The previously deployed left ICA stent is patent and without in-stent stenosis. There is no residual aneurysm. There is a small left posterior communicating artery infundibulum without aneurysmal features. The the ACA and MCA and its branches are normal in course and caliber. The bilateral ACA territories fill from the left A1 segment which is concordant with the contralateral injection.  LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. Reflux of contrast into the contralateral vertebral artery was not achieved. The origin of PICA is normal unilaterally (we will defer to CTA for evaluation of the contralateral PICA). This run is limited by early washout of contrast into the distal location of the catheter.   COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: No residual filling of the previously described bilateral ICA aneurysms. The bilateral flow diverting stents are patent and without in-stent stenosis.  [HCW], was present for the key and critical portions of the procedure and associated imaging guidance.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Sickle cell disease requiring hemapheresis  Procedure:   1. After placement of the large bore central venous catheter, as described, the tip terminates in the IVC.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a 14 French,  30 cm, non-tunneled large bore central venous catheter via the right common femoral vein.  Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Port or Reservoir infection; Site infection  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen Bard port (standard profile)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen Bard power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 2-0 absorbable sutures. A running 4-0 absorbable subcuticular stitch and  Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with a single subcuticular stitch and Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Heart failure  Procedure:   1.	Single lumen PICC placement using ultrasound and fluoroscopy      Findings:   1.  Vein patency was documented by ultrasound and stored to PACS. 2. Central venous stenosis making catheter advancement very difficult, ultimately requiring a 0.035 inch guidewire and a long peel-away sheath. Impossible to place a double lumen PICC using these methods. 3.  The catheter tip terminates near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Uneventful image guided placement of 5 French, 41 cm single-lumen PICC in the right upper extremity as described. The lumens flush and aspirate appropriately.        Treatment Plan:   Catheter tip position is confirmed as above. It is OK to use this line.       Technique:   The site was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).   Ultrasound evaluation of the right brachial vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS. Local anesthetic was used over the access site. Under ultrasound guidance, the right brachial vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS.    A 0.018" wire was passed centrally and the needle exchanged for a dilator peel-away combination. A double lumen PICC could not be advanced over the wire past a central stenosis. An .035 inch wire was advanced past the central stenosis into the inferior vena cava, and a long peel-away sheath was advanced over this wire, past the central stenosis. Next, a 5 French single-lumen PICC line was cut to appropriate length and advanced through the peel-away and positioned centrally using fluoroscopy.   The peel-away and wire were removed, and hemostasis achieved with manual compression. The catheter was aspirated, flushed, and locked per protocol. It was secured in place with Ethilon.  An antimicrobial disc and sterile dressing were applied.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Spine MRI/bone-scan is within 30 days of this procedure and was performed on [DATE]. Patient has severe back pain despite optimal non-surgical management with severe impact of vertebral body compression fracture(s) on daily functioning. Patient has kyphotic deformity due to vertebral body compression fracture(s).     Procedure:   1.	Image-guided kyphoplasty  2.	 Findings:   1.	Pre-intervention: Redemonstration of subtle endplate changes and L1, L3, and L5 2.	Post-intervention:  Successful deposition of cement within the treated vertebral body/bodies with no evidence of extravas[HCW].    Impression:   1.	Successful image guided augmentation of vertebral levels: L1, L3, and L5    Treatment Plan:   1.	 A fracture of the hip, spine or distal radius in patients over 50 years of age warrants testing or treatment for osteoporosis if not previously undertaken.   Patient was instructed to take part in an osteoporosis prevention/treatment program.  2.	If patient does not have significant pain relief in 2 weeks, can consider lumbar epidural steroid injection. Follow up with patient in clinic.  Technique:   The patient was brought to the interventional radiology suite and placed on the table in prone position. The wide area of the back around the affected area(s) was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion.   All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per [HCW]nt guidelines). A scout image was obtained in AP and lateral projections.   Skin was anesthetized with a 2% lidocaine solution.   Level by level technique:   -Vertebral level:  L 1 -Pedicle access:  Unit pedicular (Omni curve) -Access trocar gauge:  10-gauge -Balloon utilized:  15 mm  Prior to injection of cement, balloons were inserted and inflated under biplane fluoroscopy.  Static fluoroscopic images were stored to PACS documenting balloon utilization and position. -Biopsy obtained:  No -Indication for biopsy: N/A -Ablation Performed: N/A -Indication for Ablation: N/A  -Vertebral level:  L 3 -Pedicle access:  Unit pedicular (Omni curve) -Access trocar gauge:  10-gauge -Balloon utilized:  15 mm  Prior to injection of cement, balloons were inserted and inflated under biplane fluoroscopy.  Static fluoroscopic images were stored to PACS documenting balloon utilization and position. -Biopsy obtained:  No -Indication for biopsy: N/A -Ablation Performed: N/A -Indication for Ablation: N/A  -Vertebral level:  L 5 -Pedicle access:  Unit pedicular (Omni curve) -Access trocar gauge:  10-gauge -Balloon utilized:  15 mm  Prior to injection of cement, balloons were inserted and inflated under biplane fluoroscopy.  Static fluoroscopic images were stored to PACS documenting balloon utilization and position. -Biopsy obtained:  No -Indication for biopsy: N/A -Ablation Performed: N/A -Indication for Ablation: N/A   Additional Procedural Details:   Utilizing AP and lateral fluoroscopy, needles were inserted into the affected vertebral body/bodies. Needles were advanced under careful, intermittent biplane fluoroscopy to ensure that the medial wall of the pedicle was not violated prior to transgression of the needle tip into the posterior wall of the vertebral body. The Omni curve device was advanced with care not to violate the anterior wall to the level of the contralateral pedicle.  No ablation was performed.  Balloon(s) was/were inserted into the effected vertebral body/bodies and inflated under fluoroscopy. Static fluoroscopic images were stored to PACS documenting balloon position. Cement was mixed and balloons were removed after being deflated.  Cement was then injected under careful, intermittent biplane fluoroscopy to ensure no significant extravasation of PMMA cement beyond the borders of the vertebral body. Cement injection was stopped once there was adequate fill of the vertebral body. Trochars were removed with hemostasis obtained with focal compression. Static fluoroscopic images were obtained after removal of all needles documenting final cement position. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  G-tube dependent for nutrition. Pulled out G-tube. Failed replacement in ED.   Procedure: Tract evaluation with image guided replacement of gastrostomy tube    Findings:  The pre-existing gastrostomy tube was completely out. The stoma was small with no obvious discharge.  Tract evaluation with contrast injection from the skin showed a patent diminutive tract  in communication with the gastric lumen.  The newly placed 18 French gastrostomy tube is appropriately positioned.    Impression:   Mature but diminutive stoma, left mid abdomen to gastric lumen.  The diminutive tract was negotiated and a new 18 French ballooned gastrostomy tube placed.  Plan: Routine exchange in 6 months  Technique:  The anterior abdominal wall was prepped and draped in sterile fashion.   A scout radiograph was obtained. Contrast was injected at the stoma with imaging over the abdomen.   A 5 French angled catheter was then placed at the stoma and manipulated through the tract while contrast was injected. The gastric lumen was re-entered with a Glidewire. The glide was exchanged for an Amplatz.  A new 18 French gastrostomy tube preloaded with an 8mm by 4 cm balloon was placed over the wire and the balloon inflated to dilate the percutaneous tract. The gastrostomy tube was advanced in over the shoulders of the balloon. The balloon was removed and contrast injection confirmed location. The retention balloon was inflated with 10 mL tap water. Contrast injection confirmed location.  The catheter was secured to the anterior abdominal wall the usual manner. The balloon port was crushed.  The procedure was well-tolerated, and the patient was discharged from the angio suite in stable condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Thrombocytic thrombocytopenia purpura  Procedure:   1.	Non-tunneled large bore central venous catheter placement  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the large bore central venous catheter, as described, the tip terminates in the right atrium.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a 13 French,  20 cm, non-tunneled large bore central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.  Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care. The catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.   The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic. Ultrasound evaluation of the vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS. Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS.  A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, a 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   The venotomy tract was dilated to allow introduction of the catheter over the wire. The catheter was subsequently introduced over the wire and the wire removed. The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. Patient has leaking from both tubes.  Procedure:   1.	Gastrostomy tube replacement under fluoroscopic guidance. 2.	Jejunostomy tube replacement under fluoroscopic guidance  Findings:   1.	The existing tubes are properly positioned  with partial deflation of the balloons 2.	The new tubes are appropriately positioned within in the stomach and jejunum respectively.  Impression:   1.	Successful replacement of 18 French MIC gastrostomy tube.  2.	Successful replacement of 18 French MIC key 3.5 cm stoma length jejunostomy tube.  Treatment Plan:   It is OK to use the tubes immediately.  Routine check and change recommended in 6 months.  Technique:   Informed consent for the procedure was obtained, and time-out was performed prior to the procedure.  The skin overlying the access site was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). The skin and subcutaneous tissue around the existing tube were infiltrated with local anesthetic. A scout image was obtained of the abdomen.  Gastrostomy tube exchange: A wire was cannulated into the existing tube and passed into the gastric lumen. The pre-existing G-tube was removed over the wire after deflating the bulb. A new gastrostomy tube was advanced over the wire. The replacement tube overlies the stomach on static fluoroscopic image saved to PACS.  The balloon was inflated with 10 mL of a 10% contrast mixture. Gentle hand injection of contrast material documents the gastric feeding tube within the gastric lumen.   Jejunostomy tube exchange: A wire was cannulated into the existing tube and passed into the gastric lumen. The pre-existing J-tube was removed over the wire after deflating the bulb. A new jejunostomy tube was advanced over the wire. The replacement tube overlies the stomach on static fluoroscopic image saved to PACS.  The balloon was inflated with 6 mL of a 10% contrast mixture. Gentle hand injection of contrast material documents the jejunostomy feeding tube within the jejunal lumen.
