Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]C.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Malfunctioning PermCath. High pressures during dialysis.  Procedure:  1. Fluoroscopic guided exchange of tunneled PermCath catheter. 2. Limited superior vena cavagram.   Findings:  1. Scout image demonstrates existing right IJ tunneled PermCath with tip positioned at the cavoatrial junction/distal SVC. 2. Superior vena cavagram demonstrates irregularity and narrowing of the distal SVC without significant holdup of contrast. 3. Newly exchanged right IJ tunneled PermCath is appropriately positioned with the tip in the right atrium. Postexchange venogram confirms appropriate position without any abnormality.  Impression:  1. Pre-existing PermCath terminates at the lower SVC/cavoatrial junction. Venogram through the catheter demonstrates irregularity and narrowing of the distal SVC without significant flow limitation. 2. Uneventful image guided wire exchange of a right IJ tunneled PermCath catheter (15.5 French by 23 cm tip to cuff).   Plan:  1. New catheter is ready for immediate use.  2. Patient follow-up in IR clinic for further consideration of SVC venogram and possible venoplasty.  Technique:  The right chest wall and area immediately around the existing double lumen Hickman catheter was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier.  Using local anesthetic, the tract was anesthetized. Utilizing a hemostat, the tract was accessed and the cuff freed from the surrounding soft tissues.   An Amplatz wire was advanced through the catheter however was not easily navigated through the SVC and down the IVC. Given the difficulty, venogram was performed, which demonstrated filling defect around the tip of the catheter, with contrast retrograde filling and eventually dumping through the atrium and out the pulmonary outflow tract.  A Glidewire advantage was then easily navigated into the IVC.  Given the patient's current lack of IV access, and no sedation, the decision was made to just exchange the catheter over a wire and bring the patient back at a later date for SVC venography and possible stenting.  The catheter was then pulled with gentle traction until it was completely removed over the wire.   A new double lumen PermCath was advanced over the wire until the tip was positioned appropriately and the cuff positioned within the tunnel. Prolene suture was placed at the catheter tunnel exit site. An antimicrobial disc and sterile dressing were applied.  The catheter was aspirated, flushed, and heparinized per protocol. The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient was discharged in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  History of iatrogenic CBD injury status post Roux-en-Y hepatic jejunostomy in [DATE] complicated by anastomotic stricture, managed with left percutaneous transhepatic biliary drain. Patient found to have left sided biliary calculi   Procedure: 1.	Cholangiogram via the existing percutaneous internal/external biliary drain 2.	Cholangioscopy and lithotripsy 3.	Cholangioplasty of hepato-enteric anastomotic stricture. 4.	Biliary drain exchange over wire   Findings:  1.	Multiple stone in the left biliary ducts on cholangiogram and cholangioscopy 2.	Endoscopic-assisted lithotripsy of biliary stones and stone removal under fluoroscopic guidance using Fogarty balloon 3.	Surgical hepato-enteric anastomotic stricture. Cholangioplasty using 9 mm x 40 cm conquest balloon. Persistent strictured appearance post balloon dilatation. There was, however, rapid transit of contrast from the bile ducts into the bowel. 4.	Final cholangiography and endoscopy showed significantly decreased stone burden with minimal residual stones in the left biliary tree.   5.	Non opacification of the right biliary tree. Finding suggestive of right ductal obstruction from biliary calculi. 6.	Successful left internal/external biliary drain exchange over wire.   Impression:  1.	Technically successful endoscopic-assisted lithotripsy of biliary stones, and removal of numerous stone fragments. 2.	Persistent surgical hepato-enteric anastomotic stricture after cholangioplasty  3.	Technically successful internal-external biliary drainage catheter exchange.   Plan: 1.	Open to bag drainage for 24 hours. 2.	Capping trial after 24 hours. 3.	Findings were discussed with [HCW].  Patient is planned to meet with [HCW] to revisit potential surgical options.     Technique:  The existing catheter and surrounding soft tissues were prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site. Contrast injection was performed.  Initial cholangiography demonstrated contrast transit into bowel and filling defects in the left biliary tree. An 0.035" Glidewire advantage and Amplatz wire were negotiated through the catheter into the duodenum. A short 8 French sheath was then advanced into the common bile duct over the wire glidewire advantage. The Amplatz wire remained externalized (as a safety wire) and secured with a clamp. Repeat cholangiography through the sheath showed findings above.  An endoscopic device (Spyglass) was advanced through the sheath into the common bile duct into the small bowel and endoscopic exam was performed. It was retracted into the biliary tree and lithotripsy of noted stones was performed using EHL probes. Cholangioplasty of the surgical anastomosis was performed as above. Subsequently, Fogarty balloon sweeps were performed over wire to push stones through common bile duct, and into the duodenum. A final cholangiogram was performed, as above through the sheath at the end of the lithotripsy procedure.  Drain placement: Finally, a 10.2 French biliary internal-external biliary drain was placed over the wire. The anchor/loop was formed and locked in the duodenum. All wires were removed from the patient. Contrast was injected to confirm location. The catheter was secured to the skin with 2-0 non-absorbable suture material and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient has severe back pain despite optimal non-surgical management with severe impact of vertebral body compression fracture(s) on daily functioning. Patient has kyphotic deformity due to vertebral body compression fracture(s).     Procedure:   1.	Image-guided kyphoplasty   Findings:   1.	Pre-intervention: Redemonstrated L1 and L2 compression fractures. 2.	Post-intervention:  Successful deposition of cement within the treated vertebral body/bodies with no evidence of leak.    Impression:   1.	Successful image guided augmentation of vertebral levels: L1 and L2    Treatment Plan:   1.	 A fracture of the hip, spine or distal radius in patients over 50 years of age warrants testing or treatment for osteoporosis if not previously undertaken.   Patient was instructed to take part in an osteoporosis prevention/treatment program.  2.	Return to IR clinic in one month.  Technique:   The patient was brought to the interventional radiology suite and placed on the table in prone position. The wide area of the back around the affected area was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion.   All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). A scout image was obtained in AP and lateral projections. The skin, soft tissues, and periosteum were all anesthetized with a 2% lidocaine solution.   Level by level technique:   -Vertebral level:  L1     -Pedicle access:  Bipedicular -Access trocar gauge:  11-gauge -Balloon utilized:  15 mm  Prior to injection of cement, balloons were inserted and inflated under biplane fluoroscopy.  Static fluoroscopic images were stored to PACS documenting balloon utilization and position. -Biopsy obtained:  No -Indication for biopsy: N/A -Ablation Performed: N/A -Indication for Ablation: N/A   -Vertebral level:  L2     -Pedicle access:  Bipedicular -Access trocar gauge:  11-gauge -Balloon utilized:  15 mm  Prior to injection of cement, balloons were inserted and inflated under biplane fluoroscopy.  Static fluoroscopic images were stored to PACS documenting balloon utilization and position. -Biopsy obtained:  No -Indication for biopsy: N/A -Ablation Performed: N/A -Indication for Ablation: N/A   Additional Procedural Details:   Utilizing AP and lateral fluoroscopy, needles were inserted into the affected vertebral body/bodies. Needles were advanced under careful, intermittent biplane fluoroscopy to ensure that the medial wall of the pedicle was not violated prior to transgression of the needle tip into the posterior wall of the vertebral body. The drill was then advanced to the anterior one-third of the vertebral body on each side.  No ablation was performed.  Balloons were sequentially inserted into the effected L1 and L2 vertebral bodies and inflated under fluoroscopy. Static fluoroscopic images were stored to PACS documenting balloon position. Cement was mixed and balloons were removed after being deflated.  Cement was then injected under careful, intermittent biplane fluoroscopy to ensure no significant extravasation of PMMA cement beyond the borders of the vertebral body. Cement injection was stopped once there was adequate fill of the vertebral body. Trochars were removed with hemostasis obtained with focal compression. Static fluoroscopic images were obtained after removal of all needles documenting final cement position. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Recurrent malignant pleural effusion.  Additional information: Metastatic breast cancer with extensive tumor burden, recurrent left pleural effusion. Initial plan was to attempt tunneled pleural catheter placement with local and IV analgesia per preference of patient and family and, if unable, proceed with thoracentesis.  Procedure: Ultrasound-guided thoracentesis  Findings:  1.	Extensive wound/disease involving the posterolateral left chest wall limited sonographic evaluation of the left thorax. 2.	Left pleural effusion could be visualized only from a focal area in the mid-axillary line. 3.	Consensus with Anesthesia that the patient could not be repositioned for PleurX placement without GA considering her overall morbidity including marked dyspnea even while upright and inability to mobilize her severely edematous left upper extremity. We consulted with the patient's daughter further after identifying these safety concerns; decision was made to proceed with thoracentesis. 4.	US-guided left thoracentesis with 700 mL clear yellow fluid removed. 5.	Post-procedure imaging with resolution of visible portion of the effusion with apposition of lung against the chest wall.  Impression:  After identification of procedural limitations and decision-making as detailed above. Image-guided thoracentesis with of removal 700 mL pleural fluid.  Technique:  Device: 5-Fr [VENDOR] Fluid sent to lab for analysis: No  The left subaxillary thoracic wall was prepped and draped in normal sterile fashion. Ultrasonographic evaluation of the pleural space was carried out and an appropriate entry site was chosen, with attention paid to avoid vasculature, underlying lung, diaphragm, and high abdominal structures. A limited window for thoracentesis was identified with no overlying subcutaneous di[HCW]e in this region. Images were stored in PACS.  Following administration of local anesthetic, a tiny dermatotomy was created. The pleural space was accessed using the device detailed above. The catheter was attached to a drainage device and fluid was removed. Slow venous oozing was noted from the entry site. Tract embolization was performed using a Gelfoam slurry composed of Gelfoam and lidocaine with epinephrine. The catheter was removed, and adequate hemostasis was achieved with this tract embolization and manual compression.   Sterile dressing was applied. The procedure was well tolerated and patient left the recovery area in stable condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Pulmonary embolism with inability to tolerate anticoagulation.  Procedure:   1.	US-guided right IJ venous access 2.	Inferior vena cava filter placement  Findings:  Inferior vena cavogram: Single renal veins bilaterally without aberrant anatomy (no duplicated IVC or accessory renal veins). The IVC is normal in caliber and without caval thrombus. Filter placed: Argon option elite Inferior vena cavogram post-deployment: Appropriate positioning below the renal veins without significant filter tilt. No evidence of thrombosis, perforation, or other complication.  Impression:   1.  Uneventful image guided placement of an infrarenal IVC filter.  Treatment Plan:   The filter can remain indwelling indefinitely.   Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained.  The specific risks of bleeding, infection, pulmonary embolism, filter maldeployment, and filter migration were detailed and accepted. Written informed consent was obtained. The patient was assessed for conscious sedation and found to be an adequate candidate. A dedicated nurse monitored heart rate, blood pressure, and oxygen saturation throughout the procedure. Patient was brought to the procedure suite and a time out was performed prior to procedure initiation. The right neck was prepped and draped in sterile fashion.   The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the access site were infiltrated with lidocaine for local anesthetic. Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency. Under continuous ultrasound guidance, with permanent recording and reporting, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018" wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire. Through the micropuncture introducer set, an 0.035" Bentson wire was advanced down the IVC and into the left iliac vein under fluoroscopic guidance. The argon option elite filter/sheath combination was then advanced over the wire into the left iliac vein where venography was performed with details above.  Under direct fluoroscopic guidance, the filter described above was positioned and deployed through the delivery system. A repeat venogram was performed, documenting appropriate positioning.  All instruments and devices were removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression. No immediate complication occurred, and the patient was discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. INTRACRANIAL EMBOLIZATION OF CHRONIC SUBDURAL HEMATOMA MEMBRANES THROUGH MIDDLE MENINGEAL ARTERY, UNILATERAL  CLINICAL INDICATION: This is a 79-year-old Male with a past medical history of coronary artery disease status post stenting, hypertension, type 2 diabetes, hepatocellular carcinoma, bladder cancer, benign prostatic hypertrophy, COPD, prior CVA, and alcohol use disorder who is found to have a sizable chronic right-sided subdural hematoma for which she underwent burr hole evacuation. Middle meningeal artery embolization is indicated to treat membranes and help prevent recurrence.   PROCEDURE: Diagnostic angiogram. Intracranial particle embolization of chronic subdural hematoma membranes through the middle meningeal artery   DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 1.5 hrs.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician.  He supervised the entire procedure. [HCW] and [HCW]. were the fellows. Each actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right common carotid artery Right Internal Carotid Artery Right External Carotid Artery Right Middle Meningeal Artery  VESSELS TREATED: Right Middle Meningeal Artery  ANESTHESIA: General endotracheal anesthesia was administered under the supervision of the attending anesthesiologist. Pre-, intra-, and post-anesthesia monitoring records are available in the chart.  MEDICATIONS:  Heparin 3000 units IV Protamine 20 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 0.035" Bentson guidewire 0.035" Terumo GlideWire  5 French Merit Performa Vertebral catheter Excelsior 1018 microcatheter Transcend-EX microguidewire Contour PVA embolization particles (250-355 microns) Cardiva Vascade Omnipaque 300 contrast material (80 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, spinal cord infarction, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, hemorrhage, nontargeted embolization, necrosis of skin or mucus membranes, renal failure, limb loss, death, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.  After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite, intubated, and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the Right femoral artery; a 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath was introduced into the Right femoral artery. 3000  units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was completed of the above vessels. Digital angiograms were performed centered over the head and face.   Superselective catheterization of the Right middle meningeal artery was then performed with the Excelsior 1018 microcatheter and Transcend-EX microguidewire. Contour PVA particles were prepared on an adjacent table and maintained in isobaric suspension with appropriate quantities of saline and contrast and injected into the Right middle meningeal artery using a pulse-spray technique over several minutes. Control angiograms of this vessel were performed before, during, and after the embolization.   Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a Cardiva Vascade followed by manual compression. A Tegaderm was then applied over the puncture site.  COMPARISON: noninvasive imaging.  FINDINGS:  RIGHT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CERVICAL: There is a carotid web with a small amount of contrast stagnation. The bifurcation is otherwise normal, without irregularity, calcification, or hemodynamically significant stenosis with respect to the distal cervical right internal carotid artery.   RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: As displacement of the cortical vessels along the medial aspect of the convexity consistent with mass effect from the known residual subdural blood products. The choroidal blush is present but faint. No anastomosis with right ECA branches is demonstrated. All phases of the angiogram are normal.   RIGHT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No anastomosis resulting in ipsilateral ophthalmic artery or intracranial perfusion is identified.   RIGHT MIDDLE MENINGEAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL (PRE-EMBOLIZATION): No anastomoses with the right ophthalmic artery are demonstrated. No arteriovenous shunting or dural fistula is seen.   RIGHT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-EMBOLIZATION): Interval embolization of the middle meningeal artery with significant stagnation of flow. No other vessel occlusions are identified.   RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: No evidence of unintended embolization. The choroidal blush remains present..  COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: 1.	Successful intracranial PVA embolization through Right middle meningeal artery for treatment of chronic subdural hematoma membranes 2.	There is a right-sided carotid web with small amount of contrast stagnation.

CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM AND BALLOON ASSISTED COIL EMBOLIZATION OF RUPTURED RECURRENT RIGHT POSTERIOR COMMUNICATING ARTERY ANEURYSM    CLINICAL INDICATION: 63-year-old female with a history of ruptured right posterior communicating artery aneurysm in 2016 which was coil embolized. Follow-up angiogram in 2017 showed small amount of recurrence at the neck. She was asked to follow up in one year for repeat angiogram, however she was lost to follow-up. She returns with subarachnoid hemorrhage secondary to recurrent right posterior communicating artery aneurysm. Cerebral angiogram head treatment of the ruptured aneurysm are indicated.   PROCEDURE: Cerebral angiogram, balloon-assisted coil embolization of ruptured recurrent right posterior communicating artery aneurysm.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: 2 hours.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician.  He supervised the entire procedure. [HCW] and [HCW]. were the fellows. Each actively participated in catheter manipulat[HOSPITAL] and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS CATHETERIZED: Left vertebral artery Left external carotid artery Left internal carotid artery Right external carotid artery Right internal carotid artery Right posterior indicating artery  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right common femoral artery Left vertebral artery Left external carotid artery Left internal carotid artery Right external carotid artery Right internal carotid artery  VESSELS TREATED (in sequence): Right internal carotid artery  ANESTHESIA:   General Anesthesia administered by anesthesiology staff.  Pre- Intra- and post- anesthesia records are available in the patient chart.   MEDICATIONS GIVEN:  Heparin 5000 units IV Aspirin 300 mg PR Protamine 25 mg IV Ancef 2 gram IV  MATERIALS USED:  5 French micropuncture kit Cope mandrel wire 5 French transitional dilator 6 French 65cm Arrow sheath 0.038" Bentson guidewire 0.035" Terumo glidewire (180 cm)  0.035" Terumo exchange-length glidewire  5 French Merit Performa Vertebral catheter 072 Navien guide catheter Headway 17 Advanced microcatheter Transcend-EX microguidewire 4 mm x 7 mm Hyperform balloon microcatheter Omnipaque 300 contrast material (180 cc) Perclose ProGlide closure device  COILS: Framing coil:  Optimax complex 6 mm x 20 cm Filling coils:  Optima complex-10 4 mm x 10 cm Optima complex-10 4 mm x 10 cm Optima complex-10 3 mm x 8 cm Optima complex-10 2 mm x 6 cm   TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient and her daughter (via phone). Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, hemorrhage, renal failure, limb loss, death, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.  After informed, written consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and general anesthesia initiated and endotracheal intubation was performed by anesthesia staff. An XperCT was performed in order to confirm appropriate EVD placement and to evaluate for post EVD hemorrhage. The patient was then prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained by a single-wall puncture of the right common femoral artery. An angiogram of the right common femoral artery was performed through the outer cannula the dilator to ensure the arteriotomy was appropriately placed into the artery was reasonable for use of the Perclose device. A 6 French 65cm Arrow sheath was introduced Seldinger technique and was advanced over the Bentson wire into the proximal descending aorta using fluoroscopic guidance.  Using fluoroscopic guidance, the 5 French diagnostic catheter was used to select the left vertebral artery and the bilateral external and internal carotid arteries.  Digital angiograms were performed of these vessels, centered over the head. Ipsilateral and contralateral oblique projections were obtained of both internal carotid artery injections to evaluate for anterior communicating or MCA bifurcation aneurysms.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: Rotational angiography was also performed from the diagnostic catheter in the proximal cervical segment of the right internal carotid artery for better delineation of the intracranial vasculature. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.  The 5 French diagnostic catheter was then exchanged over the 0.035" [VENDOR]umo exchange-length glidewire for the 072 Navien guide catheter, which was situated at the distal cervical segment of the right internal carotid artery. The balloon was then prepared on an adjacent table, and the microguidewire and the balloon were passed coaxially through the guide catheter into the right internal carotid artery. The guide catheter was advanced over the microcatheter in the balloon into the horizontal petrous segment of the right internal carotid artery. Using roadmap guidance, the balloon was advanced to cover the ostium of the aneurysm. Superselective catheterization of the right posterior communicating artery aneurysm performed with the microcatheter over a microguidewire. The aneurysm was framed and filled with the aforementioned coils using roadmap and blank roadmap technique. Following the deployment of the first coil, an aspirin rectal suppository (300 mg) was administered. The balloon was inflated and deflated under fluoroscopic guidance as needed in order to remodel the aneurysm neck and wall the coiling catheter was removed from the aneurysm.   A final cerebral angiogram was done in the AP and lateral projection to evaluate for residual filling, and distal emboli.  Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine and Ancef was administered.  Hemostasis was achieved by application of a Perclose ProGlide. A Tegaderm was then applied over the puncture site.  A second XperCT of the head was performed in order to evaluate for any expansion of the multiple compartments hemorrhage that may have occurred during the procedure.  COMPARISON: None.  FINDINGS: RIGHT COMMON FEMORAL ARTERY: The arteriotomy is above the bifurcation of the right common femoral artery and the diameter of the vessel is adequate for a Perclose ProGlide.  LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is no visualized right P1 segment, indicative of fetal type P-comm (as imaged on right internal carotid artery injection discussed below ( No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. Reflux of contrast into the  contralateral vertebral artery was achieved. The origin of PICA is normal bilaterally.   LEFT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified.    RIGHT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is a compact coil mass which is displaced from the expected location. There is a large, wide-necked posteriorly and laterally projecting recurrence of the previously treated aneurysm just proximal to the origin of the fetal type P-comm. The dimensions are described on the 3-D rotational angiography discussed below.  No focal stenosis or early draining vein are identified.    RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-EMBOLIZATION): Interval coil embolization of the recurrent right posterior communicating artery aneurysm with small amount of residual filling, but with contrast stagnation within the aneurysm. There are no perfusion deficits to suggest distal emboli in the distal circulation.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY:  3-D rotational angiography demonstrated broad-based recurrence of the previously coil embolized right posterior communicating artery aneurysm which measures 7.1 x 6.1 x 6.5 x 5.1 mm.     COMPLICATIONS: None.  IMPRESSION: 1. There is broad-based recurrence of the previously coil embolized right posterior communicating artery aneurysm which measures 7.1 x 6.1 x 6.5 x 5.1 mm 2. Successful coil embolization of the recurrent right posterior communicating artery aneurysm with small amount of residual filling, but with contrast stagnation within the aneurysm    HEAD CT WITHOUT IV CONTRAST (prior to coil embolization of aneurysm)  INDICATION: Subarachnoid hemorrhage with hydrocephalus, status post placement of external ventriculostomy drain, confirm adequate placement and rule out new hemorrhage. FINDINGS:  The limitations of the XPER CT technique need to be noted. There is a left frontal approach external ventriculostomy drain which terminates in the body of the right lateral ventricle. There is no associated tract hemorrhage. The previously seen right-sided subdural hematoma and intraparenchymal hemorrhage are grossly stable. Stable mild right-to-left midline shift. DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: 62-year-old Male  with PMH of right middle cerebral artery stroke status post angioplasty and stenting of the right internal carotid artery and left carotid endarterectomy was more recently experienced to episodes of transient right-sided vision loss. He was evaluated by ophthalmology who felt that these episodes represented amaurosis fugax. Diagnostic cerebral angiogram was indicated to further evaluate the degree of stenosis and to evaluate for possible procedural intervention.   PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram. Sedation was administered by a specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for the duration of the procedure as outlined above (Total intra service time, 30 ). Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed. COMPARISON: Outside CTA head and neck dated [DATE].  FINDINGS: RIGHT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CERVICAL: There is a stent extending from the distal common carotid artery to the proximal cervical segment of the right internal carotid artery. The stent is well apposed throughout it's course with minimal intimal hyperplasia and no evidence of endoleak There is no appreciable stenosis of the proximal portion of the right internal carotid artery with respect to the distal cervical carotid artery. The ECA branches opacify normally.  RIGHT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is irregularity and stenosis of the intracranial carotid artery extending from the distal petrous/proximal cavernous segment to the distal ophthalmic segment, consistent with intracranial atherosclerotic disease as seen on outside CTA. There is no stenosis at the origin of the ophthalmic artery. There is no apparent delay in filling of the branches of the intracranial internal carotid artery. The right A1 segment is hypoplastic with no visible filling.  No aneurysm or early draining vein are identified.  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   LEFT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CERVICAL: The bifurcation is smooth, without irregularity, calcification, or stenosis with respect to the distal ICA. The ECA branches opacify normally.  LEFT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: Mild irregularity of the distal ICA and proximal MCA, consistent with intracranial atherosclerotic disease.  No aneurysm or early draining vein are identified.  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.    3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY: 3D Rotational angiography with volume-rendered three-dimensional reconstruction on an independent workstation, demonstrated irregularity and stenosis of the intracranial carotid artery extending from the distal petrous/proximal cavernous segment to the distal ophthalmic segment, consistent with intracranial atherosclerotic disease as seen on outside CTA. Up to 25% stenosis of the ICA (at the ophthalmic segment) as compared to the middle cerebral artery. .    COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.   IMPRESSION: 1. There is irregularity and stenosis of the intracranial carotid artery extending from the distal petrous/proximal cavernous segment to the distal ophthalmic segment, consistent with intracranial atherosclerotic disease as seen on outside CTA. The greatest degree of stenosis of the ICA with respect to the MCA is 25% (at the ophthalmic segment). Given this there is no indication for angioplasty or stenting at this time. 2. There is no appreciable residual stenosis of the proximal internal carotid arteries bilaterally. DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: This is a 60 years Female with past medical history of hypertension and asthma, who is found to have an incidental right MCA aneurysm who presents for diagnostic cerebral angiography to evaluate the aneurysm.   PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 30 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] was the fellow. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right internal carotid artery Right common carotid artery Left internal carotid artery Left external carotid artery Left vertebral artery  ANESTHESIA: Local in the right groin with bupivacaine. Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by the nurse present during the entire procedure. The patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Sedation was administered by a specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for the duration of the procedure as outlined above (Total intra service time, 30 minutes ). Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.  MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine SQ 10 cc  Versed 1 mg IV Fentanyl 50 mcg IV Heparin 3000 units IV Protamine 20 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.038" Bentson guidewire 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 5 French Cordis Vertebral catheter 5 French Vascade closure device Visipaque-270 contrast material (80 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 5 French sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP, Lateral and Oblique views.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY:  Rotational angiography was also performed from the diagnostic catheter in the right internal carotid artery for better delineation of the underlying angioarchitecture. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.    Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a 5 French Vascade closure device  followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: CTA head and neck [DATE].  FINDINGS: RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is a laterally directed right MCA bifurcation aneurysm better described on the 3-D angiogram below. There is no evidence of focal stenosis or early draining vein identified.   RIGHT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The ICA branches are as described above. The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. Of note there is no A1 segment. The left ACA is supplied from the right A1.  LEFT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: The occipital artery and internal maxillary artery opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula. The distal ECA branches are not well opacified.  LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. Reflux of contrast into the contralateral vertebral artery was not achieved. The origin of PICA is normal unilaterally (we will defer to CTA for evaluation of the contralateral PICA).   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: 3D Rotational angiography with volume-rendered three-dimensional reconstruction on an independent workstation, demonstrated a laterally directed 4.0 x 4.7 x 5.1 x 4.4 mm (transverse, transverse, dome to neck, neck) MCA bifurcation aneurysm.   COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: 1. There is a laterally directed 4.0 x 4.7 x 5.1 x 4.4 mm (transverse, transverse, dome to neck, neck) MCA bifurcation aneurysm. This aneurysm may be amenable to treatment with a WEB device.  [HCW], was present for the key and critical portions of the procedure and associated imaging guidance.

Patient's Name: [PATIENT]  MRN: [ID] Exam date: [DATE].  *	IR CENTRAL PORT, IR TUNNELED LARGE BORE CVC placement *	Removal of a tunneled right internal jugular vein large bore catheter  Indications: The patient suffers from multiple myeloma.  Request is made for removal of right internal jugular vein tunneled large bore catheter placement of an infusion port to continue IV chemotherapy. The patient reported no problems with the existing tunneled catheter that was initially placed in [DATE].  Procedure: After explaining the technique, risks, benefits, alternatives, and answering all questions, informed consent was obtained from the patient. Timeout identifying the correct patient, procedure, site, allergies was performed and observed by the operating team. The patient was positioned supine with the head turned to the right. The procedure is performed under continuous physiologic monitoring. The patient received intravenous conscious sedation using Versed 1.5 mg and fentanyl 75 mcg.  Also the patient received Ancef 2 g IV.  The left side of the lower neck and upper chest was prepped with chlorhexidine followed by Betadine and draped in a sterile fashion.  Following administration of local anesthesia using lidocaine 1% with epinephrine 7ml at the left side of the root of the neck, under ultrasound  guidance, access was obtained into the left internal jugular vein using a micropuncture device. A 0.018" guidewire was advanced under fluoroscopy into the vein centrally. Further administration of local anesthesia using lidocaine 1% with epinephrine 12 mL into the left infraclavicular region. A transverse 3.5  cm incision was performed and a pocket created inferior to the incision to accommodate the port using both sharp and blunt dissection. Through the infraclavicular incision, the port tubing 8 F was tunneled exiting at the root of the neck following a nick incision at the exit of the guidewire. The guidewire was upgraded to 0.035" guidewire that was advanced under fluoroscopy through the SVC into the IVC. A peel-away sheath was advanced over the guidewire. Following removal of the guidewire and the stiffener, the port tubing was advanced after trimming to a length of 26 cm. The sheath was peeled away and the line was buried in the subcutaneous tissues. The tip of the line is at the SVC/upper right atrium. The port was tested demonstrating easy aspiration and injection and was flushed with normal saline followed by hep saline as per protocol. The port was anchored in the subcutaneous tissues using nonabsorbable 2/0 interrupted stitches. The wound was irrigated. Hemostasis secured. The incision at the root of the neck was closed using Dermabond. The infraclavicular incision was closed using subcutaneous followed by subcuticular Vicryl 4/0 continuous stitches. Steri-Strips were applied followed by Sterile occlusive dressing.   Attention was then diverted to the right internal jugular vein tunneled catheter. The right infraclavicular region including the indwelling catheter were prepped with chlorhexidine followed by Betadine and draped in a sterile fashion. Following instillation of local anesthesia using lidocaine 1% with epinephrine, the existing catheter was freed at the anchoring cuff and removed intact. Hemostasis secured. Sterile occlusive dressing was applied. The patient tolerated to the procedures well. There were no intraprocedural complications. The patient was transferred to recovery in stable condition and eventually discharged. The port is ready to use. Please also refer to the Procedure note placed in the patient's EPIC chart on the date of the procedure.  Fluoroscopy time: 00:46.6 min.  Device implanted: 8F single lumen power port, LOT #[ID], REF #[ID].  Device removed intact: 15.5 F x 24 cm catheter.  Fellows: None. Residents: None.  IMPRESSION: 1. Uneventful ultrasound fluoroscopy guided placement of 8F Power  infusion port in the left internal jugular vein. The port is ready to use. 2. Successful removal of a right internal jugular vein large bore tunneled catheter.  Voice recognition is used in generating this report.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE].  Clinical Indication:  Recurrent ascites. Procedure: After explaining the technique, risks, benefits, alternatives, and' questions, informed consent was obtained from the patient. The patient received IV albumin per protocol.  At the end of the procedure, the cannula was removed and hemostasis was secured. Sterile occlusive dressing was applied. The procedure was well tolerated. There were no intraprocedural complications. The patient was eventually discharged  in stable condition. Please also refer to the Procedure note placed in the patient's EPIC chart on the date of the procedure.  IMPRESSION: Uneventful therapeutic paracentesis.  Voice recognition is used in generating this report.

Patient's Name: [PATIENT]  MRN: [ID] Procedure date: [DATE].  IR PERIPHERAL PICC  Indications: The patient is planned to start TPN.  Request is made for PICC placement. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication: Leaking biliary drain. Leaking gastrostomy tube  Additional clinical history: Pancreatic cancer status post Whipple in [DATE] with biliary anastomotic obstruction. A 10.2 French internal/external biliary drain was placed on [DATE]. The 10.2 French catheter was replaced and a biopsy performed at the anastomosis on [DATE]. The catheter was again replaced due to leakage at the skin site on [DATE]. She was hospitalized with gastric outlet obstruction and had a 20 French PEG tube placed endoscopically. The catheter was again replaced on [DATE] due to leaking at the skin entry site. Leaking continued and on [DATE] the biliary drain was upsized to 12 French. In spite of of an adequately positioned drain, the catheter continues to leak at the catheter entry site. In addition, the gastrostomy tube has profuse leakage around the catheter in the left upper quadrant.   PROCEDURE: 1. Catheter cholangiogram 2. Internal/external biliary drain replacement with upsizing to 16 French. 3. Gastrostomy tube replacement and upsizing to 22 French    FINDINGS: Comparison is made to multiple prior studies dating back to [DATE].  1.  Cholangiogram through the existing 12 French biliary drainage catheter demonstrates leakage beneath the skin outside the liver. 2. There is ongoing ductal prominence with debris. 3. The newly placed, larger 16 French biliary drain has its proximal sideholes barely within the right sided bile ducts, well central to the point of access. 4. There is significant retained gastric content. It is thick and not drained by the PEG tube. 5. The newly placed venting gastrostomy tube is a longer catheter with sideholes extending up into the fundus. Leakage at the skin is resolved.   IMPRESSION:   1.  Uneventful biliary catheter upsizing from 12 Fre[HOSPITAL] to 16 French with a different type drain placed with sideholes much more central. 2. The gastrostomy tube was replaced with a larger 22 French modified gastrostomy tube to improve drainage.  PLAN:  The gastrostomy tube will need to be flushed several times daily due to the viscosity/thickness of the gastric content. Catheter maintenance on a p.r.n. basis.   TECHNIQUE:    The existing biliary and gastrostomy catheters and surrounding soft tissues were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.   Biliary drain replacement:   Contrast was injected through the existing biliary drain, demonstrating leakage beneath the skin laterally. A 0.035" glidewire was negotiated through the catheter into the small bowel.  The catheter was removed and a new 16 French internal/external biliary drain was placed over the  wire .  Contrast was injected to confirm tube position.  The tube was sutured in place with 2-0 Ethilon and capped.     Attention was redirected to the existing 20 French endoscopically placed leaking gastrostomy tube.  Gastrostomy tube revision:  The existing gastrostomy tube was advanced into the fundus. There was significant retained residual which was quite thick and returned poorly through the existing gastrostomy tube.  Through the existing PEG tube, the stomach was insufflated, once the window was adequate, Two T-tacks were deployed to appose the anterior gastric wall to the anterior abdominal wall. The existing catheter was removed over a stiff Glidewire. A 22 French gastrojejunostomy tube was modified by creating multiple large additional distal sideholes. This was preloaded with an angled catheter and advanced over the glide into the stomach under fluoroscopic guidance. The wire and catheter were removed. The balloon was inflated with 10 mL capped water. The stomach was irrigated with saline with copious amounts of thick retained gastric content removed.  The catheter was secured to the anterior abdominal wall in the usual fashion.  The procedures were well tolerated, and the patient was discharged into the care of anesthesiology, still asleep for transfer to the PACU.  Procedural Personnel Attending(s): [HCW] Fellow(s): None Resident(s): None Advanced practice provider(s): None  Complications: No immediate complications.  Contrast: 50 mL Omnipaque  Fluoroscopy time: 3 minutes Fluoroscopy dose:  21.5 mGy  Conscious Sedation: The procedure was performed under general anesthesia.  Antibiotics: 2 g IV Rocephin  Blood loss:  Less than 10 ml  Checklist:	Informed consent was obtained discussing the risks, benefits and alternatives to the planned procedure.  Pre-sedation H&P was performed and sedation consent obtained. The patient’s name, medical record number, date of birth, allergies, procedure being performed including site and pertinent laboratory values were reviewed and confirmed with the technologist, nurse and patient.  These requirements including the Time Out were met prior to initiating the procedure.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]C.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Nonfunctioning right kidney. Left kidney with severe hydroureteronephrosis, concern for obstructive uropathy.  Procedure:   1.	Left nephrostogram and nephrostomy tube placement      Findings:  Comparison is made to a previous exam dated same day CT abdomen pelvis.  1.	Severe left hydronephrosis.  2.	Successful access into an upper pole calyx. No obstructing stones. Wire readily passes to the urinary bladder which is decompressed by Foley catheter. 3.	Successful placement of left PCNU (please note, no PCNU was available at time of procedure that was short enough to accommodate the patient's anatomy. A 8.5 French 40 cm biliary drain with extended sideholes was placed, with cope loop in the bladder, and radiopaque marker in the renal collecting system).  4.	Foley catheter in place. Extensive thoracolumbar hardware.   Catheter(s):  8.5 F 40 cm biliary drain with extended sideholes PCNU  Impression:   1.	Uneventful ultrasound and fluroscopic-guided placement of a left nephroureterostomy tube as described above, unless patient has interval PCNL, in which case the tube can be potentially removed. In the event that the patient requires a replacement PCNU, a 15 cm PCNU should be utilized.  Treatment Plan:   Patient should return for routine check and change in 8-12 weeks.        Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained to the patient. Written informed consent was obtained.  A time out/call to order was performed prior to procedure initiation.  The soft tissues overlying the access site were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Ultrasound was utilized to identify an appropriate access site. Static ultrasound image was obtained and stored to PACS for reference purposes. Subsequently, under fluoroscopic and real-time concurrent ultrasound guidance, access was obtained into a superior calyx using a 21 ga echogenic tip Chiba needle and a triaxial sheath system ([VENDOR]). Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site.   A 0.018 inch wire was advanced centrally. Serial dilation was accomplished over the wire. The wire and inner dilator were removed. Non-ionic contrast was injected into the collecting system and images of the antegrade pyelogram were obtained and stored to PACS.  An 0.035” Amplatz wire was advanced through the existing access. The samples wire was used to measure the tract distance from the collecting system to the bladder (15 cm). The biliary drain above was advanced over the wire and the Cope loop formed and locked in the bladder. Contrast injection confirmed location. The catheter was sutured to the flank with monofilament suture and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.  The procedure was well tolerated, and patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Painful L4 compression fracture which limits activities of daily living    Procedure:  Bipedicular vertebral augmentation at L4  Findings:  An MRI from [DATE] was reviewed  1. An anterior compression deformity is present at L4. There is marrow edema. A chronic compression deformity is present at L3. 2. Post procedure images show good interdigitation of methacrylate across the midline.    Impression:  Uneventful bipedicular kyphoplasty at L4.  Technique:  The patient was placed prone on the Angiography table.  The back was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. The C-Arm was brought into position and the L4 pedicles were identified and marked on the skin with a sterile marker. In view of the pedicle size and collapse of the L4 fracture, a transpedicular approach into the vertebral body was determined appropriate.   Under fluoroscopic guidance and through a left transpedicular approach, an 11-gauge trocar needle was advanced to just beyond the junction of the pedicle and L4 vertebral body. Needle tip position was confirmed in the AP and lateral planes to ensure the medial wall of the pedicle was not violated. A coaxial drill was placed through  the outer cannula and  advanced to the anterior third of the vertebral body toward the midline under multiplanar fluoroscopic guidance.  Attention was then turned to the contralateral side, where under fluoroscopic guidance via a right transpedicular approach, an 11-gauge trocar was advanced to just beyond the junction of the pedicle and L4 vertebral body. Needle tip position was confirmed in the AP and lateral planes to ensure the medial wall of the pedicle was not violated. The coaxial drill was advanced to the anterior third of the vertebral body toward the midline under multiplanar fluoroscopic guidance.    After completing the bilateral trocar entry into the vertebral body, inflatable bone tamps were inserted through each cannula respectively and advanced under lateral fluoroscopic guidance into the vertebral body proximal to the anterior cortex.  The balloon tamps were positioned such that the radiopaque marker bands were identified and situated just posterior to the anterior margin of the vertebral body.  Under multiplanar fluoroscopic imaging, the balloon bone tamps were inflated sequentially.  The inflations were monitored with AP and lateral imaging.  There was no breach of the lateral wall or anterior cortex of the vertebral body.  Internal fixation was achieved with low pressure injection of bone cement.  The cavity was filled under direct fluoroscopic visualization.  Once the bone cement had hardened, the cannulas were removed.  Post-procedure, excellent hemostasis was achieved at the small 5 mm puncture sites with manual compression.  A sterile dressing was applied.  The patient was kept in the prone position for approximately 10 minutes post cement injection before being transferred to a gurney and then the recovery area.  The patient tolerated the procedure well without complications. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Hemorrhagic shock, bleeding gastroesophageal varices despite multiple endoscopic interventions. Multiorgan failure.  Procedure:   1.	Primary TIPS creation 2.	Antegrade transvenous obliteration of gastroesophageal varices through TIPS access 3.	Triple lumen central venous catheter placement with ultrasound and fluoroscopic guidance  Findings:   1.	Right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses.  Needle entry was documented. 2.	Right hepatic venogram confirms vein patency. 3.	Portogram demonstrates patent splenic and portal veins. Moderate-sized short gastric and left gastric varices extending to the lower esophagus are noted. 4.	The initial portosystemic gradient is 16 mmHg. 5.	Post-TIPSS portosystemic gradient is 9 mmHg. 6.	The TIPSS extends from the right hepatic vein to right portal vein. 7.	There is good flow through the shunt at the conclusion of the procedure with no appreciable filling of varices. 8.	Technically successful antegrade transvenous obliteration of dominant gastroesophageal varices using STS foam and coils. 9.	New right internal jugular approach triple-lumen catheter terminates at the superior cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful creation of TIPS from right hepatic vein to right portal vein with three overlapping 8-10 mm controlled-expansion Viatorr stents (ballooned to 10 mm).  2.	Successful antegrade transvenous obliteration of gastroesophageal varices. 3.	The portosystemic gradient was reduced from 16 mm Hg to 9 mmHg.  Treatment Plan:   1.	Patient will be admitted to ICU for overnight monitoring 2.	Patient will be started on Lactulose/rifaximin  Technique:   Following written informed consent, the patient was placed supine on the procedure table. After induction of general anesthesia, the right neck and abdomen were prepped and draped in standard sterile fashion.   Access: The right neck was then evaluated with ultrasound. The skin overlying the right internal jugular vein was anesthetized with local, and a small dermatotomy was made.  Under ultrasound guidance a 21-gauge needle was advanced into the right internal jugular vein. A 0.018" guidewire was advanced through the micropuncture needle. The needle was exchanged for a 5 French transitional catheter. The 0.018" wire and inner dilator were removed, and a 0.035" wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava.  The transitional catheter was exchanged for a sheath. An angled catheter was placed over the wire and used to select the right hepatic vein. A right hepatic venogram was obtained.   Notes on access catheter/sheath combination: MPA/10-Fr sheath  ICE (Intra-cardiac echo) technique: A second access site was obtained in the neck using ultrasound guidance and a vascular sheath. This sheath was guided using fluoroscopy into the hepatic venous confluence and utilized to advance the ICE. Real-time echo imaging was then utilized to target an appropriate portal radical, with attention paid to avoid traversal of critical intrahepatic vessels/bile ducts and extrahepatic structures.  Pre-TIPS Pressures:  Right atrial and direct portal pressure measurements were obtained using a catheter/sheath, as detailed:  Right atrial: 30 mm Hg Portal: 14 mm Hg  CO2 Portography: No  TIPS: Using the Argon ScorpionX TIPS set, the right portal vein was accessed, which was confirmed with the hand-injection of contrast. A 0.035" wire was advanced into the portal vein and the TIPS sheaths were advanced over the wire into the portal vein. The inner sheath was removed and a marking pigtail catheter was advanced over the guidewire and used to measure the parenchymal tract and measure portal venous pressure. The sheath was ultimately advanced into the main portal vein, and a 8-10 mm x 2 cm x 8 cm Viatorr stent was deployed within the TIPS shunt. The [HOSPITAL]nt was dilated throughout using a high pressure balloon. Follow-up portogram demonstrated sluggish flow through the TIPS shunt due to tortuous course of the stent from acute access angle at the right portal vein. Two additional overlapping Viatorr stents (8-10 mm x 2 cm x 4 cm) were deployed proximal and distal to the existing stent to reinforce/reduce the tortuous angulation.  Post-TIPS Pressures: The pressures after shunt placement and stent dilation to 8 mm were recorded, as follows: Direct portal: 31 mm Hg Right atrial: 15 mmHg This corresponds to a portosystemic gradient of 16 mm Hg  The pressures after shunt placement and stent dilation to 10 mm were recorded, as follows: Direct portal: 24 mm Hg Right atrial: 15 mmHg This corresponds to a portosystemic gradient of 9 mm Hg   Antegrade Transvenous Obliteration of varices: Through the existing TIPS access, a 5 French catheter and wire combination was used to gain access into the dominant gastroesophageal varix arising at the portal mesenteric confluence. A 2.8 French prograde microcatheter was introduced into the base catheter. Contrast was injected. Images were reviewed and stored to PACS. Through the microcatheter, a 2 mL of STS foam mixture (1:2:3, lipiodol:STS:air) was injected into the varix. This was followed by coil embolization of the gastroesophageal varix using Balt Prestige coils (10 mm x 45 cm, 12 mm x 65 cm, 9 mm x 45 cm). After embolization, contrast was injected through the microcatheter. Images were reviewed.  At the end of the procedure the sheath was removed over a guidewire and a 12 French x 16 cm triple lumen catheter was placed. The catheter was flushed and heparinized per protocol. The catheter was sutured to the skin with 2-0 suture and a biodisc and sterile dressing were applied. The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no immediate complications. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Leaking around the right-sided biliary drain saturating the dressing.  Procedure:   1.	Right internal/external biliary drain replacement  Findings:   1.	Cholangiogram demonstrates existing side holes pulled slightly into the percutaneous tract with some leaking along the tract. 2.	Newly placed biliary drain is appropriately positioned with the distal tip in the third portion of the duodenum and the proximal side hole in the right-sided bile duct.  Impression:   1.	Exchange for catheter with regular sideholes to prevent sideholes leaking through the percutaneous tract.   Treatment Plan:   Catheter capped to internal drainage. Routine exchange in 2 3 months.  If patient has leaking because they are too few sideholes in this catheter, will likely need to create manual sideholes to extend drainage little bit further at time of next exchange.  Technique:   The existing catheter and surrounding soft tissues were prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site.  An 0.035" Amplatz wire was negotiated through the catheter into the small bowel. The catheter was removed .  The sheath was removed and a new 10.2 French internal/external biliary drain with extended sideholes was placed over the wire. Contrast was injected to confirm tube position. The catheter was secured to the skin with 2-0 Ethilon. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Pancreatic carcinoma with biliary obstruction managed by internal/external biliary catheter.  Procedure:   1.	Pullback sheath cholangiogram through existing percutaneous access 2.	Common bile duct stent placement 3.	Cholangioplasty of common bile duct and common bile duct stent 4.	Conversion of right internal/external biliary catheter to right external biliary catheter.  Findings:   1.	Sheath cholangiogram demonstrates stricture of the distal common bile duct 2.	Newly placed on bile duct stent is properly positioned with its distal tip in the duodenum. 3.	New external biliary catheter loop in the common bile duct just superior to the stent.  Impression:   1.	Biliary stent placement with cholangioplasty 2.	Conversion to capped external drain.  Treatment Plan:   Keep external drain capped. Place to bag and call IR if patient experiences severe new abdominal pain, fevers, chills, or rising bilirubin.  If patient passes capping trial, will remove external drain over wire. This can occur either next week if the patient is still inpatient or as an outpatient in 1-2 weeks.  Technique:   The existing catheter and surrounding soft tissues were prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site.  An 0.035" Amplatz wire was negotiated through the catheter into the small bowel. The catheter was removed and exchanged for a 10 French sheath. A pull back sheath cholangiogram was performed.  Through the sheath, over the wire, a 10 mm x 6 cm long viable partially covered stent was advanced. The distal portion was positioned approximately 1 cm into the small bowel. The stent was deployed. However, the stent was still narrowed centrally. A 10 mm x 4 mm Mustang balloon was used to perform cholangioplasty of the common bile duct within the stent. Over the wire  The sheath was removed and a new 10.2 French external Dawson-Mueller type biliary drain  was placed over the wire. Contrast was injected to confirm tube position. The catheter was secured to the skin with 2-0 Ethilon and capped to internal drainage. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Orthotopic heart transplant. Renal failure. Needs long-term dialysis access.  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled large bore central venous catheter placement  Findings:   1.	The left internal jugular vein is diminutive but sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the large bore central venous catheter, as described, the tip terminates in the right atrium (3.5 vertebral bodies below the carina).  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a  15.5 French, 27 cm (tip-to-cuff), tunneled large bore central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.  Treatment Plan:   1. Routine catheter care. 2. The catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  The skin and subcutaneous tissues overlying the vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the left internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle. An image was saved and stored to PACS.    A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, however there was is difficulty advancing the 0.018 inch wire to the IVC. Given the ultrasound access imaging, and venous appearance of the blood return from the needle, we were confident to be in the venous system, and a 5 French transitional sheath was advanced over the wire to establish stable access into the vein. An Amplatz wire was then attempted to be advanced into the IVC, again unsuccessful. The outer of the 5 French transitional sheath was exchanged for a 4 French Kumpe catheter for directionality. Through the Kumpe catheter, the Amplatz wire was successfully advanced into the IVC.  Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the dialysis catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The venotomy tract was dilated to allow introduction of a peel-away sheath.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Hepatocellular carcinomas with LR-5 lesions in segment 2 and segment IVb.  Additional Clinical Information: Hepatocellular carcinoma with intrahepatic tumors  PROCEDURE:   1. US-guided left radial artery access 2. Diagnostic visceral angiography 3. Selective internal radioembolization with Yttrium-90  FINDINGS: ANGIOGRAPHY: Vessels catheterized and angiograms performed, as follows:  Celiac artery: Conventional anatomy. Left hepatic artery: Tumoral blush identified.  Specific technical notes / catheter selection: None  Transcatheter embolization using Yttrium-90 microspheres performed from: Left hepatic artery (series 3)  IMPRESSION:   Successful Yttrium-90 Sirspheres selective internal radiotherapy of left hepatic lobe hepatocellular carcinomas.  TREATMENT PLAN:  1. Patient will return in 4-6 weeks for selective DEB-TACE of LR-5 lesion supplied by the right hepatic artery posterior division branches. 2. Access site precautions and orders placed.  TECHNIQUE:  With the patient in the supine position, the left wrist was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The left wrist was evaluated with ultrasound and left radial artery patency and acceptable size criteria were documented and images were properly stored in PACS. A modified Allen test (Barbeau test Type B) was performed on the left wrist to confirm patency of the ulnopalmar arch using pulse oximetry.   1% lidocaine solution was administered for local anesthesia. Access was obtained to the left radial artery using a 21 gauge micro needle and ultrasound guidance. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. A wire was placed through the needle. A hydrophilic Glidesheath was advanced slowly over the wire. 3000 units of heparin, 200 mcg of nitroglycerin and 2.5 mg of verapamil was given through the arterial sheath with slow hemodilution. A side flush was started.   A 5-Fr [VENDOR]y/[VENDOR] catheter was advanced over an 0.035" wire into the abdominal aorta. The catheter was used to catheterize the visceral vessels described below. Angiograms were performed. A microcatheter system was used to catheterize distal visceral and hepatic vessels, as described below. Specific vessels catheterized and embolized are described in detail below. Tumor blush was confirmed on angiography.  Once the catheter was in adequate position, a pre-determined dose of 90-Yttrium radioactive particles was infused into the target hepatic artery. The microcatheter was flushed and the microcatheter was disposed of appropriately.   All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. A TR Band was placed on the left wrist for hemostasis. The access sheath was removed and no hematoma was seen. A radial artery pulse was confirmed distal to the puncture site confirming patent hemostasis.   The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Primary hyperaldosteronism  Procedure:   1. Bilateral adrenal vein sampling 2. Left adrenal venogram 3. Right adrenal venogram  Findings:    1.  Intermittent fluoroscopic images demonstrate catheter position in the infrarenal IVC, suprarenal IVC, left renal vein, left adrenal vein, right renal vein, and right adrenal vein. 2.  Left and right adrenal venograms demonstrated conventional anatomy with drainage into the left renal vein and direct to IVC, respectively. 3.  Samples to be assayed for cortisol and aldosterone:  Infrarenal IVC: 0916  Left adrenal vein 1: 0919  Right adrenal vein 1: 0943  Right adrenal vein 2: 0949   Impression:   Successful bilateral adrenal vein sampling for cortisol and aldosterone levels.  Treatment Plan:   Sample sent to the lab for analysis. Lateralization index will be calculated when lab values are available.   Technique:   At least 30 minutes prior to the initiation the procedure, a cosyntropin infusion was initiated at 40 mcg/h through a peripheral IV.  The right groin was prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  The vascular structures were ultrasonographically evaluated.   Images were stored and transferred to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right common femoral vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  Vein patency and needle entry were documented. A 0.018" wire was placed and the needle exchanged for a 5 French dilator. The microwire was removed and a 180 cm [VENDOR]son wire was advanced into the IVC. The dilator was exchanged for a 5 French sheath and 5000 units of heparin were then administered systemically.  A Sim[VENDOR]s 2 glide catheter was advanced into the infrarenal IVC and venous sampling performed.  Next, the catheter was advanced into the left adrenal vein and venography was performed. Left adrenal vein sampling was perfo[HCW].  The catheter was then exchanged for a 5 Fr Mikaelsson catheter, which was then used to select the right adrenal vein and venography performed. Right adrenal vein samples were drawn through the base catheter, and, subsequently, through the side arm of a Tuohy-Borst adapter after coaxially advancing a 0.014 Transcend microwire into the right adrenal vein .  Catheters and sheath were removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression. A sterile dressing was applied.  Cosyntropin infusion was terminated.  Patient tolerated the procedure without complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Dysphasia.  Procedure:   1.	Gastrostomy tube placement under fluoroscopic guidance.  Findings:   1.	The gastrostomy tube is in good position.  2.	Gentle hand injection of contrast material confirms positioning of the gastrostomy tube within the gastric lumen.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of 18 French MIC gastrostomy tube as above.  Treatment Plan:   The tube should be placed to gravity drainage and should not be used for 24 hours. 25 cc of water can be administered per hour. At 4 hours, if residuals are less than 30%, the patient can have tube feeds advanced starting at a half dose.   Technique:   Informed consent for the procedure was obtained, and time-out was performed prior to the procedure.  The skin overlying the access site was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).   Using ultrasound guidance, the liver edge was identified and demarcated on the patient's skin along with the left most inferior rib. Then using fluoroscopic guidance, an appropriate puncture site was identified, and the skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the mid abdomen access site were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthesia.  3 T-fasteners were placed adjacent to the planned tube access site. Positioning of the T-fasteners within the gastric lumen was confirmed by return of air and direct injection of contrast material.    Next, under fluoroscopic guidance, an 18-gauge needle was directed into the gastric lumen. Needle positioning within the gastric lumen was confirmed with aspiration of air as well as gentle hand injection of contrast material.  A wire was advance through the 18-gauge needle.  The 18-gauge needle was removed over a wire. Serial dilation was accomplished over the stiff wire. An 18 French Halyard G-tube was advanced over a wire in an antegrade fashion and advanced through the anterior abdominal wall. All wires and catheters were removed. The bulb was inflated with 10 mL of a 10% contrast mixture. Gentle hand injection of contrast material documents the gastric feeding tube within the gastric lumen. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained for reference purposes. The tube was flushed with saline. It was affixed to the anterior abdominal wall with a rubber flange. The patient tolerated the procedure well at time of procedure completion without complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  High intermediate risk pulmonary embolus in bilateral pulmonary arteries. Patient has elevated troponin and right heart strain on CT.  Procedure:   1.	Ultrasound-guided right common femoral vein access. 2.	Catheterization of the main, right, and left pulmonary arteries. 3.	Catheterization and angiogram of the right and left lower lobe pulmonary arteries. 4.	Catheter directed thrombolysis of the right and left pulmonary arteries.  Findings:  . 1.	Appropriate placement of bilateral thrombolysis catheters in the left and right lower lobe pulmonary arteries.    Impression:   1.	 Bilateral pulmonary artery thrombolysis.  Treatment Plan:    0.5 mg of TPA will be administered through each catheter overnight. 500 units of heparin will be administered through the right femoral sheath overnight. Catheters will be removed in the morning.  Technique:    The patient was placed supine on the angiography table. The right groin was prepped and draped in the typical sterile fashion. Using micropuncture technique, the right common femoral vein was accessed using real-time ultrasound guidance.  An 11 French 10 cm sheath was advanced into the right common femoral vein. An angled pigtail catheter was used to catheterize the main pulmonary artery taking care to not cross any cordae tendoni. An Amplatz wire was advanced through the catheter, and over the Amplatz wire a 6 French 90 cm sheath was advanced into the main pulmonary artery. A second wire was advanced through the sheath. A vertebral catheter and Bentson wire were used to catheterize the left main and subsequently left lower lobe pulmonary artery. Angiogram of the left lower lobe pulmonary artery was performed demonstrating sluggish flow consistent with thrombus. The catheter was removed, and over the wire, a 20 cm infusion length UniFuse catheter was advanced into the left lower lobe pulmonary artery.  A vertebral catheter and Bentson wire were used to catheterize the right main and subsequently right lower lobe pulmonary artery. Angiogram was performed demonstrating appropriate placement within the right lower lobe pulmonary artery. The catheter was removed, and over the wire, a 20 cm infusion length UniFuse catheter was advanced into the right lower lobe pulmonary artery.  0.05 TPA milligrams per hour was administered through each infusion catheter, and 500 units of heparin per hour was infused through the sheath. The sheath was sutured to the skin, and a sterile dressing was applied. The patient was transferred to the ICU for monitoring.
