DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: 53-year-old Male  with no significant PMH who who presented with one week of headache, fever, and acute onset severe back pain and a sensation of numbness in his lower extremities followed by fever and confusion. He presented to an outside emergency department where lumbar puncture revealed xanthochromia and cerebral image showed concern for small amount of subarachnoid hemorrhage and bilateral parietal lobes and occipital lobes. He is transferred to [HOSPITAL] for further evaluation management. Diagnostic cerebral angiogram was indicated for further evaluation.  PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 30 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] was the fellow. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right internal carotid artery Right external carotid artery Left internal carotid artery Left external carotid artery Left vertebral artery  ANESTHESIA: Local in the right groin with bupivacaine. Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by the nurse present during the entire procedure. The patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Sedation was administered by a specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for the duration of the procedure as outlined above (Total intra service time, 30 ). Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.  MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine SQ 10 cc  Versed 1 mg IV Fentanyl 50 mcg IV Heparin 3000 units IV Protamine 20 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.038" Bentson guidewire 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 5 French Cordis Vertebral catheter  Cardiva Vascade Omnipaque-300 contrast material (100 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 5 French sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP, Lateral and Oblique views.   Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a Vascade followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: Noninvasive imaging with.  FINDINGS:  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified.    RIGHT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:   No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified.    LEFT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. Reflux of contrast into the contralateral vertebral artery was achieved. The origin of PICA is normal bilaterally.     COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.   IMPRESSION: No visualized vascular abnormalities which could account for patient's symptoms and imaging findings

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Painful T7 compression fracture limiting activities of daily living.  Procedure:   T7 kyphoplasty  FINDINGS:  1. A moderate anterior compression deformity is present at T7. 2. Cement distribution is excellent.    IMPRESSION: Uneventful image guided kyphoplasty for an acute T7  painful compression fracture.  TECHNIQUE:  The patient was placed under general anesthesia and positioned prone on the Angiography table.  The back was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. The C-Arm was brought into position and the     T7 pedicles were identified and marked on the skin with a sterile marker. An extrapedicular approach into the vertebral body was determined appropriate.   Under fluoroscopic guidance and through a left extrapedicular approach, an 11-gauge trocar needle was advanced into the C7 vertebral body.  Needle tip position was confirmed in the AP and lateral planes to ensure appropriate position.   The stylet needle was replaced with the drill through the outer cannula and the drill advanced to the anterior third of the vertebral body toward the midline under multiplanar fluoroscopic guidance.  Attention was then turned to the contralateral side, where under fluoroscopic guidance via a right extrapedicular approach, an 11-gauge trocar was advanced into the T7 vertebral body. Needle tip position was confirmed in the AP and lateral planes to ensure appropriate position.  The drill was then advanced to the anterior third of the vertebral body toward the midline under multiplanar fluoroscopic guidance.    After completing bilateral trocar entry into the vertebral body, inflatable bone tamps were inserted through each cannula respectively and advanced under lateral fluoroscopic guidance into the vertebral body proximal to the anterior cortex.   Under multiplanar fluoroscopic imaging, the balloon bone tamps were inflated, deflated and removed. Subsequently, the cement was delivered under biplane fluoroscopic observation with careful attention to the cement distribution.   There was no breach of the lateral wall or anterior cortex of the vertebral body.  There was partial reduction of the fracture.  Once the bone cement had hardened, the cannulas were then removed.  Post-procedure, excellent hemostasis was achieved at the small 5 mm puncture sites with manual compression.  A sterile dressing was applied.  The patient was kept in the prone position for approximately 10 minutes post cement injection before being transferred to a [HOSPITAL]rney and then the recovery area.  The patient tolerated the procedure well without complications. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.IR.1  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Intra-abdominal fluid collection  Procedure:   US-guided drainage of intraperitoneal fluid  Findings:   1. Minimally complex peritoneal free fluid seen on ultrasound.  2. Successful placement of 12Fr pigtail drain in the right lower quadrant.  Red/brown non-viscous fluid returned.  50-100mL of fluid removed during procedure.  Tube then connected to suction bag with further drainage.  Impression:   Technically successful US-guided drainage of peritoneal fluid.  Treatment Plan:   1. Flush drain with 10 cc saline q8h. 2. Technique:  Target: Right lower quadrant peritoneal fluid Imaging: Ultrasound Drain: 12 Fr APD Drainage: 50-100 mL serosanguinous fluid aspirated during procedure Microbiology: Sample sent  A superficial skin entry site was selected based on available imaging and the overlying skin entry site was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier to target the above collection. The skin surface was anesthetized with 1-2% lidocaine. Using continuous real-time grayscale and/or color doppler ultrasound guidance, a needle was introduced into the target site and imaging guidance confirmed adequate positioning. The access device was utilized with an 0.035" wire to introduce the drainage catheter listed above following any necessary serial dilatation. Ultrasound images confirmed appropriate positioning within the target structure. The catheter was secured to the skin surface using nonabsorbable suture material and dressed in typical fashion. Any samples not sent to laboratory for analysis were discarded. The patient tolerated the procedure and was sent to the recovery area for monitoring. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Progressing renal disease requiring long-term hemodialysis access.  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled large bore central venous catheter placement  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the large bore central venous catheter, as described, the tip terminates in the right atrium.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a  15.5 French, 19 cm (tip-to-cuff), tunneled large bore central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.  Treatment Plan:   1. Routine catheter care. 2. The catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissues overlying the vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle. An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 Amplatz wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the dialysis catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The venotomy tract was dilated to allow introduction of a peel-away sheath.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Dislodged gastrostomy tube. CVA, dysphagia  Procedure: Gastrostomy tube reinsertion under fluoroscopic guidance.  Findings:   1.	Opacification of a persistent gastrostomy tract. 2.	The new tube is appropriately positioned within in the stomach.  Impression:   1.	Successful replacement of 18 French MIC gastrostomy tube.  Treatment Plan:   It is OK to use the tube immediately.  Routine check and change recommended in 6 months.  Technique:   Informed consent for the procedure was obtained, and time-out was performed prior to the procedure. The skin overlying the access site was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). The preexisting sinus tract and skin around the existing tube were infiltrated with local anesthetic (Urojet). A scout image was obtained of the abdomen.  A Kumpe catheter was inserted into the preexisting sinus and contrast was injected with findings as detailed above. A glidewire was navigated through the tract into the stomach and the Kumpe catheter was advanced over the wire. Gastric access was confirmed with contrast injection. An Amplatz wire was coiled within the stomach. A 22F peel-away sheath and dilator were advanced into the stomach under direct fluoroscopic control. The obturator was removed and a new gastrostomy tube was inserted into the stomach. The sheath was removed and the retention balloon was inflated with a mixture of 10% contrast in sterile water. The balloon was pulled back to the stomach wall and the flange was cinched down gently to the level of the skin. Tube positioning within the stomach was confirmed with contrast injection. Image saved to PACS.  Procedural Personnel Attending(s): [HCW] Fellow(s): None Resident(s): None Advanced practice provider(s): None  Complications: No immediate complications. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]C.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Ischemic cholangiopathy  Procedure:   1. Right internal/external biliary drain replacement - 25 cm 14 French multipurpose drain with 5 cm of sideholes added beyond the radiopaque marker.  Findings:   1.	Cholangiogram demonstrates persistent abnormal intrahepatic biliary ducts with multiple strictures, and free flow of injected contrast into the small bowel. 2.	Newly placed biliary drain is appropriately positioned with the distal tip in the small bowel and the proximal side hole in a peripheral bile duct.  Impression:   1.	Unchanged appearance of biliary tree. Adequately positioned existing drain. 2.	Uneventful image guided replacement of the biliary catheter as described. The catheter was secured to the skin with 2-0 Prolene. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Impression:   1.	Successful replacement of 18 French MIC gastrostomy tube.   Treatment Plan:   It is OK to use the tube immediately.  Routine check and change recommended in 6 months. The skin overlying the access site was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). The skin and subcutaneous tissue around the existing tube were infiltrated with local anesthetic. A scout image was obtained of the abdomen.  A wire was cannulated into the existing tube and passed into the gastric lumen. The pre-existing G-tube was removed over the wire after deflating the bulb. A new gastrostomy tube was advanced over the wire. The replacement tube overlies the stomach on static fluoroscopic image saved to PACS.  The balloon was inflated with 10 mL of a sterile water. Gentle hand injection of contrast material documents the gastric feeding tube within the gastric lumen. Antibiotics: None  Blood loss:  Less than 10 ml  Checklist:	Informed consent was obtained discussing the risks, benefits and alternatives to the planned procedure. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Dysphagia  Procedure: Aborted percutaneous gastrostomy tube placement  Findings:  Abdominal CT from [DATE] was reviewed  1.	 The Dobbhoff feeding tube has its tip in the midesophagus. 2.	Gastric insufflation showed immediate decompression into duodenum. 3.	The stomach is high in position and no portion of the stomach comes below the costal margin. 4.	Even at the midline the insufflated stomach is above the xiphoid process.  Impression:   1.	 Aborted gastrostomy tube placement. There is no safe percutaneous window.  2.	Please note this may present a similar problem for the endoscopist.  3.	Consider open surgical gastrostomy tube placement.  Treatment Plan:    The referring clinician was verbally notified by telephone that there is no safe window and a surgical gastrostomy tube placement is the safest approach.  Technique:  The anterior abdominal wall was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. The pre-existing Dobbhoff tube was in the mid esophagus. It was advanced to just beyond the GE junction under fluoroscopic guidance. IV glucagon was administered. Insufflation resulted in immediate duodenal decompression. A second milligram of IV glucagon was administered. The gastric content continued to decompress into small bowel. The entirety of the stomach is above the costal margin and there is no safe percutaneous window for gastrostomy tube placement.   Procedural Personnel Attending(s): [HCW] Fellow(s): None Resident(s): None Advanced practice provider(s): None  Complications: No immediate complications.  Contrast: 0 mL Omnipaque  Fluoroscopy time: 1.9 minutes Fluoroscopy dose:  6.80 mGy  Conscious Sedation:  Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by nurse present during the entire procedure. Patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Administered by the specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for a total of 45 minutes (Total intra service time).  Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.  Medications: Versed 2 mg IV. Fentanyl 100 mcg IV. 4 mg IV Zofran and 2 mg IV glucagon  Antibiotics: 2 g IV Ancef  Blood loss:  Less than 10 ml  Checklist:	Informed consent was obtained discussing the risks, benefits and alternatives to the planned procedure.  Pre-sedation H&P was performed and sedation consent obtained. The patient’s name, medical record number, date of birth, allergies, procedure being performed including site and pertinent laboratory values were reviewed and confirmed with the technologist, nurse and patient.  These requirements including the Time Out were met prior to initiating the procedure.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Acute on chronic renal failure requiring emergent central venous access for dialysis.  Procedure:   1.	Non-tunneled large bore central venous catheter (trialysis) placement  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the large bore central venous catheter, as described, the tip terminates upper superior vena cava on chest radiograph.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a 15 French,  15 cm, non-tunneled large bore central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.  Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care. The catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:   The procedure was performed at bedside with ultrasound guidance. The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).    The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic. Ultrasound evaluation of the vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS. Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with an 18-gauge needle. After confirming appropriate placement within the vein using IV tubing to view respiratory variation, a 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   The venotomy tract was dilated to allow introduction of the catheter over the wire. The catheter was subsequently introduced over the wire and the wire removed. The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound images were stored in PACS. Conscious Sedation: None  Medications: None  Antibiotics: None  Blood loss:  Less than 10 ml  Checklist:	Informed consent was obtained discussing the risks, benefits and alternatives to the planned procedure.  Pre-sedation H&P was performed and sedation consent obtained. The patient’s name, medical record number, date of birth, allergies, procedure being performed including site and pertinent laboratory values were reviewed and confirmed with the technologist, nurse and patient.  These requirements including the Time Out were met prior to initiating the procedure.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Prolonged hospitalization status post bilateral orthotopic lung transplant. Now requiring dialysis with need for PermCath. Needs long-term IV access. Also has malfunctioning Kangaroo GJ.  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled large bore central venous catheter placement  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is occluded. The brachiocephalic vein isn't accessible to the patient's tracheostomy and body configuration. A small right external jugular vein is patent. 2.	After placement of the large and small bore central venous catheters, as described, both catheter tips terminate in the right atrium. 3.	The existing Kangaroo GJ tube has a fundal loop and terminates in the gastric antrum. An occluding plug was dislodged with injection through the J port. This tube was ultimately replaced for a new 18 French 45 cm MIC gastrojejunostomy tube.    Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a  15.5 French, 19 cm (tip-to-cuff), tunneled large bore central venous catheter via the right external jugular vein. 2.	Uncomplicated image guided placement of 5 French, 24 cm, tunneled small bore central venous catheter via the right external jugular vein. Successful removal and replacement of the existing GJ for and the new GJ tube above.  Treatment Plan:   1. Both catheters are available for immediate use. 2. The GJ tube is available for immediate use.   Technique:  Line placement:  The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).   The skin and subcutaneous tissues overlying the vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating occlusion, however the right external jugular vein appeared patent. Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle. An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle down to the IVC. At this point, given there would be 2 lines placed, examination of the anterior chest soft tissues was performed in plans for tunneling. The decision was made to obtain another venous access before any tunneling greater line placement approximately 1 cm more medial from the initial access. Over the existing access, the needle was removed, and a 5 French peel-away sheath was placed over the wire.   Under direct ultrasound guidance, the vessel was accessed using a new micropuncture needle. A wire was advanced around the IVC, and the needle was exchanged for a 5 French micropuncture transitional s[HCW].  Now with the 2 stable accesses in place, attention was turned to creating the tunnel. Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the dialysis catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The venotomy tract of the medial access was dilated to allow introduction of a peel-away sheath.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.  The tunneling device loaded with the smallbore catheter was then used to bring this through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy. The catheter was cut to the appropriate length; and then fed through the peel-away sheath.  The catheters were sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS.    Gastrojejunostomy evaluation/replacement: Attention was then turned to the existing can grew GJ. A fundal loop was noted. Upon initial evaluation, there was resistance to injection of the tube; which was resolved with consistent forceful injection of contrast/saline. Cine fluoroscopy images were stored to PACS. A wire was then advanced through the pre-existing GJ. The wire was able to be easily advanced postpyloric and into the jejunum however the fundal loop could not be successfully reduced using various techniques including Fogarty balloon advancement (would not advance through the existing J portion possibly due to residual intraluminal narrowing).  Ultimately the decision was made to remove the GJ in its entirety and give up the access. Through the pre-existing percutaneous tract, a Kumpe catheter and stiff Glidewire were navigated to the pylorus, into the duodenum, and into the jejunum. The Kumpe catheter was removed over the wire, and a new 18 French MIC GJ tube was advanced over the wire into the jejunum. The balloon was injected with dilute contrast within the stomach. Contrast injection through both the jejunostomy and gastrostomy ports confirmed adequate positioning. The patient tolerated the procedure well without any complication.   Procedural Personnel Attending(s): [HCW] Fellow(s): [HCW] Resident(s): None Advanced practice provider(s): None  Complications: No immediate complications.  Contrast: 20 mL Omnipaque (through the enteric access, no IV contrast administered).   Fluoroscopy time: 16.7 minutes Fluoroscopy dose:  204 mGy  Conscious Sedation:  Please see separate anesthesia documentation.  Medications: Please see separate anesthesia documentation.   Antibiotics: Ancef, 2 gm IV  Blood loss:  Less than 10 ml  Checklist:	Informed consent was obtained discussing the risks, benefits and alternatives to the planned procedure.  Pre-sedation H&P was performed and sedation consent obtained. The patient’s name, medical record number, date of birth, allergies, procedure being performed including site and pertinent laboratory values were reviewed and confirmed with the technologist, nurse and patient.  These requirements including the Time Out were met prior to initiating the procedure.  [HCW], was present for the key and critical portions of the procedure and associated imaging guidance.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Hydronephrosis despite JJ stent placement, worsening renal function  Procedure:   1.	Left nephrostogram and nephrostomy tube placement      Findings:  Comparison is made to a previous exam dated [DATE].  1.	LEFT hydronephrosis   2.	Incomplete nephrostogram performed due to concern for over pressurizing the urinary tract upon initial PCN placement in the setting of hydronephrosis   Catheter(s):  8.5 F     nephrostomy tube  Impression:   1.	Uneventful ultrasound and fluroscopic-guided placement of a left nephrostomy tube as described above.      Treatment Plan:   Patient should return for routine check and change in 8-12 weeks.        Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained to the patient. Written informed consent was obtained.  A time out/call to order was performed prior to procedure initiation.  The soft tissues overlying the access site were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Ultrasound was utilized to identify an appropriate access site. Static ultrasound image was obtained and stored to PACS for reference purposes. Subsequently, under fluoroscopic and real-time concurrent ultrasound guidance, access was obtained into a posterior, inferior calyx using a 21 ga needle and a triaxial sheath system ([VENDOR]). Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site. A wire was advanced centrally. Serial dilation was accomplished over the wire. The wire and inner dilator were removed. Non-ionic contrast was injected into the collecting system and images of the antegrade pyelogram were obtained and stored to PACS.  An 0.035” wire was advanced through the existing access. A nephrostomy tube was advanced over the wire and the Cope loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis. Contrast injection confirmed location. The catheter was sutured to the flank with monofilament suture and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.  The procedure was well tolerated, and patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by nurse present during the entire procedure. Patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Multiple myeloma  Procedure:   1.	Non-tunneled large bore central venous catheter placement  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the large bore central venous catheter, as described, the tip terminates near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a 14 French,  20 cm, non-tunneled large bore central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.  Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care. The catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Local anesthesia used for this procedure   The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic. Ultrasound evaluation of the vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS. Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS.  A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, a 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance. There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Superior mesenteric artery syndrome with chronic abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting with eating. Anorexia.  Procedure:   1.	Primary gastrojejunostomy tube placement under fluoroscopic guidance.  Findings:   1.	The gastrojejunostomy tube is in good position.  2.	Gentle hand injection of contrast material confirms positioning of the gastrostomy tube within the gastric lumen and jejunal portion near the ligament of Treitz  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of 18 French MIC gastrojejunostomy tube as above.  Treatment Plan:   The gastric portion of the tube should be placed to gravity drainage and should not be used for 4 hours. The jejunal portion can be used immediately.  Recommend routine exchange in 6 months.   Technique:   Informed consent for the procedure was obtained, and time-out was performed prior to the procedure.  The skin overlying the access site was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the mid abdomen were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.   Using fluoroscopic and ultrasonographic guidance, an appropriate puncture site was identified.  3 T-fasteners were placed adjacent to the planned tube access site. Positioning of the T-fasteners within the gastric lumen was confirmed by return of air and direct injection of contrast material.  Next, under fluoroscopic guidance, an 18-gauge needle was directed into the gastric lumen. Needle positioning within the gastric lumen was confirmed with aspiration of air as well as gentle hand injection of contrast material.  A wire was advance through the 18-gauge needle.  The 18-gauge needle was removed over a wire. A 6 French 25 cm sheath was advanced. Leaving the Amplatz as a safety wire in the stomach, a stiff glide and Kumpe catheter were used to advance the catheter into the small bowel. Contrast was injected demonstrating appropriate positioning of the ligament of Treitz. Over the stiff Glidewire, after serial dilation, a 22 French peel-away sheath was advanced. Through the sheath, over the wire, an 18 French GJ tube was advanced with its tip in the region of the ligament of Treitz in the small bowel.  The bulb was inflated with 10 mL of a sterile water. Gentle hand injection of contrast material documents the gastric feeding tube within the gastric lumen. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained for reference purposes. The tube was flushed with saline. It was affixed to the anterior abdominal wall with a rubber flange. The patient tolerated the procedure well at time of procedure completion without complication.   The gastrostomy portion was placed to gravity drainage, the jejunostomy portion was capped. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Myelodysplastic syndrome  Procedure:  1. Ultrasound and Fluoroscopic guided placement of a tunneled, cuffed central venous catheter  Findings:  1. The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and normal. Vein patency and needle entry were stored to PACS. 2. The newly placed catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating in the right atrium.  Impression:   Uneventful image guided placement of right internal jugular vein tunneled Trifusion catheter as described.  Technique:  The right neck and chest region was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. The region was ultrasonographically evaluated.  Using local anesthetic and ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was punctured with a 21 gauge needle.  An image documenting vein patency and needle entry was saved and stored to PACS.   A 0.018” wire was passed centrally and the needle exchanged for a 5 French transitional dilator. A 0.035” wire was advanced through the dilator and negotiated into the IVC.  The skin tract was dilated and a 13 French dilator peel-away combination placed over the wire.  The soft tissues caudal and lateral to the sheath entry site were anesthetized with lidocaine with epinephrine. A dermatotomy was made and a tunneling tool brought from the dermatotomy to the venotomy. The catheter was brought through the tunnel.  During suspended respiration, the catheter was advanced through the peel-away and positioned centrally using fluoroscopy. The peel-away was removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression.  The venotomy was closed with Dermabond and Steri-Strips applied. A single Prolene suture was placed at the catheter tunnel exit site. An antimicrobial disc and sterile dressing were applied.  The catheter was aspirated, flushed, and heparinized per protocol. The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient was discharged in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Urothelial carcinoma involving entire left kidney with persistent hematuria for a few weeks. Patient has no significant function in the left kidney. Patient is not surgical candidate for nephrectomy per urology. Team and patient request embolization of left kidney for palliation of hematuria. Risk of infection was discussed with urology and the patient and both are willing to proceed.  PROCEDURE:   1. US-guided left radial artery access 2. Left renal angiography 3. Arterial embolization of tumor involving the entire left kidney 4. Post-embolization angiography  FINDINGS: ANGIOGRAPHY: Vessels catheterized using base catheter and microcatheter/microwire combination and angiograms performed:  Left renal artery: Limited parenchymal opacification in the setting of known tumor. No active extravasation or pseudoaneurysm.. Post-embolization left renal artery angiography: Truncation of flow within the superior and inferior pole left renal arteries with no parenchymal opacification.  Transcatheter embolization: Vessel 1: Left renal artery Embolic: Particles Details (type/size/volume/number): 300-500 embospheres (1 vial), 500-700 embospheres (approximately 5 vials), 709 100 embospheres (approximately 3 vials)    IMPRESSION:   Technically successful particle embolization of the left kidney.  TREATMENT PLAN:  1. Continued clinical and laboratory monitoring recommended. Please contact interventional radiology if there is a change in clinical status. 2. Band to be removed in 1.5 hours per protocol.  TECHNIQUE:  With the patient in the supine position, the left wrist was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The left wrist was evaluated with ultrasound and appropriate left radial artery access criteria were documented. A modified Allen test (Barbeau test) was performed on the left wrist to confirm patency of the ulnopalmar arch using pulse oximetry.  1% lidocaine solution was administered for local anesthesia. Access was obtained to the left radial artery using a 21 gauge needle and ultrasound guidance. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. A wire was placed through the needle. A hydrophilic Glidesheath was advanced slowly over the wire. 3000 units of heparin, 200 mcg of nitroglycerin and 2.5 mg of verapamil was given through the arterial sheath with slow hemodilution. A side flush was started.   A 5-Fr angled glide catheter catheter was advanced over an 0.035" wire into the aorta. The catheter was used to catheterize the vessels described above. Angiograms were performed. A microcatheter system was used to catheterize distal vessels, as described above. Specific vessels catheterized and embolized are described in detail above.  Once the glide catheter was in adequate position, embolization was performed using the parameters detailed above taking care not to reflux particles into the aorta. Post-embolization angiography was performed, as detailed above.  All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. A band was placed on the left wrist for hemostasis. The access sheath was removed and no hematoma was seen. A radial artery pulse was confirmed distal to the puncture site confirming patent hemostasis.   The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. The left wrist was evaluated with ultrasound and left radial artery patency and acceptable size criteria were documented and images were properly stored in PACS. A modified Allen test (Barbeau test Type B) was performed on the left wrist to confirm patency of the ulnopalmar arch using pulse oximetry.   1% lidocaine solution was administered for local anesthesia. Access was obtained to the left radial artery using a 21 gauge micro needle and ultrasound guidance. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. A wire was placed through the needle. A hydrophilic Glidesheath was advanced slowly over the wire. 3000 units of heparin, 200 mcg of nitroglycerin and 2.5 mg of verapamil was given through the arterial sheath with slow hemodilution. A side flush was started.   A 5-Fr [VENDOR]y/[VENDOR] catheter was advanced over an 0.035" wire into the abdominal aorta. The catheter was used to catheterize the visceral vessels described below. Angiograms were performed. A microcatheter system was used to catheterize distal visceral and hepatic vessels, as described below. Specific vessels catheterized and embolized are described in detail below. Tumor blush was confirmed on angiography.  Cone Beam CT (CBCT) was performed intraprocedurally for purposes of treatment planning, targeting and dose calculation. Axial and coronal images were created and 3D reconstruction was performed on a separate dedicated workstation under concurrent supervision.  After confirmation of target treatment vessel, 4 mCi of Tc-99 MAA was injected slowly in this location though the catheter.   All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. A TR Band was placed on the left wrist for hemostasis. The access sheath was removed and no hematoma was seen. A radial artery pulse was confirmed distal to the puncture site confirming patent hemostasis.   The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. The patient was transferred to the Nuclear Medicine department for imaging. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESR[HOSPITAL][ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Patient with breast cancer acquiring IV chemotherapy  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen Bard port (standard profile)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen Bard power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed below.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 3-0 absorbable sutures. A running 4-0 absorbable subcuticular stitch and  Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with     Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: This is a 38 years Female who presents with SAH concerning for underlying aneurysmal rupture. Here for diagnostic cerebral angiogram with possible intervention.  PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 30 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] was the fellow. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right Internal Carotid Artery Right External Carotid Artery Left Internal Carotid Artery Left External Carotid Artery Left Vertebral Artery   ANESTHESIA: General endotracheal anesthesia was administered under the supervision of the attending anesthesiologist. Pre-, intra-, and post-anesthesia monitoring records are available in the chart.  MEDICATIONS:  Heparin 3000 units IV Protamine 20 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 F[HOSPITAL] micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.038" Bentson guidewire 6 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 5 French Cordis Vertebral catheter  Visipaque-270 contrast material (120 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 5 French sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP, Lateral and Oblique views.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY:  Rotational angiography was also performed from the diagnostic catheter in the right internal carotid artery for better delineation of the underlying angioarchitecture. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.    3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY:  Rotational angiography was also performed from the diagnostic catheter in the left internal carotid artery for better delineation of the underlying angioarchitecture. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.    Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. The sheath was left in place and on a heparinized saline drip in preparation for an intraoperative angiogram. Patient brought directly to the OR from the angiography suite.  COMPARISON: Noninvasive imaging.  FINDINGS:  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is a highly irregular multilobulated right posterior communicating artery aneurysm measuring up to 5.5 mm in maximal diameter and 5 mm in depth. There is a small lobule which is likely the site of hemorrhage which measures 2.3 x 2.1 mm. The neck of this aneurysm is 4.5 mm and the posterior communicating artery originates off the inferior aspect of the aneurysm. This is better delineated on the three-dimensional reconstructions. In addition, there is aneurysmal dilatation of the supraclinoid right ICA. There are some minor irregularities around the anterior communicating artery without clear aneurysmal features although follow-up is advised. The MCA and its branches are normal course and caliber. There is normal cortical venous drainage.  RIGHT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is a 10 x 6mm left ophthalmic artery segment aneurysm with a 6 mm base. There is a small irregular outpouching in the inferior aspect of the aneurysm. Incidental note is made of a cavernous origin of the left ophthalmic artery. The ACA and MCA and its branches are normal course and caliber. There is normal cortical venous drainage.  LEFT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. Reflux of contrast into the contralateral vertebral artery was achieved. The origin of PICA is normal bilaterally. The basilar artery and its segments are normal course and caliber. There is a patulous basilar tip without clear aneurysmal features.  3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: 3D Rotational angiography with volume-rendered three-dimensional reconstruction on an independent workstation, demonstrated a multilobulated an irregularly-shaped right posterior communicating artery aneurysm measuring 5.5 x 5 mm. There is a small distal lobule measuring 2.3 x 2.1 mm. The neck is aneurysm is 4.5 mm in the posterior communicating artery originates off the inferior portion of the aneurysm.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: 3D Rotational angiography with volume-rendered three-dimensional reconstruction on an independent workstation, demonstrated large para ophthalmic artery aneurysm measuring 10 x 5 mm with a 6 mm neck. Note is made of a cavernous origin of the ophthalmic artery.   COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: There is a multilobulated and irregularly-shaped right posterior indicating artery aneurysm measuring 5.5 x 5 mm with a small distal lobule measuring 2.3 x 2.1 mm the posterior communicating artery originates at the inferior portion of the aneurysm. Note is made of a prominent P1 segment of the right PCA. This is thought to be the cause of the patient's underlying aneurysmal rupture for which the patient is to proceed to the OR for surgical clipping.  In addition to the right posterior communicator artery aneurysm, there is a left ophthalmic artery segment aneurysm measuring 10 x 6 mm. Incidental note is made of a cavernous origin of the left ophthalmic artery.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Bladder cancer with ileal conduit and anastomotic stricture with chronic indwelling nephroureteral "upside down" nephrostomy tube. It has become dislodged with its pigtail in the mid ureter.   Procedure: Left nephrostogram and nephroureteral tube replacement              Findings: Comparison is made to a previous exam dated [DATE]. A CT of the abdomen from [DATE] was reviewed.  1. The "upside down" nephrostomy tube has its cope loop in the mid ureter. Contrast injection shows a dilated pelvicalyceal system and proximal ureter with abrupt narrowing of the distal ureter through which the tube is occlusive. 2. Filling defect and debris/mucus are identified. The wire could not be negotiated out the tip of the existing catheter, suggesting particulate occlusion. 3. The new 14 French biliary drain has its cope loop in the renal pelvis and its sideholes extending down the ureter. The hub was placed in the ileal conduit.   Impression:   Uneventful image-guided re- placement of a 14 French nephroureteral catheter/upside down nephrostomy tube as described above.  Treatment plan:  Routine exchange in 10 weeks   Technique:  The existing catheter and surrounding soft tissues were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  A scout radiograph was obtained.  Non-ionic contrast was injected through the existing nephroureteral catheter and images of the left collecting system obtained.  A 0.035” Glidewire was advanced through the existing nephroureteral catheter. The tube was removed over the wire under direct fluoroscopic visualization.  A new 14 French nephroureteral catheter (biliary drain used as an upside down nephrostomy tube) was advanced over the wire and the Cope loop formed in the renal pelvis.  Contrast injection confirmed location. The catheter hub was placed in the ileal conduit drainage bag.   The procedure was well tolerated, and patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Patient with choriocarcinoma requiring IV chemotherapy  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen MedComp port (pro fuse)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen Medcomp power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed below.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 3-0 absorbable sutures. A running 4-0 absorbable subcuticular stitch and  Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with     Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Anuric AKI  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled large bore central venous catheter placement on the right chest  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the large bore central venous catheter, as described, the tip terminates in the right atrium.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a  14 French, 23 cm (tip-to-cuff), tunneled large bore central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.  Treatment Plan:   1. Routine catheter care. 2. The catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissues overlying the vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic on the right chest.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle. An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter. Procedure:  Over-the-wire exchange of right tunneled small bore CVC  Findings:  1.	Partially retracted preexisting right-sided central venous catheter with tip overlying the SVC. 2.	Image-guided over-the-wire exchange for new tunneled small bore CVC with tip located within the right atrium on post-procedure imaging.  Impression:  Image-guided over-the-wire exchange for a new right-sided single lumen tunneled small bore CVC.  Plan:  Catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:  The patient was transported to the interventional suite and placed in the supine position. The patient's pre-existing right central venous catheter and the surrounding skin were prepped and draped utilizing maximum sterile barrier technique. A call to order was completed with all team members present and participating.  A scout image of the chest was obtained. The subcutaneous tunnel and catheter exit site were anesthetized with 2% lidocaine. A 0.018 wire was inserted through the pre-existing catheter and advanced into the inferior vena cava under direct fluoroscopic control. Images were stored in PACS. The pre-existing catheter was removed over the wire and a new 21 cm 5 French single lumen small bore catheter was advanced over the wire. The wire was removed and final catheter position with tip within the right atrium was confirmed on completion imaging. Per patient preference, the catheter was secured with a StatLock device and covered with dressing materials provided by the patient. The procedure was well-tolerated and the patient was transported from the interventional suite in stable condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  head and neck cancer, dysphagia  Procedure:   1.	Gastrostomy tube placement under fluoroscopic guidance.  Findings:   1.	Preprocedural scout imaging after gastric insufflation demonstrates adequate percutaneous window to the stomach.  2.	Gentle hand injection of contrast material confirms positioning of the gastrostomy tube within the gastric lumen. The gastrostomy tube is in good position.   Impression:   1.	Successful placement of 18 French MIC gastrostomy tube as above.  Treatment Plan:   The tube should be placed to gravity drainage and should not be used for 4 hours.   25 cc of water can be administered per hour. At 4 hours, if residuals are less than 30%, the patient can have tube feeds advanced starting at a half dose.  Technique:   The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the mid abdomen were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.   Using fluoroscopic and ultrasonographic guidance, an appropriate puncture site was identified.  3 T-fasteners were placed adjacent to the planned tube access site. Positioning of the T-fasteners within the gastric lumen was confirmed by return of air and direct injection of contrast material.  Next, under fluoroscopic guidance, an 18-gauge needle was directed into the gastric lumen. Needle positioning within the gastric lumen was confirmed with aspiration of air as well as gentle hand injection of contrast material.  A wire was advance through the 18-gauge needle.  The 18-gauge needle was removed over a wire.   An 8 mm x 4 cm Conquest balloon was loaded coaxially through An 18 French Halyard G-tube and advanced over a wire into the gastric lumen with the trailing edge of the balloon outside the skin entry site. The balloon was inflated along the skin tract until waisting of the balloon was no longer seen and the entire system was advanced under fluoroscopic guidance into the stomach. All wires and catheters were removed. The balloon was inflated with 10 mL of  sterile water. Gentle hand injection of contrast material documents the gastric feeding tube within the gastric lumen. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained for reference purposes. The tube was flushed with saline. It was affixed to the anterior abdominal wall with a rubber flange. The patient tolerated the procedure well at time of procedure completion without complication.   Procedural Personnel Attending(s): [HCW]  Complications: No immediate complications. DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: This is a 46 year old Male who presents for diagnostic cerebral angiography to better characterize multifocal acute and subacute strokes in the setting of severe vasculopathy noted on CT angiography.   PROCEDURE:  1. Diagnostic cerebral angiogram. 2. Intra-arterial non-thrombolytic infusion with follow-up study, right internal carotid artery  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 30 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. He participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right Internal Carotid Artery Right External Carotid Artery Left Internal Carotid Artery Left External Carotid Artery Right Vertebral Artery   ANESTHESIA: Local in the right groin with bupivacaine. Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by the nurse present during the entire procedure. The patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Sedation was administered by a specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for the duration of the procedure as outlined above (Total intra service time, 30 ). Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.  MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine SQ 10 cc  Versed 1.5 mg IV Fentanyl 100 mcg IV Heparin 3000 units IV Protamine 20 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.038" Bentson guidewire 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 5 French Cordis Vertebral catheter  Cardiva Vascade Omnipaque-300 contrast material (80 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 5 French sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP, Lateral and Oblique views.   After the initial angiogram of the right internal carotid artery, 15 mg of verapamil were infused over 10 minutes into the right internal carotid artery. Interval angiography was performed 10 minutes later which demonstrated no improvement of the diffuse pattern of vasculopathy.  Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a Vascade followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: Noninvasive imaging.  FINDINGS:  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  Diffuse vasculopathy affecting medium to small caliber vessels in the right anterior circulation, with moderate to severe stenosis in a diffuse pattern throughout both the anterior and middle cerebral artery territories. Focal segmental areas of stenosis and poststenotic dilatation are noted, particularly in the right inferior M2 with beading of the superior and inferior parietal arteries. There is no significant vasculopathy affecting the internal carotid artery although there may be some mild tapering at the terminus. The A1 segment is moderately involved with mild changes in the right M1 segment. No definitive evidence of an aneurysm or venous shunt.  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST VASODILATOR INFUSION): No interval improvement of the diffuse pattern of vasculopathy.   RIGHT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: Diffuse vasculopathy affecting medium to small caliber vessels in the left anterior circulation, with moderate to severe stenosis in a diffuse pattern throughout the anterior and middle cerebral artery territories. As on the right side, the anterior cerebral artery territories appear to be more diffusely affected. Focal areas of stenosis and poststenotic dilatation are noted throughout both territories. There is mild to moderate involvement of the proximal left M1 and A1 segments.  LEFT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   RIGHT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: Diffuse vasculopathy affecting primarily medium more so than smaller vessel caliber arteries and posterior circulation. The right posterior inferior cerebellar artery, bilateral superior cerebellar arteries, and bilateral posterior cerebral arteries are affected. There is no significant vasculopathy of the vertebral or basilar arteries. Retrograde opacification of the distal left ACA territory is noted along with some retrograde filling of the left MCA territory. No evidence of aneurysm or focal shunting.  COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: 1. Diffuse, moderate to severe vasculopathy primarily affecting moderate more so than small caliber vessels in the bilateral anterior circulation as well as the posterior circulation. There is notable absence of significant vasculopathy in the large vessels including the basilar, internal carotid, and vertebral arteries. The pattern is too diffuse and severe to be consistent with intracranial atherosclerotic disease, particularly in the absence of any significant atherosclerotic burden in the cervical arteries or aortic arch. Further evaluation will be necessary to assess for underlying inflammatory versus infectious vasculopathies.  2. No response to an intra-arterial vasodilator trial; in specific, there was no relaxation of the multifocal stenoses after 15 mg of verapamil infusion.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:   21 y.o. female presenting with multiple symptoms and PMHx of EDS, POTS, MCAS. Diagnostic venography  IVUS utilized during case  Findings:  Access site(s): Right internal jugular Sheath size(s): 9-Fr  Under ultrasound guidance, with continuous recording and reporting, a micropuncture needle was advanced into the target vessel detailed above and a microwire was advanced through the needle. The needle was removed and a micropuncture sheath was exchanged over the wire, through which an 0.035" wire was introduced. A micropuncture sheath was exchanged for a vascular sheath as detailed above.  VENOGRAPHY: The following vessels were catheterized and diagnostic venography was performed:  Left renal vein:  - Extrinsic compression of the proximal left renal vein resulting in any significant narrowing with associated medial collateral's and ovarian vein reflux. No evidence of thrombosis. - Ovarian vein reflux extending all the way to the pelvis and resulting in reflux through the pelvic collaterals to the right ovarian vein. Perirenal hilar varices present. - IVUS: Demonstrates up to 59% narrowing of the left renal vein.  Left common iliac vein: Extrinsic compression where the right common iliac artery crosses over with associated cross pelvic and lumbar collateral veins. No evidence of thrombosis. Left internal iliac vein: Positive for reflux Left external iliac vein: Patent vein without evidence of thrombosis. IVUS: Demonstrates up to 56% narrowing of the left common iliac vein.  Inferior vena cava: Patent vein without evidence of thrombosis.  Right common iliac vein: Patent vein without evidence of thrombosis. Brisk flow of contrast. Right internal iliac vein: No reflux. Right external iliac vein: Patent vein without evidence of thrombosis.  Impression:   - Left renal vein with hemodynamically significant narrowing - Left ovarian vein reflux which courses to the right ovarian vein - Left perirenal hilar varices - Left proximal iliac vein compression with cross-pelvic and lumbar collaterals  Treatment Plan:  - Nickel sensitivity testing - Consult with vascular surgery regarding left renal vein compression - Would address renal vein narrowing first as left ovarian vein reflux is complicated by narrowed ovarian vein centrally where it inserts on the renal vein and collateral flow through perirenal hilar varices - Follow up after nickel testing for possible stenting of the left common iliac vein  Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained. Patient was placed in supine position and, following sedation, the access sites were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  Venous Access:  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the access site(s) were infiltrated with lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed, demonstrating patency. Under continuous ultrasound guidance, with permanent recording and reporting, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle. An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018" wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire. Through the micropuncture introducer set, an 0.035" wire was advanced into the IVC under fluoroscopic guidance. A sheath was placed at the access site, as detailed. A catheter and/or sheath combination was advanced into the IVC and cavography was then performed, with findings detailed above.  Using a catheter/sheath combination, the vessels detailed above were catheterized and venography was performed.   All instruments and devices were removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression at the end of the procedure. No immediate complication occurred, and the patient was discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. INTRA-OPERATIVE CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: Status-post surgical clipping of a ruptured right posterior communicating artery aneurysm. Intra-operative angiography was requested.  PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: 30 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending. [HCW] was the fellow. [HCW] interpreted the images.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right internal carotid artery Left vertebral artery  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.038" Bentson Guidewire  5 French Cordis Vertebral catheter Mynx Closure device Omnipaque-300 contrast material (60 cc)  ANESTHESIA: The patient was under general anesthesia in the operating room.  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed. Informed consent was obtained as part of general consent for the craniotomy.  In the operating room, the right common femoral artery sheath, which had been placed in interventional radiology, was continuously perfused with heparinized saline before and during the surgery.  Following surgical clipping of the aneurysm, an intra-operative angiogram was performed using portable fluoroscopic equipment in the operating room. The 5 French Cordis Vertebral catheter was placed into the right internal carotid artery using a 0.035" Terumo Glidewire. Cerebral angiograms were then completed in multiple projections. Following clip readjustment, multiple views were obtained in the right internal carotid artery and left vertebral artery.  After completion of the angiogram, the vascular sheath was removed and hemostasis obtained using a Mynx closure device, followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: Prior angiogram from earlier the same day.  FINDINGS:  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is minimal filling of a distal lobule of the posterior communicating artery aneurysm.  No evidence of distal emboli is seen.   RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY ARTERY, CEREBRAL: Following repositioning of the aneurysm clip, there is no residual filling of the posterior communicating artery aneurysm status post clipping.  No evidence of distal emboli is seen.   LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is no residual filling of the posterior communicating artery aneurysm status post clipping.  No evidence of distal emboli is seen.   COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: There is no residual filling of the posterior communicating artery aneurysm status post surgical clipping.
