Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Urinary tract infection  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled central venous catheter placement  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the tunneled catheter, as described, the tip terminates near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a power-injectable, 5 Fr, 21` cm, tunneled non-cuffed single lumen central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.   Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care.  The catheter is ready for immediate use.    Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed below.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a peel-away sheath set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture peel-away sheath set, the wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.  Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 3-0 absorbable sutures. Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with  Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Suspected acute on chronic liver failure. Unknown etiology. Coagulopathic, precluding percutaneous liver biopsy.  Procedure:   Transjugular liver biopsy with pressure measurements  Findings:   1.	The right hepatic vein is normal in caliber and appearance. 2.	The biopsy specimen appeared adequate. 3.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. Needle entry was documented. 4.	Pressures:  a. Wedged hepatic pressure: 31 mm Hg b. Free hepatic pressure: 24 mm Hg c. Corrected Sinusoidal Pressure: 7 mm Hg  d. Right atrial: 21 mm Hg    Impression:   Successful image guided transjugular liver biopsy. Corrected sinusoidal pressure of 7 mm Hg.    Treatment Plan:  Follow up pathology results.  Technique:   The procedure, options, and risks were reviewed with patient, including bleeding, infection, and pneumothorax. A time out was performed before initiating the procedure.  The skin overlying the access site was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). Patient sedation was performed, as detailed below.  The right neck was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Using local anesthetic and ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was punctured with a 21 gauge needle with permanent reporting and recording. An image documenting vein patency and needle entry was stored and transferred to PACS. A 10 French 40 cm sheath was placed at the neck.  An MPA catheter was used to select the right hepatic vein and hepatic venography performed using nonionic contrast. Free and wedged hepatic pressures were obtained using the diagnostic catheter.  A 0.035” Rosen wire was placed in the hepatic vein and the 7 French Cook biopsy cannula was advanced over the wire. The wire was removed, and 4 passes made with the 18 gauge coaxial needle.  The specimen was placed in formalin and delivered to the laboratory.  The cannula and sheath were removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression. No immediate complication occurred, and the patient was discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]C.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  NASH cirrhosis with variceal bleeding s/p banding, hepatic encephalopathy and HCC with a 4.5 cm LR-5 lesion in segment 8.  Additional Clinical Information: Hepatocellular carcinoma with intrahepatic tumors  PROCEDURE:   1. US-guided left radial artery access. 2. Diagnostic visceral angiography 3. Transarterial chemoembolization Cone-beam CT performed for intraprocedural localization, as detailed below.  FINDINGS: ANGIOGRAPHY: Vessels catheterized and angiograms performed, as follows: Progreat 2.4, Ravi MG1 4fr x 125cm, Asahi Meister 0.016 x 180cm    Celiac artery: Tumoral blush identified. Right hepatic artery: Tumoral blush identified. Segment 8 hepatic artery: Tumoral blush identified. Segment 8 hepatic artery angiography post-embolization: Embolization performed to sub-stasis of flow.  Specific technical notes / catheter selection: None  CBCT: Yes Catheter location: Right hepatic artery, segment 8 Findings: Tumoral blush identified with supply from the target vessel.  Transcatheter embolization:  Tumor location: S8 (Treatment position(s): Series 13, image 5/10) Embolic 1: 50 mg vial 100-300 micron LC beads Embolic 2: 50 mg vial 70-150 micron LC beads   IMPRESSION:   Successful DEB-TACE treatment of the segment 8 hepatocellular carcinoma.  TREATMENT PLAN:  1. Patient will return to clinic in 6-8 weeks with abdominal MRI and labs.  2. Access site precautions and orders placed.  TECHNIQUE:  With the patient in the supine position, the left wrist was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The left wrist was evaluated with ultrasound and left radial artery patency and acceptable size criteria were documented and images were properly stored in PACS. A modified Allen test (Barbeau test Type B) was performed on the left wrist to confirm patency of the ulnopalmar arch using pulse oximetry.   1% lidocaine solution was administered for local anesthesia. Access was obtained to the left radial artery using a 21 gauge micro needle and ultrasound guidance. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. A wire was placed through the needle. A hydrophilic Glidesheath was advanced slowly over the wire. 200mcg of nitroglycerin and 2.5mg of verapamil was given through the arterial sheath with slow hemodilution. A side flush was started.   A Ravi MG1 catheter was advanced over an 0.035" wire into the abdominal aorta. The catheter was used to catheterize the visceral vessels described above. Angiograms were performed. A microcatheter system was used to catheterize distal visceral and hepatic vessels. Specific vessels catheterized and embolized are described in detail above. Tumor blush was confirmed on angiography.  [HCW]m CT (CBCT) was performed intraprocedurally for purposes of treatment planning, targeting and dose calculation. Axial and coronal images were created and 3D reconstruction was performed on a separate dedicated workstation under concurrent supervision.  All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. A TR Band was placed on the left wrist for hemostasis. The access sheath was removed and no hematoma was seen. A radial artery pulse was confirmed distal to the puncture site confirming patent hemostasis.   The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESR[HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  bowel perforation  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled central venous catheter placement    Findings:   1.	Presence of left internal jugular vein central line, confirmed in good position.  2.	After placement of the tunneled catheter over a wire from the original nontunneled catheter, as described, the tip terminates near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided conversion of a nontunneled line to a power-injectable, 5 Fr, 27 cm, tunneled non-cuffed small bore central venous catheter via the left internal jugular vein.    Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care.  The catheter is ready for immediate use.     Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed below.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the left internal jugular vein original line site was infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Sutures were removed from line. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the old central line, and a peel-away sheath set was advanced over the wire.  Through the micropuncture peel-away sheath set, the wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.  Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with an absorbable stitch and skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]C.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]    Clinical Indication:  Primary hyperaldosteronism   Procedure:    1. Bilateral adrenal vein sampling 2. Left adrenal venogram 3. Right adrenal venogram   Findings:      1.  Intermittent fluoroscopic images demonstrate catheter position in the infrarenal IVC, left adrenal vein, and right adrenal vein. 2.  Left and right adrenal venograms demonstrated conventional anatomy with drainage into the left renal vein and direct to IVC, respectively. 3.  Samples to be assayed for cortisol and aldosterone:   Infrarenal IVC: 1146   Left adrenal vein 1: 1149   Right adrenal vein 1: 1204   Right adrenal vein 2: 1216     IMPRESSION: Impression:    Successful bilateral adrenal vein sampling for cortisol and aldosterone levels.   Treatment Plan:    Sample sent to the lab for analysis. Lateralization index will be calculated when lab values are available.    Technique:    At least 30 minutes prior to the initiation the procedure, a cosyntropin infusion was initiated at 40 mcg/h through a peripheral IV.   The right groin was prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  The vascular structures were ultrasonographically evaluated.   Images were stored and transferred to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right common femoral vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  Vein patency and needle entry were documented. A 0.018" wire was placed and the needle exchanged for a 5 French dilator. The microwire was removed and a 180 cm [VENDOR]son wire was advanced into the IVC. The dilator was exchanged for a 5 French sheath and 5000 units of heparin were then administered systemically.   A Sim[VENDOR]s 2 glide catheter was advanced into the infrarenal IVC and venous sampling performed.  Next, the catheter was advanced into the left adrenal vein and venography was performed. Left adrenal vein sampling was performed.  The catheter was then exchanged for a 5 Fr Mikaelsson catheter, which was then used to select the right adrenal vein and venography performed. Right adrenal vein samples were drawn through the base catheter, and, subsequently, through the side arm of a Tuohy-Borst adapter after coaxially advancing a 0.014 Transcend microwire into the right adrenal vein .  Catheters and sheath were removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression. A sterile dressing was applied.   Cosyntropin infusion was terminated.   Patient tolerated the procedure without complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Metastatic cutaneous cancer, dysphasia  Procedure:   1.	Gastrostomy tube placement under fluoroscopic guidance.  Findings:   1.	Preprocedural scout imaging after gastric insufflation demonstrates adequate percutaneous window to the stomach.  2.	Gentle hand injection of contrast material confirms positioning of the gastrostomy tube within the gastric lumen. The gastrostomy tube is in good position.   Impression:   1.	Successful placement of 18 French MIC gastrostomy tube as above.  Treatment Plan:   The tube should be placed to gravity drainage and should not be used for 4 hours.   10 cc of water can be administered per hour. At 4 hours, if residuals are less than 30%, the patient can have tube feeds advanced starting at a half dose.  Technique:   The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the mid abdomen were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.   Using fluoroscopic and ultrasonographic guidance, an appropriate puncture site was identified.  3 T-fasteners were placed adjacent to the planned tube access site. Positioning of the T-fasteners within the gastric lumen was confirmed by return of air and direct injection of contrast material.  Next, under fluoroscopic guidance, an 18-gauge needle was directed into the gastric lumen. Needle positioning within the gastric lumen was confirmed with aspiration of air as well as gentle hand injection of contrast material.  A wire was advance through the 18-gauge needle.  The 18-gauge needle was removed over a wire.   An 8 mm x 4 cm Conquest balloon was loaded coaxially through An 18 French Halyard G-tube and advanced over a wire into the gastric lumen with the trailing edge of the balloon outside the skin entry site. The balloon was inflated along the skin tract until waisting of the balloon was no longer seen and the entire system was advanced under fluoroscopic guidance into the stomach. All wires and catheters were removed. The balloon was inflated with 10 mL of  10% contrast mixture. Gentle hand injection of contrast material documents the gastric feeding tube within the gastric lumen. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained for reference purposes. The tube was flushed with saline. It was affixed to the anterior abdominal wall with a rubber flange. The patient tolerated the procedure well at time of procedure completion without complication. Pre-sedation H&P was performed and sedation consent obtained. The patient’s name, medical record number, date of birth, allergies, procedure being performed including site and pertinent laboratory values were reviewed and confirmed with the technologist, nurse and patient. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  End-stage renal disease  Procedure:   1.	Non-tunneled large bore central venous catheter placement on the right  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the large bore central venous catheter, as described, the tip terminates in the right atrium.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a 14 French,  20 cm, non-tunneled large bore central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.  Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care. The catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).        The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic. Ultrasound evaluation of the vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS. Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS.  A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, a 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   The venotomy tract was dilated to allow introduction of the catheter over the wire. The catheter was subsequently introduced over the wire and the wire removed. The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Intractable, severe right knee pain refractory to maximal medical therapy.  Procedure:   1. Right fluoroscopic-guided genicular (superior-medial genicular, superolateral genicular, inferomedial genicular) nerve block  Findings:   1.	Patient's baseline pain in the right knee prior to the nerve block was 10 out of 10. Pain after the procedure was 8-10 out of 10. 2. Appropriate positioning of the injection needles.   Impression:   1.	 Technically successful right genicular nerve block  Treatment Plan:   Patient follow-up in 2 weeks to assess pain response.  Technique:  The patient was brought to the procedure room and placed on the exam table in a comfortable supine position. Positioning was performed to allow for appropriate needle positioning.  Needle localization was performed by [HCW]l palpation and guidance from the imaging modality documented in the procedure section. The sterile field was prepared in normal fashion. Deep and superficial local anesthesia was provided by local infiltration of 1% lidocaine.  RIGHT: 22G spinal needles were placed overlying the right knee joint, and using imaging guidance, the needle was advanced to a bony endpoint on the superolateral portion of the femoral condyle of the right knee. A second needle was advanced to a bony endpoint on the superomedial portion of the right femoral condyle. A third needle was then placed over the inferiomedial portion of the right tibial condyle until a bony endpoint was met.  Attempted aspiration yielded no fluid. Lateral x-ray views showed all the needles at 50% depth of the femur and tibia. A total of 9 cc 0.25% bupivacaine and 40 mg Kenalog was divided equally among the 3 sites in injected.    The needles and guiding catheters were then removed. Sterile dressing was applied. Patient tolerated procedure well without complication. Pain scores documented pre- and post-procedure, as above. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Renal Failure  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled large bore central venous catheter placement  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the large bore central venous catheter, as described, the tip terminates in the right atrium.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a  15.5 French, 24 cm (tip-to-cuff), tunneled large bore central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.  Treatment Plan:   1. Routine catheter care. 2. The catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissues overlying the vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle. An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the dialysis catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The venotomy tract was dilated to allow introduction of a peel-away sheath.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Multiple myeloma, and need for central venous access for stem cell collection  Procedure:  1. Ultrasound and Fluoroscopic guided placement of a tunneled, cuffed central venous catheter  Findings:  1. The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and normal. Vein patency and needle entry were stored to PACS. 2. The newly placed catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating in the right atrium.  Impression:   Uneventful image guided placement of right internal jugular vein tunneled Trifusion catheter as described.  Technique:  The right neck and chest region was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. The region was ultrasonographically evaluated.  Using local anesthetic and ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was punctured with a 21 gauge needle.  An image documenting vein patency and needle entry was saved and stored to PACS.   A 0.018” wire was passed centrally and the needle exchanged for a 5 French transitional dilator. A 0.035” wire was advanced through the dilator and negotiated into the IVC.  The skin tract was dilated and a 13 French dilator peel-away combination placed over the wire.  The soft tissues caudal and lateral to the sheath entry site were anesthetized with lidocaine with epinephrine. A dermatotomy was made and a tunneling tool brought from the dermatotomy to the venotomy. The catheter was brought through the tunnel.  During suspended respiration, the catheter was advanced through the peel-away and positioned centrally using fluoroscopy. The peel-away was removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression.  The venotomy was closed with Dermabond and Steri-Strips applied. A single Prolene suture was placed at the catheter tunnel exit site. An antimicrobial disc and sterile dressing were applied.  The catheter was aspirated, flushed, and heparinized per protocol. The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient was discharged in satisfactory condition. CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM AND ENDOVASCULAR PIPELINE EMBOLIZATION OF A RIGHT OPHTHALMIC ARTERY ANEURYSM  CLINICAL INDICATION: Opthalmic artery aneurysm  PROCEDURE:  1.	Cerebral angiogram  2.	Endovascular pipeline embolization 3.	Intra-arterial infusion of nonthrombolytic in pulse spray fashion over 10 minutes  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 2 hours.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] was the fellow. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS CATHETERIZED: Right internal carotid artery Right common femoral artery  VESSELS TREATED (in sequence): Right internal carotid artery  ANESTHESIA: General endotracheal anesthesia. Pre-, intra-, and post-anesthesia monitoring records are available in the chart.  MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine 10 cc SQ Heparin 7000 units IV Protamine 25 mg IV Ancef 2 grams IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 6 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 0.035" Bentson Guidewire, exchange length 0.035" Terumo Glidewire (180 cm) 071 benchmark guide catheter  5 French penumbra select vert catheter (125 cm) Phenom 27 microcatheter (150 cm) Asahi 018 microguidewire (200 cm) 4 mm x 10 mm pipeline embolization device Perclose ProGlide closure device Omnipaque-300 contrast (80 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, stent thrombosis/stenosis, stent migration, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, non-target embolization, puncture site hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed, written consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the [HOSPITAL]ngiography suite, intubated, and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery. Through the dilator sheath, an angiogram of the of the right common femoral artery was obtained to ensure the arteriotomy was above the level of the bifurcation and the CFA was of sufficient size to use the Perclose ProGlide closure device. An 6 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 5000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement; additional boluses of heparin were administered at one-hour intervals. The ACT was checked to ensure that it was between 250-300. Using fluoroscopic guidance,  the arteries  listed above were selectively catheterized. Digital angiograms were performed in the AP, lateral and oblique projections centered over the head and neck. We visualized a small amount of vasospasm in the petrous segment of the internal carotid artery and infused 10 mg of verapamil over 10 minutes into the right internal carotid artery.  3D rotational angiography was performed with the long selection catheter in the right internal carotid artery to better delineate the right ophthalmic artery aneurysm. The acquisition was processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced. Over the Bentson guidewire, the benchmark was successfully advanced into the distal petrous internal carotid artery. The Bentson wire was removed.   A working projection was obtained to best demonstrate the neck of the ophthalmic artery aneurysm, as well as, the distal and proximal landing zones for the stent. Superselective catheterization of the middle cerebral artery was performed with the [VENDOR]om 27 microcatheter over the Asahi 018 microguidewire. The tip of the microguidewire was situated in the middle cerebral artery. The microguidewire in the pipeline catheter was then exchanged for a 4 mm x 10 mm pipeline embolization device. The device was deployed under fluoroscopic guidance and a single shot X-ray was performed to confirm that the distal and proximal ends of the pipeline embolization device were in the communicating segment and right ICA cavernous segment, respectively. No postprocessing of the pipeline embolization device was required.  A final AP and Lateral angiogram were completed to evaluate the distal vasculature for perfusion deficits and emboli.   After completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Ancef was administered. The sheath was removed and hemostasis obtained using the Perclose ProGlide closure device. A Tegaderm were then applied over the puncture site.  COMPARISON: Cerebral angiogram [DATE].  FINDINGS:  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is a ophthalmic artery aneurysm, better described on the 3-D angiogram below. The aneurysm is stable compared to prior. There is an infundibular origin of the posterior communicating artery. There is no evidence of focal stenosis or early draining vein are identified.    RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-PIPELINE EMBOLIZATION): The Pipeline device is well apposed to the vessel walls throughout it's course without endoleak. . The distal end of the device slightly covers the origin of the posterior communicating artery and the proximal end of the device is located at the anterior genu. Stasis of contrast is noted within the aneurysm. . No perfusion deficits to suggest distal emboli are present.  3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY: A 3D rotational angiogram of the  right internal carotid artery was completed and post-processed on an independent work station. 3D angiography revealed a stable right ophthalmic artery aneurysm measuring approximately 3.5 mm in largest dimension.  RIGHT COMMON FEMORAL ARTERY: No abnormalities are detected. The arteriotomy was above the level of the bifurcation and the CFA was of sufficient size to use the Perclose ProGlide closure device.   COMPLICATIONS: none immediate.  IMPRESSION:  1. Stable right ophthalmic artery aneurysm compared to prior angiogram. 2. Successful pipeline embolization of a right ophthalmic artery aneurysm.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]C.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Upper GI bleed. Critically ill. Hemorrhagic shock.  PROCEDURE:   1. US-guided left common femoral artery access. 2. Visceral angiography 3. Subselective SMA side branch arterial embolization 4. Post-embolization angiography 5. Left common femoral artery angiogram and closure  FINDINGS: ANGIOGRAPHY: Vessels catheterized using base catheter and microcatheter/microwire combination and angiograms performed:  Superior mesenteric artery: Brisk active hemorrhage of side branch of the J1 jejunal artery. Celiac artery: No active hemorrhage.  Jejunal artery: Active extravasation identified off a side branch of J1. Post-embolization superior mesenteric and subselective jejunal artery angiography: Cessation of extravasation.  Transcatheter embolization: Embolic: nbca/glue Details (type/size/volume/number):  Glue: Lipiodol 1:3 concentration Total of 3 cc administered.  IMPRESSION:   Extremely technically challenging, however ultimately successful successful glue embolization of the bleeding jejunal artery.  TREATMENT PLAN:  1. Continued clinical and laboratory monitoring recommended. Please contact interventional radiology if there is a change in clinical status. 2. Routine post-angiography groin cares ordered.  TECHNIQUE: With the patient in the supine position, the groin was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. Following standard prepping and draping, the left common femoral artery was punctured using a needle. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. A image could unfortunately cannot be saved due to patient acuity. An 0.035" Bentson wire was advanced into the aorta. A vascular sheath was placed over the wire into the common femoral artery. A side flush was started.  A 5-Fr Cobra C2 diagnostic catheter was advanced over an 0.035" wire into the abdominal aorta. The catheter was used to first select the superior mesenteric artery. An angiogram was performed and demonstrated brisk contrast extravasation correlating with the imaging findings and preoperative CTA.  Using a Truselect 2.0 microcatheter and Transend microwire a small side branch off the jejunal J1 artery was catheterized. A subselective angiogram demonstrated that this indeed was the bleeding artery. The above glue embolization was performed, and multiple angiograms from the base catheter demonstrated cessation of active bleeding.  The Cobra catheter was then used to select celiac artery, and angiogram demonstrated no active arterial extravasation. Of note, the gastroduodenal artery did not readily opacified.   At the end of the celiac artery angiogram, the previously seen glue cast near the loop of bowel with contrast extravasation was noted, appear to have migrated. The superior mesenteric artery was then re-catheterized with the Cobra catheter, and angiogram demonstrated reconstitution of the active hemorrhage.  The above microwire/microcatheter system was then used to reattempt catheterizing the bleeding jejunal branch, however unsuccessful. Extensive different combinations of various microwires and microcatheters were also then utilized, with significant difficulty catheterizing the side branch of the jejunal artery.  The patient was significantly decompensating with anesthesiology noting blood coring out from adjacent to the nasojejunal tube. Given the concern that we would not be able to control the hemorrhage endovascularly, surgery was immediately consults for further recommendations.  During their assessment work up of the patient, were finally able to recatheterized the bleeding jejunal sidebranch, and more glue in a 3:1 concentration was used to embolize the vessel. Minimal glue reflux back into the main vessel. Postembolization angiography demonstrated preserved opacification of the distal J1B on the small side branch embolized, with overall preserved perfusion of the small bowel. No further active extravasation was noted.  A left common femoral artery angiogram was performed, demonstrating appropriate vascular access above the profunda femoris artery bifurcation. All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. Hemostasis was achieved using Angio-Seal vascular closure device. The site was dressed in usual fashion.  The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: 60-year-old male with history of migraines found to have ICA aneurysm on workup  PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 45 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] was the fellow. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right Internal Carotid Artery Left Internal Carotid Artery Left Vertebral Artery Right Vertebral Artery  ANESTHESIA: Local in the right groin with bupivacaine. Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by the nurse present during the entire procedure. The patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Sedation was administered by a specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for a total of 45  minutes (Total intra service time).  Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.  MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine SQ 10 cc  Versed 0.5 mg IV Fentanyl 25 mcg IV Heparin 3000 units IV Protamine 20 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.035" Bentson guidewire 5 French Boston Scientific sheath 5 French Cordis Vertebral catheter  Mynx Closure Device Visipaque-270 contrast material (120 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 5 French sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP, Lateral and Oblique views.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY:  Rotational angiography was also performed from the diagnostic catheter in the left internal carotid artery for better delineation of the underlying angioarchitecture. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.    3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY:  Rotational angiography was also performed from the diagnostic catheter in the right internal carotid artery for better delineation of the underlying angioarchitecture. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.    Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a Mynx Closure Device followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: Noninvasive imaging.  FINDINGS:  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. The distal internal carotid artery and its segments are normal course and caliber. The ACA and MCA and its branches are normal in course and caliber. There is normal cortical venous drainage.   LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is an aneurysmal dilatation of the origin of the left posterior communicating artery which does not meet infundibular criteria. It measures 3 x 3 mm with the takeoff of the posterior communicating artery at the toe of the boot shaped dilatation. This is better delineated on the three-dimensional reconstructions. The remainder of the ICA is unremarkable. The MCA and ACA and its branches are normal course and caliber.  LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. Reflux of contrast into the  contralateral vertebral artery was not achieved. The origin of PICA is normal on the left. The right anterior inferior cerebellar artery appears dominant. The basilar artery and its branches are normal course and caliber. There is normal cortical venous drainage.  3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: 3D Rotational angiography with volume-rendered three-dimensional reconstruction on an independent workstation, demonstrated no underlying aneurysm or vascular malformation.  3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: 3D Rotational angiography with volume-rendered three-dimensional reconstruction on an independent workstation, demonstrated a boot shaped aneurysmal dilatation of the origin of the left posterior communicating artery measuring 3 x 3 mm. This does not meet infundibular criteria and thus favor aneurysmal dilatation. The takeoff of the left posterior communicating artery is at the toe of this dilatation.  COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: There is a 3 x 3 mm boot shaped dilatation of the origin of the left posterior communicating artery that does not meet infundibular criteria and thus favors aneurysmal formation. The posterior communicating artery originates at the toe of this dilatation.     The attending radiologist, [HCW], was available for procedural supervision and interpreted the images.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]    Clinical Indication:  Renal failure  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled large bore central venous catheter placement  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the large bore central venous catheter, as described, the tip terminates in the right atrium.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a  15.5 French, 19 cm (tip-to-cuff), tunneled large bore central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.  Treatment Plan:   1. Routine catheter care. 2. The catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissues overlying the vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle. An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the dialysis catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The venotomy tract was dilated to allow introduction of a peel-away sheath.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM AND COIL EMBOLIZATION OF RIGHT MIDDLE CEREBRAL ARTERY ANEURYSM    CLINICAL INDICATION: 88-year-old with past medical history of atrial fibrillation on Eliquis, ulcerative colitis, who presented with worse headache of life and syncope and was found to have a Hunt Hess 2 subarachnoid hemorrhage centered around the right sylvian fissure. She was brought to the angiography suite for cerebral angiography and possible coil embolization.  PROCEDURE: Cerebral angiogram, coil embolization of right middle cerebral artery aneurysm.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: 2 hours.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician.  He supervised the entire procedure. [HCW] was the fellow. [HCW] was the resident. [HCW] and [HCW] actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS CATHETERIZED: Left common carotid artery Right common carotid artery Right internal carotid artery Right common femoral artery  VESSELS TREATED (in sequence): Right middle cerebral artery  ANESTHESIA:   General Anesthesia administered by anesthesiology staff.  Pre- Intra- and post- anesthesia records are available in the patient chart.   MEDICATIONS GIVEN:  0.5% Bupivacaine 10 cc SQ Heparin 5000 units IV Aspirin 300 mg PR Protamine 25 mg IV Ancef 2 gram IV  MATERIALS USED:  5 French micropuncture kit Cope mandrel wire 5 French transitional dilator 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath, long 6 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath, long 0.038" Bentson guidewire 0.035" Terumo exchange-length glidewire  5 French Simmons 3 glide catheter 5 French penumbra Simmons selection catheter 071 benchmark guide catheter (95 cm) Headway 17 Advanced microcatheter Traxcess microguidewire Omnipaque 300 contrast material (80 cc) Perclose ProGlide closure device  COILS: Filling coils: COIL OPTIMA COMPLEX 10   2 MM X 3 CM   TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, hemorrhage, renal failure, limb loss, death, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.  After informed, written consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion after intubation by the anesthesiology team. Access to the vascular system was gained by a single-wall puncture of the right common femoral artery. A 5 French long sheath was introduced into the right common femoral artery  using Seldinger technique.  Using fluoroscopic guidance, the 5 French diagnostic catheter was used to select the left common carotid artery and the right common carotid artery.  Digital angiograms were performed of these vessels, centered over the head. Ipsilateral and contralateral oblique projections were obtained of both internal carotid artery injections to evaluate for anterior communicating or MCA bifurcation aneurysms.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF LEFT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY: Rotational angiography was also performed from the Simmons catheter in the right common carotid artery for better delineation of the intracranial vasculature. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.  3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF LEFT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY: Rotational angiography was also performed from the Simmons catheter in the right common carotid artery for better delineation of the intracranial vasculature. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.  Following the diagnostic angiogram, an aspirin rectal suppository (300 mg) was administered in preparation for coiling. Additional heparin was administered to target an ACT goal of 200-300. We then advanced the benchmark guide catheter over the [HOSPITAL] [VENDOR] select catheter to select the right common carotid artery. We then advanced an 035 Terumo Glidewire up to the petrous segment of the right internal carotid artery to obtain support and then advanced the diagnostic catheter and then the benchmark into the right internal carotid artery. We then removed the diagnostic catheter and Glidewire and obtained her working projections. Superselective catheterization of the right middle cerebral  artery aneurysm performed with the microcatheter over a microguidewire.   The aneurysm was framed and filled with the aforementioned coil using roadmap and blank roadmap technique.    A final cerebral angiogram was done in the AP and lateral projection to evaluate for residual filling, and distal emboli.  Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine.  An angiogram of the right common femoral artery was obtained to confirm that the arterial puncture was above the bifurcation that the vessels of adequate size to use a Perclose ProGlide. Ancef was administered.  Hemostasis was achieved by application of a Perclose ProGlide. A Tegaderm was then applied over the puncture site.  COMPARISON: None.  FINDINGS:  LEFT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. There is evidence of mild fibromuscular dysplasia in the cervical segment of the internal carotid artery. There is significant tortuosity of the cervical segment of the internal carotid artery.  RIGHT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is a small right MCA bifurcation aneurysm better described on the 3-D angiogram below. There is no evidence of focal stenosis or early draining vein identified. The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. There is mild fibromuscular dysplasia in the cervical segment of the internal carotid artery.  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: The right MCA bifurcation aneurysm is again better visualized on the 3-D angiogram below. No evidence of other aneurysm or focal stenosis or early draining vein is identified. There is a small amount of contrast stasis within the dome of the aneurysm.  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-EMBOLIZATION): There is now small coil mass located at the site of the MCA bifurcation aneurysm. There are no perfusion deficits to suggest distal emboli in the right internal carotid artery circulation.  3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY:  3-D rotational angiography demonstrated a 2.6 x 2.4 x 2.0 x 1.7 mm (transverse, transverse, dome to neck, neck) MCA bifurcation aneurysm.   RIGHT COMMON FEMORAL ARTERY: The arteriotomy is above the bifurcation of the right common femoral artery and the diameter of the vessel is adequate for a Perclose ProGlide.  COMPLICATIONS: None.  IMPRESSION: 1. There is a 2.6 x 2.4 x 2.0 x 1.7 mm (transverse, transverse, dome to neck, neck) right MCA bifurcation aneurysm which most likely represents the etiology of the patient's subarachnoid hemorrhage. 2. Status post successful coil embolization of right MCA bifurcation aneurysm.  3. Mild fibromuscular dysplasia in significant tortuosity of the bilateral cervical internal carotid arteries.

DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM, SOLUMBRA THROMBECTOMY  CLINICAL INDICATION: 65-year-old female with left M2 occlusion.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 30 minutes. VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Left internal carotid artery Right common femoral artery  ANESTHESIA: General. Pre-, intra-, and post-anesthesia monitoring records are available in the chart.  Intubation was performed in part due to medical necessity  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 8 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath  8 French 087 Walrus balloon guide catheter (95 cm) 0.035" Bentson Guidewire 5 French Merit Performa Vertebral selection catheter (120 cm) 0.035" Terumo Glidewire (180 cm) Zoom 55 Aspiration Catheter [HCW] microcatheter (160 cm) Asahi 018 microguidewire (200 cm) 8 French Angio-Seal closure device Omnipaque-300 contrast (40 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient's family (medical proxy). Specifically, the risks of intracranial or systemic hemorrhage, cerebral infarction, distal emboli, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, device malfunction, groin hematoma, arterial dissection/laceration, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite, intubated, and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 8 French sheath was introduced into the right common femoral artery . The 8 French 087 Walrus balloon guide-catheter and 5 French diagnostic long selection catheter were introduced into the left common carotid artery as a system.   A roadmap angiogram was then completed of the common carotid artery to visualize the carotid bifurcation. The diagnostic catheter was then used to select the internal carotid artery over the 180 cm long 0.038" Bentson wire. The balloon guide catheter was then advanced into the proximal cervical internal carotid artery over the wire and selection catheter. The wire and diagnostic catheter were then removed and the balloon guide was connected to a continual heparinized saline flush. Digital angiograms were performed centered over the head.   The initial TICI score was 2c with distal left M4 branch occlusion. Given that the initial M2 segment occlusion seen on noninvasive imaging was no longer present, no intervention was pursued.  An angiogram of the right common femoral artery was obtained; the artery was deemed appropriate for use of the 8 French Angio-Seal closure device. The sheath was removed and hemostasis obtained by deployment of the 8 French Angio-Seal closure device. A Tegaderm was then applied over the puncture site.  COMPARISON: Noninvasive imaging.  FINDINGS:  LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: A distal M4 segment occlusion is identified consistent with TICI 2c. The previously visualized M2 segment occlusion seen on noninvasive imaging is no longer present.   RIGHT FEMORAL ARTERY: Atherosclerotic changes are noted along the course of the vessel without significant flow limiting effect. This vessel is suitable for use of the 8 French Angio-Seal closure device.  COMPLICATIONS: none immediate.  IMPRESSION:  1.	Distal left M4 occlusion with initial occlusion consistent with TICI 2c. No intervention was pursued given the distal location of the clot.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESR[HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Leukemia  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen port (standard profile)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 2-0 absorbable sutures. A running 4-0 absorbable subcuticular stitch and  Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with a single subcuticular stitch and Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: This is a 21 years Female who presents for diagnostic cerebral angiography for evaluation of a known right occipital arteriovenous malformation.  PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 30 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] and [HCW] were the fellows. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right Internal Carotid Artery Right External Carotid Artery Left Common Carotid Artery Left Vertebral Artery   ANESTHESIA: Local in the right groin with bupivacaine. Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by the nurse present during the entire procedure. The patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Sedation was administered by a specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for the duration of the procedure as outlined above (Total intra service time, 30min ). Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.   MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine SQ 10 cc  Versed 1 mg IV Fentanyl 50 mcg IV Heparin 3000 units IV Protamine 20 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.038" Bentson guidewire 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 5 French Cordis Vertebral catheter  Cardiva Vascade Visipaque-270 contrast material (80 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 5 French sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP, Lateral and Oblique views.   Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a Vascade followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: Prior angiogram.  FINDINGS:  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. There is no residual filling of the previously identified right occipital arteriovenous malformation. There is a relative paucity of vessels in the right occipital region, consistent with patient's known hemorrhage. The ICA and its segments are normal in course and caliber. The ACA and MCA and its branches are normal course and caliber. There is normal cortical venous drainage.  RIGHT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   LEFT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. The distal left internal carotid artery and its segments are normal course and caliber. The ACA and MCA and its branches are normal course and caliber. There is normal cortical venous drainage. The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is no residual filling of the previously identified right occipital arteriovenous malformation. There are mild irregularities with slow filling of vessels in the vicinity of the prior arteriovenous malformation, likely reactive changes to the radiation and/or hemorrhage. No early draining veins are identified. Reflux of contrast into the contralateral vertebral artery was not achieved. The origin of PICA is normal unilaterally (we will defer to CTA for evaluation of the contralateral PICA). The basilar artery and its branches are normal course and caliber.  COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: No residual filling of the previously visualized right occipital arteriovenous malformation. There are irregularities of the vessels in the right occipital region consistent with post radiation or reactive changes from known right occipital intracerebral hemorrhage. CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM AND COIL EMBOLIZATION OF MIDLINE CEREBELLAR ARTERIOVENOUS MALFORMATION FEEDING ARTERY ANEURYSM    CLINICAL INDICATION: 53-year-old male with sudden onset worst headache of life with CT concerning for diffuse subarachnoid hemorrhage brought to the angiography suite for cerebral angiography.  PROCEDURE: Cerebral angiogram, coil embolization of midline cerebellar arteriovenous malformation feeding artery aneurysm. XPER CT  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: 2 hours.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician.  He supervised the entire procedure. [HCW] was the fellow. They both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS CATHETERIZED: Right internal carotid artery Right external carotid artery Left internal carotid artery Left vertebral artery Right superior cerebellar artery   VESSELS TREATED (in sequence): Right superior cerebellar artery  ANESTHESIA:   General Anesthesia administered by anesthesiology staff.  Pre- Intra- and post- anesthesia records are available in the patient chart.   MEDICATIONS GIVEN:  0.5% Bupivacaine 10 cc SQ Heparin 5000 units IV Aspirin 300 mg PR Protamine 20 mg IV Ancef 2 gram IV  MATERIALS USED:  5 French micropuncture kit Cope mandrel wire 5 French transitional dilator 6 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 0.038" Bentson guidewire 0.035" Terumo exchange-length glidewire  5 French Simmons 3 Glide catheter 071 [HOSPITAL] Benchmark guide catheter Headway 17 Advanced microcatheter Transform SC 3mm x 5mm balloon Apollo microcatheter Cerenovus trufill liquid embolic material Transcend-EX microguidewire x3 Visipaque 270 contrast material (150 cc) mynx closure device  COILS: Framing coil: Optimax complex 5 mm x 17 cm Filling coils: Optimax complex 4 mm x 13 cm    TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, hemorrhage, renal failure, limb loss, death, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.  After informed, written consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion after intubation by the anesthesiology team. Access to the vascular system was gained by a single-wall puncture of the right common femoral artery. A 6 French short sheath was introduced into the right common femoral artery  using Seldinger technique.  Using fluoroscopic guidance, the 5 French diagnostic catheter was used to select the bilateral internal carotid arteries and the left vertebral artery.  Digital angiograms were performed of these vessels, centered over the head. Ipsilateral and contralateral oblique projections were obtained of both internal carotid artery injections to evaluate for anterior communicating or MCA bifurcation aneurysms.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY: Rotational angiography was also performed from the diagnostic catheter in the left vertebral artery for better delineation of the intracranial vasculature. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.  Following the diagnostic angiogram, an aspirin rectal suppository (300 mg) was administered in preparation for coiling. The 5 French diagnostic catheter was then exchanged over the 0.035" [VENDOR] exchange-length glidewire for the 071 [VENDOR]umbra Benchmark guide catheter, which was situated at the V2 3 junction of the left vertebral artery. Superselective catheterization of the right superior cerebellar artery branch distal to the prenidal aneurysm was selected. Trufill n-BCA liquid embolic was prepared on the back table and following infusion of dextrose solution, was injected under blank roadmap technique. The microcatheter was removed without difficulty. A control angiogram was performed to assess for distal emboli. A headway 17 microcatheter was subsequently advanced into the right superior cerebellar artery prenidal aneurysm performed with the microcatheter over a microguidewire.   The aneurysm was framed and filled with the aforementioned coils using roadmap and blank roadmap technique.   A final cerebral angiogram was done in the AP and lateral projection to evaluate for residual filling, and distal emboli.  Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine.  An angiogram of the right common femoral artery was obtained to confirm that the arterial puncture was above the bifurcation that the vessels of adequate size to use a mynx closure device. Ancef was administered.  Hemostasis was achieved by application of a mynx closure device. A Tegaderm was then applied over the puncture site.  COMPARISON: None.  FINDINGS:  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. The distal ICA and its segments are normal course and caliber. The MCA and its branches are normal in course and caliber. The A1 segment of the right ACA is hypoplastic with early washout of the distal ACA territory suggesting dominant filling from the contralateral hemisphere.   RIGHT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is brief filling of the midline superior cerebellar arteriovenous malformation via collaterals from the left posterior cerebral artery. This will be described in further detail on the left vertebral injection. The distal ICA and its segments are normal course and caliber. The posterior communicating artery is dominant supplies the posterior cerebral territory. The MCA and its branches are normal course and caliber. The ACA supplies the bilateral ACA territories. This is concordant with the contralateral internal injection. There are no aneurysms identified on the anterior right circulation.   LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is a midline superior cerebellar arteriovenous malformation supplied primarily by branches of the right superior cerebellar artery and small branches off the right posterior cerebral artery. The nidus measures 2 x 2 cm and drainage primarily into the right basal vein of Rosenthal and vein of Galen. There is a large highly irregularly-shaped right superior cerebellar artery prenidal aneurysm measuring 7 x 8 x 4 mm with multiple small daughter lobules. This is better delineated in the three-dimensional reconstructions. Reflux of contrast into the  right vertebral artery was not achieved. The origin of PICA is normal unilaterally (we will defer to CTA for evaluation of the contralateral PICA). Given the flow demand from the arteriovenous malformation, the proximal branches of the basilar artery remains largely unopacified although do not appear to have any concerning features.   RIGHT SUPERIOR CEREBELLAR ARTERY, SUPERSELECTIVE RUN: Superselective injection of the right superior cerebellar artery distal to be prenidal aneurysm demonstrates partial opacification of the arteriovenous malformation. No normal brain parenchyma is visualized.  LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST GLUE EMBOLIZATION): Following glue embolization of the branch of the right superior cerebellar artery supplying the arteriovenous malformation there remains filling of the superior cerebellar artery arteriovenous malformation from branches of the posterior cerebral arteries. However, there is significant contrast stagnation in the prenidal aneurysm in the right superior cerebellar artery. The branch of the right superior cerebellar artery originating proximal to the aneurysm remains patent and supplies normal brain parenchyma.  LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-Coil EMBOLIZATION): Following coil embolization of the prenidal aneurysm, there is minimal residual filling at the base of the aneurysm. The branch of the right superior cerebellar artery originating proximal to the aneurysm remains patent and supplies normal brain parenchyma. There are no perfusion deficits to suggest distal emboli in the posterior circulation. There remains filling of the arteriovenous malformation from distal branches of the PCA.  3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE left vertebral artery:  3-D rotational angiography demonstrated a midline superior cerebellar AVM supplied primarily by branches of the right superior cerebellar artery and PCA collaterals. The nidus measures 2 x 2 cm. There is a large highly irregularly-shaped right superior cerebellar artery prenidal aneurysm measuring 7 x 8 x 4 mm with multiple small daughter lobules. There is a branch arising from the base of the aneurysm which appears to supply normal cerebellar tissue and a branch coming off the aneurysm itself which appears to travel directly to the AVM nidus.  XPER CT: post procedural XPER CT shows diffuse SAH, increased in conspicuity from preprocedural CT imaging. There is no ICH identified. There is however new IVH noted in the right lateral ventricle. Follow-up imaging is recommended.  COMPLICATIONS: Intraprocedural rupture of the prenidal aneurysm.  IMPRESSION: 1. Patient with a midline superior cerebellar arteriovenous malformation supplied primarily by branches of the right superior cerebellar artery and PCA collaterals. The AVM nidus measures 2 x 2 cm and drains predominantly into the right basal vein of Rosenthal and vein of Galen. There is a large highly irregularly-shaped right superior cerebellar artery prenidal aneurysm measuring 7 x 8 x 4 mm with multiple small bilateral lobules. This is believed to be the cause of the patient's underlying SAH rather than the AVM itself. The decision was made to proceed with embolization of the prenidal aneurysm with sacrifice of the branch of the superior cerebellar artery which appeared to lead directly to the arteriovenous malformation and is without significant filling of the normal brain parenchyma. This was done successfully with a glue embolization of the SCA branch distal to the aneurysm followed by coil embolization of the aneurysm itself. Following embolization, there was minimal residual filling at the base of the aneurysm with patency of the right SCA branch originating at the base of the aneurysm which supplied normal brain parenchyma. The AVM itself remains patent via filling from multiple branches off the PCA.  2. An XPER CT was performed at the conclusion of the procedure given increased in bloody drainage from the external ventricular drain which was placed prior to angiography. Increased conspicuity of the diffuse SAH was noted as well as new right lateral intraventricular hemorrhage. Follow-up imaging is recommended.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Persistent bacteremia  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled central venous catheter placement  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the tunneled catheter, as described, the tip terminates near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a power-injectable, 5 Fr, 23 cm, tunneled non-cuffed central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.  Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care.  The catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion.
