CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM AND BALLOON TEST OCCLUSION OF THE INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY  CLINICAL INDICATION: 78-year-old gentleman with left skull base and retropharyngeal tumor, for cerebral angiogram and balloon test occlusion of the left internal carotid artery prior to surgery.  PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram. Balloon test occlusion of left internal carotid artery.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 60.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician.  He supervised the entire procedure. [HCW] and [HCW] were the fellows. [HCW], PhD was the resident. All actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right internal carotid artery Right external carotid artery Left vertebral artery Left subclavian artery Left internal carotid artery Left external carotid artery  ANESTHESIA: Local in the right groin with bupivacaine.   MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine SQ 10 cc Heparin 7000 units IV Protamine 20 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 6 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 0.038" Bentson guidewire 0.035" Terumo exchange-length glidewire  5 French Merit Performa Vertebral catheter 058 Navien guide catheter Asahi 014 microguidewire 7 mm x 7 mm Transform balloon microcatheter Omnipaque 300 contrast material (100 cc) Cardiva Vascade    TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, spinal cord infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography room and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 6 French sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 5000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. The ACT was checked to ensure that it was between 250-300. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was completed of the vessels listed above. Digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck.   The 5 French diagnostic catheter was exchanged for a 058 Navien guide catheter, the tip of which was situated in the distal cervical internal carotid artery. The Transform balloon catheter and mid petrous segment microguidewire were then advanced coaxially into the vertical petrous segment.  A new sterile drape was then placed over the patient's neck and chest, and the patient's hands were removed from under the drape and elevated over the bed in the anatomic position with the forearms and fingers extended. The timer was started and the balloon inflated. For the next 30 minutes, nearly continuous neurological testing was performed to assess comprehension, repetition, naming, calculation, finger recognition, gaze deviation, visual fields, right facial droop, right hemibody weakness, or right hemifacial/hemibody sensory deficit. The extent of balloon inflation and balloon position were checked periodically during this time. The balloon remained occlusive within the petrous segment of the left internal carotid artery. Neurological deficits were not observed.   After balloon deflation and removal, a followup cerebral angiogram was performed from the guide catheter in the left internal carotid artery. Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was achieved with application of a Cardiva Vascade, followed by manual compression.   COMPARISON: Axial imaging.  FINDINGS:  RIGHT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CERVICAL: The bifurcation is smooth, without irregularity, calcification, or stenosis with respect to the distal ICA. The ECA branches opacify normally.  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified.       LEFT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CERVICAL: The bifurcation is smooth, without irregularity, calcification, or stenosis with respect to the distal ICA. The ECA branches opacify normally.  LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified.       LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal ascending pharyngeal artery opacifies primarily via the vertebral artery injection.   LEFT SUBCLAVIAN ARTERY, CERVICAL: None in the descending branches of the subclavian artery including the thyrocervical trunk, the deep cervical arteries, etc. supply the tumor. The muscle branches of the carotid artery demonstrates positive tumor.  LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (DURING BTO):  The balloon is appropriately inflated in the posterior segment of the internal carotid artery and remains unchanged in position for the duration of the inflation.  LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-BTO): Normal diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  COMPLICATIONS: None.  IMPRESSION:  1. No significant tumor blush in the left skull base and retropharyngeal tumor. The outline of the tumor is vaguely visible due to stagnation and some veins in this region; however, with no arterial phase or parenchymal blush is difficult to discern whether this is in fact the tumor.   2.Successful balloon test occlusion of the left without evidence of neurological deficits. Following this procedure, the patient was taken to nuclear medicine for a brain SPECT scan to evaluate for hypoperfusion in the left anterior circulation.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  head and neck cancer, dysphagia  Procedure:   1.	Gastrostomy tube placement under fluoroscopic guidance.  Findings:   1.	Preprocedural scout imaging after gastric insufflation demonstrates adequate percutaneous window to the stomach.  2.	Gentle hand injection of contrast material confirms positioning of the gastrostomy tube within the gastric lumen. The gastrostomy tube is in good position.   Impression:   1.	Successful placement of 18 French MIC gastrostomy tube as above.  Treatment Plan:   The tube should be placed to gravity drainage and should not be used for 24 hours.   25 cc of water can be administered per hour. At 4 hours, if residuals are less than 30%, the patient can have tube feeds advanced starting at a half dose.  Technique:   The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the mid abdomen were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.   Using fluoroscopic and ultrasonographic guidance, an appropriate puncture site was identified.  3 T-fasteners were placed adjacent to the planned tube access site. Positioning of the T-fasteners within the gastric lumen was confirmed by return of air and direct injection of contrast material.  Next, under fluoroscopic guidance, an 18-gauge needle was directed into the gastric lumen. Needle positioning within the gastric lumen was confirmed with aspiration of air as well as gentle hand injection of contrast material.  A wire was advance through the 18-gauge needle.  The 18-gauge needle was removed over a wire.   An 8 mm x 4 cm Conquest balloon was loaded coaxially through An 18 French Halyard G-tube and advanced over a wire into the gastric lumen with the trailing edge of the balloon outside the skin entry site. The balloon was inflated along the skin tract until waisting of the balloon was no longer seen and the entire system was advanced under fluoroscopic guidance into the stomach. All wires and catheters were removed. The balloon was inflated with 10 mL of  10% contrast mixture. Gentle hand injection of contrast material documents the gastric feeding tube within the gastric lumen. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained for reference purposes. The tube was flushed with saline. It was affixed to the anterior abdominal wall with a rubber flange. The patient tolerated the procedure well at time of procedure completion without complication. Patient Name:  WEERASEKARA, CHAMODYA       DOB: 4/6/2001    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  WOC-COLBURN, LAILA Location:  Emory John's Creek Hospital  ESRC.IR.1  Date of exam:  2/5/2024   Clinical Indication:  Patient with pots and malnutrition requiring double lumen port for fluids and TPN. Also with right IJ tunneled CVC requiring removal Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F double-lumen Bard port (double lumen)  Findings:   1.	The left internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled left internal jugular 8 French double lumen Bard power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Please refer to anesthesia for notes.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the left internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic. Under ultrasound guidance, the left internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the left chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the left chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 3-0 absorbable sutures. A running 4-0 absorbable subcuticular stitch and  Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with     Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. Attention was then switched to right IJ tunneled CVC removal. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESR[HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Renal failure      Procedure:   1.	Tunneled large bore central venous catheter placement  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the large bore central venous catheter, as described, the tip terminates in the right atrium.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a  15.5 French, 19 cm (tip-to-cuff), tunneled large bore central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.  Treatment Plan:   1. Routine catheter care. 2. The catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissues overlying the vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle. An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the dialysis catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The venotomy tract was dilated to allow introduction of a peel-away sheath.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen Medcomp power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Multifocal HCC. Palliative Y 90 in the setting of relatively preserved liver function and excellent functional status despite advanced disease. Plan for left-sided lobar treatment today.  PROCEDURE:   1. US-guided left radial artery access 2. Diagnostic visceral angiography 3. Bland embolization of the lesion with duodenal invasion. 4. Selective left lobar internal radioembolization with Yttrium-90 5. Cone-beam CT performed for intraprocedural localization, as detailed below.  FINDINGS: ANGIOGRAPHY: Vessels catheterized and angiograms performed, as follows:  Celiac artery: Extensive multifocal Tumoral blush identified. Left hepatic artery: Tumoral blush identified. Right hepatic artery: Not performed today.   Specific technical notes / catheter selection:  5 French slender sheath [HCW]al catheter Trinav microcatheter/[HCW] Chikai microwire for bland embolization Truselect microcatheter/fathom microwire for Y90 delivery  CBCT: Yes Catheter location:  -Left hepatic artery -Parasitic branch off the left hepatic artery Findings: Tumoral blush identified with supply from the target vessel.  Transcatheter embolization using Yttrium-90 microspheres performed from: Left hepatic artery   IMPRESSION:   1. Successful bland embolization of the metastatic lesion with duodenal invasion using 100 um Embozene.  2. Successful Yttrium-90 Sirspheres left lobar radiotherapy for multifocal HCC.    TREATMENT PLAN:  1. Patient will return to clinic in 6-8 weeks with abdominal MRI and labs.  2. Access site precautions and orders placed.  TECHNIQUE:  With the patient in the supine position, the left wrist was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The left wrist was evaluated with ultrasound and left radial artery patency and acceptable size criteria were documented and images were properly stored in PACS. A modified Allen test (Barbeau test Type B) was performed on the left wrist to confirm patency of the ulnopalmar arch using pulse oximetry.   1% lidocaine solution was administered for local anesthesia. Access was obtained to the left radial artery using a 21 gauge micro needle and ultrasound guidance. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. A wire was placed through the needle. A hydrophilic Glidesheath was advanced slowly over the wire. 3000 units of heparin, 200 mcg of nitroglycerin and 2.5 mg of verapamil was given through the arterial sheath with slow hemodilution. A side flush was started.   A 5-Fr [VENDOR] catheter was advanced over an 0.035" wire into the abdominal aorta. The catheter was used to catheterize the visceral celiac artery. Angiograms and cone beam CT were performed to delineate the anatomy. Using the above microwire/microcatheter system, the artery of the lesion invading the duodenum was catheterized, and additional cone beam CTs were performed. Bland embolization was performed as above.  The Trinav microcatheter was then exchanged for the truselect, which was used to catheterize the base of the left hepatic artery. Additional angiograms and cone beam CTs were performed demonstrating appropriate position for radial embolization.   Cone Beam CT (CBCT) was performed intraprocedurally for purposes of treatment planning, targeting and dose calculation. Axial and coronal images were created and 3D reconstruction was performed on a separate dedicated workstation under concurrent supervision.  Once the catheter was in adequate position, a pre-determined dose of 90-Yttrium radioactive particles was infused into the target hepatic artery. The microcatheter was flushed and the microcatheter was disposed of appropriately.   All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. [HCW] Band was placed on the left wrist for hemostasis. The access sheath was removed and no hematoma was seen. A radial artery pulse was confirmed distal to the puncture site confirming patent hemostasis.   The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. Medications: Please see separate anesthesia documentation.  Additional Medications: Decadron 10 mg IV, Zofran 4 mg IV. Pantoprazole 40 mg. Radial cocktail: Heparin 3,000U IA, Nitroglycerin 200 mcg IA, Verapamil 2.5 mg IA  Antibiotics: None  Blood loss:  Less than 10 ml  Checklist:	Informed consent was obtained discussing the risks, benefits and alternatives to the planned procedure.  Pre-sedation H&P was performed and sedation consent obtained. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  [ID]C[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication: Acute lower GI bleed. Hypovolemic shock  PROCEDURE:   1. US-guided right common femoral artery access. 2. Visceral angiography 3. Angiography of the ileocolic branches, left colic and branches 5. Right common femoral artery angiogram and closure  FINDINGS: ANGIOGRAPHY:  Celiac artery: No active hemorrhage. Superior mesenteric artery: No active hemorrhage. Variant anatomy with an accessory hepatic from the SMA Right colic: No extravasation Ileocolic trunk: No extravasation Ileal branches: No extravasation. No definite early draining vein to suggest AVM  Transcatheter embolization: No embolization was done since no extravasation was seen.    IMPRESSION:   Angiography of the celiac artery, superior mesenteric artery and branches of the superior mesenteric artery to include the right colic, ileocolic and ileal branches. No extravasation was seen. No early draining veins identified to suggest AVM  TREATMENT PLAN:  1. Continued clinical and laboratory monitoring recommended. Please contact interventional radiology if there is a change in clinical status. 2. Routine post-angiography groin cares ordered.  TECHNIQUE: With the patient in the supine position, the groin was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. Following standard prepping and draping, the right common femoral artery was punctured using a needle. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. An 0.035" wire was advanced into the aorta. A vascular sheath was placed over the wire into the common femoral artery. A side flush was started.  A 5-Fr diagnostic catheter was advanced over an 0.035" wire into the abdominal aorta. The catheter was used to catheterize the vessels described above. Angiograms were performed. A microcatheter system was used to catheterize distal vessels, as described above. Specific vessels catheterized and embolized are described in detail above.  Once the catheter was in adequate position, embolization was performed using the parameters detailed. Post-embolization angiography was performed, as detailed.  A right common femoral artery angiogram was performed, demonstrating appropriate vascular access above the profunda femoris artery bifurcation. All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. Hemostasis was achieved using Angio-Seal vascular closure device. The site was dressed in usual fashion.  The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Renal failure  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled large bore central venous catheter placement  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the large bore central venous catheter, as described, the tip terminates in the right atrium.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a  15.5 French, 19 cm (tip-to-cuff), tunneled large bore central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.  Treatment Plan:   1. Routine catheter care. 2. The catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissues overlying the vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle. An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the dialysis catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The venotomy tract was dilated to allow introduction of a peel-away sheath.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Poor IV access requiring daily IV hydration  Procedure:   1.	Double lumen PICC placement using ultrasound and fluoroscopy in the left upper extremity  Findings:   1.  Vein patency was documented by ultrasound and stored to PACS. 2.  The catheter tip terminates near the cavoatrial junction.     Impression:   1.	Uneventful image guided placement of 5 French, 44 cm double-lumen PICC in the left  upper extremity as described. The lumens flush and aspirate appropriately.     Treatment Plan:   Catheter tip position is confirmed as above. It is OK to use this line.    Technique:   The site was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).   Ultrasound evaluation of the left basilic vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS. Local anesthetic was used over the access site. Under ultrasound guidance, the left basilic vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS.    A 0.018" wire was passed centrally and the needle exchanged for a dilator peel-away combination. The wire was used to determine catheter length, and a 5 French double-lumen PICC line cut to appropriate length. The tailored catheter was advanced through the peel-away and positioned centrally using fluoroscopy.   The peel-away was removed, and hemostasis achieved with manual compression. The catheter was aspirated, flushed, and locked per protocol. It was secured in place with Ethilon.  An antimicrobial disc and sterile dressing were applied.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Cellulitis, sepsis, renal transplant  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled central venous catheter placement  5 French single-lumen  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the tunneled catheter, as described, the tip terminates near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a power-injectable, 5 Fr, 22 cm, tunneled non-cuffed central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.  There is a marked amount of scar tissue in the right neck requiring serial dilation of the tract up to 6 French  Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care.  The catheter is ready for immediate use.        Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed below.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a peel-away sheath set was advanced over the wire.       Through the micropuncture peel-away sheath set, the wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.  Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  Placement of the peel-away sheath was challenging due to scar tissue in the right neck. This required serial dilation initially with a stiff micropuncture and then with a 6 French dilator before the 5 French peel-away could be placed. The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath. The port was tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with 2-0 Prolene suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Status post orthotopic liver transplant with worsening ascites. Initial concern for anastomotic stricture, however now requesting tissue to assess for underlying liver dysfunction.  Procedure:   1. Therapeutic paracentesis.  2. Transjugular liver biopsy without pressure measurements  Findings:   1.	The right hepatic vein is normal in caliber and appearance. 2.	The biopsy specimen appeared adequate. 3.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. Needle entry was documented.  Impression:   Successful therapeutic paracentesis, draining 3.5 L of amber-colored fluid. Successful image guided transjugular liver biopsy.   Treatment Plan:  Follow up pathology results.  Technique:   The procedure, options, and risks were reviewed with patient, including bleeding, infection, and pneumothorax. A time out was performed before initiating the procedure.  The skin overlying the right neck and right abdomen was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). Patient sedation was performed, as detailed below.  Paracentesis: Following administration of local anesthetic, the peritoneal cavity was accessed using a 5 French [VENDOR]esis needle. The catheter was attached to a drainage device and fluid was removed.   Transjugular liver biopsy: The right neck was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Using local anesthetic and ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was punctured with a 21 gauge needle with permanent reporting and recording. An image documenting vein patency and needle entry was stored and transferred to PACS. An 10 Fr French sheath was placed at the neck.  An MPA catheter was used to select the right hepatic vein and hepatic venography performed using nonionic contrast.  A 0.035” Glidewire advantage wire was placed in the right hepatic vein and the 7 French [VENDOR] biopsy cannula was advanced over the wire. The wire was removed, and 5 passes made with the 18 gauge coaxial needle (3 of which produced adequate samples).  The specimen was placed in formalin and delivered to the laboratory.  The cannula and sheath were removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression. No immediate complication occurred, and the patient was discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]C.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  ALS, dysphagia, failure to thrive requiring gastrostomy tube placement for nutrition.  Procedure:   1.	Gastrostomy tube placement under fluoroscopic guidance.  Findings:   1.	The gastrostomy tube is in good position.  2.	Gentle hand injection of contrast material confirms positioning of the gastrostomy tube within the gastric lumen.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of 18 French MIC gastrostomy tube as above.  Treatment Plan:   The tube should be placed to gravity drainage and should not be used for 24 hours. 25 cc of water can be administered per hour. At 4 hours, if residuals are less than 30%, the patient can have tube feeds advanced starting at a half dose.   Technique:   Informed consent for the procedure was obtained, and time-out was performed prior to the procedure.  The skin overlying the access site was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the mid abdomen were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.   Using fluoroscopic and ultrasonographic guidance, an appropriate puncture site was identified.  3 T-fasteners were placed adjacent to the planned tube access site. Positioning of the T-fasteners within the gastric lumen was confirmed by return of air and direct injection of contrast material.  Next, under fluoroscopic guidance, an 18-gauge needle was directed into the gastric lumen. Needle positioning within the gastric lumen was confirmed with aspiration of air as well as gentle hand injection of contrast material.  A wire was advance through the 18-gauge needle.  The 18-gauge needle was removed over a wire. Serial dilation was accomplished over the stiff wire. An 18 French Halyard G-tube was advanced over a wire in an antegrade fashion and advanced through the anterior abdominal wall. All wires and catheters were removed. The bulb was inflated with 10 mL of a 10% contrast mixture. Gentle hand injection of contrast material documents the gastric feeding tube within the gastric lumen. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained for reference purposes. The tube was flushed with saline. It was affixed to the anterior abdominal wall with a rubber flange. The patient tolerated the procedure well at time of procedure completion without complication. Lesion suspicious for HCC in the caudate, segment 4, segment 7/8.  PROCEDURE:   1. US-guided left radial artery access 2. Diagnostic visceral angiography 3. Selective internal radioembolization with Yttrium-90 4. Cone-beam CT performed for intraprocedural localization, as detailed below. Specific technical notes / catheter selection:  [HCW]ch slender sheath Ravi base catheter Left hepatic artery: Truselect microcatheter Segment 4/middle hepatic artery: Trinav microcatheter Right hepatic artery, segment 8 hepatic artery: Truselect microcatheter Fathom microwire  [ID]- Vascular embolization of occlusion procedure with use of a pressure-generating catheter (e.g., one-way valve, intermittently occluding), inclusive of all radiological supervision and interpretation, intraprocedural, roadmapping, and imaging guidance necessary to complete the intervention; for tumors, organ, ischemia, or infarction  CBCT: Yes Catheter location:  Left hepatic artery, caudate branch Middle hepatic artery/segment 4 Right hepatic artery, segment 8 Findings: Tumoral blush identified with supply from the target vessel.  Transcatheter embolization using Yttrium-90 microspheres performed from:  3 table set up: 1. Left hepatic artery, caudate branch 2. Middle hepatic artery/segment 4 3. Right hepatic artery, segment 8  IMPRESSION:   Successful Yttrium-90 Sirspheres selective internal radiotherapy of HCC lesions involving the caudate, segment 4, and segment 7/8.   TREATMENT PLAN:  1. Patient will return to clinic in 6-8 weeks with abdominal MRI and labs.  2. Access site precautions and orders placed.  TECHNIQUE:  With the patient in the supine position, the left wrist was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The left wrist was evaluated with ultrasound and left radial artery patency and acceptable size criteria were documented and images were properly stored in PACS. A modified Allen test (Barbeau test Type B) was performed on the left wrist to confirm patency of the ulnopalmar arch using pulse oximetry.   1% lidocaine solution was administered for local anesthesia. Access was obtained to the left radial artery using a 21 gauge micro needle and ultrasound guidance. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. A wire was placed through the needle. A hydrophilic Glidesheath was advanced slowly over the wire. 3000 units of heparin, 200 mcg of nitroglycerin and 2.5 mg of verapamil was given through the arterial sheath with slow hemodilution. A side flush was started.   A 5-Fr Ravi catheter was advanced over an 0.035" Bentson wire into the abdominal aorta. The catheter was used to catheterize the celiac artery. Angiograms were performed.  The above microcatheter systems were used to sequentially catheterize the caudate artery off the left hepatic lobe, segment 4/middle hepatic artery, and segment right hepatic artery. Angiograms and cone beam CTs were performed to document appropriate catheter position. And predetermined dose is of 90-Yttrium radioactive particles were infused into the target hepatic arteries (in the order listed above).    Cone Beam CT (CBCT) was performed intraprocedurally for purposes of treatment planning, targeting and dose calculation. Axial and coronal images were created and 3D reconstruction was performed on a separate dedicated workstation under concurrent supervision.  All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. A TR Band was placed on the left wrist for hemostasis. The access sheath was removed and no hematoma was seen. A radial artery pulse was confirmed distal to the puncture site confirming patent hemostasis.   The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Symptomatic uterine fibroids, focal adenomyomatosis  PROCEDURE:   1.	Ultrasound-guided right common femoral artery access  2.	Pelvic angiography 3.	Uterine artery embolization 4.	Post-embolization angiography 5.	Right femoral angiogram and vascular closure device (Perclose)  Findings:   Left internal iliac artery: Mildly enlarged left uterine artery with minimal myomatous uterine vasculature identified. Left uterine artery: Fibroid blush identified. No cervical branches.  Right internal iliac artery: Moderate enlarged right uterine artery with more definitive fibroid vasculature identified on the right. There is also myomatous uterus vasculature identified. Right uterine artery: Fibroid blush identified. No cervical branches.   Embolization:  Right uterine: 1. 1x vials 500 u Embozene 2. 1 vials 700 u Embozene  Left uterine: 1. 0.5 vials 500 u Embozene 2. 0.25 vials 700 u Embozene  Intra-arterial medication administration: lidocaine 10ml total given bilaterally.  Hypogastric Nerve Block: NONE   Post-Embolization Angiograms: Right uterine artery: Sluggish flow without opacification of the uterine fibroids. Left uterine artery: Sluggish flow without opacification of the uterine fibroids.  Technical notes: The patient elected for femoral artery uterine embolization. The patient is a chiropractor and preferred to have this procedure by femoral access than radial.  Impression:  1. Mildly enlarged uterine branches right greater than left with vascularity consistent with  with a leiomyomatous uterus on the right. Enlarged left uterine artery but only minimally. The left uterine artery likely feeds the focal adenomyoma in the fundus. 2. Status post successful bilateral uterine artery embolization.  Treatment Plan:  1. Routine access site post-procedural cares ordered. 2. The patient will be monitored for 4-6 hours to assess for the need for an observation admission for pain control. 3. Patient will be discharged with a stool softener/laxative, analgesic, anti-emetic, and a narcotic for pain control, and will follow-up in clinic with IR 1 month, 3 months, 6 months and then one year.  Technique:  With the patient in the supine position, the right groin was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The patient was placed on the table in a supine position. Following standard prepping and draping, the right common femoral artery was punctured using a needle. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. An 0.035" wire was advanced into the aorta. A vascular sheath was placed over the wire into the common femoral artery. A side flush was started.   Diagnostic Roberts uterine catheter was formed across the aortic bifurcation and then navigated into the contralateral left internal iliac artery. Left internal iliac artery angiogram was done. The left uterine artery was well-visualized. Under direct roadmapping guidance, the left uterine artery was catheterized and a 2.8 French microcatheter was advanced over a GT double angled glide catheter. Left uterine artery angiogram was done to confirm the catheter position. Following this, embolization of the left uterine artery was performed utilizing 500 um Embozene  particles followed by 700 um Embozene  particles. Embolization was done to near-complete stasis. 5 cc of intra-arterial lidocaine was administered per protocol.  The Roberts uterine catheter was flushed and then navigated into the ipsilateral right internal iliac artery. Right internal iliac artery angiogram was done. Once the right uterine artery was well visualized, the vessel was catheterized with a 2.8 French progreat microcatheter were advanced over a double angle GT glide microwire. Angiograms were performed. Embolization was done utilizing 500 um Embozene  particles followed by 700 um Embozene  particles to near-complete stasis. Following this, intra-arterial lidocaine was administered per protocol.   A right common femoral artery angiogram was performed, demonstrating appropriate vascular access above the profunda femoris artery bifurcation. All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. Hemostasis was achieved using Perclose vascular closure device. The site was dressed in usual fashion.  The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. Double lumen PICC placement using ultrasound and fluoroscopy      Findings:   1.  Vein patency was documented by ultrasound and stored to PACS. 2.  The catheter tip terminates near the right atrium.        Impression:   1.	Uneventful image guided placement of 5 French, 45 cm double-lumen PICC in the right upper extremity as described. The lumens flush and aspirate appropriately.        Treatment Plan:   Catheter tip position is confirmed as above. It is OK to use this line.       Technique:   The site was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).   Ultrasound evaluation of the right basilic vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS. Local anesthetic was used over the access site. Under ultrasound guidance, the right basilic vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS.    A 0.018" wire was passed centrally and the needle exchanged for a dilator peel-away combination. The tailored catheter was advanced through the peel-away and positioned centrally using fluoroscopy.   The peel-away was removed, and hemostasis achieved with manual compression. The catheter was aspirated, flushed, and locked per protocol. It was secured in place with Ethilon.  An antimicrobial disc and sterile dressing were applied.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM AND COIL EMBOLIZATION OF RIGHT POSTERIOR INFERIOR CEREBELLAR ARTERY ANEURYSM    CLINICAL INDICATION: 26-year-old female with a past medical history of 3 diabetes, hypertension, and marijuana use who presented with headache and reported seizure who is found to have diffuse subarachnoid hemorrhage especially within the basilar cisterns. CTA revealed evidence of a right PICA aneurysm which is likely source of her subarachnoid hemorrhage. Additionally there is noted to be evidence of hydrocephalus on noncontrast CT scan. An external ventriculostomy drain was placed prior to her being brought for angiography. Diagnostic cerebral angiogram and treatment of ruptured aneurysm is indicated for prevention of recurrent rupture.   PROCEDURE: Cerebral angiogram, coil embolization of right posterior inferior cerebellar artery aneurysm.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: 2 hours.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician.  He supervised the entire procedure. [HCW] and [HCW] were the fellows. Each actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS CATHETERIZED: Right internal carotid artery Left internal carotid artery Left vertebral artery Right vertebral artery Right posterior inferior cerebellar artery  VESSELS IMAGED: Right common femoral artery Right internal carotid artery Left internal carotid artery Left vertebral artery Right vertebral artery  VESSELS TREATED (in sequence): Right posterior inferior cerebellar artery  ANESTHESIA:   General Anesthesia administered by anesthesiology staff.  Pre- Intra- and post- anesthesia records are available in the patient chart.   MEDICATIONS GIVEN:  Heparin 5000 units IV Aspirin 300 mg PR Protamine 25 mg IV Ancef 2 gram IV  MATERIALS USED:  5 French micropuncture kit Cope mandrel wire 5 French transitional dilator 6 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 0.038" Bentson guidewire 0.035" Terumo exchange-length glidewire  5 French Cordis Vertebral catheter 6 French neuron guide catheter (95 cm) Headway 17 Advanced microcatheter Traxcess microguidewire Visipaque 320 contrast material (160 cc) Perclose ProGlide closure device  COILS: Optimax complex 4 mm x 13 cm   TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient and her family. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, hemorrhage, renal failure, limb loss, death, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.  After informed, written consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion after intubation by the anesthesiology team. Additional shielding was placed in the pelvic region given the patient's young age. Access to the vascular system was gained by a single-wall puncture of the right common femoral artery with the aid of ultrasound guidance.  An angiogram of the right common femoral artery was obtained to confirm that the arterial puncture was above the bifurcation.  A 6 French short sheath was introduced into the right common femoral artery  using Seldinger technique.  3000 units of heparin were administered. Using fluoroscopic guidance, the 5 French diagnostic catheter was used to select the bilateral internal carotid arteries and the bilateral vertebral arteries.  Digital angiograms were performed of these vessels, centered over the head. Ipsilateral and contralateral oblique projections were obtained of both internal carotid artery injections to evaluate for anterior communicating or MCA bifurcation aneurysms.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: Rotational angiography was also performed from the diagnostic catheter in the mid cervical segment of the right internal carotid artery for better delineation of the intracranial vasculature. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.  3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: Rotational angiography was also performed from the diagnostic catheter in the mid cervical segment of the left internal carotid artery for better delineation of the intracranial vasculature. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.  3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY: Rotational angiography was also performed from the diagnostic catheter in the distal V1 segment of the left vertebral artery for better delineation of the intracranial vasculature. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.  3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF RIGHT VERTEBRAL ARTERY: Rotational angiography was also performed from the diagnostic catheter in the V1 segment of the right vertebral artery for better delineation of the intracranial vasculature. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.  Following the diagnostic angiogram, an aspirin rectal suppository (300 mg) was administered in preparation for coiling. An additional 2000 units of heparin was administered IV. A CTs were evaluated and additional heparin boluses were given as needed in order to maintain an ACT level between 250 300.   The 5 French diagnostic catheter was then exchanged over the 0.038" [VENDOR] exchange-length guidewire for the 053 neuron guide catheter, which was situated at the V3 segment of the left vertebral artery. Superselective catheterization of the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery aneurysm performed with the microcatheter over a microguidewire.   The aneurysm was framed and filled with the aforementioned coil using roadmap and blank roadmap technique.    A final cerebral angiogram was done in the AP and lateral projection to evaluate for residual filling, and distal emboli.  Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Ancef was administered.  Hemostasis was achieved by application of a Mynx closure device. A Tegaderm was then applied over the puncture site.  COMPARISON: None.  FINDINGS:  RIGHT COMMON FEMORAL ARTERY: The arteriotomy is above the bifurcation of the right common femoral. The diameter of the vessel is somewhat small and therefore we used a Mynx closure device rather than Perclose device..  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified.    LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified.    LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No focal stenosis or early draining vein are identified. Reflux of contrast into the contralateral vertebral artery was achieved. There is an aneurysm at the origin of the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery, which is better described on the right vertebral artery injections discussed below.  RIGHT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is a bilobed aneurysm at the origin of the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery, the dimensions of which are described on the 3-D rotational angiography discussed below. No focal stenosis or early draining vein are identified.   RIGHT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-EMBOLIZATION): Interval placement of coil into the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery aneurysm. There is partial contrast stagnation within the aneurysm. There are no perfusion deficits to suggest distal emboli in the distal circulation.  3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: 3D Rotational angiography with volume-rendered three-dimensional reconstruction on an independent workstation, demonstrated no evidence of aneurysm.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: 3D Rotational angiography with volume-rendered three-dimensional reconstruction on an independent workstation, demonstrated no evidence of aneurysm.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY: 3D Rotational angiography with volume-rendered three-dimensional reconstruction on an independent workstation, demonstrated an aneurysm at the origin of the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery which is not well visualized on this 3-D rotational angiogram, however is well visualized on the 3-D rotational angiogram of the right vertebral artery, which is described below..   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT VERTEBRAL ARTERY: 3D Rotational angiography with volume-rendered three-dimensional reconstruction on an independent workstation, demonstrated a bilobed aneurysm of the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery at the origin which measures 6.0 x 3.9 x 3.8 x 2.9 mm.   COMPLICATIONS: None.  IMPRESSION: 1. There is a bilobed aneurysm of the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery at the origin which measures 6.0 x 3.9 x 3.8 x 2.9 mm. This is the source of patient's subarachnoid hemorrhage. 2. Successful coil embolization of the above aneurysm 3. No other aneurysms were visualized.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]C.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Metastatic medullary thyroid carcinoma, dysphagia requiring gastrostomy tube for nutrition.  Procedure:   1.	Gastrostomy tube placement under fluoroscopic guidance.  Findings:   1.	The gastrostomy tube is in good position.  2.	Gentle hand injection of contrast material confirms positioning of the gastrostomy tube within the gastric lumen.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of 18 French MIC gastrostomy tube as above.  Treatment Plan:   The tube should be placed to gravity drainage and should not be used for 24 hours. 25 cc of water can be administered per hour. At 4 hours, if residuals are less than 30%, the patient can have tube feeds advanced starting at a half dose.   Technique:   Informed consent for the procedure was obtained, and time-out was performed prior to the procedure.  The skin overlying the access site was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the mid abdomen were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.   Using fluoroscopic and ultrasonographic guidance, an appropriate puncture site was identified.  3 T-fasteners were placed adjacent to the planned tube access site. Positioning of the T-fasteners within the gastric lumen was confirmed by return of air and direct injection of contrast material.  Next, under fluoroscopic guidance, an 18-gauge needle was directed into the gastric lumen. Needle positioning within the gastric lumen was confirmed with aspiration of air as well as gentle hand injection of contrast material.  A wire was advance through the 18-gauge needle.  The 18-gauge needle was removed over a wire. Serial dilation was accomplished over the stiff wire. An 18 French Halyard G-tube was advanced over a wire in an antegrade fashion and advanced through the anterior abdominal wall. All wires and catheters were removed. The bulb was inflated with 10 mL of a 10% contrast mixture. Gentle hand injection of contrast material documents the gastric feeding tube within the gastric lumen. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained for reference purposes. The tube was flushed with saline. It was affixed to the anterior abdominal wall with a rubber flange. The patient tolerated the procedure well at time of procedure completion without complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]C.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  [PATIENT] is a 54 y.o. female w/ PMH HTN 2/2 paraganglioma s/p resection on [DATE], significant LV hypertrophy related to hypertension, DM2, HLD who has had a prolonged hospital course complicated by chylous abdominal leak, urinary tract infection, C diff infection, drain infections.  Procedure:   1. Transjugular liver biopsy with pressure measurements 2. Attempted lymphangiography.  Findings:   1.	The right hepatic vein is normal in caliber and appearance. 2.	The biopsy specimen appeared adequate. 3.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. Needle entry was documented. 4.	Pressures: a. Wedged hepatic pressure: 18 mm Hg b. Right atrial: 12 mm Hg c. Corrected sinusoidal pressure of 6 mm Hg  5. Aborted attempt of lymphangiography, unable to access retroperitoneal lymph nodes and procedure was aborted due to free floating intraperitoneal lipiodol from repeat injections.  Impression:   Successful image guided transjugular liver biopsy. Corrected sinusoidal pressure of 6 mm Hg.    Treatment Plan:  Follow up pathology results.  Technique:   The procedure, options, and risks were reviewed with patient, including bleeding, infection, bowel perforation and pneumothorax. A time out was performed before initiating the procedure.  The skin overlying the access site was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). Patient sedation was performed, as detailed below.  The left neck was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Using local anesthetic and ultrasound guidance, the left internal jugular vein was punctured with a 21 gauge needle with permanent reporting and recording. An image documenting vein patency and needle entry was stored and transferred to PACS. A 9 French sheath was placed at the neck.  An angled catheter was used to select the right hepatic vein and hepatic venography performed using nonionic contrast. Free and wedged hepatic pressures were obtained.  A 0.035” wire was placed in the hepatic vein and the 7 French Cook biopsy cannula was advanced over the wire. The wire was removed, and 2 passes made with the 18 gauge coaxial needle.  The specimen was placed in formalin and delivered to the laboratory.  The cannula and sheath were removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression. No immediate complication occurred.  Subsequently, CT Cone Beam of the abdomen was performed, the target lymph node, already enhancing lymph nodes from prior angiography. Utilizing expert guide a needle was positioned into the target lymph node, however injection multiple bilateral lymph nodes did not yield lymphatic duct access, after multiple attempts of injecting multiple lymph nodes, the procedure was aborted due to obstructive view from free floating lipiodol in the peritoneum.  The patient tolerated the procedure well and was sent to post procedural care. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]C.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  42-year-old female TPN dependent managed via indwelling right IJ Hickman which is now infected.  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled central venous single-lumen Hickman catheter placement   2.	Removal of pre-existing Hickman catheter.  Findings:    1.	The scout radiograph shows indwelling right internal jugular Hickman with tip terminating at the superior cavoatrial junction; successfully removed en bloc. 2.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  3.	After placement of the new Hickman catheter, as described, the tip terminates near the cavoatrial junction..  Impression:  Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a tunneled Hickman catheter and removal of pre-existing Hickman catheter..       Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care.  The catheter is ready for immediate use.        Technique:   The skin overlying the access site and indwelling Hickman catheter was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  Hickman Placement The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS.  A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.  Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The venotomy tract was dilated to allow introduction of a peel-away sheath.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The catheter was tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.   The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS.   Hickman Removal The skin and subcutaneous tissue along the pre-existing Hickman catheter were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic. Next, using blunt dissection the cuff was liberated and the catheter was removed en bloc. Pressures applied to the base of the neck for a few minutes for hemostasis. A clean occlusive dressing was applied to the catheter entry site. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE].   Clinical Indication:  Lung transplant.  Procedure:   Gastrojejunostomy tube placement			     Findings:  1. The window was adequate.  2. Lateral fixation hardware of the lower lumbar spine with partially visualized clamshell sternotomy wires.. 3. The new gastrojejunostomy tube is appropriately positioned with its distal tip well beyond the ligament of Treitz in its proximal sideholes within the gastric lumen.    Impression:   Uneventful image guided de novo placement of an 18 French ballooned  gastrojejunostomy tube as described.   Plan:   1.  The jejunal lumen is ready for use.  The gastric port may be used in 24 hours.   2.  Routine maintenance/replacement in 6 months.   Technique:  Ultrasound was performed to identify the liver edge. IV glucagon was administered. Through a pre-existing nasogastric tube, the gastric lumen was insufflated. An appropriate window was identified, and 2 T-fasteners placed to appose the anterior gastric wall to the anterior abdominal wall. Contrast injection confirmed each gastric puncture. A fourth puncture was made between the 2 T-fasteners, and an Amplatz wire placed into the gastric lumen. A long 7 French sheath was placed over the wire toward the pylorus.  A 5 French angled catheter was used to negotiate the pylorus and an angled Glidewire positioned well beyond the ligament of Treitz. The Amplatz wire was advanced along the long Pinnacle sheath to maintain access. The skin tract was dilated and a 22 French peel-away sheath placed over the wire.  The GJ tube was advanced over the glide through the peel-away and positioned with its tip well beyond the ligament of Treitz. The peel-away was removed. The gastric lumen was positioned and the balloon inflated within the gastric lumen. Both ports were injected to confirm location.  The catheter was secured to the abdomen and usual manner and attached to gravity drainage.  The procedure was well-tolerated, and the patient was discharged from the angio suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  History hilar cholangiocarcinoma s/p bilateral biliary drain placement at outside hospital with leaking left biliary drain and dislodgement left bili drain. Routine right biliary drain exchange.  Procedure:   1.	Cholangiogram through existing percutaneous access 2.	Right and left internal/external biliary drain replacement  Findings:   1.	Partially dislodged left internal/external biliary drain 2.	Sheath cholangiogram through left drain demonstrates hilar obstruction with mildly dilated left biliary ducts 3.	Cholangiogram through existing right drain demonstrate transit of contrast into the duodenum and appropriate catheter position. 4.	Newly placed biliary drains are appropriately positioned with the distal tip in the second/third portion of the duodenum and the proximal side hole in a peripheral bile duct.  Impression:   1.	Uneventful image guided replacement of the bilateral internal/external biliary catheter exchanges, as described.  2.	The left biliary drain was modified with additional side holes (4 cm).  Treatment Plan:   Leave the drain to gravity bag.  IR will continue to follow the patient for capping trial.  Technique:   The existing catheter and surrounding soft tissues were prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site.  Left: An 0.035" Amplatz wire and 5 French Kumpe catheter combination was negotiated through the catheter into the small bowel. The catheter was removed and exchanged for a 6 French sheath. A sheath cholangiogram was performed, as above.  The sheath was removed and a new 8.5 French internal/external biliary drain was modified with additional sideholes (4 cm) was placed over the wire. Gadolinium contrast was injected to confirm tube position. The catheter was secured to the skin with 2-0 Ethilon. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.  Right: Cholangiogram was performed through the existing drain using gadolinium, as above. An 0.035" Amplatz was negotiated through the catheter into the small bowel. The catheter was removed and new 12 Fr internal/external biliary drain non-extended sideholes was placed over the wire. Gadolinium contrast was injected to confirm tube position. The catheter was secured to the skin with 2-0 Ethilon. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen Bard port (standard profile)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen Bard power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).   The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic. Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position in the right atrium. Gentle downward traction was applied to the port under fluoroscopic guidance to [HCW]strates that the catheter still would be appropriately positioned when the patient was in a standing position given her size. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous -0 absorbable sutures. Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with a single subcuticular stitch and Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Cardiogenic shock requiring long-term IV therapy  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled small bore central venous catheter placement  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the small bore central venous catheter, as described, the tip terminates in the right atrium.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a  5 French, 24 cm double lumen tunneled noncuffed small bore central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.  Treatment Plan:   1. Routine catheter care. 2. The catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissues overlying the vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle. An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Heart failure requiring milrinone   Procedure:  Image-guided 6F double lumen right internal jugular tunneled, cuffed smallbore central venous catheter  Findings:  1. The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and normal.  Needle entry was documented.  Images were stored to PACS. 2. The newly placed catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating in the region of the cavoatrial junction. 3. A 2-lead pacer enters from the left. There is right pleural fluid. The external jugular vein is also enlarged, consistent with heart failure.  Impression:   Uneventful image guided placement of 6 French double lumen 24 cm right internal jugular tunneled, non-cuffed central venous catheter as described.  Recommendation:  The catheter is ready for immediate use.  Routine care.  Technique:  The right jugular region was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. The region was ultrasonographically evaluated.  Using local anesthetic and ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was punctured with a 21 gauge needle.  An image documenting vein patency and needle entry was saved and stored to PACS. 2 g IV Ancef were administered after IV access was achieved due to milrinone running through the peripheral access.  A 0.018” wire was passed centrally and the needle exchanged for a a peel-away sheath.   The wire was used to determine catheter length. The catheter was cut to length.  The soft tissues caudal and lateral to the sheath entry site were anesthetized with lidocaine with epinephrine. A dermatotomy was made and the catheter was brought through the tunnel to the venotomy.      During suspended respiration, the catheter was advanced through the peel-away and positioned centrally using fluoroscopy. The peel-away was removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression.  The catheter was aspirated, flushed, and heparinized per protocol.  The venotomy was closed with Dermabond  and Steri-Strips applied.  The hub was sutured in place with Ethilon. An antimicrobial disc and sterile dressing were applied.  The procedure was well tolerated. The patient was lethargic throughout the procedure. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam: [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Primary hyperaldosteronism, left adrenal nodule  Procedure:   1. Bilateral adrenal vein sampling 2. Left adrenal venogram 3. Right adrenal venogram  Findings:    1.  Intermittent fluoroscopic images demonstrate catheter position in the infrarenal IVC, suprarenal IVC, left adrenal vein, and right adrenal vein. 2.  Left and right adrenal venograms demonstrated conventional anatomy with drainage into the left renal vein and direct to IVC, respectively. 3.  Samples to be assayed for cortisol and aldosterone:  Infrarenal IVC: 09:02 Suprarenal IVC:  09:05 Left adrenal vein 1: 09:00 Right adrenal vein 1: 09:13 Right adrenal vein 2: 09:27  Impression:   Successful bilateral adrenal vein sampling for cortisol and aldosterone levels.  Treatment Plan:   Sample sent to the lab for analysis. [HCW]tion index will be calculated when lab values are available.   Technique:   At least 30 minutes prior to the initiation the procedure, a cosyntropin infusion was initiated at 40 mcg/h through a peripheral IV.  The right groin was prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  The vascular structures were ultrasonographically evaluated.   Images were stored and transferred to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right common femoral vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  Vein patency and needle entry were documented. A 0.018" wire was placed and the needle exchanged for a 5 French dilator. The microwire was removed and a 180 cm [VENDOR]son wire was advanced into the IVC. The dilator was exchanged for a 5 French sheath.  A Sim[VENDOR]s 2 glide catheter was inserted through the sheath, formed using a 4-0 Tevdek suture, advanced into the left adrenal vein and venography was performed. Once positioning was confirmed, left adrenal venous sampling was performed. A Mikaelsson catheter was advanced to the infrarenal IVC and venous sampling was performed.  Catheter was advanced to the suprarenal IVC and venous filling was performed.  Catheter was then used to select the right adrenal vein and venography performed. Right adrenal vein samples were drawn through the base catheter, and, subsequently, through a coaxially loaded 2.8 French microcatheter.  Catheters and sheath were removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression. A sterile dressing was applied.  Cosyntropin infusion was terminated.  Patient tolerated the procedure without complication.
