DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: 65-year-old male with known right para ophthalmic artery aneurysm. Here for diagnostic cerebral angiogram for further evaluation.  PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 20 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] was the fellow. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right Internal Carotid Artery  ANESTHESIA: Local in the right groin with bupivacaine. Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by the nurse present during the entire procedure. The patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Sedation was administered by a specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for a total of 20  minutes (Total intra service time).  Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.  MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine SQ 10 cc  Versed 0.5 mg IV Fentanyl 25 mcg IV Heparin 3000 units IV Protamine 20 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.035" Bentson guidewire 5 French Boston Scientific sheath 5 French Cordis Vertebral catheter  Mynx Closure Device Visipaque-270 contrast material (20 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 5 French sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP, Lateral and Oblique views.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY:  Rotational angiography was also performed from the diagnostic catheter in the right internal carotid artery for better delineation of the underlying angio-architecture. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.    Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a Mynx Closure Device followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: Prior angiogram from [DATE].  FINDINGS: RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is redemonstration of the known superior hypophyseal artery aneurysm. It measures 4.4 x 2.5 mm with a 3.25 mm neck and is bilobed in appearance. This is unchanged from patient's prior angiogram. The remainder of the right internal carotid artery is normal in course and caliber. The ACA and MCA and its branches are normal course and caliber. There is normal cortical venous drainage.  3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: 3D Rotational angiography with volume-rendered three-dimensional reconstruction on an independent workstation, demonstrated the bilobed superior hypophyseal artery aneurysm measuring 4.4 x 2.5 mm with 3.25 mm neck. It is unchanged from patient prior angiogram..   COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: There is redemonstration of the known right superior hypophyseal artery aneurysm measuring 4.4 x 2.5 mm with a 3.5 mm neck. It is bilobed in appearance and unchanged from patient's prior angiogram.     [HCW], was present for the key and critical portions of the procedure and associated imaging guidance.

Patient's Name: [PATIENT]  MRN: [ID] Procedure date: [DATE]    IR NEPHROSTOMY DRAIN Bilateral Check And Exchange  Indications: The patient presented with bilateral indwelling 10.2 F nephroureteral stents for routine check and exchange. Also the patient complained of leakage around right nephrostomy tube.  Request is made for evaluation.  Procedure: After explaining the technique, risks, benefits, alternatives, and answering all questions, informed consent was obtained from the patient. Timeout identifying the correct patient, procedure, site, allergies was performed and observed by the operating team. The patient was positioned prone. The procedure is performed under continuous physiologic monitoring. The  patient received Ancef 2 g IV.  Initial evaluation revealed the right nephroureteral stent is partially pulled out. Both loins where prepped with chlorhexidine and draped in a sterile fashion.  Following administration of local anesthesia using lidocaine 1% with epinephrine 5 ml at each site, under fluoroscopy guidance a 0.035 " glide guidewire that was advanced through the left nephroureteral stent following removal of the anchoring suture the stent was removed intact and the available new 10.2 F  x 20 cm nephroureteral stent was placed. The pigtail was formed in the renal pelvis and the distal pigtail in the urinary bladder. The catheter was anchored to the skin using Ethilon 2/0 interrupted skin stitches. Contrast was then injected through the catheter confirming good position. The catheter was connected to an external urine bag. Hemostasis was secured. Sterile occlusive dressing was applied.  Applying the same technique on the right side, a 0.035 " Glidewire was advanced through the pigtail at the right renal pelvis into the right ureter and eventually to the urinary bladder. This was followed by removal of the partially pulled nephroureteral stent. The new available 10.2 F x 20 cm nephroureteral stent was advanced. The pigtail was formed in the dependent pelvis and the distal pigtail was placed in the urinary bladder. The catheter was anchored to the skin using Ethilon 2/0 interrupted skin stitches. Contrast was then injected through the catheter confirming good position. The catheter was connected to the external urine bag. Hemostasis was secured and sterile occlusive dressing was applied. The patient tolerated to the procedure well. There were no intraprocedural complications. The patient was transferred to recovery in stable condition and eventually discharged. Please also refer to the Procedure note placed in the patient's EPIC chart on the date of the procedure.  Fluoroscopy time:  01:41.5 min.  Devices placed: Ref. [ID], Lot. [ID] X 2.   Findings:  No significant hydronephrosis or hydroureter was identified.  Recommendations: The patient will need routine evaluation and possible catheter exchange every 3 months or earlier if the need arises.   Fellows: None. Residents: None.  IMPRESSION: 1. Successful fluoroscopy-guided bilateral nephrostomy tube check and exchange.   Voice recognition software is used in generating this report.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE].   Clinical Indication:  Ureteral stricture.   PROCEDURES:  1. Tractogram, right lower quadrant transplant kidney. 2. Nephrostomy tube replacement through mature tract.   FINDINGS:  The tractogram demonstrates mature tract communicating with the collecting system.  The newly placed catheter is appropriately positioned with the cope loop in the renal pelvis.  Poor opacification of the renal pelvis without drainage of contrast material into the bladder.  IMPRESSION:   Technically successful right lower quadrant transplant kidney PCN replacement through existing tract.   TECHNIQUE:   A scout radiograph was obtained. Contrast was injected at the site of nephrostomy tube dislodgement and imaging of the collecting performed.  A 0.035" glidewire was used in combination with an angled catheter to access the pelvicalyceal system under fluoroscopic guidance.   Initially, a new 18 French nephrostomy tube was attempted to be advanced over the wire but met significant resistance at the renal pelvis. The 18 French tube was then backed out over the wire and a new 12 French 25 cm MPD was advanced over the wire under fluoroscopic guidance. The wire was removed and the Cope loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis. Contrast injection confirmed location.  The catheter was sutured to the flank and placed to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.    The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Clogged gastrojejunostomy tube  Procedure:   1.	GJ-tube replacement.       Findings:   1.	The existing tube is in appropriate position.   2.	The new tube is appropriately positioned with the distal aspect of the tube terminating in the portion of the jejunum.  Impression:   1.	Successful replacement of 22 French MIC gastrojejunostomy tube with tip in jejunum.      Treatment Plan:    It is OK to use the tube immediately.    Routine check and change recommended in 6 months.  Technique:   Informed consent for the procedure was obtained, and time-out was performed prior to the procedure.  The skin overlying the access site was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). A stiff Glidewire was cannulated into the J port of the pre-existing tube and passed into the jejunum. The pre-existing GJ tube was removed over the wire after deflating the bulb. A new gastrojejunostomy tube was advanced over the wire. Its tip was placed in the proximal jejunum. The wire was removed.  The bulb was inflated with 10 mL of a 10% contrast mixture.   Contrast injection confirmed appropriate positioning of the G and J side ports. The balloon was inflated and the disc was cinched. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID].1  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication: Malignant urinary obstruction with dislodged right modified PCNU.  Procedure:  1.	Left antegrade nephrostogram. 2.	Left over-the-wire modified PCNU exchange. 3.	Right modified PCNU reinsertion via a pre-existing tract. 4.	Right antegrade nephrostogram.   Findings:  1. Dislodged right modified PCNU . Malpositioned left modified PCNU with loop in the posterior calyx. 2. Nephrostogram demonstrates bilateral distal ureteral obstruction. No hydronephrosis. 3. Newly placed modified bilateral PCNU is appropriately positioned with the proximal loop in the renal pelvis and distal end in the distal ureter.  Impression:  Successful right modified PCNU replacement and left modified PCNU exchange over wire.   Plan:   Patient will be due for routine exchange in 6-8 weeks.   Technique:  With the patient in prone position, the bilateral flanks were prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. A scout radiograph was obtained.   Left: Contrast was injected through the existing nephrostomy/nephroureterostomy tube and imaging of the collecting was system performed. A 0.035" wire was placed through the tube and the tube removed over the wire and discarded. A new, 10.2-French x modified nephroureterostomy tube was advanced over the wire under fluoroscopic guidance. The wire was removed and the proximal loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis. Contrast injection confirmed location.  Right: A 5 Fr dilator was inserted through the pre-existing subcutaneous tract and gently guided into the urinary collecting system. A 0.035" wire was placed through the dilator, which was then removed over the wire. A new, 10.2-French modified nephroureterostomy tube was advanced over the wire under fluoroscopic guidance. The wire was removed and the proximal loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis. Contrast injection confirmed location.  The catheters were sutured to the flank and placed to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.    The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]C.[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  History of HBV Cirrhosis and prior gastric variceal bleed s/p extended TIPS, longstanding right biliary ductal dilation, admitted with sepsis with concern for cholangitis, failed ERCP.  Procedure:   1.	Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram 2.	Placement of percutaneous transhepatic external biliary drain   Findings:   1.	Dilated right-sided bilary tree.  2.	Unable to cross the central stricture after multiple attempts. No contrast is visualized in the common bile duct or small bowel. 3.	External biliary drain placement with 3 cm of extended side holes ( 8.5 cm dawson-mueller drain)  4.	TIPS stent overly the left T10 - T12 paraspinal region 5.	Post surgical changes of cholecystectomy in the right upper quadrant.  Impression:   1.	Dilated right posterior intrahepatic bile ducts with central high grade stricture. Contrast was not visualized in the common bile duct or small bowel. 2.	Unable to cross the stricture after multiple attempts. 3.	Successful external biliary drainage catheter placement.  Plan:  1.	Open to bag drainage  2.	Will consider internalization attempt next week. 3.	Routine drain exchange in 8 weeks.  Technique:   The anterior abdominal wall and right flank were prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier.  An appropriate skin entry site was identified using fluoroscopy and ultrasound, and anesthetized with local.  Under fluoroscopic guidance, a 22G Chiba needle was advanced into the liver.  The right posterior bile duct was entered and the biliary system was opacified with contrast. Cholangiographic images were obtained.  A 0.018" wire was passed centrally, and the needle exchanged for Introducer Accustick access catheter. The inner stiffener, dilator, and 0.018" wire were removed and contrast was injected to confirm location.  A and 4 French angled glide catheter was negotiated through the outer sheath. A 0.035'' glidewire was advanced through the catheter to cross the stricture which was unsuccessful. The glidewire was exchanged for a 0.035" Amplatz wire and the sheath and 4 french catheter were removed.  The tract was dilated with an 8 Fr dilator. An 8.5 French extended-sidehole [HCW]son-Mueller (external) with 3 cm of extended side holes  biliary drain was placed over the wire. The anchor/loop was formed and locked. Attention was paid that side holes were positioned within the biliary system. Contrast was injected to confirm location. The catheter was secured to the skin with 2-0 suture material and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.  Contrast was injected through the existing biliary drainage catheter and cholangiographic images obtained.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location: [HOSPITAL].  PROCEDURE: IMAGE-GUIDED LIVER LESION PERCUTANEOUS NEEDLE BIOPSY. [HOSPITAL][ID]  Date of exam: [DATE].  Clinical Indication:  The patient presented with several suspicious lesions in the liver identified on the recent CT scan of the chest. Request is made for targeted percutaneous needle biopsy.  Technique: After explaining the technique, risks, benefits, alternatives, and answering all questions, informed consent was obtained from the patient. Timeout identifying the correct patient, procedure, site and allergies were performed and observed by the operating team. The patient was positioned left lateral and initial ultrasound evaluation confirmed visualization of the suspicious lesions as previously identified on the enhanced CT scan of the abdomen. Of note, the liver was not clearly visualized in the subcostal window and a spot was chosen along the anterior axillary line in the lower chest on the right side that is closest to the right lobe of the liver segment 6. The procedure is performed under continuous physiologic monitoring. The right sided lower chest and upper abdominal quadrant were prepped with chlorhexidine followed by Betadine  and draped in a sterile fashion.  Under ultrasound guidance and following administration of local anesthesia using lidocaine 1% with epinephrine 7 mL in the lower right side of the chest along the anterior axillary line that is closest to the suspicious liver lesion and through skin stab incision, a 17  G access needle was advanced into the suspicious lesion in segment 6 of the liver. Using coaxial 18  G biopsy gun, 6 cores were obtained and submitted in formalin for histopathology. Hemostasis was secured and the needle removed. Dermabond was applied at the puncture site. Postprocedure ultrasound did not reveal any complications. The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no intraprocedural complications. The patient was transferred in stable condition for continued observations.  Fellow(s): None. Resident(s): None.  Complications: No immediate complications..  Blood loss:  None. Patient's Name: [PATIENT] MRN: [ID] Procedure date: [DATE]   IR GASTROSTOMY TUBE  Indications: Patient presented with a 20 F standard G-tube that was exchanged 3 months earlier. The patient reported the damage externally to the acute and requested exchange with a 18 F low-profile G button. Of note, the patient denied having any labs prior to the procedure and also requested not to have local anesthesia.  Procedure: After explaining the technique, risks, benefits, alternatives, and answering all questions, informed consent was obtained from the patient. Timeout identifying the correct patient, procedure, site, allergies was performed and observed by the operating team. The patient was positioned supine. The left upper abdominal quadrant including the indwelling tube was prepped with chlorhexidine  and draped in a sterile fashion.  Initial fluoroscopic evaluation revealed 20 F standard G tube. Contrast was then injected and observed under fluoroscopy through the existing tube confirming intragastric location without evidence of leakage internally. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Poor IV access. Needs antibiotics. After placement of the tunneled catheter, as described, the tip terminates in the right atrium.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a power-injectable, 5 Fr, 25 cm, tunneled non-cuffed central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.  Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care. The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  80-year-old male with diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Need for chemotherapy access.  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen Bard port (standard profile)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen Bard power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 2-0 absorbable sutures. A running 4-0 absorbable subcuticular stitch and  Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with a single subcuticular stitch and Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM, SOLUMBRA THROMBECTOMY  CLINICAL INDICATION: This is a 67-year-old Male with a past medical history of 3 prior strokes, coronary artery disease status post multiple drug-eluting stents, heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (latest EF 50-55%), tachycardia-bradycardia syndrome, atrial flutter status post ablation and is reportedly on Eliquis), hypertension, and COPD who presents with right MCA syndrome secondary to a right M1 occlusion. Perfusion scanning and ASPECTS was favorable, and therefore mechanical thrombectomy was indicated.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 60 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW], was the attending physician. He supervised the entire procedure. [HCW] and [HCW] were the fellows. Each actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right common femoral artery Right Internal Carotid Artery   ANESTHESIA: General anesthesia. Pre-, intra-, and post-anesthesia monitoring records are available in the chart.   MEDICATIONS:  Heparin 5000 units IV Ancef 2 g IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 6 French Pinnacle Terumo Sheath (as a transitional dilator) 8 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 8 French Walrus balloon guide catheter 0.035" Bentson Guidewire 0.035" Bentson Guidewire, exchange length 5 French Simmons  catheter (130 cm) Asahi 018 microguidewire Trak 21 microcatheter RED 68 Aspiration Catheter Trevo NXT 4 x 41 Stentriever device  Perclose ProGlide closure device Omnipaque-300 contrast (30 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient's family (medical proxy). Specifically, the risks of intracranial or systemic hemorrhage, cerebral infarction, distal emboli, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, device malfunction, groin hematoma, arterial dissection/laceration, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite, intubated, and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery. An angiogram of the right common femoral artery was performed through the outer cannula the dilator sheath in order to confirm suitability of the arteriotomy. An 8 French sheath was introduced into the right common femoral artery. These were advanced into the aortic arch and fluoroscopic guidance in the diagnostic catheter and Bentson guidewire were used to select the right internal carotid artery. The 8 French balloon guide-catheter was advanced into the right internal carotid artery as a system over the Bentson guidewire and selection catheter. The wire and diagnostic catheter were then removed and the balloon guide was connected to a continual heparinized saline flush. Digital angiograms were performed centered over the head.   The initial TICI score was 0 secondary to a right M1 occlusion.  A triaxial system of the aspiration catheter, microcatheter, and microguidewire were advanced into the internal carotid artery over roadmap guidance. The Trak 21 microcatheter and Asahi 018 microwire were then advanced through the aspiration catheter past the M1 occlusion. The aspiration catheter was then tracked to the face of the clot. The wire was removed from the microcatheter and replaced with the Trevo NXT 4 x 41 stentriever device.  The stentriever was deployed under fluoroscopy and the allowed to set in the clot for 5 minutes. The microcatheter was removed so that that the stentriever was "naked" in the aspiration catheter. The balloon on the guide catheter was then inflated. The stentriever was then removed under continuous aspiration using a 60cc syringe. Thrombus was  identified within the aspirate.  The balloon on the guide was deflated and a cerebral angiogram was performed through the guide catheter. Recanalization of the right MCA was achieved with revascularization of the distal territory consistent with TICI 2B 67 reperfusion score (the M2 superior division remains occluded, however there was at least partial filling of this territory from collateralization from the ACA territory.).  At the conclusion of the case, Ancef was administered, and the sheath was removed and hemostasis obtained by deployment of the Perclose ProGlide closure device. A Tegaderm was then applied over the puncture site.  COMPARISON: Non-invasive imaging, same day  FINDINGS:  RIGHT  INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: A right middle cerebral artery, M1, occlusion is identified consistent with TICI 0.  There is some retrograde filling of M4 branches via pial collaterals from the ACA territory  RIGHT  INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-THROMBECTOMY, 1st pass):  Interval recanalization of the right middle cerebral artery. Reperfusion has been reestablished consistent with TICI 2B 67. The superior division remains occluded. There is partial perfusion of this territory via pial collaterals from the ACA territory.   RIGHT FEMORAL ARTERY: No abnormalities are detected. This vessel is suitable for use of the 8 French Angio-Seal closure device.  COMPLICATIONS: none immediate.  IMPRESSION:  1. Right MCA, M1, occlusion with initial occlusion consistent with TICI 0.  2. Status-post single pass mechanical thrombectomy using combined stentriever and aspiration technique with resultant TICI 2B 67 reperfusion score.

Patient's Name: [PATIENT]  MRN: [ID] Procedure date: [DATE] 9:29 AM  IR CENTRAL PORT  Indications: The patient presented with right breast cancer and is planned to start IV chemotherapy.  Request is made for an infusion port placement.  Procedure: After explaining the technique, risks, benefits, alternatives, and answering all questions, informed consent was obtained from the patient. Timeout identifying the correct patient, procedure, site, allergies was performed and observed by the operating team. The patient was positioned supine with the head turned to the right. The procedure is performed under continuous physiologic monitoring. The patient received intravenous conscious sedation using Versed 2 mg and fentanyl 100 mcg.  Also the patient received Ancef 2 g IV.  The left side of the lower neck and upper chest was prepped with Betadine followed by chlorhexidine and draped in a sterile fashion.  Following administration of local anesthesia using lidocaine 1% with epinephrine 9 ml at the left side of the root of the neck, under ultrasound  guidance, access was obtained into the left internal jugular vein using a micropuncture device. A 0.018" guidewire was advanced under fluoroscopy into the vein centrally. Further administration of local anesthesia using lidocaine 1% with epinephrine 13 mL into the left infraclavicular region. A transverse 3.5  cm incision was performed and a pocket created inferior to the incision to accommodate the port using both sharp and blunt dissection. Through the infraclavicular incision, the port tubing 8  F was tunneled exiting at the root of the neck following a nick incision at the exit of the guidewire. The guidewire was upgraded to 0.035" guidewire that was advanced under fluoroscopy through the SVC into the IVC. A peel-away sheath was advanced over the guidewire. Following removal of the guidewire and the stiffener, the port tubing was advanced after trimming to a length of 24 cm. The sheath was peeled away and the line was buried in the subcutaneous tissues. The tip of the line is at the SVC/upper right atrium. The port was tested demonstrating easy aspiration and injection and was flushed with normal saline followed by hep saline as per protocol. The port was anchored in the subcutaneous tissues using nonabsorbable 2/0 interrupted stitches. The wound was irrigated. Hemostasis secured. The incision at the root of the neck was closed using Dermabond. The infraclavicular incision was closed using subcutaneous followed by subcuticular Vicryl 4/0 continuous stitches. Steri-Strips were applied followed by Sterile occlusive dressing. The patient tolerated to the procedure well. There were no intraprocedural complications. The patient was transferred to recovery in stable condition and eventually discharged. The port is ready to use. Please also refer to the Procedure note placed in the patient's EPIC chart on the date of the procedure.  Fluoroscopy time: 00:31.8 min.  Device implanted: 8F single lum[HCW] power port, LOT #[ID], REF #[ID].  Fellows: None. Residents: None.  IMPRESSION: 1. Uneventful ultrasound fluoroscopy guided placement of 8  F Power  infusion port in the left internal jugular vein. The port is ready to use.  Voice recognition is used in generating this report.

Patient's Name: [PATIENT]  MRN: [ID] Procedure date: [DATE]   IR SOFT TISSUE FLUID/DRAIN INTERVENTION Right shoulder joint ultrasound-guided aspiration  Indications: The patient presented with sudden onset of swelling in the right shoulder region accompanied with pain and no fever or elevated white count.  Recent CT of the chest revealed the fluid collection around the right shoulder joint. Request is made for percutaneous aspiration. Of note, the patient recently stopped oral anticoagulation.  Procedure: After explaining the technique, risks, benefits, alternatives, and answering all questions, informed consent was obtained from the patient. Timeout identifying the correct patient, procedure, site, allergies was performed and observed by the operating team. The patient was positioned relaxed left lateral. The procedure is performed under continuous physiologic monitoring. The right shoulder region was prepped with chlorhexidine followed by Betadine and draped in a sterile fashion. Initial ultrasound evaluation revealed hypoechoic fluctuant fluid collection mostly anterior to the right shoulder joint with internal echoes.  Following administration of local anesthesia using lidocaine 1% with epinephrine 3ml, under ultrasound  guidance, access was obtained into the right shoulder joint anteriorly via a lateral approach using a 22G spinal needle. Thick-walled hematoma was identified. The needle was exchanged with a 5F UAB needed cannula following further local anesthesia administration. After removal of the inner stylet, aspiration to near completion of about 20 mL of old hematoma fluid was obtained. Samples of the fluid were submitted to the lab for microbiology culture and sensitivity testing. The cannula was removed. Hemostasis was secured. Sterile occlusive dressing was applied. The patient tolerated to the procedure well. There were no intraprocedural complications. The patient was transferred to recovery in stable condition. Please also refer to the Procedure note placed in the patient's EPIC chart on the date of the procedure.  Recommendations: Follow-up imaging might be needed for possible recurrence and also pending culture and sensitivity testing to exclude septic arthritis.  Fellows: None. Residents: None. After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 5 French long sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP, Lateral and Oblique views.   Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a 5 French Vascade closure device  followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: Cerebral angiogram [DATE].  FINDINGS: RIGHT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: The anterior communicating artery aneurysm coil mass is appreciated. There is no residual filling of the anterior communicating artery aneurysm. There is no focal stenosis or early draining vein identified.  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally.   LEFT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: The anterior communicating artery aneurysm coil mass is appreciated. There is no residual filling of the anterior communicating artery aneurysm. No focal stenosis or early draining vein are identified. The visualized ECA branches opacify normally.   COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: 1. No residual filling of the previously coil embolized anterior communicating artery aneurysm. 2. Note is made of a deep aortic arch with tortuosity of the great vessels necessitating the use of a Simmons 3 catheter. Patient's Name: [PATIENT] MRN: [ID] Procedure date: [DATE] 2:46 PM  IR TUNNELED LARGE BORE CVC  Indications: Chronic kidney disease.  Request is made for conversion of the nontunneled to tunneled dialysis catheter. The patient presents with an indwelling right  internal jugular vein nontunneled catheter without complications at the entry site.   Procedure: After explaining the technique, risks, benefits, alternatives, and answering all questions, informed consent was obtained from the patient's daughter in presence of the patient. Timeout identifying the correct patient, procedure, site, allergies was performed and observed by the operating team. The patient was positioned supine. The procedure is performed under continuous physiologic monitoring. The patient received intravenous conscious sedation using Versed 0.5 mg and fentanyl 25 mcg.  The right   side of the lower neck and upper chest including the indwelling 13  F Trialysis  catheter was prepped with chlorhexidine followed by Betadine and draped in a sterile fashion. No evidence of inflammation/infection at the entry site of the catheter is noted.   Following administration of local anesthesia using lidocaine 2% with epinephrine  10  ml at the right   side of the root of the neck extending to the right  infraclavicular region, 0.035" guidewire was advanced through the existing catheter under fluoroscopy into the SVC. Through skin stab incision in the right  infraclavicular region, a 14F x 19  cm [tip to cuff] dialysis catheter was tunneled exiting at the root of the neck  at the exit of the nontunneled catheter. A peel-away sheath was advanced under fluoroscopy over the guidewire under fluoroscopy following intact removal of the nontunneled catheter [13 F x 15  cm]. Following removal of the guidewire and inner dilator, the catheter was advanced into the SVC and buried in the subcutaneous tissues following peeling of the sheath. Hemostasis was secured. The catheter tip was adjusted at the level of the SVC/upper right atrium. Both ports demonstrated easy aspiration and injection and were flushed with hep saline per protocol. The incision at the root of the neck was closed with Steri-Strips. The catheter was anchored to the skin using Ethilon 2/0 interrupted skin stitches. Sterile occlusive dressing was applied at the exit of the catheter in infraclavicular region. The patient tolerated to the procedure well. There were no intraprocedural complications. The patient was transferred to recovery in stable condition and eventually to the floor. The catheter is ready to use. Please also refer to the Procedure note placed in the patient's EPIC chart on the date of the procedure.  Fluoroscopy time: 00: 08.4 min.  Device implanted: Lot #[ID], Ref #[ID].  Recommendations: The patient will need routine catheter check and possible exchange every 3 months.  Fellows: None. Residents: None.  IMPRESSION: 1. Uneventful image guided right   internal jugular  vein tunneled dialysis catheter placement following intact removal of the nontunneled catheter. The catheter is ready to use.  Voice recognition is used in generating this report.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam: [DATE]  Clinical Indication:  Hemorrhagic shock secondary to right perinephric bleed identified on CTA, presumed secondary to retracted nephroureterostomy tube. Both left and right nephroureterostomy tubes drain bloody urine.  PROCEDURE:   1. US-guided right common femoral artery access. 2. Visceral angiography 3. Arterial embolization 4. Post-embolization angiography 5. Right common femoral artery angiogram and closure 6. Right antegrade nephrostogram and percutaneous nephroureterostomy exchange.  7. Left antegrade nephrostogram via existing nephroureterostomy catheter.  FINDINGS: ANGIOGRAPHY: Vessels catheterized using base catheter and microcatheter/microwire combination and angiograms performed:  Abdominal aorta artery: No active hemorrhage. Right renal artery: No active hemorrhage. Right renal segmental artery: No active hemorrhage. Right renal segmental artery: No active hemorrhage. Right renal segmental artery: No active hemorrhage. Right renal segmental artery: No active hemorrhage.  Post-embolization right renal artery angiography: No active hemorrhage.  Left renal artery: No active hemorrhage.   Transcatheter embolization: Vessel 1: Right renal artery  Embolic: Gelfoam Details (type/size/volume/number): one-half sheet of Gelfoam prepared as thin slurry with contrast and saline.  Right PCNU: 1. Right PCNU is malpositioned with the proximal loop in the retroperitoneal fat and distal loop in the mid-ureter.  Left PCNU: 1. Left antegrade nephrostogram demonstrates appropriate position of existing PCNU and prompt flow into bladder.  IMPRESSION:   Technically successful Gelfoam embolization of the Right renal artery. Uneventful image-guided exchange of Right percutaneous nephroureterostomy tube.  Left percutaneous nephroureterostomy tube appropriately positioned, so not exchanged.  TREATMENT PLAN:  1. Continued clinical and laboratory monitoring recommended. Please contact interventional radiology if there is a change in clinical status. 2. Routine post-angiography groin cares ordered. 3. Patient will be due for routine exchange of nephroureterostomy tubes in 10-12 weeks.    TECHNIQUE: Angiogram/Embolization: With the patient in the supine position, the groin was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. Following standard prepping and draping, the right common femoral artery was punctured using a needle. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. An 0.035" wire was advanced into the aorta. A vascular sheath was placed over the wire into the common femoral artery.  A 5-Fr diagnostic catheter was advanced over an 0.035" wire into the abdominal aorta. The catheter was used to catheterize the vessels described above. Angiograms were performed. A microcatheter system was used to catheterize distal vessels, as described above. Specific vessels catheterized and embolized are described in detail above.  Once the catheter was in adequate position, embolization was performed using the parameters detailed. Post-embolization angiography was performed, as detailed.  A right common femoral artery angiogram was performed, demonstrating appropriate vascular access above the profunda femoris artery bifurcation. All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. Hemostasis was achieved using vascular closure device. The site was dressed in usual fashion.  Right and Left PCNU: With the patient in prone position, the bilateral flanks were prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. A scout radiograph was obtained.   A 0.035" wire was placed through the existing malpositioned right nephroureterostomy tube and the tube removed over the wire and discarded. A new, 8.5-French x 26 cm nephroureterostomy tube was advanced over the wire under fluoroscopic guidance. The wire was removed and the proximal loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis. Contrast injection confirmed location.  The catheter was sutured to the flank and placed to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.  Left PCNU: Contrast was injected through the existing left nephroureterostomy tube and imaging of the collecting was system performed. Drain was not manipulated.  The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. Under ultrasound guidance, the right basilic vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS.    A 0.018" wire was passed centrally and the needle exchanged for a dilator peel-away combination. The wire was used to determine catheter length, and a 5 French double-lumen PICC line cut to appropriate length. The tailored catheter was advanced through the peel-away and positioned centrally using fluoroscopy.   The peel-away was removed, and hemostasis achieved with manual compression. The catheter was aspirated, flushed, and locked per protocol. It was secured in place with Ethilon.  An antimicrobial disc and sterile dressing were applied.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Acute undifferentiated leukemia  Procedure:  1. Ultrasound and Fluoroscopic guided placement of a tunneled, cuffed central venous catheter  Findings:  1. The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and normal. Vein patency and needle entry were stored to PACS. 2. The newly placed catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating in the right atrium.  Impression:   Uneventful image guided placement of right internal jugular vein tunneled Trifusion catheter as described.  Technique:  The right neck and chest region was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. The region was ultrasonographically evaluated.  Using local anesthetic and ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was punctured with a 21 gauge needle.  An image documenting vein patency and needle entry was saved and stored to PACS.   A 0.018” wire was passed centrally and the needle exchanged for a 5 French transitional dilator. A 0.035” wire was advanced through the dilator and negotiated into the IVC.  The skin tract was dilated and a 13 French dilator peel-away combination placed over the wire.  The soft tissues caudal and lateral to the sheath entry site were anesthetized with lidocaine with epinephrine. A dermatotomy was made and a tunneling tool brought from the dermatotomy to the venotomy. The catheter was brought through the tunnel.  During suspended respiration, the catheter was advanced through the peel-away and positioned centrally using fluoroscopy. The peel-away was removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression.  The venotomy was closed with Dermabond and Steri-Strips applied. A single Prolene suture was placed at the catheter tunnel exit site. An antimicrobial disc and sterile dressing were applied.  The catheter was aspirated, flushed, and heparinized per protocol. The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient was discharged in satisfactory condition. Patient's Name: [PATIENT] MRN: [ID]  Procedure date: [DATE]  IR TUNNELED LARGE BORE CVC  Indications: End-stage renal disease.  Request is made for tunneled dialysis catheter placement. The patient suffers from sleep apnea.  Procedure: After explaining the technique, risks, benefits, alternatives, and answering all questions, informed consent was obtained from the patient. Timeout identifying the correct patient, procedure, site, allergies was performed and observed by the operating team. The patient was positioned supine. The procedure is performed under continuous physiologic monitoring. The patient received intravenous conscious analgesia using fentanyl 25 mcg.  Also the patient received Ancef 2 g IV.   The right  side of the lower neck and upper chest was prepped with chlorhexidine followed by Betadine and draped in a sterile fashion.  Following administration of local anesthesia using lidocaine 1% with epinephrine  12  ml at the right  side of the root of the neck extending to the right infraclavicular region, under ultrasound  guidance, access was obtained into the right  internal jugular vein using a micropuncture set. A 0.018" guidewire was advanced under fluoroscopy into the SVC. This was exchanged with a 0.035" guidewire that was advanced through the SVC into the IVC. Through skin stab incision in the right infraclavicular region, a 14 F x 19 cm [tip to cuff] dialysis catheter was tunneled exiting at the root of the neck following creating a second stab incision at the exit of the guidewire. A peel-away sheath was advanced under fluoroscopy over the guidewire under fluoroscopy. Following removal of the guidewire and inner dilator, the catheter was advanced into the SVC and buried in the subcutaneous tissues following peeling of the sheath. Hemostasis was secured. The catheter tip was adjusted at the level of the SVC/upper right atrium. Both ports demonstrated easy aspiration and injection and were flushed with hep saline per protocol. The incision at the root of the neck was closed with Dermabond. The catheter was anchored to the skin using Ethilon 2/0 interrupted skin stitches. Sterile occlusive dressing was applied at the exit of the catheter in infraclavicular region. The patient tolerated to the procedure well. There were no intraprocedural complications. The patient was transferred to recovery in stable condition and eventually to the floor. The catheter is ready to use. Please also refer to the Procedure note placed in the patient's EPIC chart on the date of the procedure.  Fluoroscopy time: 00:26.6 min.  Device placed: Ref #[ID], Lot # [ID].  Recommendations: The patient will need routine catheter check and possible exchange every 3 months.  Fellows: None. Residents: None.  IMPRESSION: 1. Uneventful image guided right  internal jugular vein tunneled dialysis catheter placement. The catheter is ready to use.  Voice recognition is used in generating this report.

Patient's Name: [PATIENT]  MRN: [ID] Procedure date: [DATE].  IR BILIARY INTERNAL/EXTERNAL DRAIN  Indications: The patient presented with the hyperbilirubinemia (total and direct)].  Request is made for PTC as the patient had unsuccessful ERCP with a failed opacification of the entire common bile duct due to occlusion.  Procedure: After explaining the technique, risks, benefits, alternatives, and answering all questions, informed consent was obtained from the patient. Timeout identifying the correct patient, procedure, site, allergies was performed and observed by the operating team. The patient was positioned supine. The procedure is performed under continuous physiologic monitoring. The patient received intravenous conscious analgesia using fentanyl 175 mcg given in divided doses during the procedure.  Also the patient received Ancef 2 g IV.  The right upper abdominal quadrant and epigastrium was prepped with chlorhexidine followed by Betadine and draped in a sterile fashion.  Following administration of local anesthesia using lidocaine 1% with epinephrine 7ml, under ultrasound  guidance, access was obtained into one of the moderately dilated central bile ducts in the right lobe of the liver as evidenced by dripping relatively clear bilious fluid. Limited intrahepatic cholangiogram was performed as the patient was unable to tolerate injections. No opacification of the common hepatic/common bile duct was achieved suggesting total occlusion. Over a 0.018 " guidewire, a 3F/7F exchange catheter was placed. Through the 7F catheter, 0.035 " Glidewire manipulations were performed in an attempt to bridge the central occlusion at the anticipated location where the common hepatic duct starts. No success was achieved after several attempts to communicate with the common hepatic/common bile duct. Over the 0.035 " guidewire, the available 8F nephrostomy tube was placed uncoiled in the biliary duct. The catheter was then anchored to the skin using Ethilon 2/0 interrupted skin stitches. Contrast injection revealed intrabiliary location. Hemostasis was secured. Sterile occlusive dressing was applied. The patient tolerated to the procedure well. There were no intraprocedural complications. The patient was transferred to recovery in stable condition and eventually discharged. Please also refer to the Procedure note placed in the patient's EPIC chart on the date of the procedure.  Fluoroscopy time: 14:08.5 min.  Recommendations: The patient will probably need combined evaluation by both simultaneous PTC and ERCP with 3-D fluoroscopy in order to map both intra and extrahepatic biliary duct system in attempt to achieve communication.  Fellows: None. Residents: None.  IMPRESSION: 1. Limited PTC due to central occlusion and nonvisualization of the common hepatic/common bile duct following unsuccessful attempts of wire manipulation. 8F drain was placed.  Voice recognition is used in generating this report.

Patient's Name: [PATIENT]  MRN: [ID] Procedure date: [DATE] 9:22 AM  IR CENTRAL PORT  Indications: The patient has metastatic left lung cancer.  Request is made for an infusion port placement to start IV chemotherapy.  Procedure: After explaining the technique, risks, benefits, alternatives, and answering all questions, informed consent was obtained from the patient. Timeout identifying the correct patient, procedure, site, allergies was performed and observed by the operating team. The patient was positioned supine with the head turned to the left. The procedure is performed under continuous physiologic monitoring. The patient received intravenous conscious sedation using Versed 1 mg and fentanyl 50 mcg given in divided doses during the procedure.  Also the patient received Ancef 2 g IV.  The right  side of the lower neck and upper chest was prepped with chlorhexidine followed by Betadine  and draped in a sterile fashion.  Following administration of local anesthesia using lidocaine 1% with epinephrine 6 ml at the right  side of the root of the neck, under ultrasound  guidance, access was obtained into the right  internal jugular vein using a micropuncture device. A 0.018" guidewire was advanced under fluoroscopy into the vein centrally. Further administration of local anesthesia using lidocaine 1% with epinephrine 8 mL into the right  infraclavicular region. A transverse 3.5  cm incision was performed and a pocket created inferior to the incision to accommodate the port using both sharp and blunt dissection. Through the infraclavicular incision, the port tubing 8  F was tunneled exiting at the root of the neck following a nick incision at the exit of the guidewire. The guidewire was upgraded to 0.035" guidewire that was advanced under fluoroscopy through the SVC into the IVC. A peel-away sheath was advanced over the guidewire. Following removal of the guidewire and the stiffener, the port tubing was advanced after trimming to a length of 21 cm. The sheath was peeled away and the line was buried in the subcutaneous tissues. The tip of the line is at the SVC/upper right atrium. The port was tested demonstrating easy aspiration and injection and was flushed with normal saline followed by hep saline as per protocol. The port was anchored in the subcutaneous tissues using nonabsorbable 3/0 interrupted stitches. The wound was irrigated. Hemostasis secured. The incision at the root of the neck was closed using inverted interrupted Vicryl 3/0 interrupted subcutaneous stitch followed by Dermabond. The infraclavicular incision was closed using subcutaneous followed by subcuticular Vicryl 3/0 continuous stitches. Steri-Strips were applied followed by Sterile occlusive dressing. The patient tolerated to the procedure well. There were no intraprocedural complications. The patient was transferred to recovery in stable condition and eventually discharged. The port is ready to use. Please also refer to the Procedure note placed in the patient's EPIC chart on the date of the procedure.  Fluoroscopy time: 00: 08.3 min.  Device implanted: 8F single lumen power port, Ref. #[ID], Lot. [ID].   Fellows: None. Residents: None.  IMPRESSION: 1. Uneventful ultrasound fluoroscopy guided placement of 8  F Power  infusion port in the right  internal jugular vein. The port is ready to use.  Voice recognition is used in generating this report.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Urosepsis in the setting of obstructing left nephrolithiasis.  Procedure:   1.	Left nephrostogram and nephroureterostomy tube placement      Findings:  Comparison is made to a previous exam CT [DATE].  1.	Ultrasound demonstrates mild hydronephrosis.  2.	Left antegrade nephrostogram demonstrates mild hydronephrosis with an obstructing left ureteropelvic junction stone and prompt passage of urine into the bladder. 3.	Left nephroureterostomy tube appropriately positioned with the proximal loop in the collecting system and distal loop in the bladder.  Catheter(s):  8.5x24cm F Cook nephroureterostomy tube  Impression:   1.	Uneventful ultrasound and fluoroscopic-guided placement of a left nephroureterostomy tube as described above.      Treatment Plan:   Patient should be evaluated by Urology for definitive treatment of stone, and return for routine check and change in 8-12 weeks if it remains in place at that time.  Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained to the patient. Written informed consent was obtained.  A time out/call to order was performed prior to procedure initiation.  The soft tissues overlying the access site were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Ultrasound was utilized to identify an appropriate access site. Static ultrasound image was obtained and stored to PACS for reference purposes. Subsequently, under fluoroscopic and real-time concurrent ultrasound guidance, access was obtained into a posterior, inferior calyx using a 21 Ga needle and a triaxial sheath system ([VENDOR]). Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site. A wire was advanced centrally. Serial dilation was accomplished over the wire. The wire and inner dilator were removed. Non-ionic contrast was injected into the collecting system and images of the antegrade pyelogram were obtained and stored to PACS.  An 0.035” wire was advanced through the existing access. A nephrostomy tube was advanced over the wire and the Cope loop formed in the renal pelvis. Contrast injection confirmed location. Minimal drainage was observed so the decision was made to convert to a nephroureterostomy drain. An 0.035” wire was advanced through the existing access. The nephrostomy tube was unlocked and removed. Then, after measuring the length with a Kumpe catheter, an 8.5Fr x 24cm nephroureterostomy tube was advanced over the wire and the distal loop formed in the bladder and proximal loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis.  The catheter was sutured to the flank with monofilament suture and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.  The procedure was well tolerated, and patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. PROCEDURE:   1. US-guided left radial artery access 2. US-guided left common femoral artery access. 3. Visceral angiography 4. Arterial embolization 5. Post-embolization angiography 6. Left internal iliac artery posterior division: No active extravasation Left internal iliac artery lumbar branch: Active hemorrhage identified. Post-embolization x artery angiography: Cessation of extravasation.  Transcatheter embolization: Vessel 1: Left internal iliac artery lumber branch Embolic: Coils Details (type/size/volume/number): 2x Coils (Tornado .018 6mm-2mm)  Vessel 1: Left internal iliac artery lumber branch Embolic: Coils Details (type/size/volume/number): 1x Coil (Tornado .018 6mm-2mm)   IMPRESSION:   Technically successful coil embolization of the left internal iliac artery lumbar branches.  TREATMENT PLAN:  1. Continued clinical and laboratory monitoring recommended. Please contact interventional radiology if there is a change in clinical status.  TECHNIQUE:  With the patient in the supine position, the left wrist was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The left wrist was evaluated with ultrasound and appropriate left radial artery access criteria were documented. 1% lidocaine solution was administered for local anesthesia. Access was obtained to the left radial artery using a 21 gauge needle and ultrasound guidance. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. A wire was placed through the needle. A hydrophilic Glidesheath was advanced slowly over the wire. 3000 units of heparin, 200 mcg of nitroglycerin and 2.5 mg of verapamil was given through the arterial sheath with slow hemodilution. A 5-Fr Jacky/Sarah catheter was advanced over an 0.035" wire into the aorta. The catheter was exchanged for an Omniflush catheter for a pelvic aortogram. The Omniflush catheter was removed over the wire, but subsequent catheters could not be advanced due to vessel spasm. 50mcg nitroglycerin was administered at the site of presumed spasm, without resolution. All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. A band was placed on the left wrist for hemostasis. The access sheath was removed and no hematoma was seen. A radial artery pulse was confirmed distal to the puncture site confirming patent hemostasis.   Following standard prepping and draping, the left common femoral artery was punctured using a needle. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. An 0.035" wire was advanced into the aorta. A vascular sheath was placed over the wire into the common femoral artery.  A 5-Fr diagnostic catheter was advanced over an 0.035" wire into the abdominal aorta. The catheter was used to catheterize the vessels described above. Angiograms were performed. A microcatheter system was used to catheterize distal vessels, as described above. Specific vessels catheterized and embolized are described in detail above.  Once the catheter was in adequate position, embolization was performed using the parameters detailed. Post-embolization angiography was performed, as detailed.  A left common femoral artery angiogram was performed, demonstrating appropriate vascular access above the profunda femoris artery bifurcation. All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. Hemostasis was achieved using vascular closure device. The site was dressed in usual fashion.  The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM AND ENDOVASCULAR PIPELINE EMBOLIZATION OF A RUPTURED, SUBTOTALLY COILED POSTERIOR COMMUNICATING ARTERY ORIGIN ICA ANEURYSM  CLINICAL INDICATION: [PATIENT] is a 33-year-old woman who was recently treated for a ruptured posterior communicating artery aneurysm. The aneurysm was subtotally coiled which is planned for "plug and pipe". She now presents for flow diversion of the residual aneurysm.  PROCEDURE: Cerebral angiogram and endovascular pipeline embolization.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 60 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] was the fellow. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS CATHETERIZED: Right internal carotid artery Right middle cerebral artery Right common femoral artery  VESSELS TREATED (in sequence): Right middle cerebral and internal carotid arteries  ANESTHESIA: General endotracheal anesthesia. Pre-, intra-, and post-anesthesia monitoring records are available in the chart.  MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine 10 cc SQ Heparin 5000 units IV Ancef 2 gram IV  MATERIALS:  5 French     micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 6 French 65cm Arrow sheath 0.038" Bentson Guidewire 5 French Cordis Vertebral catheter 058 Navien guide catheter 3.75 mm x 14 mm pipeline embolization device 4.0 mm x 12 mm pipeline embolization device Phenom 27 Microcatheter Asahi 018 microguidewire Perclose ProGlide closure device Omnipaque-300 contrast (60 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, stent thrombosis/stenosis, stent migration, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, non-target embolization, puncture site hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed, written consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite, intubated, and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 6 French 65cm Arrow sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 5000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement; additional boluses of heparin were administered at one-hour intervals. The ACT was checked to ensure that it was between 250-300. Using fluoroscopic guidance,  the arteries  listed above were selectively catheterized. Digital angiograms were performed in the AP, lateral and oblique projections centered over the head and neck.   3D rotational angiography was performed with the diagnostic catheter in the right internal carotid artery to better delineate the intracranial anatomy. The acquisition was processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.   The diagnostic catheter was exchanged for a 058 Navien guide catheter under fluoroscopy and advanced into the petrous internal carotid. A working projection was obtained to best demonstrate the neck of the residual posterior communicating artery origin ICA aneurysm, as well as, the distal and proximal landing zones for the stent. Superselective catheterization of the right MCA was performed with the [VENDOR]om 27 microcatheter over the Asahi 018 microguidewire. The tip of the microguidewire was situated in the superior division of the M2.   The microguidewire was then exchanged for a 3.75 mm x 14 mm Pipeline embolization device. The device was deployed under fluoroscopic guidance and a single shot X-ray was performed to confirm that the  distal and proximal ends of the pipeline embolization device were in the proximal MCA and  cavernous carotid, respectively. Given that the morphology of the residual posterior communicating artery aneurysm hasn't substantially changed approximately one month following rupture I felt compelled to place a second device. Therefore a 4.0 mm x 12 mm pipeline embolization device was placed inside the first.  A final AP and Lateral angiogram were completed to evaluate the distal vasculature for perfusion deficits and emboli.   After completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. A roadmap of the right common femoral artery was obtained. The arteriotomy was above the level of the bifurcation and the CFA was of sufficient size to use the Perclose ProGlide closure device. Ancef was administered. The sheath was removed and hemostasis obtained using the Perclose ProGlide closure device. A Tegaderm were then applied over the puncture site.  COMPARISON:    .  FINDINGS:  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: Mild remaining mid segment and 1, A1, and supraclinoid ICA vasospasm are noted. Measurements of the three-dimensional rotational angiogram as compared to that from the original day demonstrated approximately 10-15% narrowing of these vessels. The superior apophyseal artery origin ICA aneurysm is grossly unchanged. The residual portion of the posterior communicating artery aneurysm at the neck has substantially expanded in size with a few lobule directed posteriorly.       RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-PIPELINE EMBOLIZATION): The Pipeline device is well apposed to the vessel walls throughout it's course without endoleak. . Stasis of contrast is noted within the aneurysms.  No perfusion deficits to suggest distal emboli are present.  3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY: A 3D rotational angiogram of the  right internal carotid artery was completed and post-processed on an independent work station. 3D angiography revealed mild vasospasm was noted above and the aforementioned changes to the residual posterior communicating artery aneurysm.  RIGHT COMMON FEMORAL ARTERY: No abnormalities are detected. The arteriotomy was above the level of the bifurcation and the CFA was of sufficient size to use the Perclose ProGlide closure device.   COMPLICATIONS: none immediate.  IMPRESSION:  1. Potential change to the proximal portion of the subtotally coiled, ruptured, posterior communicating artery aneurysm. There is a posterior lead directed lobule measuring approximately 4 mm. The superior hypophyseal artery origin aneurysm is unchanged.  2. Successful deployment of scalloping pipeline embolization devices for treatment of the above-described aneurysms.

Treatment Plan:  Follow up pathology re[HCW].  Technique:   The procedure, options, and risks were reviewed with patient, including bleeding, infection, and pneumothorax. No immediate complication occurred, and the patient was discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained to the patient. Written informed consent was obtained.  A time out/call to order was performed prior to procedure initiation.  The soft tissues overlying the access site were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Ultrasound was utilized to identify an appropriate access site. Static ultrasound image was obtained and stored to PACS for reference purposes. Subsequently, under fluoroscopic and real-time concurrent ultrasound guidance, access was obtained into a posterior, inferior calyx using a 21 ga needle and a triaxial sheath system. Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site. A wire was advanced centrally. Serial dilation was accomplished over the wire. The wire and inner dilator were removed. A nephrostomy tube was advanced over the wire and the Cope loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis. Contrast injection confirmed location. The catheter was sutured to the flank with monofilament suture and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.  The procedure was well tolerated, and patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition.   Procedural Personnel Attending(s): [HCW]  Complications: No immediate complications. At 4 hours, the patient can have tube feeds advanced starting at a half dose.   Technique:   Informed consent for the procedure was obtained, and time-out was performed prior to the procedure.  The skin overlying the access site was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the mid abdomen were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.   Using fluoroscopic and ultrasonographic guidance, an appropriate puncture site was identified.  3 T-fasteners were placed adjacent to the planned tube access site. Positioning of the T-fasteners within the gastric lumen was confirmed by return of air and direct injection of contrast material.  Next, under fluoroscopic guidance, an 18-gauge needle was directed into the gastric lumen. Needle positioning within the gastric lumen was confirmed with aspiration of air as well as gentle hand injection of contrast material.  A wire was advance through the 18-gauge needle.  The 18-gauge needle was removed over a wire. An 8 French sheath was advanced over wire. A 0.035 inch Stiff Glide was advanced through the sheath. The sheath was removed and Amplatz wire was secured as a safety wire. The sheath was advanced over the Stiff glide. Kumpe catheter and Stiff glide combination was negotiated into the distal duodenum, past the ligament of Treitz. The sheath and Kumpe catheter were removed.  Serial dilation was accomplished over the stiff wire. An 18 French Halyard GJ-tube was advanced over a wire in an antegrade fashion and advanced through the anterior abdominal wall into the proximal jejunum. All wires were removed. The bulb was inflated with 10 mL of a 10% contrast mixture. Gentle hand injection of contrast material documents the gastric portion feeding tube within the gastric lumen and contrast in the jejunum to confirm the distal portion.   Static fluoroscopic image was obtained for reference purposes. The tube was flushed with saline. It was affixed to the anterior abdominal wall with a rubber flange. The patient tolerated the procedure well at time of procedure completion without complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  T12 compression fracture  Additional Clinical Indication: Acute (6 weeks or less) T12 osteoporotic vertebral body/vertebral bodies compression fracture(s). Spine MRI/bone-scan is within 30 days of this procedure and was performed on [DATE]. Patient has severe back pain despite optimal non-surgical management with severe impact of vertebral body compression fracture(s) on daily functioning. Patient has kyphotic deformity due to vertebral body compression fracture(s).     Procedure:   1.	Image-guided kyphoplasty   Findings:   1.	Pre-intervention: Redemonstration of T12 compression fracture with severe height loss 2.	Post-intervention:  Successful deposition of cement within the treated vertebral body/bodies with small amount of extravasation into the superior disc space.    Impression:   1.	Successful image guided augmentation of vertebral levels: T12    Treatment Plan:   1.	 A fracture of the hip, spine or distal radius in patients over 50 years of age warrants testing or treatment for osteoporosis if not previously undertaken.   Patient was instructed to take part in an osteoporosis prevention/treatment program by discussing it with her primary care physician.   Technique:   The patient was brought to the interventional radiology suite and placed on the table in prone position. The wide area of the back around the affected area(s) was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion.   All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). A scout image was obtained in AP and lateral projections.   Skin was anesthetized with a 2% lidocaine solution.   [HCW]l by level technique:   -Vertebral level:  T12 kyphoplasty -Pedicle access:  Bipedicular -Access trocar gauge:  10-gauge -Balloon utilized:  15 mm  Prior to injection of cement, balloons were inserted and inflated under biplane fluoroscopy.  Static fluoroscopic images were stored to PACS documenting balloon utilization and position. -Biopsy obtained:  No -Indication for biopsy: N/A -Ablation Performed: N/A -Indication for Ablation: N/A  Additional Procedural Details:   Utilizing AP and lateral fluoroscopy, needles were inserted into the affected vertebral body/bodies. Needles were advanced under careful, intermittent biplane fluoroscopy to ensure that the medial wall of the pedicle was not violated prior to transgression of the needle tip into the posterior wall of the vertebral body. The drill was then advanced to the anterior one-third of the vertebral body on each side.  No ablation was performed.  Balloon(s) was/were inserted into the effected vertebral body/bodies and inflated under fluoroscopy. Static fluoroscopic images were stored to PACS documenting balloon position. Cement was mixed and balloons were removed after being deflated.  Cement was then injected under careful, intermittent biplane fluoroscopy to ensure no significant extravasation of PMMA cement beyond the borders of the vertebral body. Cement injection was stopped once there was adequate fill of the vertebral body. Trochars were removed with hemostasis obtained with focal compression. Static fluoroscopic images were obtained after removal of all needles documenting final cement position. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  end stage renal disease on dialysis, cultures clear from bacteremia treatment and ok to convert vascath to permcath for long-term dialysis access  Procedure:  1. Fluoroscopic-guided exchange of large-bore venous catheter, from nontunneled to tunneled  Findings:  1. Scout image demonstrates existing non-tunneled catheter with tip positioned in the right atrium. 2. Newly exchanged catheter is appropriately positioned, with the tip in the right atrium. Now tunneled.  Impression:  Uneventful image-guided over-the-wire exchange of a right internal jugular nontunneled large bore central venous catheter to a now  28 cm tunneled large bore central venous catheter (Permcath).   Plan:  Catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:  The right chest wall and area immediately around the existing catheter was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. Using local anesthetic, the new tract and the venotomy/original insertion site on right neck was anesthetized. A niche was made at the entry of the new tunnel site on chest. A tunneled catheter was passed through the new tunnel with a blunt tip device through and out the current catheter's insertion site/venotomy. A stiff angled glide wire was advanced through the original nontunneled catheter and into the inferior vena cava. Imaging was stored. The catheter was then pulled with gentle traction until it was completely removed over the wire. A peel-away sheath was advanced over the wire into position. A new catheter was advanced through the peel away sheath until the tip was positioned appropriately, with the cuff positioned within the tunnel. The images of appropriate positioning with tip in the right atrium saved onto PACS. Both lumens were aspirated and flushed and heparinized per protocol. Non-absorbable suture was used to secure the catheter tunnel exit site. The original venotomy site was closed with a single stitch of absorbable suture and dermabond. An antimicrobial disc and sterile dressing were applied.  Patient tolerated procedure without complication.
