DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: Right frontoparietal mixed density subdural hematoma  PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 30 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] was the resident. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right internal carotid artery Right external carotid artery Right middle meningeal artery  ANESTHESIA: General endotracheal anesthesia was administered under the supervision of the attending anesthesiologist. Pre-, intra-, and post-anesthesia monitoring records are available in the chart.  MEDICATIONS:  Heparin 3000 units IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.038" Bentson guidewire 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 5 French [HCW]rtebral catheter  Cardiva Vascade Omnipaque-300 contrast material (60 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 5 French sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP, Lateral and Oblique views.   This was intended to be a middle meningeal artery embolization for primary treatment of mildly symptomatic subdural hematoma. However, a sphenoid branch made in anastomosis to the lacrimal gland. A separate, quite large sphenoid branch made direct anastomosis to the ethmoidal arcade supplying the nose. Considering the size of these branches in their ridge anastomoses, I felt embolization would result in a very high risk of postoperative blindness. Therefore, the procedure was aborted.  Following completion of the procedure, heparin was not reversed sitting the patient has a PE and had not Eliquis today. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a Vascade followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: Axial imaging.  FINDINGS: RIGHT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: The bifurcation is smooth, without irregularity, calcification, or stenosis with respect to the distal ICA. The ECA branches opacify normally.  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified.       RIGHT MIDDLE MENINGEAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: Normal anatomy. 2 large sphenoid branches are seen. One makes anastomoses to the lacrimal artery and gland whereas the others makes a retention anastomosis to the ethmoidal arteries.   COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION:  1. Diagnostic cerebral angiogram of the right internal/external carotid arteries as well as middle meningeal artery. Middle meningeal artery embolization was aborted due to collateral study is which portends unjustifiably high risk of postprocedural blindness.

CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM AND BALLOON ASSISTED COIL EMBOLIZATION OF RUPTURED RIGHT POSTERIOR COMMUNICATING ARTERY ANEURYSM    CLINICAL INDICATION: 57-year-old male with sudden onset worst headache of life and SAH concerning for underlying aneurysm brought to the angiography suite for cerebral angiography and coil embolization of suspected right posterior communicating artery aneurysm.  PROCEDURE: Cerebral angiogram, balloon-assisted coil embolization of right posterior communicating artery aneurysm.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: 1.5 hours.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician.  He supervised the entire procedure. [HCW] was the fellow. They both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS CATHETERIZED: Right internal carotid artery Right external carotid artery Right vertebral artery Left internal carotid artery Left external carotid artery Left common carotid artery Right common femoral artery  VESSELS TREATED (in sequence): Right internal carotid artery  ANESTHESIA:   General Anesthesia administered by anesthesiology staff.  Pre- Intra- and post- anesthesia records are available in the patient chart.   MEDICATIONS GIVEN:  0.5% Bupivacaine 10 cc SQ Heparin 7000 units IV Aspirin 300 mg PR Protamine 20 mg IV   MATERIALS USED:  5 French micropuncture kit Cope mandrel wire 5 French transitional dilator 6 French 65cm Arrow sheath 0.038" Bentson guidewire 0.035" Terumo exchange-length glidewire  5 French Cordis Vertebral catheter 058 Navien guide catheter Headway 17 Advanced microcatheter [HOSPITAL] 018 microguidewire Transcend-EX microguidewire 4 mm x 10 mm Scepter C balloon microcatheter Visipaque 270 contrast material (120 cc) Perclose ProGlide closure device  COILS: Framing coil: 3 mm x 7 cm optima complex coil Filling coils: 2 mm x 3 cm optima complex coil   TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, hemorrhage, renal failure, limb loss, death, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.  After informed, written consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion after intubation by the anesthesiology team. Access to the vascular system was gained by a single-wall puncture of the right common femoral artery. A 6 French 65cm Arrow sheath was introduced into the descending aorta using Seldinger technique.  Using fluoroscopic guidance, the 5 French diagnostic catheter was used to select the bilateral internal carotid arteries and the right vertebral artery.  Digital angiograms were performed of these vessels, centered over the head. Ipsilateral and contralateral oblique projections were obtained of both internal carotid artery injections to evaluate for anterior communicating or MCA bifurcation aneurysms.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: Rotational angiography was also performed from the diagnostic catheter in the right internal carotid artery for better delineation of the intracranial vasculature. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.  Following the diagnostic angiogram, an aspirin rectal suppository (300 mg) was administered in preparation for coiling. The 5 French diagnostic catheter was then exchanged over the 0.035" [VENDOR]umo exchange-length glidewire for the 058 Navien guide catheter, which was situated at the right internal carotid artery. The balloon was then prepared on an adjacent table, and the microguidewire and the balloon were passed coaxially through the guide catheter into the right paraclinoid internal carotid artery. Superselective catheterization of the right posterior communicating artery aneurysm performed with the microcatheter over a microguidewire.   Using roadmap guidance, the balloon was advanced to cover the ostium of the aneurysm. The aneurysm was framed and filled with the aforementioned coils using both roadmap and blank roadmap technique.  A final cerebral angiogram was done in the AP and lateral projection to evaluate for residual filling, and distal emboli.  Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine.  An angiogram of the right common femoral artery was obtained to confirm that the arterial puncture was above the bifurcation that the vessels of adequate size to use a Perclose ProGlide. Ancef was administered.  Hemostasis was achieved by application of a Perclose ProGlide. A Tegaderm was then applied over the puncture site.  COMPARISON: None.  FINDINGS:  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is a 3.5 x 5 millimeter irregularly-shaped and inferiorly directed posterior communicating artery aneurysm. The posterior communicating artery itself is dominant and supplies the posterior cerebral artery territory. It arises from the base of this aneurysm. The aneurysm itself has a neck measuring 2.5 mm. The ACA and MCA and its branches are normal in course and caliber. There is normal cortical venous drainage.  RIGHT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   LEFT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CERVICAL: There is an irregularly-shaped calcified plaque just distal to the origin of the left internal carotid artery measuring up to 60% stenosis. The remainder of the left cervical ICA is unremarkable. The ECA branches opacify normally.  LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. The distal ICA and its segments are normal course and caliber. The left posterior communicating artery is dominant supplies the posterior cerebral territory. The ACA and MCA and its branches are normal course and caliber. There is normal cortical venous drainage.   LEFT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   RIGHT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysms, or early draining vein are identified. The distal vertebral artery is normal in course and caliber. Reflux of contrast into the  contralateral vertebral artery was not achieved. The origin of PICA is normal unilaterally (we will defer to CTA for evaluation of the contralateral PICA). There is a duplicated SCA on the left. The basilar artery is unremarkable. The bilateral PCAs are patent with early contrast washout concordant with competitive flow from the posterior communicating arteries. There is normal cortical venous drainage.  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-EMBOLIZATION): There is minimal residual filling at the base of the coiled right posterior communicating artery aneurysm. The right posterior communicating artery is patent. There are no perfusion deficits to suggest distal emboli in the right internal carotid circulation.  3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE right internal carotid artery:  3-D rotational angiography demonstrated a highly irregular inferiorly directed right posterior communicating artery aneurysm measuring 3.5 x 5 mm in diameter. The right posterior communicating artery originates at the base of the aneurysm..   RIGHT COMMON FEMORAL ARTERY: The arteriotomy is above the bifurcation of the right common femoral artery and the diameter of the vessel is adequate for a Perclose ProGlide.  COMPLICATIONS: None.  IMPRESSION: 1. Successful coil embolization of a right posterior communicating artery aneurysm measuring 3.5 x 5 mm in diameter. There is minimal residual filling at the base of the aneurysm and the right posterior communicating artery is patent after coil embolization. No other aneurysms are visualized.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Suspected HCC. Hepatitis C cirrhosis, with a questionable lesion in segment 7, reported as a LR 4.  PROCEDURE:   1. US-guided left radial artery access 2. Diagnostic visceral angiography 3. Selective internal radioembolization with Yttrium-90  FINDINGS: ANGIOGRAPHY: Vessels catheterized and angiograms performed, as follows:  Celiac artery: Tumoral blush identified. Right hepatic artery: Tumoral blush identified. Segment 7 hepatic artery: Tumoral blush identified.  Specific technical notes / catheter selection:  5 French slender sheath [VENDOR] catheter 2.4 Progreat microcatheter Fathom microwire  Transcatheter embolization using Yttrium-90 microspheres performed from: Right hepatic artery, segment 7  Therasphere-55.4 mCi  IMPRESSION:   Successful Yttrium-90 Therasphere selective internal radiotherapy of a segment 7 hepatocellular carcinoma.  TREATMENT PLAN:  1. Patient will return to clinic in 6-8 weeks with abdominal MRI and labs.  2. Access site precautions and orders placed.  TECHNIQUE:  With the patient in the supine position, the left wrist was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The left wrist was evaluated with ultrasound and left radial artery patency and acceptable size criteria were documented and images were properly stored in PACS. A modified Allen test (Barbeau test Type A) was performed on the left wrist to confirm patency of the ulnopalmar arch using pulse oximetry.   Access was obtained to the left radial artery using a 21 gauge micro needle and ultrasound guidance. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. A wire was placed through the needle. A hydrophilic Glidesheath was advanced slowly over the wire. 3000 units of heparin, 200 mcg of nitroglycerin and 2.5 mg of verapamil was given through the arterial sheath with slow hemodilution. A side flush was started.   A 5-Fr [VENDOR] catheter was advanced over an 0.035" Bentson wire into the abdominal aorta. The catheter was used to catheterize the celiac artery, and multiple angiograms performed to delineate the hepatic arterial anatomy (this was challenging due to patient respiratory variation). The above microcatheter/microwire system was used to catheterize the distal segment 7 hepatic artery. Tumor blush was confirmed on angiography, and catheter position was confirmed in comparison to the MAA shunt study.  Once the catheter was in adequate position, a pre-determined dose of 90-Yttrium radioactive particles was infused into the target hepatic artery. The microcatheter was flushed and the microcatheter was disposed of appropriately.   All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. A TR Band was placed on the left wrist for hemos[HCW]. The access sheath was removed and no hematoma was seen. A radial artery pulse was confirmed distal to the puncture site confirming patent hemostasis.   The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications.   Additional Medications: Benadryl 50 mg IV, Decadron 8 mg IV, Zofran 4 mg IV. Radial cocktail: Heparin 3,000U IA, Nitroglycerin 200 mcg IA, Verapamil 2.5 mg IA  Procedural Personnel Attending(s): [HCW] Fellow(s): [HCW] Resident(s): None Advanced practice provider(s): None  Complications: No immediate complications.  Contrast: 75 mL Omnipaque  Fluoroscopy time: 11.3 minutes Fluoroscopy dose:  440 mGy  Conscious Sedation:  Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by nurse present during the entire procedure. Patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Administered by the specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for a total of 90 minutes (Total intra service time).  Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.  Medications: Versed 2 mg IV. Fentanyl 100 mcg IV.      Antibiotics: Rocephin, 2 g IV  Blood loss:  Less than 10 ml  Checklist:	Informed consent was obtained discussing the risks, benefits and alternatives to the planned procedure.  Pre-sedation H&P was performed and sedation consent obtained. The patient’s name, medical record number, date of birth, allergies, procedure being performed including site and pertinent laboratory values were reviewed and confirmed with the technologist, nurse and patient.  These requirements including the Time Out were met prior to initiating the procedure.  [HCW], was present for the key and critical portions of the procedure and associated imaging guidance.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Bladder cancer with right ureteral obstruction and mild right hydronephrosis.  Procedure:   1. Right antegrade pyelogram. 2. Unsuccessful right nephrostomy placement.     Findings:    1.	Extravasation outside the kidney and ureter with very debris-filled collecting system . No urine aspirated. 2. Due to uncertain positioning within the collecting system, nephrostomy tube was not placed.   Catheter(s):  None  Impression:   Due to uncertain positioning within the collecting system, nephrostomy tube was not placed.   Treatment Plan:   Will reattempt nephrostomy placement tomorrow after contrast has cleared.  Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained to the patient. Written informed consent was obtained.  A time out/call to order was performed prior to procedure initiation.  The soft tissues overlying the access site were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Ultrasound was utilized to identify an appropriate access site. Static ultrasound image was obtained and stored to PACS for reference purposes. Subsequently, under fluoroscopic and real-time concurrent ultrasound guidance, access was obtained into a posterior, inferior calyx using a 22 ga needle and the inner portion of a triaxial sheath system (Neff). Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site. A wire was advanced centrally. Contrast was noted to extravasate outside the collecting system creating an uncertain picture of the location of the sheath.  The sheath was then removed. The procedure was well tolerated, and patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Bacteremia requiring central venous access for long-term antibiotics  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled central venous catheter placement       Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the tunneled catheter, as described, the tip terminates near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:  1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a power-injectable, 5 Fr, 26 cm, tunneled non-cuffed central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.       Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care.  The catheter is ready for immediate use.        Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a peel-away sheath set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture peel-away sheath set, the wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.  Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS.   Procedural Personnel Attending(s): [HCW] Fellow(s): [HCW] Advanced practice provider(s): None  Complications: No immediate complications. Pre-sedation H&P was performed and sedation consent obtained. Debris-filled renal collecting system with no urine from nephrostomy tube 3.	No free flow of contrast into the bladder  Catheter(s):  10.2 F Cook nephrostomy tube  Impression:   1.	Ultrasound and fluroscopic-guided placement of a right nephrostomy tube as described above.  2.	No urine could be aspirated; however, lavaged with saline was performed and sent for culture with some debris.  Treatment Plan:   Patient should return for routine check and change in 8-12 weeks.   If no urine drainage is noted from the nephrostomy tube over the coming days, this suggests that the right kidney is nonfunctional from chronic kidney disease and possibly chronic obstruction. If white count does not improve, suggest consideration of a surgical options by urology. Can also consider removal of nephrostomy tube in 4-6 weeks if there is no urine output  Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained to the patient. Written informed consent was obtained.  A time out/call to order was performed prior to procedure initiation.  The soft tissues overlying the access site were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Ultrasound was utilized to identify an appropriate access site. Static ultrasound image was obtained and stored to PACS for reference purposes. Subsequently, under fluoroscopic and real-time concurrent ultrasound guidance, access was obtained into a posterior, inferior calyx using a 21 ga needle and a triaxial sheath system (Neff). Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site. A wire was advanced centrally. Serial dilation was accomplished over the wire. The wire and inner dilator were removed. Non-ionic contrast was injected into the collecting system and images of the antegrade pyelogram were obtained and stored to PACS.  An 0.035” wire was advanced through the existing access. A nephrostomy tube was advanced over the wire and the Cope loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis. Contrast injection confirmed location. The catheter was sutured to the flank with monofilament suture and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.  The procedure was well tolerated, and patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Acute myeloid leukemia  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  6 F single-lumen Bard port (standard profile)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 6 French single lumen Bard power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 3-0 absorbable sutures.     Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with     Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma  Procedure:  1. Ultrasound and Fluoroscopic guided placement of a tunneled, cuffed central venous catheter  Findings:  1. The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and normal. Vein patency and needle entry were stored to PACS. 2. The newly placed catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating in the right atrium.  Impression:   Uneventful image guided placement of right internal jugular vein tunneled Trifusion catheter as described.  Technique:  The right neck and chest region was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. The region was ultrasonographically evaluated.  Using local anesthetic and ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was punctured with a 21 gauge needle.  An image documenting vein patency and needle entry was saved and stored to PACS.   A 0.018” wire was passed centrally and the needle exchanged for a 5 French transitional dilator. A 0.035” wire was advanced through the dilator and negotiated into the IVC.  The skin tract was dilated and a 13 French dilator peel-away combination placed over the wire.  The soft tissues caudal and lateral to the sheath entry site were anesthetized with lidocaine with epinephrine. A dermatotomy was made and a tunneling tool brought from the dermatotomy to the venotomy. The catheter was brought through the tunnel.  During suspended respiration, the catheter was advanced through the peel-away and positioned centrally using fluoroscopy. The peel-away was removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression.  The venotomy was closed with Dermabond and Steri-Strips applied. A single Prolene suture was placed at the catheter tunnel exit site. An antimicrobial disc and sterile dressing were applied.  The catheter was aspirated, flushed, and heparinized per protocol. The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient was discharged in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Neuroendocrine tumor, intrahepatic metastases  Additional Clinical Information: Metastatic pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor with intrahepatic tumors  PROCEDURE:   1. US-guided left radial artery access. 2. Diagnostic visceral angiography 3. Transarterial chemoembolization  FINDINGS: ANGIOGRAPHY: Vessels catheterized and angiograms performed, as follows:  Superior mesenteric artery: No replaced or accessory hepatic arterial branches. Celiac artery: Arterial enhancing lesions in segments 4a, 4b, 6, 7, 8 Right hepatic artery: Tumoral blush identified. Segment 4 hepatic artery: Tumoral blush identified in two lesions. After chemoembolization, contrast staining within the lesions and complete stasis of flow. Segment 6 hepatic artery: Tumoral blush identified. After chemoembolization, contrast staining within the lesion and complete stasis of flow. Segment 7 hepatic artery: Tumoral blush identified. After chemoembolization, contrast staining within the lesion and complete stasis of flow. Segment 8 hepatic artery: Tumoral blush identified. After chemoembolization, contrast staining within the lesion and complete stasis of flow.  Specific technical notes / catheter selection: Jacky 5Fr, 2.4Fr Progreat, [HCW]  CBCT: No  Transcatheter embolization:  Tumor locations: segments 4a, 4b, 6, 7, 8.  Embolics delivered at 4 discrete sites within segment 4, 6, 7, and 8 hepatic arteries. Embolic 1: 13 mL of a Doxorubicin and Lipiodol mixture containing total of 43mg Doxorubicin Embolic 2: 1/2 vial 100-300 Embospheres At each site, doxorubicin/lipiodol mixture was administered first, followed by Embospheres particles.  IMPRESSION:   Successful conventional-TACE treatment of multiple intrahepatic metastatic NET lesions as above.  TREATMENT PLAN:  1. Patient will return to clinic in [DATE]ks with abdominal MRI and labs.  2. Access site precautions and orders placed.  TECHNIQUE:  With the patient in the supine position, the left wrist was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The left wrist was evaluated with ultrasound and left radial artery patency and acceptable size criteria were documented and images were properly stored in PACS. A modified Allen test (Barbeau test B) was performed on the left wrist to confirm patency of the ulnopalmar arch using pulse oximetry.   1% lidocaine solution was administered for local anesthesia. Access was obtained to the left radial artery using a 21 gauge micro needle and ultrasound guidance. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. A wire was placed through the needle. A hydrophilic Glidesheath was advanced slowly over the wire. 3000 units of heparin, 200mcg of nitroglycerin and 2.5mg of verapamil was given through the arterial sheath with slow hemodilution. A side flush was started.   A 5-Fr [VENDOR]y/Sar[VENDOR] catheter was advanced over an 0.035" wire into the abdominal aorta. The catheter was used to catheterize the visceral vessels described below. Angiograms were performed. A microcatheter system was used to catheterize distal visceral and hepatic vessels, as described below. Specific vessels catheterized and embolized are described in detail below. Tumor blush was confirmed on angiography.  Cone Beam CT (CBCT) was performed intraprocedurally for purposes of treatment planning, targeting and dose calculation. Axial and coronal images were created and 3D reconstruction was performed on a separate dedicated workstation under concurrent supervision.  All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. A TR Band was placed on the left wrist for hemostasis. The access sheath was removed and no hematoma was seen. A radial artery pulse was confirmed distal to the puncture site confirming patent hemostasis.   The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Nash cirrhosis, esophageal variceal bleeding, portal vein thrombus  Procedure:   1.	Primary TIPSS 2.	Mechanical portal venous thrombectomy 3.	Coil embolization of portosystemic varices 4.  Placement of triple lumen 14Fr non-tunneled central venous catheter   Findings:   1.	Right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses.  Needle entry was documented. 2.	Right hepatic venogram confirms vein patency. 3.	Portogram demonstrates patent portal vein with mural thrombus. 4.	Intracardiac echo ultrasound probe images demonstrate peripheral portal venous thrombus. 5.	Brisk filling of coronary vein and additional portosystemic shunt 6.	8+2cm Viatorr stent expanded to 8mm.  After TIPS creation, improved hepatopetal flow.  TIPS stent extended superiorly to reach right atrium using 10mmx59mm Viabahn stent.  Inferior end of Viatorr left at 8mm - not expanded to 10mm. 7.	After mechanical thrombectomy, improved opacification of the main portal vein with no further filling defects. 8.	After variceal embolization, no futher filling of embolized varices. 9.	The initial portosystemic gradient is 20 mmHg. 10.	Post-TIPSS portosystemic gradient is 4 mmHg. 11.	The TIPSS has a smooth course and extends from the right hepatic vein to right portal vein. 12.	There is good flow through the shunt at the conclusion of the procedure with no appreciable filling of varices. 13.	New right internal jugular approach triple-lumen catheter terminates at the superior cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful creation of TIPS from right hepatic vein to right portal vein with a 8-10 mm x 8+2 cm controlled-expansion Viatorr stent, extended with a 	10mmx59mm Viabahn stent at the superior margin. 2.	Successful portal venous thrombectomy. 3.	Successful portosystemic shunt coil embolization. 4.	The portosystemic gradient was reduced from 20 mm Hg to 4 mmHg.  Treatment Plan:   1.	Patient will be admitted to ICU for overnight monitoring 2.	Patient will be started on Lactulose/rifaximin  Technique:   Following written informed consent, the patient was placed supine on the procedure table. After induction of general anesthesia, the right neck and abdomen were prepped and draped in standard sterile fashion.   Access: The right neck was then evaluated with ultrasound. The skin overlying the right internal jugular vein was anesthetized with local, and a small dermatotomy was made.  Under ultrasound guidance a 21-gauge needle was advanced into the right internal jugular vein. A 0.018" guidewire was advanced through the micropuncture needle. The needle was exchanged for a 5 French transitional catheter. The 0.018" wire and inner dilator were removed, and a 0.035" wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava.  The transitional catheter was exchanged for a sheath. An angled catheter was placed over the wire and used to select the right hepatic vein. A right hepatic venogram was obtained.   Notes on access catheter/sheath combination: MPA/10-Fr sheath  ICE (Intra-cardiac echo) technique: A second access site was obtained in the neck using ultrasound guidance and a vascular sheath. This sheath was guided using fluoroscopy into the hepatic venous confluence and utilized to advance the ICE. Real-time echo imaging was then utilized to target an appropriate portal radical, with attention paid to avoid traversal of critical intrahepatic vessels/bile ducts and extrahepatic structures.  Pre-TIPS Pressures:  Right atrial and hepatic pressure measurements were obtained using a balloon catheter/sheath, as detailed:  Right atrial: 13 mm Hg Wedged hepatic vein:  24 mm Hg Direct portal vein: 33 mm Hg  CO2 Portography: No  TIPS: Using the Argon ScorpionX TIPS set, the right portal vein was accessed, which was confirmed with the hand-injection of contrast. A 0.035" wire was advanced into the portal vein and the TIPS sheaths were advanced over the wire into the portal vein. The inner sheath was removed and a marking pigtail catheter was advanced over the guidewire and used to measure the parenchymal tract and measure portal venous pressure. The sheath was ultimately advanced into the main portal vein, and a Viatorr stent was deployed within the TIPS shunt. The shunt was dilated throughout using a high pressure balloon. Follow-up portogram demonstrated good flow through the TIPS shunt with persistent portal vein peripheral thrombus and filling of two portosystemic collaterals. Thrombectomy was performed by advancing the Penumbra thrombectomy device through the TIPS stent over a wire into the main portal vein. 2 passes were made with the aspiration mode engaged. Venography demonstrated improvement in portal vein clot burden. The 2 two portosystemic collaterals were then accessed using a combination of angled 5 French catheter and microcatheter, and embolized using the following coils:   First collateral embolized: BALT PRESTIGE PLUS COMPLEX XTRA TREAD 12MMX65CM BALT PRESTIGE PLUS COMPLEX XTRA TREAD 12MMX65CM BALT PRESTIGE PLUS COMPLEX XTRA TREAD 12MMX45CM  Second collateral embolized: COIL RUBY COMPLEXSTD 12X60 COIL RUBY COMPLEXSTD 12X60  Post-TIPS Pressures: The pressures after shunt placement were recorded, as follows: Direct portal: 19 mm Hg Right atrial: 15 mmHg This corresponds to a portosystemic gradient of 4 mm Hg  At the end of the procedure the sheath was removed over a guidewire and a 12 French x 16 cm triple lumen catheter was placed. The catheter was flushed and heparinized per protocol. The catheter was sutured to the skin with 2-0 suture and a biodisc and sterile dressing were applied. The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no immediate complications. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  72-year-old male with history of anaplastic thyroid cancer. Dysphagia.  Procedure:   1.	Gastrostomy tube placement under fluoroscopic guidance.  Findings:   1.	The gastrostomy tube is in good position.  2.	Gentle hand injection of contrast material confirms positioning of the gastrostomy tube within the gastric lumen.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of 18 French MIC gastrostomy tube as above.  Treatment Plan:   The tube should be placed to gravity drainage and should not be used for 4 hours. 25 cc of water can be administered per hour. At 4 hours, if residuals are less than 30%, the patient can have tube feeds advanced starting at a half dose.   Technique:   Informed consent for the procedure was obtained, and time-out was performed prior to the procedure.  The skin overlying the access site was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the mid abdomen were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.   Using fluoroscopic and ultrasonographic guidance, an appropriate puncture site was identified.  3 T-fasteners were placed adjacent to the planned tube access site. Positioning of the T-fasteners within the gastric lumen was confirmed by return of air and direct injection of contrast material.  Next, under fluoroscopic guidance, an 18-gauge needle was directed into the gastric lumen. Needle positioning within the gastric lumen was confirmed with aspiration of air as well as gentle hand injection of contrast material.  A wire was advance through the 18-gauge needle.  The 18-gauge needle was removed over a wire. Serial dilation was accomplished over the stiff wire. An 18 French Halyard G-tube was advanced over a wire in an antegrade fashion and advanced through the anterior abdominal wall. All wires and catheters were removed. The bulb was inflated with 10 mL of a 10% contrast mixture. Gentle hand injection of contrast material documents the gastric feeding tube within the gastric lumen. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained for reference purposes. The tube was flushed with saline. It was affixed to the anterior abdominal wall with a rubber flange. The patient tolerated the procedure well at time of procedure completion without complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Pelvic venous disease  Procedure:    1. Right ovarian vein venography 2. Left renal vein venography 3. Left common iliac vein venography 4. Left internal iliac vein venography 5. Left internal iliac vein STS & lipiodol sclerotherapy (12mL 3:2:1 foam) 6. Left internal iliac vein plug embolization (MVP 7-9mm plug)    Findings:  1.	Prominent right ovarian vein, without reflux into cross-pelvic collaterals 2.	No reflux into gonadal vein from left renal vein. 3.	No reflux into collaterals from left common iliac vein 4.	Prominent venous collaterals/varices with cross-pelvic flow seen upon injection of left internal iliac vein, more prominent after deployment of occlusive balloon catheter. 5.	Successful filling of varices with 12mL STS/lipiodol foam 6.	Successful plug deployment within left internal iliac vein with no further reflux of contrast on final injection.   Intervention:  Left internal iliac vein STS & lipiodol sclerotherapy (12mL 3:2:1 foam), and plug embolization (MVP 7-9mm plug)   Venography: The following vessels were catheterized and diagnostic venography was performed:   Left renal vein, Right renal vein, right ovarian vein, left external iliac vein, left common iliac vein, left internal iliac vein, left internal iliac vein    IMPRESSION:  1. Prominent cross pelvic venous collaterals seen arising from the left internal iliac vein, successfully treated with 12 mL of STS/lipiodol foam and plug embolization. 2. No reflux seen upon catheterization of the left renal vein, indicating durable effect from prior left ovarian vein embolization.  Treatment Plan:  Follow up in IR   Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained.  The specific risks of bleeding, infection, pulmonary embolism, perforation, thrombosis, and need for subsequent procedures/surgery were detailed and accepted. Written informed consent was obtained. Patient was brought to the procedure suite and a time out was performed prior to procedure initiation. Patient was placed in supine position and, following sedation, the access sites were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.   The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the access site were infiltrated with lidocaine for local anesthetic.   Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed, demonstrating patency. Under continuous ultrasound guidance, with permanent recording and reporting, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle. An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018" wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire. Through the micropuncture introducer set, an 0.035" wire was advanced into the IVC under fluoroscopic guidance. A sheath was placed at the access site, as detailed. A catheter and/or sheath combination was advanced into the IVC and cavography was then performed, with findings detailed above.   Using a catheter/sheath combination, the vessels detailed above were catheterized and venography was performed. Intervention was performed as detailed above, using the devices listed above, introduced via the access sites described. Repeat venography was performed, as detailed above.   All instruments and devices were removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression at the end of the procedure. No immediate complication occurred, and the patient was discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Myelodysplastic syndrome  Procedure:  1. Ultrasound and Fluoroscopic guided placement of a tunneled, cuffed central venous catheter  Findings:  1. The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and normal. Vein patency and needle entry were stored to PACS. 2. The newly placed catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating in the right atrium.  Impression:   Uneventful image guided placement of right internal jugular vein tunneled Trifusion catheter as described.  Technique:  The right neck and chest region was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. The region was ultrasonographically evaluated.  Using local anesthetic and ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was punctured with a 21 gauge needle.  An image documenting vein patency and needle entry was saved and stored to PACS.   A 0.018” wire was passed centrally and the needle exchanged for a 5 French transitional dilator. A 0.035” wire was advanced through the dilator and negotiated into the IVC.  The skin tract was dilated and a 13 French dilator peel-away combination placed over the wire.  The soft tissues caudal and lateral to the sheath entry site were anesthetized with lidocaine with epinephrine. A dermatotomy was made and a tunneling tool brought from the dermatotomy to the venotomy. The catheter was brought through the tunnel.  During suspended respiration, the catheter was advanced through the peel-away and positioned centrally using fluoroscopy. The peel-away was removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression.  The venotomy was closed with Dermabond and Steri-Strips applied. A single Prolene suture was placed at the catheter tunnel exit site. An antimicrobial disc and sterile dressing were applied.  The catheter was aspirated, flushed, and heparinized per protocol. The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient was discharged in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Central venous stenosis, end-stage renal disease  Procedure:   1.	Removal of left internal jugular permcath over a wire 2.	Bilateral upper extremity and central venography 3.	Venoplasty of left brachiocephalic vein with 10mm, 12mm balloons and 12mm Lutonix paclitaxel-eluting balloon 4.	Completion venography after venoplasty 5.	Right internal jugular permcath placement - malpositioned 6.	Venography through malpositioned right internal jugular permcath 7.	Venography from right internal jugular and right subclavian venous acceess 8.  Placement of new left internal jugular permcath along tract of prior permcath  Findings:   1.	Complete occlusion of the left brachiocephalic vein, successfully crossed with Glidewire Advantage 2.	Successful venoplasty as above with good flow through left brachiocephalic vein after venoplasty 3.  Newly placed right internal jugular permcath is malpositioned, terminating within the right pleural space.  When this catheter is retracted over a wire, there is brisk active extravasation from near the right brachiocephalic confluence into the right pleural space, even when a 12mm balloon is inflated within the right subclavian vein at the site of extravasation.  No evidence of active extravasation while the catheter is advanced over the wire 4.  Newly placed left internal jugular permcath is adequately positioned and OK to use 5.  Moderate layering right hemothorax  Impression:  1. Successful venoplasty of left brachiocephalic occlusion, using standard noncompliant and drug-eluting balloons.  2. Malpositioned right internal jugular PermCath requiring surgical intervention. Moderate layering right hemothorax.  Treatment Plan:   1. The right internal jugular permcath is NOT SAFE TO USE.  It is only left in place to tamponade bleeding until surgical repair.  2. Right subclavian and right internal jugular sheaths left in place.  One wire left in place, within the right internal jugular sheath.  3. Left brachial venous access removed, with suture in place for hemostasis - to be removed by IR.   Technique:   The skin overlying the bilateral arm, chest, and neck access sites was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). 2% lidocaine was infiltrated at all access sites before access.  The indwelling left internal jugular PermCath was removed over a wire and a sheath was advanced over the wire in its place.  Ultrasound evaluation of the left brachial vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle. An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance. A 10 French sheath was advanced over this wire.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle. An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire. The micropuncture set was first used to perform venography through the 5 French outer cannula and then a 0.035 inch stiff Glidewire was advanced through this access, projecting over the SVC, right atrium, and hepatic veins.  Venography was performed through the left brachial and right internal jugular vein access, demonstrating complete stenosis of the left brachiocephalic vein. The left brachiocephalic vein was dilated using a 10 mm x 4 cm Conquest balloon. Post-venoplasty venography demonstrated patency without extravasation. The left brachiocephalic vein was then dilated using a 12 mm x 4 cm Conquest balloon. Venoplasty was completed by inflating a 12 mm x 40mm Lutonix drug-eluting balloon at the site of stenosis for 3 minutes.  Post-venoplasty venography demonstrated excellent result with patent left brachiocephalic vein and good flow from left brachial access to the heart.  Over the previously placed right internal jugular access wire, serial dilators, a peel-away sheath, and finally a 15.5 French by 24 cm PermCath were advanced. The dilators and catheter advanced smoothly without difficulty. However, blood could not be aspirated from either lumen of the PermCath. Gentle contrast injection through this catheter demonstrated that the catheter tip was extravascular, within the right pleural space.  An 0.035 inch wire was advanced through this PermCath to preserve access. Then, the right internal jugular and right subclavian veins were accessed.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle. An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance. A 10 French sheath was advanced over the wire.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right subclavian vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle. An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance. A 10 French sheath was advanced over the wire.  Venography performed via right internal jugular and right subclavian access demonstrated no extravasation while the catheter was left in place, however when the catheter was withdrawn over the wire, brisk extravasation into the right pleural space from the area of the right brachiocephalic vein. With a 12 mm balloon inflated within the right subclavian vein and projecting over the catheter, catheter was withdrawn over the wire and venography was repeated, which again demonstrated brisk extravasation into the right pleural space, despite this balloon.  These findings demonstrated that this problem could not be safely resolved without surgical intervention. The surgery team was called and promptly responded.   Over the wire left in place within the tract of the previous left PermCath, the sheath was removed and a new 15.5 French by 28 cm PermCath was advanced. Aspiration and flushing confirmed proper function. The lumens were locked with heparin. The catheter was secured to the body with a nonabsorbable suture and a sterile dressing was applied.  The left brachial venous access sheath was removed. A nonabsorbable suture was left to maintain hemostasis. This will need to be removed.  Right internal jugular and right subclavian venous access sheaths were left in place, in case they would be required for further diagnostic venography and/or intervention. The malpositioned right PermCath was left in place for surgical removal.  The patient was taken to the CT scanner and then the operating room. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Central venous stenosis, end-stage renal disease  Procedure:   1.	Removal of left internal jugular permcath over a wire 2.	Bilateral upper extremity and central venography 3.	Venoplasty of left brachiocephalic vein with 10mm, 12mm balloons and 12mm Lutonix paclitaxel-eluting balloon 4.	Completion venography after venoplasty 5.	Right internal jugular permcath placement - malpositioned 6.	Venography through malpositioned right internal jugular permcath 7.	Venography from right internal jugular and right subclavian venous acceess 8.  Placement of new left internal jugular permcath along tract of prior permcath  Findings:   1.	Complete occlusion of the left brachiocephalic vein, successfully crossed with Glidewire Advantage 2.	Successful venoplasty as above with good flow through left brachiocephalic vein after venoplasty 3.  Newly placed right internal jugular permcath is malpositioned, terminating within the right pleural space.  When this catheter is retracted over a wire, there is brisk active extravasation from near the right brachiocephalic confluence into the right pleural space, even when a 12mm balloon is inflated within the right subclavian vein at the site of extravasation.  No evidence of active extravasation while the catheter is advanced over the wire 4.  Newly placed left internal jugular permcath is adequately positioned and OK to use 5.  Moderate layering right hemothorax  Impression:  1. Successful venoplasty of left brachiocephalic occlusion, using standard noncompliant and drug-eluting balloons.  2. Malpositioned right internal jugular PermCath requiring surgical intervention. Moderate layering right hemothorax.  Treatment Plan:   1. The right internal jugular permcath is NOT SAFE TO USE.  It is only left in place to tamponade bleeding until surgical repair.  2. Right subclavian and right internal jugular sheaths left in place.  One wire left in place, within the right internal jugular sheath.  3. Left brachial venous access removed, with suture in place for hemostasis - to be removed by IR.   Technique:   The skin overlying the bilateral arm, chest, and neck access sites was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). 2% lidocaine was infiltrated at all access sites before access.  The indwelling left internal jugular PermCath was removed over a wire and a sheath was advanced over the wire in its place.  Ultrasound evaluation of the left brachial vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle. An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance. A 10 French sheath was advanced over this wire.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle. An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire. The micropuncture set was first used to perform venography through the 5 French outer cannula and then a 0.035 inch stiff Glidewire was advanced through this access, projecting over the SVC, right atrium, and hepatic veins.  Venography was performed through the left brachial and right internal jugular vein access, demonstrating complete stenosis of the left brachiocephalic vein. The left brachiocephalic vein was dilated using a 10 mm x 4 cm Conquest balloon. Post-venoplasty venography demonstrated patency without extravasation. The left brachiocephalic vein was then dilated using a 12 mm x 4 cm Conquest balloon. Venoplasty was completed by inflating a 12 mm x 40mm Lutonix drug-eluting balloon at the site of stenosis for 3 minutes.  Post-venoplasty venography demonstrated excellent result with patent left brachiocephalic vein and good flow from left brachial access to the heart.  Over the previously placed right internal jugular access wire, serial dilators, a peel-away sheath, and finally a 15.5 French by 24 cm PermCath were advanced. The dilators and catheter advanced smoothly without difficulty. However, blood could not be aspirated from either lumen of the PermCath. Gentle contrast injection through this catheter demonstrated that the catheter tip was extravascular, within the right pleural space.  An 0.035 inch wire was advanced through this PermCath to preserve access. Then, the right internal jugular and right subclavian veins were accessed.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle. An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance. A 10 French sheath was advanced over the wire.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right subclavian vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle. An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance. A 10 French sheath was advanced over the wire.  Venography performed via right internal jugular and right subclavian access demonstrated no extravasation while the catheter was left in place, however when the catheter was withdrawn over the wire, brisk extravasation into the right pleural space from the area of the right brachiocephalic vein. With a 12 mm balloon inflated within the right subclavian vein and projecting over the catheter, catheter was withdrawn over the wire and venography was repeated, which again demonstrated brisk extravasation into the right pleural space, despite this balloon.  These findings demonstrated that this problem could not be safely resolved without surgical intervention. The surgery team was called and promptly responded.   Over the wire left in place within the tract of the previous left PermCath, the sheath was removed and a new 15.5 French by 28 cm PermCath was advanced. Aspiration and flushing confirmed proper function. The lumens were locked with heparin. The catheter was secured to the body with a nonabsorbable suture and a sterile dressing was applied.  The left brachial venous access sheath was removed. A nonabsorbable suture was left to maintain hemostasis. This will need to be removed.  Right internal jugular and right subclavian venous access sheaths were left in place, in case they would be required for further diagnostic venography and/or intervention. The malpositioned right PermCath was left in place for surgical removal.  The patient was taken to the CT scanner and then the operating room. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Leaking biliary catheter  Procedure:   1.	Right internal/external biliary drain replacement  Findings:   1.	Existing catheter sideholes slightly retracted and not well position within the right-sided bile ducts. 2.	Newly placed biliary drain is appropriately positioned with the distal tip in the third portion of the duodenum and the proximal side hole in a peripheral bile duct.  Impression:   1.	Uneventful image guided replacement of the biliary catheter as described.  Treatment Plan:   Cap to internal drainage. Routine exchange in 2-3 months.  Technique:   The existing catheter and surrounding soft tissues were prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site.  An 0.035" Amplatz wire was negotiated through the catheter into the small bowel. The catheter was removed    .  The new 10.2 French internal/external biliary drain with extended sideholes was placed over the wire. Contrast was injected to confirm tube position. The catheter was secured to the skin with 2-0 Ethilon. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Head/neck cancer with upcoming radiation treatment and dysphasia.  Procedure:   1.	Gastrostomy tube placement under fluoroscopic guidance.  Findings:   1.	The gastrostomy tube is in good position.  2.	Gentle hand injection of contrast material confirms positioning of the gastrostomy tube within the gastric lumen.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of 18 French MIC gastrostomy tube as above.  Treatment Plan:   The tube should be placed to gravity drainage and should not be used for 2 hours. Patient will be examined and saline injected into catheter prior to discharge.   Technique:   Informed consent for the procedure was obtained, and time-out was performed prior to the procedure.  The skin overlying the access site was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the mid abdomen were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.   Using fluoroscopic and ultrasonographic guidance, an appropriate puncture site was identified.  3 T-fasteners were placed adjacent to the planned tube access site. Positioning of the T-fasteners within the gastric lumen was confirmed by return of air and direct injection of contrast material.  Next, under fluoroscopic guidance, an 18-gauge needle was directed into the gastric lumen. Needle positioning within the gastric lumen was confirmed with aspiration of air as well as gentle hand injection of contrast material.  A wire was advance through the 18-gauge needle.  The 18-gauge needle was removed over a wire. Serial dilation was accomplished over the stiff wire. An 18 French Halyard G-tube was advanced over a wire in an antegrade fashion and advanced through the anterior abdominal wall. All wires and catheters were removed. The bulb was inflated with 10 mL of a 10% contrast mixture. Gentle hand injection of contrast material documents the gastric feeding tube within the gastric lumen. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained for reference purposes. The tube was flushed with saline. It was affixed to the anterior abdominal wall with a rubber flange. The patient tolerated the procedure well at time of procedure completion without complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Pancreatic cancer with occluded endoscopic stent, jailed by a duodenal stent precluding ERCP. Abdominal pain and fevers with biliary obstruction.   PROCEDURES: 1. Percutaneous Transhepatic Cholangiogram 2. Internal/External Biliary Drainage Catheter Placement 3. Percutaneous removal of occluded endoscopic common bile duct stent  FINDINGS:  A CT scan from [DATE] was reviewed  1. The scout radiograph shows a duodenal stent and a common bile duct stent. There are changes of dish in the lumbar spine. Contrast is present in the colon from recent CT scan. 2. Cholangiography shows   moderate dilation of the central bile ducts with an occluded endoscopic stent extending up into a central bile duct. 3. The left and right biliary ducts communicate. 4. A peripheral right bile duct was successfully punctured. An internal/external biliary drain could not be advanced beyond the endoscopic stent. 5. The occluded stent was successfully snared and removed through the parenchymal tract. 6. A 12 French internal/external biliary drain with extended sideholes has its cope loop in the duodenum (adjacent to the duodenal stent) with its side holes extending into the accessed right biliary duct.  IMPRESSION:  1. Moderate dilation of the central intrahepatic bile ducts with nondilated peripheral ducts and an occluded endoscopic stent extending to the duodenum. 2. Successful percutaneous retrieval of the occluded stent with placement of a 12 French internal/external biliary drain.   TREATMENT PLAN:  The catheter should remain to gravity drainage. It will be capped as the bilirubin trends down.  Routine catheter exchange in 8 weeks. A viable stent could be placed at that time.   PROCEDURE:  Ultrasonographic evaluation was carried out. There is no significant intrahepatic biliary ductal dilation. The anterior abdominal wall and right flank were prepped and draped in standard sterile fashion.  An appropriate skin entry site was identified using fluoroscopy and ultrasound, and anesthetized with local.  Under fluoroscopic guidance, a 22G Chiba needle was advanced into the liver and PTC performed in standard fashion.  A  bile duct was entered and the biliary system was opacified with contrast.  Cholangiographic images were obtained.  A suitable duct for drain placement was identified on the right. Under direct fluoroscopic guidance, a posterior right duct was accessed with a second 21-gauge AccuStick needle.  A 0.018" wire was passed centrally, and the needle exchanged for a 6 French transitional catheter.  The inner stiffener, dilator, and guidewire were removed and contrast was injected to confirm location.  A 0.035" glidewire and 4 French catheter were negotiated across the distal common bile duct obstruction into the small bowel. The glidewire was removed and contrast was injected to confirm location.  A 0.035" Amplatz wire was placed through the catheter. A 12 French internal-external biliary drain was placed over the wire. It could not be advanced beyond the CBD, meeting obstruction near the mid portion of the occluded endoscopic stent. A long 7 French sheath was placed. A safety wire was advanced into the duodenum. The 7 French sheath was removed over both wires and replaced over the Glidewire.  A 15 mm ensnare was placed through the 7 French sheath and used to engage the upper portion of the stent. The stent and 7 French sheath were removed together at the flank, leaving the Amplatz wire in place as a safety measure.  The 12 French internal-external biliary drain was then easily advanced over the wire into the duodenum. The Cope loop was formed and locked in the duodenum. The side holes were positioned above the level of obstruction. Contrast was injected to confirm location. The catheter was secured to the skin with 2-0 Ethilon and attached to gravity drainage.  A sterile dressing was applied.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite still asleep into the care of anesthesiology for transfer to the PACU. Procedure:   1.	Jejunostomy tube replacement  Findings:   1.	The existing tube is appropriately positioned within a jejunal loop   2. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESR[HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Patient with pancreatic cancer requiring IV chemotherapy  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen Bard port (standard profile)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen Bard power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Refer to anesthesia notes for sedation.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 3-0 absorbable sutures. A running 4-0 absorbable subcuticular stitch and  Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with     Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Chronic pelvic pain, bilateral leg swelling (left greater than right)  PROCEDURE:   1.	Ultrasound guided right internal jugular venous access 2.	Left renal venography and intravascular ultrasound evaluation 3.	Left iliofemoral venography and intravascular ultrasound evaluation 4.	Right iliofemoral venography and intravascular ultrasound evaluation 5.	Right iliofemoral thrombectomy and intravascular ultrasound evaluation 6.	Ultrasound guided right greater saphenous venous access  FINDINGS:  1. The left renal vein is normal in appearance. No significant reflux was visualized into the left gonadal vein. 2. The left common iliac, external iliac, and common femoral veins are unremarkable.  No collateral vessels were visualized. 3. There is long segment, smooth narrowing of the right common iliac and external iliac veins, with associated collateral flow and non-occlusive subacute-chronic clot.  The clot was successfully removed using a ClotTriever thrombectomy device.  IMPRESSION:   1. Successful left renal and bilateral iliofemoral venography/IVUS with pertinent findings as above. 2. Successful right iliofemoral thrombectomy.  Follow up IVUS demonstrated no significant residual thrombus.  TREATMENT PLAN:  1. Patient will return to clinic in 4 weeks with follow up CTV to assess for any recurrent/residual thrombus.  2. Patient will be started on low-dose Eliquis for DVT prophylaxis/prevention of recurrent DVT.  Should patient redevelop DVT in the right iliofemoral system, recommend stent placement at the right common iliac vein.   3. Patient and family were advised on importance of adequate hydration and daily exercise.  TECHNIQUE:  With the patient in the supine position, the right neck was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The right neck was punctured using a 21 gauge needle, and access was upsized in standard fashion using a transitional microdilator. A 0.035 Amplatz wire was advanced into the IVC and a 10 Fr, 40 cm sheath was placed.  A 5 Fr MPA catheter was used to select the left renal vein.  Venography was performed with findings as above.  Next, we turned our attention towards evaluation of the right common iliac and femoral veins.  The catheter and wire were advanced into the right common femoral vein.  The catheter was exchanged for a flush pigtail catheter and venography was performed with findings as above.  Next, IVUS was performed confirming nonocclusive thrombus throughout the right common iliac and external iliac veins.    We then turned our attention towards evaluation of the left common iliac and femoral veins.  The IVUS catheter was exchanged for an MPA catheter and the left common femoral vein was catheterized.  The catheter was exchange for a flush catheter and venography performed with findings as above.  Next, IVUS was performed demonstrating smooth long segment narrowing of the common iliac and external iliac veins, likely related to functional dehydration.  Given the presence of clinical (leg swelling) symptoms and iliofemoral thrombus, the decision was made to proceed with a right iliofemoral thrombectomy and heparinize the patient.  The patient was heparinized with target ACT of 230-250.  Due to concern of possible pulmonary emboli, decision was also made to proceed from a right lower extremity venous access.  The right groin and thigh were then prepped and draped in standard fashion.  Using ultrasound guidance, the right GSV was punctured using a 21 gauge needle and access upsized to an 0.035 system in standard fashion.  The access was sequentially dilated and a Inari ClotTriever sheath was then advanced.  The ClotTriever thrombectomy device was then inserted and two passes were made with successful removal of the right iliofemoral clot burden in its entirety.  This was confirmed with post-thrombectomy IVUS. Follow up venography was performed also confirming resolution of the previously visualized clot burden and non-filling of any collateral vessels.  No further intervention was warranted.  All sheath(s), catheters, and wires were removed.  The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. Timeout identifying the correct patient, procedure, site, allergies was performed and observed by the operating team. The patient was positioned supine. The patient was transferred to recovery in stable condition and eventually discharged. Please also refer to the Procedure note placed in the patient's EPIC chart on the date of the procedure.
