Image-guided placement of a 14 French,  30 cm, non-tunneled large bore central venous catheter via the right common femoral vein. 2.	Right lower inferior vena cava with parallel alternative vein, likely collateral, following paravertebral and vena cava pathway with tortuous branches, evidenced on injection. 3.	Final sutured position of the 30 cm catheter had exposed external length of 7 cm. Minimal to no flow while catheter, so pulled back to this position.  Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care. The catheter is ready for immediate use. Minimize anticoagulation as patient had evidence of small extravasation into a tiny portion of psoas muscle, images saved on chart. Extravasation likely from amplatz wire being manipulated in the collateral vessel. Monitor closely for pain, blood loss, catheter function changes. Catheter to be removed shortly after pheresis completed. No longer recommend any lines placed femorally.   Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.   The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right common femoral vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic. Ultrasound evaluation of the vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS. Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS.  A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, a 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance. This wire was met with lots of resistance, so contrast injected from introducer set showing some collateral vessels and variable areas of stenosis within the inferior vena cava. Decision to proceed with placement of catheter and slow wire progression. Repeated additional contrast injection to reassess more superiorly in the vena cava. Noted tiny extravasation to right psoas muscle along the vessel at site on contrast injection.  The venotomy tract was dilated to allow introduction of the catheter over the wire. The catheter was subsequently introduced over the wire and the wire removed. The catheter was pulled back out of venotomy about 6-7 cm for the purpose of having good blood flow to tolerate pheresis today at low-flow rates.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS.  Procedural Personnel Attending(s): [HCW] Fellow(s): none Resident(s): none Advanced practice provider(s): [HCW]  Complications: difficulty passing wire up IVC, injection confirmed possibly in a collateral vessel, paravertebral vein or stenotic region of inferior vena cava. Venous flow in catheter remained steady, so catheter remained in place, sutured for use for single-day procedure today. [HCW] aware of findings and recommended close monitoring of patient's hemodynamics, symptoms in abdomen/pelvis, any pain, or change in catheter function while hemapheresis running. Given small psoas extravasation, notified pheresis team of findings and if possible to lower anticoagulants/citrate/heparin during treatment today.Update: Patient remains with no symptoms post-recovery and in pheresis unit. [HCW] NP personally evaluated catheter and patient at bedside. Patient tolerated pheresis today without complication. Real-time US images through the right upper quadrant demonstrate appropriate percutaneous drainage.  Impression:   Technically successful US-guided drainage of right upper quadrant fluid collection.  Treatment Plan:   1. Flush drain with 20 cc saline q8h as inpatient and 10 cc saline q24h as outpatient. 2. When drainage falls to below 10 cc/day (excluding flushes) for three consecutive days, please obtain repeat cross-sectional imaging and/or contact IR for possible removal.  Technique:  Target: right upper quadrant fluid collection Imaging: US+fluoro Drain: 10 Fr APD/Mermaid Drainage: 55 mL purulent fluid aspirated during procedure Microbiology: Sample sent  A superficial skin entry site was selected based on available imaging and the overlying skin entry site was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier to target the above collection. The skin surface was anesthetized with 1-2% lidocaine. Using continuous real-time grayscale and/or color doppler ultrasound guidance, a needle was introduced into the target site and imaging guidance confirmed adequate positioning. The access device was utilized with an 0.035" wire to introduce the drainage catheter listed above following any necessary serial dilatation. Ultrasound images confirmed appropriate positioning within the target structure. The catheter was secured to the skin surface using nonabsorbable suture material and dressed in typical fashion. Any samples not sent to laboratory for analysis were discarded. The patient tolerated the procedure and was sent to the recovery area for monitoring. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Biliary ductal obstruction  Procedure:   1.	Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram 2.	Brush biopsies of the common hepatic duct stricture 3.	Placement of percutaneous transhepatic internal/external biliary drain   Findings:   1.	Occlusion of the common hepatic duct extending to the confluence of the right and left hepatic ducts. 2.	Communication of the right and left hepatic ducts and the biliary catheter noted.  Impression:   1.	Technically successful percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography and drainage catheter placement. 2.	Brush biopsy of the common hepatic duct stricture.  Plan:  Keep to gravity bag drainage. Trend bilirubin and will cap in the coming days.  Pending diagnosis and treatment planning, can consider stenting, although this would likely require right and left-sided stents given the location of mass.  Technique:   The anterior abdominal wall and bilateral flanks were prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier.  An appropriate skin entry site was identified using fluoroscopy and ultrasound, and anesthetized with local.  Under fluoroscopic guidance, a 22G Chiba needle was advanced into the liver.  A bile right peripheral duct was entered and the biliary system was opacified with contrast. Cholangiographic images were obtained.  A 0.018" wire was passed centrally, and the needle exchanged for a 5 French nonvascular access catheter. The inner stiffener, dilator, and 0.018" wire were removed and contrast was injected to confirm location.  A 0.035" glidewire and 4 French angled catheter were negotiated into the small bowel. The glidewire was removed and contrast was injected to confirm location. A 0.035" Amplatz wire was placed through the catheter, and the catheter subsequently removed.   A 7 French 25 cm long sheath was advanced into the common bile duct past the stricture. 3 brush biopsies of the common hepatic duct stricture were performed and placed in CytoLyt. The sheath was then removed.  Drain placement: Finally, an 8.5 French extended-sidehole internal-external biliary drain was placed over the wire. The anchor/loop was formed and locked. Attention was paid that side holes were positioned within the biliary system. Contrast was injected to confirm location. The catheter was secured to the skin with 2-0 suture material and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.  Contrast was injected through the existing biliary drainage catheter and cholangiographic images obtained.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Metastatic rectal cancer with central hepatic metastatic disease and isolated ducts. The patient received 4 units FFP for an INR of 2.0.   PROCEDURES: 1. Ultrasound guided access of a right anterior bile duct 2. Percutaneous Transhepatic Cholangiogram 3. Right Internal/External Biliary Drainage Catheter Placement from a segment VI bile duct 4. Tract embolization from the initial access used for opacification 5. Ultrasound-guided access of the segment III bile duct 6. Placement of an 8 French external biliary drain into the left bile ducts  FINDINGS:  A CT scan from [DATE] and an MRI from [DATE] were reviewed  1. Cholangiography shows  severe central ductal dilation with a high-grade obstruction at the hilum. The left and right biliary ducts are isolated. 2. The 12 French internal/external biliary drainage catheter has its cope loop in the duodenum and sideholes extending into the right biliary tree. 3. The initially accessed duct did not fill the right-sided biliary tree to the extent of the duct subsequently accessed for biliary drain placement. 4. The left-sided bile ducts are extremely dilated. A peripheral segment III duct was ultrasonographically dilated and needle entry images stored to PACS. 5. The central obstruction could not be traversed on the left and the external biliary drain has its cope loop in a left sided bile ducts centrally, just peripheral to the obstruction. 6. The cystic duct fills. The common bile duct is normal.  IMPRESSION:  1. High-grade hilar obstruction due to metastatic disease with isolated left and right biliary systems.. 2. Successful placement of 12 French internal/external biliary drain via a peripheral right duct. 3. An external biliary drain was placed on the left as the central obstruction could not be traversed.  TREATMENT PLAN:  1. The catheters should remain to gravity drainage. The right internal/external biliary drain can be capped as the bilirubin trends down. 2. The subxiphoid drain is external. An attempt at internalization can be made in 5-7 days. 3. Repeat CT is recommended after several days of drainage to ascertain the degree of hepatic drainage  achieved.   PROCEDURE:  Ultrasonographic evaluation was carried out. The anterior abdominal wall and right flank were prepped and draped in standard sterile fashion. Under direct ultrasound guidance, an anterior, relatively peripheral duct was punctured with a 21-gauge micropuncture needle. A 0.018 inch wire was passed centrally and the needle exchanged for a transitional dilator. Cholangiography was performed. Cholangiography suggested drainage would be improved with access to be slightly more cephalad bile duct. A long 6 French sheath was placed in the accessed duct and attention redirected to a second right-sided access.  A 21-gauge AccuStick needle was used to access a segment VI bile duct. A 6 French transitional dilator was placed. A 4 French catheter and Glidewire were used to negotiate into the duodenum. An Amplatz wire was placed.  Attention was redirected to the left. Under ultrasound guidance and with a 21-gauge micropuncture needle, a segment III bile duct was accessed. A 0.018 inch wire was placed, meeting resistance near the hilum. The needle was exchanged for a transitional dilator. Attempts were made at traversing the high-grade central obstruction with a 4 French angled catheter and Glidewire. The decision was made to place an external biliary drain. A short Amplatz wire was placed and the transitional dilator replaced with an 8 French locking pigtail catheter. The cope loop was formed and locked centrally and the catheter injected to confirm location. It was sutured in place and attached to gravity drainage. A Percu-Stay device was placed for improved security.  The segment VI access on the right was used to place a 12 French internal/external biliary drainage catheter with extended sideholes. The cope loop was formed and locked in the duodenum and the sideholes extended into the peripheral right duct.  The long 6 French sheath in the more anterior ducts was withdrawn to just outside the duct. A Gelfoam plug was deployed to plug the tract.  The catheter was secured to the skin with 2-0 Ethilon and attached to gravity drainage.  A sterile dressing was applied.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition into the care of anesthesiology for transfer to the PACU.. DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: Previous pipeline embolization with adjuvant coiling of a giant left ICA aneurysm by our colleague [HCW] at the [HOSPITAL].  PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 40 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] was the fellow. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right vertebral artery Left internal carotid artery Right common carotid artery  ANESTHESIA: Local in the right groin with bupivacaine. Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by the nurse present during the entire procedure. The patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Sedation was administered by a specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for a total of 40minutes (Total intra service time).  Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.  MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine SQ 10 cc  Versed 1 mg IV Fentanyl 50 mcg IV Heparin 3000 units IA 200 mcg nitroglycerin IA 2.5 mg verapamil IA Protamine 20 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.038" Bentson guidewire 5 French Terumo slender radial sheath 5 French Simmons 2 Glide catheter  TR band Omnipaque-300 contrast material (80 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right radial artery; a 5 French sheath was introduced into the right radial artery. Standard radial cocktail was administered intra-arterially following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP, Lateral and Oblique views.    Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a TR band.  COMPARISON: Axial imagi[HCW] (the angiograms we obtained from the [HOSPITAL] were incomplete).  FINDINGS: RIGHT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified  LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: Coils are seen within. To be a giant superior hypophyseal artery origin aneurysm. A pipeline embolization device is noted spanning from the supraclinoid carotid into the cavernous segment. The aneurysm no longer fills. The device is well endothelialized. No additional aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified.       RIGHT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. Reflux of contrast into the  left vertebral artery was achieved. The origin of PICA is normal bilaterally.   COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: Status post coil and pipeline embolization of a giant left superior hypophyseal artery aneurysm. This was done in [DATE] [HOSPITAL]. This now constitute the patient's two-year follow-up. No residual filling of the aneurysm is seen.  No new aneurysms are identified.  Time resolved MRA in 5 years to assess for 2 no focal aneurysms.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Malignant neoplasm of the left breast  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  6 F single-lumen Bard port (standard profile)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 6 French single lumen Bard power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 3-0 absorbable sutures.     Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with     Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Cervical cancer. Urinary diversion complicated by ureteral anastomotic stricture. Additionally, patient complaining of malaise, decreased urine output, cloudy urine. Over due for routine exchange.  Procedure:   1.	Left nephrostogram and nephrostomy tube replacement  Comparison: Previous exam [DATE]  Findings:    1.	Existing nephrostomy tube in appropriate position on scout radiograph. 2.	Nephrostography demonstrates no significant hydronephrosis. However there is no drainage into the urinary bladder, with similar appearance of UPJ obstruction is seen on prior studies. 3.	Ultimately successful over-the-wire exchange for a new left PCN.   Catheter:  8.5 F Cook nephrostomy tube  Impression:   1.	Uneventful image-guided nephrostomy tube re-placement.  Treatment Plan:   1. Follow-up urine culture results.  2. Patient should return for routine check and change in 6-8 weeks.  Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained to the patient. Written informed consent was obtained. A time out/call to order was performed prior to procedure initiation.  The existing catheter and surrounding soft tissues were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). A scout radiograph was obtained.  5 cc of cloudy urine was aspirated from the tube, and set aside for laboratory analysis.   Non-ionic contrast was injected through the existing nephrostomy tube and images of the collecting system obtained and stored to PACS, as detailed above.  Initially a 0.035 inch Bentson wire was advanced through the nephrostomy tube, however could not be advanced through the end hole. This was then again attempted with an Amplatz wire and a regular Glidewire, all unsuccessful. Given the maturity of the tract, the decision was made to abandon the access as no wire could be passed through the tube.   A 5 French Kumpe catheter was then easily navigated back through the existing tract into the collecting system. This was confirmed with contrast injection. The 0.035 inch Amplatz wire was then advanced through the Kumpe catheter. The catheter was removed over the wire, and the new 8.5 French nephrostomy tube was placed over the wire. The cope loop was formed and locked in the renal pelvis, with contrast injection confirming appropriate location.  The catheter was sutured to the flank with monofilament suture and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.  The procedure was well tolerated, and patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory cond[HCW]. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Head and neck cancer with need for gastrostomy tube  Procedure:   1.	Gastrostomy tube placement under fluoroscopic guidance.  Findings:   1.	The gastrostomy tube is in good position.  2.	Gentle hand injection of contrast material confirms positioning of the gastrostomy tube within the gastric lumen.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of 18 French MIC gastrostomy tube as above.  Treatment Plan:   The tube should be placed to gravity drainage and should not be used for 4 hours. 25 cc of water can be administered per hour. At 4 hours, if residuals are less than 30%, the patient can have tube feeds advanced starting at a half dose.   Technique:   Informed consent for the procedure was obtained, and time-out was performed prior to the procedure.  The skin overlying the access site was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the mid abdomen were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.   Using fluoroscopic and ultrasonographic guidance, an appropriate puncture site was identified.  3 T-fasteners were placed adjacent to the planned tube access site. Positioning of the T-fasteners within the gastric lumen was confirmed by return of air and direct injection of contrast material.  Next, under fluoroscopic guidance, an 18-gauge needle was directed into the gastric lumen. Needle positioning within the gastric lumen was confirmed with aspiration of air as well as gentle hand injection of contrast material.  A wire was advance through the 18-gauge needle.  The 18-gauge needle was removed over a wire. Serial dilation was accomplished over the stiff wire. An 18 French Halyard G-tube was advanced over a wire in an antegrade fashion and advanced through the anterior abdominal wall. All wires and catheters were removed. The bulb was inflated with 10 mL of a 10% contrast mixture. Gentle hand injection of contrast material documents the gastric feeding tube within the gastric lumen. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained for reference purposes. The tube was flushed with saline. It was affixed to the anterior abdominal wall with a rubber flange. The patient tolerated the procedure well at time of procedure completion without complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Multiple myeloma; need for stem cell therapy  Procedure:   1.	Non-tunneled large bore central venous catheter placement  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the large bore central venous catheter, as described, the tip terminates near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a 14 French,  20 cm, non-tunneled large bore central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.  Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care. The catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. Local anesthesia was used for this procedure   The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic. Ultrasound evaluation of the vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS. Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS.  A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter. DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: This is a 52 years Female with past medical history of Graves' disease, hypertension, who is found upon workup for periorbital swelling to have a right ICA aneurysm, who presents for diagnostic cerebral angiography to better evaluate the aneurysm.   PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 45 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] was the fellow. [HCW] was the resident. Both the attending and fellow participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right internal carotid artery Left internal carotid artery  ANESTHESIA: Local in the right groin with bupivacaine. Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by the nurse present during the entire procedure. The patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Sedation was administered by a specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for the duration of the procedure as outlined above (Total intra service time, 45 minutes). Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.  MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine SQ 10 cc  Versed 1 mg IV Fentanyl 50 mcg IV Heparin 3000 units IV Protamine 20 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.038" Bentson guidewire 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 5 French Merit Performa Vertebral catheter Visipaque-270 contrast material (60 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 5 French sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP, Lateral and Oblique views.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY:  Rotational angiography was also performed from the diagnostic catheter in the right internal carotid artery for better delineation of the underlying angioarchitecture. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.    Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a 5 French Vascade closure device  followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: None.  FINDINGS: RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is a medially directed paraophthalmic artery aneurysm, better described on the 3-D angiogram below. There is a posterior communicating artery infundibulum.   LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. There is mild irregularity of the cervical internal carotid artery, which may represent fibromuscular dysplasia versus vasospasm. The A1 segment is absent.  3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: 3D Rotational angiography with volume-rendered three-dimensional reconstruction on an independent workstation, demonstrated a 5.7 x 4.2 x 3.6 x 3.8 mm (transverse, transverse, dome to neck, neck) medially directed paraophthalmic artery aneurysm. There is also evidence of a 2.5 x 2.3 x 2.6 x 3.0 mm anterior choroidal artery aneurysm.  COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: 1. There is a 5.7 x 4.2 x 3.6 x 3.8 mm (transverse, transverse, dome to neck, neck) medially directed right paraophthalmic artery aneurysm  2. There is a 2.5 x 2.3 x 2.6 x 3.0 mm right anterior choroidal artery aneurysm.  Plan to obtain a left vertebral artery angiogram during follow-up angiogram while under anesthesia and with use of a long sheath.  [HCW], was present for the key and critical portions of the procedure and associated imaging guidance.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  symptoms of SVC syndrome ensued following [DATE] placement of right chest port in patient with a large right lung mass, with encasement of right pulmonary veins  Procedure:   1.	Superior vena cavogram 2.	Superior vena caval stent placement   Findings:   -in place, right chest port with its distal tip at the superior cavoatrial junction.  Note is made of endoluminal thrombosis adjacent and superior to the endovenous entry site -increased density in a wavy geographic distribution, medial right upper lung, is known to represent this patient's intra-thoracic neoplasm and atelectasis  -on initial venography: complete occlusion of the origin of the superior vena cava (SVC), at the confluence of the brachiocephalic veins.  Non-occlusive thrombosis is present at the very central aspect of the left brachiocephalic vein (LBCV) -post angioplasty: newly established, albeit irregular lumen of the mid SVC, albeit with mild superior extension of thrombotic disease  -on intravascular ultrasound (IVUS), minimal and maximal luminal diameter of the infra-stenotic, supra-atrial SVC: 11.4 and 17.6 mm, respectively  -stent deployed across the SVC, spanning from the inferior tip of the right brachiocephalic vein (RBCV) to the inferior aspect of the SVC, with excellent internal stent flow -post stent placement: complete mechanical thrombotic occlusion of the very central aspect of the LBCV -post mechanical thrombectomy: wide patency of the central LBCV, with excellent flow into the stent and SVC  -port catheter repositioned back to its normal intended through-the-stent position, with the distal catheter tip left at the superior cavoatrial junction.     Impression:   1.	non-occlusive thrombosis, RIJV, superior and adjacent to the venous entry of the right chest wall port catheter, with its distal tip at the superior cavoatrial jucntion 2.	thrombotic occlusion of the confluence of both brachiocephalic veins 3.	catheter/wire access gained across the occluded SVC 4.	angioplasty of the SVC allowing for temporary change in the course and distal port catheter tip, within the RIJV (to allow stent placement) 5.	SVC stenting, with brisk flow to the RA 6.	focal, thrombotic occlusion of the central LBCV, with successful treatment via mechanical thrombectomy, with resultant wide patency and brisk flow across the newly deployed stent and SVC   Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   With the patient in the supine position, sterile technique and sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance were used to gain 21-needle access to the right (RIJV) and left (LIJV) internal jugular and common femoral (RCFV) veins using a 21-g needle.  Exchange was made over an 0.018-in Cope wire for a 5-Fr. introducer set.  This afforded exchange over an 0.035-in Rosen wire for an 9-Fr. x 26-cm introducer sheath via the LIJV; 8-Fr. sheath, RIJV; 9- then 10-Fr. long sheath via the RCFV.    RIJV Via the newly placed sheath, contrast examination was carried out.  A 5-Fr. angled catheter, over an 0.035-in glide wire, was then advanced to the point of thrombotic obstruction, immediately inferior to the confluence of the brachiocephalic veins.  The catheter-wire was made to probe this point, with successful passage into the SVC, then advancement into the right atrium (RA), then the inferior vena cava (IVC).    The RCFV sheath was then advanced to the superior aspect of the IVC, with an internal 20-mm snare wire.  This was used to catch and secure the wire from the RIJV access, an 0.035-in 260-cm Amplatz wire, with its distal tip externalized and with an accessible length outside of the patient.    Over the Amplatz wire, a 12-mm balloon catheter was advanced and used to dilate the SVC stenosis.  This was followed by repeat contrast evaluation.   Exchange was then made over the wire for an 8-Fr. IVUS ([VENDOR]) catheter.  This was used to interrogate the SVC, with identification of endoluminal thrombotic disease; superior and inferior extent of disease; minimal and maximal luminal diameters.   LIJV Via the sheath, a 5-Fr. angled catheter, over an 0.035-in glide wire, was advanced to the RA where, exchange was made over the Rosen wire for the 20-mm snare wire.  This was retracted, securing the inferior tip of the port catheter.  Both were retracted, with the distal tip of the catheter left in the lateral left brachiocephalic vein (LBCV).  Repeat contrast injection via the RIJV sheath shows some superior extension of the thrombotic disease, post SVC angioplasty, encompassing the BCV confluence.  This prompted the reposition of the distal port catheter tip from the LBCV to the inferior RIJV, using the snare wire via the RIJV approach.    RCFV Exchange was then made over the indwelling Amplatz wire for a Venovo 20-mm x 6-cm stent, deployed across the SVC, spanning from the inferior tip of the RBCV to the inferior aspect of the SVC.  The stent was then dilated to 18-mm using a balloon catheter.  This was followed by contrast examination.    Over the Amplatz wire, exchange was made from the indwelling LIJV sheath to a 12-Fr. size x 40-cm sheath, with the distal tip advanced to the peri-central LBCV.  Through the sheath, a 5-Fr. angled catheter was advanced, over an 0.035-in glide wire, through the stent, and into the IVC, where exchange was made for an 0.035-in Amplatz wire.  Over this, a 12-Fr. Penumbra CAT-12 device was advanced, with the distal tip left adjacent to the newly deployed SVC stent.  The device was used for mechanical thrombectomy, with two passes made across the very short distance of thrombotic disease, yielding a small number of thrombotic clumps.  The device was then removed, with subsequent contrast examination performed.    With the port catheter having remained secured to the snare wire, both were then advanced inferiorly, into the newly deployed stent, with the distal catheter tip left at the superior cavoatrial junction.    Upon completion, all access devices were removed and manual compression was applied to effect hemostasis.    The patient tolerated the procedure well. This was promptly detected, with a 7-Fr. introducer sheath advanced into the CFA, re-directed using a 5-Fr. angled catheter over an 0.035-in glide wire.  This afforded the deployment of an extra-luminal arterial closure (Vascade) device, with manual compression applied to effect hemostasis.  This was followed by close observation during the entirety of the procedure (above)  Contrast: 40 mL Omnipaque  Fluoroscopy time: 27.5 minutes Fluoroscopy dose:  584 mGy  Conscious Sedation:  Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma; bone marrow failure; MDS  Procedure:  1. Ultrasound and Fluoroscopic guided placement of a tunneled, cuffed central venous catheter  Findings:  1. The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and normal. Vein patency and needle entry were stored to PACS. 2. The newly placed catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating in the right atrium.  Impression:   Uneventful image guided placement of right internal jugular vein tunneled Trifusion catheter as described.  Technique:  The right neck and chest region was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. The region was ultrasonographically evaluated.  Using local anesthetic and ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was punctured with a 21 gauge needle.  An image documenting vein patency and needle entry was saved and stored to PACS.   A 0.018” wire was passed centrally and the needle exchanged for a 5 French transitional dilator. A 0.035” wire was advanced through the dilator and negotiated into the IVC.  The skin tract was dilated and a 13 French dilator peel-away combination placed over the wire.  The soft tissues caudal and lateral to the sheath entry site were anesthetized with lidocaine with epinephrine. A dermatotomy was made and a tunneling tool brought from the dermatotomy to the venotomy. The catheter was brought through the tunnel.  During suspended respiration, the catheter was advanced through the peel-away and positioned centrally using fluoroscopy. The peel-away was removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression.  The venotomy was closed with Dermabond and Steri-Strips applied. A single Prolene suture was placed at the catheter tunnel exit site. An antimicrobial disc and sterile dressing were applied.  The catheter was aspirated, flushed, and heparinized per protocol. The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient was discharged in satisfactory condition. Patient's Name: [PATIENT] MRN: [ID] Procedure date: [DATE] 2:35 PM  IR TUNNELED LARGE BORE CVC  Indications: Acute on chronic kidney disease.  Request is made for conversion of the nontunneled to tunneled dialysis catheter. The patient presents with an indwelling recently placed right  internal jugular vein nontunneled catheter without complications at the entry site.   Procedure: After explaining the technique, risks, benefits, alternatives, and answering all questions, informed consent was obtained from the patient. Timeout identifying the correct patient, procedure, site, allergies was performed and observed by the operating team. The patient was positioned supine. The procedure is performed under continuous physiologic monitoring. The patient received intravenous conscious sedation using Versed 1 mg and fentanyl 50 mcg.  The right   side of the lower neck and upper chest including the indwelling 13  F Trialysis  catheter was prepped with Betadine  and draped in a steri[HCW]. No evidence of inflammation/infection at the entry site of the catheter is noted.   Following administration of local anesthesia using lidocaine 2% with epinephrine  10  ml at the right   side of the root of the neck extending to the right  infraclavicular region, 0.035" guidewire was advanced through the existing catheter under fluoroscopy into the SVC. Through skin stab incision in the right  infraclavicular region, a 16 F x 23 cm dialysis catheter [tip to cuff] was tunneled exiting at the root of the neck  at the exit of the nontunneled catheter. A peel-away sheath was advanced under fluoroscopy over the guidewire under fluoroscopy following intact removal of the nontunneled catheter [13 F x 15  cm]. Following removal of the guidewire and inner dilator, the catheter was advanced into the SVC and buried in the subcutaneous tissues following peeling of the sheath. Hemostasis was secured. The catheter tip was adjusted at the level of the SVC/upper right atrium. Both ports demonstrated easy aspiration and injection and were flushed with hep saline per protocol. The incision at the root of the neck was closed with a subcutaneous Vicryl 3/0 inverted stitch followed by Steri-Strips. The catheter was anchored to the skin using Ethilon 2/0 interrupted skin stitches. Sterile occlusive dressing was applied at the exit of the catheter in infraclavicular region. The patient tolerated to the procedure well. There were no intraprocedural complications. The patient was transferred to recovery in stable condition and eventually to the floor. The catheter is ready to use. Please also refer to the Procedure note placed in the patient's EPIC chart on the date of the procedure.  Fluoroscopy time: 00:39.4 min.  Device implanted: Ref. #[ID], LOT. #[ID].    Recommendations: The patient will need routine catheter check and possible exchange every 3 months.  Fellows: None. Residents: None.  IMPRESSION: 1. Uneventful image guided right   internal jugular  vein tunneled dialysis catheter placement following removal of the nontunneled catheter. The catheter is ready to use.  Voice recognition is used in generating this report.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Achalasia, gastrostomy tube placement requested  Procedure:   1.	Gastrostomy tube placement under fluoroscopic guidance.  Findings:   1.	The gastrostomy tube is in good position.  2.	Gentle hand injection of contrast material confirms positioning of the gastrostomy tube within the gastric lumen.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of 18 French MIC gastrostomy tube as above.  Treatment Plan:   The tube should be placed to gravity drainage and should not be used for 24 hours. 25 cc of water can be administered per hour. At 4 hours, if residuals are less than 30%, the patient can have tube feeds advanced starting at a half dose.  Technique:   Informed consent for the procedure was obtained, and time-out was performed prior to the procedure. A nasogastric tube was placed in the stomach and utilized to insufflated the stomach with air after administration of 1 mg glucagon IV. The skin overlying the access site was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the mid abdomen were infiltrated with 1% lidocaine for local anesthetic.   Using fluoroscopic and ultrasonographic guidance, an appropriate puncture site was identified.  3 T-fasteners were placed adjacent to the planned tube access site. Positioning of the T-fasteners within the gastric lumen was confirmed by return of air and direct injection of contrast material.  Next, under fluoroscopic guidance, an 18-gauge needle was directed into the gastric lumen. Needle positioning within the gastric lumen was confirmed with aspiration of air as well as gentle hand injection of contrast material.  A wire was advance through the 18-gauge needle.  The 18-gauge needle was removed over a wire. Serial dilation was accomplished over the stiff wire. An 18 French Halyard G-tube was advanced over a wire in an antegrade fashion and advanced through the anterior abdominal wall. All wires and catheters were removed. The bulb was inflated with 10 mL of a 10% contrast mixture. Gentle hand injection of contrast material documents the gastric feeding tube within the gastric lumen. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained for reference purposes. The tube was flushed with saline. It was affixed to the anterior abdominal wall with a rubber flange. The nasogastric tube was removed. The patient tolerated the procedure well at time of procedure completion without complication.  Procedural Personnel Attending(s): [HCW]  Complications: No immediate complications. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Multiple myeloma  Procedure:   1.	Non-tunneled large bore central venous catheter placement  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the large bore central venous catheter, as described, the tip terminates near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a 14 French,  20 cm, non-tunneled large bore central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.  Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care. The catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Local anesthesia was used for this procedure   The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic. Ultrasound evaluation of the vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS. Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS.  A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, a 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   The venotomy tract was dilated to allow introduction of the catheter over the wire. The catheter was subsequently introduced over the wire and the wire removed. The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: Follow up subarachnoid hemorrhage.  PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 30 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] was the fellow. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right internal carotid artery Left common carotid artery and Left vertebral artery  ANESTHESIA: Local in the right groin with bupivacaine. Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by the nurse present during the entire procedure. The patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Sedation was administered by a specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for a total of 30 minutes (Total intra service time).  Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.  MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine SQ 10 cc  Heparin 4000 units IV Protamine 20 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.035" Bentson guidewire 5 French Boston Scientific sheath 5 French Cordis Vertebral catheter  5 French Simmons 3 glide catheter Mynx Closure Device Visipaque-270 contrast material (60 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 5 French sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 4000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP, Lateral and Oblique views.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY:  Rotational angiography was also performed from the diagnostic catheter in the R ICA for better delineation of the underlying angioarchitecture. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.    3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE LEFT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY:  Rotational angiography was also performed from the diagnostic catheter in the L ICA for better delineation of the underlying angioarchitecture. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.    3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY:  Rotational angiography was also performed from the diagnostic catheter in the L vertebral artery for better delineation of the underlying angioarchitecture. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.    Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a Mynx closure device followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: Cerebral angiogram [DATE].  FINDINGS: RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No definite aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified.  There is a small outpouching at the site of the posterior communicating artery, which does not meet strict infundibulum criteria as it is not exactly pyramidal shaped. This is better seen on the 3-D angiogram below.  LEFT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified.   LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. Reflux of contrast into the  contralateral vertebral artery was achieved. The origin of PICA is normal bilaterally.   LEFT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CERVICAL: There is a critical stenosis at the origin of the external carotid artery. There is an irregular calcified plaque at the origin of the left internal carotid artery resulting in approximately 75% carotid artery stenosis by NASCET criteria. The distal common carotid artery and cervical internal carotid artery are normal in caliber.  3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: 3D Rotational angiography with volume-rendered three-dimensional reconstruction on an independent workstation, demonstrated a small outpouching at the origin of the posterior communicating artery which does not meet strict infundibulum criteria due to its shape.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY: 3D Rotational angiography with volume-rendered three-dimensional reconstruction on an independent workstation, demonstrated no definite aneurysms.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE LEFT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY: 3D Rotational angiography with volume-rendered three-dimensional reconstruction on an independent workstation, demonstrated no definite aneurysms.   COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: 1. No evidence of aneurysms or other vascular malformations that would explain patient's previous subarachnoid hemorrhage was identified on this angiogram. 2. Approximately 75% stenosis of the proximal left internal carotid artery, stable from prior. 3. Small outpouching at the site of the origin of the right posterior communicating artery, which may represent an infundibulum, though this does not meet strict infundibulum criteria based on shape. Attention on follow-up imaging. 4. Critical stenosis of the left external carotid artery origin. 5. Bovine-type arch requiring the use of a reverse curve catheter to catheterize the left common carotid artery. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]C.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Persistent leakage around left internal/external biliary drain  Procedure:   1.	Pullback sheath cholangiogram through existing percutaneous access 2.	Left internal/external biliary drain replacement 3.	Embolization of a subselective segment 2 bile duct where bile leak into biloma is present 4.	ASpiration of biloma drain.  Findings:   1.	US evaluation of the left hepatic lobe demonstrates decreased heterogenous echogenic fluid collection consistent with resolving biloma.  2.	Cholangiogram though existing 10.2 F internal-external biliary drain demonstrates existing catheter with radiopaque marker migrated peripherally.  3.	Cholangiogram demonstrates persistent bile from segment 2 duct draining into biloma fistula.  4. Following embolization, cholangiogram demonstrates adequate casting of the area of leak with no new contrast flow into the biloma. 5. New internal/external 10.2 F biliary drain with extended sideholes in appropriate position with radiopaque marker in optimal position. 6. Aspiration of biloma drain yielded <5cc thick bilious material.   Impression:   1.	Successful embolization of the branch of segment 2 biliary duct. Following embolization, no new leakage seen. 2.	Uneventful image guided replacement of the biliary catheter as described. Prior biliary catheter was noted to have migrated peripherally (radiopaque marker slightly peripheral). New catheter in optimal position.  Treatment Plan:   1. Patient to return in 8-12 weeks for exchange of internal/exchange biliary catheter if no changes or issues are present. 2. Know percutaneous cholecystostomy drain to remain in position for at least 6 weeks since placement to allow for tract maturation.  3. Biloma drain to remain in place to ensure comprehensive drainage now in the setting of sealing of area of leak.  Technique:   The existing catheter and surrounding soft tissues were prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site. Contrast was injected into the existing biliary catheter.  An 0.035" wire was negotiated through the catheter into the small bowel. The catheter was removed and exchanged for a 9 French sheath. Via a 4F Kumpe, the 0.035" wire was exchanged for an 0.035" Rosen wire, used as a buddy/safety wire in the small bowel. The Kumpe was removed and then placed in parallel to the existing wire. The Kumpe and a Glidewire Advantage were negotiated into the segment 2 biliary duct. A glidewire was then carefully advanced across the area of bile leak/fistula. The Kumpe was advanced and the wire was removed. A 130cm 2.4 Progreat microcatheter and 0.014" Runthrough wire were advanced into the duct peripheral to the area of bile leak/fistula. The wire was removed. A discussion was held regarding embolic/sealant options. Given the configuration of the area of leak, a decision was made to use thick liquid embolic (due to concern for coil prolapse into the biloma cavity). Given the concern for adhesion to the microcatheter and need for a thick, study liquid embolic, a decision was made to use a cohesive embolic. 0.5 ml Obsidio Comformable Embolic (a shear-thinning embolic) was used and carefully injected to ensure sufficient scaffolding both peripheral and central to the area of bile leak/fistula. The microcatheter was removed. Cholangiogram confirmed successful exclusion of the leak. The catheter was then removed.  The sheath was removed and a new 10.2 French internal/external biliary drain with extended sideholes was placed over the wire. Contrast was injected to confirm tube position. The catheter was secured to the skin with 2-0 Prolene. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]C.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  History of EtOH cirrhosis, ascites, hepatic hydrothorax, variceal hemorrhage, chronic PVT, and HE as well as chronic pancreatitis and pancreatic insufficiency, presenting for TIPS creation.  Procedure:   1.	Primary TIPSS 2.	Triple lumen central venous catheter placement with ultrasound and fluoroscopic guidance  Findings:   1.	Right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. Needle entry was documented. 2.	Right hepatic venogram confirms vein patency. 3.	ICE imaging demonstrates known extensive cavernous transformation of the portal vein. 4.	Portogram demonstrates patent right, left and main portal vein with cavernous transformation at the portal confluence, presence of gastroesophageal varices. 5.	The initial portosystemic gradient is 14 mmHg. 6.	Post-TIPSS portosystemic gradient is 4 mmHg. 7.	The TIPSS has a smooth course and extends from the right hepatic vein to right portal vein. 8.	There is good flow through the shunt at the conclusion of the procedure and decreased opacification of gastroesophageal varices. 9.	New right internal jugular approach triple-lumen catheter terminates at the superior cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful creation of TIPS from right hepatic vein to right portal vein with a 8-10 mm x 8 cm x 2 cm controlled-expansion Viatorr stent (ballooned to 8 mm).  2.	The portosystemic gradient was reduced from 14 mm Hg to 4 mmHg.  Treatment Plan:   1.	Patient will be admitted to ICU for overnight monitoring  Technique:   Following written informed consent, the patient was placed supine on the procedure table. After induction of general anesthesia, the right neck and abdomen were prepped and draped in standard sterile fashion.   Access: The right neck was then evaluated with ultrasound. The skin overlying the right internal jugular vein was anesthetized with local, and a small dermatotomy was made.  Under ultrasound guidance a 21-gauge needle was advanced into the right internal jugular vein. A 0.018" guidewire was advanced through the micropuncture needle. The needle was exchanged for a 5 French transitional catheter. The 0.018" wire and inner dilator were removed, and a 0.035" wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava.  The transitional catheter was exchanged for a sheath. An angled catheter was placed over the wire and used to select the right hepatic vein. A right hepatic venogram was obtained.   Notes on access catheter/sheath combination: Glidewire Advantage, MPA beacon, 10-Fr sheath  ICE (Intra-cardiac echo) technique: A second access site was obtained in the neck using ultrasound guidance and a vascular sheath. This sheath was guided using fluoroscopy into the hepatic venous confluence and utilized to advance the ICE. Real-time echo imaging was then utilized to target an appropriate portal radical, with attention paid to avoid traversal of critical intrahepatic vessels/bile ducts and extrahepatic structures.  Pre-TIPS Pressures:  Right atrial and hepatic pressure measurements were obtained using a balloon catheter/sheath, as detailed:  Free hepatic vein: 13 mm Hg Right atrial: 9 mm Hg  CO2 Portography: No  TIPS: Using the Argon ScorpionX TIPS set, the right portal vein was accessed, which was confirmed with the hand-injection of contrast. A 0.035" Rosen wire was advanced into the portal vein and the TIPS sheaths were advanced over the wire into the portal vein. The inner sheath was removed and a marking pigtail catheter was advanced over the guidewire and used to measure the parenchymal tract and measure portal venous pressure. The sheath was ultimately advanced into the main portal vein, and a Viatorr stent was deployed within the TIPS shunt. The shunt was dilated throughout using an 8 mm high pressure balloon. Follow-up portogram demonstrated good flow through the TIPS shunt. Direct portal vein pressure: 23 mm Hg Pre-TIPSS portosystemic gradient: 14 mm Hg  Post-TIPS Pressures: The pressures after shunt placement were recorded, as follows: Direct portal: 20 mm Hg Right atrial: 16 mmHg This corresponds to a portosystemic gradient of 4 mm Hg  At the end of the procedure the sheath was removed over a guidewire and a 12 French x 16 cm triple lumen catheter was placed. The catheter was flushed and heparinized per protocol. The catheter was sutured to the skin with 2-0 suture and a biodisc and sterile dressing were applied. The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no immediate complications. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Cavernous sinus mass, dysphagia  Procedure:   1.	Gastrostomy tube placement under fluoroscopic guidance.  Findings:   1.	Preprocedural scout imaging after gastric insufflation demonstrates adequate percutaneous window to the stomach.  2.	Gentle hand injection of contrast material confirms positioning of the gastrostomy tube within the gastric lumen. The gastrostomy tube is in good position.   Impression:   1.	Successful placement of 18 French MIC gastrostomy tube as above.  Treatment Plan:   The tube should be placed to gravity drainage and should not be used for 4 hours.   20 cc of water can be administered per hour. At 4 hours, if residuals are less than 30%, the patient can have tube feeds advanced starting at a half dose.  Technique:   The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the mid abdomen were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.   Using fluoroscopic and ultrasonographic guidance, an appropriate puncture site was identified.  3 T-fasteners were placed adjacent to the planned tube access site. Positioning of the T-fasteners within the gastric lumen was confirmed by return of air and direct injection of contrast material.  Next, under fluoroscopic guidance, an 18-gauge needle was directed into the gastric lumen. Needle positioning within the gastric lumen was confirmed with aspiration of air as well as gentle hand injection of contrast material.  A wire was advance through the 18-gauge needle.  The 18-gauge needle was removed over a wire.   An 8 mm x 4 cm Conquest balloon was loaded coaxially through An 18 French Halyard G-tube and advanced over a wire into the gastric lumen with the trailing edge of the balloon outside the skin entry site. The balloon was inflated along the skin tract until waisting of the balloon was no longer seen and the entire system was advanced under fluoroscopic guidance into the stomach. All wires and catheters were removed. The balloon was inflated with 10 mL of  10% contrast mixture. Gentle hand injection of contrast material documents the gastric feeding tube within the gastric lumen. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained for reference purposes. The tube was flushed with saline. It was affixed to the anterior abdominal wall with a rubber flange. The patient tolerated the procedure well at time of procedure completion without complication. Prior attempts at internalization unsuccessful (to cross the UPJ junction)  Procedure:   1.	Left nephrostogram(s) and nephrostomy tube replacement  Comparison: Previous exam [DATE]  Findings:    1.	Existing nephrostomy tube(s) in appropriate position on scout radiograph.Redemonstration of post embolization coils in the left kidney. 2. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL][ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  increasingly symptomatic right foot venous malformation.  Note is made of a total of 24 remote past sclerotherapy treatments at the Children's [HOSPITAL]  Procedure:   1. Right lower extremity angiography 2. Sclerotherapy of right foot venous malformation    Findings:   -normal appearance: right superficial femoral, popliteal, peroneal, and anterior (ATA) and posterior tibial arteries -some normal variants: no supra-ankle bifurcation of the distal peroneal artery.  Its distal aspect takes an anterior course, with fine branches terminating  along the lateral hindfoot.  The peri-ankle ATA takes a middle, instead of an anterior course, with no apparent dorsalis pedis artery -no apparent arterial contribution to any vascular malformation.  There is a singular tortuous transverse quaternary branch of the ATA with mild abnormality.  (Expected) Regions of hyperemia are along the calcaneus, medial aspect of the first MTP joint, and mid foot  -enlarged right foot, with visualized occasional prominent cutaneous veins -Ultrasound demonstrates occasional sites of subcutaneous heterogeneity, at times with numerous small abnormal venous channels  -contrast injection of multiple access channels demonstrates venous malformation anatomy -sclerotherapy treatment of multiple sites: 3rd toe, mostly lateral aspect; medial of the mid to the forefoot      Impression:   1. no apparent arterial contribution to the predominantly venous malformation of the foot 2. variant arterial anatomy, right foot 3. sites of venous malformation, treated with foam sclerotherapy: right 3rd toe and medial mid to forefoot  4. note is made of no apparent arterial or venous cause of the blue-ish discoloration of the 1st toe, on ultrasound and angiography   Treatment Plan:  1. Patient will follow up in IR clinic.  Technique:   With the patient in the supine position, sterile technique and sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance were used to gain 21-g needle access to the right common femoral artery (RCFA).  Over an 0.018-in Cope wire, advanced to the superficial femoral artery, exchange was made for a 4-Fr. micropuncture set, secured by a Tegaderm adhesive.  This was used for contrast examination of the right lower extremity, from the upper thigh through to the foot.   Upon completion, the dilator was removed, with manual compression applied to effect hemostasis after which a sterile dressing was applied.  Correlation was made with the right foot MRI examination.   Two tourniquets were applied at the peri-ankle and lower third of the right calf.  Sterile technique and sonographic guidance were then used to access multiple abnormal appearing sites that patient reported were most painful: 3rd toe; medial aspect of the right mid to forefoot, using short 25-g angiocath needles.  [HCW]d return would be sought from each access, followed by gentle contrast injection.  If/when venous malformation disease is venographically confirmed, the contrast volume injected is used to direct a similar aliquot of Sotradecol (STS) foam (1:2:3, lipiodol:Sotradecol:air) sclerosant was injected at each site. The needle would be withdrawn, with a new needle employed for each new site.   Upon completion, all access sites were dressed with sterile gauze and compressive dressing.   The patient tolerated the procedure well   Procedural Personnel Attending(s): [HCW] Fellow(s): [HCW] Resident(s): [HCW]    Advanced practice provider(s): None  Complications: No immediate complications. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Malignant neoplasm of the left breast  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen Bard port (standard profile)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen Bard power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 2-0 absorbable sutures. A running 4-0 absorbable subcuticular stitch and  Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with a single subcuticular stitch and Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] [HOSPITAL][ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Trace right pleural effusion with clinical suspicion for malignancy.  Complications: No immediate complications.  Procedure: After explaining the technique, risks, benefits, alternatives, and' questions, informed consent was obtained from the patient. Timeout identifying the correct patient, procedure, site and allergies was performed and observed by the operating team. The patient was positioned sitting and initial ultrasound evaluation revealed trace  right  pleural effusion. A spot was chosen on the right   chest posterolaterally with the largest pocket. The upper back on the right  was prepped with Betadine/chlorhexidine and draped in sterile fashion.  Under ultrasound guidance and following administration of local anesthesia using lidocaine 1%  with epinephrine 7 mL, a 5F Yueh needle cannula  was advanced into the right pleural cavity as evidenced by pleural fluid. Following removal of the inner stylet, manual and gradual aspiration to completion  of 250 mL of mildly turbid straw-colored fluid was obtained. Samples of the fluid were submitted to the lab as requested.  At the end of the procedure, the cannula was removed and hemostasis was secured. Sterile occlusive dressing was applied. The procedure was well tolerated. There were no intraprocedural complications. Post procedure CXR did not reveal any significant pneumothorax. The patient was eventually discharged  in stable condition. Please also refer to the Procedure note placed in the patient's EPIC chart on the date of the procedure.  IMPRESSION: Uneventful diagnostic and therapeutic right-sided thoracentesis.  Voice recognition is used in generating this report.

Embolization: No Vessel embolized: N/a Coils used: N/a  MAA delivery performed from: Right hepatic artery, left  hepatic artery, segement III/IV Future target Y90 delivery catheter position(s): right hepatic artery, segment III/IV and seg II/III  (Series 5 Treatment device: SIRTEX Split-Dose: Yes Dosimetry Model: Partition dosed to the right lobe/segment. Desired tumoral (if partition) dose: 150) Gy Additional details: LEFT lobe split dose 70/30 followed by RIGHT lobe split dose 50/50. See se 5  and 6  IMPRESSION:   Successful Yttrium-90 SIR-Spheres selective internal radiotherapy mapping.  TREATMENT PLAN:  1. Patient will return in 2-4 weeks for Y90 radioembolization of the left lobe, followed by the right lobe 4 weeks later.  2. Access site precautions and orders placed.  TECHNIQUE:  With the patient in the supine position, the left wrist was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The left wrist was evaluated with ultrasound and left radial artery patency and acceptable size criteria were documented and images were properly stored in PACS. A modified Allen test (Barbeau test Type A) was performed on the left wrist to confirm patency of the ulnopalmar arch using pulse oximetry.   1% lidocaine solution was administered for local anesthesia. Access was obtained to the left radial artery using a 21 gauge micro needle and ultrasound guidance. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. A wire was placed through the needle. A hydrophilic Glidesheath was advanced slowly over the wire. 3000 units of heparin, 200 mcg of nitroglycerin and 2.5 mg of verapamil was given through the arterial sheath with slow hemodilution. A side flush was started.   A 5-Fr [VENDOR]y/Sar[VENDOR] catheter was advanced over an 0.035" wire into the abdominal aorta. The catheter was used to catheterize the visceral vessels described below. Angiograms were performed. A microcatheter system was used to catheterize distal visceral and hepatic vessels, as described below. Specific vessels catheterized and embolized are described in detail below. Tumor blush was confirmed on angiography.  Cone Beam CT (CBCT) was performed intraprocedurally for purposes of treatment planning, targeting and dose calculation. Axial and coronal images were created and 3D reconstruction was performed on a separate dedicated workstation under concurrent supervision.  After confirmation of target treatment vessel, 5 mCi of Tc-99 MAA was injected slowly in this location though the catheter.   All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. A TR Band was placed on the left wrist for hemostasis. The access sheath was removed and no hematoma was seen. A radial artery pulse was confirmed distal to the puncture site confirming patent hemostasis.   The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. The patient was transferred to the Nuclear Medicine department for imaging.
