Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  56 y.o. woman with stage IV platinum refractory ovarian cancer who presented to clinic [DATE] to transfer care, found to have uncontrolled pain and nausea, admitted for management of partial SBO and further treatment planning. IR consulted for peritoneal pleurX and venting G tube placement   Procedure:   - US-guided and fluoroscopy placement of tunneled peritoneal drainage catheter. - Aborted percutaneous gastrostomy tube placement  Findings:   1. Real-time US and fluoroscopic images demonstrate adequate placement of peritoneal drain throughout the lower pneumoperitoneum.  2. Unable to insufflate stomach, after administration of clinical attempt to occlude the gastroesophageal junction with a balloon.  Impression:   - Technically successful US-guided and fluoroscopy guided tunneled peritoneal catheter. - Aborted percutaneous gastrostomy tube placement.  Treatment Plan:  - Drain care. - Recommend Consult either GI or surgery for gastrostomy tube placement.  1 Technique:   A superficial skin entry site was selected based on available imaging and the overlying skin entry site was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier to target the above collection. The skin surface was anesthetized with 1-2% lidocaine. Using continuous real-time grayscale and/or color doppler ultrasound guidance, a needle was introduced into the fluid-filled peritoneal space and imaging guidance confirmed adequate positioning. The access device was utilized with an 0.035" wire peel-away sheath. Subsequently a tract along the abdomen was anesthetized with 1-2% lidocaine, and a subcutaneous tract created up to the access site, subsequently a Pleurx drain was advanced through the tunnel and into the peel-away sheath, a peel-away sheath was removed. The incision was sutured with absorbable Vicryl and the drain sutured in place with monofilament sutures.   Attempt was made to inspect the stomach for a percutaneous gastrostomy tube however the stomach was unable to hold air even after administration of glucagon and advancing a 6 French Fogarty balloon up to the gastroesophageal in attempt to prevent air from escaping however all attempts were unsuccessful and the procedure was aborted. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]C.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  67 y.o. male with  history of hep C cirrhosis, and HCC since [DATE], which also biopsy proven cholangiocarcinoma (mixed disease). Underwent Y 90 of the segment 8 lesion in [DATE], and had complete treatment response. Developed a new LR M lesion in segment IV earlier this year, with subsequent Y90 in [DATE]. Since on systemic therapy. Most recent MRI with viable disease in segment 5&6.   Additional Clinical Information: Cholangiocarcinoma carcinoma with intrahepatic tumors  PROCEDURE:   1. Attempted ultrasound-guided right radial arterial access. 2. US-guided left femoral artery access. 2. Diagnostic visceral angiography 3. Selective internal radioembolization with Yttrium-90 4. Left common femoral artery angiogram and closure Cone-beam CT performed for intraprocedural localization, as detailed below.  FINDINGS: ANGIOGRAPHY: Vessels catheterized and angiograms performed, as follows:  Celiac artery: Tumoral blush identified. Right hepatic artery: Tumoral blush identified. Segment 6 hepatic artery: Tumoral blush identified. Segment 5 hepatic artery: Tumoral blush identified.   Specific technical notes / catheter selection: SIM. Trinav and truselect. Fathom   CBCT: Yes Catheter location: Right hepatic artery Findings: Tumoral blush identified with supply from the target vessel.  Transcatheter embolization using Yttrium-90 microspheres performed from:  - Right hepatic segment 6 artery (series 16 image 7) - Right hepatic segment 5 artery (series 27 image 12)  IMPRESSION:   Successful Yttrium-90 SIRSpheres selective internal radiotherapy of a segment 5 and 6 cholangiocarcinoma carcinoma. Delivery of seg5 dose not completed due to stasis.   TREATMENT PLAN:  1. Patient will return to clinic in 6-8 weeks with abdominal MRI and labs.  2. Access site precautions and orders placed.  TECHNIQUE:  With the patient in the supine position, the right groin was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The patient was placed on the table in a supine position. Following standard prepping and draping, ultrasound evaluation of the right artery was performed which demonstrated occluded radial artery with reconstitution at the distal segment of the renal artery, unsuccessful attempt to access the right renal artery, the decision was made to access the left common femoral artery. The left common femoral artery was punctured using a needle, and an .035 Bentson wire was advanced into the aorta. A 5-French vascular sheath was placed over the wire into the common femoral artery. A side flush was started.  A 5-Fr catheter was advanced over an 0.035" wire into the abdominal aorta. The catheter was used to catheterize the visceral vessels described below. Angiograms were performed. A microcatheter system was used to catheterize distal visceral and hepatic vessels, as described below. Specific vessels catheterized and embolized are described in detail below. Tumor blush was confirmed on angiography.  Cone Beam CT (CBCT) was performed intraprocedurally for purposes of treatment planning, targeting and dose calculation. Axial and coronal images were created and 3D reconstruction was performed on a separate dedicated workstation under concurrent supervision.  Once the catheter was in adequate position, a pre-determined dose of 90-Yttrium radioactive particles was infused into the target hepatic artery. The microcatheter was flushed and the microcatheter was disposed of appropriately.   A left common femoral artery angiogram was performed, demonstrating appropriate vascular access above the profunda femoris artery bifurcation. All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. Hemostasis was achieved using Angio-Seal vascular closure device. The site was dressed in usual fashion.  The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications.   Additional Medications: Benadryl 50 mg IV, Decadron 8 mg IV, Zofran 4 mg IV   Procedural Personnel Attending(s): [HCW] Fellow(s): [HCW] Resident(s): None Advanced practice provider(s): None  Complications: No immediate complications. Patient's Name: [PATIENT]  MRN: [ID] Procedure date: [DATE] 2:15 PM  IR CENTRAL PORT  Indications: The patient has a history of Hodgkin's lymphoma and is planned to start IV chemotherapy.  Request is made for an infusion port placement.  Procedure: After explaining the technique, risks, benefits, alternatives, and answering all questions, informed consent was obtained from the patient. Timeout identifying the correct patient, procedure, site, allergies was performed and observed by the operating team. The patient was positioned supine with the head turned to the left. The procedure is performed under continuous physiologic monitoring. The patient received intravenous conscious sedation using Versed 2 mg and fentanyl 100 mcg.  Also the patient received Ancef 2 g IV.  The right  side of the lower neck and upper chest was prepped with chlorhexidine followed by Betadine  and draped in a sterile fashion.  Following administration of local anesthesia using lidocaine 1% with epinephrine 6 ml at the right  side of the root of the neck, under ultrasound  guidance, access was obtained into the right  internal jugular vein using a micropuncture device. A 0.018" guidewire was advanced under fluoroscopy into the vein centrally. Further administration of local anesthesia using lidocaine 1% with epinephrine 9 mL into the right  infraclavicular region. A transverse 3.5  cm incision was performed and a pocket created inferior to the incision to accommodate the port using both sharp and blunt dissection. Through the infraclavicular incision, the port tubing 8  F was tunneled exiting at the root of the neck following a nick incision at the exit of the guidewire. The guidewire was upgraded to 0.035" guidewire that was advanced under fluoroscopy through the SVC into the IVC. A peel-away sheath was advanced over the guidewire. Following removal of the guidewire and the stiffener, the port tubing was advanced after trimming to a length of 22 cm. The sheath was peeled away and the line was buried in the subcutaneous tissues. The tip of the line is at the SVC/upper right atrium. The port was tested demonstrating easy aspiration and injection and was flushed with normal saline followed by hep saline as per protocol. The port was anchored in the subcutaneous tissues using nonabsorbable 3/0 interrupted stitches. The wound was irrigated. Hemostasis secured. The incision at the root of the neck was closed using Vicryl 2/0 inverted subcutaneous stitch and Dermabond. The infraclavicular incision was closed using subcutaneous followed by subcuticular Vicryl 3/0 continuous stitches. Steri-Strips were applied followed by Sterile occlusive dressing. The patient tolerated to the procedure well. There were no intraprocedural complications. The patient was transferred to recovery in stable condition and eventually discharged. The port is ready to use. Please also refer to the Procedure note placed in the patient's EPIC chart on the date of the procedure.  Fluoroscopy time: 00:13.4 min.  Device implanted: 8F single lumen power port, Ref. #[ID], Lot. [ID].  Fellows: None. Residents: None.  IMPRESSION: 1. Uneventful ultrasound fluoroscopy guided placement of 8  F Power  infusion port in the right  internal jugular vein. The port is ready to use.  Voice recognition is used in generating this report.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Neoplasm at base of tongue  Procedure:   1.	Gastrostomy tube replacement under fluoroscopic guidance.  Findings:   1.	The existing tube is appropriately positioned   2.	The new tube is appropriately positioned within in the stomach.  Impression:   1.	Successful replacement of 18 French MIC gastrostomy tube.      Treatment Plan:   It is OK to use the tube immediately.  Routine check and change recommended in 6 months.  Technique:   Informed consent for the procedure was obtained, and time-out was performed prior to the procedure.  The skin overlying the access site was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). The skin and subcutaneous tissue around the existing tube were infiltrated with local anesthetic. A scout image was obtained of the abdomen.  A wire was cannulated into the existing tube and passed into the gastric lumen. The pre-existing G-tube was removed over the wire after deflating the bulb. A new gastrostomy tube was advanced over the wire. The replacement tube overlies the stomach on static fluoroscopic image saved to PACS.  The balloon was inflated with 10 mL of a 10% contrast mixture. Gentle hand injection of contrast material documents the gastric feeding tube within the gastric lumen. Procedure:   1.	Left nephrostogram and nephrostomy tube placement 2.	Right nephrostogram and nephrostomy tube placement      Findings:    1.	Left nephrostogram: Moderate hydronephrosis.  2. Right nephrostogram: Moderate hydronephrosis. 3. Target urine from left nephrostomy tube which was sent for culture.  Catheter(s):  10 F Skater nephrostomy tube  Impression:   1.	Uneventful ultrasound and fluroscopic-guided placement of bilateral nephrostomy tubes as described above.      Treatment Plan:   Patient should return for routine check and change in 10-12 weeks.        Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained to the patient. Written informed consent was obtained.  A time out/call to order was performed prior to procedure initiation.  LEFT: The soft tissues overlying the access site were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Ultrasound was utilized to identify an appropriate access site. Static ultrasound image was obtained and stored to PACS for reference purposes. Subsequently, under fluoroscopic and real-time concurrent ultrasound guidance, access was obtained into a posterior, inferior calyx using a 21 ga needle and a triaxial sheath system ([VENDOR]). Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site. A wire was advanced centrally. Serial dilation was accomplished over the wire. The wire and inner dilator were removed. Non-ionic contrast was injected into the collecting system and images of the antegrade pyelogram were obtained and stored to PACS.  An 0.035” wire was advanced through the existing access. A nephrostomy tube was advanced over the wire and the Cope loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis. Contrast injection confirmed location. The catheter was sutured to the flank with monofilament suture and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.   RIGHT: The soft tissues overlying the access site were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Ultrasound was utilized to identify an appropriate access site. Static ultrasound image was obtained and stored to PACS for reference purposes. Subsequently, under fluoroscopic and real-time concurrent ultrasound guidance, access was obtained into a posterior, inferior calyx using a 21 ga needle and a triaxial sheath system ([VENDOR]). Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site. A wire was advanced centrally. Serial dilation was accomplished over the wire. The wire and inner dilator were removed. Non-ionic contrast was injected into the collecting system and images of the antegrade pyelogram were obtained and stored to PACS.  An 0.035” wire was advanced through the existing access. A nephrostomy tube was advanced over the wire and the Cope loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis. Contrast injection confirmed location. The catheter was sutured to the flank with monofilament suture and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.   The procedure was well tolerated, and patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient's Name: [PATIENT]  MRN: [ID] [DATE] 6:41 PM   IR NEPHROSTOMY DRAIN  Indications: Left moderate to severe hydronephrosis with recent history of pelvic neoplasia.  Request is made for percutaneous nephrostomy tube placement.  Procedure: After explaining the technique, risks, benefits, alternatives, and answering all questions, informed consent was obtained from the patient. Timeout identifying the correct patient, procedure, site, allergies was performed and observed by the operating team. The patient was positioned side. The procedure is performed under continuous physiologic monitoring. The patient received intravenous analgesia using fentanyl 100 mcg given in divided doses.  Also the patient received Ancef 2 g IV.  Initial ultrasound evaluation revealed visualization of the left kidney with moderate to severe hydronephrosis. The left  loin was prepped with chlorhexidine followed by Betadine and draped in a sterile fashion.  Following administration of local anesthesia using lidocaine 1% with epinephrine 10ml, under ultrasound  guidance both superficial and deep, access was obtained into the left renal pelvis using a 21G NephroStick needle [Cook]. A 0.018 " guidewire was advanced under fluoroscopy into the renal pelvis. This was exchanged with a 0.035 " guidewire using a 3F/6F catheter Exchange. The wire was advanced easily through the ureter into the urinary bladder. Contrast was injected delineating the renal pelvis and proximal ureter. Over the guidewire, 8F nephrostomy tube was placed following dilation of the tract. The pigtail was formed in the renal pelvis. The catheter was anchored to the skin using Ethilon 2/0 interrupted skin stitches. Contrast was then injected through the catheter confirming good position. The catheter was connected to an external urine bag. Hemostasis was secured. Sterile occlusive dressing was applied. The patient tolerated to the procedure well. There were no intraprocedural complications. The patient was transferred to recovery in stable condition and eventually discharged. Please also refer to the Procedure note placed in the patient's EPIC chart on the date of the procedure. Sample of the left renal pelvis urine was submitted for microbiology culture and sensitivity testing.  Fluoroscopy time:  00:45.5 min.  Findings: Moderate to severe left-sided hydronephrosis is identified. No significant distal ureteric obstruction is identified.  Recommendations: The patient will need routine evaluation and possible catheter exchange every 3 months or earlier if the need arises. The patient might benefit from ureteric stent if felt clinically warranted.  Fellows: None. Residents: None.  IMPRESSION: 1. Successful ultrasound and fluoroscopy-guided continuous nephrostomy tube placement on the left side.   Voice recognition is used in generating this report.

Patient's Name: [PATIENT]  MRN: [ID] [DATE] 6:56 PM   *	IR NEPHROURETEROSTOMY DRAIN check *	Cannulation of occluded distal left ureteric. *	Balloon plasty of the distal left ureter. *	Placement of a left nephroureteral stent   Indications: The patient presents left nephrostomy tube in the right nephroureteral stent. Previous attempt to place a left nephroureteral stent was unsuccessful due to distal occlusion of the left ureter.  The patient presents today for another attempt to place a left nephroureteral stent. The patient suffers from cancer.  Procedure: After explaining the technique, risks, benefits, alternatives, and answering all questions, informed consent was obtained from the patient. Timeout identifying the correct patient, procedure, site, allergies was performed and observed by the operating team. The patient was positioned prone. The procedure is performed under continuous physiologic monitoring. The patient received intravenous analgesia using fentanyl 75 mcg given in divided doses.  Also the patient received Ancef 2 g IV.  The left  loin was prepped with chlorhexidine followed by Betadine and draped in a sterile fashion.  Following administration of local anesthesia using lidocaine 1% with epinephrine 5ml, fluoroscopic evaluation revealed a 10.2 F pigtail nephrostomy tube pulled into the left renal calyx. Over a 0.035 " Glidewire, the existing nephrostomy tube was removed and an 9F sheath was placed followed by a 5F Kumpe catheter. The latter was advanced under fluoroscopy. Through the left ureter distally. Contrast was injected to revealing distal occlusion of the left ureter. Using distal subtraction imaging, ureterogram was performed distally. This revealed a faint track into the urinary bladder at the site of occlusion. After several attempts using both standard and stiff glide wires, the distal left ureteric occlusion was negotiated initially the guidewire followed by the catheter. Percutaneous balloon plasty was performed using 6 mm x 40 mm balloon catheter was inflated to full profile. Following removal of the balloon catheter and the 9F sheath, over the Glidewire, a 10.2 F-10.2 F-22 cm nephroureteral stent was successfully placed. Contrast was then injected revealing prompt filling of the left renal pelvis and the urinary bladder. This was followed by contrast aspiration. The catheter was anchored to the skin using Ethilon 2/0 interrupted skin stitch. The catheter was connected to an external urine bag. Hemostasis was secured. Sterile occlusive dressing was applied. The patient tolerated to the procedure well. There were no intraprocedural complications. The patient was transferred to recovery in stable condition and eventually discharged. Please also refer to the Procedure note placed in the patient's EPIC chart on the date of the procedure.  Fluoroscopy time:  22:20.5 min.  Findings: The left 10.2 F nephrostomy tube was found pulled into one of the calyces. Initial assessment revealed total occlusion of distal left ureter. Digital subtraction imaging revealed a faint tract into the urinary bladder that was eventually cannulated followed by balloon plasty and eventually placement of a nephroureteral stent.  Recommendations: The patient will need routine evaluation and possible catheter exchange every 3 months or earlier if the need arises. The patient might benefit from a internal ureteric stent placement and eventually removal of the nephrostomy tubes.  Fellows: None. Residents: None.  IMPRESSION: 1. Successful cannulation of occluded left ureter distally followed by balloon plasty. 2. Successful left nephroureteral stent placement.   Voice recognition is used in generating this report.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Uterine mass, prolapsed through the vaginal canal, with active bleeding. Jehovah's Witness unable to receive blood transfusions. Plan for surgical resection. Preop embolization for decreased intraoperative blood loss.  PROCEDURE:   1.	Ultrasound-guided left radial artery access 2.	Pelvic angiography 3.	Uterine artery embolization 4.	Post-embolization angiography  Findings:  Vessels catheterized and angiograms performed as detailed below:  Infrarenal abdominal aortogram: Internal iliac artery origins identified bilaterally. No evidence of suprapubic arterial uterine supply. Dilated and tortuous bilateral uterine arteries are identified extending inferiorly, through the vaginal canal and into the prolapsed uterine mass.  Left internal iliac artery: Enlarged uterine artery extending inferiorly to the prolapsed uterus. Left uterine artery: No cervical branches. Inferior extension as above.  Right internal iliac artery: Enlarged uterine artery extending inferiorly to the prolapsed uterus.. Right uterine artery:  No cervical branches. Inferior extension as above.   Embolization:  Left uterine: - 1 vials 3-500 u EmboSpheres  Right uterine: - 1 vials 5-700 u EmboSpheres - Approximately 0.5 cc Gelfoam slurry.  Intra-arterial medication administration: Lidocaine 5 ml given bilaterally (10 ml total).  Hypogastric Nerve Block: Not performed.  Post-Embolization Angiograms: Right uterine artery: Sluggish flow without opacification of the prolapsed uterus. Left uterine artery: Sluggish flow without opacification of the prolapsed uterus.  Technical notes: Radial access 5 French slender sheath 125 cm Vert catheter 2.4 Progreat microcatheter [HCW] microwire   Impression:  1. Enlarged uterine branches bilaterally extending inferiorly to a prolapsed uterine mass, status post successful bilateral uterine artery embolization.  Treatment Plan:  1. Remain inpatient under the care of OB/GYN until definitive operative management of the uterine mass. 2. Pain control per primary team.  3. TR radial band standard protocol.  Technique:  With the patient in the supine position, the left wrist was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The left wrist was evaluated with ultrasound and left radial artery patency and acceptable size criteria were documented. Images were properly stored in PACS. A modified Allen test (Barbeau test B) was performed on the left wrist to confirm patency of the ulnopalmar arch using pulse oximetry.   1% lidocaine solution was administered for local anesthesia. Access was obtained to the left radial artery using a 21 gauge micro needle and ultrasound guidance. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. A wire was placed through the needle. A hydrophilic Glidesheath was advanced slowly over the wire. A modified radial cocktail with 200 mcg of nitroglycerin and 2.5 mg of verapamil was given through the arterial sheath with slow hemodilution. A side flush was started.   An initial aortogram was performed using a flush pigtail catheter, and demonstrated no extra uterine supply. The pigtail was exchanged for the above diagnostic catheter and microcatheter/microwire combination were advanced through the sheath into the aorta and used to catheterize the bilateral internal iliac arteries and pelvic vessels described above. Once stasis was achieved, 5 mL of preservative-free lidocaine was injected into each uterine artery.   Postembolization angiography from the aorta demonstrated cessation of flow to the previously seen dilated and tortuous bilateral uterine arteries, with relative paucity of previously seen flow to the prolapsed uterus.  All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. A TR Band was placed on the left wrist for hemostasis. The access sheath was removed and no hematoma was seen. A radial artery pulse was confirmed distal to the puncture site confirming patent hemostasis.   The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. The ECA branches opacify normally.  LEFT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is no intracranial aneurysm, or early venous drainage identified. COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: There are multiple irregularities along the left cervical internal carotid artery. INTRA-OPERATIVE CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: Status-post surgical clipping of a right MCA bifurcation artery aneurysm. Intra-operative angiography was requested.  PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: 30 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending. [HCW] was the fellow. [HCW] interpreted the images.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right common carotid artery  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.038" Bentson Guidewire  5 French Terumo Pinnacle Sheath 5 French Simmons 3 Glide catheter 5 French Cordis Vertebral catheter Cardiva Vascade Omnipaque-300 contrast material (40 cc)  ANESTHESIA: The patient was under general anesthesia in the operating room.  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed. Informed consent was obtained as part of general consent for the craniotomy.  In the operating room, the patient's right groin was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. Puncture of the right common femoral artery was performed and a 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath was placed using sterile Seldinger technique. The sheath was continuously perfused with heparinized saline before and during the surgery.  Following surgical clipping of the aneurysm, an intra-operative angiogram was performed using portable fluoroscopic equipment in the operating room. The 5 French [VENDOR]s 3 Glide catheter was placed into the right common carotid artery using a 0.038" Bentson guidewire. Cerebral angiograms were then completed in the lateral projection.  After completion of the angiogram, the vascular sheath was removed and hemostasis obtained using a vascade collagen plug, followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: Prior angiogram.  FINDINGS:  RIGHT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY ARTERY, CEREBRAL: A surgical clip is identified in the region of the previously seen right MCA bifurcation aneurysm. No residual aneurysm is identified.  No evidence of distal emboli is seen.   COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: No residual filling of the previously identified right MCA bifurcation aneurysm. Note is made of challenging arch anatomy necessitating the use of a Simmons glide catheter.

DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: 73-year-old Female  with PMH of diabetes, hematologic malignancy, and migraine headache who was incidentally discovered to have a anterior communicating artery aneurysm and distal anterior cerebral artery aneurysm but evaluation for headaches. Diagnostic cerebral angiogram is indicated for further evaluation.  PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 60 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] was the fellow. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Left internal carotid artery Left external carotid artery Left vertebral artery Right common carotid artery Right internal carotid artery (3D)  ANESTHESIA: Local in the right groin with bupivacaine. Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by the nurse present during the entire procedure. The patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Sedation was administered by a specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for the duration of the procedure as outlined above (Total intra service time, 60 minutes ). Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.  MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine SQ 10 cc  Versed 0.5 mg IV Fentanyl 50 mcg IV Heparin 3000 units IV Protamine 20 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.038" Bentson guidewire 5 French Terumo Pinnacle long sheath (20 cm) 6 French 65 cm arrow sheath 5 French Cordis Vertebral catheter  Cardiva Vascade Visipaque-320 contrast material (100 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient with the aid of an in-person Korean language interpreter. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery. There is noted be significant tortuosity of the iliac vessels and therefore a 20 cm Terumo long sheath was used. However after the sheath was in place was noted to been kinked by the curvature of the iliac vascularity. This was therefore removed over a Terumo Glidewire and Cordis vert catheter. A 6 French 65 cm arrow sheath was then advanced into the proximal descending aorta using fluoroscopic guidance. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP, Lateral and Oblique views.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY:  Rotational angiography was also performed from the diagnostic catheter in the proximal to mid cervical segment of the right internal carotid artery for better delineation of the underlying angioarchitecture. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.    Following completion of the procedure, an angiogram on the right common femoral artery was performed through the sheath. The artery was deemed appropriate for use of the Perclose provide device. The arteriotomy was closed using a Perclose closure device. Heparin was reversed with protamine.   COMPARISON: Noninvasive imaging including CT head and MRA from the dilated last year..  FINDINGS: LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is a small pericallosal aneurysm which is best visualized on the oblique projections.  No focal stenosis or early draining vein are identified.    LEFT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. Reflux of contrast into the contralateral vertebral artery was achieved. The origin of PICA is normal bilaterally.   RIGHT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is a anterior communicating artery aneurysm is better visualized on 3-D rotational angiography discussed below.  No focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified.  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.    RIGHT COMMON FEMORAL ARTERY: The arteriotomy is above the bifurcation and is in suitable position for deployment of a Perclose device.    3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: 3D Rotational angiography with volume-rendered three-dimensional reconstruction on an independent workstation, demonstrated a partially bilobed anterior communicating artery aneurysm which measures 7.2 x 5.5 x 5.1 x 3.3 mm (axial by axial by neck-to-dome by neck). The location and size of this aneurysm warrants treatment. This aneurysm would likely be adequately treated with use of an intrasaccular device.,.    COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.   IMPRESSION: 1. There is a  partially bilobed anterior communicating artery aneurysm which measures 7.2 x 5.5 x 5.1 x 3.3 mm (axial by axial by neck-to-dome by neck). This aneurysm would likely be adequately treated with use of an intrasaccular device WEB 2. There is a small pericallosal aneurysm which is best visualized on the oblique projections. 3. Severe tortuosity of the iliac artery requiring large arrow sheath  4. Bovine type arch which required a Simmons 3 catheter for engaged into the right ICA and left vertebral artery..

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  26-year-old female with history of postpartum cardiomyopathy. Bacteremia.  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled central venous catheter placement       Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the tunneled catheter, as described, the tip terminates near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a power-injectable, 5 Fr, 25 cm, tunneled non-cuffed central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.       Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care.  The catheter is ready for immediate use.        Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed below.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a peel-away sheath set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture peel-away sheath set, the wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.  Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Multiple myeloma; need for CAR-T therapy, via requested venous catheter  Procedure:   Non-tunneled large bore central venous catheter placement   Findings:   -the right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible. -apparent severe focal stenosis, inferior right internal jugular vein (RIJV)   -newly placed large bore central venous catheter tip terminates near the superior cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1. central venous catheter placement  2. severe focal stenosis, inferior RIJV          Catheter: 14-Fr. 20 cm, non-tunneled large bore central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.  Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care. The catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Local anesthesia was used for this procedure   The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the RIJV were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic. Ultrasound evaluation of the vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS. Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a 21-g needle. There was some difficulty advancing the microwire so 10 cc of contrast was injected which revealed a stenotic inferior RIJV.  An image was saved and stored to PACS.  A 0.018-in wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018-in wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, a 0.035-in wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   The venotomy tract was dilated to allow introduction of the catheter over the wire. The catheter was subsequently introduced over the wire and the wire removed. The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  A sterile dressing was placed.   The patient tolerated the procedure well. XR SPINE LUMBAR PUNCTURE  CLINICAL INDICATION: Meningitis, seizures.      OPERATOR(S): [HCW], [HCW]  TECHNIQUE: The risks (including the risks of bleeding, infection, headache, and need for an epidural blood patch), benefits, and alternatives of the procedure were carefully explained to the patient who wished to proceed. Informed written consent was obtained and a call to order performed prior to beginning the study.   The patient was positioned on the fluoroscopy table. The skin over the lower back was prepped and draped in the usual, sterile fashion. Local anesthesia was used for the subcutaneous soft tissues. A lumbar puncture was performed directing a spinal needle into the spinal canal under direct fluoroscopic guidance using the following parameters:  Patient position: Left lateral decubitus  Level accessed: L2-L3, L3-L4 Approach: Interlaminar approach at L3-L4, interspinous approach L2-L3 Local anesthesia: 6 mL lidocaine Spinal needle length: 3.5 i[HOSPITAL] Spinal needle caliber: [DATE] gauge  FINDINGS: Unsuccessful attempt to access the spinal canal at multiple levels as described above. Patient positioning was additionally challenging due to contractures including the left upper extremity and left lower extremity. The patient was unable to tolerate further attempts, the procedure was aborted.  Following completion of the procedure the needle was withdrawn and a band-aid placed over the puncture site.   Complications:  None  IMPRESSION: Unsuccessful fluoroscopically guided LP, as described above. Attempts were made at multiple levels, however due to anatomic distortion from contractures no successful intrathecal access was obtained.   Findings were discussed with the clinical team, who stated that during clinical improvement further attempts may not be necessary. If the patient clinically requires CSF testing, CT guided lumbar puncture could be considered.  Total fluoroscopy time was 3.5 minutes.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Bladder cancer; requiring total urinary diversion.  Procedure:   1.	Bilateral nephrostogram and nephrostomy tube placement. 2.	Left IV pyelogram.  Findings:   Comparison is made to a previous exam dated CT abdomen pelvis [DATE].  1.	Nondilated right renal collecting system. Mild left hydronephrosis.  2.	Challenging, ultimately successfully access of right renal collecting system under ultrasound and IV pyelographic guidance. 3.	Uncomplicated access and nephrostomy placement on the left.  Catheter(s):  8.5 F Cook nephrostomy tubes  Impression:   1.	Technically challenging ultrasound and fluoroscopy guided placement of a right nephrostomy tube. 2.	Uneventful ultrasound and fluroscopic-guided placement of a left nephrostomy tube.      Treatment Plan:   Patient should return for routine check and change in 8-12 weeks.        Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained to the patient. Written informed consent was obtained.  A time out/call to order was performed prior to procedure initiation.  The soft tissues overlying the access site were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).     Right: Ultrasound was utilized to identify an appropriate access site. Static ultrasound image was obtained and stored to PACS for reference purposes. Subsequently, under real-time concurrent ultrasound guidance, multiple attempts to access a a posterior, inferior calyx using a 21 ga needle were unsuccessful. Eventual access into an upper pole calyx was established, however not suitable for catheter placement. Contrast was injected to produce a pyelogram for 2 stick technique, however contrast quickly transited away from the collecting system. The decision was made to perform IV pyelography, and 80 cc of Omnipaque was administered, which opacified the collecting system. Additional fluoroscopic attempts to access a lower pole calyx were additionally unsuccessful. After contrast administration the collecting system did dilate minimally, and a lower pole calyx was ultimately able to be accessed using a 20 gauge InRad needle.. A wire was advanced down the ureter, and a triaxial sheath system ([VENDOR]) was used to establish access into the collecting system. Serial dilation was accomplished over the wire. The wire and inner dilator were removed. Non-ionic contrast was injected into the collecting system and images of the antegrade pyelogram were obtained and stored to PACS.  An 0.035” Amplatz wire was advanced through the existing access. A nephrostomy tube was advanced over the wire and the Cope loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis. Contrast injection confirmed location. The catheter was sutured to the flank with monofilament suture and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.  The procedure was well tolerated, and patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition.   Left: Ultrasound was utilized to identify an appropriate access site. Static ultrasound image was obtained and stored to PACS for reference purposes. Subsequently, under fluoroscopic and real-time concurrent ultrasound guidance, access was obtained into a posterior, inferior calyx using a 21 ga needle and a triaxial sheath system ([VENDOR]). Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site. A wire was advanced centrally. Serial dilation was accomplished over the wire. The wire and inner dilator were removed. Non-ionic contrast was injected into the collecting system and images of the antegrade pyelogram were obtained and stored to PACS.  An 0.035” wire was advanced through the existing access. A nephrostomy tube was advanced over the wire and the Cope loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis. Contrast injection confirmed location. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Multiple myeloma; need for stem cell therapy  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled central venous catheter placement       Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the tunneled catheter, as described, the tip terminates near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a power-injectable, 5 Fr, 20 cm, tunneled non-cuffed central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.       Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care.  The catheter is ready for immediate use.        Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed below.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a peel-away sheath set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture peel-away sheath set, the wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.  Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Dysphagia  Procedure:   1.	Gastrostomy tube placement under fluoroscopic guidance.  Findings:   1.	Preprocedural scout imaging after gastric insufflation demonstrates adequate percutaneous window to the stomach.  2.	Gentle hand injection of contrast material confirms positioning of the gastrostomy tube within the gastric lumen. The gastrostomy tube is in good position.   Impression:   1.	Successful placement of 18 French MIC gastrostomy tube as above.  Treatment Plan:   The tube should be placed to gravity drainage and should not be used for 24 hours.   25 cc of water can be administered per hour. At 4 hours, if residuals are less than 30%, the patient can have tube feeds advanced starting at a half dose.  Technique:   The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the mid abdomen were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.   Using fluoroscopic and ultrasonographic guidance, an appropriate puncture site was identified.  3 T-fasteners were placed adjacent to the planned tube access site. Positioning of the T-fasteners within the gastric lumen was confirmed by return of air and direct injection of contrast material.  Next, under fluoroscopic guidance, an 18-gauge needle was directed into the gastric lumen. Needle positioning within the gastric lumen was confirmed with aspiration of air as well as gentle hand injection of contrast material.  A wire was advance through the 18-gauge needle.  The 18-gauge needle was removed over a wire.   An 8 mm x 4 cm Conquest balloon was loaded coaxially through An 18 French Halyard G-tube and advanced over a wire into the gastric lumen with the trailing edge of the balloon outside the skin entry site. The balloon was inflated along the skin tract until waisting of the balloon was no longer seen and the entire system was advanced under fluoroscopic guidance into the stomach. All wires and catheters were removed. The balloon was inflated with 10 mL of  10% contrast mixture. Gentle hand injection of contrast material documents the gastric feeding tube within the gastric lumen. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained for reference purposes. The tube was flushed with saline. It was affixed to the anterior abdominal wall with a rubber flange. The patient tolerated the procedure well at time of procedure completion without complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]  Clinical Indication:  Left hydronephrosis in patient with history of urothelial carcinoma and neobladder formation. Patient had been managed for left ureteral stricture with an indwelling stent where access was lost during exchange.  Procedure:   1.	Left nephrostogram and nephrostomy tube placement      Findings:  Comparison is made to a previous exam dated [DATE].  1.	Severe left hydronephrosis. There is no forward flow of contrast into the neobladder.  2.	Multiple attempts were made to cross the stenosis into the neobladder but were unsuccessful   Catheter(s):  8.5 F Cook nephrostomy tube  Impression:   1.	Uneventful ultrasound and fluroscopic-guided placement of a left nephrostomy tube as described above.  2.	Unsuccessful crossing of ureteral stricture to place PCNU.  Treatment Plan:   Patient should return for reattempted conversion of PCNU to PCNU in 2 weeks.   Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained to the patient. Written informed consent was obtained.  A time out/call to order was performed prior to procedure initiation.  The soft tissues overlying the access site were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Ultrasound was utilized to identify an appropriate access site. Static ultrasound image was obtained and stored to PACS for reference purposes. Subsequently, under fluoroscopic and real-time concurrent ultrasound guidance, access was obtained into a interpolar calyx using a 21 ga needle and a triaxial sheath system (Greb). Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site. A wire was advanced centrally. The inner dilator and wire were removed. Non-ionic contrast was injected into the catheter and images of the antegrade pyelogram were obtained and stored to PACS.  Using a Glidewire, multiple attempts were made to cross the ureteral stricture but were unsuccessful. The Glidewire was removed and a short Amplatz was placed through the catheter. A 7 French dilator was advanced over the wire and used to dilate the tract. The dilator was removed. An 8.5 French nephrostomy tube was advanced over the wire and the Cope loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis. Contrast injection confirmed location. The catheter was sutured to the flank with monofilament suture and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.  The procedure was well tolerated, and patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: This is a 29 years Female who presents for diagnostic cerebral angiography following CTA with concern for underlying arteriovenous malformation.   PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 60 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] and [HCW] were the fellows. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right Internal Carotid Artery Right External Carotid Artery Left Internal Carotid Artery Left External Carotid Artery Left Vertebral Artery Right Vertebral Artery   ANESTHESIA: Local in the right groin with bupivacaine. Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by the nurse present during the entire procedure. The patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Sedation was administered by a specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for the duration of the procedure as outlined above (Total intra service time, 60min). Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.   MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine SQ 10 cc  Versed 1 mg IV Fentanyl 50 mcg IV Heparin 3000 units IV Protamine 20 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.038" Bentson guidewire 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 5 French Vertebral catheter  Mynx Closure device Visipaque-270 contrast material (120 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 5 French sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP, Lateral and Oblique views.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT VERTEBRAL ARTERY:  Rotational angiography was also performed from the diagnostic catheter in the right vertebral artery for better delineation of the underlying angioarchitecture. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.    Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a Vascade followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: Noninvasive imaging.  FINDINGS:  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. The distal internal carotid artery and its segments are normal in course and caliber. The ACA and MCA and its branches are normal course and caliber. There is normal cortical venous drainage.   RIGHT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   RIGHT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is a right cerebellar arteriovenous malformation supplied by branches of the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery anterior inferior cerebellar artery, and superior cerebellar arteries. The AVM drains primarily via markedly ectatic cerebellar cortical veins into the right sigmoid and jugular veins. There is an additional cortical vein which traverses midline and drains into the left sigmoid sinus. There there are 2 small intranidal aneurysms off of the superior cerebellar artery, the larger is bilobed in appearance and measures 4 x 4 mm and the smaller is located just proximally and measures 2.5 x 2 mm. Reflux of contrast into the contralateral vertebral artery was not achieved. There is a duplicated left SCA. The bilateral PCAs are patent and unremarkable in appearance.  LEFT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CERVICAL: The bifurcation is smooth, without irregularity, calcification, or stenosis with respect to the distal ICA. The ECA branches opacify normally.  LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. The distal internal carotid artery and its segments are normal course and caliber. The ACA and MCA and its branches are normal course and caliber. There is normal cortical venous drainage.   LEFT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.    LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is redemonstration of the right cerebellar arteriovenous malformation as described in the right vertebral artery injection. The left posterior inferior cerebellar artery is unremarkable. Reflux of contrast into the contralateral vertebral artery was not achieved. There is early washout of contrast in the distal basilar artery, likely the result of washout from the contralateral vertebral artery.  3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT VERTEBRAL ARTERY: 3D Rotational angiography with volume-rendered three-dimensional reconstruction on an independent workstation, demonstrated the right cerebellar arteriovenous malformation supplied primarily by the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery, anterior inferior cerebellar artery, and superior cerebellar artery. There are multiple intranidal aneurysms on the SCA feeders, the smallest located more proximally and measuring 2.5 x 2 mm and the more distal aneurysm bilobed in appearance measuring 4 mm x 4 mm with a smaller 2 mm lobule.  COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: There is a right cerebellar arteriovenous malformation supplied primarily by the right posterior inferior cerebral artery, anterior inferior cerebellar artery, and right superior cerebellar artery. There are multiple intracranial aneurysms on the SCA, the smallest of which is located more proximally measures 2.5 x 2 mm and the larger measuring 4 x 4 mm with a smaller 2 mm lobule. Local mass effect from this intranidal aneurysm may be responsible for the pa[HCW]'s observed clinical facial palsy given its location in relation to the brainstem.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Left sided breast cancer  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen Bard port (standard profile)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French 25 cm single lumen Bard power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 3-0 absorbable sutures. A running 4-0 absorbable subcuticular stitch and  Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Hilar cholangiocarcinoma status post ERCP, sphincterotomy and stenting of the common bile duct and left hepatic duct on [DATE]. Severe stenosis of the right main bile duct secondary to known mass.  Impression:   Technically successful percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography  Unsuccessful placement of right percutaneous transhepatic biliary drain  Technique:   The anterior abdominal wall and right flank were prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier.  An appropriate skin entry site was identified using fluoroscopy and ultrasound, then anesthetized with local.  Under fluoroscopic and ultrasound guidance, a 21G Accustick needle was advanced into the liver.  A bile duct was entered with bile return and the biliary system was opacified with contrast. Cholangiographic images were obtained. Attempts to advance an 0.018" wire centrally were unsuccessful. The needle and guidewire were removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression. A sterile bandage was placed.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  refractory ascites in setting of hepatic cirrhosis, with concomitant non-occlusive portal venous thrombosis    Procedure:   1.	Creation of trans-jugular intra-hepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) 2.	Triple-lumen central venous catheter placement    Findings:   -no ascites apparent in the abdomen that would warrant evacuation  -wide patency of the right internal jugular vein (RIJV)  -wide patency of the right and middle hepatic veins (HV)   Measured venous pressures: -wedged HV: 11 mmHg -free HV: 8 mmHg -right atrium (RA): 8 mmHg  -retrograde carbon dioxide venography shows: dilated sinusoidal spaces at the periphery of the right inferolateral liver; segmental opacification of the segment 5 PV, appearingly to be abruptly terminated centrally  -no conventional needle access from the right HV to the right portal venous (PV) system -as MRImaging showed complete thrombosis of the left PV system, the left HV was not interrogated -on sonography, there is more extensive endoluminal thrombosis than expected in the PV system (compared to the most recent, [DATE], abdominal MRI), with only a small residual lumen seen along the main PV and complete thrombosis of the PV confluence; peri-central thrombosis of the most inferior dominant right PV -the inflow vessel could not be engaged from an initial access to a small PV branch in the central liver  -a transhepatic access to the aforementioned S5 PV branch had to be eventually abandoned due to excessive angulation of the entry point.  This is despite having gained wire and glide catheter access through to the SV and inferior aspect of the superior mesenteric vein (SMV)  Post PV access Measured venous pressures: -PV: 37 mmHg -right HV outflow: 15 mmHg  -transhepatic access from the middle HV to the PV confluence -significant contour irregularity along the entire opacified PV system (with sonographic visualization of endoluminal thrombosis).  No opacification of the left PV system -sizable endoluminal filling defect within the central splenic vein (SV), partial thrombosis -two variceal complexes emanate from the central SV -retrograde opacification of the inferior mesenteric vein (IMV) and a small calibered recanalized umbilical vein  -trans-catheter aspiration thrombectomy, PV system, yielding mostly chronic appearing thrombotic material  TIPS creation -mHV to PV confluence TIPS created, with excellent flow -resolution of aforementioned opacified varices and retrograde flow to IMV and umbilical vein -persistent luminal compromise of the main PV (with presumed chronic thrombotic disease), with small residual lumen segmentally, at the mid aspect.  Non-occlusive endoluminal thrombosis remains in the central SV  Measured venous pressures: -PV: 25 mmHg -right HV outflow: 17 mmHg  -RIJV triple-lumen catheter tip is at the superior cavoatrial junction.   Impression:   1. progression of thrombotic disease within the portal venous system and central splenic vein compared to [DATE] (abdominal MRI) 2. cirrhosis and portal hypertension (para-gastric varices; recanalized umbilical vein) 3. aspiration thrombectomy, splenic and portal veins, with yielding of mostly chronic appearing thrombotic material and mild diminution of the thrombotic burden 4. TIPS creation, from the middle hepatic vein to the portal venous confluence   5. the portosystemic gradient reduced from 22 to 8 mmHg 6. persistent, albeit non-occlusive thrombotic disease remains within the splenic and portal venous systems.  This is expected to slowly recede with excellent flow across the newly created TIPS 7. no ascites    Treatment Plan:   1.	Patient will be admitted to ICU for overnight monitoring 2.	new baseline Doppler Ultrasound in 4 weeks, with subsequent clinical follow-up   Technique:   Sterile technique and sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance were used to gain 21-g needle access to the RIJV, at the base of the neck.  Exchange was made over an 0.018-in Cope wire for a 5-Fr. micropuncture set.  This afforded exchange over 0.035-in Rosen wire for a 9-Fr. dilator, then a 10-Fr. 40-cm angled introducer sheath (a).  Through this, a 5-Fr. MPA catheter was advanced, over an 0.035-in glide wire, used to catheterize the right HV, with the outer sheath tip left at the HV confluence.  The catheter was advanced to the parenchymal level, where a wedged pressure measurement was obtained.  Free HV pressure was measured via the sheath.  Wedge hepatogram was performed using carbon dioxide.   Exchange was them over the Rosen wire for a Colapinto needle.  This was used to attempt to gain access to the right or confluent PV system, with no avail.  Two other PV system accesses were eventually abandoned: no inflow vessel could be found from access to a mid liver PV branch; exaggerated turn/angulation of a segment 5 PV branch did not allow necessary instrumentation despite the use of Amplatz and Meier wires through to the SV and SMV  Sterile technique and sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance were used to gain 21-g needle access to the RIJV, approximately 2 cm superior to the above.  Exchange was made over an 0.018-in Cope wire for a 5-Fr. micropuncture set.  This afforded exchange over 0.035-in Rosen wire for a 9-Fr. dilator, then a 10-Fr. 40-cm angled introducer sheath (b), with the distal tip advanced to the peri-hepatic inferior vena cava (IVC).  Through this, an 8-Fr. intra-cardiac echocardiogram (ICE) catheter was inserted, used to interrogate the right liver.  Findings are listed above.  Of note is the revelation that the middle HV is the best (and only conventional) target source to the PV system.    Through sheath (a), a 5-Fr. angled catheter, over an 0.035-in glide wire, was used to catheterize the middle HV (mHV).  Exchange was then made over an 0.035-in Amplatz wire for the Colapinto needle.  This, with ICE guidance, was used to access the confluent aspect of the main PV.  Over an 0.035-in GWA wire, exchange was made for a 5-Fr. angled glide catheter, with the distal tip advanced to the mid SV, where contrast examination was carried out.    The intrahepatic tract was then dilated using an 8-mm balloon catheter.  Exchange was then made over an 0.035-in Meier wire for a 12-Fr. introducer sheath.  While keeping wire access to the SV, a CAT-12 Penumbra aspiration thrombectomy catheter was inserted and used to probe the central SV and main PV.  Repeat contrast examination shows no significant change.  This prompted exchange over the Meier wire for a 16-Fr. introducer sheath.  Through this, a Lightning Flash thrombectomy catheter was advanced, used to perform aspiration thrombectomy in the central SV and main PV.  Completion, repeat venogram shows some improvement, with mild diminution of the endoluminal clot burden.    Exchange was then made over the Meier wire for the 10-Fr. sheath.  Through this, an 8-10-mm x 6 cm Controlled Expansion Viatorr stent was inserted, deployed across the transhepatic tract, with its inferior tip rested in the superior main PV and its superior tip, at the junction of the HV confluence and the IVC.  The newly deployed stent was dilated using the 8-mm balloon catheter.  Exchange was then made over the same wire for 5-Fr. straight flush catheter, with its distal tip left in the SV, where contrast examination was performed.  Repeat pressure measurement was performed via the same catheter and via the outer sheath, at the hepatocaval venous junction.    Upon completion, exchange from the indwelling accesses devices was made over the Rosen wire for a 12-Fr. triple-lumen central venous catheter, with the distal tip left at the superior cavoatrial junction.  The catheter was secured in place using 2-0 Prolene suturing to the skin.  Each lumen was flushed using heparinized saline.    The patient tolerated the procedure well. DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: This is a 63 years Female who presents for diagnostic cerebral angiography to evaluate for underlying right MCA bifurcation aneurysm.   PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 45 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] and [HCW] were the fellows. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right Internal Carotid Artery Right External Carotid Artery Left Internal Carotid Artery Left External Carotid Artery Left Vertebral Artery   ANESTHESIA: Local in the right groin with bupivacaine. Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by the nurse present during the entire procedure. The patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Sedation was administered by a specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for the duration of the procedure as outlined above (Total intra service time, 45min ). Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.  MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine SQ 10 cc  Versed 1 mg IV Fentanyl 50 mcg IV Heparin 3000 units IV Protamine 20 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.038" Bentson guidewire 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 5 French Cordis Vertebral catheter  Cardiva Vascade Visipaque-270 contrast material (120 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 5 French sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP, Lateral and Oblique views.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY:  Rotational angiography was also performed from the diagnostic catheter in the right internal carotid artery for better delineation of the underlying angioarchitecture. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.    Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a Vascade followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: Noninvasive imaging.  FINDINGS: RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is a laterally projecting right MCA bifurcation aneurysm measuring 8.5 x 7.5 mm with a 6 mm neck without irregular features. The ICA and its segments are normal course and caliber. The ACA and its branches are normal course and caliber. There is normal cortical venous drainage.  RIGHT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. The distal left internal carotid artery is normal in course and caliber. The left posterior communicating artery is dominant supplies the posterior cerebral territory. The ACA and MCA and its branches are normal course and caliber. There is normal cortical venous drainage.   LEFT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. Reflux of contrast into the contralateral vertebral artery was achieved. The origin of PICA is normal bilaterally. The basilar artery and its branches are normal course and caliber. The left P1 segment of the PCA is hypoplastic with early contrast washout of the PCA territory. This is consistent with the dominant left posterior communicating artery visualized on the left internal carotid injection.  3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: 3D Rotational angiography with volume-rendered three-dimensional reconstruction on an independent workstation, demonstrated a laterally projecting right MCA bifurcation artery aneurysm measuring 8.5 mm x 8 mm x 7 mm with a 6 mm neck. The M2 branches of the right MCA originate the base of the aneurysm.  COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: There is a laterally projecting right MCA bifurcation artery aneurysm measuring 8.5 x 8 x 7 mm with a 6 mm neck. The M2 branches originate the base of this aneurysm. There are no irregular features.  [HCW], was present for the key and critical portions of the procedure and associated imaging guidance.
