Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Malignant ascites  Procedure:   1.	Ultrasound and fluoroscopic-guided tunneled abdominal ascites drain catheter placement       Findings:   1.	Ultrasound demonstrates small volume loculated ascites over the abdomen. 2.	Final static fluoroscopic image documents the catheter coiled over the left abdomen.        Impression:   1.	Technically successful insertion of 15,5 French  tunneled abdominal ascites drain.  Difficulty was encountered advancing the catheter across the abdominal midline due to multiloculated nature of the ascites and numerous bowel adhesions along the anterior abdominal wall.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter may be used immediately.      Technique:   Informed consent for the procedure was obtained, and time-out was performed prior to the procedure.  The skin overlying the access site was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).   The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right lower quadrant were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the abdomen was performed demonstrating small volume ascites.  Under ultrasound guidance, peritoneal space was accessed with a 5 French angiocath needle.  Multiple attempts were made at advancing a wire across the abdominal midline in conjunction with a standard angled catheter. However, these attempts were unsuccessful. Next, approximately 1 L of normal saline was filled through the catheter to artificially distended peritoneal cavity to allow for easier wire passage. However, this was also ultimately unsuccessful. We then turned our attention towards identifying a suitable pocket of ascites along the left hemiabdomen. A small pocket was identified sonographically and local anesthetic was administered at the overlying skin. Next, the peritoneal was accessed under continuous ultrasound guidance using a 5 French Angiocath needle.   Similar to the right hemiabdomen, difficulty was encountered passing a wire across the abdominal midline due to numerous bowel adhesions along the anterior abdominal wall and resultant multiloculated nature of the ascites.  The decision was made to proceed forward with drain placement as her underlying prognosis was poor, her adhesions would only worsen with increased metastatic spread disease, and palliative intent of the procedure.  Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the upper anterior abdomen to the dermatotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the dermatotomy site.  The peritoneal access site was dilated to allow introduction of a peel-away sheath.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the catheter tip over the left, upper abdomen. The dermatotomy site was closed with a resorbable suture and Dermabond.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS.   The catheter was connected to suction and 1.5 liters of clear, yellow fluid was drained from the peritoneal cavity. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by nurse present during the entire procedure. Patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Dysphagia, right groin fluid collection  Procedure:   1.	Gastrostomy tube placement under fluoroscopic guidance. 2.	Needle aspiration of right medial thigh subcutaneous fluid collection under ultrasound guidance.  Findings:   1.	The gastrostomy tube is in good position.  2.	Gentle hand injection of contrast material confirms positioning of the gastrostomy tube within the gastric lumen. 3.	Right medial thigh fluid collection seen with ultrasound and accessed with 18g but minimal fluid collection aspirated secondary to thick internal debris.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of 18 French MIC gastrostomy tube as above. 2.	Minimal aspiration of right medial thigh fluid collection with specimen sent to laboratory for analysis.   Treatment Plan:   The tube should be placed to gravity drainage and should not be used for 4 hours. 25 cc of water can be administered per hour. At 4 hours, if residuals are less than 30%, the patient can have tube feeds advanced starting at a half dose.   Technique:   Informed consent for the procedure was obtained, and time-out was performed prior to the procedure.  The skin overlying the access site was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the mid abdomen were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.   Using fluoroscopic and ultrasonographic guidance, an appropriate puncture site was identified.  3 T-fasteners were placed adjacent to the planned tube access site. Positioning of the T-fasteners within the gastric lumen was confirmed by return of air and direct injection of contrast material.  Next, under fluoroscopic guidance, an 18-gauge needle was directed into the gastric lumen. Needle positioning within the gastric lumen was confirmed with aspiration of air as well as gentle hand injection of contrast material.  A wire was advance through the 18-gauge needle.  The 18-gauge needle was removed over a wire. Dilation was accomplished over the stiff wire using a 8 mm x 4 cm Conquest balloon. An 18 French Halyard G-tube was advanced over a wire in an antegrade fashion and advanced through the anterior abdominal wall. All wires and catheters were removed. The bulb was inflated with 10 mL of a 10% contrast mixture. Gentle hand injection of contrast material documents the gastric feeding tube within the gastric lumen. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained for reference purposes. The tube was flushed with saline. It was affixed to the anterior abdominal wall with a rubber flange.   Lastly, attention was turned to the right medial thigh fluid collection which was seen with sonographic examination. The collection was accessed with 18g needle but minimal fluid collection aspirated secondary to thick internal debris. The patient tolerated the procedure well at time of procedure completion without complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Breast cancer. Central access for treatment..  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen Bard port (standard profile)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen Bard power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire.   Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter at its intended level, however deflecting towards the left, with concern that the port tip was prolapsing into the patient's right ventricle. Although the patient had no ectopy, or symptoms on the table, the decision was made to trim the proximal end of the port an additional 3 cm. On reattachment of the port, the port tip terminated in the upper right atrium.  The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 2-0 absorbable sutures. Dermabond and Steri-Strips was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  33-year-old pregnant female with left breast cancer status post mastectomy [DATE] presents for port placement prior to adjuvant chemotherapy.  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen Bard port (standard profile)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen Bard power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter was too deep in the right atrium. The port was removed from the pocket, disconnected from the catheter, the catheter was trimmed two centimeters then reconnected to the port, and replaced into the pocket. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter was in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 2-0 absorbable sutures. Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication.   Procedural Personnel Attending(s): [HCW] Fellow(s):     Resident(s):     Advanced practice provider(s): None  Complications: No immediate complications.  Contrast: 0 mL Omnipaque  Fluoroscopy time: 0.6 minutes Fluoroscopy dose:  2.3 mGy  Sedation: Please see anesthesia documentation for details.  Medications: Please see anesthesia documentation for details.  Antibiotics: Ancef, 2 gm IV  Blood loss:  Less than 10 ml  Checklist:	Informed consent was obtained discussing the risks, benefits and alternatives to the planned procedure.  Pre-sedation H&P was performed and sedation consent obtained. The patient’s name, medical record number, date of birth, allergies, procedure being performed including site and pertinent laboratory values were reviewed and confirmed with the technologist, nurse and patient.  These requirements including the Time Out were met prior to initiating the procedure.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Post liver transplant with concern for graft malfunction/transplant failure. Thrombocytopenia.  Procedure:   Transjugular liver biopsy with pressure measurements  Findings:    1.	Post transplant anatomy with evidence of side-to-side cavocaval anastomosis.  2.	The right hepatic vein is normal in caliber and appearance. The middle hepatic vein was diminutive, however not stenotic. No definite anastomotic stricture identified. 3.	The biopsy specimen appeared adequate. 4.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. Needle entry was documented. 5.	Pressures:  a. Wedged hepatic pressure: 20 mm Hg b. Free hepatic pressure: 18 mm Hg c. Corrected Sinusoidal Pressure: 15 mm Hg  d. Right atrial: 5 mm Hg  Impression:   Technically challenging however ultimately successful image guided transjugular liver biopsy. Corrected sinusoidal pressure of 15 mm Hg.    Treatment Plan:  Follow up pathology results.  Technique:   The procedure, options, and risks were reviewed with patient, including bleeding, infection, and pneumothorax. A time out was performed before initiating the procedure.  The skin overlying the access site was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). Patient sedation was performed, as detailed below.  The left neck was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Using local anesthetic and ultrasound guidance, the left internal jugular vein was punctured with a 21 gauge needle with permanent reporting and recording. An image documenting vein patency and needle entry was stored and transferred to PACS.   Using a 0.035 inch Glidewire advantage and Simmons 1 glide catheter, and the hepatic vein confluence was easily catheterized, however the catheter would not advance over the wire for stable access within the hepatic veins. We attempted to exchange the catheter off the wire, however the wire would buckle out of the veins back into the IVC.   A 10 French by 45 cm TIPS sheath was then advanced into the IVC for increased stability. A multitude of different diagnostic catheters and wires (Rosen wire, stiff Glidewire, standard Simmons 1 catheter, Cobra C2 glide catheter, MPA catheter) were used in attempts to catheterize the right hepatic vein. Ultimately the Simmons glide catheter and stiff Glidewire were able to select the right hepatic vein. With stable access in the hepatic vein, the wire was exchanged for an Amplatz superstiff. The Simmons catheter was then exchanged for an MPA catheter and the sheath was advanced into the hepatic vein confluence.  Using the MPA catheter, a wedged hepatic pressure and free hepatic pressure were obtained.  The Amplatz wire was reintroduced, and the biopsy cannula was advanced over the wire through the sheath into the hepatic veins. The wire was removed, and 4 passes made with the 19 gauge coaxial needle.  The specimen was placed in formalin and delivered to the laboratory.  The cannula and sheath were removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression. No immediate complication occurred, and the patient was discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition.  Procedural Personnel Attending(s): [HCW] Fellow(s): [HCW] Resident(s): None Advanced practice provider(s): None  Complications: No immediate complications.  Contrast: 50 mL Omnipaque  Fluoroscopy time: 41.2 minutes Fluoroscopy dose:  285 mGy  Conscious Sedation:  Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by nurse present during the entire procedure. Patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Administered by the specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for a total of 120 minutes (Total intra service time).  Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.  Medications: Versed 1 mg IV. Fentanyl 50 mcg IV.      Antibiotics: None  Blood loss:  Less than 10 ml  Checklist:	Informed consent was obtained discussing the risks, benefits and alternatives to the planned procedure.  Pre-sedation H&P was performed and sedation consent obtained. The patient’s name, medical record number, date of birth, allergies, procedure being performed including site and pertinent laboratory values were reviewed and confirmed with the technologist, nurse and patient. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  [ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Pancreatic cancer with malignant biliary obstruction status post left-sided internal-external biliary drain placement [DATE], replaced with external-only biliary drain on [DATE] due to retraction of the original drain and inability to recross the stricture. Patient presents today for re-internalization attempt and drain exchange.  Procedure:   1.	Pullback sheath cholangiogram through existing percutaneous access 2.	Right internal/external biliary drain replacement  Findings:   1.	Sheath cholangiogram demonstrates nondilated intrahepatic biliary ducts and abrupt truncation of the common bile duct. No passage of contrast into bowel identified. 2.	Newly placed biliary drain is appropriately positioned with the distal loop in the common bile duct and the proximal side hole in a peripheral bile duct.  Impression:   1.	Inability to recross the malignant stricture. 2.	Uneventful image guided replacement of the external-only biliary catheter as described.  Treatment Plan:   Leave the drain to gravity bag. IR will continue to follow the patient for capping trial.  Technique:   The existing catheter and surrounding soft tissues were prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site.  An 0.035" stiff Glidewire was negotiated through the catheter into the common bile duct. The catheter was removed and exchanged for a 7 French sheath. A pull back sheath cholangiogram was performed.  Through the sheath and over the stiff Glidewire a 5 French angled Kumpe catheter and subsequently a 4 French navicross catheter were used to attempt identifying the site of occlusion and cross the stricture. The wire was exchanged for a Glidewire advantage, however also unsuccessful.  The sheath was removed and a new 10.2 French multi-purpose drain was placed over the wire. Contrast was injected to confirm tube position. The catheter was secured to the skin with 2-0 Ethilon. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  48-year-old male with ESRD on HD. Admitted for right foot gangrene. Need for conversion of groin permcath to the chest for vascular surgery bypass planning in the setting of occluded right internal jugular vein.  Procedure:   1.	US-guided right common femoral venous access 2.	Diagnostic venography 3.	Recanalization of right internal jugular vein from internal to external tunneling device 4.	Tunneled large bore central venous catheter placement  Findings:  Access site(s): Right common femoral vein Sheath size(s): 12-Fr  Under ultrasound guidance, with continuous recording and reporting, a micropuncture needle was advanced into the target vessel detailed above and a microwire was advanced through the needle. The needle was removed and a micropuncture sheath was exchanged over the wire, [HCW]gh which an 0.035" wire was introduced. A micropuncture sheath was exchanged for a vascular sheath as detailed above.  VENOGRAPHY: The following vessels were catheterized and diagnostic venography was performed:  RIGHT: Right subclavian vein: Patent vein without evidence of thrombosis and brisk flow into the right atrium. Right internal jugular vein. Occluded. Right brachiocephalic vein: Patent vein without evidence of thrombosis.  IVUS utilized: No  INTERVENTION: Notes on catheter/wire combinations: 12F 40cm, 10F 80cm sheath used. Merit Surfacer device.  Internal to external reverse tunneling: Surfacer device - Details (Type/duration/medication dose): Surface device positioned at the origin of the right internal jugular vein. Device advanced through the occlusion and positioned cephalad to the level of proximal clavicle. Externalized the needle wire to the right lower neck. Dilation of the tract performed with peel-away sheath.  Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the externalized venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the dialysis catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the externalized venotomy site.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS.  After placement of the large bore central venous catheter, as described, the tip terminatin the right atriumium.  Impression:   1. Technically successful recannalization of right internal jugular vein from internal to external tunneling device. 2. Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a  15.5 French, 19 cm (tip-to-cuff), tunneled large bore central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.  Treatment Plan:  1. Catheter is ready for immediate use. 2. Patient will stay admitted for bypass surgery of right lower extremity. 3. Refer to vascular surgery for future planning for HeRO graft conversion.  Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained.  The specific risks of bleeding, infection, pulmonary embolism, perforation, thrombosis, and need for subsequent procedures/surgery were detailed and accepted. Written informed consent was obtained. Patient was brought to the procedure suite and a time out was performed prior to procedure initiation. Patient was placed in prone position and, following sedation, the access sites were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  Venous Access:  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the access site(s) were infiltrated with lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right common femoral vein was performed, demonstrating patency. Under continuous ultrasound guidance, with permanent recording and reporting, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle. An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018" wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire. Through the micropuncture introducer set, an 0.035" wire was advanced into the IVC under fluoroscopic guidance. A sheath was placed at the access site, as detailed. A catheter and/or sheath combination was advanced into the IVC.  Using a catheter/sheath combination, the vessels detailed above were catheterized and venography was performed. Intervention was performed as detailed above, using the devices listed above, introduced via the access sites described. Repeat venography was performed, as detailed above.  All instruments and devices were removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression at the end of the procedure. No immediate complication occurred, and the patient was discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Medications: Please refer to the anesthesia documentation.  Antibiotics: Ancef, 3 gm IV  Blood loss:  Less than 10 ml  Checklist:	Informed consent was obtained discussing the risks, benefits and alternatives to the planned procedure. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  NASH cirrhosis with portal hypertension and bleeding varices.  Procedure:   1.	Primary TIPSS 2.	Triple lumen central venous catheter placement with ultrasound and fluoroscopic guidance  Findings:   1.	Right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses.  Needle entry was documented. 2.	Right hepatic venogram confirms vein patency. 3.	Portogram demonstrates widely patent portal veins, without thrombus. 4.	The initial portosystemic gradient is 17 mmHg. 5.	Post-TIPSS portosystemic gradient is 8 mmHg. 6.	The TIPSS has a smooth course and extends from the middle hepatic vein to right portal vein. 7.	There is good flow through the shunt at the conclusion of the procedure with no appreciable filling of varices. 8.	New right internal jugular approach triple-lumen catheter terminates at the superior cavoatrial junction. Ready to use.  Impression:   1.	Successful creation of TIPS from middle hepatic vein to right portal vein with a 8-10 mm x 8 cm x 2 cm controlled-expansion Viatorr stent (ballooned to 8 mm). Hepatic portion extended with VBX covered stent 11mm x 59mm. 2.	The portosystemic gradient was reduced from 17 mm Hg to 8 mmHg.  Treatment Plan:   1.	Patient will be admitted to ICU for overnight monitoring 2.	Patient will be started on Lactulose/rifaximin 3.	Okay to restart heparin [DATE] morning.  Technique:   Following written informed consent, the patient was placed supine on the procedure table. After induction of general anesthesia, the right neck and abdomen were prepped and draped in standard sterile fashion.   The abdomen was evaluated with ultrasound. No significant ascites noted.   Access: The right neck was then evaluated with ultrasound. The skin overlying the right internal jugular vein was anesthetized with local, and a small dermatotomy was made.  Under ultrasound guidance a 21-gauge needle was advanced into the right internal jugular vein. A 0.018" guidewire was advanced through the micropuncture needle. The needle was exchanged for a 5 French transitional catheter. The 0.018" wire and inner dilator were removed, and a 0.035" wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava.  The transitional catheter was exchanged for a sheath. An angled catheter was placed over the wire and used to select the right hepatic vein. A right hepatic venogram was obtained.   Notes on access catheter/sheath combination: MPA/10-Fr sheath  ICE (Intra-cardiac echo) technique: N/a  Pre-TIPS Pressures:  Right atrial and hepatic pressure measurements were obtained using a balloon catheter/sheath, as detailed:  Free hepatic vein: 11 mm Hg Wedged hepatic vein: 28 mm Hg Right atrial: 11 mm Hg  CO2 Portography: Yes Digital subtraction CO2 portography was obtained using a wedged catheter.  TIPS: Using the Rosc[HOSPITAL]-Uchida TIPS set, the right portal vein was accessed, which was confirmed with the hand-injection of contrast. A 0.035" wire was advanced into the portal vein and the TIPS sheaths were advanced over the wire into the portal vein. The inner sheath was removed and a marking pigtail catheter was advanced over the guidewire and used to measure the parenchymal tract and measure portal venous pressure. The sheath was ultimately advanced into the main portal vein, and a Viatorr stent was deployed within the TIPS shunt. The shunt was dilated throughout using a high pressure balloon to 8 mm. Hepatic portion was then extended with VBX covered stent 11mm x 59mm. Follow-up portogram demonstrated good flow through the TIPS shunt with no filling of collaterals.  Post-TIPS Pressures: The pressures after shunt placement were recorded, as follows: Direct portal: 31 mm Hg Right atrial: 23 mmHg This corresponds to a portosystemic gradient of 8 mm Hg  At the end of the procedure the sheath was removed over a guidewire and a 12 French x 16 cm triple lumen catheter was placed. The catheter was flushed and heparinized per protocol. The catheter was sutured to the skin with 2-0 suture and a biodisc and sterile dressing were applied. The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no immediate complications. Medications:General anesthesia with intubation provided by anesthesia team, please refer to their notes for further details. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Lung cancer with recurrent right pleural effusion  Procedure:   1.	Ultrasound and fluoroscopic-guided tunneled pleural drain catheter placement       Findings:   1.	Ultrasound demonstrates large right pleural effusion 2.	Final static fluoroscopic image documents the catheter terminating within the right lung apex  Impression:   1.	Technically successful insertion of 15,5 French  ttunneled pleural drain  Treatment Plan:   The catheter may be used immediately.      Technique:   Informed consent for the procedure was obtained, and time-out was performed prior to the procedure.  The skin overlying the access site was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).   The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right     chest were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the abdomen was performed demonstrating large volume effusion.  Under ultrasound guidance, pleural space was accessed with a 5 French Yueh needle.         Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the lower chest to the dermatotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the dermatotomy site.  The pleural access site was dilated to allow introduction of a peel-away sheath.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the catheter tip terminating within the right lung apex. The dermatotomy site was closed with a resorbable suture and Dermabond.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS.   The catheter was connected to suction and 1 liters of clear, yellow fluid was drained. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  DVT with vaginal bleeding  Procedure:   1.	US-guided right IJ venous access 2.	Inferior vena cava filter placement  Findings:  Inferior vena cavogram: Single renal veins bilaterally without aberrant anatomy (no duplicated IVC or accessory renal veins). The IVC is normal in caliber and without caval thrombus. Filter placed: Argon option elite Inferior vena cavogram post-deployment: Appropriate positioning below the renal veins without significant filter tilt. No evidence of thrombosis, perforation, or other complication.  Impression:   1.  Uneventful image guided placement of an infrarenal IVC filter.  Treatment Plan:  1. Patient will f/u in IR clinic for consultation for possible filter removal.  Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explai[HCW].  The specific risks of bleeding, infection, pulmonary embolism, filter maldeployment, and filter migration were detailed and accepted. Written informed consent was obtained. The patient was assessed for conscious sedation and found to be an adequate candidate. A dedicated nurse monitored heart rate, blood pressure, and oxygen saturation throughout the procedure. Patient was brought to the procedure suite and a time out was performed prior to procedure initiation. The right neck was prepped and draped in sterile fashion.   The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the access site were infiltrated with lidocaine for local anesthetic. Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency. Under continuous ultrasound guidance, with permanent recording and reporting, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018" wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire. Through the micropuncture introducer set, an 0.035" wire was advanced into the IVC under fluoroscopic guidance. A sheath was placed at the access site, as detailed. A catheter and/or sheath combination was advanced into the IVC and cavography was then performed, with findings detailed above.  Under direct fluoroscopic guidance, the filter described above was positioned and deployed through the delivery system. A repeat venogram was performed, documenting appropriate positioning.  All instruments and devices were removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression. No immediate complication occurred, and the patient was discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Hyperbilirubinemia with pruritis  Procedure:   1.	Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram 2.	Placement of percutaneous transhepatic internal/external biliary drain 3.	Clamshell biopsy of hilar biliary stricture  Findings:   1.	Cholangiography demonstrates high grade, short segment stricture along the biliary hilum with no communication between the right and left biliary trees 2.	Completion catheter cholangiogram demonstrates appropriate positioning of the 10.2F internal/external biliary catheter with locking loop formed within the common hepatic duct.  Impression:   1.	Technically successful percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography and drainage catheter placement. 2.	Technically successful biliary ductal biopsy with two pathologic samples sent for analysis.   Treatment Plan:   1.	Please flush with 10 mL sterile saline q8h. Trend tube output and CMP. 2.	Open to bag drainage for 24 hours. Drain education with patient and family.  Technique:   The anterior abdominal wall and bilateral flanks were prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier.  An appropriate skin entry site was identified using fluoroscopy and ultrasound, and anesthetized with local.  Under fluoroscopic guidance, a 22G Chiba needle was advanced into the liver.  A bile duct was entered and the biliary system was opacified with contrast. Cholangiographic images were obtained.  One-stick technique: A suitable duct for drain placement was then identified on the left. Under direct sonographic guidance, a segment 3 biliary duct was accessed with a 21 gauge Chiba needle.  A 0.018" wire was passed centrally, and the needle exchanged for a 4 French nonvascular access catheter. The inner stiffener, dilator, and 0.018" wire were removed and contrast was injected to confirm location.  A 0.035" stiff glidewire and 5 French Kumpe catheter were negotiated into the small bowel. The glidewire was removed and contrast was injected to confirm location. The Kumpe catheter was exchange for a 9 Fr x 30 cm sheath. Sheath cholangiogram was performed over wire, as above.  The sheath was slowly pulled back to the level of the hilar stricture and then using endomyocardial biopsy forceps (Argon), two clamshell biopsies were performed.  The sheath and biopsy device were then subsequently removed.   Drain placement: Finally, an 10.2 French extended-sidehole internal-external biliary drain was placed over the wire. The anchor/loop was formed and locked. Attention was paid that side holes were positioned within the biliary system. Contrast was injected to confirm location. The catheter was secured to the skin with 2-0 suture material and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.  Contrast was injected through the existing biliary drainage catheter and cholangiographic images obtained.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Postmenopausal vaginal bleeding  PROCEDURE:   1.	Ultrasound-guided right common femoral artery access  2.	Pelvic angiography 3.	Uterine artery embolization 4.	Post-embolization angiography  Findings:  Vessels catheterized and angiograms performed as detailed below:  Infrarenal abdominal aortogram: Internal iliac artery origins identified bilaterally. No evidence of suprapubic arterial uterine supply.  Right internal iliac artery: Enlarged uterine artery. No active extravasation. Right anterior division of the internal iliac artery: No active extravasation.  Left internal iliac artery: Enlarged uterine artery. No active extravasation. Left uterine artery: No active extravasation.  Embolization:  Right anterior division of the internal iliac artery: 1. 1 vials 5-700 u EmboSpheres 2. Approximately 10 mL of Gelfoam  Left uterine: 1. 1 vials 5-700 u EmboSpheres 2. Approximately 5 mL of Gelfoam  Hypogastric Nerve Block: N/a  Post-Embolization Angiograms: Right anterior division of the internal iliac artery: Sluggish flow with pruning of the distal uterine artery.  Left uterine artery: : Sluggish flow within the uterine artery.  Technical notes: None.  Impression:  Technically successful particle and Gelfoam embolization of the left uterine and right anterior division of the internal iliac arteries.  Treatment Plan:  1. Routine access site post-procedural cares ordered. 2. The patient will be monitored for 4-6 hours to assess for the need for an observation admission for pain control.  Technique:  With the patient in the supine position, the right groin was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The patient was placed on the table in a supine position. Following standard prepping and draping, the right common femoral artery was punctured using a needle. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. An 0.035" wire was advanced into the aorta. A vascular sheath was placed over the wire into the common femoral artery. A side flush was started. Hypogastric nerve block, if utilized, is detailed above.  Diagnostic catheter and microcatheter were advanced through the sheath into the aorta and used to catheterize the bilateral internal iliac arteries and pelvic vessels described above. Angiograms were performed. Specific vessels catheterized and embolized are described in detail above. Post-embolization angiography was performed and described above.  A right common femoral artery angiogram was performed, demonstrating appropriate vascular access above the profunda femoris artery bifurcation. All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. Hemostasis was achieved using vascular closure device. The site was dressed in usual fashion.  The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL][ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Mixed HCC/cholangiocarcinoma with intrahepatic tumors. Prior liver directed therapies. Indeterminant segment 8 lesion requiring biopsy.  PROCEDURE:   1. US-guided left radial artery access 2. Diagnostic visceral angiography 3. Percutaneous targeted liver biopsy 4. Transarterial chemoembolization Cone-beam CT performed for intraprocedural localization, as detailed below.  FINDINGS: ANGIOGRAPHY: Vessels catheterized and angiograms performed, as follows:  Superior mesenteric artery: No replaced or accessory hepatic arterial branches. Delayed phase imaging demonstrates patent portal venogram. Large gastroesophageal varices identified. Celiac artery: Tumoral blush identified. Left hepatic artery: Tumoral blush identified. Right hepatic artery: Tumoral blush identified. Segment 4 hepatic artery: Arises from the left hepatic artery and supplies the high segment 8/4a lesion.  Segment 5 hepatic artery: Arises from the right hepatic artery, with some supply to the segment 4B lesion.  Postembolization angiography: Mild persistent tumoral staining from embolization. Substatic flow to the vessels supplying the tumors.  Specific technical notes / catheter selection:  5 French slender sheath Sarah base catheter Fathom microwire Trinav microcatheter: Segment 4/middle hepatic artery supplying the high segment 8 lesion Truselect microcatheter: Segment IVb and segment 5 arteries  CBCT: Yes Catheter location:  -Left hepatic artery -Segment 4A/8 artery -Segment 4B artery Findings: Tumoral blush identified with supply from the target vessel.  Transcatheter embolization:  Tumor location:  Segment for 4A/8 lesion Embolic 1: 3/4 vial 70-150 micron LC beads Embolic 2: 1/2 vial 100-300 micron LC beads  Segment 4B lesion Embolic 1: 1/4 vial 70-150 micron LC beads Embolic 2: 1/4 vial 100-300 micron LC beads  Total of approximately 100 mg doxorubicin coated beads injected into both tumors.  IMPRESSION:    1. Successful DEB-TACE treatment of the segment 4A/8 hepatic dome, and segment IVb parafalciform hepatocellular carcinomas.  2. Successful ExperGuide fluoroscopy guided targeted liver biopsy of the segment 4A/8 hepatic dome lesion. No pneumothorax on post biopsy CT scan.  TREATMENT PLAN:  1. Patient will return to clinic in 6-8 weeks with abdominal MRI and labs.  2. Follow-up pathology results from biopsy. 3. Access site precautions and orders placed.  TECHNIQUE:  With the patient in the supine position, the left wrist was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The left wrist was evaluated with ultrasound and left radial artery patency and acceptable size criteria were documented and images were properly stored in PACS. A modified Allen test (Barbeau test Type B) was performed on the left wrist to confirm patency of the ulnopalmar arch using pulse oximetry.   Access was obtained to the left radial artery using a 21 gauge micro needle and ultrasound guidance. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. A wire was placed through the needle. A hydrophilic Glidesheath was advanced slowly over the wire. 3000 units of heparin, 200mcg of nitroglycerin and 2.5mg of verapamil was given through the arterial sheath with slow hemodilution. A side flush was started.   A 5-Fr [VENDOR] catheter was advanced over an 0.035" Bentson wire into the abdominal aorta. The catheter was used to catheterize the superior mesenteric artery, and initial angiogram carried out to the portal venous phase demonstrated no variant hepatic arterial anatomy, as well as patent portal venous flow. Additional note was made of a large gastroesophageal varix. Catheter was then used to select the celiac artery. The above microcatheter system was used to catheterize the middle hepatic artery supplying the segment 4A/8 lesion.    Biopsy:  Ultrasound evaluation of the upper abdomen was performed, and the suspect hepatic dome lesion was thought to be visualized. The biopsy introducer was advanced to this lesion, however when corresponding with fluoroscopy, as determined that this was likely the segment 4 lesion, not the hepatic dome lesion to be targeted for biopsy. A cone beam CT was performed, and [VENDOR]guide technology was used for fluoroscopic guidance to target the lesion. Under direct fluoroscopic visualization, an additional biopsy introducer was advanced into the inferior margin of the lesion, and 2 18-gauge core biopsies were obtained, placed in formalin, and delivered to the pathology lab. (The introducer needles were kept in place until after chemoembolization was performed. Gelfoam slurry was used to tract embolize both needle paths)   TACE:  The above drug-eluting chemotherapy beads were then used to embolize the hepatic dome segment 4A/8 lesion. Attention was then turned to catheterize the segment 4B lesion. The above microcatheter system was used to select the segment IVb artery arising from the left hepatic artery, chemotherapy embolization was performed as above. A cone beam CT demonstrated some concern for incomplete coverage, so segment 5 hepatic artery was catheterized and subsequently embolized as above.     Completion: Beam CT demonstrated no pneumothorax from the hepatic dome biopsy, as well as contrast staining in the 2 target lesions from chemoembolization.   All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. A TR Band was placed on the left wrist for hemostasis. The access sheath was removed and no hematoma was seen. A radial artery pulse was confirmed distal to the puncture site confirming patent hemostasis.   The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications.  Cone Beam CT (CBCT) was performed intraprocedurally for purposes of treatment planning, targeting and dose calculation. Axial and coronal images were created and 3D reconstruction was performed on a separate dedicated workstation under concurrent supervision. Technique:   The existing catheter and surrounding soft tissues were prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site. The catheter was secured to the skin with 2-0 Ethilon. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL][ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Compression fractures, intractable pain, osteoporotic compression fractures  Exam: Fluoroscopically guided L2 and L3 kyphoplasty  Following explanation of risks, benefits, and alternatives, appropriate consent was obtained.  The patient was placed in a prone position on the angiography table and his lower back draped and sterilized in the usual fashion.  The patient was sedated and monitored by the anesthesiology department.  Technique: Under sterile conditions the L2 vertebral level was identified with fluoroscopy and Lidocaine was used for regional anesthesia.  Using a uni-pedicular approach an 11Gauge needle was advanced into the anterior third of the vertebral body.  A tamping balloon was advanced and the trocar pulled back to the posterior third of the vertebral body. The balloon was inflated.  The balloon was deflated and the space was filled with PMMA cement.  Excellent distribution of the cement within the L2 vertebral level was noted.  Trochars were removed with hemostasis obtained with focal compression.    Technique: Under sterile conditions the L3 vertebral level was identified with fluoroscopy and Lidocaine was used for regional anesthesia.  Using a uni-pedicular approach an 11Gauge needle was advanced into the anterior third of the vertebral body.  A tamping balloon was advanced and the trocar pulled back to the posterior third of the vertebral body. The balloon was inflated.  The balloon was deflated and the space was filled with PMMA cement.  Excellent distribution of the cement within the L3 vertebral level was noted.  Trochars were removed with hemostasis obtained with focal compression.    The patient tolerated the procedure well.  Impression:  Successful transpedicular L2 and L3 kyphoplasty seizures, as above. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  [ID]C[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Chronic kidney disease requiring hemodialysis.  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled large bore central venous catheter placement  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the large bore central venous catheter, as described, the tip terminates in the right atrium.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a  15.5 French, 23 cm (tip-to-cuff), tunneled large bore central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.  Treatment Plan:   1. Routine catheter care. 2. The catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissues overlying the vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle. An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the dialysis catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The venotomy tract was dilated to allow introduction of a peel-away sheath.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Biliary strictures. 65-year-old male history of liver transplant complicated by ischemic cholangiopathy, bilomas, and liver abscesses with stenting and left biliary drain placement. Presents for routine maintenance exchange of drain.   Procedure:   1.	Left internal-external biliary drain replacement  Findings:   1.	Cholangiogram via existing left-sided drain demonstrates appropriate position with retention loop in the bowel and abnormal diminutive peripheral bile ducts. Two right sided GI biliary stents again noted.  2.	Newly placed biliary drain is appropriately positioned with the distal tip in the third portion of the duodenum and the proximal side hole in a peripheral bile duct.  Impression:   1.	Uneventful image guided replacement of the biliary catheter as described.  Treatment Plan:   Keep drain capped to internal drainage and return for routine exchange in 2-3 months. Would not recommend benign biliary stricture protocol given diffusely abnormal peripheral ducts.  Technique:   The existing catheter and surrounding soft tissues were prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site.  The existing catheter was cut to release the retention mechanism. An 0.035" stiff Glidewire was negotiated through the catheter and advanced into the small bowel. The catheter was removed. A new 14 French internal-external biliary drain was advanced over the wire, the wire removed, the retention loop formed in the bowel and locked. Contrast was injected to confirm tube position. The catheter was secured to the skin with 2-0 non-absorbable suture. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Obstructing renal stone. Sepsis secondary to UTI. Pyelonephritis.   Procedure:   1.	Right nephrostogram and nephroureterostomy tube placement.   Findings:  Comparison is made to a previous exam dated CT abdomen & pelvis .  1.	US demonstrates nondilated collecting system with a focal mildly dilated posterior calyx, corresponding to the findings on pre-op CT.   2.	Scout radiograph with a small radio-opaque stone.  3.	Nephrostogram delineates the obstructing stone with contrast readily passing to the bladder. No ureteral stones.  4.	Successful placement of 8.5 Fr x 22 cm Right percutaneous nephroureterostomy tube.   Catheter(s):  8.5 Fr x 22 cm Cook nephrostomy tube  Impression:   1.	Uneventful ultrasound and fluroscopic-guided placement of a right nephroureterostomy tube through the obstructed calyx as described above.      Treatment Plan:   1. Keep drain open to bag. Once acute presentation has resolved can consider capping trial.  2. Patient should return for routine check and change in 8-12 weeks.        Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained to the patient. Written informed consent was obtained.  A time out/call to order was performed prior to procedure initiation.  The soft tissues overlying the access site were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Ultrasound was utilized to identify an appropriate access site. Static ultrasound image was obtained and stored to PACS for reference purposes. Subsequently, under fluoroscopic and real-time concurrent ultrasound guidance, access was obtained into a posterior, inferior calyx (the single dilated calyx identified on pre-operative CT scan) using a 21 ga needle and a triaxial sheath system ([VENDOR]). Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site. A Nitrex wire was advanced centrally down to the bladder. Serial dilation was accomplished over the wire. The wire and inner dilator were removed. Non-ionic contrast was injected into the collecting system and images of the antegrade pyelogram were obtained and stored to PACS.  An 0.035” Bentson wire was advanced through the existing access into the bladder and used to measure the appropriate PCNU length. A nephroureterostomy tube was advanced over the wire, with the distal loop forming in the bladder and the proximal Cope loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis. Contrast injection confirmed location. The catheter was sutured to the flank with monofilament suture (2-0 Prolene) and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile [HCW]essing was applied.  The procedure was well tolerated, and patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Gastric cancer and pancreatic head mass with biliary obstruction  Procedure:   1.	Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram 2.	Placement of percutaneous transhepatic internal/external biliary drain 3.	Abdominal drain placement and paracentesis. Abdominal drain removal.  Findings:   1.	Occlusion of the common bile duct secondary to extrinsic compression from known mass.  Impression:   1.	Technically successful percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography and drainage catheter placement. 2.	Technically successful abdominal drain placement and paracentesis. Abdominal drain was removed at the conclusion of the procedure.  Plan:  1.	Open to bag drainage for 24 hours.  2.	Routine drain exchange in 8 weeks.  Technique:   The anterior abdominal wall and bilateral flanks were prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier.  An appropriate skin entry site was identified using fluoroscopy and ultrasound, and anesthetized with local.  Under ultrasound guidance 18-gauge needle was introduced into the peritoneal space. An Amplatz wire was placed via the 18-gauge needle and an 8 French drain was placed over the wire. Paracentesis was performed draining approximately 600 mL of straw-colored fluid.  Under fluoroscopic guidance, a 22G Chiba needle was advanced into the liver.  A bile duct was entered and the biliary system was opacified with contrast. Cholangiographic images were obtained.  A 0.018" wire was passed centrally, and the needle exchanged for a nonvascular access catheter. The inner stiffener, dilator, and 0.018" wire were removed and contrast was injected to confirm location.  A 0.035" glidewire and 4 French angled catheter were negotiated into the small bowel. The glidewire was removed and contrast was injected to confirm location. A 0.035" Amplatz wire was placed through the catheter, and the catheter subsequently removed.   Finally, an 8 French internal-external biliary drain was placed over the wire. The anchor/loop was formed and locked. Attention was paid that side holes were positioned within the biliary system. Contrast was injected to confirm location. The catheter was secured to the skin with 2-0 suture material and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.  Contrast was injected through the existing biliary drainage catheter and cholangiographic images obtained.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained to the patient. Written info[HOSPITAL]ed consent was obtained.  A time out/call to order was performed prior to procedure initiation.  The soft tissues overlying the access site were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).   Right: Ultrasound was utilized to identify an appropriate access site. Static ultrasound image was obtained and stored to PACS for reference purposes. Subsequently, under fluoroscopic and real-time concurrent ultrasound guidance, access was obtained into a posterior, inferior calyx using a 21 ga needle and a triaxial sheath system (Neff). Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site. A wire was advanced centrally. Serial dilation was accomplished over the wire. The wire and inner dilator were removed. Non-ionic contrast was injected into the collecting system and images of the antegrade pyelogram were obtained and stored to PACS.  An 0.035” wire was advanced through the existing access. A nephrostomy tube was advanced over the wire and the Cope loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis. Contrast injection confirmed location. The catheter was sutured to the flank with monofilament suture and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.  Left: Ultrasound was utilized to identify an appropriate access site. Static ultrasound image was obtained and stored to PACS for reference purposes. Subsequently, under fluoroscopic and real-time concurrent ultrasound guidance, access was obtained into a posterior, inferior calyx using a 21 ga needle and a triaxial sheath system (Neff). A nephrostomy tube was advanced over the wire and the Cope loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis. Contrast injection confirmed location. The catheter was sutured to the flank with monofilament suture and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.   The procedure was well tolerated, and patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Acute cholecystitis. Not currently surgical candidate.   Procedure:   Image-guided cholecystostomy tube placement  Findings:   1. US/Flouroscopic images of the gallbladder fossa demonstrate appropriate percutaneous drainage of the gallbladder.  Impression:   Technically successful US/Flouro-guided transhepatic percutaneous cholecystostomy tube placement.  Treatment Plan:   1. Flush drain with 10 cc saline Q12h as inpatient and 10 cc saline Q24h as outpatient. 2. Keep to gravity drainage.. 3. Plan for routine cholecystostomy tube check and exchange in approximately 6-8 weeks. 4. Routine drain care.  Technique:  Target: Gallbladder Imaging: US&Flouroscopy  Drain: 8 Fr APD/Mermaid Drainage: 100 mL Dark bilious fluid aspirated during procedure Microbiology: Sample sent  A superficial skin entry site was selected based on available imaging and the overlying skin entry site was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier to target the above collection. The skin surface was anesthetized with 1-2% lidocaine. Using continuous real-time grayscale ultrasound guidance, a 21Ga Chiba needle was introduced into the target site and imaging guidance confirmed adequate positioning. A 0.018" wire was advanced through the needle and coiled in the gallbladder.  An Accustick introducer kit was advanced over the wire. The wire and metal stiffener were removed, and contrast injection confirmed placement in the gallbladder.    The 0.038" wire (comes with the kit) was then advanced through the outer of the AccuStick, however was not stiff enough to serially dilate over. This was then exchanged for a 0.035" Amplatz wire and serial dilation was performed without issue.  The above 8Fr multipurpose pigtail drain was then advanced over wire and cope loop locked in place. Contrast injection confirmed placement.   The catheter was secured to the skin surface using nonabsorbable suture material and dressed in typical fashion. Any samples not sent to laboratory for analysis were discarded (total of approximately 100 cc).  The patient tolerated the procedure and was left in stable condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Congenital muscular dystrophy. Presents for routine gastrojejunostomy tube exchange.  Procedure:   1.	GJ-tube replacement.       Findings:   1.	The existing tube is appropriately positioned and patent   2.	The new tube is appropriately positioned with the distal aspect of the tube terminating in the portion of the jejunum  Impression:   1.	Successful replacement of 16 French 2cm MIC KEY  gastrojejunostomy tube with tip in jejunum.      Treatment Plan:    It is OK to use the tube immediately.    Routine check and change recommended in 6 months.  Technique:   Informed consent for the procedure was obtained, and time-out was performed prior to the procedure.  The skin overlying the access site was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). The skin and subcutaneous tissue around the existing tube were infiltrated with local anesthetic.   A scout image was obtained over the abdomen.  A stiff Glidewire was cannulated into the J port of the pre-existing tube and passed into the jejunum. The pre-existing GJ tube was removed over the wire after deflating the bulb. A new gastrojejunostomy tube was advanced over the wire. Its tip was placed in the proximal jejunum. The wire was removed.  The bulb was inflated with 10 mL of a 10% contrast mixture.   Contrast injection confirmed appropriate positioning of the G and J side ports. The balloon was inflated and the disc was cinched. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Endometrioid endometrial adenocarcinoma.  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen Bard port (standard profile)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen Bard power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 Amplatz wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position in the right atrium. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 2-0 absorbable sutures. Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Bilateral lower extremity weakness with poor venous access  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled smallbore double lumen central venous catheter placement  on the right chest  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the tunneled catheter, as described, the tip terminates near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a power-injectable, 6 Fr, 21 cm, tunneled cuffed central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.       Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care.  The catheter is ready for immediate use.        Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed below.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS. Through the micropuncture peel-away sheath set, the wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Right common femoral artery pseudoaneurysm on recent CTA.  PROCEDURE:   1. US-guided pseudoaneurysm thrombin injection.  FINDINGS:  1. Large heterogeneous and poorly defined hematoma/partly thrombosed pseudoaneurysm. Tiny narrow neck originating from the right common femoral artery corresponding with the probable footplate indentation from the closure device for the recent procedure on [DATE]. 2. Post-thrombin injection ultrasound demonstrates significantly reduced flow of the pseudoaneurysm and no thrombin reflux into the supplying artery.  IMPRESSION:   Technically successful thrombin injection into the right common femoral artery pseudoaneurysm.  TREATMENT PLAN:  1. Continued monitoring via physical exam and pain score to the access site.  TECHNIQUE:  With the patient in the supine position, the right groin was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. Ultrasound evaluation of the area of concern was performed, demonstrating a poorly defined hematoma/partly thrombosed pseudoaneurysm with a narrow neck originating from the common femoral artery.  1% lidocaine solution was administered for local anesthesia. Access was obtained to the pseudoaneurysm using a 25 gauge needle under continuous ultrasound guidance, with permanent recording and reporting. Using a 1 cc syringe, approximately 0.1 mL of thrombin (1000 units per mL concentration) was injected into the pseudoaneurysm under continued ultrasound monitoring. Significantly reduced flow of the pseudoaneurysm was observed and ultrasound demonstrated continued patency of the common femoral artery.   The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. Patient's Name: [PATIENT] MRN: [ID] [DATE] 2:26 PM  IR GASTROSTOMY TUBE  Indications: Patient presented with a 20 F G-tube and history of external leakage around the existing tube per His mother. Request is made for IR check and exchange. The mother requested a larger size G-tube..  Procedure: After explaining the technique, risks, benefits, alternatives, and answering all questions, informed consent was obtained from the the patient's mother. Timeout identifying the correct patient, procedure, site, allergies was performed and observed by the operating team. The patient was positioned supine. The procedure is performed under continuous physiologic monitoring. A 20 F G-tube is identified in place and the epigastric region with mild patulous stoma site and no evidence of inflammation or infection. The stoma site was prepped with chlorhexidine  and draped in a sterile fashion.  Initial fluoroscopic evaluation revealed that 20 F G-tube is in good position with no evidence of inflammation. Contrast was then injected and observed under fluoroscopy through the existing tube without evidence of internal leakage. Over a 0.035 " guidewire, the existing 20 F G-tube was removed following deflation of the retaining balloon. Over the guidewire, a 22F MIC  G-tube was placed with the internal length of 3.5 cm. The retaining balloon was inflated using 8 mL of normal saline. Contrast was then injected and aspirated under fluoroscopy revealing good intragastric position with no evidence of extravasation or leakage. Hemostasis was secured. Sterile occlusive dressing was applied. The patient tolerated to the procedure well. There were no intraprocedural complications. The G-tube is ready to use. The patient was transferred to recovery in stable condition and eventually discharged. Please also refer to the Procedure note placed in the patient's EPIC chart on the date of the procedure.
