Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Esophageal cancer, needing port for chemotherapy administration.  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen port (standard profile)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 2-0 absorbable sutures. Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with a single subcuticular stitch and Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].1  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Right shoulder pain. Positive response from prior shoulder nerve block.  Procedure:   Right SHOULDER:  1. Right supraclavicular glenoid nerve radiofrequency ablation using fluoroscopy guidance.         2. Right greater tuberosity axillary nerve radiofrequency ablation using fluoroscopy guidance.         3. Right anterior coracoid lateral pectoral nerve radiofrequency ablation utilizing fluoroscopy guidance.  Findings:   1.	 Patient's baseline pain in the left shoulder prior to the nerve block was 4 out of 10. Pain after the procedure decreased to 0 out of 10.   Impression:   1.	Successful right shoulder radiofrequency ablation  Treatment Plan:   IR clinic follow up in 4 weeks.  Technique:  Hx/PE/meds/allergies/applicable labs reviewed. No changes and no contraindications were found. Full description of the procedure was provided including benefits as well as possible complications including transient increased pain, stomach irritation, mood alteration, transient weakness or paresthesias as well as more serious nerve injury, bleeding, infection or allergic reaction. Informed consent was obtained and documented.  RIGHT SHOULDER: The patient was brought to the procedure room and placed on the exam table in a comfortable prone position. A call to order was performed. The place for needle placement was obtained with fluoroscopic guidance. The sterile field was prepared by chloroprep and sterile drapes. Local anesthesia superficial and deep was provided by local infiltration of 1% lidocaine ( cc).  RIGHT: With the patient in prone position, introducers with stylet were advanced to a bony endpoint on the posterior osseous surface of the glenoid fossa and to inferior lateral border of the greater tuberosity of the humerus. Radiofrequency probe was placed after removing stylet. 2 cc of 1-2% lidocaine was injected. All devices were removed.  Then the patient was rotated in supine position.    RIGHT: An introducer with stylet was advanced to a bony endpoint on the inferior half of the coracoid process. Radiofrequency probe was placed after removing stylet. 2 cc of 1-2% lidocaine was injected. All devices were removed.    Sterile dressing was applied. Patient tolerated procedure well. The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.  Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The venotomy tract was dilated to allow introduction of a peel-away sheath.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The catheter was tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.   The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. Right: The existing catheter(s) and surrounding soft tissues were prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  large arterial pseudoaneurysm in the retro-gastric upper abdomen in patient with recurrent pancreatitis  PROCEDURE:   1. Visceral angiography 2. Right common femoral artery angiogram and access closure   FINDINGS:  -gastric peristalsis confounds angiographic interpretation  Celiac axis -wide patency, along with its branches -in its territory, no active contrast extravasation to suggest active bleeding, at this time -no branch arterial supply to any apparent upper abdominal pseudoaneurysm (Psa).  With a straight medial border, a faint rectangular shaped blush, of approximately 2 cm, is adjacent to the mid stomach (with confounding peristaltic activity), not corresponding to a vertebral body.  Emanating from the peri-ostial common hepatic artery, the dorsal pancreatic artery projects adjacently, with no corresponding abnormality -wide patency of the splenic and portal veins  Gastroduodenal artery -wide patency, along with its branches -in its territory, no active contrast extravasation to suggest active bleeding, at this time -no branch arterial supply to any apparent Psa  Splenic artery -normal splenic artery and arterial distribution and normal sized spleen -no branch arterial supply to any apparent arterial Psa -wide patency, splenic vein  Superior mesenteric artery -wide patency -in its imaged upper territory, no branch arterial supply to any apparent Psa  Inferior mesenteric artery -wide patency -no branch arterial supply to any apparent Psa along the mid upper abdomen  Sonographic evaluation of the mid upper abdomen shows a multi-compartment, partially thrombosed, sizable pseudoaneurysm.   As the patient was not consented for a percutaneous, trans-gastric treatment approach, the latter will be done in 24 hours.      IMPRESSION:   1. no branch arterial supply to any apparent upper abdominal arterial pseudoaneurysm  2. wide patency of the mesenteric arteries and aforementioned corresponding veins 3. sizable, multi-lobar, partially thrombosed pseudoaneurysm remains sonographically visible at the upper abdomen.  This is to be treated via a percutaneous trans-gastric approach, following patient re-consenting   TREATMENT PLAN:  1. see the above (Impression) 2. Routine post-angiography groin cares ordered.  TECHNIQUE:  Sterile technique and sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance were used to gain 21-g needle access to the right common femoral artery (RCFA).  Over an 0.018-in Cope wire, exchange was made for a 5-Fr. micropuncture set.  This allowed for 0.035-in Bentson wire exchange for a 5-Fr. introducer sheath.  Through this, a 5-Fr. cobra catheter was advanced, used to catheterize the mesenteric arteries [celiac axis; superior mesenteric artery (SMA); gastroduodenal artery].  A 5-Fr. Sos catheter was used to access the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA)]; a 4-Fr. angled glide catheter for the splenic artery.    Upon completion, all catheters were removed and angiography of the RCFA was performed.  The indwelling sheath was removed, with simultaneous deployment of an extra-luminal vascular access closure (5-Fr. Vascade) device, with simultaneous application of manual compression, to effect hemostasis.  A sterile dressing was then applied.  The patient tolerated the procedure well. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Multifocal hepatocellular carcinoma. Mildly increased size of segment 6 lesion concerning for active disease.  PROCEDURE:  Y90 Shunt study/mapping using MAA  1. US-guided left radial artery access. 2. Diagnostic visceral angiography 3. MAA delivery Cone-beam CT performed for intraprocedural localization, as detailed below.  FINDINGS: ANGIOGRAPHY: Vessels catheterized and angiograms performed, as follows:  Celiac artery: Tumoral blush identified. Right hepatic artery: Tumoral blush identified. Cannot identify subsegmental arterial supply to the segment 6 tumor.  Specific technical notes / catheter selection:  5 French slender sheath [VENDOR]ah catheter 2.4 Progreat microcatheter Fathom microwire  CBCT: Yes Catheter location: Right hepatic artery Findings: Faint tumoral blush identified with supply from the target vessel.  MAA delivery performed from: Right hepatic artery 4 mCi Future target Y90 delivery catheter position(s): Lobar dosing from the right hepatic artery. On the day of treatment, we will try to investigate subsegmental arterial supply to the tumor.  Treatment device: SIRTEX Split-Dose: No Dosimetry Model: MIRD dosed to the right lobe posterior division territory. Desired lobar/tumoral dose: 250 Gy Additional details: N/A.   IMPRESSION:   Successful Yttrium-90 SIR-Spheres selective internal radiotherapy mapping.  TREATMENT PLAN:  1. Patient will return in 2-4 weeks for Y90 radioembolization. 2. Access site precautions and orders placed.  TECHNIQUE:  With the patient in the supine position, the left wrist was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The left wrist was evaluated with ultrasound and left radial artery patency and acceptable size criteria were documented and images were properly stored in PACS. A modified Allen test (Barbeau test B) was performed on the left wrist to confirm patency of the ulnopalmar arch using pulse oximetry.   1% lidocaine solution was administered for local anesthesia. Access was obtained to the left radial artery using a 21 gauge micro needle and ultrasound guidance. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. A wire was placed through the needle. A hydrophilic Glidesheath was advanced slowly over the wire. 3000 units of heparin, 200 mcg of nitroglycerin and 2.5 mg of verapamil was given through the arterial sheath with slow hemodilution. A side flush was started.   A 5-Fr [VENDOR] catheter was advanced over an 0.035" Bentson wire into the abdominal aorta. The catheter was used to catheterize the celiac artery. A microcatheter system was used to catheterize distal visceral and hepatic vessels, as described above. Multiple angiograms and cone beam CTs from various  segmental hepatic arteries were performed however a segmental branch with direct supply to the tumor could not be identified.   Cone Beam CT (CBCT) was performed intraprocedurally for purposes of treatment planning, targeting and dose calculation. Axial and coronal images were created and 3D reconstruction was performed on a separate dedicated workstation under concurrent supervision.  After confirmation of target treatment vessel, 5 mCi of Tc-99 MAA was injected slowly from the proximal right hepatic artery posterior division.   All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. A TR Band was placed on the left wrist for hemostasis. The access sheath was removed and no hematoma was seen. A radial artery pulse was confirmed distal to the puncture site confirming patent hemostasis.   The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. The patient was transferred to the [HOSPITAL][HOSPITAL] department for imaging. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]C.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  ESRD secondary to FSGS sp DDRT on [DATE] with history of medication noncompliance presenting with antibody-mediated rejection. Central venous access needed for PLEX/IVIG treatment.  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled large bore central venous catheter placement  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the large bore central venous catheter, as described, the tip terminates in the right atrium. 3.	Right subclavian port in place with tip in the inferior SVC.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a  15.5 French, 23 cm (tip-to-cuff), tunneled large bore central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein with tip in the atrium.  Treatment Plan:   1. Routine catheter care. 2. The catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissues overlying the vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle. An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the dialysis catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The venotomy tract was dilated to allow introduction of a peel-away sheath.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Multiple myeloma  Procedure:  1. Ultrasound and Fluoroscopic guided placement of a tunneled, cuffed central venous catheter  Findings:  1. The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and normal. Vein patency and needle entry were stored to PACS. 2. The newly placed catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating in the right atrium.  Impression:   Uneventful image guided placement of right internal jugular vein tunneled Trifusion catheter as described.  Technique:  The right neck and chest region was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. The region was ultrasonographically evaluated.  Using local anesthetic and ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was punctured with a 21 gauge needle.  An image documenting vein patency and needle entry was saved and stored to PACS.   A 0.018” wire was passed centrally and the needle exchanged for a 5 French transitional dilator. A 0.035” wire was advanced through the dilator and negotiated into the IVC.  The skin tract was dilated and a 13 French dilator peel-away combination placed over the wire.  The soft tissues caudal and lateral to the sheath entry site were anesthetized with lidocaine with epinephrine. A dermatotomy was made and a tunneling tool brought from the dermatotomy to the venotomy. The catheter was brought through the tunnel.  During suspended respiration, the catheter was advanced through the peel-away and positioned centrally using fluoroscopy. The peel-away was removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression.  The venotomy was closed with Dermabond and Steri-Strips applied. A single Prolene suture was placed at the catheter tunnel exit site. An antimicrobial disc and sterile dressing were applied.  The catheter was aspirated, flushed, and heparinized per protocol. The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient was discharged in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.IR.1  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Bilateral Hydronephrosis, Neurogenic bladder, posterior urethral valves.  Procedure:   1.	Bilateral nephrostogram and nephrostomy tube placement.      Findings:  Comparison is made to a previous exam dated [DATE].  1.	Sonographic examination reveals severe bilateral hydronephrosiss with marked thinning of the renal parenchyma. 2.	Nephrostography demonstrates severe bilateral hydronephrosis and bilateral ureteral stents overlying the ureteropelvic junction.  Catheter(s):  10 F Cook nephrostomy tube x 2  Impression:   1.	Uneventful ultrasound and fluroscopic-guided placement of bilateral nephrostomy tubes as described above.      Treatment Plan:  1.	Admit to Hospital Medicine Service for electrolyte monitoring and repletion. 2.	Flush 10 mL sterile saline q24h. 3.	IR to follow.  Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained to the patient. Written informed consent was obtained.  A time out/call to order was performed prior to procedure initiation.   Right Nephrostomy: The soft tissues overlying the access site were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Ultrasound was utilized to identify an appropriate access site. Static ultrasound image was obtained and stored to PACS for reference purposes. Subsequently, under fluoroscopic and real-time concurrent ultrasound guidance, access was obtained into the renal pelvis (no distinct calyx was visualized sonographically) using a 21 ga needle and a triaxial sheath system ([VENDOR]). Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site. A wire was advanced centrally. Serial dilation was accomplished over the wire. The wire and inner dilator were removed. Non-ionic contrast was injected into the collecting system and images of the antegrade pyelogram were obtained and stored to PACS.  An 0.035” wire was advanced through the existing access. A nephrostomy tube was advanced over the wire and the Cope loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis. Contrast injection confirmed location. The catheter was sutured to the flank with monofilament suture and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.  Left Nephrostomy: The soft tissues overlying the access site were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Ultrasound was utilized to identify an appropriate access site. Static ultrasound image was obtained and stored to PACS for reference purposes. Subsequently, under fluoroscopic and real-time concurrent ultrasound guidance, access was obtained into the renal pelvis (no distinct calyx was visualized sonographically) using a 21 ga needle and a triaxial sheath system ([VENDOR]). Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site. A wire was advanced centrally. Serial dilation was accomplished over the wire. The wire and inner dilator were removed. Non-ionic contrast was injected into the collecting system and images of the antegrade pyelogram were obtained and stored to PACS.  An 0.035” wire was advanced through the existing access. A nephrostomy tube was advanced over the wire and the Cope loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis. Contrast injection confirmed location. The catheter was sutured to the flank with monofilament suture and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.   The procedure was well tolerated, and patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Chronic hep C cirrhosis. New segment 7 LR 5 lesion, HCC.  Additional Clinical Information: Hepatocellular carcinoma with intrahepatic tumors  PROCEDURE:   1. US-guided right femoral artery access. 2. Diagnostic visceral angiography 3. Selective internal radioembolization with Yttrium-90 4. Right common femoral artery angiogram and closure Cone-beam CT performed for intraprocedural localization, as detailed below.  FINDINGS: ANGIOGRAPHY: Vessels catheterized and angiograms performed, as follows:  Superior mesenteric artery: Tumoral blush identified. Right hepatic artery: Replaced off the superior mesenteric artery. Tumoral blush identified. Segment 7 hepatic artery: Tumoral blush identified.  Specific technical notes / catheter selection:  5 French vascular sheath SOS2 base catheter 0.035 inch Glidewire Trinav microcatheter Fathom microwire  CBCT: No  Transcatheter embolization using Yttrium-90 microspheres performed from: Right hepatic artery  IMPRESSION:   Successful Yttrium-90 SIRSpheres selective internal radiotherapy of a segment 7 hepatocellular carcinoma.  TREATMENT PLAN:  1. Patient will return to clinic in 6-8 weeks with abdominal MRI and labs.  2. Access site precautions and orders placed.  TECHNIQUE:  With the patient in the supine position, the right groin was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The patient was placed on the table in a supine position. Following standard prepping and draping, the right common femoral artery was punctured using a needle, and an .035 Bentson wire was advanced into the aorta. A 5-French vascular sheath was placed over the wire into the common femoral artery. A side flush was started.  A 5-Fr SOS 2 catheter was advanced over an 0.035" Bentson wire into the abdominal aorta. The catheter was used to catheterize the superior mesenteric artery.. Angiograms were performed, and identified the segmental artery supplying the tumor in segment 7. The above microcatheter system was used to catheterize the target vessel, and angiogram performed demonstrated tumor blush.   Once the catheter was in adequate position, a pre-determined dose of 90-Yttrium radioactive particles was infused into the target hepatic artery. The microcatheter was flushed and the microcatheter was disposed of appropriately.   A right common femoral artery angiogram was performed, demonstrating appropriate vascular access above the profunda femoris artery bifurcation. All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. Hemostasis was achieved using Perclose vascular closure device. The site was dressed in usual fashion.  The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. Flush drain with 20 cc saline q8h as inpatient and 20 cc saline q24h as outpatient. 2. Technique:  Target: Right anterior abdominal wall fluid collection Imaging: Ultrasound Drain: 8.5 Fr Cook Drainage: 10 mL purulent fluid aspirated during procedure Microbiology: Sample sent  A superficial skin entry site was selected based on available imaging and the overlying skin entry site was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier to target the above collection. The skin surface was anesthetized with 1% lidocaine. Using continuous real-time grayscale ultrasound guidance, a trochar was introduced into the target site and imaging guidance confirmed adequate positioning. Ultrasound images confirmed appropriate positioning within the target structure. The catheter was secured to the skin surface using nonabsorbable suture material and an adhesive device, and dressed in typical fashion. Any samples not sent to laboratory for analysis were discarded. The patient tolerated the procedure and was sent to the recovery area for monitoring. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  57-year-old female with cystic mass in right hilum status post right hepatectomy complicated by bile leak and massive right pneumothorax. Existing left internal/external biliary drain. Progressive elevation of the total bilirubin. Need for evaluation of tube function.  Procedure:   1.	Pullback sheath cholangiogram through existing percutaneous access 2.	Left internal/external biliary drain replacement  Findings:   1.	Sheath cholangiogram demonstrates narrowing of anastomosis with minimal delay in contrast flow into the small bowel. 2.	Newly placed biliary drain is appropriately positioned with the distal tip in the jejunum and the proximal side hole in a peripheral bile duct.  Impression:   1.	Adequate position of existing biliary drain with narrowing of anastomosis with minimal delay in contrast flow into the small bowel. 2.	Successful cholangioplasty of hepaticojejunostomy anastomosis with 6 mm balloon with improved contrast flow. 3.	Uneventful image guided replacement of the biliary catheter as described.  Treatment Plan:   Leave the drain to gravity bag. IR will continue to follow the patient.  Technique:   The existing catheter and surrounding soft tissues were prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site.  An 0.035" Glidewire advantage was negotiated through the catheter into the small bowel. The catheter was removed and exchanged for a 8 French sheath. A pull back sheath cholangiogram was performed.  Cholangioplasty of the anastomosis with 6 x 40 Mustang balloon was performed.  The sheath was removed and a new 10.2 French internal/external biliary drain with extended sideholes was placed over the wire. Contrast was injected to confirm tube position. The catheter was secured to the skin with 2-0 Ethilon. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient's Name: [PATIENT]  MRN: [ID] [DATE] 5:47 PM   IR PERIPHERAL PICC  Indications: The patient is on milrinone drip and is previous PICC and a right upper extremity fell out.  Request is made for PICC placement.  Procedure: After explaining the technique, risks, benefits, alternatives, and answering all questions, informed consent was obtained from the patient. Timeout identifying the correct patient, procedure, site, allergies was performed and observed by the operating team. The patient was positioned supine with the right  arm abducted and resting on an arm board. The procedure is performed under continuous physiologic monitoring. The right arm and elbow region were prepped with by chlorhexidine and draped in a sterile fashion.  Following temporal application of a tourniquet across the right  axilla administration of local anesthesia using lidocaine 1% with epinephrine 3ml, under ultrasound  guidance, access was obtained into the right basilic  vein using a micropuncture device. A 0.018" guidewire was advanced under fluoroscopy centrally. However, Wyatt advancement was met with resistance in the axilla. Following removal of the guidewire a right upper extremity venogram was performed. This revealed complete occlusion of the right axillary/subclavian vein junction. 0.018 " guidewire manipulation in an attempt to advance through the occlusion was unsuccessful. Over the 0.018 " guidewire, a peel-away sheath was advanced. Following removal of the guidewire, a 5F double  lumen power MIDLINE was advanced through the sheath after trimming to a length of 20 cm. The sheath was peeled away and the line was further advanced with the tip at the right axilla. Both  lumens  demonstrated easy aspiration and injection and were  flushed with normalsaline per protocol. Hemostasis was secured. Sterile occlusive dressing was applied including a Biopatch.  The MIDLINE is ready to use. The patient tolerated to the procedure well. There were no intraprocedural complications. The patient was transferred to recovery in stable condition and eventually discharged. Please also refer to the Procedure note placed in the patient's EPIC chart on the date of the procedure.  Fluoroscopy time: 04:51 min.  Recommendations: Routine MIDLINE care.  Device implanted: LOT # [ID] , REF # [ID]   Fellows: None. Residents: None.  IMPRESSION: 1. Uneventful right  arm power  MIDLINE placement. The MIDLINE is ready to use.  Voice recognition is used in generating this report.

Patient's Name: [PATIENT]  MRN: [ID] [DATE] 6:02 PM   IR NEPHROSTOMY DRAIN  Indications: The patient presents with leaking from the left-sided nephrostomy tube that was exchanged for early in [DATE].  Initially, the patient had left-sided percutaneous nephrostomy in [DATE] for a distal left ureteric obstruction secondary to bladder cancer for which he just finished chemotherapy. Request is made for evaluation and possible exchange.  Procedure: After explaining the technique, risks, benefits, alternatives, and answering all questions, informed consent was obtained from the patient. Timeout identifying the correct patient, procedure, site, allergies was performed and observed by the operating team. The patient was positioned prone. The procedure is performed under continuous physiologic monitoring. The patient received Ancef 2 g IV.  Initial evaluation revealed that 10 F nephrostomy tube is not locked and the internal stranding is torn vein, in the luer-lock and hence the leaking. The left  loin was prepped with Betadine followed by chlorhexidine and draped in a sterile fashion.  Initial evaluation did not reveal the presence of any inflammation, infection or discharge at the exit site of the nephrostomy tube. Contrast was injected and observed under fluoroscopy confirming good position with no evidence of hydronephrosis and distal left ureteric occlusion. Following administration of local anesthesia using lidocaine 1% with epinephrine 5ml, under fluoroscopy guidance a 0.035 " guidewire the existing 10 F nephrostomy tube was removed and exchanged with a similar size. The guidewire was removed and the pigtail was secured. The catheter was anchored to the skin using Ethilon 2/0 interrupted skin stitches. Contrast was then injected through the catheter confirming good position. The catheter was connected to an external urine bag. Hemostasis was secured. Sterile occlusive dressing was applied. The patient tolerated to the procedure well. There were no intraprocedural complications. The patient was transferred to recovery in stable condition and eventually discharged. Please also refer to the Procedure note placed in the patient's EPIC chart on the date of the procedure.  Fluoroscopy time:  01:06.8 min.  Findings: No significant left-sided hydronephrosis seen. Again noted, distal left ureteric occlusion.  Recommendations: The patient will need routine evaluation and possible catheter exchange every 3 months or earlier if the need arises. The patient might need evaluation of the distal ureter with possible ureteric stent placement.   Fellows: None. Residents: None.  IMPRESSION: 1. Successful fluoroscopy-guided left nephrostomy tube check and exchange.  Voice recognition is used in generating this report.  Software is used in dictating this report.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Mediastinal lymphatic leak after aortic arch replacement  Clinical Indication:  Chylothorax   Procedure:    1. Nodal lymphangiography  2. Thoracic duct embolization using coil and glue   Findings:    1.	Excellent visualization of lymphatic channels extending from bilateral groin nodes to the cisterna chyli.  Eventually, injected lipiodol opacified the thoracic duct and demonstrated extravasation into the area of previously known mediastinal fluid collection.  This finding was confirmed on post-embolization cone-beam CT. 2.	Patient thoracic duct with outflow at the jugular venous angle. 3.	Plexiform cisterna chyli.  The thoracic duct has one main channel and numerous tortuous collateral channels (somewhat plexiform anatomy). 4.  Technically successful coil and glue embolization of thoracic duct, with a coil near the jugular venous angle and glue filling the thoracic duct and collateral channels from the jugular venous angle to the cisterna chyli.     IMPRESSION: Impression:    Technically successful lymphangiography with thoracic duct embolization.   Treatment Plan:   Consider repeat CT imaging in 3 days to assess for change in mediastinal fluid collection, or sooner at the discretion of the surgical team.   Technique:   The skin overlying the bilateral groins and mid upper abdomen was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Anesthesia was administered.   Bilateral groin lymph nodes were accessed with a 25-gauge needle directly under ultrasound guidance. Lipiodol was administered. Fluoroscopy confirmed intranodal injection with opacification of ascending lymphatic channels. A total of 20 mL of lipiodol was injected into the groin lymph nodes. Over time, as lipiodol moved superiorly through lymphatic channels, the cisterna chyli was opacified. The cisterna chyli was accessed percutaneously under fluoroscopic guidance using a 21-gauge Chiba needle. An 0.018 V18 wire was advanced through the needle into the thoracic duct. A 2.4 French Progreat microcatheter was advanced over this wire into the thoracic duct.   Coil embolization was performed within the thoracic duct near the jugular venous angle using one Embold 6 mm x 20 cm coil.   Subsequently, the thoracic duct was embolized using a 1:2 mixture of n-BCA glue and lipiodol (1 mL of glue). Fluoroscopy confirmed that glue filled the thoracic duct, extending from the jugular venous angle to the cisterna chyli.   All instruments and devices were removed from the patient. Access sites were dressed in the usual sterile fashion. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Multiple myeloma  Procedure:  1. Ultrasound and Fluoroscopic guided placement of a tunneled, cuffed central venous catheter  Findings:  1. The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and normal. Vein patency and needle entry were stored to PACS. 2. The newly placed catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating in the right atrium.  Impression:   Uneventful image guided placement of right internal jugular vein tunneled Trifusion catheter as described.  Technique:  The right neck and chest region was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. The region was ultrasonographically evaluated.  Using local anesthetic and ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was punctured with a 21 gauge needle.  An image documenting vein patency and needle entry was saved and stored to PACS.   A 0.018” wire was passed centrally and the needle exchanged for a 5 French transitional dilator. A 0.035” wire was advanced through the dilator and negotiated into the IVC.  The skin tract was dilated and a 13 French dilator peel-away combination placed over the wire.  The soft tissues caudal and lateral to the sheath entry site were anesthetized with lidocaine with epinephrine. A dermatotomy was made and a tunneling tool brought from the dermatotomy to the venotomy. The catheter was brought through the tunnel.  During suspended respiration, the catheter was advanced through the peel-away and positioned centrally using fluoroscopy. The peel-away was removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression.  The venotomy was closed with Dermabond. A single Prolene suture was placed at the catheter tunnel exit site. An antimicrobial disc and sterile dressing were applied.  The catheter was aspirated, flushed, and heparinized per protocol. The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient was discharged in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].1  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Bilateral pulmonary embolisms with contraindication to anticoagulation  Procedure:   1.	US-guided left femoral venous access 2.	Inferior vena cava filter placement  Findings:  Inferior vena cavogram: Single renal veins bilaterally without aberrant anatomy (no duplicated IVC or accessory renal veins). The IVC is normal in caliber and without caval thrombus. Filter placed: Argon option elite Inferior vena cavogram post-deployment: Appropriate positioning below the renal veins without significant filter tilt. No evidence of thrombosis, perforation, or other complication.  Impression:   1.  Uneventful image guided placement of an infrarenal IVC filter.  Treatment Plan:  1. Patient will f/u in IR clinic for consultation for possible filter removal.  Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained.  The specific risks of bleeding, infection, pulmonary embolism, filter maldeployment, and filter migration were detailed and accepted. Written informed consent was obtained. The patient was assessed for conscious sedation and found to be an adequate candidate. A dedicated nurse monitored heart rate, blood pressure, and oxygen saturation throughout the procedure. Patient was brought to the procedure suite and a time out was performed prior to procedure initiation. The left groin was prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  We elected to utilize a left groin approach due to a pustule in the right groin.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the access site were infiltrated with lidocaine for local anesthetic. Ultrasound evaluation of the left common femoral vein was performed demonstrating patency. Under continuous ultrasound guidance, with permanent recording and reporting, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018" wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire. Through the micropuncture introducer set, an 0.035" wire was advanced into the IVC under fluoroscopic guidance. A sheath was placed at the access site, as detailed. A catheter and/or sheath combination was advanced into the IVC and cavography was then performed, with findings detailed above.  Under direct fluoroscopic guidance, the filter described above was positioned and deployed through the delivery system utilizing an over the wire deployment technique. A repeat venogram was performed, documenting appropriate positioning.  All instruments and devices were removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression. No immediate complication occurred, and the patient was discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: 76-year-old Male  with PMH of hypertension, type 2 diabetes, latter cancer (stay 0 and chemotherapy) who presented in [DATE] with diffuse subarachnoid hemorrhage (Hunt-Hess grade 3). Angiogram at the time of his presentation showed no evidence of cerebral aneurysm or other vascular abnormality to account for his hemorrhage. Given the diffuse pattern of this hemorrhage repeat cerebral angiogram is indicated.   PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 45 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] and [HCW] were the fellows. Each actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right internal carotid artery Right external carotid artery Right vertebral artery Left internal carotid artery Left common carotid artery Left vertebral artery  ANESTHESIA: Local in the right groin with bupivacaine. Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by the nurse present during the entire procedure. The patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Sedation was administered by a specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for the duration of the procedure as outlined above (Total intra service time, 45 minutes ). Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.  MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine SQ 10 cc  Versed 1 mg IV Fentanyl 50 mcg IV Heparin 3000 units IV Protamine 20 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: [HCW]il wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.038" Bentson guidewire 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 5 French Merit Performa Vertebral catheter  Cardiva Vascade Visipaque-320 contrast material (120 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 5 French sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP, Lateral and Oblique views. Of note, we had great difficulty in trying to catheterize the right vertebral artery. We tried with both the Terumo Glidewire and shape [VENDOR] wire, as well as steam-shaped merit Performa diagnostic catheter. Ultimately we injected the subclavian artery near the origin of the right vertebral artery in order to visualize the right vertebral artery.   Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a Vascade followed by manual compression. RIGHT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL (catheter in the right subclavian artery): The right IVb segment beyond the origin of PICA is diminutive. No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified.   LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified.    LEFT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  ICA findings as above. The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. Reflux of contrast into the contralateral vertebral artery was achieved. The origin of PICA is normal bilaterally.   COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.   IMPRESSION:  1. No visualized aneurysm or arteriovenous shunting lesion or other vascular abnormality to account for subarachnoid hemorrhage. 2. Severe tortuosity of the bilateral subclavian arteries making catheterization of the vertebral arteries, especially the right vertebral artery, very difficult. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP, Lateral and Oblique views.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY:  Rotational angiography was also performed from the diagnostic catheter in the mid cervical segment of the left internal carotid artery for better delineation of the underlying angioarchitecture. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced. FINDINGS: RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. LEFT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is a large multi lobulated aneurysm of the middle cerebral artery bifurcation, which is further described on the 3-D rotational angiography discussed below. There appears to be duplicated MCA, with the anterior temporal artery originating from the distal ICA. Additionally there is early bifurcation of the MCA, and the aneurysm originates from the second-order bifurcation of the superior division of the left middle cerebral artery   No focal stenosis or early draining vein are identified.    LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. Reflux of contrast into the contralateral vertebral artery was achieved. The origin of PICA is normal bilaterally.    3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: 3D Rotational angiography with volume-rendered three-dimensional reconstruction on an independent workstation, demonstrated a large, broad-based, bilobed aneurysm of the bifurcation of the superior division of the left middle cerebral artery which measures 11.2 x 9.7 x 10.9 x 7.7 mm (axial by axial by neck-to-dome by neck). . One of the branches of the superior division originates from the sac of the aneurysm.    COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.   IMPRESSION:  1. There is a topologically complex, broad-based, bilobed aneurysm of the bifurcation of the superior division of the left middle cerebral artery which measures 11.2 x 9.7 x 10.9 x 7.7 mm (axial by axial by neck-to-dome by neck), with one of the branches of superior division originating from the second aneurysm. 2. There is anatomical variation associated with the left middle cerebral artery. There is duplication of the left middle cerebral artery with the anterior temporal artery originating from the distal ICA. Additionally there is an early bifurcation of the middle cerebral artery. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]  Clinical Indication:  Decompensated alcoholic cirrhosis complicated by hematemesis from esophageal varices. Hemorrhage uncontrolled with banding. Outside hospital failed TIPS.  Procedure:   1.	Primary TIPSS 2.	Paracentesis 3.	Triple lumen central venous catheter placement with ultrasound and fluoroscopic guidance  Findings:   1.	Right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses.  Needle entry was documented. 2.	Right hepatic venogram confirms vein patency. 3.	Portogram demonstrates no portal vein thrombosis, mild cavernous transformation, large coronary shunt filling esophageal varices, and a recannulized umbilical vein.. 4.	The initial portosystemic gradient is 26 mmHg. 5.	Post-TIPSS portosystemic gradient is 12 mmHg. 6.	The TIPSS has a smooth course and extends from the right hepatic vein to right portal vein. 7.	There is good flow through the shunt at the conclusion of the procedure with significantly decreased filling of varices. 8.	150 -200 mL of bloody ascites were drained at the end of the procedure. 9.	New right internal jugular approach triple-lumen catheter terminates at the superior cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful creation of TIPS from right hepatic vein to right portal vein with a 8-10 mm x 8 cm x 2 cm controlled-expansion Viatorr stent (ballooned to 10 mm). This was extended on the hepatic venous and with an additional 8-10 mm x 4 cm x 2 cm controlled expansion Viatorr stent (ballooned to 10 mm). 2.	The portosystemic gradient was reduced from 26 mm Hg to 12 mmHg.  Treatment Plan:   1.	Patient will be admitted to ICU for overnight monitoring 2.	Patient will be started on Lactulose/rifaximin  Technique:   Following written informed consent, the patient was placed supine on the procedure table. After induction of general anesthesia, the right neck and abdomen were prepped and draped in standard sterile fashion.   Access: Hepatic venous:  The right neck was then evaluated with ultrasound. The skin overlying the right internal jugular vein was anesthetized with local, and a small dermatotomy was made.  Under ultrasound guidance a 21-gauge needle was advanced into the right internal jugular vein. A 0.018" guidewire was advanced through the micropuncture needle. The needle was exchanged for a 5 French transitional catheter. The 0.018" wire and inner dilator were removed, and a 0.035" Amplatz wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava.  The transitional catheter was exchanged for a 10 French angled sheath. An angled catheter was placed adjacent to the wire and used to select the right hepatic vein. A right hepatic venogram was obtained.   Notes on access catheter/sheath combination: MPA/10-Fr sheath  Portal: Initially a recannulized umbilical vein was attempted to be accessed using a micropuncture kit. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, however would not track to the main portal vein. Additional access was attempted as the umbilical vein dives through the falciform ligament, however the same issues were encountered.  Ultimately the decision was made to obtain direct portal access. Under real-time ultrasound guidance, a peripheral right portal vein was accessed using a 21-gauge Chiba needle. The 0.018 inch wire was then advanced centrally, down the right main portal vein, through the portal vein and into the splenic vein. With stable access into the portal system, a 5 French sheath was advanced into the peripheral portal access, and a SOS2 catheter was advanced to the right main portal vein as a target. Portal venogram and direct portal pressures were obtained (see below).  Pre-TIPS Pressures:  Right atrial and hepatic pressure measurements were obtained using a balloon catheter/sheath, as detailed:  Direct portal: 36 mmHg  Right atrial: 10 mm Hg  TIPS:  Using the Ring TIPS set, the right portal vein was accessed, using the SOS2 catheter as a target, which was confirmed with the hand-injection of contrast. A 0.035" Glidewire was advanced into the portal vein and the TIPS sheaths were advanced over the wire into the portal vein. The inner sheath was removed and a marking pigtail catheter was advanced over the guidewire and used to measure the parenchymal tract and measure portal venous pressure. The sheath was ultimately advanced into the main portal vein, and the above Viatorr stent was deployed within the TIPS shunt. The shunt was dilated throughout using a high pressure balloon up to 10 mm. Follow-up portogram demonstrated good flow through the TIPS shunt with minimal filling of collaterals.   Injection of the neck sheath positioned at the hepatic confluence demonstrated appropriate positioning of the TIPS, however the decision was made to extend the TIPS towards the hepatic venous end with a second Viatorr.  Post-TIPS Pressures: The pressures after shunt placement were recorded, as follows: Direct portal: 24 mm Hg Mid TIPS: 21 mmHg Right atrial: 12 mmHg This corresponds to a portosystemic gradient of 12 mm Hg  At the end of the procedure the sheath was removed over a guidewire and a 12 French x 16 cm triple lumen catheter was placed. The catheter was flushed and heparinized per protocol. The catheter was sutured to the skin with 2-0 suture and a biodisc and sterile dressing were applied. The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no immediate complications.  Portal access closure: Through the transhepatic 5 French sheath, a single Nester coil was deployed for closure. However upon removal of the sheath, anesthesiology commented that the patient's pressor requirements had increased. Immediate ultrasound evaluation of the abdomen was performed without any significant expansion of the minimal ascites present. A paracentesis was performed, using a 5 French [VENDOR]eh centesis needle. A total of approximately 150 to 200 cc of bloody ascites was obtained.  The patient's hemodynamics remained tenuous, so under real-time ultrasound guidance the right portal vein that we had access was reaccessed using ultrasound and a micropuncture needle, with fluoroscopic confirmation of the correct portal vein (coil being moved by the wire). Additional tract embolization was performed with Gelfoam slurry and glue.   At the end of the case, the patient remained in critical condition and was discharged under the immediate care of anesthesiology back to the ICU. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Polymicrobial infection requiring long-term IV therapy. Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen Bard power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 2-0 absorbable sutures. Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. Post-intervention:  Successful deposition of cement within the treated vertebral body/bodies with no evidence of extravasation.    Impression:   1.	Successful image guided augmentation of vertebral levels: L1    Treatment Plan:   1.	 A fracture of the hip, spine or distal radius in patients over 50 years of age warrants testing or treatment for osteoporosis if not previously undertaken. If patient does  Technique:   The patient was brought to the interventional radiology suite and placed on the table in prone position. Level by level technique:   -Vertebral level:  L 1 -Pedicle access: Right unipedicular (omnicurve)     -Access trocar gauge:  10-gauge -Balloon utilized:  15 mm  Prior to injection of cement, balloons were inserted and inflated under biplane fluoroscopy. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Emergent Right hepatic artery pseudoaneurysm with Hemoperitoneum  PROCEDURE:   1. US-guided right common femoral artery access. 2. Visceral angiography 3. Celiac artery angiography 4. Proper hepatic angiography 5. Aortic balloon placement  FINDINGS: ANGIOGRAPHY: Vessels catheterized using base catheter and microcatheter/microwire combination and angiograms performed:  Aorta: No active hemorrhage; significant tortuosity in the iliac artery and aorta. Celiac artery: No active hemorrhage. Aneurysmal ectasia of the celiac artery origin. Pseudoaneurysms in the right hepatic artery and the left gastric artery.  Superior mesenteric artery: No active hemorrhage.  Right hepatic artery: Pseudoaneurysm identified. Right hepatic arter access obtained with 018 microwire and 2.8 microcatheter system . Angiogram via microcatheter identified pseudoaneurysm distal to the origin of a small left hepatic artery.  No 018 covered stents available to negotiate this tortuous anatomy to the distal right hepatic artery. Several unsuccessful attempts were made to convert the 018 system to a 035 system to match the available 035 covered system. None of the 035 catheters would track over the 018 system beyond the celiac axis.   6F Vascular sheath was placed for additional stability and fresh attempt to access the proper hepatic artery was contemplated when Anesthesia alerted of further instability with Blood pressure.  No catheters dor wires were in the hepatic artery at the time.  A 5f Omni flush catheter was placed above the celiac axis and a flush aortogram done.  This showed active bleeding from the area of the distal right hepatic artery pseudoaneurysm. Surgery team was notified of the findings and the recommendations for acute surgical intervention.   Low profile aortic Occlusion Ballon was not available therefore, a 180 Lunderquist wire was passed via the omni flush catheter and the 6 French vascular sheath exchanged for a 10 F short vascular sheath.  A Coda Balloon was passed over the wire to the celiac axis and inflated with dilute contrast to achieve hemostasis at the celiac aorta.  The Lunderquist Wire was maintained in the aorta to provide support and prevent migration since the thoracic and abdominal aorta were ectatic and tortuous.    Aorta angiography: Tortuous and ectatic thoracic and upper abdominal aorta with active contrast extravasation from the Distal Right hepatic artery pseudoaneurysm area.  Coda Balloon in place with flow controlled to the celiac axis and below with maintenance of blood pressure.   Patient En rout to OR for Operative intervention.    IMPRESSION:   Identification of right hepatic artery pseudoaneurysm  supplying the most of the liver parenchyma.  Smaller left gastrohepatic trunk with possible pseudoaneurysm near origin.   Unable to access proper hepatic artery with 035 system because of very tortuous anatomy of the celiac and hepatic axis. The Pseudoaneurysm again bled before this system could be placed to consider 035 covered stent deployment.   Embolization of the right hepatic artery with the 018 microcatheter system was not a survivable event. Right hepatic artery pseudoaneurysm rupture. Temporary Aortic balloon Occlusion In Preparation for surgical Exploration and repair if Possible.   TREATMENT PLAN:  1. Taken to operating room for emergency laparotomy.  2. IR will accompany patient for management of aortic balloon.   TECHNIQUE: With the patient in the supine position, the groin was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. Following standard prepping and draping, the right common femoral artery was punctured using a 21 gauge needle. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. An 0.035" wire was advanced into the aorta. A 5F vascular sheath was placed over the wire into the common femoral artery. A side flush was started.  A 5-Fr diagnostic catheter was advanced over an 0.035" wire into the abdominal aorta. The catheter was used to catheterize the vessels described above. Angiograms were performed. A microcatheter system was used to catheterize distal vessels, as described above. Specific vessels catheterized as described in detail above. The 018 microcatheter could not be converted to 035 system for covered stent deployment. Access to the hepatic artery was lost due to significant significant arterial tortuosity. When hypotension developed no   An aortic balloon was deployed over the celiac origin to stop bleeding from the ruptured distal right hepatic artery pseudoaneurysm and the patient was urgently taken immediately to the operating room with the Coda aortic balloon in place. Managed by aortic balloon inflation and immediate transfer to the operating room. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  stage IV A lung adenocarcinoma    Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen Bard port (standard profile)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen Bard power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular len[HOSPITAL] of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was affixed to the chest wall with suture due to subcutaneous tissue being quite loose.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 3-0 absorbable sutures. A running 4-0 absorbable subcuticular stitch and  Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with  Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  History of lupus cardio-myositis, anuric/oliguric  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled large bore central venous catheter placement  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the large bore central venous catheter, as described, the tip terminates in the right atrium.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a  15.5 French, 23 cm (tip-to-cuff), tunneled large bore central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.  Treatment Plan:   1. Routine catheter care. 2. The catheter is ready for immediate use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissues overlying the vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle. An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the dialysis catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The venotomy tract was dilated to allow introduction of a peel-away sheath.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: This is a 47 years Female who presents for diagnostic cerebral angiography for evaluation of residual cavernous carotid fistula status post coil-assisted pipeline embolization following presentation for new onset right eye chemosis.   PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 30 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] and [HCW] were the fellows. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right Internal Carotid Artery Right External Carotid Artery Left Internal Carotid Artery Left External Carotid Artery Left Vertebral Artery   ANESTHESIA: Local in the right groin with bupivacaine. Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by the nurse present during the entire procedure. The patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Sedation was administered by a specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for the duration of the procedure as outlined above (Total intra service time, 45min ). Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.   MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine SQ 10 cc  Versed 1 mg IV Fentanyl 75 mcg IV Heparin 3000 units IV Protamine 20 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.038" Bentson guidewire 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 5 French Merit Performa Vertebral catheter  Cardiva Vascade Visipaque-270 contrast material (120 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 5 French sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP, Lateral and Oblique views.   Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a Vascade followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: Prior angiogram from [DATE].  FINDINGS:  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: The coil mass and flow diverting stent is visualized is unchanged in appearance from prior angiogram. There is no in-stent stenosis and good wall apposition of the stent. There is no evidence of early venous drainage or connection between the carotid artery and the cavernous sinus. There is redemonstration of the previously described fenestration in the distal right cervical carotid artery. The ACA and MCA and its segments are normal course and caliber. There is normal cortical venous drainage.  RIGHT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. The distal internal carotid artery and its segments are normal course and caliber. The ACA and MCA and its branches are normal course and caliber. There is normal cortical venous drainage.   LEFT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. Reflux of contrast into the contralateral vertebral artery was achieved. The origin of PICA is normal bilaterally. The basilar artery and its branches are normal course and caliber.  COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: No residual aneurysm or carotid cavernous fistula. The coil mass and flow diverting stent are unchanged in appearance from prior angiogram and without in-stent stenosis. There is no evidence of early venous drainage. There is no underlying vascular pathology to explain the patient's right eye chemosis.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]C.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Patient undergoing heart and liver transplant evaluation. Hx congenital tricuspid and pulmonary atresia and is s/p classic BT shunt x2. A-fib on warfarin, concern for congestive hepatopathy.  Procedure:   Transjugular liver biopsy with pressure measurements  Findings:   1.	The right hepatic vein is normal in caliber and appearance. 2.	The biopsy specimen appeared adequate. 3.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. Needle entry was documented. 4.	Pressures:  a. Wedged hepatic pressure: 23 mm Hg b. Free hepatic pressure: 26 mm Hg c. Corrected Sinusoidal Pressure: 3 mm Hg  d. Right atrial: 31 mm Hg  Impression:   Successful image guided transjugular liver biopsy. Corrected sinusoidal pressure of 3 mm Hg.  Findings above suggestive of congestive hepatopathy secondary to known cardiac dysfunction.  Treatment Plan:  Follow up pathology results.  Technique:   The procedure, options, and risks were reviewed with patient, including bleeding, infection, and pneumothorax. A time out was performed before initiating the procedure.  The skin overlying the access site was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). Patient sedation was performed, as detailed below.  The right neck was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Using local anesthetic and ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was punctured with a 21 gauge needle with permanent reporting and recording. An image documenting vein patency and needle entry was stored and transferred to PACS. A 9 French sheath was placed at the neck.  An angled catheter was used to select the right hepatic vein and hepatic venography performed using nonionic contrast. Free and wedged hepatic pressures were obtained using the diagnostic catheter.  A 0.035” wire was placed in the hepatic vein and the Argon biopsy cannula was advanced over wire. 2 passes were made however the samples were not adequate. Subsequently, 7 French Cook biopsy cannula was advanced over the wire. The wire was removed, and 3 more passes made with the 18 gauge coaxial needle with 2/3 good cores.  The specimen was placed in formalin and delivered to the laboratory.  The cannula and sheath were removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression. No immediate complication occurred, and the patient was discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition.
