Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Intravascular foreign body in the pulmonary arteries. Patient underwent kyphoplasty at outside hospital with extravasation of cement that embolized with a few fragments in the bilateral peripheral pulmonary arteries as well as one longer thin fragment across the bifurcation of the right and left pulmonary arteries. Patient is symptomatic and short of breath.  Procedure:   1.	Ultrasound guided right common femoral venous access.  2.	Catheterization of the main, left main, and right main pulmonary arteries. 3.	Arteriogram of the left main pulmonary artery. 4.	Attempted intravascular foreign body retrieval.  Findings:   1.	Largest fragment noted on fluoroscopy across the bifurcation of the left and right pulmonary arteries. 2.	Post procedure fragmentation of the largest cement fragment that travel further into segmental left pulmonary artery branches.    Impression:   1.	 Attempted retrieval of largest cement fragment. The brittle thin cement fragment fractured during the procedure and travelled distally.  Treatment Plan:   Attempted retrieval of thin cement fragment that fractured during attempted retrieval. As discussed with the family prior to the procedure, it is preferred for the fragments to be smaller and distal rather than in the main pulmonary artery.  Recommend 6 months anticoagulation to allow time for the fragments to endothelialize and prevent clot formation. This recommendation is based on the available literature.  Technique:   The patient was placed supine on the fluoroscopy table. The right groin was prepped and draped in typical sterile fashion. Under continuous ultrasound guidance, using micropuncture technique, the right common femoral vein was accessed. A wire was advanced.  A 10 French sheath was advanced into the right common femoral vein. An [HCW]gled pigtail catheter was used to catheterize the main pulmonary artery, taking care not to pass through cordae tendinae. The catheter was then directed into the right main pulmonary artery where the free edge of the cement fragment was located. Catheter was exchanged for a long 8 French sheath. An ensnare was then advanced through the sheath, and used to grasp the free end of the fragment in the right pulmonary artery.  During this process, the cement fragment fractured twice into smaller pieces which traveled distally into the left segmental pulmonary arteries. Left pulmonary arteriogram was performed demonstrating patent left pulmonary artery with distal location of the cement fragments. It was determined that these could not be retrieved safely in their current location.  All sheaths were removed, and hemostasis was achieved with manual compression. A sterile dressing was applied. DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: This is a 52 years Female who presents for diagnostic cerebral angiography following transfer for a subacute clot in the right MCA.   PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 30 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] was the fellow. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right Common Carotid Artery Right Internal Carotid Artery Right External Carotid Artery Left Common Carotid Artery Left Internal Carotid Artery Left External Carotid Artery Left Vertebral Artery   ANESTHESIA: Local in the right groin with bupivacaine. Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by the nurse present during the entire procedure. The patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Sedation was administered by a specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for the duration of the procedure as outlined above (Total intra service time, 30min ). Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.  MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine SQ 10 cc  Versed 1 mg IV Fentanyl 50 mcg IV Heparin 3000 units IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.038" Bentson guidewire 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 5 French Vertebral catheter  Cardiva Vascade Visipaque-270 contrast material (100 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 5 French sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP, Lateral and Oblique views. Given this patient's good clinical exam, the decision was made not to pursue any intervention discomfort in the distal right M1 segment of the MCA and continue with medical management.  3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY:  Rotational angiography was also performed from the diagnostic catheter in the right internal carotid artery for better delineation of the underlying angioarchitecture. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.    Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a Vascade followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: Noninvasive imaging.  FINDINGS:  LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: The distal left internal carotid artery and its segments are normal in course and caliber. The MCA and its branches are normal in course and caliber. The left A1 segment of the ACA supplies the bilateral ACA territories. There are extensive collaterals from the right distal ACA branches into the right MCA territory. There are no underlying aneurysms or significant stenosis. There is normal cortical venous drainage.  LEFT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. Reflux of contrast into the contralateral vertebral artery was not achieved. The origin of PICA is normal unilaterally (we will defer to CTA for evaluation of the contralateral PICA). The basilar artery and its branches are unremarkable. There are numerous collaterals with the posterior aspect of the right MCA territory from the right PCA.  RIGHT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CERVICAL: The bifurcation is smooth, without irregularity, calcification, or stenosis with respect to the distal ICA. The ECA branches opacify normally.  RIGHT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is an inferiorly directed right posterior communicating artery aneurysm measuring 5.5 x 5 mm with a 3.5 mm neck. The right posterior communicating artery originates at the base of this aneurysm. The aneurysm itself is mildly irregular in shape. In addition, there is a subocclusive clot at the right MCA bifurcation with slow filling of the MCA branches distally. There is occlusion of multiple distal M3 branches. Upon review of imaging from collaterals with the ACA and PCA territories, the majority of the territory supplied by these branches fills from these collaterals. The right A1 segment of the ACA is hypoplastic with early washout of contrast suggesting dominant flow from the contralateral hemisphere.  3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: 3D Rotational angiography with volume-rendered three-dimensional reconstruction on an independent workstation, demonstrated the previously described inferiorly directed right posterior communicating artery aneurysm measuring 5.5 x 5 mm with a 3.8 mm neck. The right posterior communicating artery originates at the base of this aneurysm. There is redemonstration of the subocclusive clot at the distal M1 and MCA bifurcation with filling of the M2 branches distally.  COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: There is an inferiorly directed right posterior communicating artery aneurysm measuring 5.5 x 5 mm with a 3.8 mm neck. This aneurysm itself is mildly irregular in shape and the posterior communicating artery itself arises from the base of this aneurysm.   In addition, there is a subocclusive clot noted in the distal right M1 segment and MCA bifurcation with slow filling of the M2 branches. There are occlusions of multiple distal M3 segments of the right MCA. The majority of the right MCA territory is supplied by collaterals with the distal ACA and PCA branches. No intervention was pursued given the patient's good clinical exam on optimal medical management.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Hyperbilirubinemia secondary to malignant biliary obstruction.  Procedure:   1.	Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram 2.	Placement of percutaneous transhepatic external biliary drain  Findings:   1.	Occlusion of the common bile duct secondary to extrinsic compression from known mass.  Impression:   1.	Technically successful percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography and drainage catheter placement into segment 4B duct.  Plan:  1.	Open to bag drainage.  2.	Return within 1 week as inpatient for repeat attempt at drain internalization.  Technique:   The anterior abdominal wall and bilateral flanks were prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier.  An appropriate skin entry site was identified using fluoroscopy and ultrasound, and anesthetized with local.  Under fluoroscopic guidance, a 22G Chiba needle was advanced into the liver.  A bile duct was entered and the biliary system was opacified with contrast. Cholangiographic images were obtained.  A 0.018" wire was passed centrally, and the needle exchanged for a 6 French transitional dilator. The inner stiffener, dilator, and 0.018" wire were removed and contrast was injected to confirm location.  A 0.035" Glidewire was placed through the catheter, and the catheter subsequently removed.   Drain placement: Finally, an 10.2 French all-purpose (external) biliary drain was placed over the wire. The anchor/loop was formed and locked. Attention was paid that side holes were positioned within the biliary system. Contrast was injected to confirm location. The catheter was secured to the skin with 2-0 suture material and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.  Contrast was injected through the existing biliary drainage catheter and cholangiographic images obtained.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  pancreatic cancer  Procedure:   1. The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen Bard power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed below.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 2-0 absorbable sutures.     Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication.   Procedural Personnel Advanced practice provider(s): [HCW]  Complications: No immediate complications. CLINICAL INDICATION: This is a 70 years Male with large left intracranial mass, here for preoperative embolization.   PROCEDURE: Diagnostic angiogram. Intracranial particle embolization of a large left intracranial mass through the bilateral middle meningeal arteries.   DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 2 hrs.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician.  He supervised the entire procedure. [HCW] and [HCW] were the fellows. They both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right Internal Carotid Artery Right External Carotid Artery Right Middle Meningeal Artery Left Internal Carotid Artery Left External Carotid Artery Left Middle Meningeal Artery   VESSELS TREATED: Right Middle Meningeal Artery Left Middle Meningeal Artery  ANESTHESIA: General endotracheal anesthesia was administered under the supervision of the attending anesthesiologist. Pre-, intra-, and post-anesthesia monitoring records are available in the chart.  MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine SQ 10 cc  Heparin 5000 units IV Protamine 25 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 6 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 0.035" Bentson guidewire 0.035" Terumo exchange-length glidewire  5 French Merit Performa Vertebral catheter Excelsior 1018 microcatheter Transcend-EX microguidewire Contour PVA embolization particles (250-355 microns) Cardiva Vascade Visipaque 270 contrast material (120 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, spinal cord infarction, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, hemorrhage, nontargeted embolization, necrosis of skin or mucus membranes, renal failure, limb loss, death, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.  After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite, intubated, and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the Right femoral artery; a 6 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath was introduced into the Right femoral artery. 5000  units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was completed of the above vessels. Digital angiograms were performed centered over the head and face.   Following access into the Right external carotid artery, 2 mg of intra-arterial milrinone was administered for vasospasm noted in the proximal portion of the right middle meningeal artery. A run was performed of the Right external carotid artery following injection.  Super selective catheterization of the right middle meningeal artery was then performed with the [VENDOR]sior 1018 microcatheter and transcend-EX microguidewire. Due to vasospasm of the middle meningeal artery, the decision was made to move to the left middle meningeal artery to allow for resolution of the vasospasm. The diagnostic catheter was transferred to the left external carotid artery and converted to a guide catheter.  Superselective catheterization of the Left middle meningeal artery was then performed with the Excelsior 1018 microcatheter and Transcend-EX microguidewire. Contour PVA particles were prepared on an adjacent table and maintained in isobaric suspension with appropriate quantities of saline and contrast and injected into the Left middle meningeal artery using a pulse-spray technique over several minutes. Control angiograms of this vessel were performed before, during, and after the embolization.   Attention was then turned to the right middle meningeal artery and the diagnostic catheter was transferred to the right external carotid artery and once again, converted to the guide catheter. [HCW]rselective catheterization of the Right middle meningeal artery was then performed with the Excelsior 1018 microcatheter and Transcend-EX microguidewire. An injury was noted while traversing the frontal branch of the right middle meningeal artery feeding into a fistulous connection. Contour PVA particles were prepared on an adjacent table and maintained in isobaric suspension with appropriate quantities of saline and contrast and injected into the Right middle meningeal artery using a pulse-spray technique over several minutes. Control angiograms of this vessel were performed before, during, and after the embolization. It was noted after infusion of particles, that this fistulous connection was still present. The decision was made to proceed with coil embolization of the frontal branch of the right middle meningeal artery. The following coils were deployed:  Hydrosoft 3D 1mm x 3cm Hydrosoft 3D 1.5mm x 3cm Optimax Complex 1mm x 3 cm Optimax Complex 1mm x 2 cm Optimax Complex 1.5mm x 2 cm Optimax Complex 10 1mm x 3 cm Hydrosoft 3D 1.5mm x 4cm Optimax Complex 2mm x 6 cm Optimax Complex 2mm x 6 cm  Following deployment of these coils, the microcatheter was removed, and a run through the guide catheter was performed following deployment of these coils which demonstrated no residual fistulous connection. A final run was performed of the right common carotid artery.  An XPER CT scan was completed to evaluate for any underlying hematoma.  Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a Cardiva Vascade followed by manual compression. A Tegaderm was then applied over the puncture site.  COMPARISON: noninvasive imaging.  FINDINGS:   RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: The distal right internal carotid artery and its segments are normal course and caliber. The MCA and its branches are normal course and caliber. The right A1 segment of the ACA supplies the bilateral ACA territories. There is a markedly rightward bowing of the bilateral ACA branches likely from underlying mass effect from the mass. There is a branch of the left ACA which appears to supply the mass itself although the mass does not demonstrate significant vascularity on this injection. There are no underlying aneurysms or significant stenoses. There is normal cortical venous drainage.  RIGHT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: The frontal branch of the right middle meningeal artery traverses midline and appears to supply the medial aspect of the left parafalcine mass. The remaining branches of the external carotid artery are unremarkable. There is no evidence of underlying fistula.   LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: The distal left internal carotid artery and its segments are normal course and caliber. The posterior communicating artery is dominant supplies the posterior cerebral artery territory. There is an anterior falcine branch which originates at the ophthalmic artery which appears to supply a small anterior portion of the mass. The MCA and its branches are normal course and caliber. The left A1 segment of the ACA supplies the bilateral ACA territories. There is a markedly rightward bowing of the bilateral ACA branches likely from underlying mass effect from the mass. There is a branch of the left ACA which appears to supply the mass itself although the mass does not demonstrate significant vascularity on this injection. The same branch was visualized on the contralateral injection. There are no underlying aneurysms or significant stenoses. There is normal cortical venous drainage.  LEFT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: The frontal branch of the left middle meningeal artery traverses midline and appears to supply the lateral aspect of the left parafalcine mass. This vessel is of an increased caliber when compared to the parietal branch of the middle meningeal artery. The remaining branches of the external carotid artery are unremarkable. There is no evidence of underlying fistula.   LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. Reflux of contrast into the contralateral vertebral artery was achieved. The origin of PICA is normal bilaterally. The basilar artery and its branches are unremarkable.  RIGHT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY (PRE INTRA-ARTERIAL INJECTION OF MILRINONE), CEREBRAL: No anastomosis resulting in ipsilateral ophthalmic artery or intracranial perfusion is identified. There is mild to moderate vasospasm of the proximal portion of the right middle meningeal artery.  RIGHT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY (POST INTRA-ARTERIAL INJECTION OF MILRINONE), CEREBRAL: No anastomosis resulting in ipsilateral ophthalmic artery or intracranial perfusion is identified. There remains moderate vasospasm of the right middle meningeal artery around the foramen spinosum.  LEFT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No anastomosis resulting in ipsilateral ophthalmic artery or intracranial perfusion is identified.   LEFT MIDDLE MENINGEAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL (PRE-EMBOLIZATION): No anastomoses with the right ophthalmic artery are demonstrated. No arteriovenous shunting or dural fistula is seen. There is redemonstration of filling of the left parafalcine mass from the distal branch of the frontal meningeal artery.  LEFT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-EMBOLIZATION): Interval embolization of the frontal branch of the middle meningeal artery with significant stagnation of flow. No other vessel occlusions are identified. The tumor blush of the left parafalcine mass is no longer visualized.  RIGHT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No anastomosis resulting in ipsilateral ophthalmic artery or intracranial perfusion is identified. There remains mild vasospasm of the proximal portion of the right middle meningeal artery.  RIGHT MIDDLE MENINGEAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL (PRE-EMBOLIZATION): There is a direct arteriovenous fistula between the frontal branch of the middle meningeal artery and dural draining veins. There remains filling of the left parasagittal mass.   RIGHT MIDDLE MENINGEAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST TUMOR EMBOLIZATION): Interval embolization of the distal portion of the frontal branch of the right middle meningeal artery with significant stagnation of flow no residual filling of the left parasagittal mass. There remains the iatrogenic direct arteriovenous fistula between the frontal branch of the middle meningeal artery and the dural draining veins.  RIGHT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST RIGHT MIDDLE MENINGEAL ARTERY COIL EMBOLIZATION): Interval coil embolization of the right middle meningeal artery with coils. The direct arteriovenous fistula is no longer visible. There is no early draining vein. The remaining vessels of the external carotid artery are normal course and caliber.  COMPLICATIONS: Iatrogenic right middle meningeal artery dural arteriovenous fistula status-post coil embolization  IMPRESSION: 1.	Successful intracranial PVA embolization through bilateral middle meningeal artery for preoperative embolization of a left parasagittal mass. Procedure complicated by iatrogenic right middle meningeal artery dural arteriovenous fistula which was successfully embolized with coils.   HEAD CT WITHOUT IV CONTRAST  INDICATION: Preoperative embolization of a left parasagittal mass via bilateral middle meningeal arteries: Rule out hemorrhage following iatrogenic right middle meningeal artery dural arteriovenous fistula.   TECHNIQUE: XPER computed tomography images were obtained. Axial images from the skull base to the vertex were reconstructed.   COMPARISON: Preprocedure head CT.   FINDINGS:  The limitations of the XPER CT technique need to be noted. There is no evidence of contrast staining in the right hemisphere. There is no definite evidence of any intraparenchymal or extra-axial hemorrhage. There is no evidence of any large areas of hypodensity but the resolution of the XPER CT technique does not allow for proper definition of early infarcts. There is no evidence of significant mass effect or midline shift. The ventricles are normal in size shape and position.   IMPRESSION:  There is no evidence of any intraparenchymal or extra-axial hemorrhage. If clinically indicated brain MRI with gradient echo sequence would be helpful to establish the presence of hemorrhage.

All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissues overlying the vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle. An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the dialysis catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The venotomy tract was dilated to allow introduction of a peel-away sheath.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. Level by level technique:   -Vertebral level:  L3 kyphoplasty -Pedicle access:  Unipedicular -Access trocar gauge:  10-gauge curved trochar -Balloon utilized:  20 mm  Prior to injection of cement, balloons were inserted and inflated under biplane fluoroscopy. Cement injection was stopped once there was adequate fill of the vertebral body. Trochars were removed with hemostasis obtained with focal compression. Static fluoroscopic images were obtained after removal of all needles documenting final cement position. DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM, ASPIRATION THROMBECTOMY  CLINICAL INDICATION: 59-year-old L with past medical history admission for gastric ulcer status post exploratory laparotomy, found to have a left MCA syndrome with left M1 occlusion.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 45 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW], was the attending physician. He supervised the entire procedure. [HCW] was the fellow. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Left common carotid artery Left internal carotid artery Right common femoral artery  ANESTHESIA: General. Pre-, intra-, and post-anesthesia monitoring records are available in the chart.  MEDICATIONS:  Heparin 5000 U   MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 6 French Pinnacle Terumo Sheath (as a transitional dilator) 8 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 8 French walrus balloon guide catheter 0.038" Bentson Guidewire 0.035" Terumo Glidewire 5 French penumbra 7 1 catheter APRO 70 Aspiration Catheter  Marksman microcatheter (160 cm) [HCW] 018 microguidewire (200 cm) Angio-Seal closure device Omnipaque-300 contrast (80 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the agents family. Specifically, the risks of intracranial or systemic hemorrhage, cerebral infarction, distal emboli, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, device malfunction, groin hematoma, arterial dissection/laceration, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite, intubated, and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; an 8 French sheath was introduced into the right common femoral artery. The 8 French walrus balloon guide-catheter and 5 diagnostic catheter were introduced into the left common carotid artery as a system. An angiogram was completed of the common carotid artery to visualize the carotid bifurcation. The diagnostic catheter was then used to select the internal carotid artery over a Terumo Glidewire. The balloon guide catheter was then advanced into the cervical internal carotid artery over the wire and diagnostic catheter. The wire and diagnostic catheter were then removed and the balloon guide was connected to a continual heparinized saline flush. Digital angiograms were performed centered over the head.   The initial TICI score was 0, left M1.  The APRO 70 aspiration catheter was then snaked up to the face of the occlusion and aspiration was applied via the Vac-Lok syringes. The balloon on the balloon guide catheter was inflated. The aspiration catheter was removed after 2 minutes. The balloon was deflated and an angiogram showed recanalization was achieved with TICI 2A  A second pass was performed. The [VENDOR]man microcatheter and [VENDOR]kai 018 microguidewire (200 cm)microwire were then advanced through the guide catheter passed the superior division M2 occlusion. The APRO 70 aspiration catheter was then tracked to the face of the clot. The microcatheter and wire were removed. The balloon on the guide catheter was inflated. The aspiration catheter was then removed under continuous aspiration using Vac-Lok syringe. Thrombus was not found in the aspirate.  The balloon on the guide was deflated and a cerebral angiogram was performed through the guide catheter. Recanalization of the left MCA was achieved with revascularization of the distal territory consistent with TICI 2B 67.  An angiogram of the right common femoral artery was obtained; the artery was deemed appropriate for use of the 8 French Angio-Seal closure device. The sheath was removed and hemostasis obtained by deployment of the Angio-Seal closure device. A Tegaderm was then applied over the puncture site.  COMPARISON: CTA head and neck same date.  FINDINGS:  LEFT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CERVICAL: There is a smooth but slightly irregular mild stenosis at the proximal internal carotid artery. The visualized ECA branches opacify normally.  LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: A left M1 occlusion is identified consistent with TICI 0.    LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-THROMBECTOMY, PASS 1):  Reperfusion has been reestablished consistent with TICI 2A. There is a residual superior division M2 occlusion.  LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-THROMBECTOMY, PASS 2):  Reperfusion has been reestablished consistent with TICI 2B67. There is a residual M4 occlusion of the superior division MCA.  RIGHT FEMORAL ARTERY: No abnormalities are detected. This vessel is suitable for use of the Angio-Seal closure device.  COMPLICATIONS: none immediate.  IMPRESSION:  1. Left M1 occlusion with initial occlusion consistent with TICI 0.  2. Left MCA with reperfusion consistent with TICI 2B 67.

CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM AND ONYX EMBOLIZATION OF A INTRANIDAL ANEURYSMS  CLINICAL INDICATION: 29-year-old female with no significant past medical history who presented with one week of right facial weakness was discovered to have a right CP angle arteriovenous malformation. A 6 French Terum[VENDOR] Pinnacle sheath was introduced into the right common femoral artery. 5000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement; additional boluses of heparin were administered at one-hour intervals, and ACT was checked to maintain values between 250-300. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of the arteries listed above. Digital angiograms were performed centered over the head and skull base.   3D rotational angiography of the right vertebral artery was performed with the guide catheter in the distal V2 segment for better evaluation of the angioarchitecture of the arteriovenous malformation. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.   Superselective catheterization of the accessory superior cerebellar artery was performed with the Apollo 1.5cm detachable tip microcatheter and [VENDOR] X10 microguidewire and a superselective angiogram was performed. 0.7 cc of DMSO was then infused in a timed fashion and Onyx-18 liquid embolic agent was injected under blank roadmap technique over several minutes. The microcatheter was removed without difficulty. A final control angiogram was performed to assess for residual aneurysm or for distal emboli.  Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine.  An angiogram of the right common femoral artery was obtained to confirm that the arterial puncture was above the bifurcation and not retroperitoneal. Ancef was administered.  Hemostasis was achieved by application of a 6 Fr Mynx . A Tegaderm was then applied over the puncture site.  COMPARISON: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram from [DATE].  FINDINGS:  RIGHT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: Revisualized is an arteriovenous malformation in the region of the right brachium pontis as seen on prior angiogram and MRI which is supplied by large hypertrophied pontine perforators as well as small feeders from the right PICA and SCA. Unchanged intranidal aneurysms which are likely source of the patient's symptoms via mass effect on cranial nerve VII. Drainage is via the IPS to the right sigmoid sinus and intercavernous sinus as well as an ectatic cerebellar vein over the left hemisphere to the left sigmoid sinus.   RIGHT-SIDED HYPERTROPHIED PONTINE PERFORATOR (SUPERSELECTIVE): The catheter is intravascular and proximal to the aneurysms. No perfusion of normal brain tissue is noted.  RIGHT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL (status post Onyx embolization): Post-treatment surveillance angiography demonstrates interval embolization of arteriovenous malformation feeding artery. There is Onyx embolization material within the nidus. The previously seen intranidal aneurysms are no longer visualized.. No perfusion deficits to suggest distal emboli are identified.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT VERTEBRAL ARTERY:  3-D rotational angiography demonstrated the aforementioned arteriovenous malformation with intranidal aneurysms as described above. The larger of the 2 intracranial aneurysms which originates off of one of the hypertrophy pontine perforators is highly irregular and multilobulated and measures roughly 5.8 x 4.3 x 2.4 mm (axial by neck-to-dome by neck)..   RIGHT COMMON FEMORAL ARTERY: The arteriotomy is above the bifurcation of the right common femoral artery. There is a small amount of narrowing of the common femoral artery just distal to the arteriotomy which may represent vasospasm. The arteriotomy was closed with 6 French Mynx.  COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION:  Successful Onyx embolization of right brachium pontis arteriovenous malformation intranidal aneurysms which were the likely source of the patient's facial weakness via mass effect on the 7th cranial nerve..

DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM, SOLUMBRA THROMBECTOMY AND INTRACRANIAL STENTING FOR STENOSIS  CLINICAL INDICATION: 55-year-old Male with a PMH of hypertension and diabetes presenting with right middle cerebral artery syndrome with CTA demonstrating subocclusive blockage of the M1 segment of the right middle cerebral artery and favorable ASPECTS. The patient did not receive IV tPA because he was out of window. Mechanical thrombectomy was indicated.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 120 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW], [HCW], was the attending physician. He supervised the entire procedure. [HCW], was the fellow. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right internal carotid artery Right middle cerebral artery Right common femoral artery  ANESTHESIA: General. Pre-, intra-, and post-anesthesia monitoring records are available in the chart.  MEDICATIONS:  Heparin 5000 IU IV  Aspirin 300 mg PR Aggrastat 12.5 mcg/kg bolus followed by 0.15 mcg/kg/m IV Ancef 2 g  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 9 French Stryker sheath  8 French Walrus balloon guide catheter 0.035" [VENDOR]son Guidewire 5 French Merit Performa Vertebral selection catheter (125 cm) 0.035" Terumo Glidewire (180 cm) Zoom 71 Aspiration Catheter (132 cm) Marksman microcatheter (160 cm) Asahi 018 microguidewire (200 cm) Trevo NXT 4 x 41 mm Stentriever device  Sofia 6 French 125 cm catheter Onyx frontier 2 mm x 15 mm balloon mounted drug-eluting stent Asahi 014 microguidewire (200 cm) 8 French Angio-Seal closure device Omnipaque-300 contrast (180 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient's family (medical proxy). Specifically, the risks of intracranial or systemic hemorrhage, cerebral infarction, distal emboli, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, device malfunction, groin hematoma, arterial dissection/laceration, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite, intubated, and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 9 French sheath was introduced into the right common femoral artery . The 8 French Walrus balloon guide-catheter and 5 French diagnostic long selection catheter were introduced into the right internal carotid artery as a system over the Terumo Glidewire.The wire and diagnostic catheter were then removed and the balloon guide was connected to a continual heparinized saline flush. Digital angiograms were performed centered over the head.   There was a subocclusive clot/stenosis within the M1 segment of the right middle cerebral artery with resultant delayed flow through the right MCA territory as compared to the ACA territory.  The Marksman microcatheter and Asahi 018 microwire were then advanced through the Zoom 71  aspiration catheter into the guide catheter as a system past the right M1 occlusion. The wire was removed from the microcatheter, and intravascular position was confirmed with contrast injection. The Trevo NXT stentriever device was then tacked up the microcatheter and the stentriever was deployed under fluoroscopy. A run was performed through the aspiration catheter with the stentriever was deployed with resultant improved flow through the right middle cerebral artery. With the stentriever in place and deployed, there was no significant delay between the right middle cerebral artery and right anterior cerebral artery territories. The Zoom 71 aspiration catheter was then tracked to the face of the clot with continuous aspiration on through the Penumbra aspiration machine.  Once in place, the aspiration catheter was noted to be 'plugged' with occlusive suction against the clot.  The balloon on the guide catheter was then inflated. The stentriever was then removed under continuous aspiration using a 60cc locking syringe system. Thrombus was not  identified within the stentriever device or the aspirate.  The balloon on the guide was deflated and a cerebral angiogram was performed through the guide catheter. As compared with the immediate prior run or the stentriever was deployed, there is slight delay in the filling of the MCA territory compared to the ACA territory, but not quite to baseline. Additional repeat run showed progressive slowing of the perfusion of right MCA as compared to the ACA territory. The decision was to proceed with placement of intracranial stent. An XperCT was performed to evaluate for any evidence of hemorrhage. XperCT showed no evidence of intracranial hemorrhage. 300 mg of aspirin was given PR. And Aggrastat bolus of 12.5 mcg/kg was administered IV followed by a drip of 0.15 mcg/kg/m.  3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY:  Rotational angiography was also performed from the diagnostic catheter in the cervical right internal carotid artery for better delineation of the underlying angioarchitecture and measurement of the vessel caliber for sizing of the stent. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.    The marksman microcatheter and Asahi 18 microguidewire were then advanced through the 6 French Sofia catheter into the balloon guide catheter to the ophthalmic segment of the ICA. The marksman microcatheter and Asahi microguidewire were removed. The Onyx frontier drug-eluting stent was advanced through the Sofia guide catheter over and Asahi 014 microguidewire. Under fluoroscopic guidance it was advanced over the Asahi 014 microguidewire across the area of subtotal occlusion. The balloon was inflated submaximal to 7 atm (opening diameter of 1.85 mm for the stent).  The balloon was deflated and a run was performed through the Sofia guide catheter after was pulled down into the petrous segment of the ICA. There is noted to be improved caliber and contrast opacification of the previously partially occluded M1 segment with improved filling of the distal MCA territory with which was now in phase with the ACA territory. There is no evidence of distal perfusion deficit.  An angiogram of the right common femoral artery was obtained; the artery was deemed appropriate for use of the 8 French Angio-Seal closure device. The sheath was removed and hemostasis obtained by deployment of the 8 French Angio-Seal closure device. A Tegaderm was then applied over the puncture site.  COMPARISON: CTA from same date.  FINDINGS:  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is a subocclusive clot/stenosis within the M1 segment of the right middle cerebral artery with resultant delayed flow through the right MCA territory as compared to the ACA territory.  RIGHT MIDDLE CEREBRAL ARTERY, SUPERSELECTIVE: The microcatheter in intravascular and distal to the partial occlusion.     RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (STENTRIEVER DEPLOYED): Improved flow through the right middle cerebral artery with no significant delay between the right middle cerebral artery and right anterior cerebral artery territories   RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-THROMBECTOMY PASS):  As compared with the immediate prior run or the stentriever was deployed, there is slight delay in the filling of the MCA territory compared to the ACA territory, but not quite to baseline.    RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (DELAYED POST-THROMBECTOMY): Additional repeat run showed progressive slowing of the perfusion of right MCA as compared to the ACA territory.   RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-STENTING): There is noted to be improved caliber and contrast opacification of the previously partially occluded M1 segment with improved filling of the distal MCA territory with which was now in phase with the ACA territory. There is no evidence of distal perfusion deficit.  RIGHT FEMORAL ARTERY: No abnormalities are detected. This vessel is suitable for use of the 8 French Angio-Seal closure device.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: 3D Rotational angiography with volume-rendered three-dimensional reconstruction on an independent workstation, demonstrated the aforementioned subocclusive clot/stenosis within the M1 segment of the right middle cerebral artery. This 3-D imaging was obtained in order to permit more precise measurement of the vessel caliber for sizing of the intracranial stent..   COMPLICATIONS: none immediate.  IMPRESSION:  1. Right middle cerebral artery subocclusive clot/stenosis within the M1 segment of the right middle cerebral artery with resultant delayed flow through the right MCA territory as compared to the ACA territory.   2. Successful placement of Onyx frontier drug-eluting stent within the stenotic/partially occluded M1 segment with resultant significantly improved distal perfusion and resolution of the delay between the MCA and ACA territory.  *Patient will need to remain on DAPT for period of one year following placement of drug-eluting stent.   HEAD CT WITHOUT IV CONTRAST  INDICATION: Right MCA stroke status post endovascular procedure: Rule out hemorrhage.   TECHNIQUE: XPER computed tomography images were obtained. Axial images from the skull base to the vertex were reconstructed.   COMPARISON: Preprocedure head CT.   FINDINGS:  The limitations of the XPER CT technique need to be noted. There is no evidence of contrast staining in the right hemisphere. There is no definite evidence of any intraparenchymal hemorrhage. There is no evidence of any large areas of hypodensity but the resolution of the XPER CT technique does not allow for proper definition of early infarcts. There is no evidence of significant mass effect or midline shift. The ventricles are normal in size shape and position.   IMPRESSION:  There is no evidence of contrast staining in the right hemisphere. No definite evidence of any intraparenchymal hemorrhage. If clinically indicated brain MRI with gradient echo sequence would be helpful to establish the presence of hemorrhage.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].1  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Recurrent metastatic breast cancer; port dysfunction and associated chest wall pain.  Procedure:   1.	Right portogram 2.	Left port placement 3.	Right port removal  Findings:   1.	Expected appearance of preexisting right port with catheter intact and tip overlying the cavoatrial junction. 2.	On portogram, contrast opacifies the reservoir and catheter and demonstrates normal flow in the right atrium. However, there is significant difficulty aspirating. 3.	Patent and compressible left internal jugular vein on ultrasound. 4.	Image-guided placement of a left port with catheter tip in the right atrium on post-procedure imaging. 5.	Removal of preexisting right port en-bloc.  Catheter: Left transjugular Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen Bard port (standard profile)  Impression:   1.	Right portogram without radiologic abnormality. However, the port functions poorly possibly due to partial occlusion, extrinsic compression, or fibrin cap that is not evidence on imaging. 2.	Placement of a left transjugular port, which is ready to use immediately. 3.	Removal of the preexisting right port en bloc.  Treatment Plan:   IR follow up as needed.  Technique:   The anterior chest wall on both sides and the neck on both dies were prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The port was accessed with a Huber needle. Contrast was injected through the needle into the port reservoir and port catheter. Digital subtraction angiograms were obtai[HCW] under fluoroscopy. Images were reviewed and saved in PACS. The access needle was removed from the port.  Attention was turned to the left neck and chest. The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the left internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the left internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the left internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the left chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution, both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the left chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 3-0 absorbable sutures. A running 4-0 absorbable subcuticular stitch and  Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with a single subcuticular stitch and Dermabond.   Attention was returned to the right chest. The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right chest were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic. An incision was made. The port pocket was accessed using sharp and blunt dissection. The port catheter was removed en bloc.    The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 3-0 absorbable sutures. Dermabond was used to close the skin. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by nurse present during the entire procedure. Patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Administered by the specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for a total of 75 minutes (Total intra service time). CEREBRAL  ANGIOGRAM AND MIDDLE MENINGEAL ARTERY EMBOLIZATION   CLINICAL INDICATION: 69-year-old gentleman with a symptomatic right hemispheric subdural hematoma status post burr hole evacuation. At that time the surgeon's report significant membranes; therefore, the patient presents for middle meningeal artery embolization. Patient has bilateral subdural, ascending colon, the left holohemispheric subdural is largely hyperdense indicative of relatively acute to subacute blood. In this instance with the fellow that membrane formation would likely be minimal and therefore the held off on embolization at this time. Embolization for the for the left side later.   PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram, middle meningeal artery embolization   DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 20.  OPERATORS: [HCW]. [HCW], PhD.   VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right internal carotid artery Right external carotid artery Right middle meningeal artery Right common femoral artery  VESSELS TREATED: Frontal division of the right middle meningeal artery  ANESTHESIA: General endotracheal anesthesia was administered under the supervision of the attending anesthesiologist. Pre-, intra-, and post-anesthesia monitoring records are available in the chart.  TOTAL MONITORED SEDATION TIME:      MEDICATIONS:  Heparin 5000 units IV Protamine 20 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: [VENDOR] Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 0.038" Bentson guidewire 5 French Merit Performa Vertebral catheter Excelsior 1018 microcatheter Asahi 014 microguidewire Contour PVA embolization particles (250-350 microns) Cardiva Vascade Omnipaque 300 contrast material (40 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, hemorrhage, nontargeted embolization, necrosis of skin or mucus membranes, renal failure, limb loss, death, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.  After informed, written consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion after intubation by the anesthesiology team.  Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 5000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following the sheath placement; additional boluses of heparin were administered at one-hour intervals. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of the above listed vessels. Digital angiograms were performed of these vessels, centered over the head.   Following the diagnostic portion of the angiogram, the Excelsior 1018 microcatheter and Asahi 14 microguidewire were passed coaxially through the diagnostic catheter into the middle meningeal artery artery. The large sphenoid branch with anastomosis to the lacrimal artery with competitive flow indicated a large caliber anastomosis between the middle meningeal artery and orbital vasculature via the recurrent meningeal artery. Given this configuration, the navigated our microcatheter quite distal into the frontal division to avoid reflux and potentially embolizing the retina. We specifically did not catheterize the parietal branches that had relatively little capacitance and reflux risk backing out to the common bifurcation sphenoid branch. Contour PVA particles were then prepared in the usual fashion with appropriate quantities of saline and contrast in order to maintain the particles in isobaric suspension and injected into the frontal division of the right middle meningeal artery using a pulse spray technique. A Gelfoam pledget was injected into the frontal division of the middle meningeal artery following the PVA embolization.   Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a Cardiva Vascade followed by manual compression. A Tegaderm was then applied over the puncture site.  COMPARISON: Axial imaging.  FINDINGS:  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: Normal arterial and venous anatomy. The choroidal blush is noted.  RIGHT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: Normal arterial and venous anatomy. The anastomosis from the middle meningeal to intraorbital circulation as described in detail above..  RIGHT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (STATUS POST EMBOLIZATION): The frontal division of the middle meningeal artery no longer opacifies. The parietal division as well as the sphenoid branch to recurrent meningeal and lacrimal arteries are all stable in appearance.  RIGHT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (STATUS POST EMBOLIZATION): Normal arterial venous anatomy. The choroidal blush is noted. Post embolization changes of the middle meningeal artery as described above.  COMPLICATIONS: none immediate.  IMPRESSION:  1. Successful middle meningeal artery embolization of the right side status post burr hole evacuation of a holohemispheric subdural.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Liver transplant, cirrhosis, and elevated liver function tests. Allergy to iodinated contrast.  Procedure:   Transjugular liver biopsy with pressure measurements  Findings:   1.	The right hepatic vein is diminutive. 2.	The biopsy specimen appeared adequate. 3.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. Needle entry was documented. 4.	Pressures:  a. Wedged hepatic pressure: 17 mm Hg b. Free hepatic pressure: 5 mm Hg c. Corrected Sinusoidal Pressure: 12 mm Hg  d. Right atrial: 3 mm Hg e. Infra-hepatic IVC: 4 mm Hg f. Post-anastomotic IVC: 3 mm Hg     Impression:   Successful image guided transjugular liver biopsy. Corrected sinusoidal pressure of 12 mm Hg.    Treatment Plan:  Follow up pathology results.  Technique:   The procedure, options, and risks were reviewed with patient, including bleeding, infection, and pneumothorax. A time out was performed before initiating the procedure.  The skin overlying the access site was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). Patient sedation was performed, as detailed below.  The right neck was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Using local anesthetic and ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was punctured with a 21 gauge needle with permanent reporting and recording. An image documenting vein patency and needle entry was stored and transferred to PACS. A 9 French sheath was placed at the neck. The sheath was advanced into the inferior vena cava, and right atrial, infrahepatic, and post anastomotic IVC pressures were obtained.  A Sos catheter was used to select the right hepatic vein and hepatic venography performed using carbon dioxide. Free and wedged hepatic pressures were obtained using the diagnostic catheter.  A lateral image was obtained to confirm appropriate positioning in the right hepatic vein posteriorly.  A 0.035” wire was placed in the hepatic vein and the 7 French [VENDOR] biopsy cannula was advanced over the wire. The wire was removed, and 3 passes made with the 18 gauge coaxial needle.  The specimen was placed in formalin and delivered to the laboratory.  The cannula and sheath were removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression. No immediate complication occurred, and the patient was discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. CEREBRAL  ANGIOGRAM AND MIDDLE MENINGEAL ARTERY EMBOLIZATION   CLINICAL INDICATION: 63-year-old gentleman with a symptomatic right hemispheric subdural hematoma status post burr hole evacuation.   PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram, middle meningeal artery embolization   DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 20.  OPERATORS: [HCW]. [HCW], PhD.   VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right internal carotid artery Right external carotid artery Right middle meningeal artery Right common femoral artery  VESSELS TREATED: Frontal division of the right middle meningeal artery  ANESTHESIA: General endotracheal anesthesia was administered under the supervision of the attending anesthesiologist. Pre-, intra-, and post-anesthesia monitoring records are available in the chart.  MEDICATIONS:  Heparin 5000 units IV Protamine 20 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 0.038" [HCW]idewire 5 French Merit Performa Vertebral catheter Excelsior 1018 microcatheter Asahi 014 microguidewire Contour PVA embolization particles (250-350 microns) Cardiva Vascade Omnipaque 300 contrast material (40 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, hemorrhage, nontargeted embolization, necrosis of skin or mucus membranes, renal failure, limb loss, death, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.  After informed, written consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion after intubation by the anesthesiology team.  Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 5000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following the sheath placement; additional boluses of heparin were administered at one-hour intervals. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of the above listed vessels. Digital angiograms were performed of these vessels, centered over the head.   Following the diagnostic portion of the angiogram, the [VENDOR]sior 1018 microcatheter and Asa[VENDOR] 14 microguidewire were passed coaxially through the diagnostic catheter into the middle meningeal artery artery. The large sphenoid branch with anastomosis to the lacrimal artery with competitive flow indicated a large caliber anastomosis between the middle meningeal artery and orbital vasculature via the recurrent meningeal artery. Given this configuration, the navigated our microcatheter quite distal into the frontal division to avoid reflux and potentially embolizing the retina. We specifically did not catheterize the parietal branches that had relatively little capacitance and reflux risk backing out to the common bifurcation sphenoid branch. Contour PVA particles were then prepared in the usual fashion with appropriate quantities of saline and contrast in order to maintain the particles in isobaric suspension and injected into the frontal division of the right middle meningeal artery using a pulse spray technique. A Gelfoam pledget was injected into the frontal division of the middle meningeal artery following the PVA embolization.   Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a Cardiva Vascade followed by manual compression. A Tegaderm was then applied over the puncture site.  COMPARISON: Axial imaging.  FINDINGS:  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: Normal arterial and venous anatomy. The choroidal blush is noted.  RIGHT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: Normal arterial and venous anatomy. The anastomosis from the middle meningeal to intraorbital circulation as described in detail above..  RIGHT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (STATUS POST EMBOLIZATION): Normal arterial venous anatomy. The choroidal blush is noted. Post embolization changes of the middle meningeal artery.  COMPLICATIONS: none immediate.  IMPRESSION:  1. Successful middle meningeal artery embolization of the right side status post burr hole evacuation of a holohemispheric subdural.

CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM WITH INTRA-ARTERIAL VERAPAMIL AND MILRINONE INFUSION FOR TREATMENT OF VASOSPASM  CLINICAL INDICATION: 41-year-old woman a complicated, an extended hospital stay following rupture of a left clinoid ICA aneurysm. He had known bilateral carotid artery saccular dysplasia with a left proximal cervical internal carotid artery dissection. That is being managed heparin. The patient also suffered from a moderate size left MCA distribution infarction shortly appreciated microsurgical clip ligation of her aneurysm therefore underwent decompressive hemicraniectomy. Overall the patient had stabilized and weaning her external ventricular drain was challenging. In an effort to normalize or intracranial compliance prior to determining if she needs permanent shunt, the patient underwent recent cranioplasty. She had been doing well until shortly before this intervention when she developed a change in exam was moving her right side less. Interval imaging was concerning for multifocal, sizable, left MCA distribution infarction and vasospasm of the left internal carotid artery and middle cerebral artery.  PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram. Intra-arterial milrinone and verapamil infusion in left common carotid artery.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 45.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician. He supervised the entire procedure. [HCW] was the fellow. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Left common carotid artery Right common carotid artery Right common femoral artery  VESSELS TREATED: Left common carotid artery  ANESTHESIA: General endotracheal anesthesia administered by anesthesia staff.   MEDICATIONS:  Heparin 5000 units IV Milrinone 10 mg IA (left common carotid artery) Verapamil 15 mg IA (left common carotid artery) Ancef 2 gram IV  MATERIALS:  5 French     micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 0.038" Bentson guidewire 0.035" Terumo exchange-length glidewire  5 French Simmons 3 Glide catheter Omnipaque 300 contrast material (80 cc) Perclose ProGlide closure device  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient's medical proxy. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, balloon rupture, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, heart block, hypotension, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery. A 6 French sheath was introduced into the right common femoral artery. 5000 units of heparin were administered intravenously after sheath placement; additional boluses of heparin were administered at one-hour intervals. Using fluoroscopic guidance, the left common carotid artery was selectively catheterized with the 5 French Simmons 3 catheter. Digital angiograms were performed centered over the cervical region then head.  The left proximal cervical internal carotid artery dissection is quite a bit worsened with a stenotic inflow into the dissection flap and pouch measuring approximately 1.3 mm in outflow measuring sub-0.5 mm.  Severe/critical left supraclinoid ICA and proximal M1 vasospasm.  10 mg of intra-arterial milrinone followed by 15 mg of intra-arterial verapamil were administered in the left common carotid artery using a pulse spray technique over 10 minutes. This resulted in moderate improvement follow-up angiography.  Given the extensive worsening of the dissection on the left we elected to evaluate the right side. Indeed, a new dissection with pseudoaneurysm was noted in the distal cervical internal carotid artery. On the cranial view the right anterior circulation cross filling of the left hand opacifies the left MCA distribution. There is washout indicative of continued antegrade flow on the left.  Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine.  An angiogram of the right common femoral artery was obtained to confirm that the arterial puncture was above the bifurcation that the vessels of adequate size to use a Perclose ProGlide. Ancef was administered.  Hemostasis was achieved by application of a Perclose ProGlide. A Tegaderm was then applied over the puncture site.  COMPARISON: Cerebral angiogram dated [DATE].  FINDINGS: LEFT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CERVICAL: The left proximal cervical internal carotid artery dissection is quite a bit worsened with a stenotic inflow into the dissection flap and pouch measuring approximately 1.3 mm in outflow measuring sub-0.5 mm.  LEFT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (PRE-SPASMOLYSIS): Severe/critical left supraclinoid ICA and proximal M1 vasospasm.  Surigcal clips are seen in the region of previously clipped supraclinoid ICA aneurysm. Perfusion through the MCA distribution is delayed.  LEFT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (IA SPASMOLYSIS): Moderately and through the supraclinoid ICA and proximal MCA vasospasm.   RIGHT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CERVICAL: Continued FMD changes. A new distal cervical ICA pseudoaneurysm is noted.  RIGHT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: Normal intracranial vasculature. The right anterior circulation opacifies the left A1 across the ICA terminus to the MCA distribution with washout indicative of continued antegrade left anterior circulation flow.  RIGHT COMMON FEMORAL ARTERY: The arteriotomy is above the bifurcation of the right common femoral artery and the diameter of the vessel is adequate for a Perclose ProGlide.  COMPLICATIONS: none immediate.  IMPRESSION:  1. Worsened left proximal cervical ICA dissection as described above.  2. Severe left supraclinoid ICA and MCA vasospasm treated with sure arterial spasmolytic stenosis as described above.  3. New distal cervical right ICA dissection with pseudoaneurysm.  4. Given the extent of left MCA distribution infarction at this time, we felt that stenting the worsened left proximal cervical ICA dissection was contraindicated given the requirement for dual antiplatelet therapy and the associated risks of post ischemic hemorrhage.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication: Chronic isolated right biliary ductal dilatation recently complicated by cholangitis s/p external biliary drainage. Multiple unsuccessful previous attempts to cross the biliary occlusion.  Procedure:   1.	Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram. 2.	SpyGlass cholangioscopy. 3.	Upsize/replacement of right external biliary drain.  Findings:   1.	Persistent biliary obstruction with isolation of right hepatic ducts. 2.	On cholangioscopy, the patient's TIPS stent was directly visualized transecting and obstructing a central bile duct. Normal-appearing biliary epithelium without focal areas of raised, friable, or hypervascular tissue. No stone disease. No biopsy performed. 3.	Upsize to 14 French Dawson-Mueller right external biliary drain.  Impression:   Findings discussed with internal medicine and hepatology. 1.	Cholangioscopy reveals biliary transection and occlusion by the TIPS stent. Complete right-sided biliary obstruction on cholangiography correlates. 2.	No focal suspicious intraductal lesions as detailed above. No biopsy performed. 3.	Successful right external biliary drain upsize to 14F (Dawson-Mueller type).  Plan:  1.	Right external drain to remain open to bag. 2.	Further management per hepatology, hepatobiliary surgery as warranted. 3.	Routine catheter exchange in approximately 3 months as needed. 4.	Findings suggested the TIPS transected bile duct or in placement has cause biliary obstruction since. Further management of this biliary obstruction or hepatology and surgery.  Technique:   The patient was transported to the interventional suite placed in the supine position. The right hemiabdomen was prepped and draped utilizing maximum sterile barrier technique. A call order was performed with all team members present and participating.  Scout imaging was obtained. Coronal angiogram was performed through the existing 8.5 French external drain with findings as detailed above. The stay suture and catheter were cut to release the locking loop. A Rosen wire was advanced through the catheter and the catheter was removed. Following serial tract dilatation, a 12 French peel-away sheath was inserted over the wire to allow for introduction of the Spyglass cholangioscope.   Cholangioscopy was then performed with findings as detailed above. . No biopsy was performed  The cholangioscope and sheath were then removed over the wire. A new 14 French by 25 cm external biliary drain ([HCW][HOSPITAL][HCW]) was advanced over the wire centrally to the level of the obstruction. The wire and stiffener were removed, and the cope loop was formed and locked. The catheter was secured with 2-0 Prolene.  The patient tolerated the procedure well without any evidence of immediate complication. She was discharged from the angiography suite under the direct care of anesthesiology. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Sickle cell disease  Procedure:   1.	Non-tunneled large bore central venous catheter placement  Findings:   1.	The left internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the large bore central venous catheter, as described, the tip terminates in the right atrium.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a 14 French,  20 cm, non-tunneled large bore central venous catheter via the left internal jugular vein.  Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care. The catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).   The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the left internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic. Ultrasound evaluation of the vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS. Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS.  A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, a 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   The venotomy tract was dilated to allow introduction of the catheter over the wire. The catheter was subsequently introduced over the wire and the wire removed. The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a peel-away sheath set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture peel-away sheath set, the wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.  Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS.
