Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Urine leak.  Procedure:   1.	Right nephrostogram(s) and nephrostomy tube replacement  Comparison: Previous exam [DATE].  Findings:    1.	Existing nephrostomy tube(s) in appropriate position on scout radiograph. 2.	Nephrostography demonstrates hydronephrosis without drainage into the urinary bladder.   Catheter:  10.2 F Cook nephrostomy tube(s)  Impression:   1.	Uneventful image-guided nephrostomy tube re-placement. 2.	Nephrostogram demonstrates absence of urine leak.  Treatment Plan:   Patient should return for routine check and change in 6-8 weeks.  Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained to the patient. Written informed consent was obtained. A time out/call to order was performed prior to procedure initiation.  The existing catheter(s) and surrounding soft tissues were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site. A scout radiograph was obtained.  Non-ionic contrast was injected through the existing nephrostomy tube(s) and images of the collecting system obtained and stored to PACS. There was no urine leak demonstrated in multiple obliquities.  An 0.035” wire was advanced through the nephrostomy tube. The tube was removed over the wire under direct fluoroscopic visualization. A new nephrostomy tube was advanced over the wire and the Cope loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis. Contrast injection confirmed appropriate location. The catheter was sutured to the flank with monofilament suture and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.  The procedure was well tolerated, and patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  [ID][HOSPITAL][ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Metastatic colorectal cancer to the liver.  Additional Clinical Information: Colorectal carcinoma with liver metastases  PROCEDURE:   1. US-guided left radial artery access 2. Diagnostic visceral angiography 3. Selective internal radioembolization with Yttrium-90  FINDINGS: ANGIOGRAPHY: Vessels catheterized and angiograms performed, as follows:  Celiac artery: Variant anatomy with separate origin of the common hepatic artery from the aorta and separate origin of the splenic artery from the aorta at the same level. Right hepatic artery: Tumoral blush identified. Segment 8 hepatic artery: Tumoral blush identified.  Specific technical notes / catheter selection: 2.4 Fr [HCW]  Transcatheter embolization using Yttrium-90 microspheres performed from: Right hepatic artery [HCW]nt 8 dorsal branch (series 3)  IMPRESSION:   Successful Yttrium-90 Sirspheres selective internal radiotherapy of a segment 8 hepatocellular carcinoma.  TREATMENT PLAN:  1. Patient will return to clinic in 6-8 weeks with abdominal MRI and labs.  2. Access site precautions and orders placed.  TECHNIQUE:  With the patient in the supine position, the left wrist was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The left wrist was evaluated with ultrasound and left ULNAR artery patency and acceptable size criteria were documented and images were properly stored in PACS. A modified Allen test (Barbeau test Type B) was performed on the left wrist to confirm patency of the ulnopalmar arch using pulse oximetry.   1% lidocaine solution was administered for local anesthesia. Access was obtained to the left ULNAR artery using a 21 gauge micro needle and ultrasound guidance. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. A wire was placed through the needle. A hydrophilic Glidesheath was advanced slowly over the wire. 3000 units of heparin, 200 mcg of nitroglycerin and 2.5 mg of verapamil was given through the arterial sheath with slow hemodilution. A side flush was started.   A 5-Fr [VENDOR]y/[VENDOR] catheter was advanced over an 0.035" wire into the abdominal aorta. The catheter was used to catheterize the visceral vessels described below. Angiograms were performed. A microcatheter system was used to catheterize distal visceral and hepatic vessels, as described below. Specific vessels catheterized and embolized are described in detail below. Tumor blush was confirmed on angiography.  Once the catheter was in adequate position, a pre-determined dose of 90-Yttrium radioactive particles was infused into the target hepatic artery. The microcatheter was flushed and the microcatheter was disposed of appropriately.   All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. A TR Band was placed on the left wrist for hemostasis. The access sheath was removed and no hematoma was seen. A radial artery pulse was confirmed distal to the puncture site confirming patent hemostasis.   The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications.   Additional Medications: Decadron 8 mg IV, Zofran 4 mg IV. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESR[HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Patient with sarcoma requiring IV chemotherapy  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen MedComp port (dignity)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen Medcomp power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed a.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 3-0 absorbable sutures and 4-0 running absorbable sutures.     Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with     Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]C.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Indwelling right upper extremity midline catheter, need for central venous access. Request is made for placement of a right upper extremity PICC.  Procedure:   1.	Double lumen PICC placement using ultrasound and fluoroscopy   Findings:   1.  Vein patency was documented by guidewire passes under fluoroscopy along the expected course of the right upper extremity veins, central veins, superior vena cava, and right atrium 2.  The catheter tip terminates in the mid right atrium.   Impression:   1.	Uneventful image guided placement of 5 French, 37 cm double-lumen PICC in the right upper extremity as described. The lumens flush and aspirate appropriately.     Treatment Plan:   Catheter tip position is confirmed as above. It is OK to use this line.    Technique:   The indwelling right upper arm midline catheter site was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).   A 0.018" wire was passed centrally through the indwelling midline catheter without resistance into the right atrium, and the midline catheter was exchanged for a dilator peel-away combination. The wire was used to determine catheter length, and a 5 French double-lumen PICC line cut to appropriate length. The tailored catheter was advanced through the peel-away and positioned centrally using fluoroscopy.   The peel-away was removed, and hemostasis achieved with manual compression. The catheter was aspirated, flushed, and locked per protocol. It was secured in place with Ethilon.  An antimicrobial disc and sterile dressing were applied.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition.   The PICC length is 37 cm from the hilum to the tip. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Acute lymphoblastic leukemia  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen port (standard profile)  Findings:   1.	The left internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled left internal jugular 6 French single lumen power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the left internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the left internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the left internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the left chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the left chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 3-0 absorbable sutures. Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Breast cancer, port not aspirating  Procedure:   Evaluation of the right internal jugular vein chest port utilizing contrast and fluoroscopy. US guided right common femoral vein access Port catheter stripping  Findings:   1. Right internal jugular chest port with tip overlying the cavoatrial junction. 2. Port and catheter tubing appear intact. The catheter flushes appropriately but does not aspirate. 3. TPA infusion performed in the pre-procedure area over 2 hours, with continued inability to aspirate blood 4. Digital subtraction angiogram demonstrates fibrin sheath at catheter tip.  5. After catheter stripping, digital subtraction angiogram demonstrates prompt jet of contrast with resolution of fibrin sheath. Port readily aspirates.  Impression:   Successful evaluation and stripping of the right internal jugular vein chest port. The catheter flushes and aspirates appropriately.   Treatment Plan:   1.	Port is ready for use 2.	Per discussion with the patient, she has been told by her oncologist that she will need this port for infusions likely for a long period of time. If short term recurrence of fibrin sheath, consider port removal and replacement.   Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).    Port check: On physical examination, the right chest wall incision was healed without cellulitis or skin breakdown. The patient arrived in the procedure room with the port accessed. There was no backflow of blood, however, there was easy forward flushing with saline. The fluoroscopic scout film showed proper port position without flipping, kinking, or catheter breakage. Contrast injection showed brisk flow into the SVC and heart with evidence of a fibrin sheath. There is no defect/crack/leak in the port. Attention was turned to the right groin.   Fibrin sheath stripping: Using ultrasound guidance a 21-gauge needle was used to access the right common femoral vein with real-time ultrasound guidance. Using modified Seldinger technique a 6 French vascular sheath was placed. Through the vascular sheath a snare device (Ensnare 6 French) was used to grab the inferior aspect of the port catheter. The fibrin sheath was stripped using the snare device. A snare device was removed. Next a port check was performed.  Port check: At this point there was prompt aspiration of blood via the port. Contrast injection showed brisk flow into the SVC and heart without evidence of fibrin sheath or other obstruction to flow. There is no defect/crack/leak in the port. The port was deaccessed and a sterile dress was applied.  The patient tolerated the procedure well with no immediate complications. DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: This is a 62 years Female with past medical history of the left vertebrobasilar junction aneurysm status post coil embolization and left V4 post PICA sacrifice [DATE] who presents for diagnostic cerebral angiography to evaluate whether the finding on recent MRA correlates with residual aneurysm filling.   PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 30 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] was the fellow. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Left vertebral artery Right vertebral artery Left internal carotid artery  ANESTHESIA: Local in the right groin with bupivacaine. Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by the nurse present during the entire procedure. The patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Sedation was administered by a specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for the duration of the procedure as outlined above (Total intra service time, 30 minutes ). Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.  MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine SQ 10 cc  Versed 1 mg IV Fentanyl 50 mcg IV Heparin 3000 units IV Protamine 20 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.038" Bentson guidewire 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 5 French merit Performa catheter  Mynx closure device Visipaque contrast material (60 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 5 French sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP, Lateral and Oblique views.   Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a Mynx closure device followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: Cerebral angiogram [DATE], [DATE].  FINDINGS:  LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is evidence of fibromuscular dysplasia in the distal cervical internal carotid artery. No focal stenosis, aneurysm, or early draining vein is identified. Of note there is filling across the posterior communicating artery and retrograde down the basilar artery ending in the left anterior inferior cerebellar artery. No filling of the left vertebrobasilar junction aneurysm is visualized.  LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: The left vertebral artery ends at the coil mass. Just proximal to the coil mass at the left PICA is opacified. No filling of the left vertebrobasilar junction aneurysm is visualized.  RIGHT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There are mild atherosclerotic changes in the V3-3 4 junction. There is a branch off the distal vertebral artery which crosses midline and reaches the vertebrobasilar junction aneurysm, but no filling of the aneurysm is visualized. There is a collateral branch from the right PICA which crosses midline to supply the left anterior inferior cerebellar artery.  COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: 1. No residual filling of the previously coiled left vertebrobasilar junction aneurysm is visualized 2. The bilateral vertebral arteries end in PICA and the basilar artery fills retrograde from the anterior circulation across the left posterior communicating artery.  [HCW], was present for the key and critical portions of the procedure and associated imaging guidance.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  [ID][HOSPITAL][ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  High risk pulmonary embolism. Central pulmonary embolism with hypotension. Prior pulmonary embolectomy [DATE].  Procedure:   1.	Ultrasound-guided right common femoral vein access 2.	Right iliocaval venogram 3.	Selective catheterization of the right main pulmonary artery 4.	Percutaneous fluoroscopic-guided right main pulmonary artery thrombectomy 5.	Right main pulmonary artery angiogram 6.	Selective catheterization of the left lower lobe pulmonary artery 7.	Percutaneous fluoroscopic-guided left lower lobe and main pulmonary artery thrombectomy 8.	Left main pulmonary artery angiogram 9.	Fluoroscopic guided inferior vena cava retrievable filter placement 10.	Activated clotting time measurements   Findings:   1.	 Ultrasound evaluation of the right groin demonstrated patent right common femoral vein. 2.	Right iliocaval venogram:  Patent right common iliac vein and inferior vena cava without thrombus or stenosis. 3.	Right main pulmonary artery angiogram (postthrombectomy): Significant reduction of thrombus burden within the right pulmonary arteries with small residual right lower lobe segmental pulmonary artery embolus. 4.	Left main pulmonary artery angiogram (postthrombectomy): Significant reduction of thrombus burden within the left main and left lower lobe pulmonary arteries with small residual left lower lobe segmental pulmonary artery embolus. 5.	Appropriate positioning of IVC filter below the level of the renal vein origins. 6.   Large volume pulmonary emboli removal from right and left pulmonary arteries.  Impression:   1.	 Technically successful fluoroscopic guided percutaneous bilateral pulmonary thrombectomy. 2.	Technically successful infrarenal IVC filter placement.   Treatment Plan:   Continued high standard heparin drip. Transthoracic echocardiogram in 24 hours.   Technique:    The patient was placed supine on the angiography table and prepped and draped in sterile fashion. The skin underlying soft tissue was anesthetized with 1% lidocaine. Ultrasound evaluation of the right common femoral vein was performed and ultrasound images were saved to the patient's electronic medical records. Under real-time ultrasound guidance, a 21-gauge needle was used to access the right common femoral vein. A microwire was advanced through the needle and the needle exchanged for a transitional dilator. A right iliocaval venogram was obtained.  Throughout the procedure, activated clotting time was measured and heparin administered accordingly.  A stiff guidewire was advanced through this transitional dilator and exchange for an 8 French sheath. An angled pigtail catheter was advanced over the guidewire through the vascular sheath. The guidewire was retracted and the pigtail formed within the intrahepatic IVC. The pigtail catheter was advanced through the IVC into the right atrium, right ventricle and pulmonary artery. Pulmonary artery pressure manometry was attempted, however due to equipment malfunction could not be performed.  The pigtail catheter was exchanged for an angled catheter over a guidewire. Using a Bentson wire and an angled catheter, the right lower lobe pulmonary artery was catheterized. The Bentson guidewire was exchanged for a 1 cm floppy tip superstiff Amplatz wire. Over the guidewire, the 8 French sheath was exchanged for a 24 French sheath. A 24 French aspiration catheter ([VENDOR]ri T24) was advanced into the distal right main pulmonary artery and multiple aspirations were performed resulting in large volume thrombus removal. Right main pulmonary artery angiogram was performed.  The aspiration catheter was removed over a guidewire and exchanged for an angled catheter. The guidewire was exchanged for a Bentson wire. Using the angled catheter and Bentson wire, the left lower lobe pulmonary artery was catheterized. The Bentson wire was exchanged for a 1 cm floppy tip superstiff Amplatz wire. The angled catheter was removed and a 16 French curved and 24 French aspiration catheters (Inari T16 curve and T24) were advanced into the proximal left lower lobe pulmonary artery and distal left main pulmonary artery, respectively. Multiple aspirations were performed. A left main pulmonary artery angiogram was performed.  During the procedure, the blood aspirated was returned to the patient via the vascular sheath using the cell saver.  Under fluoroscopic guidance, an infrarenal Option Elite IVC filter was placed through the existing access.  A modified purse string suture was used to achieve hemostasis and removed the right groin sheath. Compression applied until hemostasis.  The patient tolerated the procedure without immediate complication. Procedure:   1.	Right internal/external biliary drain exchange  Findings:   1.	The existing internal/external biliary drain has been partially retracted. The drainage bag is completely full. 2.	Newly placed biliary drain is appropriately positioned with the distal tip in the third portion of the duodenum and the proximal side hole in a peripheral bile duct.  Impression:   1.	Uneventful image guided exchange of the biliary catheter as described.  Treatment Plan:   1. Leave the drain to gravity bag. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Hemoptysis  PROCEDURE:   1. US-guided right common femoral vein access. 2. Pulmonary angiography with selective catheterization             A. Right middle lobe pulmonary artery             B. Anterobasal segment right lower lobe pulmonary artery             C. Lateral basal segment right lower lobe pulmonary artery             D. Posterobasal segment right lower lobe pulmonary artery 3. Right lower lobe arteriovenous malformation embolization 4. Post-embolization angiography 5. Right common femoral vein compression and dressing.   FINDINGS: ANGIOGRAPHY: Vessels catheterized using base catheter and microcatheter/microwire combination and angiograms performed:  1  Right middle lobe pulmonary artery: Normal course and caliber.  No active extravasation or early-draining pulmonary venous outflow. 2. Anterobasal segment right lower lobe anterobasal segment pulmonary artery: Normal size and course.  No active extravasation or early-draining pulmonary venous outflow.  3. Lateral basal segment right lower lobe subsegmental pulmonary artery: Inflow opacification of contrast with early-draining outflow into right inferior pulmonary vein, compatible with AVM .No active extravasation.  Complete segment occlusion of this artery after embolization with coils and Obsidio. 4. Posterobasal segment right lower lobe pulmonary artery: Incomplete occlusion with two small collateral branches filling an early-draining right lower lobe pulmonary vein through existing coil pack.  Complete segment occlusion of this artery after embolization with coils and Obsidio. 5. Post-embolization right pulmonary artery angiography: Cessation of arteriovenous shunting.  Transcatheter catheterization/embolization: Vessel 1: lateral segment of the right middle lobe.  Embolic: None Details (type/size/volume/number): None  Vessel 2: anterior basal segment of the right lower lobe.  Embolic: None Details (type/size/volume/number): None  Vessel 3: lateral basal segment of the right lower lobe.  Embolic: Coils and Obsidio liquid embolic  Details (type/size/volume/number): 6mm diameter x 14 cm long Nester microcoil and 0.1 mL Obsidio.  Vessel 4: posterior basal segment of the right lower lobe.  Embolic: Coils and Obsidio liquid embolic Details (type/size/volume/number): 6mm diameter x 20 cm long and 8mm diameter x 20 cm long microcoils and 0.4 mL Obsidio.   IMPRESSION:   Technically successful microcoil and Obsidio liquid embolic embolization of the right lower lobe subsegmental pulmonary arterial branches feeding pulmonary AVM.  Complete cessation of flow into the lateral basal and posterobasal segment right lower lobe pulmonary artery branches feeding the AVM after combined microcoil and liquid embolic embolization.  TREATMENT PLAN:  1. Follow-up CTA pulmonary arteriogram in 1 month 2. Routine post-angiography groin cares ordered.  TECHNIQUE: With the patient in the supine position, the groin was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. Following standard prepping and draping, the right common femoral vein was punctured using a needle. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. An 0.035" wire was advanced into the aorta. A vascular sheath was placed over the wire into the common femoral artery. A side flush was started.  A 5-Fr diagnostic catheter was advanced over an 0.035" wire into the abdominal aorta. The catheter was used to catheterize the vessels described above. Angiograms were performed. A microcatheter system was used to catheterize distal vessels, as described above. Specific vessels catheterized and embolized are described in detail above.  Once the catheter was in adequate position, embolization was performed using the parameters detailed. Post-embolization angiography was performed, as detailed.  A right common femoral artery angiogram was performed, demonstrating appropriate vascular access above the profunda femoris artery bifurcation. All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. Hemostasis was achieved using vascular closure device. The site was dressed in usual fashion.  The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  [ID]C[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Symptomatic Uterine Fibroids   Other History:  40 y.o. female with history of migraines, HTN and presents for UFE consult. Patient complains of heavy menstrual bleeding with blood clots. She is anemic due to the heavy bleeding and has required blood transfusions in the past. She states that she has to change her pad/tampon in less than hour to prevent soiling her clothes. She also complains of pelvic cramping for which she takes ibuprofen and bloating.  BMI = 46   PROCEDURE:   1.	Ultrasound-guided left radial artery access 2.	Pelvic angiography 3.	Uterine artery embolization 4.	Post-embolization angiography  Findings:  Vessels catheterized and angiograms performed as detailed below:  Left internal iliac artery: Uterine artery with a myomatous uterus identified. Left uterine artery: Fibroid blush identified. No cervical branches.  Right internal iliac artery: Uterine artery with a myomatous uterus identified. Right uterine artery: Fibroid blush identified. No cervical branches.    Embolization:  Left uterine: 1. 1 vials 500 u Embozene 2. 2 vials 700 u Embozene  Right uterine: 1. 1 ml 500 u Embozene 2. 2.5 ml 700 u Embozene   Intra-arterial medication administration: lidocaine 10 ml given bilaterally.  Hypogastric Nerve Block: N/a  Post-Embolization Angiograms: Right uterine artery: Sluggish flow without opacification of the uterine fibroids. Left uterine artery: Sluggish flow without opacification of the uterine fibroids.  Technical notes: 125 cm MPA, Double angled GT glide micro, Fathom, NTG due to spasm  Impression:  1. Successful bilateral uterine artery embolization. Patient's MRI upon further review suggests possible adenomyosis therefore embolization was done with 500 um Embozene particles followed by 700 um Embozene particles.  2. High radiation dose noted due to patient's body habitus. The patient will be watched and F/U in IR clinic   Treatment Plan:  1. The patient will be monitored for 4-6 hours to assess for the need for an observation admission for pain control. 2. Patient will be discharged with a stool softener/laxative, analgesic, anti-emetic, and a narcotic for pain control. 3. Patient will follow-up in clinic with IR.  Technique:  With the patient in the supine position, the left wrist was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The left wrist was evaluated with ultrasound and left radial artery patency and acceptable size criteria were documented. Images were properly stored in PACS. A modified Allen test (Barbeau test A) was performed on the left wrist to confirm patency of the ulnopalmar arch using pulse oximetry.   1% lidocaine solution was administered for local anesthesia. Access was obtained to the left radial artery using a 21 gauge micro needle and ultrasound guidance. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. A wire was placed through the needle. A hydrophilic Glidesheath was advanced slowly over the wire. 3000 units of heparin, 200 mcg of nitroglycerin and 2.5 mg of verapamil was given through the arterial sheath with slow hemodilution. A side flush was started.   Diagnostic catheter and microcatheter were advanced through the sheath into the aorta and used to catheterize the bilateral internal iliac arteries and pelvic vessels described above. Angiograms were performed. Specific vessels catheterized and embolized are described in detail above. Post-embolization angiography was performed and described above.  All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. A TR Band was placed on the left wrist for hemostasis. The access sheath was removed and no hematoma was seen. A radial artery pulse was confirmed distal to the puncture site confirming patent hemostasis.   The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a power-injectable, 5 Fr, 21 cm, tunneled non-cuffed central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.       Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care.  The catheter is ready for immediate use.        Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed below.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a peel-away sheath set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture peel-away sheath set, the wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.  Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESR[HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Lung cancer  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance on the right chest  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen Bard port (standard profile)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen Bard power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed below.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 2-0 absorbable sutures. Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  [ID]C.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Segment 8 and segment 7 hepatocellular carcinoma. Right adrenal metastases. Left hepatic lobectomy [DATE], multiple ablations involving segments 5/8, 7 and 8 hepatocellular carcinomas [DATE], Y90 radioembolization segment [DATE] and segment 8 [DATE].  Additional Clinical Information: Hepatocellular carcinoma with intrahepatic tumors  PROCEDURE:  Y90 Shunt study/mapping using MAA  1. US-guided right common femoral artery access 2. Diagnostic visceral angiography 3. MAA delivery 4. Right common femoral artery angiogram and closure, 6 French Angio-Seal 5. Cone-beam CT performed for intraprocedural localization, as detailed below.  FINDINGS: ANGIOGRAPHY: Vessels catheterized and angiograms performed, as follows:  Right main renal artery: Patent right main renal artery. Small ascending inferior adrenal ar[HCW].  Celiac artery: Conventional anatomy with celiac axis giving rise to splenic, left gastric and common hepatic arteries. Patent gastroduodenal, and proper and right hepatic arteries.  Right gastroepiploic artery branch: No hepatic tumor supply.  Right hepatic artery: Tumoral blush identified. Patent right segmental hepatic arteries. Patent hepatic artery supplying the caudate lobe.  Segment 8 hepatic artery branch: Tumoral blush identified.  Segment 8 hepatic artery branch: Tumoral blush identified.  Segment 7 hepatic artery branch: Tumoral blush identified.    Specific technical notes / catheter selection: Simmons 1, Progreat 2.8 Fr, Fathom 0.016   CBCT: Yes Catheter location: Branch of right gastroepiploic artery Findings: No tumor feeders.   CBCT: Yes Catheter location: Right hepatic artery Findings: Tumoral blushes identified with supply from the target vessel arising from cranially directed caudate branch, segment 7 and segment 8 branches.   CBCT: Yes Catheter location: Segment 8 hepatic artery branch Findings: Tumoral blush identified with supply from the target vessel.   CBCT: Yes Catheter location: Segment 8 hepatic artery branch Findings: Tumoral blush identified with supply from the target vessel.   CBCT: Yes Catheter location: Segment 7 hepatic artery branch Findings: Tumoral blush identified with supply from the target vessel.    Embolization: No Vessel embolized: N/a Coils used: N/a   MAA delivery performed from: Right hepatic artery (series 18) Future target Y90 delivery catheter position(s): Not applicable; patient not a candidate for radioembolization.    IMPRESSION:   Successful Yttrium-90 TheraSpheres selective internal radiotherapy mapping.  TREATMENT PLAN:  1. Patient will for superselective transarterial chemoembolization. 2. Access site precautions and orders placed.   TECHNIQUE:  With the patient in the supine position, the groin was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The patient was placed on the table in a supine position. Following standard prepping and draping, the common femoral artery was punctured using a needle. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. An 0.035" wire was advanced into the aorta. A 6 French vascular sheath was placed over the wire into the common femoral artery. A side flush was started.  A 5-Fr catheter was advanced over an 0.035" wire into the abdominal aorta. The catheter was used to catheterize the vessels described below. Angiograms were performed. A microcatheter system was used to catheterize distal vessels, as described below. Specific vessels catheterized and embolized are described in detail below.  Cone Beam CT (CBCT) was performed intraprocedurally for purposes of treatment planning, targeting and dose calculation. Axial and coronal images were created and 3D reconstruction was performed on a separate dedicated workstation under concurrent supervision.  After confirmation of target treatment vessel, 5 mCi of Tc-99 MAA was injected slowly into this location though the catheter.   A right common femoral artery angiogram was performed, demonstrating appropriate vascular access above the profunda femoris artery bifurcation. All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. Hemostasis was achieved using vascular closure device, 6 French Angio-Seal. The site was dressed in usual fashion.  The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. The patient was transferred to the Nuclear Medicine department for imaging. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Classical Hodgkin's lymphoma  Procedure:  1. Ultrasound and Fluoroscopic guided placement of a tunneled, cuffed central venous catheter  Findings:  1. The left internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and normal. Vein patency and needle entry were stored to PACS. 2. The newly placed catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating in the right atrium.  Impression:   Uneventful image guided placement of left internal jugular vein tunneled Trifusion catheter as described.  Technique:  The left neck and chest region was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. The region was ultrasonographically evaluated.  Using local anesthetic and ultrasound guidance, the left internal jugular vein was punctured with a 21 gauge needle.  An image documenting vein patency and needle entry was saved and stored to PACS.   A 0.018” wire was passed centrally and the needle exchanged for a 5 French transitional dilator. A 0.035” wire was advanced through the dilator and negotiated into the IVC.  The skin tract was dilated and a 13 French dilator peel-away combination placed over the wire.  The soft tissues caudal and lateral to the sheath entry site were anesthetized with lidocaine with epinephrine. A dermatotomy was made and a tunneling tool brought from the dermatotomy to the venotomy. The catheter was brought through the tunnel.  During suspended respiration, the catheter was advanced through the peel-away and positioned centrally using fluoroscopy. The peel-away was removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression.  The venotomy was closed with Dermabond and Steri-Strips applied. A single Prolene suture was placed at the catheter tunnel exit site. An antimicrobial disc and sterile dressing were applied.  The catheter was aspirated, flushed, and heparinized per protocol. The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient was discharged in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Multiple myeloma  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  6 F single-lumen Bard port (standard profile)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 6 French single lumen Bard power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 3-0 absorbable sutures.     Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with     Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: This is a 41 years Female with a pair of incidentally discovered right paraophthalmic artery aneurysms status post pipeline embolization [DATE] who presents for diagnostic cerebral angiography for six-month follow-up.   PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 30 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] was the fellow. [HCW], PhD was the resident. All actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right internal carotid artery  ANESTHESIA: Local in the right groin with bupivacaine. Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by the nurse present during the entire procedure. The patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Sedation was administered by a specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for the duration of the procedure as outlined above (Total intra service time, 30 minutes ). Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.  MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine SQ 10 cc  Versed 1 mg IV Fentanyl 50 mcg IV Heparin 3000 units IV Protamine 20 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.038" Bentson guidewire 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 5 French Merit Performa Vertebral catheter Visipaque-270 contrast material (40 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 5 French sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP, Lateral and Oblique views.   Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a 5 French Vascade closure device  followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: Cerebral angiogram [DATE].  FINDINGS: RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: The pipeline device is visualized in the intracranial internal carotid artery. There is no evidence of residual paraophthalmic artery aneurysms. There is no evidence of endoleak or in-stent stenosis. No new aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified.   COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: 1. Complete obliteration of the previously pipeline embolized right paraophthalmic artery aneurysms without evidence of in-stent stenosis or endoleak.  Plan: Patient may discontinue present prasugrel, continue aspirin, and we will obtain an MRA TOFTR in 2 years  [HCW], was present for the key and critical portions of the procedure and associated imaging guidance.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  24 year-old female with adrenal Cushing's.  Procedure:   1. Bilateral adrenal vein sampling 2. Left adrenal venogram 3. Right adrenal venogram Conebeam CT was performed. 3D rendering based on intraprocedural cone beam CT thin reconstructions was performed and post processed on a separate independent workstation for purposes of treatment planning.  Findings:    1.  Intermittent fluoroscopic images demonstrate catheter position in the infrarenal IVC, suprarenal IVC, left adrenal vein, and right adrenal vein. 2.  Left and right adrenal venograms demonstrated conventional anatomy with drainage into the left renal vein and direct to IVC, respectively. 3.  Samples to be assayed for cortisol, aldosterone, and catecholamines:  Infrarenal IVC: 8:31, 8:32, 8:33 Suprarenal IVC: 8:28, 8:29, 8:30 Left adrenal vein 1: 8:34, 8:35, 8:36 Left adrenal vein 2: 9:04, 9:05, 9:06 Right adrenal vein 1: 8:48, 8:49, 8:50  Impression:   Successful bilateral adrenal vein sampling for cortisol, aldosterone, and catecholamine (epinephrine) levels.  Treatment Plan:   Sample sent to the lab for analysis. Lateralization index will be calculated when lab values are available.   Technique:   The bilateral groin was prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  The vascular structures were ultrasonographically evaluated.   Images were stored and transferred to PACS.    Under ultrasound guidance, the left common femoral vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  Vein patency and needle entry were documented. A 0.018" wire was placed and the needle exchanged for a 5 French dilator. The microwire was removed and a 180 cm Bentson wire was advanced into the IVC. The dilator was exchanged for a 6 French sheath.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right common femoral vein was accessed with a micropuncture ne[HCW].  Vein patency and needle entry were documented. A 0.018" wire was placed and the needle exchanged for a 5 French dilator. The microwire was removed and a 180 cm [VENDOR]son wire was advanced into the IVC. The dilator was exchanged for a 6 French sheath.  A Simmons  1 catheter was advanced to the infrarenal IVC and venous sampling was performed.  Catheter was advanced to the suprarenal IVC and venous sampling was performed.  Catheter was exchanged for a Simmons 2 glide catheter which was advanced into the left renal vein. Catheter was retracted into the left adrenal vein and venography was performed. Left adrenal vein sampling was performed.  The right renal vein was then selected with a Simmons 1 glide catheter from the contralateral groin and venous sampling performed.  Catheter was then used to select the right adrenal vein and venography performed. Right adrenal vein samples were drawn through the catheter.  Catheters and sheath were removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression. A sterile dressing was applied.  Dry conebeam CT was performed. 3D rendering based on intraprocedural cone beam CT thin reconstructions was performed and post processed on a separate independent workstation for purposes of treatment planning.  Patient tolerated the procedure without complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Pancreatic head mass with biliary obstruction and hyperbilirubinemia  Procedure:   1.	Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram 2.	Placement of percutaneous transhepatic internal/external biliary drain  Findings:   1.	Occlusion of the proximal to mid common bile duct secondary to extrinsic compression from known mass.  Impression:   1.	Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography and right drainage catheter placement.  Plan:  1.	Keep to gravity bag drainage until bilirubin downtrends. 2.	Can consider stent placement at in 4 weeks.  Technique:   The anterior abdominal wall and bilateral flanks were prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier.  An appropriate skin entry site was identified using fluoroscopy and ultrasound, and anesthetized with local.  Under fluoroscopic guidance, a 22G Chiba needle was advanced into the liver.  A right side bile duct was entered and the biliary system was opacified with contrast. Cholangiographic images were obtained. Attempts were made to access a more peripheral right sided duct with a 22 gauge chiba needle under fluoroscopic guidance but were unsuccessful given the very small caliber of the ducts. Therefore the initial access was used for catheter placement.  A 0.018" wire was passed centrally, and the needle exchanged for a 5 French nonvascular access catheter. The inner stiffener, dilator, and 0.018" wire were removed and contrast was injected to confirm location.  A 0.035" glidewire and 4 French angled catheter were negotiated into the small bowel. The glidewire was removed and contrast was injected to confirm location. A 0.035" Amplatz wire was placed through the catheter, and the catheter subsequently removed.   Drain placement: Finally, an 8.5 French standard-sidehole internal-external biliary drain was placed over the wire. The anchor/loop was formed and locked. Attention was paid that side holes were positioned within the biliary system. Contrast was injected to confirm location. The catheter was secured to the skin with 2-0 suture material and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.  Contrast was injected through the existing biliary drainage catheter and cholangiographic images obtained.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL][ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  64M with  htn, new back pain after fall, compression deformities of T3, T4, T9, and L1.    Other clinical information : Traumatic Brain Injury, Prior GLF on [DATE], now with worsened back pain.  New T6 deformity, worsened at L2.   [PATIENT] has debilitating pain since his fall on [DATE].  Since then, he cannot stand up or even move his torso at all due to excruciating pain.  His pain is mostly focused at the T6 level, with some pain correlating to L2.  Additional Clinical Indication: Subacute (6-12 weeks) T6 and L2 osteoporotic vertebral body/vertebral bodies compression fracture(s). Spine MRI/bone-scan is within 30 days of this procedure and was performed on [DATE]. Patient has severe back pain despite optimal non-surgical management with severe impact of vertebral body compression fracture(s) on daily functioning. Patient has kyphotic deformity due to vertebral body compression fracture(s).     Procedure:   1.	Image-guided kyphoplasty of T6  2.	image guided kyphoplasty L2   Findings:   1.	Pre-intervention: Multilevel compression fractures , T6 and L2 vertebral bodies 2.	Post-intervention:  Successful deposition of cement within the T6 and L2 treated vertebral body/bodies with no evidence of extravasation.   3.	Subacute compression fracture of T3,T4 not treated today  Impression:   1.	Successful image guided augmentation of vertebral levels: T6 and L2 vertebral bodies    Treatment Plan:   1.	Routine post procedure care. We will continue to follow along to assess pain control. 2.	 A fracture of the hip, spine or distal radius in patients over 50 years of age warrants testing or treatment for osteoporosis if not previously undertaken.   Patient was instructed to take part in an osteoporosis prevention/treatment program.   Technique:   The patient was brought to the interventional radiology suite and placed on the table in prone position. The wide area of the back around the affected area(s) was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion.   All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). A scout image was obtained in AP and lateral projections.   Skin was anesthetized with a 2% lidocaine solution. Bupivacaine was injected in the periosteum at T6 and L2  Level by level technique:   -Vertebral level:  T6 kyphoplasty -Pedicle access:  Unipedicular -Access trocar gauge:  11-gauge -Balloon utilized:  15 mm  Prior to injection of cement, balloons were inserted and inflated under biplane fluoroscopy.  Static fluoroscopic images were stored to PACS documenting balloon utilization and position. -Biopsy obtained:  No -Indication for biopsy: N/A -Ablation Performed: N/A -Indication for Ablation: N/A  -Vertebral level:  L2 kyphoplasty -Pedicle access:  Bipedicular -Access trocar gauge:  10-gauge -Balloon utilized:  15 mm  Prior to injection of cement, balloons were inserted and inflated under biplane fluoroscopy.  Static fluoroscopic images were stored to PACS documenting balloon utilization and position. -Biopsy obtained:  No -Indication for biopsy: N/A -Ablation Performed: N/A -Indication for Ablation: N/A   Additional Procedural Details:   Utilizing AP and lateral fluoroscopy, needles were inserted into the T6 vertebral body. The 11-gauge introducer needles were advanced under careful, intermittent biplane fluoroscopy to ensure that the medial wall of the left pedicle was not violated prior to transgression of the needle tip into the posterior wall of the vertebral body. The drill was then advanced to the anterior one-third of the vertebral body on each side and medialized since a unipedicular approach was being utilized.  A 15 mm Balloon was  inserted into the T6 vertebral body/bodies and inflated under fluoroscopy. Static fluoroscopic images were stored to PACS documenting balloon position. Cement was mixed and balloons were removed after being deflated.  Cement was then injected under careful, intermittent biplane fluoroscopy to ensure no extravasation of PMMA cement beyond the borders of the vertebral body. Cement injection was stopped once there was adequate fill of the vertebral body. A total of 5 cc of cement was injected without incident. Trochars were removed with hemostasis obtained with focal compression. Static fluoroscopic images were obtained after removal of all needles documenting final cement position.     Utilizing AP and lateral fluoroscopy, needles were inserted into the L2 vertebral body. The 10-gauge introducer needles were advanced under careful, intermittent biplane fluoroscopy to ensure that the medial wall of the left and right pedicle were not violated prior to transgression of the needle tip into the posterior wall of the vertebral body. The drill was then advanced to the anterior one-third of the vertebral body on each side.  A 15 mm Balloon(s) was inserted into the L2 vertebral body and inflated under fluoroscopy. Static fluoroscopic images were stored to PACS documenting balloon position. Cement was mixed and balloons were removed after being deflated.  Cement was then injected under careful, intermittent biplane fluoroscopy to ensure no significant extravasation of PMMA cement beyond the borders of the vertebral body. Cement injection was stopped once there was adequate fill of the vertebral body. Approximately 4 cc of cement was injected without incident. Trochars were removed with hemostasis obtained with focal compression. Static fluoroscopic images were obtained after removal of all needles documenting final cement position.    No ablation was performed. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  58 year old with cirrhosis and HCC s/p segment 6 microwave ablation and recurrent ascites requiring weekly large volume paracentesis.  Procedure:   1.	Primary TIPSS 2.	Paracentesis 3.	Triple lumen central venous catheter placement with ultrasound and fluoroscopic guidance  Findings:   1.	Right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses.  Needle entry was documented. 2.	Right hepatic venogram confirms vein patency. 3.	Portogram demonstrates patent main, right and left portal veins. Note of a small recanalized umbilical vein. 4.	The initial portosystemic gradient is 17 mmHg. 5.	Post-TIPSS portosystemic gradient is 7 mmHg. 6.	The TIPSS has a smooth course and extends from the right hepatic vein to right portal vein. 7.	There is good flow through the shunt at the conclusion of the procedure with no appreciable filling of varices. 8.	5 liters of fluid were drained during the procedure. 9.	New right internal jugular approach triple-lumen catheter terminates at the superior cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful creation of TIPS from right hepatic vein to right portal vein with a 8-10 mm x 8 cm x 2 cm controlled-expansion Viatorr stent (ballooned to 8 mm).  2.	The portosystemic gradient was reduced from 17 mm Hg to 7 mmHg.  Treatment Plan:   1.	Patient will be admitted to ICU for overnight monitoring  Technique:   Following written informed consent, the patient was placed supine on the procedure table. After induction of general anesthesia, the right neck and abdomen were prepped and draped in standard sterile fashion.   Paracentesis: The abdomen was evaluated with ultrasound. An appropriate skin entry site was chosen and anesthetized with local. Under ultrasound guidance, a 21-gauge needle was advanced into the peritoneal space. A 0.018 inch wire was advanced into the peritoneal space, and the needle was exchanged for a transitional dilator. A transitional dilator was exchanged for an 0.035 inch wire and a drain was advanced into the peritoneal space and wire was removed. The drain was attached to suction and was drained during the case.  Access: The right neck was then evaluated with ultrasound. The skin overlying the right internal jugular vein was anesthetized with local, and a small dermatotomy was made.  Under ultrasound guidance a 21-gauge needle was advanced into the right internal jugular vein. A 0.018" guidewire was advanced through the micropuncture needle. The needle was exchanged for a 5 French transitional catheter. The 0.018" wire and inner dilator were removed, and a 0.035" wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava.  The transitional catheter was exchanged for a sheath. An angled catheter was placed over the wire and used to select the right hepatic vein. A right hepatic venogram was obtained.   Notes on access catheter/sheath combination: 5 French MPA/10-Fr sheath  ICE (Intra-cardiac echo) technique: A second access site was obtained in the neck using ultrasound guidance and a vascular sheath. This sheath was guided using fluoroscopy into the hepatic venous confluence and utilized to advance the ICE. Real-time echo imaging was then utilized to target an appropriate portal radical, with attention paid to avoid traversal of critical intrahepatic vessels/bile ducts and extrahepatic structures.  Pre-TIPS Pressures:  Right atrial and hepatic pressure measurements were obtained using a balloon catheter/sheath, as detailed:  Right atrial: 17 mm Hg Direct portal: 34 mm Hg  CO2 Portography: No   TIPS: Using the Argon ScorpionX TIPS set, the right portal vein was accessed, which was confirmed with the hand-injection of contrast. A 0.035" Bentson wire was advanced into the portal vein. A 4 Fr glide catheter was advanced over the wire into the SMV. The 10 Fr sheath was advanced over the glide catheter and the Bentson but was unsuccessful. A 6mm balloon was used to dilate the TIPS tract. The sheath was then successfully advanced in combination with a Lunderquist wire. TIPS sheaths were advanced over the wire into the portal vein. A marking pigtail catheter was advanced over the guidewire and used to measure the parenchymal tract and measure portal venous pressure. The sheath was ultimately advanced into the main portal vein, and a Viatorr stent was deployed within the TIPS shunt. The shunt was dilated throughout using a high pressure balloon. Follow-up portogram demonstrated good flow through the TIPS shunt with no filling of collaterals.   Post-TIPS Pressures: The pressures after shunt placement were recorded, as follows: Direct portal: 28 mm Hg Right atrial: 21 mmHg This corresponds to a portosystemic gradient of 7 mm Hg  At the end of the procedure the sheath was removed over a guidewire and a 12 French x 20 cm triple lumen catheter was placed. The catheter was flushed and heparinized per protocol. The catheter was sutured to the skin with 2-0 suture and a biodisc and sterile dressing were applied. The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no immediate complications. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  [ID]C[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Prostate cancer with bilateral ureteral obstruction managed with bilateral PCNUs. Patient has tolerated capping and is voiding well. He and his urologist wish to convert catheters to internal double J stents.  Procedure:  1. Bilateral antegrade nephrostogram and exchange for internal double J stents and capped nephrostomy tubes.   Findings:  1. Right antegrade nephrostogram demonstrates flow though the stent into the bladder 2. left antegrade nephrostogram demonstrates flow though the stent into the bladder 2. Newly placed interal ureteral stents and nephrostomy tubes are appropriately positioned with the proximal loop in the renal pelvis and distal loop in the urinary bladder.  Impression:  Conversion of bilateral PCNUs to internal stents.   Plan:   Return in 2 weeks with repeat Cr level for likely removal of nephrostomy tubes over a wire.  Technique:  With the patient in prone position, the bilateral flanks were prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. A scout radiograph was obtained.   Right: Contrast was injected through the existing nephroureterostomy tube and imaging of the collecting was system performed. A 0.035" wire was placed through the tube and the tube removed over the wire and discarded. A new, 8-French x 26 cm nephroureterostomy tube was advanced over the wire under fluoroscopic guidance. The wire was removed and the proximal loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis and the distal loop in the bladder. Over a safety wire, a 10.2 F nephrostomy was advanced with the loop locked in the renal pelvis Contrast injection confirmed location.  Left: Contrast was injected through the existing nephroureterostomy tube and imaging of the collecting was system performed. A 0.035" wire was placed through the tube and the tube removed over the wire and discarded. A new, 8-French x 26 cm nephroureterostomy tube was advanced over the wire under fluoroscopic guidance. The wire was removed and the proximal loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis and the distal loop in the bladder. Over a safety wire, a 10.2 F nephrostomy was advanced with the loop locked in the renal pelvis Contrast injection confirmed location.  The catheters were sutured to the flank and placed to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.    The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Recurrent cholangiocarcinoma with resultant upstream intrahepatic biliary ductal dilation and hyperbilirubinemia. Biliary drain to decrease bilirubinemia for potential chemotherapy.  Procedure:   1.	Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram 2.	Placement of left percutaneous transhepatic internal/external biliary drain  Findings:   1.	Postsurgical changes from prior Whipple. 2.	Occlusion of the common bile duct secondary to extrinsic compression from known mass.  Impression:   1.	Technically successful percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography and drainage catheter placement. 2.	Technically successful internal biliary drain placement.  Plan:  1.	Drain to remain open to bag with daily bilirubin trend. Once bilirubin plateaus, plan for capping trial.  2.	Routine drain exchange in 8 weeks.  Technique:   The anterior abdominal wall and bilateral flanks were prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier.  An appropriate skin entry site was identified using fluoroscopy and ultrasound, and anesthetized with local.  Under fluoroscopic guidance, a 21G Chiba needle was advanced into the left hepatic lobe.  A bile peripheral segment 3 duct was entered and the biliary system was opacified with contrast. Cholangiographic images were obtained.   A 0.018" wire was passed centrally, and the needle exchanged for an AccuStick 6 French French nonvascular access kit. The inner stiffener, dilator, and 0.018" wire were removed and contrast was injected to confirm location.  A 0.035" Glidewire advantage and 4 French angled catheter were negotiated into the small bowel. The Glidewire advantage was removed and contrast was injected to confirm location.   The Glidewire advantage was then readvanced into the small bowel, and the Kumpe catheter and outer of the AccuStick kit were removed over the wire. Finally, an 10 French standard sideholes internal-external biliary drain was placed over the wire. The cope loop was formed and locked. Attention was paid that side holes were positioned within the biliary system. Contrast was injected to confirm location. The catheter was secured to the skin with 2-0 Prolene suture material and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.  Contrast was injected through the existing biliary drainage catheter and cholangiographic images obtained.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  ESRD  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled large bore central venous catheter placement  Findings:   1.	The right common femoral vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the large bore central venous catheter, as described, the tip terminates inferior vena cava.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a  14French, 40 cm, (tunneled large bore central venous catheter via the common femoral vein internal jugular vein.  Treatment Plan:   1. Routine catheter care. 2. The catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed below  The skin and subcutaneous tissues overlying the vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right common femoral vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle. An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the dialysis catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The venotomy tract was dilated to allow introduction of a peel-away sheath.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS.
