CEREBRAL  ANGIOGRAM AND TUMOR EMBOLIZATION   CLINICAL INDICATION: 54-year-old female with recently discovered large left sphenoid wing meningioma and unruptured left superior hypophyseal artery aneurysm which was discovered after she presented with 6 months of left by patient loss in several weeks of intermittent confusion. Resection of her sphenoid wing meningioma is scheduled within the coming days, and diagnostic cerebral angiogram for characterization of the cerebral vasculature as it relates to the tumor as well as possible tumor embolization was requested.   PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram, tumor embolization   DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 120 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician. He supervised the entire procedure. [HCW] was the fellow. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Innominate artery Right common carotid artery, cervical Right common carotid artery, cerebral Left vertebral artery Left common carotid artery, cervical Left internal carotid artery, cerebral Left external carotid artery, cranial Left internal maxillary artery, superselective Left middle meningeal artery, superselective  VESSELS TREATED: Left internal maxillary artery Left middle meningeal artery  ANESTHESIA: General endotracheal anesthesia was administered under the supervision of the attending anesthesiologist. Pre-, intra-, and post-anesthesia monitoring records are available in the chart.  MEDICATIONS:  Heparin 7000 units IV Protamine 25 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 0.038" Bentson guidewire 0.035" Terumo exchange-length glidewire  5 French Cordis Vertebral catheter Excelsior 1018 microcatheter Transcend-EX microguidewire Contour PVA embolization particles (250-355 microns) Cardiva Vascade Omnipaque 300 contrast material (110 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, spinal cord infarction, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, hemorrhage, nontargeted embolization, necrosis of skin or mucus membranes, renal failure, limb loss, death, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.  After informed, written consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion after intubation by the anesthesiology team.  Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following the sheath placement; additional boluses of heparin were administered at one-hour intervals. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of the above listed vessels. Digital angiograms were performed of these vessels, centered over the neck and head.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY:  Rotational angiography was also performed from the diagnostic catheter in the cervical segment of the left internal carotid artery for better delineation of the underlying angioarchitecture. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.    Following the diagnostic portion of the angiogram, the Excelsior 1018 microcatheter and Transcend-EX microguidewire were passed coaxially through the Cordis vertebral catheter into the distal internal maxillary artery artery. Contour PVA particles were then prepared in the usual fashion with appropriate quantities of saline and contrast in order to maintain the particles in isobaric suspension and injected into the branches of the internal maxillary artery supplying the meningioma artery using a pulse spray technique. The microcatheter was withdrawn partially and microrun showed additional supply to the tumor from the distal branches of the internal maxillary artery. Additional PVA embolization was performed using the same technique. The microguidewire and microcatheter were then advanced into the branch of the middle meningeal artery supplying the meningioma where PVA embolization was performed using the same technique.  Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a Cardiva Vascade followed by manual compression. A Tegaderm was then applied over the puncture site.  COMPARISON: Noninvasive imaging including MRI of brain dated [DATE].  FINDINGS: INNOMINATE ARTERY: The origin of the right common carotid artery, right vertebral artery, internal mammillary artery, and visualized branches of the costocervical and thyrocervical trunks opacify normally. The right internal carotid artery is severely stenosis just beyond the carotid bulb. This is better visualized on the common carotid artery injection discussed below.  RIGHT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CERVICAL: The right internal carotid artery is severely stenosed just beyond the carotid bulb and appears to terminate in the distal cervical segment. The intracranial right internal carotid artery, and a turn right middle cerebral artery, opacifies from retrograde filling from the ophthalmic artery which is in turn supplied by enlarged anastomosis from the internal maxillary artery. There is washout from competitive flow from the left internal carotid artery across the anterior communicating artery which is better visualized on the left internal carotid artery injection discussed below.  RIGHT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  There is no visualized opacification of the intracranial right internal carotid artery from the cervical carotid artery. As described above, the intracranial right internal carotid artery, and a turn right middle cerebral artery, opacifies from retrograde filling from the ophthalmic artery which is in turn supplied by enlarged anastomosis from the internal maxillary artery as well as the middle meningeal artery.  LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. Reflux of contrast into the contralateral vertebral artery was not achieved, however there appears to be an AICA-PICA complex bilaterally, which were both opacified. The posterior right middle cerebral artery territory is supplied via pial anastomosis from the right PCA. Additionally there is collateralization to the pericallosal artery via the posterior choroidal arteries.  LEFT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CERVICAL: The bifurcation is smooth, without irregularity, calcification, or stenosis with respect to the distal ICA. There is tumor blush via supply from the internal maxillary artery which is better visualized on the left external carotid artery injection discussed below. The ECA branches otherwise opacify normally.  LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is a medially directed aneurysm of the ophthalmic segment of the left internal carotid artery (superior hypophyseal artery aneurysm), the dimensions of which are described on 3-D rotational angiography discussed below. There is superior displacement of the proximal left middle cerebral artery. The right ACA is filled from the left ICA injection via the anterior communicating artery. There is fusiform dilation of the right A1 segment, attention on follow-up. Additionally there is significant supply to the right middle cerebral artery, though there is washout is seen from retrograde supply from the right ophthalmic artery to the intracranial right ICA (as discussed above on the right common carotid artery injection).   No focal stenosis or early draining vein are identified.    LEFT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  There is tumor blush in the left anterolateral skull base consistent with sphenoid wing meningioma with supply from the distal branches of the internal maxillary artery as well as the sphenoidal branch of the middle meningeal artery.  LEFT INTERNAL MAXILLARY ARTERY (DISTAL BRANCHES), SUPERSELECTIVE: Prominent tumor blush without evidence of dangerous anastomosis with the retina or other structures.  LEFT MIDDLE MENINGEAL ARTERY (SPHENOIDAL BRANCH), SUPERSELECTIVE: Tumor blush without evidence of dangerous anastomosis with the retina.  LEFT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-PVA EMBOLIZATION): Interval embolization of distal branches of the internal maxillary artery as well as the sphenoidal branch the middle meningeal artery. There is approximately 80% reduction in tumor blush.  3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: 3D Rotational angiography with volume-rendered three-dimensional reconstruction on an independent workstation, demonstrated a medially directed superior hypophyseal artery aneurysm which measures 5.6 x 4.9 x 6.0 x 3.1 mm (axial by axial by neck-to-dome by neck).    COMPLICATIONS: none immediate.  IMPRESSION:  1. There is a left-sided medially directed superior hypophyseal artery aneurysm which measures 5.6 x 4.9 x 6.0 x 3.1 mm (axial by axial by neck-to-dome by neck).  2. The right internal carotid artery is severely stenosed just beyond the carotid bulb and appears to terminate in the distal cervical segment. The intracranial right internal carotid artery, and in turn right middle cerebral artery, opacifies from retrograde filling from the ophthalmic artery which is in turn supplied by enlarged anastomosis from the internal maxillary artery and middle meningeal artery. The right middle cerebral artery territory is further supplied by pial anastomosis from the right PCA as well as supply from the left ICA via the anterior communicating artery. The right ACA is filled from the left ICA via the anterior communicating artery as well as collaterals from the posterior choroidal arteries..  3. There is fusiform dilation of the right A1 segment, attention on follow-up.  4. There is superior displacement of the proximal left middle cerebral artery. 5. Tumor blush centered in the left anterolateral skull base consistent with sphenoid wing meningioma, with predominant vascular supply from the left internal maxillary artery and left middle meningeal artery.  6. PVA embolization of sphenoid wing meningioma, with 80% reduction of vascular supply to the tumor post-procedure.

CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM AND WOVEN ENDOBRIDGE (WEB) EMBOLIZATION OF RIGHT MIDDLE CEREBRAL ARTERY ANEURYSM    CLINICAL INDICATION: 52-year-old female with a history of migraines who was found to have an incidental right middle cerebral artery bifurcation aneurysm on workup for her headaches. Given the size, location, and morphology of the aneurysm in conjunction with her young age and good health status, treatment of her aneurysm was indicated.   PROCEDURE: Cerebral angiogram, Woven Endobridge device embolization of right middle cerebral artery aneurysm.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: 1.5 hours.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician.  He supervised the entire procedure. [HCW] was the fellow. They both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right common femoral artery Right internal carotid artery   VESSELS TREATED (in sequence): Right middle cerebral artery  ANESTHESIA:   General Anesthesia administered by anesthesiology staff.  Pre- Intra- and post- anesthesia records are available in the patient chart.   MEDICATIONS GIVEN:  0.5% Bupivacaine 10 cc SQ Heparin 5000 units IV Ancef 2 gram IV  MATERIALS USED:  5 French micropuncture kit Cope mandrel wire 5 French transitional dilator 8 French Terumo Pinnacle Sheath 088 AXS Infinity LS (80 cm) 0.035" Bentson guidewire 0.035" Terumo glidewire (180 cm) 5 French Merit BERN 1 (125 cm) catheter AXS Catalyst 5 guide catheter (115 cm)  VIA 17 microcatheter (156 cm) Transcend-EX microguidewire (200 cm) Omnipaque 300 contrast material (80 cc) 8 French AngioSeal closure device  DEVICE IMPLANTED: Woven Endobridge SL 5 mm x 3 mm  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, hemorrhage, renal failure, limb loss, death, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.  After informed, written consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion after intubation by the anesthesiology team. Access to the vascular system was gained by a single-wall puncture of the right common femoral artery. An angiogram of the right common femoral artery was obtained through the outer cannula the dilator to confirm that the arterial puncture was above the bifurcation that the vessels of adequate size to use a 8 French AngioSeal. A 8 French short sheath was introduced into the right common femoral artery using Seldinger technique.  Using fluoroscopic guidance, the 5 French 125 cm selection catheter was advanced through the 088 AXS Infinity LS (80 cm) to select the right internal carotid artery.  The long sheath was then advanced over the selection catheter into the right internal carotid artery. Digital angiogram was performed, centered over the head.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: Rotational angiography was also performed from the diagnostic catheter in the cervical right internal carotid artery for better delineation of the intracranial vasculature. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.  Following the diagnostic angiogram, the 5 French diagnostic catheter was withdrawn.  Through the long sheath, a AXS Catalyst 5 guide catheter (115 cm) was advanced into the distal petrous segment of the right internal carotid artery over the VIA 17 microcatheter and Transcend-EX microguidewire.  Superselective catheterization of the right middle cerebral artery aneurysm was then performed with the VIA 17 microcatheter over a Transcend-EX microguidewire. The WEB SL 5 mm x 3 mm device was then deployed inside of the aneurysm using roadmap and blank roadmap technique.   A final cerebral angiogram was done in the AP and lateral projection to evaluate for residual filling, and distal emboli.  Following completion of the procedure Ancef was administered and hemostasis was achieved by application of a 8 French AngioSeal. A Tegaderm was then applied over the puncture site.  COMPARISON: None.  FINDINGS: RIGHT COMMON FEMORAL ARTERY: The arteriotomy is above the bifurcation of the right common femoral artery and the diameter of the vessel is adequate for a 8 French AngioSeal.  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is a wide necked laterally directed aneurysm at the MCA bifurcation, the dimensions of which are described on the 3-D rotational angiography discussed below. There is mild irregularity of the mid to distal cervical ICA which may present FMD changes. No focal stenosis or early draining vein are identified.   RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-WOVEN ENDOBRIDGE DEVICE DEPLOYMENT): Interval deployment of WEB device within the MCA aneurysm with reduced contrast opacification and stagnation of contrast within the aneurysm. The device sits fully within the aneurysm and there is no intrusion of the device within the MCA branches. The MCA bifurcation divisions appear patent and fill without delay. There are no perfusion deficits to suggest emboli in the distal circulation.  3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY:  3-D rotational angiography demonstrated a wide-necked, laterally directed aneurysm at the MCA bifurcation which measures 5.2 x 4.6 mm (axial by neck-to-dome).   COMPLICATIONS: None.  IMPRESSION: 1.	Successful deployment of WEB device within unruptured right MCA bifurcation aneurysm with maintained patency of MCA bifurcation branches

DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: This is a 54 years Female with past medical history of hypertension, who was admitted to [HOSPITAL] with a left-sided intracerebral hemorrhage, found to be due to to and arteriovenous malformation. She now presents for repeat angiogram to evaluate changes in the arteriovenous malformation prior to embolization/surgery.   PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 30 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] and [HCW] were the fellow. All actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Internal carotid artery Right vertebral artery  ANESTHESIA: Local in the right groin with bupivacaine. Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by the nurse present during the entire procedure. The patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Sedation was administered by a specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for the duration of the procedure as outlined above (Total intra service time, 30 minutes ). Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.  MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine SQ 10 cc  Heparin 3000 units IV Protamine 20 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.038" [VENDOR]son guidewire 5 French [VENDOR]umo Pinnacle sheath 5 French merit Performa catheter  Mynx closure device Visipaque contrast material (80 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient's healthcare proxy. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 5 French sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP, Lateral and Oblique views.   Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a Vascade followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: Cerebral angiogram [DATE].  FINDINGS:  LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: The previously seen left parietal arteriovenous malformation is again visualized and appears grossly stable compared to prior angiogram. The arterial feeders arise from the distal left pericallosal artery and the distal left middle cerebral artery. No prenatal aneurysms are identified. The venous drainage is through a superficial vein, then subsequently into the superior sagittal sinus. There is a small draining vein that was previously best visualized on the right vertebral artery injection, which is now better visualized on this internal carotid artery injection. This vein drains slightly later than the AVM nidus. No areas of significant stenosis or other aneurysms are identified.  RIGHT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm or focal stenosis is identified.. Reflux of contrast into the contralateral vertebral artery was not achieved. The origin of PICA is normal on the right. There are distal PCA branches which now very faintly opacify a small draining vein, which was better visualized on the previous angiogram.  COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: 1. Stable size and morphology of the Spetzler Martin 2 left parietal arteriovenous malformation, which has arterial feeders arising primarily from the distal left pericallosal artery, distal left middle cerebral artery. The previously seen supply from the distal left posterior cerebral artery branches is now very faintly visualized. The venous drainage remain stable via a cortical vein which drains into the superior sagittal sinus.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Liver failure. Liver transplant status. Uptrending liver enzymes.  Procedure:   1.	Diagnostic venography: right internal jugular vein, left brachiocephalic vein, right hepatic vein, IVC 2.	Transjugular liver biopsy with pressure measurements 3.	Removal of malpositioned non-tunneled right internal jugular central venous catheter and placement of new non-tunneled 8Fr right IJ double lumen CVC  Findings:   1.	The right hepatic vein is normal in caliber and appearance. 2.	The biopsy specimen appeared adequate. 3.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. Needle entry was documented. However, inferiorly the right brachiocephalic vein was completely occluded, confirmed by venography. 4.	Indwelling right internal jugular CVC is malpositioned, with the tip terminating in the left brachiocephalic vein. This was repositioned under fluoroscopic guidance with the tip directed towards the SVC and right atrium. Biopsy performed via this access.  5.	A new properly positioned non-tunneled double lumen CVC was placed with the tip at the superior cavoatrial junction.  This catheter is ready for use. 6.	Right hepatic vein and IVC widely patient with no stenosis. No significant pressure gradients across the transplant liver anastomosis.  Pressures:  Free hepatic vein: 9mm Hg Wedged hepatic vein: 14mm Hg Corrected sinusoidal pressure HVPG: 5mm Hg (normal)   Right hepatic vein proximal to anastomosis: 9 mm Hg Right hepatic vein at anastomosis: 8 mm Hg Inferior cavo-atrial junction: 7 mm Hg Right atrium: 6 mm Hg   Infrahepatic IVC: 8 mm Hg IVC at anastomosis: 7 mm Hg Right atrium: 6 mm Hg   No significant pressure gradients noted across the anastomosis.   Impression:   1.	Successful image guided transjugular liver biopsy. Corrected sinusoidal pressure of 5 mm Hg. 2.	Patent transplant liver vasculature without significant pressure gradients across the anastomosis. 3.	Occluded right brachiocephalic vein. Successful replacement of malpositioned non-tunneled right internal jugular CVC.  Treatment Plan:  Follow up pathology results.  Technique:   The procedure, options, and risks were reviewed with patient's family, including bleeding, infection, and pneumothorax. A time out was performed before initiating the procedure.  The skin overlying the access site was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). Patient sedation was performed, as detailed below.  The right neck was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Using local anesthetic and ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was punctured with a 21 gauge needle with permanent reporting and recording. An image documenting vein patency and needle entry was stored and transferred to PACS. A wire could not be passed through the right brachiocephalic vein. Venography confirmed complete right brachiocephalic venous occlusion. An 0.035'' wire was advanced through the malpositioned right internal jugular central venous catheter and navigated through the SVC into the IVC. The catheter was removed and over this access, a 9 French sheath was placed at the neck.  An angled catheter was used to select the right hepatic vein and hepatic venography performed using nonionic contrast. Free and wedged hepatic pressures were obtained using a fogarty balloon. Venography and pressure measurements were performed as above.  A 0.035” wire was placed in the hepatic vein and the 7 French Cook biopsy cannula was advanced over the wire. The wire was removed, and 2 passes made with the 18 gauge coaxial needle.  The specimen was placed in formalin and delivered to the laboratory.  The cannula and sheath were removed over a wire and a new 8 French non-tunneled double lumen central venous catheter was placed. A pursestring suture was tied around the catheter and the catheter was sutured to the skin. Both lumens were tested and locked with heparin. A sterile dressing was placed. Hemostasis was achieved. The catheter is ready for use. No immediate complication occurred, and the patient was discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM, ENDOVASCULAR THROMBECTOMY  CLINICAL INDICATION: 41 years-year-old Female with PMH of iron deficiency anemia secondary to uterine fibroids presenting with right-sided weakness and aphasia with CTA demonstrating left M1 occlusion and favorable aspects and perfusion imaging. The patient did not IV tPA. Mechanical thrombectomy was indicated.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 45 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW], was the attending physician. He supervised the entire procedure. [HCW] and [HCW] were the fellow. [HCW] PhD was the resident. The fellows and attending actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Left common carotid artery, roadmap Left internal carotid artery Left middle cerebral artery, super selective Right common femoral artery  ANESTHESIA: General. Pre-, intra-, and post-anesthesia monitoring records are available in the chart.  MEDICATIONS:  Heparin 3000 IU IV Ancef 2 g  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 8 French Stryker DASH sheath  8 French Walrus balloon guide catheter 0.035" Bentson Guidewire 5 French penumbra Simmons selection catheter (125 cm) 0.035" Terumo Glidewire (180 cm) Zoom 71 Aspiration Catheter (137 cm) Marksman microcatheter (160 cm) Aristotle 18 microguidewire (200 cm) Trevo NXT 4 x 41 Stentriever device  8 French Angio-Seal closure device Omnipaque-300 contrast (60 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient's family (medical proxy). Specifically, the risks of intracranial or systemic hemorrhage, cerebral infarction, distal emboli, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, device malfunction, groin hematoma, arterial dissection/laceration, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite, intubated, and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 8 French sheath was introduced into the right common femoral artery. The 8 French Walrus balloon guide-catheter and 5 French diagnostic long selection catheter were introduced into the left common carotid artery as a system.   A roadmap angiogram was then completed of the common carotid artery to visualize the carotid bifurcation. The diagnostic catheter was then used to select the internal carotid artery over the 180 cm long 0.035" Terumo Glidewire. The balloon guide catheter was then advanced into the cervical internal carotid artery over the wire and selection catheter. The wire and diagnostic catheter were then removed. Digital angiograms were performed centered over the head.   The initial TICI score was 0.  The Marksman microcatheter and Aristotle microwire were then advanced through Zoom 71  aspiration catheter into the guide catheter as a system past the left M1 occlusion. The wire was removed from the microcatheter, and intravascular position was confirmed with contrast injection. The Trevo NXT stentriever device was then tacked up the microcatheter and the stentriever was deployed under fluoroscopy and the allowed to set in the clot for 5 minutes. The microcatheter was removed so that that the stentriever was "naked" in the aspiration catheter.  The Zoom 71 aspiration catheter was then tracked to the face of the clot with continuous aspiration on through the [VENDOR] aspiration machine.  Once in place, the aspiration catheter was noted to be 'plugged' with occlusive suction against the clot.  The balloon on the guide catheter was then inflated. The stentriever was then removed under continuous aspiration using a 60cc [VENDOR]-[VENDOR]k locking syringe system. Thrombus was  identified within the stentriever device and the aspirate.  The balloon on the guide was deflated and a cerebral angiogram was performed through the guide catheter. Recanalization of the left MCA was achieved with revascularization of the distal territory consistent with TICI 2C.  An angiogram of the right common femoral artery was obtained; the artery was deemed appropriate for use of the 8 French Angio-Seal closure device. The sheath was removed and hemostasis obtained by deployment of the 8 French Angio-Seal closure device. A Tegaderm was then applied over the puncture site.  COMPARISON: CTA from same date.  FINDINGS:  LEFT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CERVICAL (roadmap): The bifurcation is smooth, without irregularity, calcification, or stenosis with respect to the distal ICA. The ECA branches opacify normally. This roadmap is primarily used for selection of the left internal carotid artery.  LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: A left M1 occlusion is identified consistent with TICI 0.    LEFT MIDDLE CEREBRAL ARTERY, SUPERSELECTIVE (PASS 1): The microcatheter in intravascular and distal to the occlusion.     LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-THROMBECTOMY, PASS 1):  Reperfusion has been reestablished consistent with TICI 2C. There are 2 distal M3 occlusions in the superior M2 division remaining.  RIGHT FEMORAL ARTERY: No abnormalities are detected. This vessel is suitable for use of 8 French Angio-Seal closure device.  COMPLICATIONS: none immediate.  IMPRESSION:  1.	Left M1 occlusion with initial occlusion consistent with TICI 0. 2.	Left middle cerebral artery with reperfusion consistent with TICI 2C.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  poor venous access  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled central venous catheter placement       Findings:   1.	The right external jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the tunneled catheter, as described, the tip terminates near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a power-injectable, 5 Fr, 27 cm, tunneled non-cuffed central venous catheter via the right External jugular vein. The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications. DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: This is a 70 years Male with past medical history of prior strokes, former smoker who presents for diagnostic cerebral angiography to evaluate two right-sided aneurysms and a possible basilar tip aneurysm.   PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 120 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] was the fellow. [HCW] PhD was the resident. All actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right internal carotid artery Left common carotid artery Right radial artery Right vertebral artery  ANESTHESIA: Local in the right groin with bupivacaine. Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by the nurse present during the entire procedure. The patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Sedation was administered by a specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for the duration of the procedure as outlined above (Total intra service time, 120 min ). Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.  MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine SQ 10 cc  Versed 1 mg IV Fentanyl 50 mcg IV Heparin 3000 units IV Protamine 20 mg IV  Radial cocktail: 2.5 mg of verapamil, 1000 units heparin, 200 mcg nitroglycerin  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.038" Bentson guidewire 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 5 French Terumo slender sheath 5 French merit Performa catheter 5 Fr[HOSPITAL] glide catheter 5 French Vascade closure device Visipaque-270 contrast material (80 cc) TR Band  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the left femoral artery; a 5 French sheath was introduced into the left femoral artery. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP, Lateral and Oblique views.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY:  Rotational angiography was also performed from the diagnostic catheter in the right internal carotid artery for better delineation of the underlying angioarchitecture. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.    Due to the bovine configuration, we switched the diagnostic catheter for a [VENDOR] 3 glide catheter and selected the left common carotid artery. After performing angiograms of the left common carotid artery, we attempted to catheterize the right vertebral artery, as based on the noninvasive imaging he appeared to be completely right vert dominant. After unsuccessful attempts, we proceeded with attempting radial access.   Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right radial artery under ultrasound guidance; a 5 French slender sheath was introduced into the right radial artery using ultrasound guidance. 1000 units of heparin, 200 mcg of nitroglycerin, 2.5 mg of verapamil were administered intra-arterially through the sheath after sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, the right vertebral artery was selectively catheterized using the [VENDOR]s catheter over the Glidewire. Digital angiograms were performed of these vessels, centered over the head and neck.   Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a TR Band. Hemostasis was obtained in the left common femoral artery by the application of a 5 French Vascade closure device followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: MRA brain [DATE].  FINDINGS: RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is an anterior choroidal artery aneurysm better described on the 3-D angiogram below. There is a small lenticulostriate aneurysm also better described on the 3-D angiogram below. Of note there is an infundibular origin of the right posterior communicating artery. There is no evidence of focal stenosis or early draining vein identified.   LEFT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. There is a fetal posterior communicating artery. The left A1 segment is absent.  RIGHT RADIAL ARTERY: The right radial artery opacifies normally.  RIGHT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. Reflux of contrast into the contralateral vertebral artery was not achieved. The origin of PICA is normal on the right.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: 3D Rotational angiography with volume-rendered three-dimensional reconstruction on an independent workstation, demonstrated an anterior choroidal artery aneurysm measuring approximately 4.3 x 4.0 x 4.6 x 4.2 mm (transverse, transverse, dome to neck, neck). There is also an aneurysm at the origin of a large lenticulostriate branch measuring approximately 3.3 x 1.6 x 1.4 x 2.1 mm (transverse, transverse, dome to neck, neck).   COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: 1. There is an anterior choroidal artery aneurysm measuring approximately 4.3 x 4.0 x 4.6 x 4.2 mm (transverse, transverse, dome to neck, neck). There is also an aneurysm at the origin of a large lenticulostriate branch measuring approximately 3.3 x 1.6 x 1.4 x 2.1 mm (transverse, transverse, dome to neck, neck).  2. Bovine-type arch necessitating the use of a Simmons catheter for selection of the left common carotid artery. 3. Significant tortuosity of the great vessels. Consider a radial access for future angiograms.  [HCW], was present for the key and critical portions of the procedure and associated imaging guidance.

CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM AND ENDOVASCULAR PIPELINE EMBOLIZATION OF A RIGHT SUPERIOR HYPOPHYSEAL ARTERY ANEURYSM  CLINICAL INDICATION:  45-year-old female with past medical history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes, hyperlipidemia, carcinoid tumor, and angiodysplasia or presented in 2015 with subarachnoid hemorrhage and bilateral superior hypophyseal artery aneurysms. It was unclear which of these was the source of the subarachnoid hemorrhage and therefore both were coil embolized. Subsequent imaging showed sessile recurrence of both aneurysms. Given her young age and history of subarachnoid hemorrhage treatment is indicated.  PROCEDURE:  1.	Cerebral angiogram  2.	Endovascular pipeline embolization   DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 1.5 hours.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] was the fellow. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire pr[HCW].  VESSELS CATHETERIZED: Right internal carotid artery Right middle cerebral artery  VESSELS INJECTED: Right common femoral artery Right internal carotid artery  VESSELS TREATED (in sequence): Right internal carotid artery  ANESTHESIA: General endotracheal anesthesia. Pre-, intra-, and post-anesthesia monitoring records are available in the chart.  MEDICATIONS:  Heparin 8000 units IV Protamine 25 mg IV Ancef 2 grams IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 8 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 0.035" Bentson Guidewire 0.035" exchange length Bentson 071 Penumbra Benchmark guide catheter (115 cm) with vert insert Phenom 27 microcatheter (150 cm) Asahi 018 microguidewire (200 cm) 4.0 mm x 12 mm pipeline embolization device Perclose ProGlide closure device Omnipaque-300 contrast (100 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, stent thrombosis/stenosis, stent migration, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, non-target embolization, puncture site hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed, written consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite, intubated, and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery. Through the dilator sheath, an angiogram of the of the right common femoral artery was obtained to ensure the arteriotomy was above the level of the bifurcation and the CFA was of sufficient size to use the Perclose ProGlide closure device. A 6 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 5000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement; additional boluses of heparin were administered at one-hour intervals. The ACT was checked to ensure that it was between 250-300. Using fluoroscopic guidance,  the right internal carotid artery was selectively catheterized. The 071 benchmark catheter was advanced over the benchmark insert selection catheter and the exchange length Bentson guidewire into the proximal horizontal petrous portion of the right internal carotid artery. The selection catheter and guidewire were removed. Digital angiograms were performed in the AP and lateral projections centered over the head and neck.   3D rotational angiography was performed with the guide catheter in the right internal carotid artery artery to better delineate the intracranial vasculature. The acquisition was processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.   A working projection was obtained to best demonstrate the neck of the superior hypophyseal artery aneurysm, as well as, the distal and proximal landing zones for the stent. Superselective catheterization of the middle cerebral artery was performed with the [VENDOR]om 27 microcatheter over the Asahi 18 microguidewire. The tip of the microguidewire was situated in the superior division of the middle cerebral artery. The microguidewire in the pipeline catheter was then exchanged for a 4.0 mm x 12 mm pipeline embolization device. The device was deployed under fluoroscopic guidance and a single shot X-ray was performed to confirm that the distal and proximal ends of the pipeline embolization device were in the right ICA communicating segment and right ICA ophthalmic segment, respectively. Postprocessing of the pipeline embolization device was performed with a curved microwire with successful improvement in apposition of the proximal aspects of the device.  A final AP and Lateral angiogram were completed to evaluate the distal vasculature for perfusion deficits and emboli.   After completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Ancef was administered. The sheath was removed and hemostasis obtained using the Perclose ProGlide closure device. Tegaderms were then applied over the puncture site.  COMPARISON: Diagnostic angiogram dated [DATE] and [DATE].  FINDINGS:  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is a compact coil mass seen in the expected location. There is sessile recurrence of the previously coiled superior hypophyseal artery aneurysm which is grossly stable from prior and further visualized on 3-D rotational angiography discussed below. No focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified.   RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-PIPELINE EMBOLIZATION): The Pipeline device is well apposed to the vessel walls throughout it's course without endoleak. . . No perfusion deficits to suggest distal emboli are present.  3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY: A 3D rotational angiogram of the  right internal carotid was completed and post-processed on an [VENDOR][HOSPITAL]dent work station. 3D angiography demonstrated the previously described sessile recurrence of the previously coiled superior hypophyseal artery aneurysm. This 3-D rotational angiography was performed in order to select views for pipeline device deployment as well as to appropriately sized the pipeline embolization device.  RIGHT COMMON FEMORAL ARTERY: No abnormalities are detected. The arteriotomy was above the level of the bifurcation and the CFA was of sufficient size to use the Perclose ProGlide closure device.   COMPLICATIONS: none immediate.  IMPRESSION:  1.	Grossly stable appearance of the sessile recurrence of the previously coiled right superior hypophyseal artery aneurysm. 2.	Successful deployment of pipeline embolization device from the communicating segment of the right internal carotid artery to the proximal ophthalmic segment of the right internal carotid artery, and covering the ostium of the aneurysm. The stent is well apposed to the vessel wall without endoleak.

Initially, all flow from splenic and mesenteric veins passed into three large spontaneous portosystemic shunts, and there was no hepatopedal flow into the main or intrahepatic portal vein.  Two of the spontaneous shunts had been embolized retrogradely in [DATE] and [DATE]. 2. TREATMENT PLAN:  1.	Recovery in PACU.   2. Will request admission for observation after [PATIENT] wakes up. 3. Promacta can be stopped 48 hours after his procedure if his H/H remain stable. 4. Hopefully, his encephalopathy will be improved enough that he can reduce his current dosage of Lactulose and his portal vein will remain patent to allow for orthotopic liver transplantation.   5. In addition, he is still very interested in surgical repair of his right inguinal hernia and hydrocele. 6. Follow-up with me in clinic in 3-4 weeks to assess his encephalopathy.  If it is still a problem, would plan to discuss further embolization and/or TIPS creation with him, his wife, and [HCW].   TECHNIQUE: The patient was placed in the supine position on the angiography table and the abdomen was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion.  Under direct ultrasound guidance with aseptic technique, local anesthetic was administered using 1% lidocaine, and a 22-gauge needle was placed into a peripheral portal vessel within the target organ described above. A peripheral splenic vein branch was cannulated and a microwire was passed centrally under fluoroscopy. The needle was then removed and a transitional dilator, sheath, and catheter were placed over the wire in series, and advanced centrally under fluoroscopy. A  7-French sheath was placed over the wire and advanced into the portal venous system. A diagnostic catheter was advanced through the sheath over the wire, and venography was performed, with findings detailed above. Venography was performed using both iodinated contrast and CO2, to limit the total iodinated contrast volume.  Additional vessels were catheterized and angiograms were performed, as detailed above. Embolization was performed are detailed above. Post-treatment venography findings are listed above.  All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. The sheath was retracted under fluoroscopic guidance peripherally with continuous contrast injection to delineate the access site with the assistance of real time ultrasound. The access site was embolized in retrograde fashion through the indwelling sheath using the technique delineated above. Hemostasis was achieved and the access site was dressed appropriately.  The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  57 y.o. female with past medical history significant for stage IIa ER/PR positive HER2  neu negative infiltrating ductal carcinoma of the right breast and was recently on ribociclib treatment twice complicated by rising liver labs which led to its cessation. IR consulted for transjugular liver biopsy    Procedure:   Transjugular liver biopsy with pressure measurements  Findings:   1.	The right hepatic vein is normal in caliber and appearance. 2.	The biopsy specimen appeared adequate. 3.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. Needle entry was documented. 4.	Pressures:  a. Wedged hepatic pressure: 19 mm Hg b. Free hepatic pressure: 16 mm Hg c. Corrected Sinusoidal Pressure: 3 mm Hg  d. Right atrial: 16 mm Hg  Impression:   Successful image guided transjugular liver biopsy. Corrected sinusoidal pressure of 3 mm Hg.    Treatment Plan:  Follow up pathology results.  Technique:   The procedure, options, and risks were reviewed with patient, including bleeding, infection, and pneumothorax. A time out was performed before initiating the procedure.  The skin overlying the access site was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). Patient sedation was performed, as detailed below.  The right neck was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Using local anesthetic and ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was punctured with a 21 gauge needle with permanent reporting and recording. An image documenting vein patency and needle entry was stored and transferred to PACS. A 10 French sheath was placed at the neck.  An angled catheter was used to select the right hepatic vein and hepatic venography performed using nonionic contrast. Free and wedged hepatic pressures were obtained using the diagnostic catheter.  A 0.035” wire was placed in the hepatic vein and the 7 French TLAB Argon biopsy cannula set was advanced over the wire. The wire was removed, and 3 passes made with the 18 gauge coaxial needle.  The specimen was placed in formalin and delivered to the laboratory.  The cannula and sheath were removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Leukemia. Requires central venous access.  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled central venous catheter placement       Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the tunneled catheter, as described, the tip terminates in the right atrium.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a power-injectable, 5 Fr, 25 cm, tunneled non-cuffed central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.       Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care.  The catheter is ready for immediate use.        Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed below.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a peel-away sheath set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture peel-away sheath set, the wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.  Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  86 y.o. female who per chart review has a past medical history of dementia, Anemia, Chronic kidney disease, Neurogenic bladder with chronic Foley catheter in place, functional quadriplegia, Dysphagia s/p percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube placement ([DATE]) who presents from [HOSPITAL] with G-tube dislodgement. Last exchange with [HOSPITAL] IR [DATE] with 20Fr MIC.   Procedure:   1.	New Gastrostomy tube placement under fluoroscopic guidance.  Findings:   1.	The gastrostomy tube is in good position.  2.	Gentle hand injection of contrast material confirms positioning of the gastrostomy tube within the gastric lumen.  Impression:   1. Unable to recanalize prior G tube tract, prior incision is completely healed 2. Successful placement of 18 French MIC gastrostomy tube as above.  Treatment Plan:   The tube should be placed to gravity drainage and should not be used for 4 hours. 25 cc of water can be administered per hour. At 4 hours, if residuals are less than 30%, the patient can have tube feeds advanced starting at a half dose.  Routine exchange in 6 months   Technique:   Informed consent for the procedure was obtained, and time-out was performed prior to the procedure.  The skin overlying the access site was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the mid abdomen were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.   Using fluoroscopic and ultrasonographic guidance, an appropriate puncture site was identified.  2 T-fasteners were placed adjacent to the planned tube access site, just below the prior site. Positioning of the T-fasteners within the gastric lumen was confirmed by return of air and direct injection of contrast material.  Next, under fluoroscopic guidance, an 18-gauge needle was directed into the gastric lumen. Needle positioning within the gastric lumen was confirmed with aspiration of air as well as gentle hand injection of contrast material.  A wire was advance through the 18-gauge needle.  The 18-gauge needle was removed over a wire. Serial dilation was accomplished over the stiff wire. An 18 French Halyard G-tube was advanced over a wire in an antegrade fashion and advanced through the anterior abdominal wall. All wires and catheters were removed. The bulb was inflated with 10 mL of a 10% contrast mixture. Gentle hand injection of contrast material documents the gastric feeding tube within the gastric lumen. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained for reference purposes. The tube was flushed with saline. It was affixed to the anterior abdominal wall with a rubber flange. The patient tolerated the procedure well at time of procedure completion without complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  [ID]C[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  56 year-old male with primary aldosteronism, hypertension, right adrenal nodule.  Procedure:   1. Bilateral adrenal vein sampling 2. Left adrenal venogram 3. Right adrenal venogram  Findings:    1.  Intermittent fluoroscopic images demonstrate catheter position in the infrarenal IVC, suprarenal IVC,  left adrenal vein, and right adrenal vein. 2.  Left and right adrenal venograms demonstrated conventional anatomy with drainage into the left renal vein and direct to IVC, respectively. 3.  Samples to be assayed for cortisol and aldosterone:  Infrarenal IVC: 11:35, 11:36 Suprarenal IVC: 11:33, 11:34 Left adrenal vein 1: 11:40, 11:41 Right adrenal vein 1: 11:47, 11:48  Impression:   Successful bilateral adrenal vein sampling for cortisol and aldosterone levels.  Treatment Plan:   Sample sent to the lab for analysis. Lateralization index will be calculated when lab values are available.   Technique:   At least 30 minutes prior to the initiation the procedure, a cosyntropin infusion was initiated at 40 mcg/h through a peripheral IV.  The bilateral groin was prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  The vascular structures were ultrasonographically evaluated.   Images were stored and transferred to PACS.    Under ultrasound guidance, the left common femoral vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  Vein patency and needle entry were documented. A 0.018" wire was placed and the needle exchanged for a 5 French dilator. The microwire was removed and a 180 cm Bentson wire was advanced into the IVC. The dilator was exchanged for a 6 French sheath.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right common femoral vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle. Vein patency and needle entry were documented. A 0.018" wire was placed and the needle exchanged for a 5 French dilator. The microwire was removed and a 180 cm Bentson wire was advanced into the IVC. The dilator was exchanged for a 6 French sheath.  4,000 units of heparin was administered.   A Simmons 1 catheter was advanced to the infrarenal IVC and venous sampling was performed.  Catheter was advanced to the suprarenal IVC and venous sampling was performed.  Catheter was exchanged for a Simmons 2 glide catheter which was advanced into the left renal vein. Catheter was retracted into the left adrenal vein and venography was performed. Left adrenal vein sampling was performed.  Using a Simmons 1 catheter from the contralateral groin, the right adrenal vein was catheterized and venography performed. Right adrenal vein samples were drawn through the catheter. Catheters and sheath were removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression. A sterile dressing was applied.  Cosyntropin infusion was terminated.  Patient tolerated the procedure without complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESR[HOSPITAL][ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  52 year-old female with lupus, prior myomectomy with uterine fibroids, with chronic severe life-limiting pelvic pain and back pain. Completion venography  IVUS utilized during case  Findings:  Access site(s): Right internal jugular vein Sheath size(s): 9-Fr 25 cm sheath  Under ultrasound guidance, with continuous recording and reporting, a micropuncture needle was advanced into the target vessel detailed above and a microwire was advanced through the needle. The needle was removed and a micropuncture sheath was exchanged over the wire, through which an 0.035" wire was introduced. A micropuncture sheath was exchanged for a vascular sheath as detailed above.  VENOGRAPHY: The following vessels were catheterized and diagnostic venography was performed:  Left renal vein: There is a gradient suggesting some level of compression at the level of where the superior mesenteric artery crosses over. Left renal vein with 5 degree tilt: There is mild early reflux into the left ovarian vein, however, it washes out very quickly. Left ovarian vein: The left ovarian vein is small (not engorged). Upon accessing, it is noted to be friable with small focal contrast extravasation. No pooling/reflux of contrast below is noted. Distal left ovarian vein: There is some prominent of the vein, however, the valves appear intact, no reflux to pelvic varices is noted. Contrast briskly washes out  Right iliocaval veins: Patent vein with brisk flow. Left iliocaval veins: There is a gradient where the right common iliac artery crosses over. There is reflux into the left internal iliac vein. Left iliocaval veins with 5 degree tilt: The reflux into the left internal iliac vein becomes more prominent with cross-pelvic collaterals filling.  IVUS utilized: Yes List each individual vessel catheterized and findings: Left renal vein: Marked narrowing of the more central renal vein. There is a 64.4% relative narrowing at the level of compression when compared with the reference area. Right iliocaval veins: No thrombus. Normal caliber. Left iliocaval veins: No thrombus. There is marked narrowing of the left common iliac vein where the right common iliac artery crosses over. There is a 70.8% relative narrowing at the level of compression when compared with the reference area.  Pressure measurements: Yes  Left common iliac vein: 16 mm Hg IVC: 13 mm Hg Gradient across left common iliac vein narrowing: 3 mm Hg  Left renal vein: 11 mm Hg IVC above renal vein: 9 mm Hg Gradient across left renal vein narrowing: 2 mm Hg  SVP Classification:  S2 V2 P LRV,O,NT; LCIV,O,NT; LIIV,R,NT  Impression:   1. No left ovarian vein reflux or pelvic varices in continuity with the ovarian vein. 2. Left common iliac vein narrowing with reflux into the left internal iliac vein associated with cross-pelvic collaterals that worsen with tilt table. 3. Left renal vein narrowing of unknown clinical significance. Narrowing does not result in ovarian vein reflux.  Treatment Plan:  1. Will relay findings to patient's referring team and discuss with interdisciplinary group. 2. Consideration of left common iliac vein stenting. If patient's symptoms improve with stenting, however, back pain and other findings associated with renal vein narrowing are present, could consider possibility of Nutcracker syndrome.  Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained.  The specific risks of bleeding, infection, pulmonary embolism, perforation, thrombosis, and need for subsequent procedures/surgery were detailed and accepted. Written informed consent was obtained. Patient was brought to the procedure suite and a time out was performed prior to procedure initiation. Patient was placed in supine position and, following sedation, the access site was prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  Venous Access:  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the access site(s) were infiltrated with lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed, demonstrating patency. Under continuous ultrasound guidance, with permanent recording and reporting, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle. An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018" wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire. Through the micropuncture introducer set, an 0.035" wire was advanced into the IVC under fluoroscopic guidance. A sheath was placed at the access site, as detailed. A catheter and/or sheath combination was advanced into the IVC and venography was then performed, with findings detailed above. The left renal vein was selected and venography was performed. The tilt table was engaged and venography was performed. The left ovarian vein was catheterized and venography was performed. The inferior left ovarian vein was catheterized and venography was performed. The catheter was withdrawn to the left renal vein and exchanged over an 0.035" for IVUS. Pullback IVUS was performed. IVUS was removed.  The catheter and wire were then navigated to the right external iliac vein. A pigtail flush catheter was placed and iliocaval venography was performed. The catheter was removed over a wire and pullback IVUS was performed.  The catheter and wire were then navigated to the left external iliac vein. A pigtail flush catheter was placed and iliocaval venography was performed. The tilt table was engaged and repeat venography was performed. The catheter was removed over a wire and pullback IVUS was performed.  Pressures were measured across the left common iliac vein. The catheter was then advanced to the left renal vein and pressures were measured across the left renal vein.  All instruments and devices were removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression at the end of the procedure. No immediate complication occurred, and the patient was discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: 45-year-old female with hypertension and diabetes who presented with sudden onset worst headache of life found to have subarachnoid hemorrhage (Hunt-Hess grade 3). Diagnostic cerebral angiograms indicated for further evaluation management.  PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 60 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] was the fellow. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right internal carotid artery Right external carotid artery Left internal carotid artery Right vertebral artery  ANESTHESIA: General endotracheal anesthesia was administered under the supervision of the attending anesthesiologist. Pre-, intra-, and post-anesthesia monitoring records are available in the chart.  MEDICATIONS:  Heparin 3000 units IV Protamine 20 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.035" Bentson guidewire 5 French Boston Scientific sheath 5 French Cordis Vertebral catheter  Cardiva Boomerang Visipaque-320 contrast material (120 cc) ProGlide Perclose device  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 5 French sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP and lateral views.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY:  Rotational angiography was also performed from the diagnostic catheter in the proximal right internal carotid artery for better delineation of the intracranial circulation. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.    3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY:  Rotational angiography was also performed from the diagnostic catheter in the proximal left internal carotid artery for better delineation of the intracranial vasculature. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an [VENDOR][VENDOR] workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.    Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a Boomerang followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: Noninvasive imaging.  FINDINGS:  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: Hypoplastic A1 segment. No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified.   RIGHT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  The visualized ECA branches opacify normally. No arteriovenous shunting is identified to suggest a dural arteriovenous fistula.   LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is a small anterior communicating artery aneurysm which is better visualized on 3-D rotational angiography discussed below. No focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified.    RIGHT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified. Reflux of contrast into the  left vertebral artery was not achieved. The origin of PICA is normal unilaterally (we will defer to CTA for evaluation of the contralateral PICA).   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: 3D Rotational angiography with volume-rendered three-dimensional reconstruction on an independent workstation, demonstrated no evidence of aneurysm.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: 3D Rotational angiography with volume-rendered three-dimensional reconstruction on an independent workstation, demonstrated a small, 2.8 x 2.3 x 1.9 x 2.0 mm (axial by axial by neck-to-dome by neck), aneurysm at the left A1-2 junction.   COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION:  1. There is a small, 2.8 x 2.3 x 1.9 x 2.0 mm (axial by axial by neck-to-dome by neck), aneurysm at the left A1-2 junction. This aneurysm is the source of patient's subarachnoid hemorrhage. 2. No other aneurysms were visualized. 3. Hypoplastic right A1.

DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM, SOLUMBRA THROMBECTOMY  CLINICAL INDICATION: This is a 46-year-old Male with past medical history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation/flutter status post cardioversion in 2017 who is not on anticoagulation due to hematuria with oral anticoagulation (but was on 81 mg of aspirin daily) who presented to the hospital 2 days prior with complaint of worsening cough and hemoptysis as well as orthopnea was started on heparin drip for left ventricular thrombus. He was subsequently noted to have a right middle cerebral artery syndrome. CTA showed a right middle cerebral artery occlusion. Perfusion imaging and ASPECTS were favorable for proceeding with mechanical thrombectomy.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 60minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW], was the attending physician. He supervised the entire procedure. [HCW] was the fellow. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right Internal Carotid Artery Right common femoral artery  ANESTHESIA: General anesthesia. Pre-, intra-, and post-anesthesia monitoring records are available in the chart. First pass was in part delayed due to patient medical status requiring intubation.  MEDICATIONS:  Heparin .3000 units IV Ancef 2 g IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 8 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 8 French Walrus balloon guide catheter 0.035" Bentson Guidewire 0.035" Bentson Guidewire, exchange length 5 French Merit Performa Vertebral catheter Asahi 018 microguidewire Trak 21 microcatheter RED 72 Aspiration Catheter Trevo NXT 4 x 41 Stentriever device  Perclose ProGlide closure device Omnipaque-350 contrast (45 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient's family (medical proxy). Specifically, the risks of intracranial or systemic hemorrhage, cerebral infarction, distal emboli, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, device malfunction, groin hematoma, arterial dissection/laceration, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite, intubated, and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; an 8 French sheath was introduced into the right common femoral artery. The 8 French balloon guide-catheter and diagnostic catheter were introduced into the right common carotid artery as a system. The balloon guide catheter was then advanced into the cervical internal carotid artery over the wire and diagnostic catheter. The wire and diagnostic catheter were then removed and the balloon guide was connected to a continual heparinized saline flush. Digital angiograms were performed centered over the head.   The initial TICI score was 0 secondary to a proximal right M1 occlusion. There is noted be significant collateralization to the right middle cerebral artery territory via pial collaterals extending from the right ACA and PCA territories.  A triaxial system of the aspiration catheter, microcatheter, and microguidewire were advanced into the internal carotid artery over roadmap guidance. The Trak 21 microcatheter and Asahi 018 microwire were then advanced through the aspiration catheter past the right M1 occlusion. A microrun confirmed intravascular placement.  The aspiration catheter was then tracked to the face of the clot. The wire was removed from the microcatheter and replaced with the Trevo NXT 4 x 41 stentriever device.  The stentriever was deployed under fluoroscopy and the allowed to set in the clot for 5 minutes. The microcatheter was removed so that that the stentriever was "naked" in the aspiration catheter. The balloon on the guide catheter was then inflated. The stentriever was then removed under continuous aspiration using a 60cc syringe. Thrombus was  identified within the stentriever device and the aspirate.  The balloon on the guide was deflated and a cerebral angiogram was performed through the guide catheter. Recanalization of the right middle cerebral artery was achieved with revascularization of the distal territory consistent with TICI 3. There is noted to be significant catheter induced spasm of the cervical ICA. 10 mg of verapamil were infused over approximately 10 minutes for treatment of the spasm. Follow-up angiogram showed resolution of the spasm and good intracranial perfusion (recanalization remains consistent with TICI 3)  An angiogram of the right common femoral artery was obtained; the artery was deemed appropriate for use of the 8 French Angio-Seal closure device. The sheath was removed and hemostasis obtained by deployment of the 8 French Angio-Seal closure device. A Tegaderm was then applied over the puncture site.  COMPARISON: Non-invasive imaging, same day  FINDINGS:  RIGHT  INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: A proximal right M1 occlusion is identified consistent with TICI 0.  There is noted be significant collateralization to the right middle cerebral artery territory via pial collaterals extending from the right ACA and PCA territories.  RIGHT  INTERNAL carotid ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-THROMBECTOMY):  Interval recanalization of the right middle cerebral artery Reperfusion has been reestablished consistent with TICI 3. There is significant catheter induced spasm of the cervical ICA.   RIGHT  INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-IA VERAPAMIL):  Interval resolution of the previously visualized ACA spasm and persistent TICI 3 reperfusion of the middle cerebral artery circulation.   RIGHT FEMORAL ARTERY: No abnormalities are detected. This vessel is suitable for use of the 8 French Angio-Seal closure device.  COMPLICATIONS: none immediate.  IMPRESSION:  1. Proximal right M1 occlusion with initial occlusion consistent with TICI 0.  2. Status-post single pass combined aspiration and stentriever technique thrombectomy with resultant TICI 3.  3. Severe catheter induced spasm of the right cervical ICA which resolved completely following infusion of IA verapamil.

INTRA-OPERATIVE CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: Status-post left-sided craniotomy and clip ligation of anterior communicating artery aneurysm. Intra-operative angiography was requested.  PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: 30 minutes (includes time repositioning clip).  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending. [HCW] was the fellow. [HCW] interpreted the images.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Left internal carotid artery  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.038" Bentson Guidewire  5 French Terumo Pinnacle Sheath 5 French Cordis Vertebral catheter 0.035" Terumo Glidewire 5 French Mynx closure device Omnipaque-300 contrast material (100 cc)  ANESTHESIA: The patient was under general anesthesia in the operating room.  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patie[HCW] and the patient's family. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed. Informed consent was obtained as part of general consent for the craniotomy.  In the operating room, the patient's left groin was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. Puncture of the left common femoral artery was performed and a 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath was placed using sterile Seldinger technique. The sheath was continuously perfused with heparinized saline before and during the surgery.  Following surgical clipping of the aneurysm, an intra-operative angiogram was performed using portable fluoroscopic equipment in the operating room. The 5 French Cordis Vertebral catheter was placed into the left internal carotid artery using a 0.035" Terumo Glidewire.
