FINDINGS:  LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: A surgical clip is identified in the region of the previously seen anterior communicating artery aneurysm. No residual aneurysm is identified.  No evidence of distal emboli is seen.   COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION:  Status-post clipping of anterior communicating artery aneurysm with no angiographic evidence of residual aneurysm or distal artery occlusion.

DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: 58-year-old female with past medical history of hypertension, diabetes, chronic headaches, and a reported nonocclusive thrombus of the left distal transverse sinus for which she was started on oral anticoagulation. She presents with ongoing and unremitting headaches and sensation of pressure with her head. Findings on recent CTA or concerning for presence of possible arterial venous shunting lesion. Diagnostic cerebral angiograms indicated for further evaluation management.  PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 45 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] was the fellow. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right common femoral artery Right internal carotid artery Right external carotid artery Left internal carotid artery Left external carotid artery Left vertebral artery  ANESTHESIA: Local in the right groin with bupivacaine. Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by the nurse present during the entire procedure. The patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Sedation was administered by a specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for a total of 45  minutes (Total intra service time).  Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.  MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine SQ 10 cc  Versed 1 mg IV Heparin 3000 units IV Protamine 20 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope [VENDOR]ril wire, 5 F[HCW] transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.035" Bentson guidewire 5 French Boston Scientific sheath 5 French Cordis Vertebral catheter  5 Fr Mynx closure device Visipaque-320 contrast material (120 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 5 French sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP, Lateral and Oblique views.   Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a Boomerang followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: Noninvasive imaging including CTA from the day prior.  FINDINGS: RIGHT COMMON FEMORAL ARTERY: The arteriotomy is above the bifurcation, and the caliber of the vessel is appropriate for use of an intravascular closure device.  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No aneurysm, focal stenosis, or early draining vein are identified.   RIGHT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  There is faint early opacification of the left transverse sinus which appears to arise from distal feeders from the parietal branch the middle meningeal artery in the occipital artery. The visualized ECA branches otherwise opacify normally.   LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is shunting to the left transverse sigmoid junction via a loose nidus of vessels, supplied by branches of the middle cerebral artery and MHT, in the posterior inferior left temporal lobe which appear to primarily coalesce into a short dominant draining vein which empties into the left transverse sigmoid junction. There appears to be additional supply directly to the transverse sigmoid junction from the MHT. No aneurysm or focal stenosis are identified. The left A1 segment is hypoplastic. The left posterior communicating artery is fetal type (see left vertebral artery injection below)  LEFT EXTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:  There is diffuse fistulization to the left transverse and sigmoid sinuses from the occipital artery, middle meningeal artery, and posterior auricular artery.  LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is additional supply to the previously described nidus (or possibly a second, separate nidus) from the left AICA and SCA. There is additional direct fistulization to the left transverse sinus from the posterior meningeal artery. The left P1 segment is hypoplastic (left fetal P-comm). No aneurysm or focal stenosis are identified. Reflux of contrast into the  right vertebral artery was achieved. The origin of PICA is normal unilaterally (we will defer to CTA for evaluation of the contralateral PICA).     COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: 1. There is shunting to the left transverse sigmoid junction via a loose nidus of vessels, supplied by branches of the middle cerebral artery and MHT, in the posterior inferior left temporal lobe which appear to primarily coalesce into a short dominant draining vein which empties into the left transverse sigmoid junction. There may be additional supply to this nidus versus supply to a second, separate leads nidus from the left AICA and SCA, which also drains into the left transverse sigmoid junction. 2. There is direct fistulization to the left transverse and sigmoid sinus from the left occipital artery, middle meningeal artery, and posterior auricular artery, the right middle meningeal and occipital arteries, and the posterior meningeal artery. 3. This is most consistent with an arteriovenous malformation (Spetzler Martin 2) with recruitment of branches of the external carotid artery versus Borden type I dural AV fistula with pial recruitment. MRI would be helpful in evaluating the exact location of the nidus in relationship to the brain surface/parenchyma.

DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM, SOLUMBRA THROMBECTOMY  CLINICAL INDICATION: This is a 70-year-old year old Male with a past medical history of hyperlipidemia and BPH who presents with an acute stroke syndrome (left MCA syndrome-aphasia and right upper extremity weakness) secondary to a left M2 occlusion. ASPECTS was favorable.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 60 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW], was the attending physician. He supervised the entire procedure. [HCW] was the fellow. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED:  Left common carotid artery (roadmap) Left Internal Carotid Artery Right common femoral artery  ANESTHESIA: General anesthesia. Pre-, intra-, and post-anesthesia monitoring records are available in the chart.   MEDICATIONS:  Heparin 5000 units IV Ancef 2 g IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 9 French Stryker Dasch sheath 8 French Walrus balloon guide catheter 0.035" Bentson Guidewire 0.035" Bentson Guidewire, exchange length 5 French Simmons 3 Glide catheter Asahi 018 microguidewire Trak 21 microcatheter RED 62 Aspiration Catheter kit Trevo NXT 3 x 32 Stentriever device  Perclose ProGlide closure device Omnipaque-300 contrast (40 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient's family (medical proxy). Specifically, the risks of intracranial or systemic hemorrhage, cerebral infarction, distal emboli, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, device malfunction, groin hematoma, arterial dissection/laceration, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite, intubated, and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; an 9 French sheath was introduced into the right common femoral artery. The 8 French balloon guide-catheter and diagnostic catheter were introduced into the left common carotid artery as a system. A roadmap angiogram was completed of the common carotid artery to visualize the carotid bifurcation. The diagnostic catheter was then used to select the internal carotid artery over the guidewire. The balloon guide catheter was then advanced into the cervical internal carotid artery over the wire and diagnostic catheter. The wire and diagnostic catheter were then removed and the balloon guide was connected to a continual heparinized saline flush. Digital angiograms were performed centered over the head.   The initial TICI score was 0 secondary to a left M2 superior division occlusion.  A triaxial system of the aspiration catheter, microcatheter, and microguidewire were advanced into the internal carotid artery over roadmap guidance. The Trak 21 microcatheter and Asahi 018 microwire were then advanced through the aspiration catheter past the M2 occlusion. The aspiration catheter was then tracked to the face of the clot. The wire was removed from the microcatheter and replaced with the Trevo NXT 3 x 32 stentriever device.  The stentriever was deployed under fluoroscopy and the allowed to set in the clot for 5 minutes. The microcatheter was removed so that that the stentriever was "naked" in the aspiration catheter. The balloon on the guide catheter was then inflated. The stentriever was then removed under continuous aspiration using a 60cc syringe. Thrombus was  identified within the stentriever device and the aspirate.  The balloon on the guide was deflated and a cerebral angiogram was performed through the guide catheter. Recanalization of the left middle cerebral artery was achieved with revascularization of the distal territory consistent with TICI 3.  An angiogram of the right common femoral artery was obtained; the artery was deemed appropriate for use of the Perclose ProGlide closure device. The sheath was removed and hemostasis obtained by deployment of the Perclose ProGlide closure device. A Tegaderm was then applied over the puncture site.  COMPARISON: Non-invasive imaging, same day  FINDINGS:  LEFT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CERVICAL (ROAD MAP): This run was done primarily for navigation and selection of left internal carotid artery and is of limited diagnostic utility. Within those confines, the bifurcation is smooth, without irregularity, calcification, or stenosis with respect to the distal ICA. The ECA branches opacify normally.  LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: A M2 superior division occlusion is identified consistent with TICI 0.   LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-THROMBECTOMY):  Interval recanalization of the previously occluded left M2 superior division Reperfusion has been reestablished consistent with TICI 3.   [HCW]T FEMORAL ARTERY: No abnormalities are detected. This vessel is suitable for use of the Perclose ProGlide closure device.  COMPLICATIONS: none immediate.  IMPRESSION:  1. Left M2 superior division occlusion with initial occlusion consistent with TICI 0.  2. Status-post single pass combined stentriever and aspiration technique thrombectomy with resultant TICI 3.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Infected hematoma  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled small bore single lumen central venous catheter placement  on the left chest  Findings:   1.	The left internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the tunneled catheter, as described, the tip terminates near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a power-injectable, 6 Fr, 26 cm, tunneled non-cuffed central venous catheter via the left internal jugular vein.       Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care.  The catheter is ready for immediate use.        Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).   The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the left internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the left internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the left internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a peel-away sheath set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture peel-away sheath set, the wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.  Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM WITH INTRA-ARTERIAL SPASMOLYTIC INFUSION FOR TREATMENT OF VASOSPASM  CLINICAL INDICATION: 37-year-old female with Hunt-Hess 3 subarachnoid hemorrhage from a ruptured left posterior communicating artery aneurysm with vasospasm on the basis of noninvasive imaging and trans-cranial doppler and CTA imaging.  PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram. Intra-arterial verapamil and milrinone infusion in left and right internal carotid arteries.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 60 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician. He supervised the entire procedure. [HCW] was the fellow. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Left internal carotid artery Right internal carotid artery Right common femoral artery  VESSELS TREATED: Left internal carotid artery Right internal carotid artery  ANESTHESIA: Local   MEDICATIONS:  Heparin 5000 units IV Verapamil 30 mg IA (15 mg in the left ICA and 15 mg in the right ICA) Milrinone 10 mg IA (10 mg in the left ICA)   MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 0.035" Bentson guidewire 5 French Cordis Vertebral catheter Visipaque 320 contrast material (60 cc) Mynx closure device  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, balloon rupture, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, heart block, hypotension, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery. A 5 French sheath was introduced into the right common femoral artery. 5000 units of heparin were administered intravenously after sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, the above listed arteries were selectively catheterized with the 5 French diagnostic catheter. Digital angiograms were performed centered over the head. 15 mg of intra-arterial verapamil were administered in the left ICA over 10 minutes. Subsequently 15 mg of verapamil were administered intra-arterially into the right ICA. Follow-up angiogram left internal carotid artery. Continued severe spasm. 10 mg of intra-arterial milrinone were administered into the left ICA approximately 20 minutes.   A follow-up control angiogram was performed of the left internal carotid artery showed significant improvement in the degree of vasospasm.  Following completion of the procedure, hemostasis was achieved by application of a Mynx device. Gauze and Tegaderms were then applied over the puncture site.  COMPARISON: Cerebral angiogram dated [DATE].  FINDINGS: LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (PRE-SPASMOLYSIS):  A surgical clip is seen in the expected location. There is no evidence of recurrent or residual aneurysm. There is severe spasm of the distal internal carotid artery and proximal middle cerebral artery, and mild to moderate spasm of the left anterior cerebral artery.   RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL:. There is moderate spasm of the right anterior cerebral artery.  LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST IA VERAPAMIL): Slight improvement in the degree of spasm of the distal left ICA and proximal left MCA..   LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST IA MILRINONE): Further improvement in the degree of spasm of the distal left ICA and proximal MCA and ACA. The spasm is now moderate in the distal ICA and proximal MCA and mild in the proximal ACA..   LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: No appreciable spasm of the posterior circulation  COMPLICATIONS: none immediate.  IMPRESSION:   1. There is severe spasm of the distal left internal carotid artery and proximal left middle cerebral artery. There is mild to moderate spasm of the left anterior cerebral artery and moderate spasm of the right anterior cerebral artery. 2. Following infusion of intra-arterial spasmolytic, there is improvement in the degree of spasm of the distal left ICA and proximal left MCA and ACA. The spasm is now moderate in the distal ICA and proximal MCA, and mild in the proximal ACA on the left. There appear to be greater response to milrinone infusion as compared to verapamil infusion. 3. No evidence of residual or recurrent left posterior communicating artery aneurysm.

A Sim 1 catheter was then used to catheterize the right adrenal vein. Follow-up in IR clinic  Technique:  With the patient in the supine position, the left wrist was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The left wrist was evaluated with ultrasound and left radial artery patency and acceptable size criteria were documented and images were properly stored in PACS. A modified Allen test (Barbeau test Type A) was performed on the left wrist to confirm patency of the ulnopalmar arch using pulse oximetry.   1% lidocaine solution was administered for local anesthesia. Access was obtained to the left radial artery using a 21 gauge micro needle and ultrasound guidance. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. A wire was placed through the needle. A hydrophilic Glidesheath was advanced slowly over the wire. 3000 units of heparin, 200 mcg of nitroglycerin and 2.5 mg of verapamil was given through the arterial sheath with slow hemodilution. A side flush was started.   A diagnostic catheter was advanced through the sheath into the aorta. Following aortography (if listed above), a catheter/microcatheter system was used to catheterize and opacify the pelvic vessels. First, catheterization and angiography of the left internal iliac artery was performed, followed by third order arteries and the prostatic artery, as listed above. Next, catheterization and angiography of the right internal iliac artery was performed, followed by third order arteries and the prostatic artery, as listed above.   Cone Beam CT (CBCT) was performed intraprocedurally to aid with anatomic localization, for treatment planning, and for confirmation of target embolization. Axial and coronal images were created and 3D reconstruction was performed on a separate dedicated workstation under concurrent supervision.  Embolization was performed using the technique and embolic listed above. Post-embolization angiography was then performed.  All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. A TR Band was placed on the left wrist for hemostasis. The access sheath was removed and no hematoma was seen. A radial artery pulse was confirmed distal to the puncture site confirming patent hemostasis.   The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Cervical cancer  Procedure:   1. The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen Bard power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed below  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 2-0 absorbable sutures. A running 4-0 absorbable subcuticular stitch and  Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with  Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: This is a 46 years Female who presents for diagnostic cerebral angiography following coil embolization of ruptured posterior communicating artery aneurysm   PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 30 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] was the fellow. Both actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Right Internal Carotid Artery Left Internal Carotid Artery  ANESTHESIA: Local in the right groin with bupivacaine. Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by the nurse present during the entire procedure. The [HCW]ient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Sedation was administered by a specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for the duration of the procedure as outlined above (Total intra service time, 30min ). Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.  MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine SQ 10 cc  Versed 1 mg IV Fentanyl 50 mcg IV Heparin 3000 units IV Protamine 20 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.038" Bentson guidewire 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 5 French Cordis Vertebral catheter  Mynx Closure Device Visipaque-270 contrast material (60 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery; a 5 French sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP, Lateral and Oblique views.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY:  Rotational angiography was also performed from the diagnostic catheter in the left internal carotid artery for better delineation of the underlying angioarchitecture. Three-dimensional angiographic images were processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.    Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a Mynx followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: Prior angiogram from [DATE].  FINDINGS:  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is redemonstration of the previously known right superior hypophyseal artery aneurysm measuring 3 x 2 mm. This is unchanged in size and appearance from prior angiogram. The ACA and MCA and its branches are normal in course and caliber. There is normal cortical venous drainage.   LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: Interval compaction of the coil mass.  The previously coil embolized left posterior communicating artery aneurysm demonstrates minimal residual filling at the base of the aneurysm. This measures 1.8 x 1 mm with a 3 mm neck. The posterior communicating artery is patent and arises from the base of the aneurysm. The ACA and MCA and its branches are normal course and caliber. There is normal cortical venous drainage.   3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY OF THE LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY: 3D Rotational angiography with volume-rendered three-dimensional reconstruction on an independent workstation, demonstrated residual filling at the base of the previously coil embolized left posterior communicating artery aneurysm measuring 1.8 x 1 mm with a 3 mm neck. The posterior communicating artery is patent and arises from the patient's aneurysm.  COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: 1. Interval coil compaction and residual filling at the base of the previously coil embolized left posterior communicating artery aneurysm measuring 1.8 x 1 mm with a 3 mm neck. The posterior communicating artery is patent and arises from the base of this aneurysm.  2. The previously identified right superior hypophyseal artery aneurysm is unchanged in size and appearance and measures 3 x 2 mm. 3. The patient was advised to discontinue aspirin.  [HCW], was present for the key and critical portions of the procedure and associated imaging guidance.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Small bowel resection, TPN dependent.  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled central venous single-lumen Hickman catheter placement via right internal jugular access 2.	Right chest porta catheter removal.   Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the Hickman catheter, as described, the tip terminates near the cavoatrial junction.. 3.	Right chest porta catheter was removed in its entirety.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a tunneled Hickman catheter. 2.	Technically successful right chest port catheter removal.       Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care.  The catheter is ready for immediate use.        Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS.  A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.  Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The venotomy tract was dilated to allow introduction of a peel-away sheath.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The catheter was tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.   The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS.     Attention was directed to the right chest port. The skin underlying soft tissue was anesthetized with 1% lidocaine. An incision was made along the old chest port incision with a 15 blade. The chest port reservoir was freed from surrounding scar tissue using blunt dissection. The chest reservoir and attached catheter were removed in its entirety. The incision was closed with 3-0 Vicryl and Dermabond. Sterile dressing applied.  The patient tolerated the procedure without immediate complication. PICC placement   Findings:   -right cephalic vein patency was documented by ultrasound and stored to PACS -bifurcation of the central cephalic vein to two small veins, making superior and inferior cephalic arches -PICC tip terminates near the superior cavoatrial junction.     Impression:   1.	PICC placement via the right cephalic vein   Catheter: 5-Fr. 40 cm double-lumen PICC   Treatment Plan:   Catheter tip position is confirmed as above. The line was secured in place using 2-0 Prolene suture and each lumen was flushed with heparinized saline. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].IR.1  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  significant left nephrolithiasis, for percutaneous nephrolithotomy.  Percutaneous nephrostomy access gained yesterday  Procedure:   1.	Intra-operative left nephrostogram 2.	Left nephrostomy tube replacement  Comparison: Previous exam [DATE]  Findings:    -radiographic suggestion of nephromegaly -very significant stone burden, with chunky calcific densities projecting over every part of the left renal collecting system -indwelling nephrostomy tube (NT) in a mid pole calyx -no apparent propagation of contrast past the opacified upper pole calyces  -severe limitation by the radiographic equipment during the procedure, with rapid onset of the X-ray tube over-heating; repeated and prolonged need to pause to allow for cooling of the X-ray tube  -given the aforementioned limitation, no success at crossing the upper pole calyces into the renal pelvis.  Similar outcome resulted from gaining percutaneous access to a different upper/mid pole calyx. This forced the abandonment of the percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL) -new 8.5-Fr. NT left in place, in anticipation of patient returning for repeat percutaneous access and trans-renal intubation of the ureter and urinary bladder    Catheter:  8.5-Fr. pigtail catheter    Impression:   1.	left nephromegaly and very significant nephrolithiasis, with multiple staghorn calculi occupying the entirety of the collecting system 2.	stone obstruction of accessed mid pole calyces, preventing timely wire/catheter access to the stone filled renal pelvis and ureter 3.	NT left in place   Treatment Plan:   Patient to return for re-access to the left renal collecting system, with mandatory intubation of the ureter and urinary bladder   Technique:   The procedure was performed in the operating room, with the patient intubated, in the prone position.    This intra-operative procedure was severely limited by the radiographic equipment, with rapid onset of the X-ray tube over-heating; repeated and prolonged need to pause to allow for cooling of the persistently over-heated X-ray tube.    Sterile technique and fluoroscopic guidance were used to inject contrast via the indwelling left NT. Exchange was made over an 0.035-in Amplatz wire for an 8-Fr. introducer sheath.  Through this, a 5-Fr. angled glide catheter, over an 0.035-in glide wire, was used to negotiate past the calyx, in attempt to intubate the renal pelvis.  There was some success, with the distal catheter tip reaching the superior aspect of the renal pelvis, albeit without the ability to further advance the catheter.   21-g needle access was then gained to a different, immediately more superior calyx, with exchange made over an 0.018-in Cope wire for a 5-Fr. Accustick introducer set.  This afforded 0.035-in Rosen wire exchange for an 8-Fr. introducer sheath, through which a 5-Fr. angled catheter, over the glide wire, was used to attempt to cross into the renal pelvis.  There was no apparent exit possible, within the limited time, to exit from the enlarged, stone burdened calyx.   Exchange was then made over an 0.035-in Rosen wire for a new 8.5-Fr. pigtail catheter, with the distal loop left within the accessed calyx.  The catheter was secured in place using 2-0 Prolene suturing to the skin, then connected to gravity bag drainage.  Patient tolerated the procedure well. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].1  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication: right UPJ obstruction and indwelling, known non-functional ureteral stent and (functional) nephrostomy tube (NT).  Patient due for maintenance change of the latter but presents through the ED for suspicion of catheter dislodgement  Procedure:   1.	right nephrostogram 2.	Retrieval: right internal ureteral stent 3.	Placement: right nephroureterostomy tube    Findings:  Comparison is made to a previous exam dated [DATE].  -external drainage catheter, in proper position -adequate decompression of the partially duplicated, low lying renal collecting system -no propagation of contrast past the (short) renal pelvis -no opacification of the indwelling stent  -independent guide wire/catheter passage along side the ureteral stent -percutaneous retrieval of the ureteral stent -placement of a new nephroureterostomy (PCNU) catheter-stent  Catheter(s):  10-Fr. 22-cm nephroureterostomy tube   Impression:   1.	adequate decompression of the elongated, partially duplicated, renal collecting system, with a low-lying renal pelvis, via a properly positioned external nephrostomy tube 2.	occluded internal ureteral stent, removed 3.	placement of a nephroureterostomy tube   Treatment Plan:   Care instructions given to the patient, including 24-hr contact information for Interventional Radiology Patient should return for routine check and change in 12 weeks.     Technique:   Scout radiograph shows a low-lying upper loop of the indwelling right internal ureteral stent.  The indwelling nephrostomy tube (NT) appears to be properly positioned.    Sterile technique and fluoroscopic guidance were used to inject contrast via the indwelling right NT.  Over an 0.035-in Amplatz wire, the latter was removed, exchanged for an 8-Fr. x 25-cm introducer sheath, with the distal tip left within the renal pelvis.  Through the sheath, a 5-Fr. angled catheter, over an 0.035-in glide wire, was advanced, made to pass through the ureter, with successful intubation of the bladder.  The catheter was then removed, leaving wire access.   Through the sheath, a 25-mm gooseneck snare wire was advanced, used to catch the superior loop of the ureteral stent.  The latter was retracted, and removed in its entirety, along with the outer sheath.   Exchange was then made over the Amplatz wire for a new 10-Fr. x 22-cm dual loop internal/external nephroureteral stent-catheter, with each loop left within the bladder and renal pelvis.  The catheter was secured in place, left capped for sole internal drainage.    The patient tolerated the procedure well. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Gastric varices. NASH cirrhosis and portal hypertension status post TIPS placement in [DATE] and TIPS revision to 10 mm in 2018.  PROCEDURE:   1. US-guided right common femoral vein access. 2. Left renal venogram 3. Gastrorenal shunt venogram 4. Balloon & coil-assisted sclerosis & embolization of gastrorenal shunt 5. Post-embolization venogram  FINDINGS: ANGIOGRAPHY: Vessels catheterized and angiograms performed, as follows:  Left renal vein: Findings: Note of duplicated left renal veins with retro-aortic course. Dominant superior left renal venogram demonstrates a gastrorenal shunt.  Left gastrorenal shunt:  Findings: Shunt opacified without and with balloon occlusion technique, identifying the known varix.   Post-treatment angiogram of the gastrorenal shunt: Findings: No persistent filling. Static staining of sclerosant identified within the varix.  Transcatheter sclerosis: Sclerosant: Sotradecol (STS) Details: 3:2:1 concentration; 12 mL utilized  Transcatheter embolization: Embolic: Coils Details (type/size/volume/number):  Balt Prestige Plus Complex 15 mm x 65 cm (x2) Balt Prestige Plus Complex 14 mm x 45 cm (x1) Balt Prestige Plus Complex 12 mm x 65 cm (x2) Balt Prestige Plus Complex 9 mm x 65 cm (x2)  Specific technical notes / catheter selection: None  IMPRESSION:   Technically successful BRTO.  TREATMENT PLAN:  1. Continue to trend hemoglobin 2. Routine post-procedural orders written 3. Patient will be seen in clinic in 3 months  TECHNIQUE: With the patient in the supine position, the right groin was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The patient was placed on the table in a supine position. Following standard prepping and draping, the right common femoral vein was punctured using a needle. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. Using this access, an 0.035" wire was advanced into the IVC. A vascular sheath was placed over the wire into the common femoral vein.  Using a reverse curve catheter, the left renal vein was catheterized and angiography was performed. The communicating gastrorenal shunt was then catheterized using the diagnostic catheter and angiography was performed. Using a stiff wire for exchange, the existing catheter was removed and replaced with a long vascular sheath, which was placed carefully into the shunt. A balloon catheter was introduced through the sheath and utilized to opacify the shunt in retrograde fashion. Using the balloon and a microcatheter/microwire combination, the shunt was cannulated and sclerosed/embolized using the technique detailed above. Angiography was then repeated to ensure technical success.  All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. Manual pressure was used for hemostasis. The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL][ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Enthesioblastoma with deep venous thrombosis of the lower extremity in [DATE]. Patient could not receive anticoagulation at that time so required IVC Filter.  Now tolerating Eliquis without issue.   Procedure:   1.	US-guided right IJ venous access 2.	Inferior vena cavogram pre-filter removal 3.	Fluoroscopic-guided IVC filter removal 4.	Inferior vena cavogram post-filter removal  Findings:  Initial Inferior Vena Cavogram: No significant captured thrombus. No significant filter tilt documented.  Retrieval technique: Technique: Multiple techniques utilized.  Snare, unsuccessful.  Hangman, unsuccessful.  Forceps, successful.   Post-retrieval Inferior Vena Cavogram: Inferior vena cavography was then performed from the indwelling catheter/sheath, confirming IVC integrity and en-bloc filter retrieval without retained fragments.  Impression:   1.	Successful IVC filter retrieval.  Treatment Plan:   Continue anticoagulation as indicated.  Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained to the patient. The specific risks of bleeding, vascular damage and pulmonary embolus were detailed and accepted. Written informed consent was obtained. A time out/call to order was performed prior to procedure initiation.  The patient was brought to the procedure suite and placed on the table in supine position. The right neck was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).   The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the access site were infiltrated with lidocaine for local anesthetic. Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency. Under continuous ultrasound guidance, with permanent recording and reporting, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018" wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire. Through the micropuncture introducer set, an 0.035" Amplatz wire was advanced into the IVC under fluoroscopic guidance. The Cook retrievable set sheath was placed at the access site and advanced into the IVC and cavography was then performed, with no evidence of caval thrombus, or significant filter tilt.  Initial attempts to snare the filter using standard loops near and Tulip snare techniques were all unsuccessful. We then exchanged the Cook retrievable set for Argon [VENDOR]k 16 French/14 French sheath combination, and converted to hangman technique using a reverse curve SOS2 catheter, 0.035 inch exchange length Glidewire, and loop snare. The filter was able to being engaged using hangman technique, however could not be over sheathed.  Given the difficulties, the indwelling sheath was then upsize to an 18 French sheath. Through the 18 French sheath, forceps were used to engage the apex of the filter off of the vessel wall. The grasped filter/forceps were sheathed over and the filter was removed without issue.  After retrieval from the patient, the filter was deployed on the procedure table to document adequate capture and removal of all components of the filter itself.   Post-filter removal venography was then performed, without any findings of caval injury.   All instruments and devices were removed and hemostasis achieved with a woggle suture. No immediate complication occurred, and the patient was discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  End-stage renal disease, tunneled large bore central venous catheter requested.  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled large bore central venous catheter placement  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the large bore central venous catheter, as described, the tip terminates in the right atrium. 3.	Previously placed non-tunneled large bore central venous catheter noted.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a  15.5 French, 19 cm (tip-to-cuff), tunneled large bore central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.  Treatment Plan:   1. Routine catheter care. 2. The catheter is ready for immediate use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissues overlying the vein were infiltrated with 1% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle. An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the dialysis catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Ovarian cancer, port placement requested  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen Bard port (standard profile)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses.  2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen Bard power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 1% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 2-0 absorbable sutures. Dermabond and Steri-Strips was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with Dermabond and Steri-Strips.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication: Acute (6 weeks or less) L4 osteolytic malignant vertebral body/vertebral bodies compression fracture(s), from metastatic prostate cancer. Spine MRI/bone-scan is within 30 days of this procedure and was performed on [DATE]. Patient has severe back pain despite optimal non-surgical management with severe impact of vertebral body compression fracture(s) on daily functioning. Patient has kyphotic deformity due to vertebral body compression fracture(s).     Procedure:   1.	Image-guided L4 kyphoplasty  2.   Image-guided lumbar epidural steroid injection (interlaminar approach)   Findings:   1.	Pre-intervention (kyphoplasty): L4 vertebral body compression deformity. 2.	Post-intervention (kyphoplasty):  Successful deposition of cement within the treated vertebral body/bodies with no evidence of extravasation.   3.	Appropriate positioning of the needle within the lumbar epidural space.  Impression:   1.	Technically successful image guided L4 vertebral augmentation with cavity creation (kyphoplasty). 2.	Technically successful image guided lumbar epidural steroid injection.   Treatment Plan:   1.	 A fracture of the hip, spine or distal radius in patients over 50 years of age warrants testing or treatment for osteoporosis if not previously undertaken.   Patient was instructed to take part in an osteoporosis prevention/treatment program.    Technique:   The patient was brought to the interventional radiology suite and placed on the table in prone position. The wide area of the back around the affected area(s) was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion.   All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). A scout image was obtained in AP and lateral projections.   Skin was anesthetized with a 2% lidocaine solution.   Level by level technique:   -Vertebral level:  L4     -Pedicle access:  Bipedicular -Access trocar gauge:  11-gauge -Balloon utilized:  15 mm  Prior to injection of cement, balloons were inserted and inflated under biplane fluoroscopy.  Static fluoroscopic images were stored to PACS documenting balloon utilization and position. -Biopsy obtained:  No -Indication for biopsy: N/A -Ablation Performed: N/A -Indication for Ablation: N/A  Additional Procedural Details:   Utilizing AP and lateral fluoroscopy, needles were inserted into the affected vertebral body/bodies. Needles were advanced under careful, intermittent biplane fluoroscopy to ensure that the medial wall of the pedicle was not violated prior to transgression of the needle tip into the posterior wall of the vertebral body. An angled cannula was advanced to the anterior one third of the vertebral body using a unipedicular approach under fluoroscopic guidance.  A balloon was inserted into the effected vertebral body and inflated under fluoroscopy. Static fluoroscopic images were stored to PACS documenting balloon position. Cement was mixed and balloon was removed after being deflated.  Cement was then injected under careful, intermittent biplane fluoroscopy to ensure no significant extravasation of PMMA cement beyond the borders of the vertebral body. Cement injection was stopped once there was adequate fill of the vertebral body. Trochars were removed with hemostasis obtained with focal compression. Static fluoroscopic images were obtained after removal of all needles documenting final cement position.   Lumbar epidural steroid injection:  Using fluoroscopic guidance, a 22-gauge spinal needle was advanced into the lumbar epidural space using a loss-of-resistance technique and a interlaminar approach at the L5-S1 level. Aspiration yielded no CSF fluid or blood. Less than 1 cc of Omnipaque 240 was injected without resistance demonstrating appropriate positioning of the needle within the epidural space. A total of 2 cc 0.25% bupivacaine and 40 mg Kenalog was injected through the spinal needle without resistance. The needle was removed.    Sterile dressings were applied.    The patient tolerated the procedure without immediate complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Metastatic renal cell carcinoma to the femur. Plan for surgical resection. Preop embolization to decrease intraoperative blood loss.  PROCEDURE:   1. US-guided left common femoral artery access. 2. Right lower extremity angiography 3. Arterial embolization 4. Post-embolization angiography 5. Left common femoral artery angiogram and closure  FINDINGS: ANGIOGRAPHY: Vessels catheterized using base catheter and microcatheter/microwire combination and angiograms performed:  Right common femoral artery artery: Widely patent without any focal abnormality. Right superficial femoral artery artery: Tumoral blush identified that supplies both PET avid lesion and additional lesion in the metaphysis. Right deep femoral artery (profunda femoris) artery: Tumoral blush identified that supplies both PET avid lesion and additional lesion in the metaphysis. 4th order branch off the right superficial femoral artery (series 10): No tumoral blush identified. 4th order branch off the right superficial femoral artery (series 11): Tumoral blush identified that supplies both PET avid lesion and additional lesion in the metaphysis. 4th order branch off the right deep femoral artery (series 29): Tumoral blush identified that supplies the PET avid lesion in the distal femur. Post-embolization angiography: Significantly decreased tumor blush and vascularity in the known right femoral RCC metastasis in the distal femur.  Transcatheter embolization: Vessel 1: 4th order branch off the superficial femoral artery (series 15)  Embolic: Particles Details (type/size/volume/number):  1/4 vial Embozene 500 um  Vessel 2: 4th order branch off the deep femoral artery (series 31)  Embolic: Particles Details (type/size/volume/number):  1/4 vial Embozene 500 um   IMPRESSION:   Technically successful particle embolization of the right femur renal cell carcinoma metastatic lesion with significant reduction of tumor blushing. Of note, there is an additional lesion in the distal femur metaphysis that was not PET avid.  TREATMENT PLAN:  1. Admit to orthopedics. Plan for surgical resection tomorrow. 2. Routine post-angiography groin cares ordered.  TECHNIQUE: With the patient in the supine position, the groin was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. Following standard prepping and draping, the left common femoral artery was punctured using a needle. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. An 0.035" Bentson wire was advanced into the aorta. A vascular sheath was placed over the wire into the common femoral artery. A side flush was started.  A 5-Fr SOS 2 diagnostic catheter was advanced over an 0.035" wire into the abdominal aorta, and then used for up and over access. The SOS was then exchanged for a 5 French Kumpe catheter. Initial angiograms were performed to delineate the vascular supply to the tumor, with tumor blush identified off the small branches from both the SFA and DFA.  The SFA was catheterized, and a 2.0 Progreat/Fathom wire microcatheter/microwire combination was used to select a feeder vessel supplying the tumor. Embolization was performed as above. Postembolization angiography showed significantly decreased tumor blush.  Attention was then turned to the profunda femoris, and the above microcatheter/microwire combination was used to select first the small feeders supplying the tumor. Additional embolization as above was performed, to substasis.  A final post embolization angiogram demonstrated significantly decreased tumor blush to the known metastatic lesion; and preserved perfusion down the patient's leg.   The catheters were removed from the patient. A left common femoral artery angiogram was performed, [HCW]trating appropriate vascular access above the profunda femoris artery bifurcation. All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. Hemostasis was achieved using Angio-Seal vascular closure device. The site was dressed in usual fashion.  The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. Post intervention pulses were intact, and unchanged from before the procedure in the bilateral lower extremities. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]  Clinical Indication:  Bacteremia  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled central venous catheter placement       Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the tunneled catheter, as described, the tip terminates near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a power-injectable, 6 Fr, 22 cm, tunneled non-cuffed central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.       Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care.  The catheter is ready for immediate use.        Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed below.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a peel-away sheath set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture peel-away sheath set, the wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.  Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS.          Procedural Personnel Attending(s): [HCW] Advanced practice provider(s): [HCW]  Complications: No immediate complications. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Right pelvic renal transplant, with mid/distal ureteral stricture. Follow-up.  Procedure:  1. Right antegrade nephrostogram and percutaneous nephroureterostomy exchange.   Findings:  1. Right antegrade nephrostogram demonstrates severe mid to distal ureter narrowing, worse since prior exam [DATE]. 2. Newly placed PCNU is appropriately positioned with the proximal loop in the renal pelvis and distal loop in the urinary bladder.  Impression:  Uneventful image-guided exchange of Right percutaneous nephroureterostomy tube. Given interval worsening, decision was made to replace with a PCNU rather than PCN for capping trial.  Plan:   Patient will be due for routine exchange in 8 weeks, preferably after patient has been seen and evaluated by transplant team in their anticipated follow-up visit.  Technique:  With the patient in supine position, the anterior right lower quadrant was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. A scout radiograph was obtained.   Contrast was injected through the existing nephroureterostomy tube and imaging of the collecting was system performed. A 0.035" wire was placed through the tube and the tube removed over the wire and discarded. The distal tip of the catheter was occluded and able to be traversed using a 0.035" Glidewire and 5 Fr Kumpe catheter. Over-the-wire, a 9 French by 25 cm sheath was advanced to the ureterovesicular junction where contrast was injected as the sheath was retracted to the collecting system, with findings as above. Sheath was removed, and over the wire a new, 18-French x 25 cm nephroureterostomy tube was advanced over the wire under fluoroscopic guidance as there was interval worsening of the mid to distal ureter stricture since [DATE]. The wire was removed and the proximal loop formed and locked in the bladder. Contrast injection confirmed location.  The catheter was sutured to the anterior abdominal wall and capped. A sterile dressing was applied.    The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Caretaker:  [PATIENT] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Line exchange and replacement due to persistent fungemia.  Procedure:   1. Right external jugular venography 2. Right subclavian venoplasty 3. Right central venous triple lumen non-tunneled catheter placement 4. Right central venous non-tunneled double lumen line exchange  	  Findings:   -wound vac is present at the right upper anterior chest wall -few surgical clips and wires are scattered over the right hemithorax -right subclavian AICD and left lower chest LVAD, in place -endotracheal and nasogastric tubes appear in good position -indwelling right internal jugular central venous (RIJV) catheter (CVC) has its distal tip at the superior cavoatrial junction  -significant stenosis at the junction of the right subclavian and brachiocephalic (BCV) veins prevented the advance of the right external jugular central venous (REJV) catheter.  This was possible only after venoplasty of the stenotic lesion  -over-a-wire exchange of the indwelling RIJV CVC   Impression:   1. over-the-wire exchange of the indwelling RIJV hemodialysis catheter 2. significant stenosis at the junction of the right SCV and BCV prevented the advance of the REJV CVC, with the presence of the chronically indwelling AICD lead wires.  Catheter advancement was made possible by  venoplasty of the stenotic lesion  Catheters RIJV: 14-Fr. x 20-cm dual-lumen non-tunneled hemodialysis catheter REJV: 7-Fr. x 20-cm triple-lumen catheter    Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care. The catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:   Sterile technique and sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance were used to gain 21-g needle access to the REJV.  Exchange was made over an 0.018-in Cope wire for a 5-Fr. micropuncture set.  The direction of wire propagation was isolated to across the mid  upper hemithorax, prompting contrast investigation.    Exchange was made over an 0.035-in glide wire for a 4-Fr. angled catheter.  The catheter-wire combination was retracted and re-directed caudally, into the central right SCV, then advanced to the superior vena cava (SVC).  exchange was then made over an 0.035-in Amplatz wire for a 7-Fr. dilator, followed by the 7-Fr. triple-lumen CVC.  The latter could not be advanced past the right SCV-BCV junction prompting the exchange for a 4-mm balloon catheter.  The latter was used to dilate the right SCV-BCV junction, followed by the successful advancement of the REJV CVC, with its distal tip left at the superior cavoatrial junction.     Through the indwelling RIJV hemodialysis (HD) catheter, exchange was made over the Amplatz wire for a new 14-Fr. 20-cm dual-lumen HD catheter, with its distal tip advanced to the superior cavoatrial junction.    Each port of each newly placed catheter was tested to ensure adequate function, then flushed with heparinized saline solution.   The catheters wer3 sutured to the skin using 2-0 Prolene suture.  A sterile dressing was placed at each catheter entry site.    The patient tolerated the procedure well. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Partially dislodged left external biliary catheter. Hilar mass with biliary obstruction.  Procedure:   1.	Internalization/conversion of left external biliary catheter to left internal/external biliary catheter under fluoroscopic guidance. 2.	Right internal/external biliary drain contrast evaluation under fluoroscopic guidance  Findings:   1.	Preprocedure precarious positioning of the left external biliary catheter with peritoneal loop 2.	Newly placed internal/external biliary drain is appropriately positioned with the distal tip in the third portion of the duodenum and the proximal side hole in a peripheral bile duct. 3.	Unchanged position of right internal/external biliary catheter. 4.	Moderate stricture of the right segment 8 duct; however, it fills briskly with gentle contrast administration.  Impression:   1.	Internalization of left biliary catheter and evaluation of right biliary catheter.  Treatment Plan:   Leave the drains to gravity bag until cholangitis resolves. If bilirubin does not down trend, consideration for separate drainage of segment 8 ducts (although this would possibly risks transpleural catheter placement), repeat plasty of segment 8 duct, or possible catheter upsize will be made at time of next procedure.  Technique:   The existing catheter and surrounding soft tissues were prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site.  An 0.035" Bentson wire was fully negotiated through the catheter into the left sided ducts. The catheter was removed, and a Kumpe catheter was advanced. A Rosen wire was advanced through the Kumpe. A 5 French 25 cm sheath was advanced. Using a Kumpe catheter and Glidewire, the wire was negotiated into the small bowel through the tight common duct stenosis. The wire was exchanged for an Amplatz.   A new 8.5 French internal/external biliary drain with standard sideholes was placed over the wire. Contrast was injected to confirm tube position. The catheter was secured to the skin with 2-0 Ethilon. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Choledochojejunostomy with anastomotic stricture. Patient underwent cholecystectomy and choledochal jejunostomy for gallbladder adenocarcinoma and metastatic pancreatic neuroendocrine carcinoma in [DATE]. Patient underwent forceps and brush biopsy which were negative on [DATE].  Procedure:   1.	Sheath cholangiogram through existing percutaneous access 2.	Brush biopsy x3 of the biliary anastomotic stricture. 3.	Cholangioplasty of the anastomotic stricture. 4.	Left internal/external biliary drain replacement  Findings:   1.	Sheath cholangiogram demonstrates free flow of contrast into the small bowel through the anastomosis. However, there is still moderate narrowing and irregular appearance of the stricture. 2.	Mildly improved appearance the stricture post cholangioplasty 3.	Newly placed biliary drain is appropriately positioned with the distal tip in the third portion of the duodenum and the proximal side hole in a peripheral bile duct.  Impression:   1.	Brush biopsy x3 and cholangioplasty with exchange of left-sided internal/external biliary catheter. 2.	 Treatment Plan:   Patient capped to internal drainage. Instructed to place to gravity bag drainage if she experiences significant pain, fevers, chills, or large leakage.  Patient will need to undergo one additional biopsy (she has had 2) to rule out underlying malignancy as a cause of the stricture and an abundance of caution. This could be performed in 3 months the time of her next routine exchange.  At that point, likely will replace 18 French catheter with plans to perform external drain capping trial during the following procedure.  Technique:   The existing catheter and surrounding soft tissues were prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site.  A stiff Glidewire was negotiated through the catheter into the small bowel with a 4 French catheter. The Glidewire was exchanged for an Amplatz. The catheter was removed and exchanged for a 14 French sheath. A sheath cholangiogram was performed.  Next, through the sheath, 3 brush biopsies were performed of the anastomotic stricture. These were placed in CytoLyt. Next, over the wire, a 12 mm x 4 cm long Mustang balloon was advanced to the anastomosis. This size balloon was selected based on prior cholangioplasty for this patient. Cholangioplasty was then performed. Contrast was injected demonstrating mild improvement in the appearance of the stricture.  The sheath was removed and a new 18 French internal/external biliary drain with extended sideholes was placed over the wire. Contrast was injected to confirm tube position. The catheter was secured to the skin with 2-0 Ethilon. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]  Clinical Indication:  Leukemia  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen Bard port (standard profile)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen Bard power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 2-0 absorbable sutures. A running 4-0 absorbable subcuticular stitch and  Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with a single subcuticular stitch and Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication.
