Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  [ID]C[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Liver predominant breast cancer metastases, refractory to chemotherapy. Patient is not a surgical candidate for the liver metastases. Patient currently on Oserdu.    PROCEDURE:  Y90 Shunt study/mapping using MAA  1. US-guided right femoral artery access 2. Diagnostic visceral angiography 3. MAA delivery 4. Right common femoral artery angiogram 5. Cone-beam CT performed for intraprocedural localization, as detailed below. 6. Right common femoral arteriotomy closure using a closure device   FINDINGS: ANGIOGRAPHY: Vessels catheterized and angiograms performed, as follows:  Superior mesenteric artery: No replaced or accessory hepatic arterial supply. Celiac artery: Tumoral blushes identified corresponding to the right hepatic lobe and caudate lobe. Right gastric artery appears to arise from the proximal left hepatic artery. Left hepatic artery: Left hepatic artery gives rise to segments 2, 3 and 4 arteries. Right gastric artery arises from the proximal left hepatic artery. Right hepatic artery: Tumoral blushes identified. No extrahepatic arterial supply.    Specific technical notes / catheter selection: 2.8 Fr Progreat, Fathom 0.016  CBCT: Yes 1. Catheter location: Left hepatic artery Findings: No tumor blush.   CBCT: Yes 2. Catheter location: Right hepatic artery Findings: Tumoral blushes identified with supply from the target vessel to the right hepatic lobe and caudate lobe tumors. No extrahepatic arterial supply.    Embolization: No Vessel embolized: N/a Coils used: N/a    MAA delivery performed from: Right hepatic artery (series 9-11)  Future target Y90 delivery catheter position(s): Right hepatic artery (Series 9-11) Treatment device: [VENDOR]aSphere Split-Dose: No Dosimetry Model: MIRD dosed to the right lobe. Desired lobar/tumoral (if partition) dose: 110 Gy Additional details: None   IMPRESSION:   Successful Yttrium-90 TheraSpheres selective internal radiotherapy mapping.  TREATMENT PLAN:  1. Patient will return in 2-4 weeks for Y90 radioembolization. 2. Access site precautions and orders placed.  TECHNIQUE:  With the patient in the supine position, the groin was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The patient was placed on the table in a supine position. Following standard prepping and draping, the common femoral artery was punctured using a needle. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. An 0.035" wire was advanced into the aorta. A 6 French vascular sheath was placed over the wire into the common femoral artery. A side flush was started.  A 5-Fr catheter was advanced over an 0.035" wire into the abdominal aorta. The catheter was used to catheterize the vessels described below. Angiograms were performed. A microcatheter system was used to catheterize distal vessels, as described below. Specific vessels catheterized and embolized are described in detail below.  Cone Beam CT (CBCT) was performed intraprocedurally for purposes of treatment planning, targeting and dose calculation. Axial and coronal images were created and 3D reconstruction was performed on a separate dedicated workstation under concurrent supervision.  After confirmation of target treatment vessel, 5 mCi of Tc-99 MAA was injected slowly into this location though the catheter.   A right common femoral artery angiogram was performed, demonstrating appropriate vascular access above the profunda femoris artery bifurcation. All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. Hemostasis was achieved using vascular closure device, 6 French Angio-Seal. The site was dressed in usual fashion.  The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. The patient was transferred to the Nuclear Medicine department for imaging. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Multiple myeloma; stem cell therapy  Procedure:  1. placement of a tunneled, cuffed central venous catheter  Findings:  1. The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and normal. Vein patency and needle entry were stored to PACS. 2. The newly placed catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating in the superior cavoatrial junction  Impression:   Placement of right internal jugular vein tunneled triple-lumen (Trifusion) catheter   Technique:  The right neck and chest region was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. The region was ultrasonographically evaluated.  Using local anesthetic and ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was punctured with a 21-g needle.  An image documenting vein patency and needle entry was saved and stored to PACS.   A 0.018” wire was passed centrally and the needle exchanged for a 5 French transitional dilator. A 0.035” wire was advanced through the dilator and negotiated into the IVC.  The skin tract was dilated and a 13 French dilator peel-away combination placed over the wire.  The soft tissues caudal and lateral to the sheath entry site were anesthetized with lidocaine with epinephrine. A dermatotomy was made and a tunneling tool brought from the dermatotomy to the venotomy. The catheter was brought through the tunnel.  During suspended respiration, the catheter was advanced through the peel-away and positioned centrally using fluoroscopy. The peel-away was removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression.  The venotomy was closed with Dermabond and Steri-Strips applied. A single Prolene suture was placed at the catheter tunnel exit site. An antimicrobial disc and sterile dressing were applied.  The catheter was aspirated, flushed, and heparinized per protocol. The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient was discharged in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL][ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Uterine fibroids with menorrhagia  PROCEDURE:   1.	Ultrasound-guided left radial artery access 2.	Pelvic angiography 3.	Uterine artery embolization 4.	Post-embolization angiography  Findings:  Vessels catheterized and angiograms performed as detailed below:  Right internal iliac artery: enlarged uterine artery with a myomatous uterus identified. Right uterine artery: Fibroid blush identified. No cervical branches.   Left internal iliac artery: enlarged uterine artery with a myomatous uterus identified. Left uterine artery: Fibroid blush identified. No cervical branches.  Embolization:  Right uterine: 1. 1.5 vials 5-700 u EmboSpheres  Left uterine: 1. 2.5 vials 5-700 u EmboSpheres  Intra-arterial medication administration: lidocaine 10 mL given bilaterally (5 mL each side).  Hypogastric Nerve Block: N/a  Post-Embolization Angiograms: Right uterine artery: Sluggish flow without opacification of the uterine fibroids. Left uterine artery: Sluggish flow without opacification of the uterine fibroids.  Technical notes: None.  Impression:  1. Enlarged uterine branches bilaterally with a leiomyomatous uterus, status post successful bilateral uterine artery embolization.  Treatment Plan:  1. The patient will be monitored for 4-6 hours to assess for the need for an observation admission for pain control. 2. Patient will be discharged with a stool softener/laxative, analgesic, anti-emetic, and a narcotic for pain control. 3. Patient will follow-up in clinic with IR.  Technique:  With the patient in the supine position, the left wrist was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The left wrist was evaluated with ultrasound and left radial artery patency and acceptable size criteria were documented. Images were properly stored in PACS. A modified Allen test (Barbeau test Type A) was performed on the left wrist to confirm patency of the ulnopalmar arch using pulse oximetry.   1% lidocaine solution was administered for local anesthesia. Access was obtained to the left radial artery using a 21 gauge micro needle and ultrasound guidance. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. A wire was placed through the needle. A hydrophilic Glidesheath was advanced slowly over the wire. 3000 units of heparin, 200 mcg of nitroglycerin and 2.5 mg of verapamil was given through the arterial sheath with slow hemodilution. A side flush was started. Hypogastric nerve block, if utilized, is detailed above.  Diagnostic catheter and microcatheter were advanced through the sheath into the aorta and used to catheterize the bilateral internal iliac arteries and pelvic vessels described above. Angiograms were performed. Specific vessels catheterized and embolized are described in detail above. Post-embolization angiography was performed and described above.  All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. A TR Band was placed on the left wrist for hemostasis. The access sheath was removed and no hematoma was seen. A radial artery pulse was confirmed distal to the puncture site confirming patent hemostasis.   The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Dysphagia after large MCA territory infarct, requiring gastrostomy placement in [DATE]. Additional development of probable aspiration pneumonia after gastrostomy placement, requiring gastrojejunostomy.  Procedure:   1.	Conversion of G tube to a gastrojejunostomy (GJ-tube) over a wire.  Findings:   1.	The existing tube courses through the stomach with tip terminating in the first segment of the duodenum.  2.	The new tube is appropriately positioned with the distal aspect of the tube terminating in the proximal portion of the jejunum.  Impression:   1.	Successful conversion of existing G tube for a new 18 French MIC GJ tube with tip in jejunum. Please refer to same day procedure note for further recommendations regarding optimal GJ tube placement.  Treatment Plan:   It is OK to use the tube immediately.    Routine check and change recommended in 6 months, which can either be done at patient's local hospital versus within the [HOSPITAL] system. The skin overlying the access site was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). The skin and subcutaneous tissue around the existing tube were infiltrated with local anesthetic.  A scout image was obtained over the abdomen.  The pre-existing gastrostomy tube was injected with contrast, demonstrating the tip to be at the first segment of the duodenum. A stiff Glidewire was cannulated into the port of the pre-existing tube and passed into the stomach. The pre-existing G tube was removed over the wire after deflating the bulb. A 5Fr Kumpe catheter was advanced over the wire, and then advanced with the Glidewire into the third segment of the duodenum. The Glidewire was exchanged for an Amplatz wire, which was navigated into the jejunum. The Kumpe catheter was removed. A new gastrojejunostomy tube was advanced over the wire. Its tip was placed in the proximal jejunum. The bulb was inflated with 10 mL of a 10% contrast mixture. The wire was removed.    Contrast injection confirmed appropriate positioning of the G and J side ports. The disc was cinched. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE].  Clinical Indication:  Recurrent tense ascites. Request is made for emergency paracentesis.  Complications: No immediate complications.  Procedure: After explaining the technique, risks, benefits, alternatives, and' questions, informed consent was obtained from the patient. Timeout identifying the correct patient, procedure, site and allergies was performed and observed by the operating team. The patient was positioned supine  and initial ultrasound evaluation revealed large  ascites. A spot was chosen in the LLQ  with the largest pocket. The anterior abdominal wall was prepped with Betadine/chlorhexidine and draped in sterile fashion.  Under ultrasound guidance and following administration of local anesthesia using lidocaine 1%  with epinephrine 7 mL, a 5F Yueh needle cannula  was advanced into the peritoneal cavity as evidenced by ascites fluid. Following removal of the inner stylet, aspiration to completion  of 8500 mL of turbid ascitic fluid was obtained. Samples of the fluid were submitted to the lab as requested.  The patient received IV albumin per protocol.  At the end of the procedure, the cannula was removed and hemostasis was secured. Sterile occlusive dressing was applied. The procedure was well tolerated. There were no intraprocedural complications. The patient was eventually discharged  in stable condition. Please also refer to the Procedure note placed in the patient's EPIC chart on the date of the procedure.  IMPRESSION: Uneventful diagnostic and therapeutic paracentesis.  Voice recognition is used in generating this report.

DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: This is a 52 years Female with an arteriovenous malformation of the brain who presents for diagnostic cerebral angiography to guide stereotactic radiosurgery today.     PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram and ultrasound guided femoral artery access  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 30 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW], PhD was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure, interpreted the images, and was present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Left internal carotid artery Left vertebral artery  ANESTHESIA: Local in the right groin with bupivacaine. Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by the nurse present during the entire procedure. The patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Sedation was administered by a specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for the duration of the procedure as outlined above (Total intra service time, 30 ). Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.  MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine SQ 10 cc  Versed 1 mg IV Fentanyl 50 mcg IV Heparin 3000 units IV Protamine 20 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.038" Bentson guidewire 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 5 French Cordis Vertebral catheter  Cardiva Vascade Omnipaque-320 contrast material (80 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   The patient was brought into the room directly from the MRI suite with the head-frame already in place.  Informed consent was obtained and the patient was then prepped and draped in the usual fashion.   Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery using constant ultrasound guidance.  Ultrasound images are recorded and permanently available for review in the patient's medical record.    A 5 French sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP and Lateral views, consistent with the [HOSPITAL][HOSPITAL] by which images would be transferred to the Gamma Knife system.   Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a Vascade followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: Prior cerebral angiogram  .  FINDINGS:  LEFT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: Large AVM nidus is noted within the thalamus and basal ganglia with extension into the frontal white matter. Primary feeding artery is served from the lenticular striates and hypertrophied middle cerebral artery branches. A cast of embolic material is seen in the distal left middle cerebral artery territory. Venous drainage is via the Galenic system and the sylvian system to the sphenoparietal sinus. A smaller cortical draining vein to the superior sagittal sinus is noted.  LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: The thalamic and posterior aspect of the nidus are opacified by branches of the posterior choroidal arteries, both medial and lateral; as well as, hypertrophied thalamic perforators. Venous drainage is via the Galenic system. No aneurysm or focal stenosis are identified. Reflux of contrast into the contralateral vertebral artery was not achieved. The origin of PICA is normal unilaterally (we will defer to CTA for evaluation of the contralateral PICA).   COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: 1. Successful diagnostic angiogram with fiduciary makers to guide stereotactic radiosurgery. 2. Redemonstration of previously described left thalamic/basal ganglia Spetzler Martin grade 4 arteriovenous malformation.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication: at a [HOSPITAL] in [HOSPITAL], a series of events led to non-retrieval of the indwelling inferior vena caval filter.  Patient coded on the procedure table, reportedly related to over sedation (Anesthesia)   Procedure:   1. Right thigh venogram  2. Inferior vena cavogram    Findings:  -indwelling inferior vena caval (IVC) (Gunther-Tulip) filter in place, at the level of L3-L4 .  There is significant filter tilting, with the head oriented medially.  One superior right filter leg is deviated superolaterally, with the tip appearing superolateral to the filter head.  Another, subjacent filter leg appears to be deviated to mild superolateral degree -lumen of the supra-filter IVC begins at the level of the left and right renal veins.   -left and right renal veins are widely patent -short, approximately 2.5 cm, caval segment between the top of the filter and the renal vein inflows is shown to be chronically occluded, with no access to the filter from the RIJV approach  Sonographic evaluation: -findings of chronic occlusion of the left and right common femoral veins (CFV)  Venography: -wide patency of the right greater saphenous vein (GSV), albeit with superior occlusion and short segment discontinuity with the femoral vein (FV) -mid to superior right FV shows a normal sized luminal caliber, with endoluminal disease shown at its most superior segment, adjacent to the change to the CFV -no right CFV lumen.  In its place, there are myriad and variably sized venous channels. -venous collateral circulation from the superior right FV, to the deep femoral venous system, to the right external and common iliac venous system -some retrograde reflux to right para-ovarian veins, with collateral venous circulation from the right to the left upper pelvis -myriad venous collateral channels parallel the expected course of the infra-filter IVC -collateral venous flow to both mid to upper gonadal veins -normal appearance of the supra-renal IVC   Impression:  1. chronic iliocaval occlusion, extending to approximately 2.5 cm superior to the indwelling Gunther-Tulip caval filter, shown with significant medial tilt, at the level of L3-L4 2. normal supra-renal IVC 3. normal left and right CFV, with chronic thromboocclusive disease 4 no IVC filter retrieval attempted nor necessary   Treatment Plan:  More detailed clinical history was secured from the patient's husband, [PATIENT]: patient, a traveling nurse, had been working in [HOSPITAL].  Oral contraceptive medications led to left lower extremity (LLE) deep venous thrombosis (DVT).  The latter may have occurred while patient was on oral anticoagulation; therefore a vena caval filter was placed, in [DATE], at a [HOSPITAL] institution, [HOSPITAL].   LLE edema became evident on [DATE], at the same time as a skin ulcer at the inferior half-third aspect of the left anterior tibial region.  This prompted IVC investigation and attempted filter retrieval in [HOSPITAL], [DATE].  Intra-procedural over sedation led to a code and the procedure was aborted; although some endoluminal catheter thrombectomy was performed (location, uncertain).  Patient has returned to her [HOSPITAL] home, with request for a renewed effort at filter retrieval.    1. continue anticoagulation as indicated. 2. will schedule iliocaval stent reconstruction, following discussion with the patient and her husband   Technique:   Sterile technique and sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance were used to gain 21-g needle access to the RIJV.  Over an 0.018-in Cope wire, exchange was made for a 5-Fr. micropuncture set, affording 0.035-in Rosen wire exchange for a 14/16-Fr. (Agon) introducer sheath.  Through this, a 5-Fr. straight flush catheter was advanced, with the distal tip advanced to the peri-renal IVC.  Inability advancing past the indwelling caval filter prompted the use of an 0.035-in glide wire over a 5-Fr. angled catheter.  This combination also met the same resistance, with supra-filter, infra-renal caval obstruction suspected.  Contrast examination was performed.     This prompted venographic evaluation from the groin approach.  Sonographic evaluation shows no widely patent CFV lumen.  Similar evaluation shows wide patency of the right GSV.  This was then accessed using a 5-Fr. micropuncture set, at the inferior third of the thigh.  Through this access, contrast examination was performed, as reported above.  Venographic roadmap imaging afforded percutaneous access to the mid right FV, using a 5-Fr. micropuncture set, with sonographic confirmation of no trans-arterial routing.  Contract examination was performed, of the right groin and iliac venous system and the infra-renal IVC.    All instruments and devices were removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression.  The patient tolerated the procedure well. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Malfunctioning gastrojejunostomy tube.  Procedure:   1.	GJ-tube replacement.       Findings:   1.	The existing tube is in appropriate position.   2.	The new tube is appropriately positioned with the distal aspect of the tube terminating in the portion of the jejunum  Impression:   1.	Successful replacement of 18 French MIC gastrojejunostomy tube with tip in jejunum.      Treatment Plan:    It is OK to use the tube immediately.    Routine check and change recommended in 6 months.  Technique:   Informed consent for the procedure was obtained, and time-out was performed prior to the procedure.  The skin overlying the access site was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). The skin and subcutaneous tissue around the existing tube were infiltrated with local anesthetic.   A scout image was obtained over the abdomen.  A stiff Glidewire was cannulated into the J port of the pre-existing tube and passed into the jejunum. The pre-existing GJ tube was removed over the wire after deflating the bulb. A new gastrojejunostomy tube was advanced over the wire. Its tip was placed in the proximal jejunum. The wire was removed.  The bulb was inflated with 10 mL of a 10% contrast mixture.   Contrast injection confirmed appropriate positioning of the G and J side ports. The balloon was inflated and the disc was cinched. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Right breast cancer with malpositioning surgical port. Still requiring port catheter for chemotherapy  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	New left internal jugular port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance 3.	Existing left subclavian port removal  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen Bard port (standard profile)  Findings:   1.	The left internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The new port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction. 3.	The existing left subclavian port with tip appeared to be in appropriate location but the port reservoir was flipped within the pocket  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled left internal jugular 8 French single lumen Bard power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance. 2.	Left subclavian port removed en bloc.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).   The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the left internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the left internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the left internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the left chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the left chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 3-0 absorbable sutures. A running 4-0 absorbable subcuticular stitch and  Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with Dermabond.   Port removal  The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the left chest were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic. An incision was made. The port pocket was accessed using sharp and blunt dissection. The port catheter was removed en bloc.    The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 3-0 absorbable sutures. A running 4-0 absorbable subcuticular stitch and  Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication. DIAGNOSTIC CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: This is a 38 years Male with an arteriovenous malformation of the brain who presents for diagnostic cerebral angiography to guide stereotactic radiosurgery today.     PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram and ultrasound guided femoral artery access  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 30 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW], PhD was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure, interpreted the images, and was present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Left vertebral artery  ANESTHESIA: Local in the right groin with bupivacaine. Preprocedure assessment (including review of history and physical and appropriate diagnostic tests) was performed, which documented that the patient was an appropriate candidate for conscious sedation. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by the nurse present during the entire procedure. The patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Sedation was administered by a specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for the duration of the procedure as outlined above (Total intra service time, 30 ). Total medication dosages are listed separately within the body of the report.  MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine SQ 10 cc  Versed 0.5 mg IV Fentanyl 50 mcg IV Heparin 3000 units IV Protamine 10 mg IV  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.038" Bentson guidewire 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 5 French Cordis Vertebral catheter  Cardiva Vascade Omnipaque-300 contrast material (40 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   The patient was brought into the room directly from the MRI suite with the head-frame already in place.  Informed consent was obtained and the patient was then prepped and draped in the usual fashion.   Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery using constant ultrasound guidance.  Ultrasound images are recorded and permanently available for review in the patient's medical record.    A 5 French sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 3000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, selective catheterization was done of these above mentioned vessels and digital angiograms were performed, centered over the head and neck with AP and Lateral views, consistent with the mechanism by which images would be transferred to the Gamma Knife system.   Following completion of the procedure, heparin was reversed with protamine. Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a Vascade followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: Prior cerebral angiogram, [DATE] and [DATE].  FINDINGS:  LEFT VERTEBRAL ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is a small, left occipital arteriovenous malformation fed by a single distal PCA branch feeding into a small 1 to 2 cm nidus with drainage superficial venous drainage via a single cortical vein into the superior sagittal sinus. The feeding artery demonstrates mild irregularities and overall is decreased in caliber when compared to the prior angiogram from [DATE] but unchanged from [DATE]. Reflux of contrast into the contralateral vertebral artery was not achieved. The origin of PICA is normal unilaterally although the contralateral PICA has notably been imaged before and negative for abnormalities. The remaining branches of the basilar artery are unremarkable.  COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION:  1. Successful diagnostic angiogram with fiduciary makers to guide stereotactic radiosurgery.  2. Redemonstration of previously described small, left occipital arteriovenous malformation fed by a single distal PCA branch feeding into a small 1 to 2 cm nidus with drainage superficial venous drainage via a single cortical vein into the superior sagittal sinus. The flow through this arteriovenous malformation and the size of the nidus is markedly reduced when compared to the angiogram from 2018  3. Patient had a reaction to protamine when 10U were given over 5 minutes (planned 20U over 10minutes).  Attention to rate of interval protamine administration will be required on follow-up.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Ovarian cancer with pelvic mass resulting in bilateral ureteral obstruction. Ureteral stents are no longer functioning, and patient has bilateral hydronephrosis.  Procedure:   1.	Bilateral nephrostogram and nephrostomy tube placement      Findings:    1.	Moderate left and severe right hydronephrosis  2.	Moderate left and severe right hydronephrosis noted on nephrostogram. 3.	Appropriately positioned catheters post procedure. Patient has indwelling stents preprocedure.  Catheter(s):  10.2 F Cook nephrostomy tube  Impression:   1.	Uneventful ultrasound and fluroscopic-guided placement of a bilateral nephrostomy tube as described above.      Treatment Plan:   Patient should return for routine check and change in 8-12 weeks.   Patient can return to her urologist for retrieval of ureteral stents.  Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained to the patient. Written informed consent was obtained.  A time out/call to order was performed prior to procedure initiation.  The soft tissues overlying the access site were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).   Left nephrostomy placement:  Ultrasound was utilized to identify an appropriate access site. Static ultrasound image was obtained and stored to PACS for reference purposes. Subsequently, under fluoroscopic and real-time concurrent ultrasound guidance, access was obtained into a superior calyx using a 21 ga needle and a triaxial sheath system ([VENDOR]). Because this access was not ideal for tube placement, a second needle was advanced into an inferior posterior calyx under direct fluoroscopic guidance. A wire was advanced centrally. Serial dilation was accomplished over the wire. The wire and inner dilator were removed. Non-ionic contrast was injected into the collecting system and images of the antegrade pyelogram were obtained and stored to PACS.  An 0.035” wire was advanced through the existing access. A nephrostomy tube was advanced over the wire and the Cope loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis. Contrast injection confirmed location. The catheter was sutured to the flank with monofilament suture and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.  Right nephrostomy placement:  Ultrasound was utilized to identify an appropriate access site. Static ultrasound image was obtained and stored to PACS for reference purposes. Subsequently, under fluoroscopic and real-time concurrent ultrasound guidance, access was obtained into a midpole calyx using a 22 ga needle and a triaxial sheath system ([VENDOR]).  A wire was advanced centrally. Serial dilation was accomplished over the wire. The wire and inner dilator were removed. Non-ionic contrast was injected into the collecting system and images of the antegrade pyelogram were obtained and stored to PACS.  An 0.035” wire was advanced through the existing access. A nephrostomy tube was advanced over the wire and the Cope loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis. Contrast injection confirmed location. The catheter was sutured to the flank with monofilament suture and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.   The procedure was well tolerated, and patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location: [HOSPITAL].  PROCEDURE: IMAGE-GUIDED LIVER LESION PERCUTANEOUS NEEDLE BIOPSY. [HOSPITAL][ID]  Date of exam: [DATE] .  Clinical Indication:  The patient presents with large masses in the liver especially the left lobe segment 2 and history of GIST. Request is made for percutaneous needle biopsy.  Technique: After explaining the technique, risks, benefits, alternatives, and answering all questions, informed consent was obtained from the patient. Timeout identifying the correct patient, procedure, site and allergies were performed and observed by the operating team. The patient was positioned supine  and initial ultrasound evaluation confirmed visualization of the suspicious lesions as previously identified on the enhanced CT scan of the abdomen. The procedure is performed under continuous physiologic monitoring. The epigastrium and right upper abdominal quadrant were prepped with chlorhexidine followed by Betadine  and draped in a sterile fashion.  Under ultrasound guidance and following administration of local anesthesia using lidocaine 1% with epinephrine 7 mL in the RLQ subcostal region  that is closest to the suspicious liver lesion identified in the left lobe mostly segment 2 and through skin stab incision, a 17  G access needle was advanced into the suspicious lesion. Using coaxial 18  G biopsy gun, 4 cores were obtained and submitted in formalin for histopathology.  Hemostasis was secured and the needle removed. Gelfoam sludge was injected through the access needle during withdrawal. Dermabond was applied at the puncture site. Postprocedure ultrasound did not reveal any complications. The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no intraprocedural complications. The patient was transferred in stable condition for continued observations.  Fellow(s): None. Resident(s): None.  Complications: No immediate complications..  Blood loss:  None.  Impression: Uneventful successful liver lesion percutaneous needle biopsy under ultrasound guidance.  Voice recognition software is used in generating this report.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Biliary obstruction in setting of treated gallbladder adenocarcinoma  Procedure:   1.	Pullback and antegrade cholangiography 2.	Biliary brush and clamshell biopsy 3.	Biliary catheter exchange/upsize  Findings:   1.	Expected appearance of preexisting right internal-external biliary drain. 2.	Antegrade cholangiogram demonstrates long segment irregular narrowing of the CHD and CBD. Contrast passes distally into the small bowel. 3.	Image-guided biliary biopsy with brushings submitted in cytolyte and four clamshell specimens submitted in formalin. Adequate positioning of biopsy devices prior to tissue sampling. 4.	Placement of a right 16F internal-external biliary drain with opacification of intrahepatic ducts and small bowel on completion cholangiogram.  Impression:   Biliary brush and clamshell biopsy of persistent CHD/CBD narrowing. Biliary catheter upsize to 16F.  Treatment Plan:   1.	Trend tbili and drain output. 2.	Follow up pathology. 3.	Routine catheter exchange in 10-12 months.  Technique:   The patient was transported to the interventional suite and placed in the supine position. The existing catheter and surrounding soft tissues were prepped and draped utilizing maximum sterile barrier technique. A call to order was performed with all team members present and participating.  Scout imaging of the abdomen was obtained. Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site. The catheter and stay suture were cut. A stiff Glidewire was advanced through the pre-existing drain and coiled within the small bowel. The drain was removed. A Kumpe catheter was inserted in the stiff Glidewire was exchanged for a stiff Amplatz. A 14 French sheath. Pullback and antegrade cholangiography was performed as described above.  A brush biopsy device was advanced through the sheath and passes with the device through the target region were performed under direct fluoroscopic visualization. The device was removed and the brush was submitted in CytoLyt. A clamshell biopsy device was advanced through the sheath and specimens were obtained in the target region under direct fluoroscopic visualization. The specimens were submitted in formalin. The sheath was removed over the wire.  A new 16 French biliary catheter was advanced over the wire into the small bowel. The locking loop was formed and the catheter was positioned with sideholes traversing the CHD/CBD narrowing. Completion cholangiogram was performed as described above. The catheter was secured to the skin with 2-0 Ethilon. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Bleeding from right lower quadrant transplant PCN bag. Drop in hemoglobin. Drain appears malpositioned on recent x-ray.  Procedure:   1.	Right lower quadrant transplant nephrostogram and nephrostomy tube replacement  Comparison: Previous exam nephrostomy drain placement [DATE]  Findings:    1.	Existing nephrostomy appears malpositioned with the distal loop flipped down towards an inferior calyx. 2.	Nephrostography demonstrates no significant hydronephrosis. No filling defects or clot within the collecting system. Contrast opacifies the native transplant ureter as well as the uretero-vesicular conduit near the renal pelvis. 3.	Successful over-the-wire upsize for a new 12 French Dawson-Mueller drain terminating in upper pole calyx.  Catheter:  12 F Dawson-Mueller nephrostomy tube  Impression:   1.	Uneventful image-guided right lower quadrant transplant nephrostomy tube upsizing and repositioning.  Treatment Plan:   1. Monitor quality of the urine in the nephrostomy bag. If patient continues to have bloody output with ongoing drops in hemoglobin requiring transfusion or becomes hemodynamically unstable, please contact interventional radiology for potential angiogram.  2. Otherwise, patient should return for routine check and change in 6-8 weeks.  Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained to the patient. Written informed consent was obtained. A time out/call to order was performed prior to procedure initiation.  The existing catheter and surrounding soft tissues were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). A scout radiograph was obtained.  Non-ionic contrast was injected through the existing nephrostomy tube and images of the collecting system obtained and stored to PACS (findings detailed above).  An 0.035” Amplatz wire was advanced through the nephrostomy tube. The tube was removed over the wire under direct fluoroscopic visualization. A new [VENDOR] multipurpose drain nephrostomy tube was advanced over the wire, however cope loop cannot be adequately formed in the collecting system. This MPD was removed over the wire, and a 12 French Dawson-Mueller drain was advanced over the wire into an upper pole calyx, and the Cope loop formed and locked in the renal pelvis. Contrast injection confirmed appropriate location. The catheter was sutured to the flank with monofilament suture and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.  The procedure was well tolerated, and patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  breast cancer  Procedure:   1.	Venous access with ultrasound guidance   2.	Port insertion under fluoroscopic guidance  Catheter: Power-injectable  8 F single-lumen Bard port (standard profile)  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is ultrasonographically patent and compresses. An ultrasound image documenting vein patency was stored to PACS. 2.	The port catheter has a smooth course with the tip terminating near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of a tunneled right internal jugular 8 French single lumen Bard power Port-A-Cath using sonographic and fluoroscopic guidance.  Treatment Plan:   The catheter tip is in good position. The line flushes and aspirates appropriately.  The catheter is okay to use.  Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed below  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   Subsequently, the right chest was anesthetized with lidocaine solution , both with and without epinephrine. An incision was made. A port pocket was created. The port reservoir was placed within the port pocket after adequate hemostasis was achieved.  The port was not affixed to the chest wall with suture.  The catheter was tunneled under the skin of the right  chest.   Under fluoroscopic guidance, a peel-away sheath was advanced through the venotomy site over a guide wire to the level of the right atrium. The catheter was inserted through the peel-away sheath and into the  internal jugular vein  via a peel-away sheath after removal of the dilator and wire. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained documenting the tip of the port catheter in good position near the cavoatrial junction. The port flushes and aspirates appropriately.   The port pocket was closed with buried, interrupted subcutaneous 2-0 absorbable sutures. Dermabond was used to close the skin.  The access site was sealed with Dermabond.   The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate post procedural complication.   Procedural Personnel Advanced practice provider(s): [HCW]  Complications: No immediate complications. Expected appearance of preexisting right nontunneled dialysis catheter with tip overlying the right atrium   2.	After placement of the large bore central venous catheter, as described, the tip terminates in the right atrium.  Impression:   1. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Metastatic colorectal cancer. Left biliary stricture. Attempted stenting last week, however unfortunately cholangiogram demonstrated portobiliary fistula. Now with worsening hyperbilirubinemia.  Procedure:   1.	Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram.  2.	Placement of biliary stent 3.	Gelfoam tract embolization  Findings:   1.	Occlusion of the central left hepatic bile duct secondary to extrinsic compression from known mass. 2.	Interval resolution of previously seen portobiliary fistula. 3.	Successful placement of uncovered biliary stent across left bile duct stricture (fully uncovered 8 mm x 4 cm WallFlex stent, inflated to 6mm).  Impression:   1.	Interval resolution of previously seen portobiliary fistula.  2.	Technically successful percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography and biliary stent placement.  Plan:  Continue to monitor patient's clinical symptoms and trend bilirubin.  Technique:   The anterior abdominal wall and pre-existing left internal/external biliary drain was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The drain access site was anesthetized with local lidocaine. An Amplatz wire was advanced through the existing drain into the small bowel, and the drain was removed over the wire. An 8 French sheath was then advanced over the wire, and a pullback sheath cholangiogram demonstrated persistent stricture of the left intrahepatic bile duct without opacification of the previously seen portobiliary fistula.  Biliary stent type: WallFlex Stent size: 8 mm x 4 cm Technique: The pre-existing sheath was removed from the wire, and a 9 French sheath was then placed over the wire. A 5-French marker pigtail catheter was placed over the wire into the biliary tree for measurement.  A cholangiogram was performed, demarcating the location of the biliary confluence, and peripheral entry site. Lesion length was measured. The desired stent was advanced over the wire and positioned using fluoroscopy. The stent was deployed and lesion and stent were dilated with a 6 mm balloon. A final cholangiogram was performed through the sheath demonstrating brisk transit of contrast through the stent down the common bile duct and into the small bowel.  We then attempted placing a 10 French external Amplatz anchor drain; however, drain anchor would not appropriately form given the peripheral nature of the desired placement. The decision was made to abandon the access given brisk flow of contrast through the stent and resolution of previously demonstrated portobiliary fistula.  The sheath was pulled back to immediately peripheral to the bile duct entry site and the tract was embolized with Gelfoam slurry.   No acute bleeding was noted from the access site, and a sterile dressing was applied.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL][ID]  DATE OF EXAM:  [DATE]   CLINICAL INDICATION:  39 y.o. male with a painful left flank mass for 15 years. It began as a small lesion (originally thought to be a lipoma) but continued to grow. Patient is has had three resections but the mass continues to grow in size. He reports significantly worsening of pain if he is bumped.   PROCEDURE:   1.	Ultrasound-guided left radial artery access 2.	Aortogram 3.	Left Pelvic and lumbar angiography 4.	Left subclavian angiography 5.	Venous malformation sclerotherapy/embolization using STS foam 6.	Lymphatic malformation embolization using STS foam  7.	Venous and lymphatic malformation biopsy   FINDINGS:  1. Vessels catheterized and angiograms performed as detailed below using 5 Fr RAVI MG1 *	Infrarenal abdominal aortogram: No feeding vessels or inflow to the left flank venous/lymphatic malformation. There was similar appearance of contrast opacification of the pelvic vessels bilaterally. *	Left internal iliac artery: No feeding vessels identified.  *	Left superior gluteal artery: No feeding vessels identified. *	Left L5 and L4 lumbar level arteries: No feeding vessels identified.  2. Ultrasound shows large left flank mass representing venous and lymphatic malformations. The lymphatic component of the mass is in the superomedial aspect. The venous component occupies the lateral and inferior aspect.  3. Approximately 200 ml of dark brownish lymphatic malformation fluid was aspirated and sent for lab analysis. Successful core biopsy of the solid component of the malformation.  4. Sclerotherapy/embolization of the lymphatic component of the malformation was performed using 6 ml of STS foam ( separate 4 ml and 2 ml were injected into the inferior and superior aspects respectively)  5. The Venous malformation component was treated with 18 ml of STS foam. Venogram showed no outflow into systemic circulation.    IMPRESSION:  1. Large left flank venous/lymphatic malformation. No feeding vessels on aortogram and pelvic angiogram. 2. Sclerotherapy of the malformations were successful performed under ultrasound and fluoroscopic guidance. 3. Core biopsy and fluid aspirate were sent for tissue/lab analysis.  TREATMENT PLAN:  1. Patient will be likely scheduled for additional embolization/sclerotherapy of left flank malformation in 6-8 weeks with [HCW] with anesthesia support. 2. Start ibuprofen 800 mg every 8 hours starting tonight for days 1-3  3. On days 4-7 take ibuprofen every 8 hours while awake. Pt also sent Rx for percocet as needed 4. Follow-up biopsy results.   TECHNIQUE:  Pelvic Angiogram With the patient in the supine position, the left wrist was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The left wrist was evaluated with ultrasound and left radial artery patency and acceptable size criteria were documented. Images were properly stored in PACS. A modified Allen test (Barbeau test Type B) was performed on the left wrist to confirm patency of the ulnopalmar arch using pulse oximetry.   1% lidocaine solution was administered for local anesthesia. Access was obtained to the left radial artery using a 21 gauge micro needle and ultrasound guidance. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. A wire was placed through the needle. A hydrophilic Glidesheath was advanced slowly over the wire. 3000 units of heparin, 200 mcg of nitroglycerin and 2.5 mg of verapamil was given through the arterial sheath with slow hemodilution. A side flush was started.   Diagnostic catheter was advanced through the sheath into the aorta and used to catheterize the left internal iliac arteries, lumbar, left subclavian and pelvic vessels described above. Angiograms were performed. No embolization was performed.  All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. A TR Band was placed on the left wrist for hemostasis.    TECHNIQUE: Venous lymphatic sclerotherapy/embolization and biopsy Prior to starting procedure, patient was asked to point of areas of maximal pain/discomfort, these areas were then marked as possible targets for treatment. With the patient in the supine position, the area was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. Under direct ultrasound guidance, a 21-gauge needle was advanced into the targeted area of maximal vessel size of the malformation in the lateral flank. Venogram was then performed, as described above. Embolization/sclerotherapy was then carried out with Sotradecol 3% solution (3:2:1 air :Sotradecol: lipiodol), as above. Repeat ultrasound demonstrated satisfactory embolization with sclerosing material throughout visualized abnormal veins.   Under direct ultrasound guidance, a 17 gauge needle guide was advanced into solid aspects of the malformation. Images documenting needle access and biopsy course were saved.  Four coaxial passes were made with an 18 gauge biopsy gun. The specimen was placed in formalin.   Under direct ultrasound guidance, access was then obtained into the target area of cystic component in the superior and medial aspect of the malformations. Venogram and fluid aspiration was performed, and was determined to be lymphatic malformation. Embolization/sclerotherapy was then carried out Sotradecol 3% solution (3:2:1 air :Sotradecol: lipiodol), as above. Repeat ultrasound evaluation demonstrated satisfactory embolization with sclerosing material throughout visualized abnormal veins.   The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  right upper extremity swelling, chronically significant since a reported [DATE] motor vehicular accident in patient with concomitant extensive arteriovenous malformation involving the right superior extrathoracic chest.  The latter has had multiple treatment sessions to date at [HOSPITAL].  Today's attention will be for possible treatment of the venous disease, with [DATE] venography showing tapering right axillary venous occlusion  Procedure:   1.	Right upper extremity venography 2.	Right subclavian vein recanalization 3.	Intravascular Ultrasound evaluation of the right central thoracic veins   Findings:   -unexpectedly, following the initial RBrV access, the J-tip guide wire spontaneously advanced past the right axillary vein, with eventual venographic examination showing that the point of venous occlusion is not the right axillary but the RSCV.  Flow diversion via adjacent, well formed collateral channels is believed to have caused a functional obstruction.  Much peri-occlusion flow diversion is via an enlarged, tortuous right cephalic vein.  This and over collateral venous channels lead to the opacification of the RIJV -there is an unusual, irregularly complex appearing occlusion of the junction of the RSCV and RBCV  -following initial (8- and 12-mm) venoplasty, there is new antegrade flow across the dilated venous segment and significant diminution of flow to the aforementioned collateral venous channels, albeit with significant residual stenotic disease    IVUS evaluation: -pre-stenotic RSCV: minimal and maximal luminal diameter, 9 and 10.6 mm; surface area, 79 mm2 -point of stenosis, RSCV-RBCV junction: minimal and maximal luminal diameter, 5.4 and 6.3 mm; surface area, 26 mm2.  This yield a 68% difference in surface area  -completion venography shows: persistent antegrade flow across the dilated venous segment; improvement in the residual stenotic disease (compared to above).  Due to the location of this venous disease, at the thoracic outlet, and the excellent appearing decision was made not to stent, at this time, favoring close clinical and venographic followup   Impression:   1. point of right upper extremity venous occlusion is unexpectedly at the RSCV and not the right axillary vein.  Prior reported point of occlusion can be blamed on a dynamic or functional obstruction related to flow diversion from adjacent, well-formed collateral venous circulation 2. catheter-wire passage across the RSCV-RBCV junctional occlusion 3. treatment of the RSCV-RBCV junctional occlusion/stenosis, a moderate technical success.   Stent placement deferred, at this time, favoring close clinical and venographic followup.  Calculated fears: excellent appearing antegrade flow; thoracic outlet location of the venous disease; young patient age   Treatment Plan:  1. Patient to be scheduled for 2-3 week venographic re-evaluation + AVM embolization via the RIMA 2. Start oral anticoagulation    Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained.  The specific risks of bleeding, infection, pulmonary embolism, perforation, thrombosis, and need for subsequent procedures/surgery were detailed and accepted. Written informed consent was obtained. Patient was brought to the procedure suite and a time out was performed prior to procedure initiation. Patient was placed in the supine position and, following sedation, the access sites were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  Venous Access:  Sterile technique and sonographic guidance were used to gain 21-g needle access to the right brachial vein.  Exchange was made over an 0.018-in Cope wire for a 5-Fr. micropuncture set.  This afforded 0.035-in Rosen wire exchange for a 6-Fr. x 25-cm introducer sheath, through which contrast examination was performed.  Through the sheath, a 5-Fr. angled catheter was advanced, with the distal tip advanced to immediately adjacent to the point of right subclavian venous (RSCV) occlusion.  Through the catheter, an 0.035-in angled glide wire was advanced and, along with the catheter, was used to probe the aforementioned point of venous occlusion, with eventual traversal of the guide wire.  Sterile technique and sonographic guidance were used to gain 21-g needle access to the right common femoral vein.  Exchange was made over an 0.018-in Cope wire for a 5-Fr. micropuncture set.  This afforded 0.035-in Rosen wire exchange for an 8-Fr. x 65-cm introducer sheath, withe distal tip advanced to the superior most aspect of the superior vena cava (SVC).  Through this, a 6-Fr. 25-mm snare wire was advanced and used to catch the glide wire (from the RBrV approach), then retracted into the sheath.  Via the RBrV approach, exchange was made over the glide wire for a 4-Fr. angled catheter.  This was advanced past the occlusive lesion, and into the RCFV sheath, where exchange was made for a 260-cm Amplatz wire.  This was again caught with the the snare wire, retracted into the sheath, then externalized via the RCFV access.    Through the RBrV sheath, exchange was  made for an 8-Fr. x 25-cm sheath through which an 8-mm balloon catheter was advanced, used to dilate the occlusive right SCV-BCV junction lesion.  Check venography was performed, followed by 12-mm balloon dilatation.  This was followed by formal angiography.  Exchange was then made for an 8-Fr. ([VENDOR]) IVUS catheter, used to interrogate the dilated venous segment.  This same venous segment was then dilated using a 12-mm high pressure ([VENDOR]) balloon catheter, in a prolonged fashion.  Completion venography was then performed.  At the [HOSPITAL], exchange was then made over the indwelling Amplatz wire for a 7-Fr. short introducer sheath.  The latter was then removed with simultaneous deployment of an extra-luminal vascular access closure (Amplatz) device, with manual compression applied to effect hemostasis.   At the [HOSPITAL], a 5-Fr. angled catheter was advanced over the indwelling Amplatz wire, allowing for removal of the latter.  The sheath was then removed, with manual compression applied to effect hemostasis.  A sterile bandage was applied to each venous access site.  The patient tolerated the procedure well. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL][ID]  DATE OF EXAM:  [DATE]   CLINICAL INDICATION:  39 y.o. male with a painful left flank mass for 15 years. It began as a small lesion (originally thought to be a lipoma) but continued to grow. Patient is has had three resections but the mass continues to grow in size. He reports significantly worsening of pain if he is bumped.   PROCEDURE:   1.	Ultrasound-guided left radial artery access 2.	Aortogram 3.	Left Pelvic and lumbar angiography 4.	Left subclavian angiography 5.	Venous malformation sclerotherapy/embolization using STS foam 6.	Lymphatic malformation embolization using STS foam  7.	Venous and lymphatic malformation biopsy   FINDINGS:  1. Vessels catheterized and angiograms performed as detailed below using 5 Fr RAVI MG1 *	Infrarenal abdominal aortogram: No feeding vessels or inflow to the left flank venous/lymphatic malformation. There was similar appearance of contrast opacification of the pelvic vessels bilaterally. *	Left internal iliac artery: No feeding vessels identified.  *	Left superior gluteal artery: No feeding vessels identified. *	Left L5 and L4 lumbar level arteries: No feeding vessels identified.  2. Ultrasound shows large left flank mass representing venous and lymphatic malformations. The lymphatic component of the mass is in the superomedial aspect. The venous component occupies the lateral and inferior aspect.  3. Approximately 200 ml of dark brownish lymphatic malformation fluid was aspirated and sent for lab analysis. Successful core biopsy of the solid component of the malformation.  4. Sclerotherapy/embolization of the lymphatic component of the malformation was performed using 6 ml of STS foam ( separate 4 ml and 2 ml were injected into the inferior and superior aspects respectively)  5. The Venous malformation component was treated with 18 ml of STS foam. Venogram showed no outflow into systemic circulation.    IMPRESSION:  1. Large left flank venous/lymphatic malformation. No feeding vessels on aortogram and pelvic angiogram. 2. Sclerotherapy of the malformations were successful performed under ultrasound and fluoroscopic guidance. 3. Core biopsy and fluid aspirate were sent for tissue/lab analysis.  TREATMENT PLAN:  1. Patient will be likely scheduled for additional embolization/sclerotherapy of left flank malformation in 6-8 weeks with [HCW] with anesthesia support. 2. Start ibuprofen 800 mg every 8 hours starting tonight for days 1-3  3. On days 4-7 take ibuprofen every 8 hours while awake. Pt also sent Rx for percocet as needed 4. Follow-up biopsy results.   TECHNIQUE:  Pelvic Angiogram With the patient in the supine position, the left wrist was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The left wrist was evaluated with ultrasound and left radial artery patency and acceptable size criteria were documented. Images were properly stored in PACS. A modified Allen test (Barbeau test Type B) was performed on the left wrist to confirm patency of the ulnopalmar arch using pulse oximetry.   1% lidocaine solution was administered for local anesthesia. Access was obtained to the left radial artery using a 21 gauge micro needle and ultrasound guidance. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. A wire was placed through the needle. A hydrophilic Glidesheath was advanced slowly over the wire. 3000 units of heparin, 200 mcg of nitroglycerin and 2.5 mg of verapamil was given through the arterial sheath with slow hemodilution. A side flush was started.   Diagnostic catheter was advanced through the sheath into the aorta and used to catheterize the left internal iliac arteries, lumbar, left subclavian and pelvic vessels described above. Angiograms were performed. No embolization was performed.  All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. A TR Band was placed on the left wrist for hemostasis.    TECHNIQUE: Venous lymphatic sclerotherapy/embolization and biopsy Prior to starting procedure, patient was asked to point of areas of maximal pain/discomfort, these areas were then marked as possible targets for treatment. With the patient in the supine position, the area was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. Under direct ultrasound guidance, a 21-gauge needle was advanced into the targeted area of maximal vessel size of the malformation in the lateral flank. Venogram was then performed, as described above. Embolization/sclerotherapy was then carried out with Sotradecol 3% solution (3:2:1 air :Sotradecol: lipiodol), as above. Repeat ultrasound demonstrated satisfactory embolization with sclerosing material throughout visualized abnormal veins.   Under direct ultrasound guidance, a 17 gauge needle guide was advanced into solid aspects of the malformation. Images documenting needle access and biopsy course were saved.  Four coaxial passes were made with an 18 gauge biopsy gun. The specimen was placed in formalin.   Under direct ultrasound guidance, access was then obtained into the target area of cystic component in the superior and medial aspect of the malformations. Venogram and fluid aspiration was performed, and was determined to be lymphatic malformation. Embolization/sclerotherapy was then carried out Sotradecol 3% solution (3:2:1 air :Sotradecol: lipiodol), as above. Repeat ultrasound evaluation demonstrated satisfactory embolization with sclerosing material throughout visualized abnormal veins.   The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Patient with hip infection requiring long-term IV antibiotics, malpositioned right upper extremity PICC also needs removal  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled central venous catheter placement    Findings:   1.	The left internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the tunneled catheter, as described, the tip terminates near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a power-injectable, 5 Fr, 28 cm, tunneled cuffed central venous catheter via the left internal jugular vein.       Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care.  The catheter is ready for immediate use.        Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the left internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the left internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the left internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a peel-away sheath set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture peel-away sheath set, the wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.  Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. Right upper extremity PICC line pulled at conclusion of procedure. Without any complications. Clean dry dressing applied. Single lumen PICC placement using ultrasound and fluoroscopy.  Findings:   1.  Vein patency was documented by ultrasound and stored to PACS. 2.  The catheter tip terminates near the cavoatrial junction.    Impression:   1.	Uneventful image guided placement of 5 French, 45 cm single-lumen PICC in the left upper extremity as described. Patient's Name: [PATIENT] MRN: [ID]  Procedure date: [DATE]  IR TUNNELED LARGE BORE CVC  Indications: End-stage renal disease.  Request is made for tunneled dialysis catheter placement.  Procedure: After explaining the technique, risks, benefits, alternatives, and answering all questions, informed consent was obtained from the patient. Timeout identifying the correct patient, procedure, site, allergies was performed and observed by the operating team. The patient was positioned supine. The procedure is performed under continuous physiologic monitoring. The patient received intravenous conscious sedation using Versed 2 mg and fentanyl 100 mcg given in divided doses during the procedure.  Also the patient received Ancef 1 g IV.   The right  side of the lower neck and upper chest was prepped with chlorhexidine followed by Betadine and draped in a sterile fashion.  Following administration of local anesthesia using lidocaine 1% with epinephrine  10 ml at the right  side of the root of the neck extending to the right infraclavicular region, under ultrasound  guidance, access was obtained into the right  internal jugular vein using a micropuncture set. A 0.018" guidewire was advanced under fluoroscopy into the SVC. This was exchanged with a 0.035" guidewire that was advanced through the SVC into the IVC. Through skin stab incision in the right infraclavicular region, a 14 F x 19 cm [tip to cuff] dialysis catheter was tunneled exiting at the root of the neck following creating a second stab incision at the exit of the guidewire. A peel-away sheath was advanced under fluoroscopy over the guidewire under fluoroscopy. Following removal of the guidewire and inner dilator, the catheter was advanced into the SVC and buried in the subcutaneous tissues following peeling of the sheath. Hemostasis was secured. The catheter tip was adjusted at the level of the SVC/upper right atrium. Both ports demonstrated easy aspiration and injection and were flushed with hep saline per protocol. The incision at the root of the neck was closed with Dermabond. The catheter was anchored to the skin using Ethilon 2/0 interrupted skin stitches. Sterile occlusive dressing was applied at the exit of the catheter in infraclavicular region. The patient tolerated to the procedure well. There were no intraprocedural complications. The patient was transferred to recovery in stable condition and eventually to the floor. The catheter is ready to use. Please also refer to the Procedure note placed in the patient's EPIC chart on the date of the procedure.  Fluoroscopy time: 00:10.8  min.  Device placed: Ref #[ID], LOT #[ID].  Recommendations: The patient will need routine catheter check and possible exchange every 3 months.  Fellows: None. Residents: None.  IMPRESSION: 1. Uneventful image guided right  internal jugular vein tunneled dialysis catheter placement. The catheter is ready to use.  Voice recognition is used in generating this report.

Patient's Name: [PATIENT]  MRN: [ID] [DATE] 5:23 PM   IR TUNNELED SMALL BORE CVC  Indications: The right-sided tunneled PICC is no longer needed. The patient suffers from right breast cancer and she status post right mastectomy and radiation therapy. Request is made for tunneled PICC removal. The patient reported no problems with the existing PICC.  Procedure: After explaining the technique, risks, benefits, alternatives, and answering all questions, informed consent was obtained from the patient. Timeout identifying the correct patient, procedure, site, allergies was performed and observed by the operating team. The patient was positioned supine with the head turned to the left. The procedure is performed under continuous physiologic monitoring. The right side of the upper chest was prepped with chlorhexidine followed by Betadine and draped in a sterile fashion.  Initial evaluation revealed a 5F double lumen power PICC without evidence of inflammation or infection. [HCW]wing administration of local anesthesia following removal of the anchoring suture, the noncuffed 5F double lumen power PICC that measured 25 cm in length was removed intact without difficulty. Hemostasis was secured. Sterile occlusive dry dressing was applied followed. Postprocedure fluoroscopy imaging was performed confirming complete removal of the PICC. The patient tolerated to the procedure well. There were no intraprocedural complications. The patient was transferred to recovery in stable condition and eventually discharged.
