Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  poor venous access  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled central venous catheter placement   Findings:   1.	The right subclavian vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the tunneled catheter, as described, the tip terminates near the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a power-injectable, 5 Fr, 26 cm, tunneled non-cuffed central venous catheter via the right subclavian vein.    Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care.  The catheter is ready for immediate use.    Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed below.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right subclavian vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right subclavian vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right subclavian vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a peel-away sheath set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture peel-away sheath set, the wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.  Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. Patient's Name: [PATIENT] MRN: [ID] Procedure date: [DATE]   IR TUNNELED LARGE BORE CVC Exchange  Indications: End-stage renal disease.  Request is made for routine right groin tunneled dialysis catheter exchange . The patient reported no problems with the existing catheter. The patient requested to general anesthesia for the procedure.  Procedure: After explaining the technique, risks, benefits, alternatives, and answering all questions, informed consent was obtained from the patient. Timeout identifying the correct patient, procedure, site, allergies was performed and observed by the operating team. The patient was positioned supine. The procedure is performed under continuous physiologic monitoring. The procedure was performed under monitored anesthesia care.  The right groin including the indwelling 16 F x 32 cm dialysis catheter was prepped with chlorhexidine followed by Betadine and draped in a sterile fashion.  Initial evaluation revealed an existing 16 F x 32 cm tunneled right common femoral vein dialysis catheter with no evidence of inflammation, infection or discharge. Following administration of local anesthesia using lidocaine 1% with epinephrine  5 ml at the right groin, a 0.035" guidewire was advanced under fluoroscopy through the existing catheter into the IVC after freeing of the catheter at the anchoring cuff. The catheter was removed intact over the guidewire and was exchanged with a similar new 16 F x 32 cm dialysis catheter through the existing tunnel. The guidewire was removed. The catheter tip was adjusted at the lower IVC. Both ports demonstrated easy aspiration and injection and were flushed with hep saline per protocol. The catheter was anchored to the skin using Ethilon 2/0 interrupted skin stitches. Sterile occlusive dressing was applied at the exit of the catheter in infraclavicular region. The patient tolerated to the procedure well. There were no intraprocedural complications. The patient was transferred to recovery in stable condition and eventually discharged. The catheter is ready to use.  Please also refer to the Procedure note placed in the patient's EPIC chart on the date of the procedure.  Fluoroscopy time: 00: 04.8 min.  Device placed: Reference #[ID], LOT #[ID].  Recommendations: The patient will need routine catheter check and possible exchange every 3 months.  Fellows: None. Residents: None.  IMPRESSION: 1. Uneventful image guided right common femoral vein tunneled dialysis catheter exchange. The catheter is ready to use. The tip was submitted to for culture and sensitivity testing as requested.  Voice recognition is used in generating this report.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Patient with right upper extremity PICC line malpositioned needs replacement over wire  Procedure:   1.	PICC replacement with fluoro/ultrasound  Findings:   1. Existing PICC catheter tip is pulled approximately 8 cm out of position. 2. Replaced PICC catheter tip is in expected position in the region of the cavoatrial junction.  Impression:   1.	Uneventful image guided replacement of a 5 French, 49 cm double-lumen PICC in the right upper extremity. The lumens flush and aspirate appropriately.  Treatment Plan:   Catheter tip position is confirmed as above. It is OK to use this line.  Technique:   The existing PICC access site was prepped and draped in sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines). A scout radiograph was obtained.  The existing catheter was withdrawn at the skin and cut. Local anesthetic was used over the access site. A 0.018" wire was passed centrally through the catheter fragment, which was then removed over the wire and discarded. The wire was repositioned in order to allow for PICC tip positioning at the cavoatrial junction. The site was reprepped. The dilator peel-away combination was placed over the wire. The wire was used to determine catheter length, and PICC line cut to appropriate length. The tailored catheter was advanced through the peel-away and positioned centrally using fluoroscopy.   The peel-away was removed, and hemostasis achieved with manual compression. The catheter was aspirated, flushed, and heparinized per protocol. It was secured in place with Ethilon.  An antimicrobial disc and sterile dressing were applied.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  73 y.o. male s/p Liver transplant with severe distal stenosis choledo-choledochal anastomosis. Prior failure of benign stricture protocol and has had int/ext drain since [DATE]. s/p Retrievable partially covered wall-flex stent placement in the distal hepaticojejunostomy. Int/evt biliary drain 14 fr.  Procedure:   1.	Cholangiogram through the existing internal/external biliary drain. 2.	Successful retrieval of biliary stent using combination of biliary endoscopy and snare. 3.	Balloon sweep of the left biliary duct and choledo-choledochal anastomosis. 4.	Placement of an external 14 French drain with pigtail terminating at the hilum.  Findings:   1.	Sheath cholangiogram after stent retrieval and balloon sweep demonstrates patent choledo-choledochal anastomosis. 2.	Newly placed biliary drain is appropriately positioned with the tip in the biliary hilum and the proximal side hole in a peripheral bile duct.  Impression:   1.	Successful removal of biliary stent 2.	Uneventful image guided placement of the external biliary catheter as described.  Treatment Plan:   Leave the drain capped.  Follow-up cholangiogram in 2 weeks for drain evaluation and possible removal..  Technique:   The existing catheter and surrounding soft tissues were prepped and draped in sterile fashion. Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site. Contrast was injected through the existing catheter, with findings as described above.  An 0.035" Amplatz wire was negotiated through the catheter into the small bowel. The catheter was removed and exchanged for a 16 French coaxial sheath system. A safety wire was placed descending into the small bowel  An alligator forceps was advanced through the 16 French coaxial system into the proximal aspect of the stent. An attempt was made to retrieve the stent, however, unsuccessful, given the stiff shaft of the forceps and the angle of the biliary tract entry. Alligator forceps were removed, and a 7 French clamshell clamp was advanced through the sheath, again unsuccessful attempt for stone retrieval. During these maneuvers, the proximal end of the stent became kinked and migrated into the small bowel. Subsequently, Spyglass endoscopy was utilized to visualize the stent and clamshell (CoreDx) clamps were used to grab the stent and bring it back to the level of the ampulla.  The stent was unable to be pulled back into the common bile duct, however. The spyglass scope was then removed and a loop snare was advanced through the sheath and used to grab the stent.  The stent and sheath were then successfully removed as a unit.  The stent was successfully removed in its entirety.  The sheath was then reinserted.  Cholangiography was performed demonstrating multiple filling defects through the common bile duct, likely related to blood clots and debris.  A Fogarty balloon was then utilized to sweep the left biliary duct and common bile duct. Follow-up sheath cholangiogram demonstrated persistent mild narrowing of the choledocho choledochal anastomosis with brisk passage of contrast through the biliary system and into the small bowel   The sheath was removed and a new 14 French external biliary drain was placed over the wire. Contrast was injected to confirm tube position. The catheter was secured to the skin with 2-0 Ethilon. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]C.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Complex hepatobiliary history with history of necrotizing pancreatitis status post necrosectomy and complicated with history of biliary strictures requiring an occluded ERCP stent (since removed) and requiring right internal/external biliary drainage catheter since [DATE]. Last exchange [DATE]. Symptoms of intractable intercostal pain from right internal/external biliary drain.  Procedure:   1.	Ultrasound-guided intercostal nerve block (at level of internal/external biliary drain - T8-T9) 2.	Pullback sheath cholangiogram through existing percutaneous access 3.	Clamshell and brush biopsy of common bile duct 4.	Right internal/external biliary drain replacement  Findings:   1.	Successful delivery of 20 mL bupivacaine to the right intercostal nerve adjacent to the internal/external biliary drain (at T8-T9). 2.	Sheath cholangiogram demonstrates severe long segment CBD narrowing with moderate to severe upstream intrahepatic biliary duct dilatation. Biopsies and brushings obtained of the common bile duct. 3.	Newly placed biliary drain is appropriately positioned with the distal tip in the third portion of the duodenum and the proximal side hole in a peripheral bile duct.  Impression:   1.	Long segment CBD moderate-grade stricture with moderate to severe upstream intrahepatic biliary duct dilatation. 2.	Uneventful image guided replacement of the biliary catheter as described.  Treatment Plan:   1. Leave the drain to gravity bag. IR will continue to follow the patient for capping trial. 2. If patient tolerates capping and biopsies return negative, then recommend conversion to covered, retrievable Wallflex biliary stent.   Technique:   The existing catheter and surrounding soft tissues were prepped and draped in sterile fashion. A scout image was obtained, showing a right internal/external biliary drain, a right nephrostomy drain, and a right partly imaged double-J stent. Using ultrasound guidance, local anesthetic was injected at the level of the right internal/external biliary drain with delivery of 20 mL bupivacaine to the adjacent intercostal nerve. An image was saved to PACS.  Next, attention to exchange the right internal/external biliary drain was performed. Initial cholangiogram demonstrated severe intrahepatic biliary duct dilatation and minimal opacification of the common bile duct (possibly due to occluded sideholes.). Contrast was not seen entering the duodenum on this initial cholangiogram. The indwelling internal/external biliary drain was removed over a 0.035" stiff Glidewire, and antegrade sheath cholangiogram (5 Fr x 10 cm sheath) demonstrated severe intrahepatic biliary duct dilatation and a severe long segment common bile duct stricture with mild delay of contrast into the duodenum. The 5 French sheath was exchanged for an 8 Fr x 25 cm sheath, and a safety 0.035" Amplatz wire was negotiated through the sheath into the small bowel. The sheath was then removed and placed over the 0.035" stiff Glidewire, and the wire was then removed. Pullback sheath cholangiogram was performed and further delineated the severe long segment common bile duct narrowing. Several clamshell (approximately five passes) and a brush biopsy of the common bile duct was obtained. The sheath was then removed. The new 10.2 Fr internal/external biliary drain without extended sideholes was then placed over the safety 0.035" Amplatz wire. Contrast was injected to confirm tube position. The catheter was secured to the skin with 2-0 Ethilon. The patient tolerated the procedure well without immediate complications.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  78 year-old female with gallbladder cancer s/p cholecystectomy and Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy and radiation in [DATE]. Since the surgery she has had intermittent episodes of jaundice, pruritus, abdominal pain, and chills at least every 2 months. Wheelchair bound. She is suspected to have an anastomotic stricture.  Procedure:   1.	Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram 2.	Placement of percutaneous transhepatic internal/external biliary drain  Findings:   1.	High-grade anastomotic stricture at the hepaticojejunostomy 2.	Moderate to severe upstream biliary ductal dilatation. Both right and left intrahepatic biliary ducts communicate with each other. 3.	Due to tortuous anatomy and poor peristalsis of the afferent limb, we were unable to place distal loop further into the small bowel. Drain tip terminates in the small bowel just distal to the anastomosis.  Impression:   1.	Technically successful percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography and drainage catheter placement.  Plan:  1.	Open to bag drainage for 2 weeks until the next outpatient appointment. 2.	Repeat cholangiogram, drain evaluation, brush biopsy and possible upsizing in 2 weeks.  Technique:   The anterior abdominal wall and bilateral flanks were prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier.  An appropriate skin entry site was identified using fluoroscopy and ultrasound, and anesthetized with local.  Under fluoroscopic guidance, a 22G Chiba needle was advanced into the liver.  A bile duct was entered and the biliary system was opacified with contrast. Cholangiographic images were obtained.  A 0.018" wire was passed centrally, and the needle exchanged for a 5 French nonvascular access catheter. The inner stiffener, dilator, and 0.018" wire were removed and contrast was injected to confirm location.  A 0.035" glidewire and 5 French angled catheter were negotiated into the proximal portion of the small bowel, just distal to the anastomosis, unable to advance wire passed this point, which may be related to tortuous anatomy versus poor peristalsis. The glidewire was removed and contrast was injected to confirm location. A 0.035" Amplatz wire was placed through the catheter, and the catheter subsequently removed.   Drain placement: Finally, an 8.5 French standard sidehole internal-external biliary drain was placed over the wire. The anchor/loop was formed and locked. Attention was paid that side holes were positioned within the biliary system. Contrast was injected to confirm location. The catheter was secured to the skin with 2-0 suture material and attached to gravity drainage. A sterile dressing was applied.  Contrast was injected through the existing biliary drainage catheter and cholangiographic images obtained.  The procedure was well tolerated, and the patient discharged from the angiography [HOSPITAL]te in satisfactory condition. CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM AND ENDOVASCULAR PIPELINE EMBOLIZATION OF A RIGHT OPHTHALMIC ARTERY ANEURYSM  CLINICAL INDICATION: 78-year-old female with history of migraines, incidentally discovered right ophthalmic artery and left cavernous internal carotid artery aneurysms in [DATE], who developed symptoms of optic neuropathy on the right, and was planned to have flow diversion treatment with pipeline embolization device. However the size of the parent vessel measured slightly large for the pipeline device at that time, and plan was made to return when the pipeline vantage was available. She also presented to the hospital in [DATE] with symptoms of double vision, and underwent an MRI/MRA, which when compared to a study in [DATE], showed slight interval enlargement of bilateral aneurysms. She presents today for pipeline embolization of her right ophthalmic artery aneurysm.  PROCEDURE:  1.	Cerebral angiogram  2.	Endovascular pipeline embolization  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: Approximately 4.5 hours.  OPERATORS: [HCW]. was the attending physician who supervised the entire procedure and interpreted the images. [HCW] was the assisting physician. [HCW]. and [HCW] were the fellow. All actively participated in catheter manipulation and were present in the room for the entire procedure.  VESSELS CATHETERIZED: Right common carotid artery Right internal carotid artery Right common femoral artery  VESSELS TREATED (in sequence): Internal carotid artery  ANESTHESIA: General endotracheal anesthesia. Pre-, intra-, and post-anesthesia monitoring records are available in the chart.  MEDICATIONS:  0.5% Bupivacaine 10 cc SQ Heparin, please see MAR for complete records Ancef 2 grams IV Nitroglycerin 200 mcg IA Verapamil 2.5 mg IA  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 8 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath 0.035" Bentson Guidewire 0.035" Terumo Glidewire (180 cm) AXS Infinity [HCW] sheath (80 cm)  5 French merit Performa catheter (125 cm) 5 French penumbra select Simmons catheter (125 cm) 6 French penumbra neuron select Sim V catheter (125 cm) 058 Navien intermediate catheter (105cm) 072 Navien intermediate catheter (95 cm) 6 F Sofia Distal Access Catheter (115 cm) Headway 17 microcatheter (150 cm) x2 Phenom 27 microcatheter (160 cm) AXS Vecta 46 Intermediate catheter (125 cm) Transcend-EX 014 microguidewire (200 cm) Transcend-EX 014 soft tip microguidewire (20 cm) Asahi Chikai 014 microguidewire (200 cm) x2 Asahi Chikai 018 microguidewire (200 cm)  Hyperform Balloon 7x7 mm 5.5 mm x 30 mm pipeline embolization device 8 French Angio-Seal closure device Omnipaque-300 contrast (160 cc)  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, stent thrombosis/stenosis, stent migration, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, non-target embolization, puncture site hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed.   After informed, written consent was obtained, the patient was brought to the angiography suite, intubated, and prepped and draped in the usual fashion. Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right femoral artery. Through the dilator sheath, an angiogram of the of the right common femoral artery was obtained to ensure the arteriotomy was above the level of the bifurcation and the CFA was of sufficient size to use the 8 French Angio-Seal closure device. An 8 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath was introduced into the right femoral artery. 5000 units of heparin were administered intravenously following sheath placement; additional boluses of heparin were administered at one-hour intervals. The ACT was checked to ensure that it was between 250-300. Using fluoroscopic guidance,  the arteries listed above were selectively catheterized. Digital angiograms were performed in the AP, lateral and oblique projections centered over the head and neck.   3D rotational angiography was performed with the long selection catheter in the right internal carotid artery to better delineate the right ophthalmic artery aneurysm. The acquisition was processed on an independent workstation, and volume-rendered three-dimensional images were produced.   We then attempted to select the right internal carotid artery using a combination of different wires and selection catheters through the Infinity long sheath. We encountered significant tortuosity at the proximal right common carotid artery. We tried several different combinations, including the 035 Glidewire, the 038 Glidewire, the stiffened Glidewire, and the Glidewire advantage, through several different selection catheters including the penumbra Simmons catheter, the penumbra Sim-V, the Merit performa (both in original shape, and with a steamed tip). We also attempted to turn her head to the left and right to change the angles of turns in the vessels. However after trying many combinations and attempting catheterization for over an hour, we were unable to advance the Infinity long sheath into the common carotid artery via the transfemoral approach and decided to attempt a transradial approach. We closed the right common femoral artery access site using an 8 French Angio-Seal.   Access to the vascular system was gained in the usual way by a single-wall puncture of the right radial artery under ultrasound guidance; a 6 French 25 cm slender sheath was introduced into the right radial artery using ultrasound guidance. 200 mcg of nitroglycerin, 2.5 mg of verapamil were administered intra-arterially through the sheath after sheath placement. Using fluoroscopic guidance, again attempted to selectively catheterize the right common carotid artery. Due to the severe tortuosity at the origin of the right common carotid artery, we encountered significant difficulty from a radial approach as well. We tried a combination of selection catheters and intermediate catheters and were finally able to obtain some purchase with a 6 French Sofia distal access catheter into the right internal carotid artery.  We were unable to advance the Sofia past the petrous segment without concern of kinking or herniating catheter at the origin of the right common carotid artery. We prepared a hyperform balloon on the back table in the usual fashion and advanced it through the Sofia over the its microwire and inflated the balloon in the petrous segment then client with the Sofia. We then were concerned that advancing the pipeline device through Phenom 27 without more support would cause herniation of the system in the chest, so we advanced a vector 46 through the Sofia, then advanced the Phenom 27 over the Asahi 018 into the M1 segment. We exchanged the microwire for the 5.5 mm x 30 mm pipeline embolization device. The device was deployed under fluoroscopic guidance and a single shot X-ray was performed to confirm that the distal and proximal ends of the pipeline embolization device were in the supraclinoid and right ICA cavernous segment, respectively. Postprocessing of the pipeline embolization device was performed with a curved microwire with successful improvement in apposition of the proximal aspects of the device.  A final AP and Lateral angiogram were completed to evaluate the distal vasculature for perfusion deficits and emboli.   After completion of the procedure, Hemostasis was obtained by the application of a TR Band.  COMPARISON: Cerebral angiogram [DATE].  FINDINGS:  RIGHT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: The distal cervical and intracranial ICA are unremarkable in course and caliber. There is a large medially directed ophthalmic artery aneurysm better described on the 3-D angiogram below. The MCA and ACA branches opacify normally. The ECA branches are visualized and opacify normally. There is no evidence of focal stenosis or early draining vein.  RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL: There is a large medially directed ophthalmic artery aneurysm best described on the 3-D angiogram below. The MCA and ACA branches opacify normally. There is no evidence of focal stenosis, other aneurysm or early draining vein.   RIGHT INTERNAL CAROTID ARTERY, CEREBRAL (POST-PIPELINE EMBOLIZATION): The Pipeline device is well apposed to the vessel walls throughout it's course without endoleak. . Stasis of contrast is noted within the aneurysm. . No perfusion deficits to suggest distal emboli are present.  3D ROTATIONAL ANGIOGRAPHY: A 3D rotational angiogram of the  right internal carotid artery was completed and post-processed on an independent work station. 3D angiography revealed a large ophthalmic artery aneurysm measuring approximately 9.5 x 12.4 mm (transverse by transverse).  RIGHT COMMON FEMORAL ARTERY: No abnormalities are detected. The arteriotomy was above the level of the bifurcation and the CFA was of sufficient size to use the 8 French Angio-Seal closure device.   COMPLICATIONS: none immediate.  IMPRESSION:  1.	Successful transradial deployment of a pipeline vantage embolization device in the right internal carotid artery for treatment of a right ophthalmic artery aneurysm, with no evidence of endoleak or in-stent stenosis. 2.	Extremely significant tortuosity of the proximal right common carotid artery which precluded catheterization from a transfemoral approach.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL][ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  Cancer of the lower gingiva. Requires gastrostomy tube for nutrition.  Procedure:   1.	Gastrostomy tube placement under fluoroscopic guidance.  Findings:   1.	The gastrostomy tube is in good position.  2.	Gentle hand injection of contrast material confirms positioning of the gastrostomy tube within the gastric lumen.  Impression:   1.	Successful placement of 18 French MIC gastrostomy tube as above.  Treatment Plan:   The tube should be placed to gravity drainage and should not be used for 24 hours. 25 cc of water can be administered per hour. At 4 hours, if residuals are less than 30%, the patient can have tube feeds advanced starting at a half dose.  Routine exchange in 6 months.   Technique:   Informed consent for the procedure was obtained, and time-out was performed prior to the procedure.  The skin overlying the access site was subsequently prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the mid abdomen were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.   Using fluoroscopic and ultrasonographic guidance, an appropriate puncture site was identified.  2 T-fasteners were placed adjacent to the planned tube access site. Positioning of the T-fasteners within the gastric lumen was confirmed by return of air and direct injection of contrast material.  Next, under fluoroscopic guidance, an 18-gauge needle was directed into the gastric lumen. Needle positioning within the gastric lumen was confirmed with aspiration of air as well as gentle hand injection of contrast material.  A wire was advance through the 18-gauge needle.  The 18-gauge needle was removed over a wire. Serial dilation was accomplished over the stiff wire using an 8 mm x 4 cm conquest balloon.. An 18 French Halyard G-tube was advanced over a wire in an antegrade fashion and advanced through the anterior abdominal wall. All wires and catheters were removed. The bulb was inflated with 10 mL of a 10% contrast mixture. Gentle hand injection of contrast material documents the gastric feeding tube within the gastric lumen. Static fluoroscopic image was obtained for reference purposes. The tube was flushed with saline. It was affixed to the anterior abdominal wall with a rubber flange. The patient tolerated the procedure well at time of procedure completion without complication. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  History of segmental pulmonary embolus, recent surgery and unable to be anticoagulated till day 10 postoperative.  Procedure:   1.	US-guided right IJ venous access 2.	Inferior vena cava filter placement  Findings:  Inferior vena cavogram: Single renal veins bilaterally without aberrant anatomy (no duplicated IVC or accessory renal veins). The IVC is normal in caliber and without caval thrombus. Filter placed: Denali filter Inferior vena cavogram post-deployment: Appropriate positioning below the renal veins without significant filter tilt. No evidence of thrombosis, perforation, or other complication.  Postsurgical changes and thoracolumbar hardware visualized.  Impression:   1.  Uneventful image guided placement of an infrarenal IVC filter.  Treatment Plan:   1. Patient will f/u in [HOSPITAL] clinic for consultation for possible filter removal.  Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained.  The specific risks of bleeding, infection, pulmonary embolism, filter maldeployment, and filter migration were detailed and accepted. Written informed consent was obtained. The patient was assessed for conscious sedation and found to be an adequate candidate. A dedicated nurse monitored heart rate, blood pressure, and oxygen saturation throughout the procedure. Patient was brought to the procedure suite and a time out was performed prior to procedure initiation. The right neck was prepped and draped in sterile fashion.   The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the access site were infiltrated with lidocaine for local anesthetic. Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency. Under continuous ultrasound guidance, with permanent recording and reporting, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018" wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire. Through the micropuncture introducer set, an 0.035" wire was advanced into the IVC under fluoroscopic guidance. A sheath was placed at the access site, as detailed. A catheter and/or sheath combination was advanced into the IVC and cavography was then performed, with findings detailed above.  Under direct fluoroscopic guidance, the filter described above was positioned and deployed through the delivery system. A repeat venogram was performed, documenting appropriate positioning.  All instruments and devices were removed and hemostasis achieved with manual compression. No immediate complication occurred, and the patient was discharged from the angiography suite in satisfactory condition. INTRA-OPERATIVE CEREBRAL ANGIOGRAM  CLINICAL INDICATION: Status-post left MCA aneurysm clip ligation. Intra-operative angiography was requested.  PROCEDURE: Diagnostic cerebral angiogram.  DURATION OF PROCEDURE: 20 minutes.  OPERATORS: [HCW] was the attending. [HCW] was the fellow. Both interpreted the images and participated in catheter manipulation.  VESSELS ANGIOGRAMMED: Left common carotid artery  MATERIALS:  5 French micropuncture kit: Cope Mandril wire, 5 French transitional dilator, 21-gauge needle 0.038" Bentson Guidewire  5 French Terumo Pinnacle Sheath 5 French Cordis vert catheter 5 French glide catheter Simmons 3 catheter Skin closure device Omnipaque-300 contrast material (40 cc)  ANESTHESIA: The patient was under general anesthesia in the operating room.  TECHNIQUE: Prior to the procedure, the technical aspects of the procedure, as well as potential risks and benefits, were explained to the patient. Specifically, the risks of cerebral infarction, hemorrhage, blindness, cranial nerve palsy, facial pain, anaphylaxis, renal failure, limb loss, death, groin hematoma, arterial dissection, arterial pseudoaneurysm, and arteriovenous fistula were discussed. Informed consent was obtained as part of general consent for the craniotomy.  In the operating room, the patient's left groin was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. Puncture of the left common femoral artery was performed and a 5 French Terumo Pinnacle sheath was placed using sterile Seldinger technique. The sheath was continuously perfused with heparinized saline before and during the surgery.  Following aneurysm clip placement, an intra-operative angiogram was performed using portable fluoroscopic equipment in the operating room. The 5 French [VENDOR]s glide catheter was placed into the left internal carotid artery using a 0.038" Bentson guidewire. Cerebral angiograms were then completed in AP and lateral projections.  After completion of the angiogram, the vascular sheath was removed and hemostasis obtained using a vascade collagen plug, followed by manual compression.  COMPARISON: Angiogram [DATE].  FINDINGS:  LEFT COMMON CAROTID ARTERY ARTERY, CEREBRAL: The ECA branches are faintly opacified and not well visualized. The cervical and intracranial ICA are unremarkable in course and caliber. The aneurysm clip is visualized. The MCA, posterior communicating artery, and ACA branches appear stable compared to prior angiogram.  No evidence of distal emboli is seen.   COMPLICATIONS: None immediate.  IMPRESSION: Status-post clip ligation of the MCA bifurcation aneurysm with no angiographic evidence of residual aneurysm. The MCA and ACA branches appear stable compared to prior angiogram.

Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  [ID][HOSPITAL][ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  66yF hyperparathyroidism and recurrent nephrolithiasis. Left flank pain, Stone burden in the upper pole of the left kidney.    Other indication: Planned percutaneous nephrolithotomy by Urologist requires antegrade access.    Procedure:   1.	Left nephrostogram and nephroureterostomy 6 fr sheath placement for planned nephrolithotomy.  Findings:  Comparison is made to a previous exam dated CT [DATE].  1.	Nondistended kidney with multiple calculi most prominent and largest within the upper pole.  2.	Antegrade nephrostogram demonstrates filling defect in the superior pole of the renal calyx consistent with previously seen stone, the renal collecting system is not dilated and contrast flows freely through the ureter into the bladder.  Catheter(s): 6 French destination sheath.  [HCW]ession:   1.	Uneventful ultrasound and fluroscopic-guided placement of a left antegrade nephroureterostomy access sheath as described above.   Treatment Plan:   Patient patient will be transferred immediately to the operating room for planned lithotomy.  Technique:   The risks, benefits, and alternatives to the procedure and sedation were explained to the patient. Written informed consent was obtained.  A time out/call to order was performed prior to procedure initiation.  The soft tissues overlying the access site were prepped and draped in sterile fashion.  All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Ultrasound was utilized to identify an appropriate access site. Static ultrasound image was obtained and stored to PACS for reference purposes. Subsequently, under fluoroscopic and real-time concurrent ultrasound guidance, access was obtained into a posterior, superior calyx using a 21 ga needle and a triaxial sheath system (Gre[VENDOR]). Local anesthetic was injected at the catheter entry site. A wire was advanced centrally. Serial dilation was accomplished over the wire. The wire and inner dilator were removed. Non-ionic contrast was injected into the collecting system and images of the antegrade pyelogram were obtained and stored to PACS.  An 0.035” GWA wire was advanced through the existing access and advanced through ureter into the bladder. A 6 French destination sheath was advanced over the wire into the bladder. Contrast injection confirmed location. The sheath was sutured to the flank with monofilament 2-0 Prolene suture and covered with sterile dressing.   The procedure was well tolerated, and patient discharged to the PACU for transition to the OR. Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]  Clinical Indication:  Benign prostatic hyperplasia with lower urinary tract symptoms  Procedure:  1.	Ultrasound-guided left radial artery access. 2.	Pelvic angiography 3.	Prostate artery embolization 4.	Post-embolization angiography  Cone-Beam CT performed as detailed below  Findings:  Vessels catheterized and angiograms performed as detailed below:  Infrarenal abdominal aortogram: Internal iliac artery origins identified bilaterally.  Right internal iliac artery: Three arterial branches supplying the prostate, one from the superior vesicular artery and two from the inferior vesicular artery. Superior Vesicular artery: Prostatic artery origin identified. Inferior vesicular artery: Two prostatic artery origins identified. Right prostatic artery #1: Patent. Supply to collateral structures: None Right prostatic artery #2: Patent. Supply to collateral structures: None Right prostatic artery #3: Patent. Supply to collateral structures: None  Left internal iliac artery: Two prostatic arterial branches originating from the Superior Vesicular artery. Superior Vesicular artery: Two prostatic artery origins identified. Left prostatic artery #1: Patent. Supply to collateral structures: None Left prostatic artery #2: Patent. Supply to collateral structures: None  CBCT:  1. Right prostatic arteries originate from the superior and inferior vesicular arteries. Supply to collateral structures: None  2. Left prostatic arteries originate from the Superior Vesicular artery. Supply to collateral structures: None   Embolization:  Right: Prostatic artery #1, Superior vesicular origin: 6mL Embozene 500uM, 0.5mL gelfoam Prostatic artery #2, Proximal Inferior vesicular origin: 4mL Embozene 500uM, 0.5mL gelfoam Prostatic artery #3, Distal Inferior vesicular origin: 9mL Embozene 500uM, 0.5mL gelfoam  Left: Prostatic artery #1, Proximal superior vesicular origin: 5mL Embozene 500uM Prostatic artery #2, Distal superior vesicular origin: 1mL Embozene 500uM Common trunk of #1 and #2: 1mL gelfoam  Adjunctive techniques: Right prostatic: None Left prostatic: None  Post-Embolization Angiograms: Right prostatic artery: Prostatic parenchyma no longer opacified. Left prostatic artery: Prostatic parenchyma no longer opacified.  Technical notes on catheter selection: Ravi MG2, Vanschie3, Progreat Lambda, Runthrough guidewire  Impression:  1. Technically successful localization and embolization of the bilateral prostatic arteries.  Treatment Plan:   1. Routine access site care. 2. Follow-up in IR clinic.  3. Access site precautions and orders placed.  Technique:  With the patient in the supine position, the left wrist was prepped and draped with maximum sterile barrier. The left wrist was evaluated with ultrasound and left radial artery patency and acceptable size criteria were documented and images were properly stored in PACS. A modified Allen test (Barbeau test B) was performed on the left wrist to confirm patency of the ulnopalmar arch using pulse oximetry.   1% lidocaine solution was administered for local anesthesia. Access was obtained to the left radial artery using a 21 gauge micro needle and ultrasound guidance. Real time ultrasound visualization was performed of the vascular needle entering the vessel. Permanent recording and reporting of the saved image and study into the PACS system was performed. A wire was placed through the needle. A hydrophilic Glidesheath was advanced slowly over the wire. 3000 units of heparin, 200 mcg of nitroglycerin and 2.5 mg of verapamil was given through the arterial sheath with slow hemodilution. A side flush was started.   A diagnostic catheter was advanced through the sheath into the aorta. Following aortography (if listed above), a catheter/microcatheter system was used to catheterize and opacify the pelvic vessels. First, catheterization and angiography of the right internal iliac artery was performed, followed by third order arteries and the prostatic artery, as listed above. Next, catheterization and angiography of the left internal iliac artery was performed, followed by third order arteries and the prostatic artery, as listed above.   Cone Beam CT (CBCT) was performed intraprocedurally to aid with anatomic localization, for treatment planning, and for confirmation of target embolization. Axial and coronal images were created and 3D reconstruction was performed on a separate dedicated workstation under concurrent supervision.  Embolization was performed using the technique and embolic listed above. Post-embolization angiography was then performed.  All catheters and wires were removed from the patient. A TR Band was placed on the left wrist for hemostasis. The access sheath was removed and no hematoma was seen. A radial artery pulse was confirmed distal to the puncture site confirming patent hemostasis.   The patient tolerated the procedure well and left the angiography suite in stable condition without any immediate postprocedural complications. All vital signs were monitored and recorded by nurse present during the entire procedure. Patient returned to baseline mental status prior to transfer from the department. Administered by the specifically trained nurse under the direct supervision of the single attending physician noted above, conscious sedation was administered and actively monitored for a total of 105 minutes (Total intra service time). Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Male Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL].[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE].   Clinical Indication:  Acute kidney injury.  Procedure:   1.	Tunneled central venous catheter placement       Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the tunneled catheter, as described, the tip terminates in the right atrium.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a power-injectable, 5 Fr, 23 cm, tunneled non-cuffed central venous catheter via the right internal jugular vein.       Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care.  The catheter is ready for immediate use.        Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed below.  The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic.  Ultrasound evaluation of the right internal jugular vein was performed demonstrating patency.  Under ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS. A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a peel-away sheath set was advanced over the wire.  The 0.018 wire was used to determine the intravascular length of the catheter.  Through the micropuncture peel-away sheath set, the wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.  Local anesthesia was then used to anesthetize a subcutaneous tunnel extending from the anterior chest to the venotomy site.  A small incision was made, and a blunt tunneling device was used to bring the catheter through the subcutaneous tunnel, exiting at the venotomy site.  The catheter was then advanced through the peel-away sheath.  The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  The venotomy site was closed with skin glue.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS. Patient Name:  [PATIENT]       DOB: [DATE]    SEX: Female Ordering Physician:  [HCW] Location:  [HOSPITAL]  ESRC.[ID]  Date of exam:  [DATE]   Clinical Indication:  sickle cell crisis  Procedure:   1.	Non-tunneled large bore central venous catheter placement  Findings:   1.	The right internal jugular vein is sonographically patent and compressible.  2.	After placement of the large bore central venous catheter, as described, the tip terminates in the right atrium.  Impression:   1.	Uncomplicated image-guided placement of a 15.5 French,  15 cm, non-tunneled large bore central venous catheter (trialysis) via the right internal jugular vein.  Treatment Plan:   Routine catheter care. The catheter is ready for immediate use.   Technique:   The skin overlying the access site was prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion. All elements of maximal sterile barrier technique were followed including: cap and mask and sterile gown, sterile gloves, a large sterile sheet, and hand hygiene and 2% chlorhexidine for cutaneous antisepsis (or acceptable alternative antiseptics, per current guidelines).  Moderate sedation was administered via the medications listed above.   The skin and subcutaneous tissue overlying the right internal jugular vein were infiltrated with 2% lidocaine for local anesthetic. Ultrasound evaluation of the vein was performed demonstrating patency and an image was saved and stored to PACS. Under ultrasound guidance, the vein was accessed with a micropuncture needle.  An image was saved and stored to PACS.  A 0.018 wire was advanced through the needle, and a micropuncture introducer set was advanced over the wire.  Through the micropuncture introducer set, a 0.035 wire was advanced into the inferior vena cava under fluoroscopic guidance.   The venotomy tract was dilated to allow introduction of the catheter over the wire. The catheter was subsequently introduced over the wire and the wire removed. The ports were tested to ensure adequate function, flushed and locked per protocol.   The catheter was sutured to the skin with nonresorbable suture.  A sterile dressing was placed.  There were no immediate complications.  Ultrasound and fluoroscopic images were stored in PACS.
